title: Letters to the Editor
description: Theodore Winner (letter Dec. 22) depicts taxi drivers as slackers who stay at home at the sight of the first cloud and when on duty alternately spend their time passing up passen gers and taking coffee breaks. He says that when these traits are eliminated we can start to talk about parity for hackers with other motormen.

title: Utilities Trace Problems
description: Two industries that had their share of problems during 1970, gas and electrical, disclosed in yearend statements yesterday that overall the year had not been too bad.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: S.I. Bank Under New Name
description: The Northfield Savings Bank, a $43million Staten Island in stitution that was formerly the Northfield Savings and Loan Association, begins operations as of today under its new name.

title: Measles Shots for 638,077
description: ALBANY, Dec. 31 (UPI) The State Health Department announced today that 26.4 per cent of the state's population from 1 to 12 years old had been immunized in public pro grams against german measles. This represents 638,077 children vaccinated in a statewide cam paign that began in late 1969.

title: Rockefeller and 3 Aides Take Oaths of Office Here
description: Governor Rockefeller was sworn in for a fourth four year term at a brief, informal noontime ceremony yester day in his office at 22 West 55th Street. Taking the oath of office with him were Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and Controller Arthur Levitt, who also were reelected on Nov. 3. With their right hands raised and their left hands on a Bible that had belonged to the Gov ernor's grandmother, Mrs. Laura Spellman Rockefeller, the four replied, I do, when Secretary of State John P. Lo menzo asked: Do you sol emnly swear to support the Constitution of the United States and the ConStitution of the State of New York and to faithfully discharge to the best of your ability the du ties of your offices?

title: Despite Acrimony in Its Final Hours, the Democratic 91st Congress Made Its Mark
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 For all the furer of its dying hours, the Democraticcon trolled 91st Congressthe first Congress in moret han a cen tury to confront a new Presi dent of the opposite party produced less friction, and more legislation than most observers had expected when it first con vened nearly two years ago.

title: Only a Dog Is Noisy in West Side House
description: The loudest noise at 210 West 89th Street last night was a small gray poodle barking in the hallway.

title: About Pro Football
description: Most pro football experts and the oddsmakers favor San Francisco over Dallas for the National Conference championship on Sunday. The single reason revolves around quarterbacks  not that the 49ers John Brodie is likely to be so good but that the Cowboys Craig Morton might be so bad. Few people would want to be Mor ton in Kezar Sta dium on Sunday. Completing his sixth pro season at age 27, Morton has a history of fail ure in playoff games. It is the ability of his teammates like allpro candidates Bob Lilly, Mel Renfro arid John Niland that brings Morton to these big games.

title: Goodell Is Praised By His Colleagues As Term Runs Out
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)  Senator Charles E. Goodell, Republican of New York, shunned by the White House in the November election that saw him defeated in a threeman race, was praised by Senate colleagues today as a man of compassion and high courage.

title: Maine Elks Get Licenses
description: RUMFORD, Me., Dec. 31 (UPI)Some Elks lodges in Maine got their liquor licenses in time for the New Year's Eve under a temporary court order.

title: More P.O.W. Interviews Are Shown on TV Here
description: Two Americans being held in North Vietnamese camps ap peared in a television interview made public yesterday.

title: Reynolds Clarifies Earnings
description: Reynolds & Co. recorded the fourthhighest annual profit in its history in 1970, the firm announced yesterday. Earlier, the brokerage house said it was the thirdhighest. In a clarifying statement, Reynolds said last year's profit ranked behind 1967, 1968 and 1969. The firm is one of the few re tail brokerage houses that managed to maintain profitabil, ity throughout the recent stock market decline.

title: $100,000 IS PROMISED FOR CITY ATHLETICS
description: New York City's public high school athletic program, which faced serious curtailment be cause of lack of funds, received a promise yesterday from the. Board of Education of a mini mum of $100,000 to sustain the program through June 30.

title: Raymond Mondon, French Head Of Transportation, Dies at 56
description: PARIS, Dec. 31Raymond Mondon, French Minister of Transportation, died early this morning at a hospital in Metz, the eastern French city of which he had been Mayor for 23 years. He was 56 years old.

title: Tax Changes to Affect TakeHome Pay
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI)  Social Security taxes will increase tomorrow but in come tax withholding rates will decrease.

title: For Blacks, Soul Food Is a New Year's Day Tradition
description: Before Headrick Williams went home the other night after work, he stopped off at Andy's Meat Market at 643 Lenox Avenue and picked up a smoked hog's head, some pigs tails and feet, chitter lings, collard greens and cowpeas.

title: 40 British Papers Show a Fear Of Roosevelt's Views on Hitler
description: LONDON, Dec. 31In 1940, six months after World War II started, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of Britain was disturbed by what he re garded as indications that President Roosevelt was con templating peace negotiations that would leave Hitler in power.

title: Issues in City's Pay Talks
description: Following are the parties and issues in the city's current negotiations with its uniformed Services:

title: ETHEL GORDON DIES; BROADWAY WORKER
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 Mrs. Ethel Gordon, who worked many years for New York the atrical producers and press agents, died today after a long illness. She was 83 years old.

title: 1970 Cotton Crop Off
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI)  The 1970 cotton crop fell an estimated 961,000 bales short of total domestic and ex port needs, the Agriculture Department estimated today. Law requires the department to estimate annually the shortfall in production and to offer to plug the gap with sales from government stocks at current market prices.

title: STOCK PRICES EASE ON TAXLOSS SALES
description: A flurry of taxloss selling sent stock prices lower yester day, but the market rang out the old year on a definite note of optimism.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: LISBON, Dec. 31A repre sentative of Amnesty Interna tional who came to Portugal last week to study the situa tion of political prisoners was expelled yesterday, according to a spokesman for the Nation al Commission for Aid to Polit ical Prisoners.

title: Curbs on Dairy Imports Set
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) President Nixon signed to day a proclamation imposing import quotas for the first time on four types Of dairy products that have been entering the country from abroad in increas ing quantities.

title: 2 Major Airline Mergers Granted Nixon's Approval
description: Two major airline mergersin each case bringing a troubled carrier under the wing of a stronger linewere approved yesterday by President Nixon. The mergers, which have already been approved by the Civil Aeronautics Board, will bring together American Airlines with Trans Caribbean Airways and Northwest Air lines with Northeast Airlines. American and Northwest, the stronger partners, will be the surviving corporations.

title: Guide to Dining Out
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Firemen Revive Woman Overcome in Bronx Blaze
description: A 67yearold woman, found burned and near death on the floor of her Bronx apartment, was revived by firemen yes terday.

title: Today's  Laurel Card Put Off
description: LAUREL, Md., Dec. 31 (UPI) Heavy snows tonight forced the cancellation of the New Year's Day racing card at Laurel race track. Racing is expected to resume Saturday with a revised card.

title: Books of The Times
description: MILITARY MEN. By Ward Just. 256 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $6.95.

title: CONGRESS DELAYS ENDING OF SESSION UNTIL TOMORROW Supersonic Transport, Last Remaining Issue, Appears on Way to Agreement A DAY OF COMPROMISES Food Stamp Extension and Federal Pay Rise Passed Foreign Aid Signed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31  The capital said goodby to the old year tonight but not the old Congress.

title: Nixon's Nod to Cowboys
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) President Nixon, the nation's No. 1 football fan, has given a conditional nod to the Dallas Cowbays in Sunday's National Football Conference champion ship with San Francisco. Nixon, talking to reporters on New Year's Eve, noted that the Dal las quarterback, Craig Morton, has a somewhat erratic passing record.

title: Sports of The Times
description: And a happy New Year to you, too. If the rhythmic beat of cleats on a gridiron sounds like the rasp of a pneumatic drill sorry, ol boy, you had too much to drink last night. Perhaps the least painful way to ride out the stormthere's no cure for a hangoveris to ease the old carcass in front of the television set and watch foot ball bowl games. Start with TexasNotre Dame in the Cotton Bowl and take in Stan fordOhio State in the Rose Bowl. Other than that you're on your own.

title: PRINCESS'S LETTERS OFFERED FOR SALE
description: Letters written by Princess Margaret to the late Robin DouglasHome, nephew of for mer British Prime Minister Sir Alec DouglasHome, were of fered for sale and publication here earlier this year, accord ing to Charles Hamilton, the autograph dealer.

title: Insubordination, $5, Takes Tropical Dash by 6 Lengths
description: MIAMI, Dec. 31 (UPI)In subordination took the lead at the start and led the rest of the way today to capture the $5,500, sixfurlong allowance feature at Tropical Park.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A full quarter of a century ago the people of Korea, north and south alike, burst into tears of joy and ex treme emotion over the country's lib eration from more than thirty years of foreign occupation. Today, the Land of the Morning Calm remains divided, the peoplewho share the same ances try, language and heritage  are still separated by an arbitrary demarcation line.

title: PAUL E. THURLOW, 71, FINANCIAL ADVISER
description: Paul E. Thurlow, a financial consultant, died yesterday at his home, 2 Sutton Place, after a short illness. He was 71 years old.

title: 1971 Greeted by City With Revelry and Reverence
description: The ritual of the changing of the year was observed last night by millions of New York ers in tens of thousands of ways that ran the emotional spectrum from solemnity to hilarity.

title: Litton Gives Subcontract For Navy Engines to G.E.
description: Litton Industries has an nounced the awarding of a subcontract to the General Electric Corporation with a potential value of $130million to produce marine gas turbine engines for 30 Navy Spruance class destroyers.

title: Environmentalists Are Irrational
description: The man who does not do his own thinking, observed the 19th century oratoressayist Robert G. Ingersoll, is a slave and is a traitor to himself and his fellowmen.

title: JOSEPH COHEN, 80, GELATIN EXPERT
description: BOSTON, Dec. 31Joseph H. Cohen, founder of the Atlantic Gelatin division of General Foods Corporation, who retired as a vice president of the cor poration in 1955, died here yes terday. He was 80 years old and lived at 100 Beacon Street.

Cricket Test Off Again
description: MELBOLTRNE, Australia Fri day, Jan. 1 (Reuters)Torren tial rain washed out today the third cricket test between Aus tralia and England for the second straight day.

title: Man in the News
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 31  If there can be such a thing as an affable male Cassandra, John James Deutsch fills the bill.

title: Chile Buys controlling Interest In Nation's largest Coal Mine
description: SANTIAGO, Chile (UPI)  President Salvador Allende Gossens brought another part of Chile's economy under state control today as the Govern ment purchased the controlling share of the nation's largest coal complex 24 hours after announcing a plan to national ize the banks.

title: Nashville Paper Scans Suit Over Women in Press Club
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 31 (AP) The Nashville Tennessean has threatened the National Press Club in Washington with a civil rights lawsuit unless it admits Elaine Shannon, its Washington correspondent, as a member. The club currently bars women.

title: Kristofferson Sings Sad Songs At Recital Here
description: Kris Kristofferson, riding the crest of support from Johnny Cash and the success of his two songs, Me and Bobby Mc Ghee and Sunday Morning Comin' Down, meandered through his first New York concert appearance Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall.

title: Screen: A Moving Comedy of Indians:'Flap,' Based on a Clair Huffaker Book, Opens Anthony Quinn Is Star of Tribal Surprise
description: Finally, at long last, there comes a movie about the bleak plight of today's American Indian that is as funny as it is moving. That's "Flap," for Flapping Eagle, which also provides Anthony Quinn with his best role in several years, as a dim-witted tribal revolutionary and con man and the pride and problem of his home reservation. The picture is a delightful surprise, for several reasons.There is the sight of Mr. Quinn, after all those glum, one-note dirges, dimensionally stretching his central role with sly comic gusto and relish. There is Clair Huffaker's excellent adaptation of his novel "Nobody Loves a Drunken Indian," with its cutting sociological ironies and beautiful, barbed-wire dialogue, handled by a solid gallery of unstereotyped, picaresque characters.And finally, you'll never guess who directed it, exquisitely at home on the New Mexico rangeland, with its Indian shantytowns. Carol Reed, that's who. Yes, Sir Carol, the distinguished British knight who mastered suspense and won an Oscar for the splashy "Oliver!" has quietly nurtured a blooming cactus of prickly humor and even pricklier truths.The real beauty of the picture is the crisp pacing and graceful dexterity as the tumbling, ribald antics of the hard-headed hero and his tribal pals build to a grave, touching and admirably restrained conclusion. If only one of those rock laments and a croupy vocalist weren't slopping up the sound track. And by the way, somebody, why is an ex-Army sergeantthat's Mr. Quinnwearing a Navy jacket?Sir Carol's direction is so snug and the parts so well-defined that the first-rate cast seems to be performing effortlessly. Among them are Claude Akins, Tony Bill, Victor Jory, Don Collier, Victor French, Rodolfo Acosta, Anthony Caruso and Susana Miranda. Shelley Winters adds a scalding note as a petulant madam.The plight of the American Indian is no laughing matter. The laughter here makes it matter even more.

title: Donors Are Urged to Help Victims of Blood Diseases
description: Children with leukemia and hemophilia face a sudden and drastic Shortage of the blood components that help keep them alive, officials of the Greater New York blood pro gram said yesterday.

title: Right Rev. John Esquirol Dies; Episcopal Bishop of Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 31The Right Rev. John H. Esquirol, bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Connecticut, died today after a long illness at his home. He. was 70 years old.

title: 5.6% RISE RECORDED IN RAIL TONMILEAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31  Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Dec. 26 were both above the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

title: 6TH GAIN IN ROW SCORED ON AMEX
description: The American Stock Ex change ended the year on a bullish note yesterday as the list finished higher for the sixth consecutive session on moderate trading.

title: DELAY IS GRANTED BY APPEALS JUDGE
description: A judge decided yesterday to delay the appearance before a grand jury of the daughter of a lawyer who has defended militant opponents of United Statespolicies.

title: 2 State Troopers, 2 Others Indicted in Car Repair Fraud
description: ALBANY, Dee. 31  Two state troopers were among four men arrested today on in dictments charging them with reporting fake repairs and pur chases for state police autos.

title: CLAIR WILCOX, 72, ECONOMIC ADVISER
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 (AP)  Clair Wilcox, professor emeritus of economics at Swarthmore College and Gov ernment economic adviser in the thirties and forties, died today while on a trip to Ari zona, the college announced. He was 72 years old.

title: Wisniewski Wins Mile Run In Development Meet Here
description: George Wisniewski, a former New York University distance star who now runs for the United A.A., completed a good series of December perform ances by winning the mile run in the final 1970 indoor devel opment meet sponsored by the Metropolitan. Amateur Athletic Union Wednesday night.

title: Denunciation of Kennedy
description: LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP)  Other newly disclosed records show that the British Govern ment was incensed by Ambas sador Kennedy's predictions that Britain could not win the war against Germany.

title: PRICES INCREASED BY WESTINGHOUSE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it had raised prices on selected models of all Major appliances by 5 to 7 per cent.

title: World Group Says Freedom of Press Is Under Siege
description: GENEVA, Dec. 31The free dom of the press is under siege from all quarters, the International Press Institute said today in its annual report.

title: U.C.L.A. Luring Crowds With its Winning Ways
description: The University of California Los Angeles basketball team is a promoter's dream.

title: Higher Costs Beset Steel;
description: For the domestic steel indus try 1971 will be a year of the blahs, caused mainly by higher costs and the possibility of a midyear strike.

title: Gulf Pact Eases Refinery Strike Peril
description: DENVER, Dec. 31A tenta tive settlement with the Gulf Oil Corporation announced this morning by the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union has apparently ended the possibility of a major strike at the nation's oil refineries.

title: A Problem Seen
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (AP) The report said that the arch diocese's investments were a source of concern in that they are still so small against our total obligations of service and need.

title: Discharged Employe Stabs Radio Official in Harlem
description: The vice president of a Har lem radio station was allegedly stabbed yesterday by a dis missed employe and taken to Harlem Hospital in serious con dition.

title: An Astronaut's View
description: To stand on the surface of the moon and look at the earth high over head is certainly a unique experience. Although very beauti ful, it is very remote and ap parently very small. You might suspect that in such a situation the observer would dismiss the earth as relatively unimportant. Paradoxically, the opposite con clusion has been reached by each of the individuals who has had the opportunity to share that view. We have all been struck by the simile to an oasis or an island. More importantly, it is the only Island that we know is a suitable home for man. The importance of protecting and saving that home has never been felt more strongly. Protection seems most required, however, not from foreign aggres sors cr natural calamity, but from its population.

title: Black Hawks Beat Red Wings by 83 As Maki, Hull Star
Connecticut and New York Take Over the New Haven
description: The Metropolitan Transpor tation Authority and the Con necticut Department of Trans portation took over operation of the commuter lines of the Penn Central's New Haven Division at 12:01 A.M. today.

title: L.I. Bandits Seized In 70Minute Chase
description: Three gunmen who held up a Long Island bank and took three women tellers hostage yesterday were captured in Brooklyn after a 70minute chase by police cars and two helicopters that included a plan by the bandits to hijack an air plane to Europe or Africa.

title: PEKING DENOUNCES SOVIET AND THE U.S.
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 31  Communist China placed itself at the head of world revolu tion against United States im perialism and Soviet social imperialism in a New Year statement issued from Peking today.

title: Death in the Mines
description: The awesome toll of 38 I'ves taken by the explosion that rocked a Kentucky mine tunnel is a fiery reminder of the dangers faced by those who toil underground.

title: Storm Rescue Effort Is Criticized in France
description: PARIS, Dec. 31 (Reuters)  Temperatures throughout France dropped well below freezing today, turning roads into icy death traps. The Government was accused of making inadequate attempts to help 20,000 people believed stranded in their cars by large snowdrifts.

title: Labor Camps Fall Into 4 Categories Of Rising Severity
description: The labor camps to which the 11 Leningrad hijacking defend ants have been sentenced rep resent only one of three forms of deprivation of freedom un der a Soviet prison code adopted in 1970.

title: Saigon Hints Wrong Girl Met Father is Africa
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 31 (Reuters)Her name is Martine and her mother's name is Nguyen Thi Hue, and so the 17yearold trav eled last month to the Cen tral African Republic for a reunion with a former ser geant in the French Army who was said to be her father.

title: Arnold Reuben Is Dead at 87; Founded Popular Restaurant
description: Arnold Reuben, founder of Reuben's restaurant here long popular with theater people, died. yesterday in Palm Beach, at the age of 87.

title: Relief Is Expressed Over Soviet Action
description: Opinion leaders throughout the world hailed as a voice of universal conscience the commutation yesterday of the death sentences of two Soviet Jews convicted of having plotted to hijack an airplane in order to flee to Israel.

title: ILLINOIS FUNDS HELD NOT PART OF CACHE
description: SPRINGFIELD, lll., Dec. 31 There is no indication that state funds were involved in the hoard of more than $800,000 in cash discovered in the apart ment of the late Secretary of States of Illinois, Paul Powell, it was announced today.

title: Dillingham Elects New President
description: The Dillingham Corpora tion announced yesterday the election of Herbert C. Cornuelle as president and chief operating officer of the Hawaiibased company en gated in marine transporta tion, oceanography, land development, liquefied petro leum gas distribution, con struction, quarrying and min ing.

title: Wholesale Prices Renew Rise in Industrial Sector
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31In dustrial wholesale prices re sumed their rise in December after leveling in November, the Labor Department reported to day.

title: A Rose for Miss Emily Given Premiere
description: William Faulkner, in 1924, wrote A Rose for Emily, a short story about a Southern spinster who murdered her lover, then proceeded to lie by his side for 40 years.

title: HUGHES IS NAMED BY MAHEU IN SUIT
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 31 (AP)Robert A. Maheu, the ousted head of Howard Hughes's $300million Nevada operations, today sued the bil lionaire for $50million dam ages. He said that an accord for life employment had been breached.

title: Journalist's Trimaran Survives Australian Race
description: HOBART, Australia, Dec. 31 (UPI)  A French journalist, Alain Colas, sailed his battered 67foot trimaran, Pen Duick IV, into Hobart today after battling big seas off the Tas manian east coast.

title: Ranchland Expropriated
description: SANTIAGO, Dec. 31 (AP) Chile announced today it has expropriated 1.8 million acres of ranchland to be redistributed to peasant families in a contin uation of the land reform pro gram begun under the previous administration.

title: No Obscure Hangings
description: PARISThe somber year of 1970 ended with patches of unexpected light when Franco commuted the sen tences of six Basque nationalists sentenced to die, and almost immedi ately thereafter the Soviet Union re duced the death penalty for two Jewish citizens condemned for an al leged skyjacking conspiracy.

title: Dr. Theodore B. Russell ls Dead; Retired Physician and Teacher
description: Dr. Theodore B. Russell, a retired physician of Courtland Gardens, Stamford, Conn., died of a heart ailment Wednesday in ColumbiaPresbyterian Medi cal Center, where he served his interneship and had been a staff member. He was 66 years old.

title: Miss Hogan in Semifinals Of Western Australia Tennis
description: PERTH, Australia, Dec. 31 (AP)Patti Hogan of Irvine. Calif., moved into the semi finals of the Western Australian tennis championships today with a 6.0, 62 victory over J. Sawamatsu of Japan.

title: Mrs. Nancy Whitaker Mead Wed to Stephen B. Mahoney.
description: TESEQUE, N.M., Dec. 31 Mrs. Nancy Whitaker Mead and Stephen B. Mahoney were married here today at Oe holne of the bride. Thee. ReV. Bruce RoIstead, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Nat'l Hockey League. LAST NIGHT'S GAMES
description: Chicago 8, Detroit 3 Pittsburgh 4, Minnesota 1.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31It looked like confetti, but it was really the winter's first big snow, just in time to muffle the din that was 1970 in the capi tal. There was not much cele bration in the halls of Govern ment, but the recriminations of a bitter year were finally muted. The Repubicans in Congress did manage to get in some last minute complaints about the way in which the Democrats had managed the legis ative calendar. And President Nixon, unmoved by the holiday spirit, managed to leave his Democratic challenger, Senator Edmund S. Muskie, off the in vitation list for the signing of the cleanair bill. The under lying impulse, however, was to get this year over with at last and, out of sight, at least, to engage in a good deal of self examination.

title: Peril in the Fire Houses
description: For reasons that defy rational analysis, the city's fire men have decided to start 1971 with an illegal slowdown that could lead to civic disaster. The combined effects leadership timidity in the face of powerhungry militants, a pervasive sense of grievance among the rank and file and pathetic ineptitude in presentation of the city's strong case have launched the Uniformed Firefighters Association on a confrontation course as perilous to the union as it is to every New Yorker.

title: POLICE DISMISSALS ROSE 100% IN 1970
description: More than twice as many men were dismissed from the New York Police Department in 1970 than were dismissed in 1969, an examination of depart ment records showed yester day.

title: Pinehurst Club Is Sold for $9Million
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 31 Pinehurst, the 7,500acre winter golf resort in the Sand hills region of North Carolina, has been sold for just over $9 million to a holding company controlled by Malcolm McLean, an industrialist.

title: Looking Back . . .
description: Seen from the first of January, a year just past is too fresh a unit of time either for its disasters to be glossed over by nostalgia or its achievements to be viewed perspective. One looks back not to indulge his wistful ness, as he might on a decade long gone, but rather contrast its still painful follies, failures and irritations with the hopes he entertains for the year about to un fold. It can't be any worse is the common and healthy reaction of man as every twelve months he willingly rings out the old and euphorically rings in the new.

title: SOCIALISTS PLAN A COLLEGE DRIVE
description: Twelve hundred delegates and observers at the. Young Socialist Alliance convention voted yesterday to give even greater emphasis to making every university a Red uni versity.

title: Ph.D.'s Job Market Hits Hard Times
description: This week's array of schol arly meetingsfrom the his torians gathered in Boston to the engineers and physicists convened in Chicagopro duced at least one indisput able conclusion: The Ph.D. is no longer an honored pass port to preferred employ ment.

title: Merger News
description: Air Products and Chemicals, Inc., Allentown, Pa., a manu facturer of cryogenic equip ment, industrial gases and other chemicals, has agreed in prin ciple to purchase for cash the chemicals and plastics business of the Air Reduction Company, a New Yorkbased diversified manufacturing concern, the companies an nounced yester day. An Air Reduc tion spokesman said his company would receive about $30million in the trans action. Close to $17million of this is to be paid within the first year and the rest over a period of eight years.

title: egyptian Says Only Force Will Settle Israeli Conflict
description: CAIRO, Friday, Jan. 1  Mo hammed Hassanein Heykal, chief editor of the authoritative newspaper Al Ahram, declared today that military force had become essential to break the deadlock in the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: Shell Oil Platform Burns
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP) Fire broke out today, on an other offshore oil platform of the Shell Oil Corporation, but workmen were able to put it outbefore it spread to the oil wells in production there. A spokesman said that four men had been burned and taken to hospitals in Morgan City.

title: MRS. MINA SINAI
description: Mrs. Mina Sinai, mother of Mrs. Bery Nossek, secretary in the Rome bureau of The New York Times since 1952, died Wednesday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. She was 77 years old and lived at 4 East 70th Street.

title: Mint Stops Taking Orders For 1971 Proof Coin Sets
description: WASHINGTON; Dec: 31  Mrs. Mary T. Brooks, Director of the Bureau of the Mint, an nounced that, as of today, the San Francisco Assay Office would stop taking orders for 1971 proof coin sets.

title: Oyster Bay Crew Wins Icy Carter Cup Race
News of Commutations Pleases Idaho Basques
description: BOISE, Idaho, Dec. 31 (AP)  That makes us very happy, Ramon Menique said yesterday when advised that six Basques who had been sentenced to death in Spain had received commutations.

title: In Vietnam, a Weary Look Back at a Harsh Decade
description: CANTHO, South Vietnam, Dec. 27Ten years ago, when Le Van Phuoc and his family lived in a village that they still remember as their real home, the farmers did not have radios or newspapers. In 1961, there was some talk of the war but no one knew very much.

title: S.E.C. DELAYS FILING INSTITUTIONAL STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31  The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it will not be possible to file with Congress by today's dead line its special study of insti tutional trading on the stock exchanges.

title: Lawyer Appointed to Mrs. Spatt's Job
description: Mayor Lindsay appointed Brooklyn lawyer to the City Planning Commission yesterday thereby ignoring the energetic campaign that was aimed at getting the Mayor to reappoint Mrs. Beverly Moss Spatt to the post.

title: U.S.Loses I.T.T.Suit;
description: The Department of Justice yesterday lost a yearanda halfold effort to break up the 1969 merger of the Interna tional Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Grinnell Corporation, the nation's larg est manufacturer of sprinklers.

title: Flatbush Bank in Merger
description: The merger of the Flatbush Savings Bank into the Greater New York Savings Bank, pro ducing an institution with re sources of more than $1billon, becomes effective today. The bank has 12 locations in Brook lyn, Queens and Manhattan.

title: FINNISH SHIP SPLIT WITHOUT WARNING
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 31It just broke in two there was no w??ing, said the senior surviving officer of the Finnish oil tanker Ragny to night in describing the loss of his ship fin an Atlantic storm last Saturday.

title: Soviet Spares Two Jews; Three Get Eased Terms
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 31  The Russian Republic's Supreme Court, noting that a planned hijacking last June was never carried out, today commuted the death sentences given two Jewish defendants in the Lenin grad case.

title: Justice Kupferman Named To State. Appellate Bench
description: ALBANY, Dec. 31  Gover nor Rockefeller announced to day the designation of Supreme Court Justice Theodore R. Kup ferman of Manhattan as an as sociate justice of the Appellate Division, First Department.

title: Barenboim Impressive In Leading Philharmonic
description: Daniel Barenboim, the 28 yearold pianist and conduc tor, led the New York Phil harmonic for the first time on Wednesday night, in Philhar monic Hall, ending the pro gram with nothing less than Beethoven's Eroica Sym phony. The performance was, in a way, that or a young artist, but an artist of such excentional gifts that it never lost its fascination from opening to final chord.

title: Four Tons of Salt Water Fish Seized as DDTContaminated
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 (AP) Some 8,000 pounds of king fish caught off Los Angeles have been impounded by Fed eral agents, who described it as the nation's first seizure of DDT  contaminated saltwater fish.

title: Counterreaction Spurred by Protests
description: MADRID, Dec. 31  The scathing foreign reaction to the Basque courtmartial aroused an angry counterreaction in Spain, but ultimately ithelped to save the lives of the ac cused.

title: The Me Nobody Knows
description: There has always been a show business shibboleth that says: Uptown is uptown and downtown is downtown, and never the twain shall meet. In other words, you may be a hit off Broadway but you will never be able to trans fer successfully on Broad way.

title: WILLIAM DWYER, SAVINGS OFFICER
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 31 William J. Dwyer, who retired here in January after 35 years as president and then chairman of the Franklin Society Federal Savings and Loan Association, died in Holy Cross Hospital yesterday after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: 3d Mylai Trial Set Tuesday; Sergeant Pleads Not Guilty
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Dec. 31 (UPI)Sgt. Charles E. Hutto, 22 years old, of Tullulah, La., entered a plea of not guilty to day to charges stemming from the alleged mass killing of South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai, clearing the way for his courtmartial to start net Tuesday.

title: Mrs. John N. Irwin 2d Is Dead; State Department Aide's Wife
description: Mrs. Jane Watson Irwin, wife of Under Secretary of State John N. Irwin 2d, died yesterday at their home here, 888 Park Avenue. She was 55 years old.

title: Maritime Provinces Study Merger Proposal
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia Strains on the Canadian, confed oration, especially the separatist threats and disorders in Quebec, are driving the three Maritime Provinces to think seriously about political union.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31President Nixon is going into the third quarter of his term with a slightly different team, a revived political opposition, a troubled electorate, and the same old problems. In the last few weeks he has seemed more calm and concilia tory, yet he must be aware at the beginning of 1971 that many people who wish him well are still anxious and dissatisfied with the state of our affairs.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: New LawsThe President signed the clean air bill, the International Financial Insti tutions Act, the Disaster Re lief Act of 1970, Bank Hold ing Company Act amend ments, the Federal Aid to Highways Act of 1970 and the Poison Prevention Act of 1970.

title: Bridge: Junior TransAtlantic Event Will Start Here Tomorrow
description: The junior tournament, for players under 25 years old, to be played tomorrow and Sunday at the Royal Man hattan Hotel, Eighth Avenue between 44th and 45th Streets, will be unusual in several ways.

title: 12,252UNIT PROJECT ASKS RENT INCREASE
description: Parkchester, a 12,252apart ment project in the Bronx, has applied to the city's Depart ment of Rent and Housing Main tenance for a $2million annual rent increase.

title: Pakistani Air Crash Kills 6
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 31 Six persons were killed to day when a Pakistan Interna tional Airlines plane crashed while landing at Shamsherna gar in northeast Pakistan. There were 27 survivors. The plane was a Dutchmanufac tured Fokker Friendship.

title: Shop Talk
description: Mark Cross, the Fifth Ave nue specialty shop at 55th Street, has joined the grow Ing list of stores taking pity on males who haplessly stuff their pockets with all of the paraphernalia necessary to get through the day. It has just introduced two hand bags for men  well, one actually is a shoulder bag. The latter is a hand some affair in palomino calf that is likely to end up on the wife's shoulder instead. It's certainly roomy enough to accommodate al most anything one might deign to carry. The other, more conservative, handbag looks like a small leather envelope with a handstrap. It comes in pigskin taupe and costs $45. The shoulder bag is $70.

title: Court Appoints New Chief For Boston &
description: John W. Barriger, 71year old chairman of the executive commitee of the Missouri KansasTexas Railroad, has been approved by the Federal District Court in Boston as the new chief executive officer of the Boston & Maine Corpora tion.

title: U.S. offiOials Say a Seriles of Commitment Won IsraeIis  Return to Mideast Peace Talks at the U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31The Nixon Administration won Is rael's agreement this week to return to the Middle East peace talks at the United Nations by making what senior officials described today as a series of military, political and diplo matic commitments to the Is raelis, who lack a formal alli ance with the United States.

title: GIEREK PROMISES AN HONEST POLICY TO POLISH NATION
description: WARSAW, Dec. 31Edward Gierek, Poland's new Commu nist party leader, pledged today that government policy in 1971 would be honest, direct, clear and understandable to every one.

title: FIRE UNION PLANS JOB ACTION TODAY; CITY GETS A WRIT
description: The city's firemen, dissatis fied with the progress in con tract negotiations, announced yesterday that they would start curtailing their nonemer gency services at 9 A.M. today, but would continue to respond to fire alarms.

title: U.S. Combat Deaths Rise by 15 To 41 in Week Despite Truce
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 31  The United States command announced today a sharp rise in American combat deaths last week despite the Christmas ceasefire.

title: JOHN G. LIPPERT
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 31  John G. Lippert, aeronautic staff engineer of the Society of Automotive Engineers since 1963, who was active in coordi nating standards for space equipment, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital after surgery. He was 47 years old and lived at 212 West Post Road.

title: Organ Recital Series To Open Here Sunday
description: The Organ as a Primary Medium, a yearlong recital series planned to cover the organ literature of five cen turies will begin at the New York Cultural Center on Sun day at 3 P.M.

title: 4 Safe in Wilderness Area
description: AUBURN, Calif., Dec. 31 (UPI)  Four young persons were found safe today in the snowcovered Bear Valley wil derness area where they had hiked to play in the snow. The Placer County Sheriff's office said that all were suffering from exposure. They were iden tified as Danny Erickson, 21 years old, and his sister, Cindy, 16; Jesse Rodriquez, 22, and Lynette Blumhart, 16.

title: Ohio State Is Choice Over Stanford
The Screen
description: The current program, to Jan. 6, in the Whitney Mu seums New American Film makers Series offers two films by Beverly and Tony Conrad. Coining Attrac tions, a featurelength movie directed by Mrs. Conrad (bet ter known, and of happy memory, as Beverly Grant, a star of the New York under ground a few years ago), was photographed by Tony Con rad.

title: New Haven. Picks a Chief From Ranks
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec, 31 Capt. Biagio DiLieto, a men ber of the New Haven Police Department for 22 years and an ally of the conserva tive leadership of this city's Democratic party, was named Chief of Police today by Mayor Bartholomew F. Guida.

title: 2 Negroes Get New Trial After Appeal on Jury Bias
description: RICHMOND, Dec. 31 (AP) The 4th United States Circuit Court of Appeals overturned the convictions of two Negro men today after ruling that a Fed eral judge had erred by refusing to allow prospective jurors to be questioned about racial prejudice.

title: EDGAR M. JOHNSON 3D
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 31 Edgar M. Johnson 3d, retired president of Cinder Products Company, died at his home here on Monday at the age of 72.

title: Putting On Our Thinking Caps
description: BETHESDA, Md.We tend to blame the worldwide power struggle for our direst problems. But is it realized that this struggle reflects the established organization of man's brain?

title: Amer. Hockey League WEDNESDAY NIGHT'S GAMES
description: STANDINGOF THE CLUES

title: AtomSmasher Taking A TwoMonth Holiday
description: STANFORD, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP)The Stanford Linear Accellerator Center plans to close its twomilelong atom smasher during February and August as an economy measure.

title: Jarrlrig Due Hero Tomorrow
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 31Dr. Jarring is exptct ed in New York Saturday eve ning in preparation for the re sumption of the Middle East peace talks and Secretary Gen eral Thant is due to report on the current situation to the Security Council Tuesday.

title: MEANY CHIDES NIXON ON HIS GAME PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI)  George Meany said today that labor viewed the coming year with apprehen sion and grave concern be cause of inflation and rising unemployment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WRITEOFF IS MADE BY GREAT AMERICAN
description: Directors of Great American Industries, Inc., authorized the writeoff of substantially all the assets of its subsidiary, Great American Minerals. Corpora tion, resulting in a nonrecurring loss of about $4,790,000 before the tax.

title: JAMES A. ALLIS, 89, PLANE EXECUTIVE
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 31 James Ashton Allis, former banker and chairman of Fair child Engine and Airplane corporation, a founder of the system of hiking trails in the Eastern United States, died Tuesday in a nursing home here. He was 89 years old and lived at 200 Inwood Avenue, Upper Montclair.

title: Miner Croup Scores Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) A splinter group of the Unit ed Mine Workers of America accused President Nixon today of preventing enforcement of the 1969 Federal Coal Mine Health and Safety Act. Chip Yablonski, a spokesman for the Miners for Democracy, issued a statement accusing the Bureau of Mines of knuckling under to industry threats and propa gandizing of a coal shortage. He asked that a Senate inquest be held into the Hyden tragedy.

title: T.W.A. Seeks Ship Line
description: Trans World Airlines, Inc., has received the approval of the Civil Aeronautics Board of plans to enter the passenger shipping business, L. Edwin Smart, senior vice president for external affairs, announced yesterday.

title: Katherine May Becomes Bride Of E.W.Bickford
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Dec. 31  Miss Katherine Hart wick May and Edward. Wat son Bickford were married here this afternOon in St. Mark's Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Phil Port er Jr., who was assisted by the Rev. Dr. W. Colin Lee, the rector emeritus.

title: Indian Ocean Countries Say Aid By South Africa Has No Color
description: PORT LOUIS, Mauritius, Dec. 21The Foreign Minister of Mauritius said recently that money has no color, and a few days ago the Foreign Minister of Madagascar said that money has no odor.

title: LSD Linked to Dead Youth
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 31 (UPD)The authorities said to day that an Illinois youth who died in a 100foot plunge from a firetower had apparently been under the influence of LSD. The Leon County Sheriff, Raymond Hamlin, said the dead youth, Fred Seiigmn of Peoria, had either jumped or fallen from the Florida Forest Service watch tower.

title: REED, DICK ACE, TACK IN HOSPITAL
description: Willis Reed of the Knicks was admitted to Roosevelt Hos pital yesterday for extensive tests and a complete physical checkup. Only 11 days ago, he was discharged from the hos pital after a threeday bout of influenza.

title: SINGAPORE BARS AIDE OF AMNESTY SOCIETY
description: SINGAPORE. Dec. 31 (AP) The Government of Singapore has refused entry to a repre sentative of Amnesty Interna tional, a Londonbased group that investigates the conditions of political prisoners and tries to help them.

title: Ho Chi Minh Trail Raided
description: SAIGON, Dec. 31 (AP)  The United States Military command disclosed today a series of devastating bombing raids on the Ho Chi Minh trail in Laos that am believed to have disrupted North Viet namese plans for an early spring offensive.

title: EAST SIDERS CLAIM HIGHRISE VICTORY
description: Community planning boards on Manhattan's East Side claimed a major victory yester day as the City Planning Com mission said it was shelving its proposal to permit new high rise housing on northsouth avenues there to go above ex isting height limits.

title: City's First ES. Magistrates  Take Oath in Brooklyn
description: The city's first Federal MagistratesMax Schiffman and Vincent A. Catoggio were sworn in yesterday by Chief Judge Jacob Mishler of Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Partial Closing Is Set For 3 Midtown Streets
description: One traffic lane on 48th, 49th and 50th Streets be tween the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Ave nue will be closed fox about six months beginning Mon day because of construction in the area, the citys De partment of Traffic an nounced yesterday.

title: NIXON SCHOOL BILL KILLED IN SENATE Southerners and Liberals Block $1.5Billion Plan to Promote Desegregation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31  President Nixon's school deseg regation bill died in the Senate today, a casualty of adjourn moot pressures and of strong opposition from both Southern ers and liberal Democrats.

title: Everything Lovely Captures Santa Anita Dash by Head
description: ARCADIA, Calif.,Dec. 31 (AP)  Everything Lovely charged from last place today and won the $29,000 feature race at Santa Anita. The victor, owned by Colin Campbell, ran the six furlongs in 1:09 1/5.

title: PAROCHIALAID FOES OPPOSE PUPIL PLAN
description: An organization that has op posed state aid for religious schools declared yesterday that it would fight any effort to pro vide state tuition grants to par ents of parochial school chil dren.

title: GEORGE R. FARNUM
description: BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP)  George R. Farnum, president of the New England AntiVivisec tion Society for the last 33 years, died Tuesday in Massa chusetts General Hospital. He was 85 years old.

title: ANGHELOS EVERT OF GREEK POLICE
description: ATHENS, Dec. 31Lieut. Gen. Anghelos Evert, who used his position as Athens Chief of Police to aid the Allies and Greek resistance forces during the Axis occupation, died of heart failure at his home today. He was 76 years old.

title: Age Is Not a Number
description: The last decade has been an ironic time: scholars asked their students what subjects should be studied; pro fessed rebels dressed, acted and spoke in identical ways; it was widely be lieved that a few incompetent subver sives had multitudes of intelligent young men under rigid control; indi vidualists read the same books and used the same slogans; disillusioned and disenfranchised youths worked hard to elect party men.

title: DR. STAUFFER RITES PLANNED FOR JAN. 9
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31A memorial service will be held Saturday, Jan. 9, at St. Martin intheFields Church, Chestnut Hill, for Dr. Herbert M. Stauf fer, chairman of the department of radiology at Temple Univer sity Medical Center, who was found dead in his garage Dec. 18, a victim of carbon monox ide poisoning.

title: Rockland: The Longer View
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Dec. 31See that mountain over there? We just bought it.

title: Prices Paid to Farmers Slip
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Prices paid to farmers for raw products dropped 2 per cent in December and averaged 7 per cent less than a year be fore, the Agriculture Depart ment announced today.

title: . . . and Looking Up
description: If that were the whole chronology instead of a selec. tive segment, 1970 would have been a year uniquely dismal. But no period can be so characterized that saw the war in Vietnam, in spite of flareups, slowly grinding toward a haltundeclared, unofficial and uncertain, but nonetheless welcome. Nor could any year be considered wholly bad that saw calm, however dispirited, returning to the campuses and to the streets of American cities.

title: SATO GIVES JAPAN. APPEAL ON TRADE
description: TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 1Pre mier Eisaku Sato has, appealed to the Japanese textile industry to accept temporary losses for the sake of future trade rela tions between Japan and the United States.

title: Shorter of Florida Captures Brazil's New Year Marathon
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Friday, San. 1 (UPI)  Frank Shorter of Gainesville, Fla. sloshed through rainswept streets and won the 46th annual Sao Syl vestre New Year's Eve mara thon early this morning. Shorter won the United States Amateur Athletic Union title in December.

title: Money and Bank Credit Show Moderate Growth
LEAKING TEAR GAS HAS AREA CRYING
description: GREAT MEADOWS, N. J., Dec. 31  People in this quiet, rural community 65 miles west of Manhattan are hoping that Jan. 15 will mark the end of the intermittent teargas at tacks they have been suffering.

title: MERCHANTS SEEKING TIGHTER SUNDAY LAW
description: The Fifth Avenue Association announced yesterday that it would urge the Legislature to pass provisions strengthening the state's Sabbath Law, which bans the sale of some items during certain hours on Sun day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawsuit Spells Breakup for Beatles
description: LONDON, Dec. 31  The Beatles, collective folk he roes of the nineteensixties, finally broke apart today.

title: The Midi Laid an Egg in 1970, but it Did Hatch Other Fashions
description: And so the midi, that midcalf skirt length touted as the be all, end all of fashion, bombed in Manhattan in 1970. Stores that last fall said they bought lots of midis are now saying they didn't really. What they did buy didn't sell very well. And women's knees are not yet obsolete.

title: State Grants Gas Rate Rise For Orange and Rockland
description: ALBANY, Dec. 31 (AP)The Public Service Commission to day granted a gas rate in crease to Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., to raise $1,922, 000 in additional revenue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: One of the tests political commen tators set up for Senator Edmund Muskie in this year's election was his ability to carry back into office Maine's incumbent Democratic Governor Ken neth Curtis, who had initiated a much needed but unpopular sales tax. Now that Curtis's reelection has been made official in a recount, the innuendoes that Muskie's coattails are too short to make him an effective Presidential candidate have been laid to rest.

title: Son for the Tony Curtises
description: LONDON, Dec. 31 (UPI) The 26yearold wife of Tony Curtis, the actor, gave birth to day to a 7pound boy in King's College Hospital. Both mother and baby are well, a spokesman said. Mr. Curtis and his wife, Lesley Allen, a former model, were married in April, 1968.

title: State Ban on 10 Pesticides, Including DDT, Is in Effect
description: ALBANY, Dec. 31 (AP)Be ginning New Year's Day, DDT and nine other pesticides will be banned in New York State under regulations of the En vironmental Conservation De partment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Index of Commodity Prices Dipped to 104.1 in Week
Recheek Was Overdue
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31The Kentucky coal mine in which 38 men were killed in an ex plosion yesterday had been per mitted to continue operating despite explosion safety hazards discovered by United States Bureau of Mines inspectors last month.

title: MONDALE WARNS NATIONS ON TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31  A leader of the group in the Sen ate that succeeded in killing the importlimiting trade bill urged the Nixon Administra tion today to use devices in existing law to force an end to unfair foreign competition and undue foreign restriction on our own exports.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: Las Vegas, Nev.Gil King, 147 pounds, Los Angeles, outpointed Paulie Annstead, 146, Los An geles, 10 rounds.

title: Penguins Call Up Zaine
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 31 (UPI)  The Pittsburg Penguins of the National Hockey League re called Rod Zaine from their Amarillo, Tex., farm club to day to replace Ken Schinkel, who suffered a broken collar bone last night at Montreal.

title: Chicago Archdiocese Lists $85.5Million Assets
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (UPI) The Roman Catholic Arch diocese ofChicago, the nation's largest, made a public dis closure of its financial assets for the first time today.

title: Paroles Are Given by U.S. To 3 Who Jumped From Ship
description: MIAMI, Dec. 31 (AP)Immi gration officials have granted indefinite paroles to three East Germans who jumped from a cruise ship off the Florida keys last month. The paroles will al low, them to live and work in this country.

title: Mrs. Warren Given Robust Production On London Stage
description: LONDON, Dec. 31Britain's Shaw revival began five years ago with a production of his first play, Widowers' Houses, which coincided illuminatingly with a slum housing scandal. Ronald Eyre, who directed the play, now offers its companion piece, Mrs. Warren's Profes sion, at the National Theater, evidently in the hope of bring ing Shaw to bear on the Wom en's Lib movement.

title: President Signs Bill to Cut Auto Fumes 90% by 1977
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31  President Nixon, pledging vig orous enforcement, signed into law today a clean air bill that sets a sixyear deadline for the automobile industry to develop an engine that is nearly free of pollution.

title: I.C.C. BARS RAIL BID FOR 15% RATE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today a re quest by Southern railroads for a 15 per cent increase in freight rates.

title: BUDGET IS REVISED BY CITY PLANNERS
description: The City Planning Commis sion submitted Its amended $1.6billion capital construction program for 197172 to Mayor Lindsay yesterday after adding. a School, hospital renovations and park projects.

title: T. V. A. Says Its Efforts Show Environment Can Be Improved
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) The Tennessee Valley Authority says its work aimed at reducing or eliminating air and river pollution points the way toward an improved en vironment in the United States.

title: DAMAGE SUIT SCORES `FRITO BANDITO ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) The MexicanAmerican Anti Defamation Committee said to day that it planned to file suit asking for $610million in dam ages because of the Frito Ban dito television advertisements by a corn chip company.

title: MarijuanaUse Dismissal By Peace Corps Challenged
description: A suit has been filed in Fed eral Court here challenging the dismissal of a Peace Corps member who admitted smoking one cigarette that might have contained marijuana.

title: Broadway Musical Stays Open As Cast Accepts Lower Wage
description: The Broadway musical Lovely Ladies, Kind Gentle men has Won a temporary re prieve from an early demise as a result of the collective effort of its cast and production staff.

title: BargainHungry Shoppers Lift Sales Here
description: It's been the strongest postChristmas period in some time, a Macy's New York spokesman stsid yesterday.

title: NIXON SIGNS BILL ON BANK CONTROL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) President Nixon signed today legislation to require the break up of some combinations of banks with nonbanking busi ness.

title: House Ethics Panel Urges Detailed Data by Lobbyists
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)  The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct is proposing that lobbyists tell the public about each outlay of $50 or more spent to try to in fluence a Senator or Rep resentative.

title: Wisdom in Moscow
description: The Soviet Government has mixed wisdom with com passion in commuting the death sentences against two defendants in the Leningrad skyjack case and in reducing the prison sentences of some of the other convicted persons.

title: First Honors List Under Heath Omits Hereditary Titles
description: LONDON, Dec. 31The first British honors list since the Conservative party took office in June was announced to night. Its most striking feature was the absence of hereditary honors. That means none of the titles awarded can be passed on to the heirs of those hon ored. And the strong belief here is that there will be no hereditary honors as long as Edward Heath is Prime Minister.

title: WRIT BARS STRIKE BY 3 L.I.R. UNIONS
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday extended a tempo rary restraining order barring three Long Island Railroad unions from striking until at least Jan. 11.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Excelsior Insurance Company of New York has appointed Charles R. Woolfort, formerly vice president ard treasurer, as president. He succeede Forrest H. Witmeyer who has retired. Norris John son was named chairman to succeed Guy T. War field, and J. Paul Pizor was made executive vice president.

title: Nebraska Orange Bowl Choice; Tennessee Is Sugar Bowl Pick
PROXMIRE ACCEPTS EXTENSION OF SST
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31  The battle of the supersonic transport, which embroiled the House and Senate for nearly a month and threatened the or derly adjournment of the 91st Congress, appeared to be over this evening when Senator Wil liam Proxmire, the Wisconsin Democrat who has led the militant SST opposition, agreed to a threemonth lease on life for the controversial airliner.

title: Lion Tamer Is Mauled
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 31 (AP)  Corporal Borvanali, a 41  year  old lion tamer who pleaded for someone to kill him after he was mauled by a lion, was reported in satisfactory condition at a hospital here to day. Mr. Borvanali, who per forms under the name of Prince Mohammed, was attacked by an 18yearold male lion late Tues day at the winter quarters of the Carson and Barnes Circus at Hugo in southeastern Okla homa.

title: Nixon Invites Newsmen To Join Holiday Drinks
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)With snow falling thickly outside, President Nixon wound up a busy New Year's Eve in his office today by inviting what remained of the White House press carps to join him for holiday drinks and. conversation.

title: Internal Issues Also Guided Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 31  Early this week, the French Ambas sador, Roger Seydoux, met with a highranking Soviet official to express France's unhappi ness with the death sentences meted out in Leningrad and, the hope that they would be commuted.

title: Decision on Dancer's Image Formally Entered in Court
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 31 (UPI)Franklin County Circuit Judge Henry Meigs 2d formally entered today the judgment of his opinion Dec. 11 when he overruled the Kentucky Racing Comission and awarded first place money of $122,600 in the disputed 1968 Kentucky Derby to Dancer's Image.

title: All Bodies Recovered
description: WOOTON, Ky., Dec. 31 The last of 38 bodies was re moved from the Finley Brothers coal mine this morning, end ing any hope that somebody had survived the explosion shortly after noon yesterday.

title: Menus for Holiday Weekend Cooks
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Ratliff Wins Tennis Final
description: James Ratliff of Greenwich, Conn., won the Eastern indoor junior tennis championship yesterday at the Sterling courts in Corona, Queens defeating Joseph Wade of New York, 64, 16, 63.

title: Urban Housing Bill is Signed by Nixon, Now at Camp David
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) The White House announced this morning that President Nixon had signed a S2.9billion housing bill containing a new urban growth policy that in cludes increased Federal aid for new towns.

title: ABRAHAM LESSOW
description: Abraham Lessow, a linotype operator in the composing room of The New York Times, died yesterday at his home atter a heart attack. He was 66 years old and lived at 5915 47th Avenue, Woodside, Queens. Mr. Lessow joined The Times on March 18, 1955.

title: Dughi Wins Tennis Honors
description: Tom Dughi, of Essex Fe??s, N. J., won the Eastern boys indoor tennis championship at the Sterling Courts in Corona, Queens, yesterday, defeating Cid Praderas of New York, 61, 61 in the final.

title: Strike Halts Publication of the Washington Star
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1The Washington Evening Star was unable to publish any editions today when editorial and other Union members refused to cross Picket lines of striking garage mechanics.

title: A RedBloc World Bank Commences Its Operations
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1The Soviet Union and six of its Communist economic partners formally opened a major chap ter in their financial relations with the Western world today as the Moscowbased Interna tional Investment Bank began its operations.

title: Furniture Business Vies For Consumer's Dollar
description: After a decade of mergers both within the industry and involving conglomerates  the furnishings industry is beginning to emerge as a major single force aggres sively vying for the consum er dollar.

title: Pennsylvania Fire Kills 2
description: SPANGLER, Pa., Jan. 1 (UPI) Two volunteer firemen were killed and two were seriously injured today when a wall col lapsed on them during a fire that destroyed three buildings in the business district of this coal mining community in Western Pennsylvania. The dead men were identified as Frank Kincaid, 47 years old, and John Deedee, 32, both of nearby Patton.

title: The Black and White Bus Lines
description: DURHAM, N. C.A recent trip that I made from Durham, my home, to Orangeburg, S. C., Strom Thurmond's home, where I work at South Carolina State College, realized for me the enormousness of the change that has taken place in my reaction to the world in which I live and move and have my being in the comparatively Short time of five years.

title: Rochester Breaks the Ice
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 1 (AP) The Rochester Americans cele brated their first happy New Year on home ice tonight with a 51 American Hockey League victory over the Quebec Aces. Rochester went into the game with an 051 wonlost home record for New Year's Day games and had an overall Jan. 1 mark of 182.

title: The Talk of Bible Cities
description: QURNAH, Iraq  The leg endary site of the Garden of Eden is browner than usual this winter. But it is still splendid enough to stir the faith of Arab peasants.

title: Bronx Man, 57, Slain
description: What the police described as the first homicide of the year in the city was reported at 1:30 A.M. yesterday as a 57 yearold man was fatally stabbed in the Bronx. The vic tim, Emilio Rosa of 235 Cy press Avenue, the Bronx, was assaulted during an argument in a hallway at 618 East 138 Street. Raphael Rivera, 28, of 2011 Lafontaine Avenue, the Bronx, was arrested on a charge of homicide.

title: Miss Chanfreau of France Upsets Patti Hogan at Net
description: PERTH, Australia, Jan. 1 (AP)Patti Hogan of Irvine, Calif., the No. 2 seeded player, suffered an 86, 63 upset to day at the hands of Gail Chan freau of France in the quarter finals of the West Australian tennis championships.

title: Prettybelle Gets Ready For Date on Broadway
description: It was the first day of rehearsal for Prettybelle. Gower Champion, the direc tor, was apologizing for the lack of heat. Alexander H. Cohen, the producer, was urging that everybody take a flu shot.

title: DR. SARAH A. LUSE, A PATHOLOGIST, 52
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 Dr. Sarah A. Luse, an interna tionally known expert on sub microscopic changes in tissues caused by disease, died here Monday in her sleep. She was 52 years old and lived at 50 Haven Avenue in New York.

title: Bridge: Young Players Tournament Gets Under Way Here Today
Stanford Upsets Ohio State, 2717, on Late Rally;
Irish Victory Formula: Theismann and Defense
description: DALLAS, Jan. 1I haven't been so happy since I was married, Joe Theismann said with a wide grin, and that was only three weeks ago.

title: Slugs Pose Mounting Problem
description: New Yorkers who buy packages of cigarettes with brass disks, dial pay tele phone calls with Malaysian one sen pieces and purchase handfuls of peanuts with plastic bingo markers are be coming a major problem this year for vending machine owners and toll collectors.

title: Murphy Names 4 High Officers To Interim Police Assignments
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced four high level appointments yesterday, including new commanders for the department's patrol and de tective forces.

title: Snow Pats Off Racing At 3 Eastern Tracks
description: Heavy snow forced can cellation of racing yesterday at three major race tracks: Laurel in Maryland, Liberty Bell in Philadelphia and Lin coln Downs in Rhode Island. Each track plans, to operate today.

title: 2d Decade of War Begins; Truce Broken by Clashes
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 1The United States today be gan the second decade of its involvement in the Vietnam war, with military spokesmen reporting a surge of fighting that marred a 24hour New Year's truce proclaimed by the allies.

title: RANGERS TO FACE PENGUINS TONIGHT
description: The New York Rangers make a quick trip to Pittsburgh today to oppose the Penguins in a National Hockey League game. Right after the contest, the Broadway sextet will fly back home for a Sunday night en gagement with the Canadiens of Montreal in Madison Square Garden.

title: Public Relaxes at HomeGovernor's
description: ALBANY, Jan. 1They pawed the Picassos. They showered crumbs onto plush beige and red carpets. They raced up and down the graceful stairway of the Governor's mansion during the annual open house here this afternoon.

title: Britons Report Severe Phobias Are Relieved by Close Contact
description: LONDON, Jan. 1A 20year old secretary, terrified of cats, was successfully treated by British doctors when the animal was put into close contact with her.

title: Police in Brooklyn Open Neighborhood Service
description: A young woman stepped off the snowcovered corner of Utica Avenue and Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn yester day morning and hailed a passing police car.

title: NEW WEEKLY BIOGRAPHICAL SERVICE.
description: The New York Times Biographical Edi tion. Profiles of today's newsmakers In a looseleas edition. Write: The New York Times, Library Services, Box FP480. ??9 West 43d Street. New York. N.Y. 10036.

title: CourtMartial Due Tuesday For 12th in Leningrad Case
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 1 (UPI)Len ingrad sources said today that a Jewish member of the Soviet armed forces would be court martialed next Tuesday on charges that he was the 12th man involved in the Leningrad plot to hijack an airliner.

title: Vatican to Sign Pact for Nuclear Curb
description: ROME, Jan. 1The Vatican, which has no other arms than the medieval halberds of its Swiss Guards, announced today that it would sign the inter national treaty on halting the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: For weeks and months there has been a public clamor by Government officials and private citizens for the North Vietnamese Government offi cially to name those Americans it holds prisoner and those whom it knows to have died. This the North Vietnamese now have done. Without any certain knowledge that the released list of 339 prisoners and of twenty persons who have died is in error, Secretary of State Rogers calls the releasing of the list a contemptible maneuver and in humane. The Times [editorial Dec. 27] says he spoke to the point.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: State Commissioner Nyquist urges the adoption of the informal British approach to schooling as an antidote to the oppressive, grim, and joy less schools. I should like to know how he plans to sell this program to the parents.

title: Cambodians Meet Resistance
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 1 (AP)Cambodian troops who are beginning a long awaited drive to clear Route 4 and break the enemy's grip on the eco nomic life of the country ran into heavy resistance today 85 miles southwest of Pnompenh.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 1 (AP)Is rael's state radio asserted today that nine Jews In Leningrad, who are scheduled to be tried next week on charges of anti Soviet activities, had been tortured by Soviet interrogators in an attempt to extract con fessions from them.

title: The New Year Rings In Some More of the Same
description: One of the bells that rang in the New Year on Thursday night had a discordant tone. It was the first fire alarm of 1971, and it turned out to be false.

title: Monzon Could Forfeit Title, World Boxing Unit Warns
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 1 (UPI)  The World Boxing Association warned Carlos Monzon today that he would be stripped of his world middleweight title if he honored a return bout con ?? for a rematch with Nino ?? of Italy.

title: Copper Market Study: Question of Sufficiency
description: The copper market's dis tinctionone that will be of increasing importance in the coming decadeis that the United States does not pro duce enough for its own needs, although it is the world's top producer.

title: FAMILY OF FIVE DIES IN MOBILE HOME FIRE
description: BATAVIA, N. Y., Jan. 1 (AP)  Three children and their parents died early today when fire swept through their mo bile home and kept rescuers at bay in the hamlet of Bushville near here.

title: Eyebrows Going Out Of Style?
description: Eyebrows are fading. With hardedged eyeliner only a memory from the swinging sixties and false eyelashes being forsaken by the avant garde, a bleachedout eye brow appears to be the next step toward the natural beauty face.

title: Use of Paper Gold Pressed as an Aid By Needy Nations
description: PARIS, Jan. 1  Developing countries as well as the World Bank and other organizations associated with development as sistance are pressing govern ments of rich countries to use the world's newest reserve as set as a means of increasing aid.

title: Blame for the F111
description: The final report of the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee on its long inquiry into the F111 airplane contract might well be called The Revenge of the Mili taryIndustrial Complex.

title: Man in the News
description: DALLAS, Jan. 1  When Ara Parseghian, arrived for his first Cotton Bowl news conference several days ago, he looked at the battery of microphones in front of him on the dais and smiled.

title: OIL UNION STRIKES BIG TEXACO PLANT
description: PORT ARTHUR, Tex., Jan. 1 (AP)Members of the oil work ers union struck Texaco's larg est refinery today just after midnight, but an industrywide walkout failed to develop al though most contracts for 60, 000 workers expired at that hour.

title: Arrest of More Basques In Protest Strikes Reported
description: BILBAO, Spain, Jan. 1 (Reut ers)Informed sources said to day that the police had arrested more than 50 Basques in Bil bao's industrial suburb of Ses tao in a further move against workers who struck to protest death sentences imposed on six Basques in the Burgos trial.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Jan. 1In an expansive holiday mood the other day, Roy Dean of Bromley, Kent, wrote a letter to The Times of London. His subject was the daily crossword puzzle, of which The Times by then had published 12,468.

title: Chicago Banker Is Indicted In $8.5Million Stock Fraud
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (UPI) A Chicago investment banker, James J. White was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of defrauding six brokerage firms of $8.5mil lion.

title: Defiance in the Snow
description: The heavy snow that ushered in the New Year dem onstrated how suddenly potential disaster can engulf the city. Vital services would have been paralyzed almost at once if sanitation crews, ignoring the expiration of their old union contract, had not worked around the clock to keep main arteries open. And, even at that, it will be days or weeks before normalcy is restored.

title: Chiang Marks Anniversary
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 1 (AP) President Chiang Kaishek presided today at a gathering of Chinese Nationalist leaders, commemorating the 60th anni versary of the establishment of the Republic of China.

title: Plows a Welcome Sight To Residents of Queens
description: The sidewalks were in visible. The side streets were easier to get stuck in than drive through. The secondary routes were partly plowed, but by plows without sand or salt. And to the people of Queens, it was quite acceptable.

title: KNICKS TO MEET HAWKS TONIGHT
description: Yesterday, when many, holi day revelers were nursing strange ailments, Willis Reed of the Knicks was still waiting to hear the source of his dis comfort.

title: Martinsen of Norway Beats Gallagher in Night Ski Race
description: AUBURN, Me., Jan. 1 (AP) Ode Martinsen, Norway's top crosscountry skier, won last night in the United States Ski Association's night race cir cuit.

title: Bronx Man Seized at Airport
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 1 (UPI) A 34yearold Bronx man was arrested here today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on a charge of unlawful pos Session of a firearm aboard an airplane flight. The F.B.I. said James F. Brown, of 1451 Prospect Ave, had threatened to use a pistol aboard United Flight 825 from LaGuardia Air port to the Greater Pitsburgh Airport.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We welcome the concern expressed in your Dec. 22 editorial on the prob lems of surface mining. This is a matter which has commanded the con cern of and action by the Tennessee Valley Authority for decades.

title: Hiker Freezes in Idaho
description: EMMETT, Idaho, Jan. 1 (UPI) A 25yearold man hiking from a disabled vehicle to a cabin in heavy snow country near here froze to death yes terday when he stopped to rest and removed his wet coat. Charles D. Horsman, of Em mett, was barely conscious when his companions, who hiked on, returned for him. He died a few hours later.

title: Continued Growth Expected In BottledWater industry
description: For the first time in its his tory, the bottled water indus try hit the $80million mark in sales in 1970 and estimates by experts in the field are that it will be in excess of $100mil lion this year.

title: Rockets Vanquish Lakers, 117106, As Hayes Gets 40
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 1 (UPI)Elvin Hayes scored 40 points and grabbed 21 re bounds tonight as the San Diego Rockets registered their first victory here, a 117106 de cision over the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: 60 to Bow Out of Congress With Vote on SST Today
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1The 91st Congress prepared today to face its final headache to morrow  the supersonic trans port program  so it could take its place in history.

title: 9 New Yorkers Ending Congress Careers
description: WASHINGTON; Jan. 1 The oncebustling office suite was nearly deserted the other day as Senator Charles E. Goodell sat at his desk, listening to a tape record ing of music from Funny Girl, toying with his new Ben Franklinstyle reading glasses and sifting through the morning mail.

title: Team's Plane With 30 Missing off Algeria
description: ALGIERS, Jan. 1 (UPI)A chartered French airliner car rying members of an Algerian soccer team disappeared and presumably crashed on New Year's eve in the Mediter ranean off the Algerian coast.

title: Many Confused on Starting Date Of Cigarette Commercial Ban
description: Telephone calls came in a steady flow yesterday to tele vision networks here from viewers asking why commer cials for cigarettes were still on the air.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It was appalling to me to hear that the United States Public Health Service Hospital on Staten Island may be closed because of limited goals. It is most grievous that our politicians can allot money for big business, war, and space travel while thousands of people in New York City are greatly in need of medical care.

title: Castro Sees Little Hope For Cuban Economy in 71
description: MIAMI, Jan. 1Premier Fidel Castro said last night that Cuba faced 1971 with few prospects of overcoming her perennial economic and social problems.

title: Parsley Frees 2 Youths
description: NATCHEZ, Miss., Jan. 1 (AP) Two Texas teenagers picked up for vagrancy and Investiga tion of marijuana possession here were on their way home today. A justice of the peace suspended their 30day vagran cy sentences after, what ap peared to be two marijuana cigrettes found in their posses sion turned out to be parsley.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1A robot mower that was pat ented this week cuts a lawn quietly and thoroughly with out human supervision. The Mowbot, as it is trade marked, is selfpropelled and selfguided, staying within the owner's yard in compli ance with signals from a wire around the bound ary. Patent 3,550, 714 was granted to Spencer L. Bel linger, an elec tronics engineer, who assigned it to Mowbot, Inc., of Tonawanda, N. Y. The company has sold about 250 of the machines in this country and abroad, at retail prices of $800 or more.

title: Bruins Rout Sabres, 94, and Lift Lead
Frostbite Regatta Deferred
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 1The Frostbite Yacht Club's regatta was postponed today until tomorrow because of the snowstorm.

title: He Left Adults'
description: Harlin Quist is an icon oclast in the world of chil dren's books.

title: MICHIGAN DEFEATS YALE SEXTET, 111
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 1 (AP)  Michigan and Dartmouth posted easy victories today for the right to play for honors tomor row night in the sixth annual Nichols School college hockey tournament.

title: As the Curtain Time Changes, Restaurants Dance to the Theater's Tune
description: Starting Monday, curtains are going up earlier at many theater  district restaurants, too.

title: Clippers Tie Reds, 44
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 1 (AP) Defensive errors by the Balti more Clippers dissipated a 31 lead tonight and they needed Jim Niekamps goal with 1 minute 56 seconds remaining to salvage a 44 tie with the Prov idence Reds in an American Hockey League game.

title: City's Snow Emergency Will Be in Effect Today
description: The snow emergency and suspension of alternateside ofthestreet parking begun yesterday will be continued today, Traffic Commissioner Theodore Karagheuzoff an nounced.

title: U. of Tennessee President Asks New Pact for Battle
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) The president of the Univer sity of Tennessee said tonight he would recommend that Coach Bill Battle be given a new fiveyear contract with a substantial pay rise.

title: Unemployment Here Climbs to 4.6%
