description: The Bureau of Labor Statis tics reported yesterday that em ployment in New York City rose by only eighttenths of 1 per cent last year, the smallest rate of increase since 1965.

title: Ray Henderson, the Songwriter, Is Dead at 74
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 1 Ray Henderson, the composer of many popular songs that were enthusiastically received by the American public, died of a heart attack last night at his home here. His age was 74.

title: TENNESSEE COACH APPLAUDS 2 MEN
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) They tried to stop our run ning game, but we passed, too, the Tennessee coach, Bill Battle, said today in summing up the Vols victory in the Sugar Bowl.

title: CHARLES I. BRADY
description: KINNELON, N. J., Jan. 1 Charles I. Brady, a sales engi neer with the Sylvania Electric Products Company, Teterboro, died yesterday of a stroke after a brief illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 344 Brookvale Road, Smoke Rise.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your editorial of Dec. 19 Refuge at Jamaica Bay, was a laudable ex pression of concern for the protection of that valuable wetland and wildlife sanctuary. Regrettably, however, it in correctly stated my position.

title: First Withdrawal of 1971
description: SAIGON, Jan. 1 (AP)  The United States command an nounced the first troop re deployment of the new year. It said authorized American troop strength was reduced, by 170 men with the withdrawal of an Army air supply company.

title: Issues in City's Pay Talks
description: THE PARTIES The New York City government, rep resenting eight million residents, and labor groups serving three of the, city's basic needs: the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, representing 30,000 policemen; the Uniformed Firefighters. Association, representing 11,300 firemen, and the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, representing 11,000 garbage collectors. Eighty smaller groups represent ing about 45,000 other city workers in various fields are also involved.

title: The First of 38 Coal Miners Is Buried in Kentucky
description: HYDEN, Ky., Jan. 1The first funeral was held today for one of 38 miners who died Wednesday in an explosion at the Finley Brothers coal mine.

title: 4 Die in CarTrain Crash
description: LAKE ODESSA, Mich., Jan 1 (AP)Four members of the Charles Lewis family, who were burned out of their home on Christmas Eve, died today in a cartrain collision. The vic tims were Charles Lewis, 39 years old his wife, Ruby, 35; and two of their four sons, Leroy, 13, and Ernest, 9. Another son, Charles Jr., 15, was in critical condition. David Lewis, 12, was at his grandmother's house when the crash occurred at a Chesapeake & Ohio Rail road crossing, about one mile east of here.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: NEW HAVENIn the autumn of 1968 members of the black community in Hyde County, N. C., engaged in daily marches and demonstrations at the local public school. Fortyfive Children and numerous adults were arrested and convicted of disorderly conduct and impeding the regular flow of traffic in the street passing the school. As with other civil rights cases in recent years, these convictions were appealed. A landmark decision is expected when the appeal comes before the United States Supreme Court this term. How ever, the issue which the Court will be asked to decide is one that goes far beyond the special concerns of civil rights activists. It is:

title: City Massed Its Forces to Battle the Seasons First Snowstorm
description: In order to save money and to allow men to spend New Year's Day with their families, the Sanitation Department, in its early planning, had decided to cut back sharply on its force for yesterday's midnight to8 A.M. shift, leaving only a thin force of 188 men on duty.

title: Manmade Wasteland in Vietnam
description: Investigators from the American Association for the Advancement of Science have produced shocking new evidence of the devastating effects of United States military cropspraying on the land and people of South Vietnam.

title: In the World of Mideastern Oil, Profits Are Nigh but So Are Perils
description: BEIRUT, LebanonIn an office building in the center of Teheran a New York oil eco nomist jotted down a few dol lar signs and said: We're all still making money. But there's this constant daily maneuver and jockeying all over the oil world.

title: WILLIAM CARLOUGH SR.
description: RUTHERFORD, N. J., Jan. 1 William W. Carlough Sr., an executive of the First National City Bank of New York, died yesterday in Hackensack Hos pital. He was 62 years old and lived at 62 Menona Avenue.

title: 150 in Saigon Protest Ban On Seeing Jailed Relatives
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 1About 150 South Vietnam ese peasants demonstrated on the steps of the National As sembly building today after Government officials barred them from visiting relatives at the central detention center.

title: Aparicio's Father Dies
description: MARACAIBO, Venezuela, Jan. 1 (UPI)Luis Aparicio Sr., the father of Luis Aparicio, the Boston Red Sox shortstop, died here today after a heart attack. He was 58 years old and had played professional baseball in Puerto Rico, Santo Domingo and Cuba.

title: Police in Syracuse Claim Largest Heroin Seizure
description: SYRACUSE, Jan. 1 (AP) Nine persons were arrested to day when the police raided a house here and confiscated what they claimed was the largest amount of heroin ever seized in this city, worth $50,000.

title: 9.2% RISE SEEN IN G.N.P. FOR 71
description: The gross national product of the free world's 21 loading in dustrial nations were projected at $2.32trillion for 1971 in a study released yesterday by McGrawHill Publications eco nomic department.

title: It's Not Cricket Down Under
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 2 (Reuters)  Rain prohibited play for the third successive day in the third cricket test between England and Australia today. With only two days re maining, not a ball has been bowled in the match.

title: Involved Writers in the World
description: EAST BERLIN I have recently had to do resear?? on Daniel Defoe, whose Robin?? crusoe and Moll Flan ders are perennials. A number of years, before he published these best sellers, Defoe stood in a London pillory three times on successive days  one day in Cornhill by the Exchange, the next in Cheapside near the Conduit and the third in Fleet Street by Temple Barwith a paper above his head that read, Daniel Defoe, for writing and publishing a seditious libel entitled The Shortest Way With the Dis senters'.

title: Polish Church Puts Terms to Regime
description: WARSAW, Jan. 1The Ro man Catholic Church in Poland today published its conditions for the full normalization of relations with the nation's new Communist leadership.

title: U.S. DRAWING SET ON PAPER GOLD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1The Treasury announced today that the United States had been al located $713Million of paper gold, by the International Mon etary Fund following lastmin ute action by Congress and the President on the necessary leg islation.

title: Lion Sleeps Wins New Year's Day Handicap for fourth in Row at Tropical
California Court Bombed
description: EL MONTE, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP)A bomb that exploded at the municipal court build ing in this Los Angeles suburb last night tore a heavy wooden door off its hinges, ripped out chunks of concrete and blew out a dozen windows. There were no injuries.

title: The Talk of Bible Cities
description: NINEVEH, IraqCautious devil worshipers, fervent Moslems, members of old Christian sectsthe varie gated peoples of modern Nineveh coexist busily around the ruins of this ancient metropolis.

title: CUTS IN SERVICES BEGUN BY FIREMEN AS CONTRACT ENDS
description: City firemen refused yester day to perform nonemergency duties, some defying a depart ment order to clear snow away from firehouse entrances and hydrants.

title: Toledo Streak Now Longest
description: DALLAS, Jan. 1 (AP)With the end of Texas 30game win ning streak today in the Cot ton Bowl, the University of Toledo has the longest winning streak among major college football teams23 games. The longest winning streak of mod em times is 47 by Oklahoma.

title: Warning by Thieu
description: SAIGON, Jan. 1 (UPI)Presi dent Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam in a speech to members of the diplomatic corps who came to bring him New Year's greetings, said he believed any peace agreement with the Vietcong would be worthless unless the Communist movement in South Vietnam was first rooted out and de stroyed.

title: CONSUMER BILLS CASUALTY OF 91ST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 With the Nixon Administration playing what was widely re garded as an anomalous role, consumer advocates generated much controversy but little major legislation in the 91st Congress.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has produced in this centennial year a series of experiments that have gen erated applause as well as criticism.

title: Sonics Stop Blazers, 121118
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 1 (AP)A free throw by Lee Winfield with five seconds left to play tonight helped the Seattle SuperSonics score a 121118 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: THOMAS J. LEWIS, 95, COSMETICS OFFICIAL
description: Thomas Jenkins Lewis, a re tired cosmetic executive, died on Thursday at Doctors Hos pital. He was 95 years old and lived at 21 East 90th Street.

title: RollsRoyce Output at Peak
description: LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) RollsRoyce, the giant British engineering company which faced a loss of $115.6million in 1970 and had to be supported by government aid, had a rec ord year for car production. More than 2,000 RollsRoyce Silver Ghost and Bentley li m??usines brought in $36mill lion the division's best per formance in five years, it was announced yesterday. More than 1,000 of the cars were exported.

title: CANADIAN DOLLAR SHOWS STRENGTH
description: TORONTO, Jan. 1In a yearend rally that few Ca nadians cheered, the floating Canadian dollar traded at up to 99 United States cents this week before wrapping up the old year at 98.88 cents.

title: Bayh Becomes Chairman Of Senate Delinquency Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) Birch Bayh, Democrat of In diana, moved into the chair manship of The Juvenile Delin quency Subcommittee today, observing that the present sys tem of dealing with youthful offenders was almost totally ineffectual.

title: GOVERNOR RENEWS PLEA FOR U.S. AID IN INAUGURAL TALK
description: ALBANY, Jan. 1 Governor Rockefeller began his fourth term today with the same mes sage he repeatedly sounded in the final months of his third termthat the state needs Fed eral help to meet its problems.

title: Food Truck Strike Averted
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 (UPI) The International Brother hood of Teamsters reached a tentative contract with area food chains today, averting a threatened strike by 1,600 food truck drivers. Details of the threeyear contract were with held pending a ratification vote Sunday by the members of six teamsters locals here and in Chester, Pa., Camden, N.J., and Wilmington, Del.

title: NewIssues Market Held Months From Recovery
description: The newissues market, which spent most of 1970 in the dol drums following a general col lapse in stock prices, is still months away from any broad recovery.

title: New Voters First Step
description: The eligibility to vote in Federal elections now enjoyed by a million New Yorkers between the ages of 18 and 21 will be meaningless unless they register. To make sure that youths are in position to exercise the voting rights extended them by Congress and the Supreme Court, the New York City Board of Elections will hold a special registration drive for newly eligible voters beginning Monday.

title: Pact at Pittsburgh Press
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 1 (UP1) The Pitsburgh Press Company, publisher of The Evening and Sunday Press and printing agent for the morning Post reached tentative agreement with its pressmen's union on a new wage contract covering 230 employes. The union had threatened a strike if no agree ment were reached. A strike would have left the city without Gazette, announced today it had a daily newspaper.

title: Auto Output in '70 Of 8,273,791 Units Was 8Year Low
description: DETROIT, Jan. 1 (AP)Econ omizing consumers and a cost ly strike at the General Motors Corporation pushed 1970 auto motive production to its lowest level in eight years, industry sources report.

title: Colts, Stadium in Fine Shape
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 1Protected by a tarpaulin from five inches of snow and cleared by 316 workmen at a cost of about $18,000 to this city, the field at Memorial Stadium was in comparatively excellent condition today for the American Con ference championship game here Sunday between the Colts and the Oakland Raiders.

title: Holidays Busy at Colorado Resort
description: VAIL, Colo.This seems to be The Place To Be this holiday season. At least Mrs. Katharine Graham thinks so. And so do the Gerald Fords, Mrs. Patricia Lawford, the John Murchisons and Mrs. Conrad Hilton Jr.

title: Coast Crash Kills Youths
description: BIG SUR, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) Kevin Bagshaw, 19 years old, of Boston, and a companion died yesterday when their car plunged off California 1 and tumbled 600 feet down a hill to the Pacific Ocean. The driver, Bruce Howes, 25, of Van Nuys, also was killed.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: Eleven years ago C. P. (now Lord) Snow caused a stir in intellectual circles by his perceptive analysis of the widening gulf between scientists and humanists in modern society. To day that rift still exists and it is related to a greater and more serious social phenomenon, the growing cleav age between the university world and the Government.

title: On Campus at a Very Early Age
description: Kelli Robinson spends her days on the campus of Brooklyn College. Some times she recites the alphabet, some times she sings and sometimes she plays with dolls or draws pictures. Kelli is 2 years old, and she neither knows the meaning of, nor particularly cares about, a college degree. But her mother does.

title: Laver, Rosewall Play Here Today in $10,000 Match
description: When you talk about the best tennis player of 1970, you run into a muddle. Rod Laver won more money and more tournaments but not the big ones. Ken Rosewall captured the United States Open and reached the final of Wimbledon. John New combe won Wimbledon, and Tony Roche the United States professional championship.

title: Legislation in Connecticut Asked to Lift Boxing Ban
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 1 (UPI) State Senator Joseph J. Fau liso proposed legislation yes terday to remove Connecticut as the only state in the nation that prohibits professional box ing.

title: Muskegon Mich., Bank Sale Is 9th by Parsons Group
description: DETROIT, Jan. 1 (AP)The Sale of the Muskegon Bank and Trust Company to a group headed by Robert B. Evans, a Detro??t industrialist and former board chairman of the American Motors Co??poration, brings to a total of nine the number of banking interests that have been sold by the socalled Par sons Group, it was announced here.

title: Orioles to Tour Japan
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 1 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles today accepted an invitation to make a monthlong exhibition tour of Japan next fall. The Orioles will play 18 games against Japanese teams of the Central and Pacific leagues, starting in Tokyo on Oct. 23.

title: An Auction for Silver Dollars
description: For numismatists and for those who use the less im pressive title of just coin collector, a big event has just plodded one step closer to reality. It is the proposed auction of nearly 3 million silver dollars, called by some coin dealers the biggest such sale in history.

title: SOME CALLS T0 911 TAFN BY NURSES
description: New Yorkers who call the 911 emergency number to re quest an ambulance may find themselves answering questions from a registered nurse whose job is to determine whether an ambulance is really necessary.

title: The Dance: Diversity
description: The joy of the American Ballet Theater repertory is its massive diversity. It has made eclecticism into a style of its own. On Thursday night at the New York City Center It revived three bal lets Frederick Ashton's Les Patineurs, Birgit Cullberg's Miss Julie and Jerome Rob bine's Fancy Free, and a more widely assorted trio it would be difficult to find.

title: Otsego Judge Appointed
description: ALBANY, Jan. 1 (AP)Jo seph A. Mogavero Jr. of Una dilla was appointed by Gov ernor Rockefeller today as judge of the County Court and Family Court in Otsego County. Judge Mogavero, who served as Otsego County District At torney from 1960 through 1969, succeeds Frederick W. Loomis, who resigned.

title: Train Is Derailed Upstate
description: PORT EWEN, N. Y., Jan. 1 (UPI)Eighteen cars of a Penn Central freight train derailed to day near this Ulster County village. The state police said a buildup of snow apparently caused the rails to separate. No injuries were reported.

title: Pulp Mill's Waste Vexes Island in Florida
Mobile Food Caterers Post 7.5% Sales Gain in Year
description: Food caterers chalked up sales of $1,151,036,000 for 1970, compared with $1,071, 322,915 in 1969, according to a survey by Vend magazine.

title: MRS. T. M. BERNSTEIN, EDITOR'S WIFE, DIES
description: Mrs. Beatrice Alexander Bern stein, wife of Theodore M. Bernstein, editorial director of The New York Times book di vision, died at University Hos pital yesterday after an illness of several weeks. She was 63 years old and lived at 2 Fifth Avenue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: After having spent over 35 years in national labor relations program ing on behalf of labor and manage ment I believe that what Is needed at this time is enactment of new labor laws to deal especially with workers whose occupation is essential to the economy, and the disruption of whose performance is inimical to that econ omy.

title: Increasing Campus Crime Spurs Security Measures
description: Until this fall, Libby Honey cutt, a 21yearold senior at the University of South Caro lina in Columbia, walked to the library in the evenings without a worry. Not any more.

title: HANDEL OPERAS SET IN CONCERT VERSION
description: Two operas by Handel, Or lando and Ariodante, will be sung in New York for the first time in concert versions to be presented this season by the Handel Society of New York at Carnegie Hall, They will be given in a threeevent Monday night series that will also include Handel's Solo mon, an oratori.

title: ECONOMIST SEES 71 IMPROVEMENTS
description: LONDON, Jan. 1 (AP)Prof. Paul A. Samuelson of the Mass achusetts Institute of Technol ogy said today the year 1971 will bring improvement to the American economy.

title: Hussein Ordered to Rest
description: LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) King Hussein of Jordan, ad mitted to a hospital here Mon day for a checkup, has been ordered to stay about 10 days for a complete rest, a Jordanian Embassy spokesman said today.

title: MRS. LEONARD HAMMOND
description: WASHINGTON, Conn., Jan. 1  Mrs. Dorothy Perry Ham mond, widow of Leonard C. Hammond, president of the Hammond, Lumber Company of San Francisco, died at her home here on Tuesday. She was 86 years old.

title: U.S. Airman Killed in Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 1 (UPI)A United States Air Force captain and a Laotian officer were killed when their light observation plane was shot down over the Plaine des Jarres, a United States Embassy spokesman announced today. The American was identified as Park G. Bunker, 30 years old, of Matteson, Ill., who had been in Laos since June as an assist ant to the United States air attach at the embassy here. He was acting as a forward air controller to spot enemy targets for air strikes.

title: Tuna Fleet Gambles Millions Against Taint
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 1At the stroke of midnight, nearly 100 ships of the American tuna fleet paraded out to sea today on what may be a multimillion dollar gamble. At stake are the fortunes of the ship owners, skippers and every one of the 1,400 fishermen who make up their crews.

title: Gear Makers Fill Post
description: William W. Ingraham has been appointed executive director of the American Gear Manufactur ers Association, Detroit. He is a graduate of Bowdoin College and lives with his wife and two children in Chevy Chase, Md. The group was founded in 1916 and is made up of 147 member companies in the United States and Canada.

title: Nation's Imports of Gold Showed Gain in November
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (Reu ters)United States gold im ports rose to $60,934,536 in November from $14,258,892 the previous month, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

title: Presentation of 30 Debutantes Marks New Year's Ball Here
description: The 49th Debutante As sembly and New Year's Ball took place last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Wal dorfAstoria in a setting of silver foliage and tiny white lights.

title: Bible Read in 79 Hours
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 1 (UPI)A Biblereading marathon ended yesterday at a church in subur ban Ferguson, with the 85 par ticipants claiming a possible world record for completing the reading of the Bible in 79 hours 15 minutes. The reading by members of the Church of the Nazarene started Sunday night.

title: Little Cheer for Great Stores of Paris
description: PARIS, Jan. 1  Window shopping was less enjoyable because the display lacked the luster and wit of yester year. Inside the stores the lingerie counter was an easi er target because the crowds were thinner.

title: Animal Vaccine Restricted By Agriculture Department
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) The Agriculture Department has ordered off the market all animal vaccine and similar products made by Ranel Lab oratories, Inc., and its subsid iaries.

title: Chill Wind From Albany
description: The last thing anyone in Albany wants to contemplate at year's beginning is new state taxes, but initial budget briefings by Governor Rockefeller's aides make it plain that new taxes are urgently needed.

title: Entry 1, 2 at New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) Hindiya outran his stable mate, Roll and Toss, to win by a neck in the Holiday Purse at the New Orleans Fair Grounds today, sprinting the six furlongs in 1:13 25.

title: Cyril Ritchard's Stylish Perichole Is Given at Met
description: The Metropolitan Opera celebrated New Year's Eve with style by reviving Cyril Ritchard's production of Offenbach's La Prichole. T??s operetta was created for Paris and introduced there at the BouffesParisiens the ater in 1868, but Mr. Ritchard gave it a decidedly English touch when he first staged it here in 1956, and, fortu nately, that touch, that style, is with it still.

title: WALL ALSO SPLITS A GERMAN VILLAGE
description: MODLAREUTH, West Ger many, Jan. 1 (UPI)Mrs. Lena Zeh, squinting through the morning haze, pointed across the village at a twostory brick house where her sisterinlaw lives.

title: Sports of at auto The Times
description: Robert Short owns the Washington Senators, a club he periodically threatens to sell or leave on someone's door step unless the District of Columbia works out a stadium tenancy arrangement that will, according to his figures, let him make instead of lose money on the club. A 52yearold who made his own millions, Short bought the basketball Lakers when the team was in Minneapolis, his hometown, moved the club to Los Angeles and sold it for a profit.

title: Pistons Set Up Award Nobody Wants to Win
description: DETROIT, Jan. 1 (UPI)  The Detroit Pistons have es tablished an award, pre sented by teammates after each game to the player they decide has made the the most blatant mistakes.

title: City's First Little Police Chief To Seek Amity With the People
description: Is that the Little Colonel in there? a patrolman shout ed into a back room at the police station where Sgt. William Hart Ambrose sat talking to a visitor.

title: Nebraska's Dream Comes True And Coach Claims No. 1 Rating
description: MIAMI, Jan. 1 (AP)Hell, yes, we're No. 1, Coach Bob Devaney shouted tonight after his Nebraska Cornhuskers scored a hairraising 1712 vic tory over Louisiana State and staked a claim to the national collegiate football champion ship.

title: Soviet Girl Wins on TV With Herring and Waltz
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 1 (UPI) Nina Romanenko, a 24year old kindergarten teacher, to day won a nationally tele vised talent contest in which she was called upon to turn a herring into a tasty salad in five minutes.

title: French Poll Chooses Pope As the Most Admired Man
description: PARIS, Jan. 1 (UPI)Pope Paul VI is the man most ad mired by the French, according to an opinion poll published today.

title: Slight Rise in Sex Crimes Is Reported in Copenhagen
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 1 (Reuters)Sex crimes in Copenhagen increased slightly last year after several years of sharp decline that coincided with the liberalization of por nography laws, the police re ported.

title: Danish Freighter Sinks
description: HARWICH, England, Jan. 1 (Reuters)The 300ton Danish coastal freighter Thuroklint sank tonight after a collision with a Dutch ferry off south east Britain, Coast Guard spokesmen said. The freighter's sevenman crew was rescued by a pilot launch.

title: Antiques: Rare Connecticut Clocks
description: It's getting hard to find the simple late 19thCentury ??nnecticut clocks that are called Early American al though they ??ce were used in lower middle class homes on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: 8Inch Snow Snarls Air and Road Travel
description: The first major storm of the winter buried the city in up to eight inches of snow yesterday, but light holiday traffic and New Year's Day inertia blunted the effect of the heavy snow fall.

title: The Bowl Games
description: Notre Dame ended the win ning streak of Texas, the top ranked college football team, at 30 games yesterday by winning the Cotton Bowl contest, 2411, before 73,000 spectators at Dallas.

title: 3 Chinese Provinces Rebuilding Party
description: HONG KONG, Jan 1An announcement from Peking said today that great headway had be??n made recently in the rebuilding of the Chinese Communist party at lower levels.

title: U.S. SALES OF WINE CLIMB TO A RECORD
description: The American public's taste for wine reached record pro portions last year.

title: JERSEY LAYOFFS EXPAND WELFARE
description: PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 1 When the Labor Department designated this city and sur irounding Bergen and Passaic Counties as an area of sub stantial unemployment this week, it came as no surprise to Frank Kaster.

title: The Talk of Bible Cities
description: BABYLON, IraqLike King Nebuchadnezzar in Biblical times, the rulers of modern Iraq have walled off this ancient city.

title: Hugh W. Babb Dies at 83; Retired Law Professor
description: CUMBERLAND, Me., Jan. 1 (AP)  Hugh W. Babb, retired law professor at Boston Univer sity and former chairman of the law department of its Col lege of Business Administra tion, died today in a Portland hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: Farm Equipment: Tractors and Money
description: Survival in the business of making farm equipment de pends on several factors, but the most important is under standing the everchanging customer.

title: Ukrainian Rite Catholics Protest Vatican's Role
description: Ukrainian Rite Catholics have started a campaign of protest against what they call second class treatment by the Vatican.

title: George A. Armstrong Dies; A Foreign Service Officer
description: NEPTUNE, N. J., Jan. 1 George Alexander Armstrong, a veteran career officer in the State Department who served in embassies in Europe and Asia, died here last night. His age was 82.

title: CommunistOwned Liner Is Due Here on Monday
description: The first Communist passen ger liner to enter New York Harbor in 18 ears is to dock at Pier 40 on the Hudson River on Monday morning.

title: Hearings Slated on Curbs On Santa Barbara Drilling
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) The Interior Department will open unusual hearings in mid January to determine how much control to exercise over now drilling platforms on oil leases in the Santa Sarbara Channel so as to avoid oil leaks.

title: Strikes Casting a Pall Over Fleet Street
PLUNKETT'S PLAY DRAWS PLAUDITS
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (U??I)  The Stanford coach, John Ralston, was literally at a loss for words to describe how he felt about his quarterback, Jim Plunkett.

title: Pacha, 54Foot Sloop, Wins Sydney  to  Hobart Race
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 1 (UPI)The Cruising Yacht Club of Australia officials said today that Pacha, a 54foot alumi num sloop, had been named the winner of the SydneytoHobart yacht race.

title: Peaches Beneath Oaks Picked for a Rose Title
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP)A float showing three Georgia beauty queens sitting under stately oak trees cap tured the sweepstakes trophy today as the colorful Tourna ment of Roses parade kicked off the new year before 1.5 million spectators.

title: RUTH HAGEMAN, 49, ARTIST AND TEACHER
description: Ruth Hageman, an artist and teacher who specialized in the abstract and expressionist form, died Wednesday of cancer at the New York Infirmary. She was 49 years old and lived at 340 West 28th Street.

title: Modern Society Perils the Role of the Fading Volunteer Fireman
description: LAKE BARTON, FlaAs old as the Minuteman and as enthusiastic as a member of a Texas posse, the volun teer fireman in America has long been a symbol of the democratic notion that a neighbor can depend on his neighbor in times of trouble.

title: $650,000 Is Granted to Aid Studies of the Revolution
description: The Ford Foundation has awarded two grants totalling $650,000 for projects designed to giye scholars and historians, better access to basic docu ments on the American Revo lution and the Continental Con gress.

title: Rozelle Says N.F.L. Will Add Six Clubs for Total of 32 in Coming Decade
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 (UPI)Commissioner Pete Ro zelle said today ha expected the National Football League to add six teams during the cord ing decade, bringing the total to 32.

title: Texas Oil Union to Strike American Refinery Today
description: TEXAS CITY, Tex., Jan. 2 (UPI)  Union workers at the American Oil Company re finery here gave strike notice today and said picket lines would be established tomorrow.

title: Mishima
description: Just after midnight, in the early morning of Nov. 25, the telephone rang. A Japanese newspaper corre spondent was calling to inform me that Yukio Mishima had broken into the headquarters of the Eastern Corps Headquarters of the Japanese Self Defense Force, harangued the soldiers unsuccessfully, then committed sep puku, the ritual disembowelment. What are your impressions? the man asked.

title: News of Dogs
description: Entries for the Westmin ster Kennel Club show at Madison Square Garden, Feb. 15 and 16, have closed with 3,036 dogs. Heading the list are poodles, with 227; dachs hunds, 96, Afghan hounds, 83, Siberian huskies, 79, and Great Danes, 76.

title: Robert Robe Jr. And Lucy Barry To Be Married
description: Miss Lucy. Brown Barry of New York and Robert S. Robe Jr. of Oyster Bay, L.I., plan to be married at the Colony Club here on Feb. 6.

title: TENNIS IS JOINING WAR ON POLLUTION
description: The first Clean Air Tennis Classic was announced yester day. Scheduled for Feb. 9 to 14, the tournament will be played at the Vanderbilt International Racquet Club, 42d Street and Vanderbilt Avenue.

title: GROUP URGES DEFEAT OF 3 PANEL LEADERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) Common Cause, an organi zation headed by John W. Gardner, former Secretary of Health, Education and Wel fare, urged today the defeat of three House committee chair men at the Democratic caucus later this month. It identified them as:

title: Chess
description: GRANDMASTER Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles captured first place in the interzonal knockout round robin of Majorca, Spain, 18 4. He outdistanced the 24man field by 3 points, winding up with a seven game winning streak.

title: ADOLPH P. MORRIS
description: Adolph P. Morris, a floor of ficial and member of the New York Stock Exchange, died Friday in Hollywood, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived in Cedarherst, L.I.

title: Taking Law From the Poor
description: Now comes the crunch for the Office of Economic Opportunity's legal services program. On top of the dis missal of the program's director and deputy director and cutbacks in its funds, Governor Reagan is tryingfor least the third timeto kick the Federal lawyers for the poor out of California. If his latest effort is not resisted by the White House and the O.E.O., the entire legal serv ices program can be picked off, state by state.

title: Christmas Swapping Booms in Coast Shop
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 (AP) For most retailers the boom comes just before Christmas, but for Ted and Shirley Margulis it is here now. They are the proprietors of the Gift Exchange Center, where people flock to swap white elephant gifts.

title: Dreith Named Referee For Game at Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 2Ben Dreith, an official through out the decade of the old American Football League, has been selected as the referee for tomorrow's Amer ican Conference champion ship game.

title: Drake Is Upset, 6059
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 2 (AP) Cincinnati upset seventhrank ed Drake, 6059, tonight as they pressured the Bulldogs into numerous turnovers and held them well below their 88point agame average. The Bulldogs have now lost two straight after winning eight.

title: Television
description: CENTURIES ago, in 1950, when televi sion was young, there was a Chi cago program, Studs Place. My three colleagues were superb per formers. Studs Place was something of a small restaurant and tavern. Our heroes were bluecollars. Though an attempt at reality was made  the players created their own dialogue, and critics as well as audience accepted it as true to life  it was merely the stuff of dreams, sweet rather than dirk. We had imagined an Eden. It was a place of trust and worth and unforgivable innocence. Brecht would have roared. The Fall, after all, had oc curred some time ago.

title: Alan Zuckers Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Alan Zucker of Auburn dale, Queens, on Dec. 20 at the Flushing Hospital. The child has been named Douglas Alan. Mr. Zucker is a teacher in the New York City school system. His father, Robert Zucker, is Mayor of Roslyn Estates.

title: Honor to the Bride Like the Pigeon That Guards Its Grain Under The Clove Tree
description: Get the title under your belt and go on. There's no pigeon, no grain, no clove tree, but there is a brideafter a fash ion. And how she comes to be fashioned into a bride is but an other example of the fascinat ing ways of the mysterious East Morocco, that is.

title: Linda Sue Ulevitch Engaged to Be Wed
description: PEORIA, Ill., Jan. 2The engagement of Miss Linda Sue Ulevitch to Mark W. Ka rasick has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Ule vitch, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Rabbi and Mrs. Joseph Karasick of New York and Long Beach, L. I.

title: Khrushchev Remembers
description: First things first. This is Nikita S. Khrushchev speakingspeaking in voice that often is his familiar earthy self, flailing at Stalin (and paying off old party scores), again justifying his brashest, most dangerous maneuvers, preening himself over Eisenhower, Dulles, that sonofabitch Nixon, Mao (not a madman) and Malen kov, warm but a mite condescending on J.F.K. and R.F.K., tendentiously revising history to burnish his image and, finally, like a great Russian patriarch, calling upon his country men to create a new and better society, a freer more pleasant com munity of men under, of course, what he calls the banner of Marxism Leninism.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Ski Touring: Leisurely Pace, Starlit Views and Hot Mulled Wine
description: VAIL, Colo.With searchlights strapped to their foreheads, a group of 19 adults and children glided through powder snow to skitour mountain trails here one night last week shortly after the sun had set behind the Rockies.

title: Movies
description: GIMME SHELTER  the cinema verite account by Albert and David Maysles and Charlotte Zwerin of the Rolling Stones's 1969 Amer ican tour, which ended in the ghistly debacle of the Alta mont Free Festivalhas re cently been roughed up by some critics in much the way messengers used to be pun ished for bearing bad tidings. Admittedly a harrowing and depressing glimpse of the state of American rock cul ture, this film is, not inci dentally, a beautifully craft ed, remarkably mature work. of cinematic art, a fact that not even the inevitable and in this case highly applicable moral ambiguities of cinema verite (what effect does the presence of a camera have on the reality that passes before it?) can negate.

title: Dr. Wozniak to Wed Carol A. McNamara
description: PLANDOME, L. I., Jan. 2 Mr. and Mrs. William P. McNamara have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Ann McNamara, to Dr. Lawrence Francis Wozniak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wozniak of Whitestone, Queens.

title: Boeing's 70 (67) Model
description: LOS ANGELES  Don't buy that big 1970 model. You really don't need it. We'll sell you a 1967 job that looks almost as big, bet ter meets your needs and is a lot cheaper.

title: Japanese Wrestlers on Way
description: TOKYO, Jan. 2 (AP)A 29 member Japanese high school wrestling team left today for Seattle for a series of matches in the United States. The team is scheduled to meet U.S. teams in Seattle and other cities in Oregon and Colorado.

title: SUDAN RESTUDIES ECONOMIC POLICY
description: KHARTOUM, The Sudan Without actually renouncing any of its socialist aims, the revolutionary Government of Maj: Gen. Gaafar alNimeiry is quietly trying to restore confidence in the private eco nomic sector and persuade it that it has a place in the Sudan.

title: NU SAID TO SET UP BASE IN THAILAND
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 2 U Nu, the former Burmese Premier who is leading in surgent forces against the Gov ernment of Gen. Ne Win, is re ported to have based his Bur mese National Liberation Front headquartersat least tempo rarilyon the Thai side of the border about 310 miles north west of here.

title: Art
description: IF there was an interna tional conspiracy pro moting modern art in the early years of this cen tury, then 27 Rue de Fleurus was very close to the heart of it. It was there, in the large picturestudded studio room where Gertrude and Leo Stein regularly enter tained on Saturday evenings, that one could expect to meet the Parisian artists who had perpetrated the avant garde revolution: Picasso, Matisse, Braque, Derain, Picabia, De launay, Duchamp  even, on rare occasions, that furtive soul, the primitive painter Henri Rousseau.

title: Herbalist First by Nose
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 (AP) Herbalist beat Robin's Bug by a nose today in the $15,000 New Year's Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

title: A WESTERN GROUP AIDED PAKISTANIS
description: DACCA, PakistanAmid the chaos of the relief effort after the Nov. 12 cyclone in East Pakistan, one fairly smooth op eration stood outspontane ously organized by a group of Westerners living in Pakistan, together with their Pakistani friends.

title: Reader's Report
description: It wasn't one of those peri ods like the the Mauve Decade or the Era of Good Feeling, writes Jerome Weidman, that had to wait for a historian to come along years later and give it a name. Everybody in 1930 knew he was living through the Great Depression, all in upper case.

title: Track Writers to Hear Washington Director
description: The Track Writers Associ ation will hold its first lunch eon meeting of the winter at noon tomorrow at Mama Leone's.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  As Con gress was in the fitful throes of adjournment last week, Senator Hugh Scott, the Senate Republican leader, arose late one evening to observe that the situation reminded him of King Charles II of England, who on his deathbed said to those sur rounding him: Gentlemen, I am sorry to be such an unconscion ably long time dying.

title: Other Proposals for Park
description: The Temporary Study Commission on the future of the Adirondacks made a total of 181 recommendations in its report. In addition to those mentioned in the accompanying article, the following other significant proposals were made:

title: Miss Noreen E. Ross Is Planning Nuptials
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Jan. 2Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Noreen E. Ross, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. George. J. Ross, to Samuel G. Saunders Jr., Gon of Mr. and Mrs. S. Grant Saunders of Boca Raton, Fla., formerly of Montclair.

title: Malaysia Is Hockey Host
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Jan. 2 (AP)Hockey teams from Frankfurt, Cologne and South Australia will visit Ma laysia in 1971.

title: Movies
description: ACRIME without an instigator is the way Altamont was described by Ralph J. Gleason, the West Coast critic who made the most ex haustive study of the illfated Rolling Stones festival last December. Certainly, none of the participants including the Hell's Angels who rolled out from Oakland on their hogs to dig the sounds and drink the free beerintended that Mick Jagger's Christ mas and Chanukah rite for American youth should de generate into an orgy of vio lence and madness, leaving in its wake four dead, hundreds injured, thousands freaked out and the counterculture riven to its base.

title: Beauty and amenity in a human settlement and shelter
description: In 1967 a young and hitherto un known Canadian architect was cata pulted into international prominence by the remarkable building he had designed for Montreal's Expo 67. The name of the project was Habitat; the name of the designer was Moshe Safdie; and this is an autobiographical account of his experiences before, during and after that, for him, mo mentous event. It is a candid and informative record of how he con ceived this unusual building; of how he piloted it safely through an un imaginably hazardous sequence of administrative, financial and politi cal hazards; and of what he learned in the process about the problems of human settlement and shelter. In view of the battles he was compelled to fight, the friends lost and enemies made, it is also a surprisingly re laxed and good natured tale. Clearly Mr. Safdie  by his own account a strongwilled and opinionated young man  has emerged from this ex perience a wiser (though not a much

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  A law professor who used to work at the Securities and Ex change Commission has pro posed a reexamination of the American system for electing the directors of corporations. That system gives corporate shareholders one vote for each share of stock they own.

title: The cream of the cream
description: For half a century, devoted editors have made annual picks of the best short stories to appear in this country and pub lished them as the O. Henry Awards. The cream of those 50 collections has been skimmed off to fill this twovolume, 1,048page jumbo, providing us with the best best of the last generation or two. The 50 col lections contained 889 stories by 569 authors: The present collection contains 60 stories by 53 authors.

title: Pacers Top Colonels, 134132
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 2 (AP) The Indiana Pacers squan dered a 10point fourthquarter lead, then battled back with 2 minutes 4 seconds remaining tonight to defeat Kentucky, 134132.

title: Mrs. Jeanne Thompson Is Wed To John Blum, Brooklyn Banker
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., Jan. 2 Mrs. Jeanne Cotten Thomp son and John R. H. Blum, both of Brooklyn, were mar ried here this afternoon at the home of the bride's brother inlaw and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Jakob Isbrandtsen. The bride is a governor of the Brooklyn Museum, and the bridegroom is chairman of the Kings Lafayette Bank in Brooklyn and president of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.

title: Movies
description: FEB. 18, 1971. How time flies! It seems only yesterday that all the city's pornographic movie theaters were on Times Square. I suppose I should have foreseen disaster when they began spreading uptown to the 50's. But now the tide laps at my very doorstep. Today Zabar's delicatessen be came the Eros 80th Street. It features a free peep show with every pound of lean corned beef. Is nothing sacred?

title: Medallions to Math Winter Carnival
description: Sponsors of the Manches ter, N. H., Winter Carnival, scheduled for Feb. 13 through 21, again will issue silver and solid bronze me dallions to mark the event.

title: In Helen, Ga. We'll Do Backflips  to Get on the Map...
description: HELEN Ga.It seems hard to be lieve that it is only a couple of years now since that fateful noon??ne in january when Jim W??kins Bob Towler and Pete Hodkin son sat thoughtfully over their lunch in the Mountain Air Restaurant and gazed out the window at Helen's bleak main street Jim. Bob and Pete ex changed angaished books their minds working as onethe town was ?? ?? was painfully ordinary. A few cars were angled into the curbs between rows of onestory concreteblock buildings with tin roofs that gleamed coldly in the winter sunlight. A lone trash can sat abandoned on the empty sidewalk. Everything was blank, squat and boring. Somehow, to Pete, it all looked like Death Valley.

title: Elizabeth Tepe Becomes Bride
description: GREENVILLE, Del., Jan. 2 Miss Elizabeth Stratford Tepe was married here this afternoon to John Christo pher Meyer 3d. The Rev. John O'Hear performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred.

title: And a Terrific Tap Dancer
description: ME,I'm a terrific person, a great tap dancer, and of course I'm tremendously rich and don't have to act for a living. And that's about as serious as Mau reen Stapleton, who isn,t rich and can't tap dance, gets when you try to get serious about her genius; about the stun ning lightshow of emotion and of self satire she furnishes for any theater she plays, the extra baby spots she tarns on all by herself when she steps on stage.. Try analyzing her stupendous giftS and she just laughs, a phlegmy yet startlingly young noise, like a col leen with her first real Irish whisky hangover.

title: 2 Play Monopoly 62 Hours
description: WINNIPEG, Manitobia, Jan. 2 (Canadian Press)  Two 16 yearold Winnipeg boys, Doug Grantham and Gary Kosack, are claiming a world record for nonstop monopoly playing, after a 62hour session this week

title: S. Spencer Scott, ExPresident Of Harcourt, Brace, Dead at 78
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Jan. 2S. Spencer Scott, who retired in 1954 as president of Harcourt, Brace & Co., the book publishers, died here yes terday. He was 78 years old and lived at Quaker Center, Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Kentucky's personal income this year will be approxi mately $10.6billion, up about $615million from the esti mated $9.9billion in 1970, according to an economic fore cast of the University of Kentucky's Office of Devel opment Services and Busi ness Research.

title: The Ten Worst Films of 1970.
description: MYRA BRECKIN RIDGE was not. the worst movie of 1970 and, in fact, it doesn't even make my list of the 10 Worst Films of the Year. Not that Myra Breckinridge isn't awful (it is), but its awfulness is of such insignificance that to label it with any kind of superlative would give it a totally inappropriate impor tance.

title: Jacksonville Victor
description: ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Jan. 2 (UPI)Artis Gilmore tal lied 29 points tonight to pace eighthranked Jacksonville to a 10595 basketball victory over a surprisingly tough Virgin Islands team.

title: Jumpers Are Off and Flying for Opening of the Bear Mountain Season
Dance
description: WHY do film critics have all the fun? The old year has only the squalid indecency to. finishor almost finishbe fore my colleagues of the silver screen (are they still silver?) are racing up with their lists like bucolic infants exultant at a garden party and asked to prepare a list of their 10 favorite flowers. It is very healthy, and very traditional.

title: The Second Season
description: All season, Coach Bob Devaney of Nebraska had insisted his team was as good as any in the country. Devaney affirmed this think ing by voting Nebraska No. 1 each week as a member of a balloting board of college football coaches.

title: The World
description: CAIROAt a meeting with top Government and political lead ers last week, President Anwar elSadat said the coining six months would be decisive ones in the ArabIsraeli conflict. On February 5, he said, we shall be faced with our first major decision.

title: Despite Budget Problems, Sate and Local Aides Are Wary of RevenueSharing Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  President Nixon's proposal for sharing Federal revenues with state and local governments is meeting with considerable quiet skepticism and opposition among officials whose jurisdic tions would receive the money.

title: Policy Review by Kosygin Affirms ArmsPact Desire
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 2Premier Alelcsei N. Kosygin said today that the Soviet Union was seeking a reasonable agree ment with the United States on the limitation of strategic arms that would not give either side an advantage.

title: With No U.S. Fatalities in 70, Nation's Scheduled Airlines Set Safety Record.
description: The nation's scheduled air lines ended 1970 with their best accident record in history.

title: Drug Seizures by Customs Rose 100% Here and in Nation in 70
description: Seizures of narcotics and other drugs by the Bureau of Customs, both in the New York City area and nationally, in creased more than 100 per cent in 1970, according to Myles J. Ambrose, United States Com missioner of Customs.

title: Sadat Says He Is Ready For War if the Truce Ends
description: CAIRO, Jan. 2President Anwar elSadat declared today that the armed forces of the United Arab Republic were ready for an allout battle against Israel after the Suez Canal ceasefire expires on Feb. 5.

title: Reagan Installs TV Guard
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP)As part of their increased security, the state police have installed 16 television cameras in the state Capitol to scan six fleers of corridors, Gov. Ronald Reagan's office and the base ment. The picture's are fed through a closedcircuit system to a bank of screens in the Capitol state police office so they can be monitored by one man. State Police Chief Guy Cates said videotape machines there can preserve events for use as courtroom evidence.

title: Mauritania Allows Hunting
description: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania, Jan. 2 (Apnea FrancePresse) Mauritania, today lifted her fiveyear ban on game hunting.

title: Reader's Report
description: It seemed to Moorman that he had spent so much of his life in company with unattractive old people. And with unattrac tive young people as well. With Mona Lisa di Valvona, his land lady's monstrous daughter, not to mention his monstrous land lady herself. With Meatball, a teenage vandal, with Miss Toye, a strange, wild old junk and vegetable dealer. And most of all with Mothera fish andchips merchant whose fur jacket smells of deep frying. Mr. Norman, a writer for The London Sunday Times, de scribes with misanthropic relish his hero's affinity for human gargoyles and his fumbling at tempts at human relationships.

title: Dr. LoewyLabalme, Surgeon And Cancer Researcher, Dies

description: ANCHORAGE, Jan. 2 (UPI) In Alaska the main litter prob lem is not empty beer cans but discarded oil drums.

title: The Nation
description: Along with that dismal piece of annual postChristmas mail, the Federal Income Tax form, the American taxpayer this holi day season got some good news a cut in his 1971 Federal in come taxes. The cut is the result of a law passed more than a year ago, the Tax Reform Act of. 1969, that reduced taxes for in dividuals by a total of more than $9billion. The cuts were stretched out over several years with the 1971 reduction, which took effect on Jan. 1, the largest of all: $3.5billion.

title: Wintertime Landscapes
description: ATHOUGH gardens are often thought of as strictly, growing season projects, the first snow of winter exposes their design flaws and virtues. Snow bares a land scape's bones.

title: Law
description: Fathers and daughters. Lovely when the daughter is 5 and cute, and daddy can take her to the Plaza Ho tel's Palm Court for tea; not so lovely, perhaps, when the daughter is older (and maybe cuter) and goes to the Plaza with someone else. Or marches on the Pentagon. Or grows her hair down to her waist. Or, as two New York fathers found out last week, simply decides on a life of her own.

title: One Last Puff
description: The scheduled showing of a movie, Crack in the Mirror on WABCTV early today was interrupted by a decidedly un scheduled commercial, a 30sec ond spot advertising Vantage cigarettes. A spokesman for the network said It was human error that put the videotaped commercial on screens in the New York viewing area at 12:40 A.M.just 24 hours and 40 minutes after all cigarette com mercials were, by Federal law, to have vanished from the tele vision screen foreveer.

title: NEW BRITISH PRISON HAS PINUP FACILITIES
description: LONDON, Jan. 2 (UPI)If an inmate of Britain's newest prison wants to tack pinups on the wall of his centrally heated cell he will find a bul letin board there for the pur pose.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  When President Nixon vetoed the campaign finance regulations that Congress passed last fall, he said it was not because he was against the idea but because the specific measure be fore him was too narrowly aimed and tended to favor incumbents. When the veto was sustained, many members of Congress gave the same reasons. Some thing like a moral obligation, there fore, lies upon both Mr. Nixon and the next Congress to take action in this important field.

title: Joan Mary Marchi Bride in Italy

title: Inside story
description: One secret of successful renovating is the ability to look not at the wreck the interior may be at the moment, but beyond. When Karl Springer a designer, came across this old Victorian house on Long Island, he knew from the instant he saw it that it could be turned into his ideal year retreat. Ali it needed: new walls, new ceilings, new floors, new balusters, new plumbing, new heating andoh, yes a larger kitchen. And that's what it got. The out side was left unchanged  except for closing in the front porch. Thus it gives no clue to the airy look Spzinger achieved inside.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: The Literary Vision of Liam O Flaherty
description: Liam O'Flaherty is to be seen quite frequently in the area of Dublin City between Baggot Street Bridge and Trinity College: a handsome wellbuilt man in his seventies with the clear hard eyes of an Man islander, eyes that still keep the reflection of the ocean that encircled his boyhood. His own way of putting it once was: I was born on a stormswept rock and hate the soft growth of sun baked lands where there is no frost in men's bones. Swift thought and the swift flight of ravenous birds, and the squeal of terror of hunted ani mals are to me reality. I have seen the leaping salmon fly before the salmon whale, and I have seen the sated buck horn his mate, and the wanderer leave his wife in search of fresh bosoms with the fire of joy in his eyes.

title: Sea Gulls to Inherit Kezar Stadium
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2Kezar Sta dium, the site of tomorrow's 49erDallas Cowboy game for the National Conference championship, had a reprieve. When the 49ers defeated Atlanta at Kezar last Dec. 6, it was their scheduled last game at an outdated and universally deplored facility famous to the nation's television audience as a home for sea gulls.

title: . . .But in Scotland Neck, Leave Us in Peace
description: SCOTLAND NECK, N. C.When the swallows come back to Capistrano, people write romantic songs. But when 12 million grackles, starlings, cowbirds and redwing blackbirds de scend every fall on the rookery here in Scotland Neck, in eastern North Carolina, and the whirr of wings makes an eerie, frightening roar throughout the winter, the townspeople write angry letters and cook up fiendish plans to get rid of them.

title: The World
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Program for moving India along the socialist path to progress has been running out of steam in re cent years at about the same rate as the Congress party, the dominant force of Jawaharlal Nehru's India, has been losing power to extremist elements of both left and right. Caught be tween the Communists and other leftist parties on whose support she depends and the rightists who are united only in opposition to her, Mrs. Gandhi has had to maneuver skillfully just to stay in office. Meanwhile, booming population growth has been push ing India economically and so ciaily downhill.

title: Movies
description: WHERE there's life, there's Hope. And sometimes Crosby, too. Bob and Bing, that is. The two veterans of the road are all but set to costar with Jackie Gleason in The Bride Wore Blink ers. Hope and Gleason will play a couple of Florida con men who smuggle a race horse into Ireland for the purpose of breeding her on a famous stud farm. The plan is for Crosby to play an Irish priestbut not Father O'Malleyand for John Wayne, to do a cameo as the owner of the stud farm. The picture will be produced by Naho Productions, a Bob HopeNBC combine.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: A little more than rain drops have fallen on the chil dren's apparel industry and forced many manufacturers to take cover. This was evi dent in recent weeks with announcements of the liqui dation of two prominent chil dren's wear companies. One was Alyssa Originals, Inc., which for a decade or more has held a leading position in children's dresses. The other was the 15yearold Young Sophisticates, Inc., making children's sportswear.

title: Woman: A Net as Big as the Sea
description: WOMAN is an imagi nary being, a fab ulous animal kin to the manticore, the hippogriff, the antlion. Woman does not exist. What exists in the space woman would occupy, if she existed, is a concatenation of ideas about women. Throughout history men and women have attempted to zoo the animal. Imagine an immense net, woven of paintings, epigrams, laws, courtesies, lies, clothing, Polaroids, aggression, desire, and dreams. Imagine a net as big as a sea, stretching from the Advanced Palaeolithic to the present time. Imagine hu man beings standing along the circumference of the net, doing their best to support it the mighty effort, the co lossal straining. Yet the ani mal escapes. And a strange thing happens. The net be comes the animal.

title: For Young Readers
description: A restless, often disoriented guest at the American literary table, the Spanish  speaking child has been poorly served by books that offer him, only those cues necessary for assim ilation. Although the vivid di mensions of Latin culture and the conflicts of immigrant life offer splendid opportunities for creative fiction, until recently, few books were available to authenticateor even describe the world of the barrio as its younger residents experience it. The impact of a minority group market on publisher's sensibili ties can best be judged by the recent appearance of a handful of fictionalized histories em phasizing Spanish  American history, and several novels and picture books about Latin American families. Designed to proselytize, flawed by an ex cess of missionary fervor, the history tends to be mechanical. The fiction is more often duti ful than dramatic.

title: Art
description: UNDER the slightly misleading title of Two Cultures, the well known English painter and critic Patrick Heron has just published in the December number of the Lon don art magazine Studio International a virtual declaration of war on Ameri can art and on American domination of the British art scene. The Two Cul tures, in this case, are the New York and London art establishments, and it is Mr. Heron's contention that the latter has thoroughly sold out to the blandish ments of the former. Going further, he suggests that certain highly vaunted ac complishments of recent American art actually owe their origin to British ar tists. He is ferociously critical of some of the younger reputations in American artFrank Stella and Donald Judd are especially singled out for demolition and he is openly bitter about the way British critics, particularly the younger critics, have joined the American band wagon, denigrating British accomplish ments in the process. He dismisses much of the American art that commands such steadfast allegiance among his com patriots as a new Americanpromoted international academicism.

Bernstein, regional director of the De partment of Health, Education and Welfare, announced yes terday. Mr. Welsh was named special assistant for the Fed eral Regional Council, which is composed of the regional heads of several Federal agencies.

title: The World
description: In interviews in Jerusalem and Cairo last week with James Reston of The New York Times, Premier Golda Meir and President Anwar elSadat gave their views on the pospects for peace on the eve of the next possible round of negotiations. The following are excerpts from the interviews.

title: Sudden Deaths to Settle Ties
description: The American Conference and National Conference foot ball championship games will be played with sudden death in effect if the teams are tied after 60 minutes of regulation time.

title: An Appraisal
description: The corporate graveyards of Detroit are filled with the reputations of onromeand fin executives who insisted American motorists would never buy a small and simple car. They disdained all the arguments about lower pur chase price, cheaper mainte ity and easier parking. Now that foreignbuilt oars have reached 13. per cent of the sales in this coun try, the General Motors Cor poration and the Ford Motor Companya have Motor begun to compete with the small Im ports on their own turfsize and, to a lesser extent, price.

title: Snow
description: One needn't be fanatical about it, but the fact persists that snow is beautiful. There is nothing in nature more simply graceful than the curve of a snowdrift, and the lip of a drift beside a country brook can be one of the most pleasing of all plastic shapes. But the ultimate beauty is in the snowflake itself.

title: Cambodian Armor on Move
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 2 (AP)An armored Cambodian column was reported to have swept past light resistance to day and headed south to the Elephant Mountains, where enemy forces are blocking Highway 4.

title: NEW POLICY URGED FOR ADIRONDACKS
description: Governor Rockefeller yester day released a twoyear study of the Adirondacks that calls for creation of an independent agency with power to regulate the use and development of all land, public and private, in the six  million  acre Adirondack State Park.

title: M. G. Himoff to Wed Susan H. Mathews.
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 2  Mr. and Mrs. Irving Mathews have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Susan Henri Mathews, to Michael G. Himoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Townsend Himoff of White Plains.

title: Two German Soccer Stars Scolded in Lima for Conceit
description: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 2 (AP) Two stars of West Germany's touring Bayern Munchen soccer team were accused today by Lima newspapers of displaying conceit and poor manners.

title: St. Louis lops Dartmouth
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 2 (UPI) Jim Irving scored 16 of his 23 points in the first half to help St. Louis build a 16point lead en route to a 9175 victory over Dartmouth tonight.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 2 (AP) Rutgers beat Pitt., 9787, today. Steve Kaplan led Rutgers with 37 points, scoring 13 of 13 from the foul line.

title: JAPANESE TO PRESS THALIDOMIDE CASE
description: TOKYO, Jan. 2Plaintiffs in Japan's thalidomide babies case have decided to continue seeking a legal verdict against the Government and two phar maceutical companies, despite the recent termination of court proceedings in West Germany.

description: Nat'l Hockey League
