Leslie Blake Is Affianced
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 2 Norman P. Blake, a senior vice president of Pan Ameri can World Airways, and Mrs. Blake have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Leslie Eleanor Blake, to Peter William Fuss, a petty officer 3d class aboard the Coast Guard cutter Sage brush in San Juan, P.R. He is the son of Mrs. Norman G. Gans of Greenwich.

title: Dutch Win in Volleyball
description: VEENENDAAL, the Nether lands, Jan. 2 (AP)The Nether lands women's volleyball team defeated Israel, 30 (1513, 159, 1316) here tonight.

title: The Nation
description: What began on a small scale in the Depression Thirties has become a monster . . . it is bringing states and cities to the brink of financial disaster... it is failing to meet the elemen tary human, social and finan cial needs of the poor. It breaks up homes. It often penalizes work. It robs recipients of dig nity. And it grows.

title: Kentucky Triumphs, 10395
description: OXFORD, Miss., Jan. 2 (UPI)  Johnny Neumann, the na tion's leading scorer, dropped in 46 points tonight in a losing cause as Kentucky defeated Mississippi, 10395.

title: Taiwan to Export Bananas
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan.2 (AP) Taiwan Will export nearly 26.7 million cases of bananas to Japan during the first seven months of 1971, the Taiwan Fresh Fruit Association has announced.

title: At Last, Investor Insurance
description: The long and brutal stock market slump and the wreck age it scattered along Wall Street finally have given birth to something good  Federal legislation to insure investors for the first time in history against losses in case of brokeragehouse fail ures.

title: The Contentious 91st
description: Anger, crosspurposes and diffuse leadership charac terized the closing weeks of the 91st Congress as they had for most of its twoyear life. A deeply divided and warweary nation has found its conflicts mirrored in its national legislature. Under the circumstances, what is surprising is not that there has been discord but that, notwithstanding it, so much has been accomplished.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Florida State Signs Jones
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 2 (UPI)Larry B. Jones, 37 years old, first assistant coach of Ten nessee, today was named head football coach at Florida State University. Jones succeeds Bill Peterson, who left to become athletic director and head coach at Rice.

title: TATE'S 251 JUMP SETS MEET MARK
description: Norm Tate of the New York Pioneer Club gave himself a birthday present yesterday as he won the Metropolitan Senior Amateur Athletic Union long jump title at the Columbia Uni versity Airdrome.

title: New England Governors Urge Improved Rail Travel Service
description: BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP)The New England Regional Com mission has submitted recom mendations for rail passenger service in New England that include 14 round trips a day between Boston and New York.

title: Roller Derby Tickets Go on Sale Tomorrow
description: Tickets will go on sale tomorrow at 10 A.M. at the Madison Square Garden Cen ter box office for the return of the roller derby to the Garden, Jan. 31, at 1:05 P.M.

title: TransAtlantic Chill
description: BRUSSELSThis city, the Common Market capital, is a little like Washington, a city of perpetual diplomatic re ceptions and intimate dinner parties where it is almost impossible to keep a secret.

title: West Germany's Boom Leaves Its Hospitals Short of Nurses
description: BONN, Dec. 21West Ger many's wave of prosperity has left its hospitals short of staff. Nurses are called on to bear the brunt of the shortages, and now there are even too few nurses.

title: The Porn Capital Of America
description: SAN FRANCISCO. EVRYTHING'S up to date in San Francisco these days, which means, according to some, that they've gone about as far as they can go. Too far for Dianne Feinstein, the attractive brunette who happens to be presi dent of the city's Board of Super visors. Mrs. Feinstein and a party of concerned citizens recently made an educational tour of the town's booming pornographic establish ments, or porn shops, as they're more familiarly known to thousands of contented patrons. What they found appalled them. Appalling is a modest term, wrote one, colum nist Merla Z. Goerner, on the so ciety page of the daily Chronicle. What we found was total degrada tion of the human spirit, a terrifying look into the darkest recesses of the sick mind. Mrs. Feinstein herself gave an interview to the press in which she pointed out, while calling for legislative curbs, that the porno graphic movie industry has spread so drastically in San Francisco that we have become a kind of smut capital of the United States.

title: Mary Webster Plans Marriage In Spring to William Levit Jr.
description: Miss Mary Elizabeth Web ster of New York will be married in the spring to Wil liam H. Levit Jr., who is a lawyer with the New York firm of Davis, Polk & Ward well. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mrs. Ferdi nand Hinrichs and Kenneth Fletcher Webster, both of Milwaukee.

title: El Al  The world's Toughest Airline
description: ISRAEL'S El Al Airlines likes to think of itself as a little different. It's Jewish, after all, and Jews have traditionally thought of themselves as . . . well, a little different from others. Its planesand there are only 10 in its whole fleet cross the Atlantic loaded with more passengers per plane, on the average, than any other airline. Perhaps most important, El Al is more conscious than any other airline of its physical securityand will surely continue to keep up its guard, even though most of the nations of the world recently moved into agreement that aircraft hijacking ought to be a crime subject to severe punishment.

title: At This London Store, Some U.S. KnowHow
description: LONDONAt last. A place to get creamy peanut butter and jelly sandwich here. And cold beer, kingsize fitted sheets, extension cords and a variety of other products Americans cherish.

title: Nixon Signs Bill to Give $20Million to the U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) President Nixon has signed legislation authorizing up to $20million for part of the cost of expanding and improving the United Nations headquar ters in New York.

title: Students Questioning Role and Cost of College Athletics
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2  In growing numbers, college stu dents are complaining that the money spent supporting and promoting bigtime collegiate athletics could be better spent elsewhere, and their complaints seem to be having some effect.

title: Outlook for Glass
description: A 25percent rise in flat glass usage per car is sched uled by car manufacturers over the next two years.

title: A Noose Hangs Loose In Colts'
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 2  The noose hangs low in the Colts' locker room. The noose is made out of white adhesive tape and it dangles near Ray May's locker.

title: Jordan Assures Palestinians
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 2 Jordan reemphasized her ac ceptance of a peaceful settle ment in the Middle East today with an assurance to the Palestinians that an accord would not infringe on their basic rights.

title: On Concert Stage, a Pianist (I'm a Working Man) in Jumpsuit?
description: Just before his recent debut here as a pianist, 19yearold Jeremy Menuhin, Yehudi's son, said that he dreaded, even resented, having to get into that absurd waiter's suit, meaning the con ventional white tie and tails.

title: The Nation
description: Money is the name of the ur ban game in 1971. Only it really isn't a game. It's a warwith mayors, governors and the Fed eral Government fighting over the same taxpayer. A dramatic skirmish in that war was fought last week here in New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. WILL HOLD UP KOREAN PULLOUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2Pres ident Nixon has directed the Defense Department to delay Indefinitely plans for troop withdrawals from South Korea beyond the 20,000 men sched uled to be, removed by June, according to Administration sources.

title: Maple Leafs Crush Red Wings, 130, Getting Seven Goals in Third Period
News of the Rialto
description: ON Jan. 14 and 15, Dame Judith Anderson, one of the great talents of the Englishspeaking theater, will be at Carnegie Hall playing the title role of Hamlet. But hold on, girls, no need to go running over the landscape in praite of Women's Liberation. As Dame Judith herself would be quick to tell you, this is no major breakthrough. She's not the first and surely not the last of her sex to essay the Dane.

title: Divorces Off in Nevada
description: CARSON CITY, Nev. Jan. 2 (UPI)Divorces in Nevada dur ing the first 11 months of 1970 dropped more than 15 per cent, apparently because of a new liberalized law in California. The State Health Division re ported that preliminary figures showed that 7,998 divorces or annulments were granted last year through November, com pared to 9,474 for the same period in 1969.

title: TAIWAN SHELVES NEWCITY PROJECT
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 2 Urban planning in Taipei has been set back five to 10 years, in the opinion of foreign ex perts, is a result of the gov ernment's decision this month to shelve plans for a satellite city of 450,000 people on the Linkow Plateau west of Taipei.

title: PROTHRO IS SIGNED AS COACH OF RAMS
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2The Los Angeles Rams announced today the selection of Tommy Prothro as head coach to re place George Allen.

title: Peace Corps Volunteer Ends 6Year Stay in Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) Barkley Moore thinks that it is important to love people, and as a Peace Corps member he demonstrated that belief by staying at his overseas post longer than any of the other 37,000 volunteers.

title: News of Dogs
description: There's something special about the American Spaniel Club's 54th national specialty next Saturday and Sunday. Last year's bestinshow win ner, Ch. BeGay's Tan Man, will be back to defend his laurels at the Staler Hilton Hotel. However, Ch. Ancram's Simon, the 1969 top per former, will be there, too striving to regain the title. Tan Man, a tri colored American cocker spaniel, is a homebred and is shown by Bill Ernst, of New Milford, Conn., who coowns him with his wife, Gay (hence the BeGay kennel name).

title: DR. FRANCIS DI GIORGI
description: Dr. Francis Di Giorgi, former chief of oral surgery at Colum bus Hospital, died Friday in Lin coln Hospital after a long ill ness. He was 47 years old and lived at 35 Forest Circle, New Rochelle, N. Y.

title: Gallup Survey Finds Americans Pessimistic About Jobs Outlook
Unbeaten Marquette Tops Detroit by 7061 for No. 9
description: DETROIT, Jan. 2 (AP)Un beaten Marquette University broke an 1111 tie in the second period and went on to a 7061 triumph over the University of Detroit tonight. The victory was Marquette's ninth of the season.

title: Miss Cindy Williams Is Fiancee Of 2d Lieut. Atwood Collins 3d
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 2  Judge Alexander Harvey 2d of the United States District Court in Maryland and Mrs. Harvey have announced the engagement of Mrs. Harvey's daughter, Miss Cynthia Mal lory Williams, to Second Lieut. Atwood Collins 3d, who is serving with the Army at Fort Hood, Tex. He is the son of Mr. Collins 2d of West Hartford, Conn., and Mrs. Burton G. Tremaine of Hartford.

title: War in Cesar Chavez country
description: It is said that Ann Fair bairn's previous novel of a Louisianaborn black man who made good up North, Five Smooth Stones, has sold more than two million copies in all editions, and obviously this one is meant to achieve the same kind of popular success. It has several things going for it. The key situation is interesting and topical. The characters are colorful. And, for those read ers who want to lose them selves, there is plenty of ter ritory to escape in . . . some thing like 400,000 words.

title: Millrose Games Tickets Go On Sale Tuesday
description: The Millrose Athletic Asso ciation, whose 64th annual Wanamaker Millrose Games open the Madison Square Garden indoor track season on Friday, Jan. 29, will set up temporary headquarters for the month of January in Room 1508 at the Hotel. New Yorker.

title: Businessmen Against the War
description: With many segments of the antiwar movement from stu dents to clergy, the Business Executives Move for Viet nam Peace seemed to have dropped out of sight.

title: McCormack Enjoyed Every Second
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2It's time, Mr. Speaker.

title: St. Francis Beats Siena As Rowinski Stars, 6965
description: John Rowinski scored 19 points to lead St. Francis to a 69.65 victory over Siena Col lege last night at the 69th Regiment Armory. At the half the victors were in front, 3836.

title: VERNON G. KNEESKERN
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 2 (AP) Vernon G. Kneeskern, a vice president and director of Rey nods Metals Company, died to day of a heart attack at his home. He was 62 years old.

title: In Brief
description: I'll be damned, wrote Thomas Wolfe to F. Scott Fitz gerald, if I'll believe anyone lives in a place called The Gar den of Allah. It was 1937, and Fitzgerald was living out his dying, at $300 a month, in a Hollywood hotel really called The Garden of Allah. Now Shei lah (Beloved Infidel) Graham has written a book about The Garden, which in its heyday supplied enough starstudded and, for that matter, studstar ring gossip to fuel many a newspaper column, her own in cluded.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: WALTER M. JENSEN Sr.
description: Walter M. Jensen Sr., for 27 years an account executive with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., member, of the New York Stock Exchange died yesterday in Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, L.I

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: LEADING ECONOMIC INDICATORS rose in November for first time since July; rise previously reported for October was revised to small decline. Trade balance narrowed in November. . . . Conference Board panel of economists predicted 1971 gross national product would rise 7 per cent to $1.05trillion. Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development predicted a 4 per cent rise. O.E.C.D. also criticized expansionary trend in Britain.

title: chrysler Plans Warehouse
description: WESTBORO, Mass., Jan. 2 (AP)The Chrysler Corporation will build a $2.5million ware house here, it was announced today by the Middlesex Realty Company of Marlboro.

title: Burglar Trapped 45 Minutes Escapes When Police Fail to Respond to 911 Calls
description: A 25yearold Bellevue regis tered nurse, her boyfriend and her mother held a burglar at bay in their East Village apart ment house ror nearly an hour Friday night while frantically telephoning the police three times.

title: Richard Hanley, an Aide Of the Burtons, Dies at 61
description: Richard Hanley, who retired as chief executive assistant for Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor and their production companies last spring, died Friday of a heart attack in Palm Springs, Calif., where he had moved. His age was 61.

title: Canadiens Top Seals, 53
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 2 (UPI) Pete Mahovlich tallied his 15th goal of the season as the Mon treal Canadiens got four goals in the second period tonight and went on to defeat the Cali fornia Seals, 53, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: CITY HELD STALLING ON EVICTION REFORM
description: Two City Councilmen of Manhattan charged yesterday that city housing officials and Mayor Lindsay's office had been stalling on promised new eviction regulations while hold ing secret negotiations with the building industry that would result in tens of thou sands of tenant evictions.

title: Science
description: CHICAGO  In 1848, when Philadelphia was little changed from Colonial days and the country lookea to science for aid in its expan sion and industrialization, a small group of men met in that city to found the Amer ican Association for the Ad vancement of Science. Last week the association held its annual meeting here in the heart of a giant, modern city, facing a very different array of challenges  not least of them, an explosive divergence of opinion within its own ranks and a grow ing public disaffection with science Itself.

title: Variations on Urban Mass Transit Aid Growing Number in Suburbia
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 Slowly end almost unnoticed, a primitive new form of urban mass transportation is develop ing where there is little mass, in the ballooning suburban reaches of metropolitan Amer ica.

title: Britain Encounters Problems in Forming a Professional Army
description: LONDON, Dec. 27Britain's intense but largely unsuccess ful efforts to recruit soldiers, sailors and airmen for long pro fessional service indicate that higher pay and better condi tions do not alone suffice to make the military more attrac tive than civilian employment.

title: Brownsville Girl Abducted at Gunpoint
description: A 14yearold girl was appar ently kidnapped at gunpoint from a Brownsville grocery store yesterday afternoon While several patrons and clerks looked on, not realizing what had happened.

title: SNOWSTORM COST NEARLY $1MILLION
description: It came close to a $1million bill  $619,466 for overtime, and $323,344 for rock salt but the New Year's Day snow of up to eight inches was rap idly cleared from most or the city's streets with good feeling exuding by and for the Sani tation Department yesterday.

title: Japanese Hail Emperor
description: TOKYO, Jan, 2 (UPI)Em peror Hirohito stood behind bulletproof glass today to re ceive cheers of Banzai from thousands of Japanese and for eigners celebrating Japan's big gest holiday. The shield was erected after a worker fired a steel ball from a slingshot in the direction of the Emperor in 1969.

title: Clarkson Sextet Wins
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 2 Clarkson's hockey team rallied from a threegoal deficit tonight to defeat Princeton, 6.4, for its 11th victory in 13 games. Princeton is without a triumph in nine games.

title: When money's no object
description: Saffron may be the most expensive spice in the world. And understandably. It is the dried stigmas of the flowering crocus and it takes more than 200,000 stigmas handpicked  to make a pound. The spice comes in whole stem form and in powder. It is generally quite pungent a little goes a long wayand gives foods (rice, for instance) a magnificent golden color. A tablespoonful is called for in the recipes on this page, but the amount may be varied according to conscience and pocketbook: It could be omitted altogether, but then, of course, it would scarcely be saffron beef. Saffron is usually available wherever fine spices are sold.

title: WORLD LIBERTIES IN 70 SURVEYED
description: The progress of freedom fared badly in general throughout the world in 1970, according to the annual survey on the subject prepared by Freedom House.

title: Mummers, a Day Late, Parade in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 (AP) Philadelphia's Mummers rang in the New Year today with a highstrutting, banjo ringing parade that was de layed a day by a heavy snowfall.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: Philip L Berman, who is in many ways hard to believe, has come up with what he considers to be a highly be lievable business concept: People in business need a challenge. Expansion gives it to them and challenge, in turn, creates further expan sion. It's a circle that need never end as long as people respond to challenge.

title: Ballet Theater Gives Debut of Smuin Work
description: The real trouble with Michael Smuin's Schubert iade, which was given its world premiere by the Amer ican Ballet Theater at the City Center on Friday night, is that it suggests compari sons that are never in 13 favor. It is certainly not a bad balletindeed, in places it is rather a good onebut we have seen better of the same style.

title: Mrs. Joseph Has Child
description: FLEMINGTON, N. J., Jan. 2  A daughter was born here to Dr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Joseph on Dec. 17.

title: Facts on N.F.C. Game
description: Title at StakeNational Foot ball Conference championship and Super Bowl berth.

title: Sports of The Times
description: There is a bridge in the San Francisco Bay Area connecting San Francisco with Oakland, but it does not serve to bring the two cities together. In their supercilious way, San Franciscans regard it as an escape route for those unfortunates on the wrong side, meaning the Oakland side. The Oaklanders merely sneer at the snobs from Nob Hill and environs.

title: Designer Produces an Outboard Motor Boat That Flies
description: If the opening boat shows of 1971 are any criteria, you may have to look up to discover the latest trends in naytical ac complishment.

title: RHODESIA OFFERING FARMS TO SETTLERS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 2 (Agence FrancePresse)The Rhodesian Government is offer ing 38 newly developed farms to European settlers between the ages of 25 and 45.

title: The Nation
description: WOOTON, Ky.The workers at the Finley Brothers Coal Mine do not expect their wives and their mothers to visit them on the jobwitness the display of pinups on the door of the work shack. When coal women do visit a mine, it is for the worst of reasons, as it was here last Wednesday when they trudged down the muddy road after an explosion in Mines 15 and 16. All 38 miners in the two shafts at the time of the blast were killed instantly.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 2 (AP)  Cornell won its 46th consecu tive hockey game at home to day, defeating Guelph, Ont., 72.

title: 24 Athletes to Receive Citations From Benrus
description: Outstanding athletes and other celebrities will be honored in the second annual Benrus Citation Awards for the best time of the year in their cate gories. This year, the 24 awards will be presented by George Plimpton, Yvette Mimieux, Alan King, Jack Dempsey and Jack Valenti at Toots Shor's on Jan. 14.

title: COAST RACE WON BY JUNGLE SAVAGE
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 2 (UPI)Jungle Savage, trained by Johnny Longden, made a powerful run in the stretch to day to score a 3length vic tory over heavily favored Ack Ack in the 19th running of the $32,850 Palos Verdes Handicap at Santa Anita.

title: Issues in City's Pay Talks
description: Following are the parties and issues in the city's current negotiations with its uniformed services:

title: Celtics Down 76ers, 125120, and Take Over 2d Place in Atlantic Division
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 (UPI) Dave Cowens, John Havlicek and Don Chaney combined for 80 points tonight to lead the Boston Celtics to a 125120 vic tory over the Philadelphia 76ers in a National Basketball Asso ciation game.

title: A cocktail party for Consciousness III
description: In his preface to this anthology of vibrations, this consciousness tank, this Federalist Papers of The Move ment, Mitchell Goodman, novelist, troublemaker, truthseeker and as sembler of these telephonebook thick proceedings, remarks that his catalogue is made up of two ele ments: 1) the body of the cumu lative experience [of The Movement], and 2) reflections and speculations on that experience.

title: MRS. T. M. BERNSTEIN, EDITOR'S WIFE, DIES
description: Mrs. Beatrice Alexander Bern stein, wife of Theodore M. Bernstein, editorial director of The New York Times book di vision, died at University Hos pital Friday after an illness of several weeks. She was 63 years old and lived at 2 Fifth Avenue.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe big po litical story of 1970 was that Richard Nixonwhom all the pundits had called the consum mate politician  was proven exceedingly vulnerable . . . . The Nixon Administration lacks initiative, it lacks imagination, it lacks compassion for human needs. It has established no rap port, no communication, with the people. It has given the na tion no clear vision of a direc tion for the future.LAWRENCE F. O'BRIEN, Democratic National Chairman, Dec. 27, 1970.

title: WILLIAM J. FELLOWS
description: NORWALK, Conn., 3an. 2 William Francis Fellows per sonnel manager for General Foods Corporation, in White Plains, died Thursday at Yale New. Haven Medical Center. He was 56 years old and lived at 33 Douglas Drive here.

title: No Conclusions on Blast
description: WOOTEN, Ky., Jan. 2After five and a half hours in the Finley Brothers Coal Company mine, Federal and state inves tigators emerged today to say they had made no conclusions about the explosion that killed 38 men here last Wednesday.

title: Kathleen Koob Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry F. Koob of New York have an nounced the engagement of Mr. Koob's daughter, Miss Kathleen E. Koob, to An drew P. Wittenborn, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Witten born of Scarsdale, N. N. An April wedding is planned. Miss Koob teaches high school social studies in Briar cliff Manor, N. Y. Her fiance works for his family's firm. Wittenborn & Co., in New York, dealers in books on fine arts.

title: Encounter Groupers Up Against the Wall
description: jULIA B. was 32 years old, at tractive, unmarried, and had recently ended a lengthy and un satisfying affair. She was lonely and becoming more and more depressed about her social life. Since her de pressions were recurrent, Julia thought she needed some kind of therapy, though she didn't know what kind. She shared her concern with her few friends, even telling them that she'd thought of suicide. One friend told her about encounter groups run in New York City by one of the founders of the Synanon method of group confrontation.

title: GUEVARA BREAKS SHOTPUT RECORD
description: Rudy Guevara of Essex Cath olic, overshadowed by Steve Adams of St. Joseph's of Mont vale, N. J., last year in the shot put, showed again yesterday that he might make schoolboy track and field fans forget Adams, now a freshman at Michigan.

title: Facts on A.F.C. Game
description: Title at StakeAmerican Foot ball Conference championship and Super Bowl berth.

title: On the Calendar
description: JANUARY courses have been announced by the New York Botanical Garden. A threeSatur day course opens this week on Identifying Trees and Shrubs in Winter. Miss Elea nor Yarrow, the instructor, will meet her classes from 10:30 A.M. to 12 noon. Regis tration fee is $12.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Elite Snow Force Tackles Hunts Point
description: The city's snow emergency force churned through the Hunts Point Market in the Bronx yesterday, clearing the vast fooddistribution point for the beginning of the week's business today.

title: Italian Court Voids Law On IllegitimateChild Heir
description: ROME, Jan. 2 (AP)The Italian Supreme Court has de clared unconstitutional a law limiting an illegitimate child's Inheritance.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  The nation's economy has been through the worst of both worlds  com bined recession and inflation  in 1970, said Paul McCracken, the President's chief economic adviser, the other day. In 1971, he added, there is good reason to hope for the best of both worlds.

title: Ohio Dominican Tops Calvin
description: HOLLAND, Mich, Jan. 2 (AP) Ohio Dominican beat Calvin, 7775, tonight. Ken Richardson of Ohio was the high scorer with 24 points.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON; Jan. 2For the last few Weeks, the Nixon Administration has been getting together its second State of. the World Message, and its conclusion seems to be that things are a little better at the beginning of 1971 than they were a year ago. Here, at least, is the way Secretary of State Rogers sees it:

title: Gift for Teacher Is a Donation By Class to the Neediest Cases
description: Nobody in Florence Lane's class at Public School 232 in Queens gave his teacher a present this Christmas. In stead the sixthgraders gave $22.25 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Headliners
description: After 22 years in Congress and a meteoric flight across the political skies in 1968. Former economics professor Eugene J. McCarthy, 54, retired from the Senate last week .to work from outside for reforms of Congress and the political parties. Characteristically cryptic as to whether his reform plans might include running for President in 1972 or forming a new party, the Minnesota Democrat said there were three issues that could motivate me to action: the Vietnam war, the militarization of American life, and the handling of the economy. His fellow Senators, who did not always enjoy his caustic wit, were generous in their praise on his departure. He's a fine man, said Senator John Stennis of Mississippi, no political ally, and I hope he has a further contribution to make to American life.

title: Why Did the Lady Kill Her Cousin?
description: ONE of the damnable things about the theater, and no doubt about every other aspect of life, is that the moment you discover some one thing to be true you also discover that, its opposite is true. This isn't ex actly news. It's always been apparent. to. me, for instance, that film depended far its liveliness and its very individu ality on montage. quick cutting, shifts of viewpoint. I grew up on film and watched the dizzying process mature. U has, for just as long a time, been equally clear that Chaplin, the greatest of them all, couldn't have cared less about montage, quick cutting, and shift ing viewpoints. Most of the time Chap lin planted his camera square in front of the action and left it there until the ac tion was finished. Oh, an insert here and there; but mainly headon, nonon sense stuff. Both attitudes have to be valid; no theorist could effectively rule

title: State School for Retarted Is Opposed
Barbara Irwin Plans Nuptials
description: BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Jan. 2The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Merle S. Irwin have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Jean Irwin, to Peter V. Holden, son of Chief Justice James S. Holden of the Ver mont State Supreme Court and Mrs. Holden of North Bennington.

title: Undercover Agent In Drugs Succeeds, But Loses Friends
description: NORFOLK, Va., Jan 2 (AP) Rick Snively's first assign ment as a policeman was un dercover work to infiltrate drug circles. The assignment resulted in 54 indictments, but cost him most of his friends.

title: REGIONAL POSTMARK FOR OMAHA OPPOSED
description: OMAHA, Jan. 2Leaders of smaller communities around Omaha are contending that the Post Office Department's plan ned regional postmark will hasten the decline of their com munities.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Henry Kahn Weds Anne Hazelwood
description: STANFORD, Con., Jan. 2 Miss Anne Greer Hazel wood and Henry Charles Kahn were married here to day at the Unitarian Uni versalist Society by the minister, the Rev. Joel Baehr.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Deborah Johnson Will Be a Bride
description: WATERTOWN, N. Y., Jan. 2 The engagement of Miss Deborah Jane Johnson to Fitz hugh Elder 3d of Alexandria, Va., son of Mr. and Mrs. Elder Jr. of Staunton, Va., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John B. John son of Watertown, where Mr. Johnson is the editor and publisher of The Watertown Daily Times. Her fianc's father, a lawyer, is vice president of the First and Merchants National Bank in Staunton.

title: DARTMOUTH TAKES HOCKEY FINAL, 65
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 2 (AP)Jim Johnston scored the decisive goal with three minutes left tonight as Dartmouth defeated Michigan, 65, for the title in the sixth annual Nichols School invitation college hockey tournament.

title: 15 Die in Malaysian Floods
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Jan. 2 (AP)Fifteen persons died this week in floods in five Malaysian states, the Govern ment said today. Thousands of persons have been evacuated to higher ground, and thou sands more have been told to be ready to move out of their homes.

title: Blin Outpoints Polite
description: MAINZ, West Germany, Jan. 2 (UPI)Jurgen Blin of West Germany outpointed Charlie Polite of Boston tonight in an eightround heavyweight bout. Blin weighed 198 pounds to Polite's 209.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Joyce A. Gagen To Be a Bride
description: DOVER, Del., Jan. 2The engagement of Miss Joyce Ann Gagen to Joseph Patrick McMurray Jr., son of Dr. McMurray, president of Queens College of the City University of New York, and Mrs. McMurray, has been an nounced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Gagen. The wedding is planned for Feb ruary.

title: Skorich Likely to Succeed Collier as Browns Coach
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 2 (UPI) Art Modell, the owner of the Cleveland Browns, is expected to name the successor to Blan ton Collier as head coach next week and it appears the suc cessor will be Nick Skorich.

title: W. ONTARIO SIX WINS IN R.P.I. TOURNEY, 32
description: TROY, N. Y., July 2 (AP) The University of Western On tario used a tough defense to stop Wisconsin, 32, today in the first game of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute hockey tournament.

title: Recordings: New Music as Public Art?
description: THAT Art and Commerce are natural and im placable enemies is so often and so easily demonstrated that, as with any obvious idea, it needs challenging occasionally. In fact, it can be argued that they are not so much enemies as conjoined dialectical forces like light and dark, neither of which is good or evil, or conceivable except in rela tion to the other. Out of such dimly understood disputes, something we recognize as history emerges  or so an unreconstructed Hegelian might content.

title: What's New in Theater
description: LOVELY LADIES, KIND GEN TLEMEN, a musical with book by John Patrick, music and lyrics by Stan Freeman and Franklin Underwood, based on The Teahouse of the August Moon, opened to three favorable reviews, two mixed and five that were unfavorable. Although Clive Barnes admired one or two decent things about it, and three or four half decent things, particularly the acting of Kenneth Nel son, Ron Husmann, David Burns, Eleanor Calbes and Remak Ramsay, he wrote, Oh dearl I come to bury Lovely Ladies, Kind Gen tlemen, not to praise it. I think two basic questions need to be asked. The first is whether the play itself would today be worth re viving. I think the answer is no: It is a little too cute, a little too coy, a little too patronizing to the defeated Asians. The second ques tion is whether it might be Improved by a little happy music and a few gay lyrics. As the music and lyrics sound like chop suey of al most, compelling unorigi nality, this is, a more open question. But no: I don't think anything could really have helped except second thoughts about the first idea

title: Mr. Brandt and His Friends
description: As he contemplates the New Year, Willy Brandt must be tempted to echo Voltaire in saying: May God defend me from my friends; I can defend myself from. my enemies. So many powerful American voices are being raised in alarm over West Germany's efforts to improve relations with Communist Europe that Chancellor Brandt might well suspect a deliberate campaign to undermine his Eastern policy.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: SLIGHT RISE IS NOTED IN SWISS ROPULATION
description: GENEVA, Jan. 2The popu lation explosion does not ap ply to the Swiss, whose num bers have increased only about 10 per cent in the last decade.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Bucks Trounce Cavaliers
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 2 (UPI) The Milwaukee Bucks set two records tonight in their final meeting of the season with the Cleveland Cavaliers in record ing a 11873 victory.

title: FEDERAL ADVISERS STUDY COURT LOAD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2Ad visers to three agencies of the Federal judiciary, operating un der the leadership of Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, are working on proposals to lighten the heavy burden of cases on the Federal courts.

title: Price Named Texas Coach
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 2 (AP) The Unversity of Texas named Cleburne Price today as head track coach and director of the Texas Relays. Price succeeds Jack Patterson, who resigned to become athletic director at Baylor University.

title: Stamps
description: DURING the year this column has described many new publica tions that should be of interest to stamp collec tors. However, some books do get bypassedfor lack of space or time to study their contents.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: North Carolina Wins
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Jan. 2 (UPI)Dennis Wuycik scored 19 points before fouling out to lead North Carolina to a 10179 victory over Tulane tonight.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: P.G.A. INCREASES SATELLITE EVENTS
description: Satellite tournaments will be more numerous on the 1971 pro golf circuit than they were last year. Instead of six there are 15 of these supplementary events listed for the tour which opens on Thursday in Los Angeles.

title: Phantom Punch Gives Urtain Berlin Victory
description: BERLIN, Jan. 2 (AP) Jos Manuel Ibar Urtain, the Basque from Spain, won a heavyweight boxing match tonight when 232pound Ever ett Copeland of the United States was disqualified for falling to the canvas without being hit in the fourth round. The 194pound Urtain, who recently lost the European heavyweight title to Henry Cooper of England battered Copeland at will in the first three rounds without regis tering a knockdown.

title: Dr. Henry E. Meleney Dies; Authority on Parasitology
description: Dr. Henry E. Meleney, an au thority on parasitology and preventive medicine, died on Wednesday in Gainesville Fla., of a heart failure.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The Gallup Poll has identified, the ten most ad mired men in America and, what is worse, has published the list. As an index of our tastes in heroes It is sad document.

title: FOR FRENCH REDS, AN AWKWARD TIME
description: PARIS, Jan. 2The Polish riots and the Leningrad sen tences could hardly have come at a more awkward time for the French Communist party.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Sell the Federal Reserve System? Pay off the national debt?

title: New Leadership in the House
description: The election of Representative Carl Albert of Oklahoma as Speaker holds promise of more vigorous, effective leadership of the House of Representa tives in the incoming Congress. He is a liberal, internationalist Democrat from a conservative state. His style is lowkeyed, pragmatic, cautious.

title: Advertising:
description: The 37yearold Esquire magazine, which has been almost as big as Life for its entire life, will shrink to Timesize with the September issue.

title: RUSSIANS INVITED TO THE DAVIS TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The United States Government has proposed to 14 leading Soviet scientists that they attend as observers the forthcoming murder trial of Angela Davis, the black Communist militant and philosophy teacher, to assure themselves of the fair ness of the proceedings.

title: Prague's Census Abroad Called A Move to Intimidate Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  Czechoslovakia is seeking to conduct a census of her citizens abroad in a move interpreted by Czechoslovak organizations in the West as an attempt to intimidate refugees of the 1968 Sovietled invasion.

title: Find of Crucified Skeleton Is Linked to a Bent Nail
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 3A nail's hitting a knot in the wood of a cross, 2,000 years ago appar ently provided for the preser vation of the only material evidence to be found In modern times of a crucifixion in the Holy Land.

title: SAMUEL FROST
description: Samuel Frost, a vice presi dent of the Textile Workers Union of America: died Satur day in Kingsbrook Jewish Med ical Center, Brooklyn, after an illness of several months. He was 55 years old and lived at 2440 East 29th Street, Brook lyn.

title: Kidnapped Girl, 14, Found Walking in Brooklyn Street
description: A 14yearold Brooklyn gir?? who was kidnapped Saturday by an armed man in a Browns ville grocery was found yester day, walking and crying, about three blocks from the store. She had a bruise over her left eye.

title: Record of Congress Session
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3Following is a summary of President, Nixon's major legislative proposals and of the action taken by Congress during its 1970 session, along with bills that were not approved:

title: ... Government Pay Yardstick
description: In a rare act of selfabnegation, Congress has turned over to a semiautomatic mechanism operating under the President the authority to determine future pay increases for Federal civil service and military employes. The im mediate effect will be an acrosstheboard wage boost of slightly over 6 per cent. But the highly commendable longterm point is to take politics and pressure out of the pay equation and establish a firm scientific link between what Federal employes earn and the wages of comparable workers in private industry.

title: Boy, 5, Dies in Rescue Effort
description: TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 3 (UPI) A 5yearold boy trying to awaken his 66yearold grand mother after a Christmas tree caught fire died last night as flames swept through their home. Michael T. Kolbas's grandmother, Mary O'Hara, was reported in critical condition today at St. Joseph's Hospital.

title: Personal Finance: Home Payments
description: Bankers say that the gen eral weakness of the economy together with rising unem ployment will further increase the number of homeowners who will be unable to meet mortgage payments in the next few months.

title: UNITAS STANDOUT IN TITLE STRUGGLE
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 3At the age of 37, John Unitas proved today that youth must be served.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Problems Mount For Industrial Research
description: The golden image of re search, and development in this country has been dulled by the tarnish of controver sy.

title: RAY SHANNON, COMIC OF STAGE AND RADIO
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 3 (AP) Ray Shannon, a comedian once teamed with Stan Laurel, died Friday in Christ Hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: Sudanese Concede Snag to Arab Unity
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan  The Sudanese now generally admit to a split in their alle giances and increasingly con sider themselves part of the African as well as the Arab world. The new National Char ter consecrates this double loyalty by describing the Su dan as an integral part of both the African and the Arab revo lutions.

title: Mr. Gierek's Pledges
description: Taken literally, Polish Communist party chief Edward Gierek has made some breathtaking pledges in his New Year's Eve address to the people of Poland. Not only must state policy be clear and understandable to every one, but practice should not be contrary to words and decisions and deeds must be born in an honest, direct conversation with the working class, with the whole nation.

title: London Newsmen Return After Striking for 3 Days
description: LONDON, Jan. 4 (Reuters) Newsmen of The London Daily Mirror and The Sun returned to work today after a three day strike.

title: Super Bowl Even Bet
description: Jimmy (The Greek) Snyder, the Las Vegas oddsmaker, yes terday listed the Jan. 17 Super Bowl game between Baltimore and Dallas as even.

title: For Losers, No Tomorrow
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 3John Mackey, among other things the president of the National Football League Players As sociation, put an arm around Carroll Rosenbloom, among other things the first Na tional Football League club president ever to come out of a Super Bowl as a loser, and whispered:

title: Israel Says Hostile Action Caused 237 Deaths in 70
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 3 (Reuters) During 1970 there were 237 Israelis killed and 782 wounded as a result of hostile action, according to official army fig ures published here.

title: Digest Unit Agrees No One Must Buy Unordered Books
description: A consumer who receives a condensed book he says he did not order from the Reader's Digest Association does not have to pay for it, Commis sioner Bess Myerson Grant of the Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday.

title: Extension of Job Benefits Begins in Jersey This Week
description: TRENTON, Jan. 3 (UPI)  Jobless New Jerseyans who have used up their unemploy ment benefits can begin collect ing extra compensation this week.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  A Federal mediator, Nicholas A. Fidandis, has summoned repre sentatives of The Washington Evening Star and the Inter national Association of Ma chinists to meet tomorrow in an effort to settle a dispute that has forced the paper to suspend publication since Fri day.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 3 (AP) The United States, on the strength of straightset vic tories by Harold Solomon and Brian Gottfried, beat South Africa and captured its second straight Sunshine Junior Cup tennis title today.

title: U.S. Voting Rolls Open To 18YearOlds Today
description: The Board of Elections will begin registering today 18to 20yearolds, who have been given the right to vote in na tional elections.

title: Raiders United in Assessment Of Unitas: You Cant Fool Him
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 3 (UPI) The beaten, disheartened Oak land Raiders didn't have much to say in their gloomy dressing quarters today but when they did talk they all talked about one man, Johnny Unitas.

title: Greek Celebrations Mark 150 Years of independence
description: ATHENS, Jan. 3 (Reuters) Nationwide celebrations began today to mark the 150th an niversary of the Greek war of independence against the Turks.

title: Blues 73 Victors
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 3 (UPI)Frank St. Marseille and Christian Bordeleau paced a balanced attack with a foal and two assists apiece tonight as the St. Louis Blues scored a 73 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Saemy Rosenberg, 78, President Of International Art House, Dies
description: Saemy Rosenberg, president of Rosenberg & Stiebel, 32 East 57th Street, a leading inter national art dealer, died Friday in New York Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 101 Central Park West.

title: Thomas Admits a Mistake On His Touchdown Run
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3 (AP)Duane Thomas acknowl edged in the jubilant Dallas Cowboys locker room today that he had made a wrong start on his 13yard touchdown run against the San Francisco 49ers.

title: Rangers Set Back Canadiens, 65, in Last 55 Seconds on Balon's 2d Goal
Times Square Merchants Shrug Off Their Weekly Sabbath Law Summonses
description: In the morning, I opened up and the cop followed me in the door, said Stanley Lee of Tie Empire in Times Square, point ing to a fresh summons for a Sabbath law violation taped to his cash register.

title: E.V.KNOX,EDITED PUNCH 16 YEARS
description: LONDON, Jan. 3E. V. Knox, editor of Punch from 1932 to 1949, died yesterday at his home here. He was 89 years old.

title: WISCONSIN SIX ROUTS NORTHEASTERN, 143
description: TROY N. Y., Jan. 3 (AP) Wisconsin rebounded from yes terday's defeat by Western On tario and downed Northeastern, 14.3, today in the second round of the Rensselaen college hockey tournament.

title: M'CAFFERTY KEPT FAITH IN HIS TEAM
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 3 (UPI) More than three months ago the Baltimore Colts, new to the American Football Conference, were beaten, 4424, by the Kan sas City Chiefs, the defending pro football champions, and doubts were raised about their ability to win.

title: Losers Weepers: Mistakes of 49ers Bewailed by Nunley
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3 The losers weep. Following the Dallas Cowboys victory over the San Francisco 49ers today for the National Confer ence championship, Frank Nunley of the 49ers wept a little bit. The young middle linebacker said, Their two touchdowns came as a result of an interception and a penalty  our mistakes.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Jan. 3Vietnam does not dominate our consciousness as it did. Weariness suppresses thought about any subject eventually, and we find reasons for wishing it away. The rea sons in Vietnam, though they promise no real end, are the lower casualties and gradual American withdrawal.

title: VIETCONG GIVE TERNS ON TRUCE WITH U.S.
description: TOKYO, Jan. 3 (UPI)  The Vietcong said today that they would agree to a ceasefire with the United States if Washington declares it will withdraw all its troops and the troops of other foreign countries from South Vietnam.

title: National Board of Review Picks Patton as Best Movie of 1970
description: Patton, the biographical drama about the World War II tank commander, has been selected as the best film of 1970 by the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures in the 50th annual poll of the or ganization. Henry Hart, chair man, said:

title: JOHN THOMPSON JR., A.S.P.C.A. PRESIDENT
description: John Fairfield Thompson Jr., president of the American So ciety for the .Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, died Satur day of a heart attack at his farm in Wytheville, Va. He was 51 years old and also lived at the University Club here.

title: MOST Y.M.C.A. UNITS IN SOUTH INTEGRATE
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 3 (AP)  Almost all Y.M.C.A.'s in the South have integrated their membership rolls and facilities since racial discrimination was banned by the National Coun cil of Y.M.C.A.'s three years ago, the council reports.

title: Eton Gently Sheds Aristocratic Ways
description: ETON, England, Dec. 28 Eton, the gothic school on the Thames that has symbolized starched exclusiveness, is quietly lifting its cloak of privilege.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Dec. 24 editorial cites daily hospital rates ranging from $51.59 to $122.53, teaching hospitals being in the highest bracket and voluntary hospitals charging less.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan to Be Sworn In
description: Sacramento, Calif., Jan. 3 (UP)  Gov. Ronald Reagan will be sworn tin for a second term tomorrow during a day long celebration. The 59year old Republican already has an nounced this will be his final fouryear term as Governor.

title: Scribner Will Consider Petition for Removal of Overton From School Board Tonight
description: Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, the city's School Chancellor, has called a meeting for tonight to consider a petition for the removal of L. Joseph Overton, a prominent but controversial Harlem labor leader, from the District 5 Local School Board.

title: CREDIT MARKETS RESUMING ACTION
description: The credit markets are head ing into the new year this week with many influential analysts convinced that interest rates are still headed lower.

title: Oil on Louisiana Shore
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 (UPI)  Floating oil from a burning Gulf of Mexico drill ing platform washed ashore along 20 miles of Louisiana coastline today. An aerial sur vey of the Shell Oil Company platform also showed an oil slick stretching two miles northwest into the Gulf.

title: Nixon Plans to Propose Overhaul of Health Services That Would Seek to Involve the Private Sector
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3Late this winter the Nixon Adminis tration will propose a therapy program for the nation's patch work medical care system, which two years ago the White House said bordered on col lapse. The program could affect the health of tens of millions of Americans.

title: JOSEPH GRUBER
description: STAMFORD, Conn, Jan. 3 Joseph Gruber, who had been president of the United Cloak Manufacturing Company, died Friday following a long illness.

title: Nixon Is Seeking to Placate Black Aides Ready to Quit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The Nixon Administration plans a series of moves to placate several top Negro officials who are distressed over the Administration's civil rights policies and are threatening to resign. At least two black officials have indicated that they plan to quit their posts shortly, while several others have set an informal deadline of June for the Administration to make some positive changes.

title: Judge Orders Mendoza Trial
description: MANILA, Monday, Jan. 4 (AP) A Manila judge ruled today that Benjamin Mendoza y Amor Floes can readily stand trial on charges that he tried to mur der Pope Paul VI. The ruling came after a psychiatric team asked for more time to deter mine the Bolivian painter's fit ness for trial.

title: 3 KEY INDIAN PARTIES ALLIED FOR ELECTION
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 3 (AP) Three major Indian political parties buried their ideological differences tonight and formed an alliance to oppose Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's ruling New Congress party in the coming parliamentary elections.

title: Dallas and Baltimore Win Playoffs and Will Meet in Super Bowl Jan. 17
description: The Dallas Cowboys and the Baltimore Colts qualified yesterday to meet in the Su per Bowl at Miami on Jan. 17 by scoring victories in Na tional Football League con ference championship games. The Cowboys captured the National Conference crown by downing the San Francisco 49ers, 1710, at San Fran cisco. The Colts won the American Conference title, topping the Oakland Raiders, 2717, at Baltimore. The Cow boys broke a 33 halftime tie with two touchdowns in the third quarter. Johnny Unitas of the Colts outdueled George Blanda in a battle of aging quarterbacks.

title: AMEX AUTOMATING DIVIDEND CLAIMS
description: Wall Street will test a new system of handling unpaid dividend claims at nine leading brokerage houses in a pilot program starting today.

title: The Echo of Violence
description: Radicals at Harvard explode a bomb in the Center for International Affairs. Rightwing vigilantes dynamite a liberal radio station in Houston, Tex. An extremist Jewish group publicly applauds when an explosion shat ters windows in a Soviet tourist office. Ku Klux Klan nightriders stage a destructive commando raid on an ecumenical church center at the University of Delaware.

title: Steven Perlmutter Weds Judith Miller
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 3  Miss Judith Barbara Miller and Steven Perlmutter were married here this after noon. Rabbi Maynard Hyman performed the ceremony in Adas Yeshuron Synagogue.

title: Italian Who Saw Peking Says Digging of Trenches Continues
description: ROME, Jan. 3The first Ital ian Communist newsman to be authorized to visit Communist China in nearly 10 years re ported today that the digging of trenches was continuing in many neighborhoods of Peking.

title: New Director of U.S.O. Was in Vietnam 5 Years
description: Samuel G. Anderson has been named national execu tive director of the United Service Organizations to succeed Justin M. Morrill, who had been active in the organization since 1941.

title: Bridge: M.I.T. Pair Capture Honors In TransAtlantic Tourney
description: The first transAtlantic bridge competition, a junior pair championship restricted to players under 26 years old was won Saturday by Mike Gurwitz of Hillside, N.J., and Mark Feldman of Cambridge, Mass.

title: Asia Slowly Awakening to Need for Pollution Control
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 1In Asia, where millions live in squalor, many governments are giving new attention to the problem of environmental pollution.

title: For Garment Industry's Workers, It's BeltTightening Time
description: The gaiety is muted In many of the households of the city's quarter of million garment workers as the new year dawns. How can there be good cheer when work is scarce?

title: Campaign Speeches Defended by Agnew On Buckley's Show
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) Vice President Agnew says his 1970 campaign speeches were not divisive but rather reflected the natural competition of the political arena.

title: British Book Says German and Soviet Officials Met in 43 to Discuss Peace
description: LONDON, Dec. 24Did For eign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov of the Soviet Union meet Joachim von Ribbentrop, Hitler's Foreign Minister, be hind the German lines in Rus sia early in 1943 to discuss a negotiated peace?

title: Stage:'71  Is Off to a Lamentable Start
description: I cannot Imagine a more dispiriting and dismal eve ning in the theater than that provided by Stag Movie, which last night opened pit iably at the Gate Theater and got the new theatrical mar off to its most lament able start since the death of Little Nell. It would be at least pleasant if one could recommend it to the voyeur istically inclined among us.

title: Pipeline Break Perils Wildlife in Wisconsin
description: JACKSON, Wis., Jan. 3 (AP)An oil pipeline broke in the Jackson Marsh wild life area during the holidays, but quick action and cold weather, may save plant and animal life from disaster.

title: Teton Climbers Turn Back
description: MOOSE, Wyo., Jan. 3 (AP) Paul Petzoldt, 62 years old, and his party of 23 young climbers turned back this afternoon from their assault on 13,766foot Grand Teton Peak after ad vancing to within 1,000 feet of the summit. Everything up here is covered with rime ice, Mr. Petzoldt said. It would be just too dangerous to try going the rest of the way.

title: THOMAS EXCELS, GAINING 143 YARDS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3  The Dallas Cowboys marched to the Super Bowl today. Out in front was Duane Thomas, the rookie running back who gained 143 yards as the Cow boys, with a punishing ground game, beat the San Francisco 49ers, 1710, before 59,625 fans in Kezar Stadium.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklynites Bid a Nostalgic Farewell to the Fox
description: The Fox Theater, the movie palace that along with the Brooklyn Paramount, once drew thousands to the down town Brooklyn area, is final ly coming down.

title: Model Rooms Unveiledat Sale Prices
description: Everything else on this floor is on sale at this time of year. It doesn't seem fair, then, to keep a customer from getting new things at a markeddown price. Speak ing was Lester Gribetz, Bloomingdale's merchandise manager for furniture, and the floor he was referring to was the department store's fifth.

title: PostMortems: Smiling Victors Look Ahead;
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3 (UPI)To a man, the San Francisco 49ers agreed the bruising running game and deadly ball control of the Dallas Cowboys carried them into the Super Bowl.

title: Robert Lusk, Former Chairman Of Benton &
description: Robert Emmett Lusk, chair man of the executive commit tee and former president and board chairman of Benton & Bowles, Inc., a major advertis ing agency, died Saturday at his home. He was 68 years old and lived at 45 Sutton Place South.

title: Brooklyn Congregation Clothes and Feeds Derelicts
description: Stamping their feet against the cold on the slushcovered sidewalk yesterday, a group of men stood in the glare of a bright morning sun across the street from the Shelter Care Center for Men on East Third Street. They waited for a yel low school bus with signs on front and back reading: Lord, help us to help somebody.

title: Transfer of Civic Sovereignty ...
description: Eightmillion New Yorkers are learning the hard way that they live by sufferance of the civil service unions, whose members they are paying $4 billion a year in wages, pensions and other benefitsa rise of 40 per cent In the last two budgets.

title: Can It Happen Here?
description: Can it happen here?

title: CITY REEXAMINES U.S. RELIEF PLAN Seeks Greater Aid for Itself and Better Job Program
description: New York City, with nearly a tenth of the nation's 12 mil lion relief recipients, is re assessing its support for the welfare reform proposal Presi dent Nixon says he will press again in Congress after last year's defeat. The city now wants greater help for its own rising money crisis.

title: Daily Mirror Appears On Newsstands Here
description: The Daily Mirror, a 32 page tabloid, made its first appearance on newsstands here early today.

title: MRS. COURT TAKES PERTH TENNIS TITLE
description: PERTH, Australia, Jan. 3 (AP)Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia defeated Virginia Wade of England, 61, 62, to day to win the West Australian women's singles title at Royal Kings Park in 37 minutes.

title: Mayor Prods Councilmen To Form Taxi Commission
description: In 1,000word letters sent to each of the City Councilmen, Mayor Lindsay called yesterday for the creation of a Taxi Commission as an absolutely essential ingredient of any agreement to increase cab fares.

title: FEDERAL PRISON HIT BY A DISTURBANCE
description: About a dozen prisoners. at the Federal House of Detention refused to return to their cells for about four hours yesterday afternoon. New York City Po lice and Fire Department units were called to the scene and asked to stand by outside the building in case Federal au thorities were unable to con tain the disturbance.

title: Shop Talk
description: The name of the shiny new glass and supergraphics shop that opened recently at 1049 Madison Avenue (80th Street) is Genesis and it may mean the genesis of a new way of dressingin accessory clothes. For at Genesis, where belts some times double as skirts, it's often hard to tell the acces sories from the clothes them selves. Ronald Kolodzio and Philip Haight, the owners designers, have put together an allencompassing collec tion of fashion parts that allow a woman to put her self together as the fashion spirit moves her. At Gene sis, there is, for example, a group of peasant blouses and tiered skirts in various color andprint combinations of cotton voile, and these can mix and match to the infi nite power. The blouses in this group are $40 while the skirts are $30 for one tier, $45 for two.

title: LANDRY RATES COLTS AS SIMILAR TO 49ERS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3 (AP)  When asked about meeting the Baltimore Colts in the Super Bowl, Coach Tom Lan dry of the Dallas Cowboys said today he thought the Colts offense could be somewhat si milar to the 49ers  lots of passing.

title: SUN HELPS MACHINES CHASE REST OF SNOW
description: A sunny Sunday with tem peratures above freezing helped 3,704 sanitationmen clear the city's streets yesterday of the remnants of the New Year's Day snowfall.

title: Arms Withdrawal Announced
description: BEIRUT, Jan. 3(AP)Al Fa tah announced today at a news conference that it would with draw arms, from its men in Lebanon in a move for closer cooperation with the Govern ment.

title: For Students, New York Is a Winter Festival
description: Judy, a 21yearold senior at the University of Illinois, spent New Year's Eve snug gled under a blanket on the driver seat of a horsedrawn cab.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: It is with profound sorrow we announce the passing of our Chairman of the Board

title: Duryea Sees State Tax Rise Unless U.S. Splits Revenue
description: Speaker Perry B. Duryea Jr. of the Assembly warned yester day that New York State faced a tax increase or a very seri ous cutback in services if the Congress did not pass a bill for $10billion in revenueshar ing with the states.

title: Books of The Times
description: The times, they have changed. Wilhelm Reich (18971957), the Austrian sexologist and inventor of the socalled orgone energy accumulator, has made a comeback. And the editors of Farrar, Straus & Giroux have wisely seen fit to bring out in a new trans lation one of his more highly regarded books, The Mass Psychology of Fascism. This is no great esthetic event: Norman Mailer was all too correct when he called Reid hip as a mind but square as a stylist. Yet there is little doubt about the book's pertinence to all sorts of current concerns. It addresses the youth culture and the sexual revolution. (It is another of the many books that Charles A. Reich should have read before writing The Greening of America.) It squarely confronts the major issues of women's liberation. (Happily, Kate Millett did read it before she wrote Sexual Politics.) It surpasses Herbert Marcuse's attempts to reconcile Freud and Marx. It hasn't an elitist bone in its body. And whereas 15 years ago this reviewer contemplated Reich's theories of sexeconomy and orgone energy with horrified shudders, reading The Mass Psychology of Fascism today made him, wonder a little.

title: Arts Abroad
description: BERLINTwo weeks ago, on the night of Dec. 19, the managing director of Ham burg's famous Schauspielhaus committed suicide. Gerard Hirsch, 47 years old, left a note, with the line I could not stand the general lack of courage any more. One week earlier, the one impor tant experimental theater group of West Berlin, the Schaubuehne, be came the center of a political storm. As municipal elections were coming up, the Chris tian Democratic opposition in its bid to upset the Social Democrats leveled an attack against that theater, charging its director with practicing subversive indoctrination. The theater, under the direc tor, Peter Stein, was playing Maxim Gorki's The Mother in Bertolt Brecht's adaptation to full houses. The Socialist City Senator for Cultural Af fairs came to the defense of what he called a showcase of West Berlin theatrical ac tivity. But his party col leagues among City Council men went ahead anyway and suspended part of the subsidy they had been allotting to the Schaubuehne, pending the conclusion of an official in vestigation. A silent majority gone strident thus imposed a decision that widely disap pointed and angered intellec tuals in West Berlin and West Germany at large, including the normally stolid national newspaper Frankfurter Allge meine Zeitung.

title: Sports of The Times A Great Start
description: Dr. George A. Sheehan is a 52yearold Red Bank, N. S., cardiologist, essayist, philosopher and runner. One of 14 children and the father of 12, he has found inspira tion and reverie while running. A crosscountry runner and miler at Manhattan College, he began running again only nine years ago when a broken hand kept him from playing tennis during a summer vacation. He became, he says, a mainline jogger. Because he has been known to sprint with highschool athletes and, last April, he fin ished his seventh Boston Marathon in 3 hours 2 min utes 20 seconds, Dr. Shee han's example is not neces sarily a practicable goal for everyone: Do as he says, not as he does.

The transaction, whose terms were not dis closed, will pro vide an early test for the new bank holding company law, which Presi dent Nixon signed on New Year's Eve. Under the new law, onebank holding companies such as the First Na tional City Corporation are lim ited in their nonbanking activi ties to businesses so closely related to banking or managing or controlling banks as to be a proper incident thereto.

description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4 (UPI) A double dividend was paid in advertently to shareholders of the Signet Corporation, but the company might skip the next quarterly payout to square its books.

title: A DANCE DEBUT SET BY HARLEM TROUPE
description: The Dance Theater of Har lem, under the direction of Arthur Mitchell and Karel Shook, will make its formal New York City debut with three performances in the main (gallery of the Guggenheim Museum on Friday, Saturday land Sunday at 8:30 P.M.

title: Rockefeller Asks Changes In U.S. Rail Network Plan
description: ALBANY, Jan. 4Governor Rockefeller complained today that a proposed Federal plan for revamping railroad passen ger lines into a national system would isolate upstate New York and reduce vital links to the metropolitan area.

title: Fog and Strike Hit Orly
description: PARIS, Jan. 4 (AP)Service at Orly Airport was reduced today by heavy fog and a strike of French airline employes. De spite the strike, by unions representing pilots and cabin personnel of Air France and two other carriers, about 30 Air France flights left normal ly. Several flights of other lines were diverted from Orly to Le Bourget field because of the fog.

title: First Pennsylvania Bank Cuts Prime Rate to 6% Major Institutions Fail to Follow Drop From 6 %, but Decline Is Seen Likely if Reserve Lowers Its Discount Rate
description: The First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company, the largest bank in Philadelphia, reduced its prime rate on busi ness loans yesterday to 6 per cent from 6 per cent.

title: Curtains on Broadway Go Up at 7:30
description: Broadway's legitimate the aters went on Patron Saving Time last night. Curtains went up an hour earlier, at about 7:30, instead of at about 8:30.

title: Pontiff Exhorts Bishops on Teachings
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4Pope Paul VI called on the world's Roman Catholic Bishops today to rededicate themselves to teaching the traditional funda mentals of the faith.

title: Veteran Tells of Spying on Youth Group
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) A former military undercover agent says he spied for nearly six months on a Colorado youth group and its leader because a lieutenant colonel feared they would turn soldiers against the Vietnam war.

title: At Squaw Valley, Guests From Afar
Kinoy's Daughter Loses Appeal, Goes Before a U.S. Grand Jury
description: The United States Court of Appeals refused yesterday to let the daughter of a Rutgers University law professor who has defended the civil rights of radicals delay her appearance before a grand jury.

title: New Crimmins Trial Set For Jan. 18
description: A new trial has been scheduled for Jan. 18 for Alice Crimmins, who faces charges of manslaughter and murder in the deaths of her two children.

title: PITTSBURGH SHUTS SCHOOLS IN STRIKE 3,260 Teachers Off Their Jobs in Salary Dispute
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4  This city's 112 public schools were closed today by a strike of teachers in a dispute over pay demands.

title: Insight, an interview Show, Begins Monday on WQXR
description: Clifton Daniel, an associate editor of The New York Times, will moderate a news and inter view program called Insight, to be broadcast weekday eve nings from 7:30 to 8 over WQXR beginning next Monday.

title: Primer Cords Found
description: HYDEN, Ky., Jan. 4. (UPI) A Federal official said tonight that illegal primer cords, which are used to detonate explosives, were found inside the Finley Coal Company mine.

title: Colts to Leave for Miami Thursday to Start Drills
description: The Colts, in preparation for the Super Bowl game with the Dallas Cowboys in Miami a week from Sunday, will leave Baltimore by chartered airliner on Thursday evening. Their headquarters will be at the Miami Lakes Country Club, with practice facilities at Bis cayne College.

title: FIRST 1971 MOVIE IS READY TO SHOOT
description: Local movie production, which has risen in recent years to the filming of more than 40 features here last year, will start a new year on Monday when shooting begins on Shaft in the Times Square area.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4Madge and Bob were invented in the golden days of radio. He was a newsboy who wanted to travel the world and do good, and she was the girl next door.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dolph III With Pneumonia
description: Commissioner Jack Dolph of the American Basketball Asso ciation was resting in a Green wich, Conn., hospital after being stricken with pneumonia, his New York office reported yesterday.

title: DOOR TO BIG BOARD AJAR FOR INSURER
description: A major insurance company would gain potential access to the New York Stock Exchange through a complex merger transaction that is under nego tiation between a small mem ber firm and a small regional brokerage house.

title: 2 Sudanese Rebels, Charging Genocide, Seek. Help at U.N.
description: Two representatives of black Sudanese liberation move tient charged here yesterday that the Arabled Government of Sudan was using Egyptian and Libyan troops as well as Soviet planes in the 16year conflict that has pitted Chris tian and pagan blacks of the South against Moslems of the north.

title: Airlines to Shift at Key West
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board has authorized National Air lines to suspend service at Key West, Fla., for three years. During that time, Southeast Airlines, an air taxi operator, will provide replacement serv ice.

title: U.S. Asks Supreme Court To Uphold Disney Resort
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)  The Federal government has asked the Supreme Court to clear the way for a $35million Walt Disney ski resort on public land in the Mineral King Valley in California's scenic Sierra Nevada Mountains.

title: DEFENSE COSTS UP IN ISRAELI BUDGET
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 4Israelis have become the world's most highly taxed citizens, accord ing to Finance Ministry calcu lations. These indicate that Is rael moved ahead of Sweden in 1970 as the country with the highest percentage of its gross national product going to the Government.

title: 91Day Bill Rate Up to 4.921%; 182Day Discount Is at 4.927%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  Treasury bill rates advanced moderately at today's Auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

title: ANDREW J. FLANAGAN OF NEW ARK NEWS, 64
description: SEA GIRT, N. J., Jan. 4 Andrew J. Flanagan, former national advertising manager of The Newark News, died yes terday in the Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune, after a brief illness. He was 64 years old and lived at 508 Phila delphia Boulevard here.

title: Previews at Mercury
description: Previews at Mercury The Shrinking Bride, a com edy by Jonathan Levy with songs by William Bolcom, will begin a series of eight preview performances tonight at the Mercury Theater, 134 East 134th Street. The play, which stars Jack Somack and Joe Silver and is directed by Marvin Gordon, will open officially next Monday.

title: Light Needed in Albany
description: There is pervading darkness in Albany as the State Legislature prepares to convene tomorrow. The issues confronting the State of New York are numerous, massive and yet, in their exact size and shape, uncertain.

title: PRESIDENT TERMS CUBA OFF LIMITS FOR SOVIET SUBS
SNOW'S REMOVAL HAILED IN QUEENS
description: If Queens residents had a complaint yesterday about snow removal, it was that their neighbors had been lax in clearing sidewalks.

title: President Predicts Gains In Econotny for'71 and'72
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4Presi dent Nixon forecast significant improvements in the economy in 1971, followed by a very good year in 1972, as he de livered a generally: hopeful as sessment of the future of. the United States before a nation wide television audience tonight.

title: To Many Working Mothers, a Job Is Almost a Losing Proposition
description: Jane Doe has a decision to make. She has a job and a baby and is torn between staying home and molding her life around that of her Child or returning to work and paying someone else to care for the infant.

title: Utility Sets Expansion
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 4 (UPI)  The Northern States Power Company said today it expects to spend $197million on new construction in its fourstate service area in 1971, compared with an estimated $167million in 1970.

title: Socialism Comes to a TraditionBound Iraqi Port
description: UMM QASR, IragFrom a distance there is nothing striking about this sleepy lit tle port at the head of the Persian Gulf, an area that has been a bastion of conserva tism in the Middle East.

title: 2d Trial in Leningrad Is Reported Postponed
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 4 (UPI) Informed sources said today that Soviet authorities had postponed the trial of nine Leningrad Zionists charged with promoting antiSoviet activities. The trial had been scheduled to start Wednes day.

title: Many Under 21 Register to Vote Here
description: Under the age of 21 but newly eligible to vote, the young people came out yes terdaynot in drovesbut singly or in groups of two or three to qualify in good num bers to participate in Federal elections of the future.

title: Burnet to Contest Action
description: Charles M. Cushing, partner of W. E. Burnet & Co., stated last night that, while the con cern had not had the oppor tunity to study the charges, it and he believed themselves in nocent of any violation of law and would vigorously contest the proceedings.

title: Reed Leaves Hospital, Rejoins Knicks Today
description: Willis Reed was discharged from Roosevelt Hospital yes terday and will work out with the Knicks today prior to accompanying them on their fivegame road trip that begins tomorrow night in Cleveland.

title: Sadat Reveals Israeli Raid Killed 6 Soviet Missilemen
description: CAIRO, Jan. 4  President Anwar elSadat acknowledged today that Soviet soldiers had been brought in to man Egyptian missile sites and said six of them had been killed in a raid on Dahshur, 20 miles south of Cairo.

title: 4 Students and the Drama Desk Seek New Program for Youth
description: Professional theater peo ple and young drama stu dents agreed yesterday that the commercial theater was failing to attract large num bers of young people as audi ence but differed somewhat on the reasons. Surprisingly, the students thought their elders were trying too hard to please them.

title: Civilians Settle in Sinai
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 4 (Reuters) The first Israeli civilian ag ricultural settlement to be opened in the Sinai Desert, seized from Egypt during the 1967 war, was established to day between Rafah and El Arish. There are already sev eral paramilitary villages in Sinai.

title: Boycott Greets First Communist Passenger Ship Here in 20 Years
description: The Polish luxury liner Ste fan Batory sailed into the har bor yesterday to become the first Communist passenger ship to dock here in 20 years.

title: One Ivy Aide Returns and Another Is Elevated
description: Harvard reached into the Canadian Football League and Dartmouth cut off one of its assistant coaches at the pass yesterday to fill Cue remaining head football coaching vacan cies in the Ivy League.

title: Defendant Pleads Not Guilty In the Yablonski Murders
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Jan. 4 Claude E. Vealey, 26 years old, one of five persons charged with the murders of Joseph A. Yablonski, an official of the United Mine Workers of Amer ica, and two members of his family, pleaded not guilty to day at his formal arraignment in Washington County Court.

title: Met. Squash Racquets
description: CLASS D

title: S.E.C. In Baerwald Move
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 4The S.E.C. also announced discipli nary proceedings today against Baerwald & DeBoer, a former New York Stock Exchange member that is in liquidation.

title: Dutiful Firemen Refuse Nonessential Firewater
description: Firemen responding to an alarm on a kitchen fire at Sardi's restaurant at 234 West 44th Street last night found the fire had been extinguished before they arrived.

title: Profits Stepped Up By C. & O.B. & O.
McClendon to Get $31,500
description: BATON ROUGE, Jan. 4 (AP) Coach Charlie McClendon of Louisiana State University will get a new contract with a $4,000 raise and other addition al benefits, the university an nounced today. The university board of supervisors was ex pected to approve the new five year pact, giving McClendon a salary of $31,500 and rights to L.S.U. game films.

title: No Soviet Reply Yet
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 4A spokes man for the United States Em bassy said today that no re sponse had been received from the 14 Soviet scientists invited last week to attend the trial of Angela Davis, the American Communist charged with mur der in California.

title: Art Theft Defendant Pleads Insanity
description: A Denver businessman charged with the interstate transportation and sale of stolen art works contended yes terday that he was the victim of toxic insanity resulting, from medication he took for an asthmatic condition.
