title: The Unemployed Know Impact Of the Statistics of Joblessness
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8  This is the worst. Alexander Stuckert, a thin, softspoken man of 56, was describing the economic situation that has kept him from working in his trade of carpentry since July.

title: Baleful BoatWhistle Blares the End Of U.S. Liner Service on the Atlantic
description: With three fullbodied blasts, the liner Santa Rosa slipped from her Manhattan pier at twilight yesterday, putting an end to more than a century of regular Ameri canflag passenger steam ship sailing from New York.

title: Many Craft Becalmed in Snow On Way to Boat Show in Paris
description: PARIS, Jan. 8The world's largest boat show opened today to the sound of ham mer and saw, the touch of fresh paint and the faint aroma of performing seals. Missing, however, were about 40 boats, lost in a sea of snow on the highways of France.

title: Rangers to Face Worsley On Minnesota Ice Tonight
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 8The New York Rangers skate against the Minnesota North Stars tomorrow night in hopes of keeping up with the Boston Bruins in the East Division race of the National Hockey League.

title: BARRY HELPS NETS TOPPLE COLONELS
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 8With Rick Barry scor ing 16 of his 41 points in the fourth quarter and their new rebounder, Manny Leaks, mak ing his usefulness clear, the New York Nets defeated the Kentucky Colonels tonight, 125 111, at Island Garden.

title: Carbide's Air CleanUp Plan Is Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Wil liam D. Ruckelshaus, adminis tor of the Environmental Pro tection Agency, informed the Union Carbide Corporation to day that its schedule for reduc ing sulphur oxide emissions from its ferroalloy plant in Marietta, Ohio, was not acceptable.

title: Twins'
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Jan. 8 (UPI)  Dick Wiencek, a for mer West Coast supervisor of scouts for the Minnesota Twins, today joined the Cali fornia Angels as assistant to General Manager Dick Walsh.

title: MR ENDS MIXED IN LOWER VOLUME Prices Ease After Report of Rise in Jobless Rate
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Crocker National Reports 11% Rise In Net for Quarter
description: The $6.03billion Crocker Na tional Corporation, parent of San Francisco's CrockerCiti zens National Bank, reported yesterday that income before securities transactions rose 11 per cent in the fourth quarter and 9.3 per cent for all of 1970.

title: Suspect in Ramsey Shooting
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 (UPI)  Jimmy Harrison, 35 years old, of Philadelphia, was ar raigned before a Municipal Court judge today on charges of assault with intent to kill and two counts of aggravated assault and battery and fire arms violations in the Dec. 14 shooting of Nate Ramsey, co captain and safety forthe Phila delphia Eagles.

title: SUBURBAN PROPANE RAISES ITS PROFITS
description: The Suburban Propane Gas Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net in come for the year ended Sept. 30, 1970. The report placed total revenues at $96,598,744 against $90,748,222 a year ear lier.

title: Marine Midland Cuts Rate
description: The Marine Midland Bank New York announced yester day that it had joined other major New York City banks in reducing its interest charges on personal loans.

title: Sanitation Collections Improving, Mayor Says
description: On the basis of daily re ports by 200 volunteer moni tors, the Sanitation Depart ment's overall service has improved in areas where ir regular collections three times a week were cut to two regu lar pickups, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.

title: Army Drops Murder Case Against Green Beret Officer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) The Army dismissed a murder charge today against a Green Beret captain whose court martial conviction in the 1967 slaying of a Cambodian agent in South Vietnam was thrown out by an appeals court last October.

title: 4 Million Will Get Raises as Nixon Approves 6 Bills
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 8 (AP)President Nixon signed one bill and two executive or ders today that granted $2.2 billion in pay Increases to four million military personnel and whitecollar workers.

title: Susan Eisenhower Wed to A. H. Bradshaw
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., Jan. 8 Miss Susan Elaine Eisen hower, secondoldest grand daughter of the late President Dwight D. Eisenhower, was married this evening to Alex ander Hugh Bradshaw, a London lawyer.

title: OutofState Tracks Balk City Bet Plan
description: Outofstate race tracks are prepared to take court actions to block New York City from establishing sep arate offtrack betting pools on their races, a telephone survey disclosed yesterday.

title: Article 13  No Title
description: DETROIT, Jan. 8 (UPI)  Overtime work at the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company is help ing the auto industry resume its fast pace, Ward's Automo tive Reports said today.

title: Patman Comments on Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (Reu ters)  Representative Wright Patman, Chairman of the House Banking and Currency Commit tee, said today reductions in the discount and prime lending rates had come too late to head off what he called an onrush ing recession.

title: GTE Communications to Sell All Its Cable TV Properties
description: GTE Communications, Inc., a subsidiary of the General Tele phone and Electronics Corpora tion, announced yesterday that it has put up for sale all of its cable television (CATV) proper ties. The subsidiary operates 20 CATV systems in 32 suburban and rural communities with an undisclosed number of sub scribers.

title: Again, the Tupamaros
description: The brazen kidnapping of the British Ambassador in Montevideo by Uruguay's Tupamaros serves as a sharp reminder to all governments of the inadequacy of methods thus far devised to discourage political abductions.

title: Bullets Set Back Hawks
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 8 (UPI) Gus Johnson scored 31 points and had 24 rebounds tonight as the Baltimore Bullets broke the game open in the second quar ter and went on to beat the Atlanta Hawks, 115104.

title: What Kind of Place Is This?
description: Late in the session a couple of years ago, Governor Rockefeller's message of necessity had sped mimeo graphed copies of vital changes in welfare laws to the desks of every member of the State Assemblyto the desks of every member except freshman Assemblyman Stephen Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn. As debate began and votes were being taken, Mr. Solarz asked the clerk for a copy of the changes under consideration. He was told there were no more copies. He demanded a copy of the bills he was being asked to vote on.

title: Bowdoin Six Sinks Hamilton
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Jan. 8 Jim Block and Jim Burnett scored two goals each tonight as Bowdoin College's hockey team whipped Hamilton, 84, and strengthened its grip on first place in the Eastern Col lege Athletic Conference Divi sion II smallcollege standing.

title: G.I.'s Account Says He Shot Civilians At Mylai on Orders
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Jan. 8  A statement by an Army sergeant that he had fired his rifle into a group of South Vietnamese civilians on orders from his superiors was read to a courtmartial panel today by the prosecution.

title: BLAST DAMAGES SOVIET BUILDING IN WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8A small bomb exploded outside a Soviet cultural building here before dawn this morning, harming no one but shattering the glass in several windows and hurling an iron gate to a roof 250 feet away.

title: CAPTAIN OF POLICE A SUICIDE IN BRONX
description: A police captain attached to the first deputy commis sioner's office shot and killed himself on City Island, the Bronx, yesterday morning the police reported.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI) The Defense Department said today that the following serv icemen from the New York area had been killed in action in Southeast Asia:

title: REPUTED MAFIOSO INDICTED ON USURY
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 8 Nicholas Rattenl, a reputed Mafia leader, and four other men were indicted today by a Federal grand jury for conspir acy, loansharking and threat ening to use violence to collect payments on illegal loans.

title: Strike at Hoboken Hospital
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., Jan. 8 (AP) A substantial number of the more than 300 nonprofessional workers at St. Mary's Hospital here walked off their jobs today. A spokesman for the 360bed hospital said the work ers, members of Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Workers Union, staged the walkout de spite continuing contract talks. The union was certified as bar gaining agent for the nonpro fessional workers after an election in November. Union spokesmen were not imme diately available for comment.

title: Corn Off the Cob Scores For Ussery's 4th Victory
description: MIAMI, Jan. 8 (UPI)Corn Off The Cob made a successful return to the races at Tropical Park today with a neck victory in the $6,000 allowance feature at six furlongs.

title: DOUGLAS SHEARER, MGM SOUND CHIEF
description: Douglas Shearer, for 41 years head of the sound re cording department of Metro GoldwynMayer Pictures and winner of 12 Academy Awards, died Tuesday in a convales cent hospital in Culver City, Calif. He was 70 years old.

title: Agnew Plans Two Parleys
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) Vice President Agnew will at tend regional meetings of the National Association of Counties Jan. 27 in Atlanta and Kansas City, Mo., His office announced today.

title: CALIFORNIA GAINS WELFARE ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Cal ifornia won a lastminute re prieve today from a cutoff of $684million in Federal welfare funds.

title: Lefkowitz Accuses Club
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz is seeking to close down a Greenwich Village res taurant and club where he charges deviate sexual acts were exhibited on stage for a fee. Mr. Lefkowitz complained that Christopher's End, a club at 180 Christopher Street, con stituted a public nuisance that imperiled the physical and emo tional wellbeing of thousands of Greenwich Villagers.

title: FUROR DISRUPTS FIREMEN'S TALKS
description: Negotiators for the city and the firemen resumed their bar gaining talks yesterday after a furor stemming from reports, immediately denied, that an of fer for major pension improve ments had been made.

title: Ammonia Cargo Derailed
description: CALLAO, Mo., Jan. 8 (AP) A derailed tank car of liquid ammonia burst open on a rail road bridge today. Dangerous fumes leaking from the wreck age caused evacuation of 20 farm homes in the area. No injuries were reported.

title: LANDLORDS DECRY POSSIBLE TAX RISE
description: Landlords of rentcontrolled buildings reacted with anger, dismay and dire predictions yesterday to a forecast by the Citizens Budget Commission that the local real estate tax rate would rise by 18 cents in the 197172 tax year.

title: Hodgson Says President Seeks Curbs on Construction Wages
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Sec retary of Labor James D. Hodg son said today that the Nixon Administration was working to curb what he suggested were excessive wage increases to construction workers.

title: Blazers Post a First
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (UPI) Geoff Petrie had 27 points and Jim Barnett 26 tonight to lead the Portland Trail Blazers to a 113105 triumph over Chi cago, their first victory over the Bulls in three games this season.

title: COLUMBIA DOWNS YALE FIVE, 7358
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 8  Co lumbia's basketball team de feated Yale, 7358, tonight in an Ivy League battle, sending the Elis to their 10th straight loss.

title: Barenboim and Tempo
description: It may be that Daniel Bar enboim tried too hard at his Thursday night Philharmonic concert, but whatever the reason, he did not conduct with the flair and authority he had demonstrated last month with the Philadelphia Orchestra. Of course it also may have been a matter of familiarity with the reper tory. The young conductor is learning as he goes along, and he cannot have con ducted the Brahms First Sym phony too many times in public.

title: Mortgage Rates Lowered
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 8 (Canadian Press)  The Central Mortgage and Housing Corporation an nounced today a reduction in the rate charged for its own mortgage lending to 9 per cent from 9 per cent.

title: Frederick Deyle Stiteler, Gave $200,000 to U. of P.
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 Frederick Deyle Stiteler, who gave the University of Penn sylvania $200,000 toward con struction of Stiteler Hall, a building for psychology, social work and education, died Wednesday at the age of 82.

title: 3 Jersey Women Win $50,000 Each in Lottery
description: TRENTON, Jan. 8 (AP) Three New Jersey women, two of them from Middlesex County, have won top prizes of $50,000 each in New Jer sey's first lottery.

title: LUNCHTIME SERIES STRIKES JAZZ NOTE
description: A series of weekly, midday concerts starring wellknown jazz groups was started yester day at Downbeat, Lexington Avenue at 42d Street, with the Marion McPartland Trio and Teddi King, the singer, as fea tured performers.

title: Network Carries Photos
description: A new, highspeed facsimile communications network, in troduced by Facsimile Trans mission Network, Inc., links more than 250 cities through out the United States and Can ada. Using this Faxmail, a businessman can transmit hard copy duplicates of written, drawn, printed or photo graphed materials over tele phone lines.

title: SHINYA UCHIDA
description: TOKYO, Jan. 8 (AP)Shinya Uchida, a shipping magnate and cabinet minister before and after World War II, died of bronchitis yesterday in Tokyo. He was 90 years old.

title: FREEMAN OF STARS IN FOURMAN TRADE
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 8 (AP)The Utah Stars of the American Basketball Associa tion traded temperamental Donnie Freeman, the team's second leading scorer, and Wayne Hightower to the Tex as Chaparrals today.

title: MANSON'S ATTORNEY ENDS HIS SUMMATION
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (UPI) Irving Kanarek, defense at torney for Charles M. Manson, finally ended his marathon sum mation in the Tate murder trial today by telling the jury that Manson was not guilty of any crime.

title: Taylor Says by Yamashita Ruling Westmoreland May Be Guilty
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 8Tel ford Taylor, former chief Unit ed States prosecutor at the Nu remberg trials, has declared that Gen. William C. West moreland, the Army Chief of Staff, might be convicted as a war criminal if war crimes standards established during World War II were applied to his conduct of the war in Viet nam.

title: Flies to Cataline
description: AVALON, Calif., Jan. 8 (UPI) President Nixon flew to Catalina Island today. He was accompanied on the twotour excursion 40 miles across the Pacific by his daughter, Tricia, 21, and a friend, Charles G. Rebozo of Key Biscayne, Fla.

title: 12 FAST ATOM SUBS ORDERED BY NAVY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) The Navy awarded multimillion dollar contracts to two com panies today for construction of a new class of highspeed, nu clearpowered attack subma rines.

title: Alcoa Expansion Cited
description: TOKYO, Jan. 8 (Reuters)A spokesman for the Furukawa Industrial Group said today the Aluminum Company of Amer ica wants to build a joint alum inum smelting venture in Okin awa, which is expected to re vert to Japan next year.

title: Brains Are Not Surplus
description: It is a devastating commentary on the aimlessness of American society that expert assessments of graduate education find university scholarship at a highwater mark of quality and simultaneously declare Ph.D.'s a sur plus commodity. Shorn of all statistical jargon, the mes sage flashed to able young people is that it may not pay for them to invest in the refinement of their intellectual talents.

title: Bucks Present a Challenge to the Knicks
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 8 Last spring, the Milwaukee Bucks acquired Oscar Robert son, often regarded as the best guard ever to play in the Na tional Basketball Association, from the Cincinnati Royals for Flynn Robinson and Charlie Paulk, a rookie center. The Bucks, although they had draft ed Lew Alcindor the year be fore, felt that to put together a championship team they needed a backcourt man of Robertson's ability and expe rience.

title: SITDOWNS REPORTED AT GDANSK SHIPYARD
description: WARSAW, Jan. 8 Reports reaching Warsaw tonight indi cated that shipyard workers in the northern coastal city of Gdansk had been conducting minor work stoppages in recent days.

title: A Warning to the Democrats
description: The Democratic party today is a party without iceas. It suffers from the Chicago Syndrome, a notion that Dem ocrats should concentrate on unify ing themselves and do nothing which, might arouse again the passions of the 1968 Convention. New policies are the first casualties. The modest gains at the midterm elections, part of a his torical pattern, have not appreciably changed this approach. Presidential politics in the next year may do so.

title: Negro on G.M. Board Ready for Challenge
description: I don't expect to go in as any Sir Galahad. I'm no Martin Luther King. I'm just a plain fellow out of West Virginia.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  A high school team physician, alarmed at the number of leg injuries to football, hockey and lacrosse players, has invented a hydraulic de vice to protect the knee joint. Dr. Joseph P. Viglione of Stroudsburg, Pa., was granted Patent 3,551,912 this week for what he calls the hydrolig, a name derived from hydraulic and ligament. Plastic sheeting around the knee contains a quantity of water or other liquid. The shock of a blow against one side is neutralized by its distribution to the other side.

title: RICHMAN CALLED A VIOLENT SCHOOL
description: Julia Richman High School, at Second Avenue and 67th Street, was described yesterday as undergoing a frightening period of escalating violence and of being clearly on the brink of complete chaos.

title: Labor Bids Congress Set $2anHour Minimum Wage
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI) Organized labor said today that it would make a strong fight in the 92d Congress to get the present intolerable $1.60anhour minimum wage raised to $2 and extended to about 13 million workers not now covered.

title: Three Shows Are Closing
description: Lovely Ladies, Kind Gentle men, the musical based on John Patrick's The Teahouse of the August Moon, will give its 16th and final performance at the Majestic Theater tonight. Foreplay closes tomorrow at the Bijou after 38 perform ances, and Light, Lively and Yiddish also leaves the boards tomorrow at the Belasco after completing 88 performances.

title: Democrats Score Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI) Democrats jumped on the unemployment rate rise today to renew attacks on President Nixon's economic policies and his veto last month of a multi billiondollar manpower train ing bill.

title: Cunningham Discloses Signing by 76ers, Charges Cougars Breached Pact
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 (AP) Billy Cunningham, the all star forward of the Philadelphia 76ers, has signed a fiveyear contract with the National Bas ketball Association team, and his lawyer said today the play er's agreement to jump next season to the American Bas ketball Association had been breached by the Carolina Cou gars.

title: Evans Lowers World Indoor Mark for 500 Run With 54.4Second Clocking
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 8  A 27yearold haematolo gist named Del Meriwether, who first took up track and field last summer, joined such familiar heroes as Lee Evans, Tom Van Ruden and John Ma son in the victory circle tonight at the National invitation track meet.

title: Russian Sub Tender That Stirred Capital Quits Cuban Waters
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Four Soviet naval vessels, including a submarine tender whose ar rival at Cienfuegos, Cuba, alarmed official Washington last fall, have reportedly left Cuba, apparently on their way home.

title: Most Still Oppose Corona Home Deal, Battista Declares
description: Assemblyman Vito P. Battis ta said yesterday that most homeowners affected by the city's lastminute Corona com promise were against it and willing to fight further for their interests.

title: Layoffs at Sikorsky
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 8 (AP)  The Sikorsky division of the United Aircraft Corpo ration will lay off 200 produc tion employes, the company said today. Sikorsky, the largest single employer in the Bridge port area, has 8,000 workers. Two years ago it had 10,500.

title: Antiques: An Ornate Italian Table
description: A great carved, painted and gilded neoclassicalstyle table in the Masterpieces of 50 Centuries exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum ought to prove to doubters that Italian furniture can be as fine as the Best French and English work.

title: SEATTLE 7 BAIL SET BY APPEALS COURT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ordered today that the Seattle 7 conspiracy defendants be freed on $25,000 bail apiece. The court rejected a Govern ment contention that freeing them would be a danger to the community.

title: Libraries Combat Rising Book Thefts
description: A rising rate of book thefts from college and public li braries across the nation is forcing the institutions to take costly and elaborate measures to combat the problem.

title: Bengtson Is Appointed Charger Defense Aide
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 8 (UPI) Phil Bengtson, who quit as head coach and general man ager of the Green Bay Pack ers three days before Christ mas was named tonight as defensive coach of the San Diego Chargers.

title: Sibyl MoholyNagy, Architectural Critic, Is Dead
description: Sibyl MoholyNagy, an archi tectural critic, writer and teach er and widow of the painter, Laszlo MoholyNagy, died yes terday in New York Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived at 330 East 33d Street.

title: MINERS FUNERALS PRODUCE CRITICISM
description: HYDEN, Ky., Jan. 8 (UPI) Judge George Wooton of Leslie County today denounced as outrageous the cost of funer als for the 38 miners killed in an explosion at the Finley Coal Company mine on Dec. 30.

title: CONNECTICUT PUTS JOBLESS AT 8.1%
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 8Unem ployment in heavily industrial Connecticut has climbed past 8 per cent, a spokesman for the state's Labor Department said today.

title: Rutgers Ends Automatic Policy Of Evacuation in Bomb Threats
Soprano and Tenor To Make Debuts At Met Next Month
description: Catarina Ligendza, a Swedish soprano, and Josef Gabriels, a tenor from the Union of South Africa, will make their Metro politan Opera debuts during the 21st week of the company's season.

title: Jewish Defense League Denies, But Won't Condemn, Bombing
description: Never again!, the motto of the militant Jewish Defense League, was one of the slo gans shouted in a telephone call to a news agency in Wash ington yesterday after the So viet Embassy's cultural build ing had been bombed. The call er also said: This is a sample of things to come. Let our peo ple go!

title: Campaign Contributors Concealed in a Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) The chairman of a special House panel that is investigat ing campaign spending used a hidden committee in the na tion's capita to conceal the names of donors who gave him $12,000 last yearwhen he was unopposed for reelection.

title: An Alliance of Students and Workers?
description: Those who would divide usstu dent from worker and worker from studentare committing a crime against society. Those who succumb to this shallow line of separation are playing into the hands of demagogues who would exploit our few differences for their own political or psychological purposes.

title: WINGS'
description: DETROIT, Jan. 8 (UPI)The Detroit Red Wings, shaken by the sudden resignation of Sid Abel, announced today that their firstyear coach, Ned Harkness, had been shifted to Abel's job as general manager of the National Hockey League team.

title: Retailers Cope With Inventory
description: Merchants are gradually Making more progress in cop ing with the typical 500,000 different items in their stores and with the daily transac tions of thousands of shop pers.

title: F.T.C. Chief Speaks Out on Ads
description: Miles W. Kirkpatrick, the new chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said yester day he often found advertising uninformative, insulting, taw dry, tasteless and a bad re flection of American business.

title: MRS. KY DENIES BID FOR LAND IS ILLEGAL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 8 (UPI)Mrs. Nguyen Cao Ky, wife of South Vietnam's Vice President, said today that her plans to acquire 3,600 acres of farmland in the Central High lands free of charge had been misunderstood.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Stage: Isaac Enchants
description: Without any qualification The Last Sweet Days of Isaac, now in its second sea son at the East Side Play house, is a most engaging musical. It is always difficult to return to a musicalany musical.

title: Hofstra Five Wins, 9636
description: WOLFVILLE, Nova Scotia, Jan. 8 (AP)Hofstra defeated Dahousie University of Halifax, 9636 tonight in the opening game of the annual Bluenose Classic basketball tournament. Rich Link led Hofstra with 19 points.

title: A Dream of a Job If You're a Nurse And Unattached
description: There are at least two single women in town who don't go around complaining that they never get a chance to meet men in their jobs.

title: HEALTH COSTS SET AT $793MILLION
description: The city's new Health and Hospital Corporation submitted its first expense budget to they Mayor and the Budget Director yesterday, saying it planned to spend more money next year at less cost to the city.

title: News Analysis
description: Remember John Lindsay's angry denunciation of the power brokerswhom he de fined as those labor leaders who entered City Hall through the back doorand Michael Quill's fiery fulminations against Mayor Lindsley?

title: Mrs. Johnson Is Appointed To Regents at U. of Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 8 (UPI) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson, wife of the former President, was named today to the University of Texas Board of Regents, ef fective immediately.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Jan. 8Senator Edmund Muskie was having lunch in the cellar restaurant of the Grosvenor House, London, the other day when the waiter brought a bottle of champagne. It had been sent by a man eating at a table across the way. The Senator went over to say thanks.

title: The Next Moves for the Peace Movement
description: American planes once again are murdering North Vietnamese. Through out Indochina, B52's now drop the equivalent of 2 Hiroshimas a month. Some day the war may end, but there is no more reason now to believe it will end than there was in 1965, 1967 or 1968.

title: GLEN COVE ORDERED NOT TO TAX RUSSIANS
description: A Brooklyn Federal judge issued an injunction yesterday restraining the City of Glen Cove, L. I., from auctioning off the 36acre estate now oc cupied by members of the So viet Union's United Nation's delegation.

title: Merger News
description: The USLIFE Corporation an nounced late yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the North American Life Insurance Com pany of Chicago through a tax free plan under the Illinois In surance Code.

title: RICHARD KERR, RADIO PERFORMER
description: Richard Kollmar, former ac tor and theatrical producer, who was the husband of the late Dorothy Kilgallen, the news paper columnist and radio and television personality, died Thursday in his sleep at his home, 45 East 68th Street, ap parently of a heart attack. He was 60 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pentagon Disputes Study Of Spraying Devastation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The Defense Department denied to day that there was conclusive evidence that the United States Army defoliation programs had been as catastrophic for South Vietnam as alleged in a recent study for the American Asso ciation for the Advancement of Science.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Travelers Corpo ration announced yester day the appointment of Morrison H. Beach as president and chief ad ministrative officer, and the election of Roger C. Wilkins as chairman.

title: Turning On for Fun
description: When the question, Why do kids smoke marijuana? is asked of some one society calls an expert on drugs typically, a local policeman, a gym or health teacher, or general practi tionerthe expected answer is sup posed to sound something like this: 1) marijuana use is an escape from reality; 2) kids today are troubled, frightened, insecure, and grass is a misplaced effort at solving problems; 3) smoking marijuana is an egoboost for youngsters with weak egos and a low selfesteem; 4) when a kid is depressed, when he's in trouble, when he can't handle the complexities of lifehe reaches for a joint; 5) mari juana use is a product of a too per missive society; 6) smoking mari juana is a result of social pressure, desire to be fashionable, to be in the swim; 7) smoking grass is a form of rebellion, of shocking one's parents, a desire to do something daring and

title: AIRLINES TO BORROW FROM BRITISH BANKS
description: A syndicate of six British banks agreed yesterday to lend $141  million to four airlines to finance the acquisition of Rolls Royce RB 211 engines for the Lockheed Aircraft Corpo ration's L1011.

title: Harrison Smith of the Saturday Review is Dead
description: Harrison Smith, retired presi dent of the Saturday Re view and a wellknown figure in the literary world, died yes terday in White Plains's New York Hospital, where he had been a patient for fouranda years.

title: Congress Added $6.6Billion to Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The Congress that just ended, by actions and inactions on spend ing and revenue bills, added $6.6billion to the budget defi cit, a final scorekeeping report disclosed today.

title: Too Much Gravy Market Place: With Potatoes
description: Jules Salzbank is accus tomed to crowds.

title: Harlem Police Station Turned Into a Temporary Art Museum
description: The basement of the 32d Precinct police station, 250 West 135th Street, looked yes terday like an exhibition room at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Tobacco Men Bar Evasion of TV Ad Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The tobacco and broadcasting in dustries promised today to obey the spirit as well as the letter of the new law barring cigarette advertising from tele vision and radio.

title: Oil Trailer Spills Cargo and Blocks Brooklyn Highway
description: A onemile stretch of the Brooklyn  Queens Expressway was closed from 11 P.M. Thurs day until almost 9 A.M. yester day after thousands of gallons of thick fuel oil spilled from an overturned tank trailer.

title: DOW SLIPS BY 0.82 AS VOLUME DROPS Decline in Index to 837.01 Brings Loss for Week to Just Under 2 Points VOLUME IS 14.1 MILLION Winners Exceed Losers by 717 to 681, While Highs Top Lows, 115 to 2
Bing Sparks Pistons
description: DETROIT, Jan. 8 (AP)Dave Bing scored 13 of his 31 points in the final quarter tonight to lead the Detroit Pistons to a 115109 victory over the Cin cinnati Royals.

title: Guerrillas Report Big Jordanian Attack
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 8 The Jordanian Army began to day a sweep against Palestinian commandos in a large area north of Amman, shelling guer rilla bases, arresting the com mandos and confiscating their weapons, according to guerrilla statements.

title: Family With Its Own Playgroundon the Roof
description: In good weather, 2year old Brooke Siler, her carrot red hair blowing in the wind, is likely to be flying around her own private playground on a little bicycle, or chug ging along in a toy plastic train with several small friends in tow, while her 7 yearold brother, Matthew, concentrates on hopscotch or improvised stoop ball or roller skate hockey with his friends, or with his older stepbrothers.

title: Queens Halts Coast Guard
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 8 (AP)Queens College, trail ing until the final minute, con verted a 3point play and a foul shot tonight to top Coast Guard, 5149.

title: Print Show Is Seen at Cultural Center
description: The New York Cultural Center, that esthetic refresh ment stand in the vast desert of Columbus Circle, has start ed the New Year with three exhibitionsa print show, The Epoch of L'Estampe Originale; a thing show, of objects from the Cooper Hewitt Museum of Decora tive Arts and Design; and Modular II a conceptual display in the lobby by an Australian artist, Robert Jacks, that can be seen with out paying the $1 entrance fee. Since the two other shows are worth it, however, you might as well pay it and go right upstairs.

title: AMISH EXEMPTED FROM SCHOOL LAW
description: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 8 The Wisconsin Supreme Court ruled today that forcing Amish children to attend public schools violated their constitu tional right of freedom of re ligion.

title: Percentage Drops
description: Stocks with the largest per centage losses on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday:

title: Atlanta Reserve Cuts Rate
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta yesterday joined the 10 Reserve banks that on Thurs day cut the discount rate  point to 5 per cent. Only the Dallas bank remains at the for mer level.

title: Businessman Is Convicted in Stolen Art Case
description: A Denver businessman ac cused of having transported art works stolen from a Colorado ranch house to New York City was convicted in Federal Dis trict Court here yesterday.

title: THOMAS TROXELL, 75, INVESTMENT OFFICER
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 8  Thomas Franklin Troxell, who retired in 1957 as a vice president of Dillon Read & Co., investment securities, died to day in Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge. He was 75 years old and lived at 46 Llewellyn Road.

title: Duvalier Hints That His Son Is Heir to Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  President Francois Duvalier of Haiti has publicly hinted that his son, Jean Claude, a 20 yearold firstyear law student, will succeed him as President on his death.

title: Another Candidate For Top S.E.C. Post
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Add James T. Lynn, the Commerce Department's general counsel, to the list of candidates for the chairmanship, of the Secu rities and Exchange Commis sion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Fund Will Purchase Tickets for Dream
description: The Theater Development Fund will buy up to $30,000 worth of tickets to the Peter Brook  Royal Shakespeare Company production of A Midsummer Night's Dream, which opens Jan. 18 at the Billy Rose Theater. The play is being presented for a limited run by the David Merrick Arts Foundation.

title: New Issues Post Sharp Increases On Quality List
description: Highquality new stock issues posted sharp advances in re cent days, but lowgrade issues showed little movement.

title: ANNOUNCEMENT DUE IN APRIL ON TROOPS
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 8 (Reuters)The White House said today that. President Nixon would announce in midApril new troop withdrawals from South Vietnam.

title: British Panel Upholds Expulsion of Rudi Dutschke as Security Risk
description: LONDON, Jan. 8In a de cision with profound implica tions for British law and the tradition of asylum, Rudi Dutschke was told today that he was not welcome in this country.

title: Canadian Champion 11th
description: Betsy Clifford of Canada, the defending World Cup giant sla lom champion, was 11th.

title: CANADIAN BANKS CUT PRIME RATE
description: TORONTO, Jan. 8 (AP)  Canada's five major banks an nounced today that they would reduce their prime rate from 7 per cent to 7 per cent and cut the interest rate paid on certain savings accounts from 5 per cent to 5 per cent.

title: Danish Youth Seriously Hurt When He Swallows Rocket
description: AARHUS, Denmark, Jan. 8 (AP)  Vagn Larsen, 17 years old was in a hospital in serious condition today after acciden tally swallowing a small card board rocket that fired in his mouth, went down his gullet and exploded in his chest.

title: Top American Takes 2d In CrossCountry Skiing
PENNSY IS SEEKING $110MILLION LOAN
description: An underwriting group, head ed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, tentatively is going forward with plans for marketing two issues of trustee certificates totaling $110mil lion for Penn Central Transpor tation Company.

title: DR. KYLE HILL
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 8 Dr. Kyle Hill of 151 Cathedral Avenue, a retired pediatrician who had practiced here since 1931, died Wednesday in Bruns wick Hospital Center. His age was 72.

title: Buckley Staff Gets to Work in Old Murphy Suite
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 Senatorelect James L. Buck ley, who has vowed to take office with a clean slate, has acquired at least two ele ments of the pastCharles E. Goodell's old telephone number and George Murphy's shillelagh.

title: Brown Routs Cornell
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 8 Russ Tyler, the team captain, and Arnie Berman scored 27 and 26 points, respectively, in leading Brown University's basketball team to an 8168 victory over Cornell tonight in an Ivy League game before 2,000 fans in the Marvel Gym nasium.

title: MISS JACOT FIRST IN GIANT SLALOM
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles DuBois Coryell Is Dead; Chemist Worked on Atom Bomb
description: BOSTON, Jan. 8Dr. Charles DuBois Coryell, a leading nu clear chemist and professor of chemistry at the Massachu setts Institute of Technology since 1946, died yesterday of cancer in New England Dea coness Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in East gate, Cambridge.

title: G.E. THREATENS LAYOFF OF 1,400 Jobs of 10% of Pittsfield Plant Staff in Danger
description: The jobs of more than 10 per cent of the 11,000 employes at the General Electric Company's electric power transformer plant at Pittsfield, Mass., are in danger because of foreign imports, Charles Meloun, vice president and general manager, said yesterday.

title: BrazilEximbank Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI) Brazil and the ExportImport Bank of the United States have signed a contract involving over $25.5million to help in the construction of Brazil's first subway, to be located in so Paulo.

title: Funds Flow Into London
description: LONDON, Jan. 8 (Reuters) Foreign money flowed into London today as currency in vestors turned their dollars and other funds into pounds to take advantage of Britain's more at tractive interest rate.

title: Ties Between Cuba and Vatican Said to Improve
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 9 (UPI) A Mexican Catholic lay organization says that Cuba and the Vatican are drawing closer despite difficulties of the Roman Catholic Church under the Government of Premier Fidel Castro.

title: Cruise Passengers Safe in Barbados After Rescue
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Jan. 9Passengers and crew members from the French Line's cruise liner Antilles ar rived here today after a har rowing night of rescue from their flaming ship.

title: Retailers Gearing Up for a Year of HardSell
description: Although inflation is likely to hold down the purchasing power of consumers in 1971, they probably will be courted more avidly than ever by sellers, marketing men be lieve.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: BRANDON, Vt.The wild American paradise of upper New England is being briskly recolonized.

title: Chess
description: THE recent 24man interzonal in Majorca, Spain, featuring the world's best chess players, was spotty in form. The goal of every starter was at least sixth, sufficient to qualify for the 1971 elimination matches the next step in the world title test.

title: Control by Brain Studied As Way to Curb Body Ills
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 The patient sits in a hospital bed in Baltimore, watching three little lights arranged like a traffic signalred on top, yellow in the middle green on the bottom.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Any house wife buying groceries for her family these days must be groggy from trying to figure out what not to put on her shopping list. In the last year, headlines have proclaimed mercury in fish, botu lism in pizzas, pesticides in tur keys, arsenic in chickens, anti biotics in cheese, hormones in meat, salmonella in soup, cyclo mates in soft drinks and DDT in practically everything.

title: Rubin's TaxExempt Foundation Target of I.R.S. Legal Move
description: The Internal Revenue Service has moved to revoke the tax exempt status of a private foundation set up by Jerry Rubin, the Yipple leader.

title: KENT STATE VICTIMS SUEFOR$15.5MILLION
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 9 (UPI) Seven civil suitsincluding two by residents of upstate New Yorkasking a total of about $15.5million in damages have been filed in Federal District Court in Cleveland in connec tion with the shooting deaths of four students and wounding of nine others at Kent State University last May 4.

title: M'MULLEN FIRST IN SKI JUMPOFF
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 9  Twentytwoyearold Andre McMullen, who learned to ski jump as a youth in Eau Claire, Wis., showed them how today as he won the Norsemen ski jumping tournament.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: You plainly sought to honor The Pentagon of Power (Dec. 13) by choosing Prof. Ger ald Holton of Harvard to review it. Had you asked me, I could not have hit upon a scholar seemingly better prepared to cope with my book and do just ice to its original contributions. If I had been told he would for once abandon his salutary prac tice of never reviewing a book by a friend, I would have been specially pleased because of the assurance that The Penta gon of Power would come under the scrutiny of a mind primed to take in as a whole my delicately modulated and carefully articulated summation of modern man's technological predicament.

title: Columbus Club to Cite Stan at Feb. 5 Dinner
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 9 (UPI)  Bart Starr of the Green Bay Packers Is to be one of the quarterbacks hon ored by the Columbus Touch down Club at its 16th annual allsports dinner Feb. 5.

title: Casper to Be Honored For Service to Golf
description: Billy Casper, one of three pro golfers who have won more than $1million in purses, will receive the Gold Tee Award of the Metropoli tan Golf Writers Association at their annual dinner Feb. 16.

title: Reader's Report
description: A good title thisfor its heroine is usually naked, and with reason. The reason is sexual intercourse, which a young English girl discovers early on is her true vocation. So it's hurrah for John, James, Adrian, Rex, Ned, Evan, Lowry, Michael, Cedric, Mr. Hobbs, Pro fessor Threadand Ellie's nameless clients, when she turns briefly professional. Ac tually, the naked reasoner feels that the magic number of bed buddies one should have at any one time is ideally six. (This is my love mathematics) Why such conscientious copulation? I thought you'd never ask. El lie's aim is sex without pos sessiveness. She seeks to evolve a practice of joy, with out passions and outbursts. Something on a level with the satisfaction granted by a belch, perhaps.

title: Country Lawyer from Harvard
description: WILBUR D. MILLS . . . brilliant and industrious . . . one of a handful of men in the House of Representa tives who is. . . He does little except work. . . . Few have known where the Arkansas Democrat would stand on an issue until he, himself, de cided to disclose his inten tions . . . fundamentally con servative . . . but he can move to the left when circum stances dictate. . . . For ex ample, he stopped opposing Medicare when it became evident that his Ways and Means Committee would override him. . . . Avoiding visible defeat, either in the committee or on the House floor, sometimes seems his highest priority. . . He has great influence on the tax, tariff, Social Security and welfare legislation that must go through his committee. . . often because he knows more about these subjects than anyone else in Congress. . . He will be the eighthranking member of the new House, having been first elected to Congress at 29, but at 61 he is not among the ancients. . . . In manner, a country lawyer . . . charming when he chooses. . . . He can tell good story about the home folks in Arkansas . . . always visi ble is the combination of his two alma maters, Hendrix College and Harvard Law School.

title: Gardens
description: IN his move out of urban areas to more rural ones, man tampers with the thing he seeks to be closest tothe natural en vironment. All animal life is in need of the same basic requirements to survive food, shelter and water. Man can aid his wildlife neighbors in survival by reintroducing into the landscape the plants that will furnish food and shelter especially for the critical period  late fall through winter to early spring when snow and ice prevail and few insects and fruits available.

title: GREENWOOD GETS LEAD BY 3 SHOTS
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 Bobby Greenwood, a sopho more on the Professional Golf ers Association tour, moved to the front today in the third round of the $110,000 Glen CampbellLos Angeles open tourney. The 32yearold blond professional from Cookeville, Tenn. (80 miles east of Nash ville) led the field by three strokes with a 54hole aggre gate of 204.

title: Economic Impasse
description: The unemployment rate climbed to 6 per cent last month, though the General Motors strike had ended three weeks before the survey was taken. As a Bureau of Labor Statistics official said, the jobless trend has been steadily upward since August. And, with slow growth (or continued recession) in prospect, no turn in that trend is yet in sight.

title: Immobilized Trailer Taxed
description: BOSTON, Jan. 9 (AP)A mobile home, ordinarily subject to automobile license fees and taxes, becomes subject to real estate taxes if its wheels are removed and it is mounted on a foundation with a cellar under it, the State Supreme Judicial Court ruled this week.

title: Executives Hurry to Retire (and Start All Over Again)
description: By the end of the 1970's thousands of business execu tives in their late 40's and early 50's may be retiring with sizable pensions and em barking on new careers.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON  The magnificent American Interstate Highway System, the cost of which has risen toward $80 million, is now nearing completion. On any rational timetable, this is about ten years behind time, since these great highways essentially were the transportation system most required for the 40's and 50's. Consequently, the nation also is running ten or more years behind in developing the modern urban transit and rapid intercity trans it systems that are the next necessary stage in American transportation.

title: DISPUTE ERODING INDIANEPAL TIES
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 9  Rela tions between India and neigh boring Nepal are deteriorating as a dispute over a new trade and transit treaty drags on.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OLIVER, RODRIGUEZ TOP CAR QUALIFIERS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 9 (AP) Jackie Oliver of Britain and Pedro Rodriguez of Mexico, driving a Porsche 9I7P, beat a Ferrari team from Italy in the closing heats today and estab lished the fastest qualifying time for the Argentine 1,000 kilometer (621.37mile) sports prototype auto race tomorrow.

title: Mr. Nixon on Vietnam
description: President Nixon sees the United States as half out of Vietnam by summer and the war winding down; he de scribes this as his Administration's major achievement to date. His critics see the United States still half in Viet nam, with more than a quartermillion American troops there, andas the Times of London recently concluded in a detailed analysisno end to the war in sight.

title: A flutter of chiffons
description: There's a fresh fashion breeze blowing in from England, and it's bringing a new look for 1971. In onceswinging London, the fashion pendu lum has stopped at soft. Two of London's most avantgarde designers, Zandra Rhodes and Ossie Clark, are turning out fluttery, fem inine, transparent chiffon prints. (Zandra de signs and prints her own, Ossie's are designed by his wife. Celia Birtwell.) English birds have added their stillswinging touch  they wear these transparencies over little or no thing at all. Are we ready?

title: Scott, Martin Win Title
description: BOSTON, Jan. 9  Eugene Scott of New York and Alastair Martin of Bedford, N. Y., cap tured the United States open court tennis championship to day by defeating Jimmy Dunn and William Voight of Philadel phia by 64, 65, 64. Dunn, a former Davis Cup player, and Martin settled down to run off five games in a row.

title: Small Prize Money Is Keeping Schranz From Pro Skiing Ranks
description: ST. ANTON, AustriaIs Karl Schranz, the old master of the Austrian ski team, ready to turn pro? The answer is yesbut for a guarantee of about $200,000 for three years.

title: Scheel Plans to Visit U.S.; Brandt Maps a Trip Later
description: BONN, Jan. 9Foreign Mini ster Walter Scheel of West Germany is expected to fly to Washington in February, fol lowing a brief visit in London, it was announced today.

title: Sexual swinger, social prude, son of France
description: A popular biography of Prosper Merimee? If modern readers know Merimee at all, it's because they've read Mateo Falcone in second year Frenchand probably hated it. Yet, unexpectedly, from A. W. Raitt's pages emerges one of the most ab sorbing figures of the Romantic century.

title: PITTSBURGH PACT WON BY TEACHERS
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 9 (UPI) The striking Pittsburgh Feder aion of Teachers and city school officials reached agree ment on a tentative contract today.

title: the traveler's world
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Our trial run of the threecountry tour of East Africa organized by East African Airways to inaugurate its new onestop, sameplane service between New York and East Africa started in this capital city of half a mil lion a scant 100 miles south of the Equator. East Africa is not a political entity but a common market of three sovereign countries, Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania, with related economic, polit ical and development problems and a customs union that does not, unfortu nately, prevent complete immigration and customs inspections each time the tourist crosses from one country to the other.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThe Fed eral Government, without in tending anything particularly wicked, is currently engaged in a spirited exercise in gamesmanship.

title: MASTROIANNI MAKES LOCAL PIANO DEBUT
description: Although he was born in Pittsburgh and studied here at the Juilliard School, Thomas Owen Mastroianni has largely confined his American concert izing to the Midwest, and only now has come around to mak ing his New York debut.

title: Betty C. Tankersley to Be Married
description: SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, Jan. 9Mr. and Mrs. George Tankersley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Carol Tankersley, to Henry Clark Harvey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9People who work in the White House usually say pleasant and generous things about the President, even when he drives and torments them, as President John son did, but there is something both sad and insistent about the official praise for President Nixon on his 58th birthday.

title: MRS. MILTON TROOSLIN
description: WEST ORANGE, Jan. 9Mrs. Charlotte Lamchick Trooslin. who had been an editor for Popular Library, Inc., and the Ace Publishing Corporation, both in New York, died today in St. Barnabas Medical Cen ter, Livingston. She was 61 years old and lived at 17 Gavin Road.

title: KAYHKO CAPTURES LAKE PLACID JUMP
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 9 A warming trend, in which the thermometer jumped from 20 below zero to 20 above in less than a dozen hours, en abled officials of the annual masters ski jumping tourna ment to stage their annual in ternational event today on schedule.

title: Commodity Futures Trading Expected to Rise Again
Army Enlisted Men Getting a Time Limit to Move Up in Rank or Move Out
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The Defense Department disclosed today a new program under which Army enlisted men must move up or move out.

title: Sallie B. Ayers Will Be Wed
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., Jan. 9Mr. and Mrs. Gregory Smith Prince have made known the engagement of Mrs. Prince's daughter, Miss Sallie Brownell Ayers, to Stephen Kilbourne Barker. His parents sire Mr. and Mrs. James Sherman Barker of Concord, N. H., and Heron Island, Me. A June wedding is planned.

title: Rhoads Post First Victory As Golf Pro on 71 for 209
description: SALINAS, Calif., Jan. 9 (AP) Ron Rhoads, a 29yearold as sistant club pro from West Los Angeles, finished with a one underpar 71 today and won his first Professional Golfers Association tournament.

title: Leger: He Bit Into Reality
description: Art in London

title: Music
description: IF this is Beethoven's bicen tenary, a Wagner Year may soon commemorate the first performances of The Ring at Bayreuth in 1876. His works have not lost their megalithic popular ity, except with Mr. Bing and with the pundits who man age the Bolshoi; they remain the backbone of the reper toire of almost every opera house. A couple of years ago the relatively small city of Venice scheduled (outside the tourist season) three cycles of The Ring, as is the cus tom also in Buenos Aires. Where do we stand with the staging of Wagner after the revolutionary experiments of his grandsons?

title: Mrs. Grant Warns Stores on Signs
description: Mrs. Bess Myerson Grant, the city's Consumer Affairs Com missioner, handed out warnings to Times Square discount stores yesterday that they were vio lating a new regulation when they put signs like Watches $2.98 and up in their windows.

title: Reader's Report
description: When you learn at the outset of this new novel by Elizabeth Cadell that pretty, perky Emma Challis is engaged to a young prig of a lawyer, you wonder how long the mismating is going to last. Well sir, it's going to last right down to page 218, because Miss Cadell is a thrifty hand at plotting, putting only a few characters in motion and making the most of their sentimental predicaments. But why am I telling you all this? Is not the author's name almost a guarantee of a good natured romantic fantasy? Of course. And is not this one the best of her multivolume oeuvre? Yes, indeed. Exotic places, a sympathetic ingenue and juve nile, a sprinkling of crotchety supporting players and a hap py endingthat's the recipe here. If it isn't your kind of novel, you can reread Story of O for all I care.

title: What Has Two Skis, Tank Treads
description: MINNEAPOLISGone is the silence and the sanctity of the deep north woods. This winter more than 200,000 snowmobilesthose raucous matings of two short skis with an outboard motor and tank treadsare churning over hundreds of miles of marked trails and rattling down side streets of small towns all across Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Upon reading the article by Lawrence Dame entitled Along Jamaica's Back  a Bush Trail (Travel section, Dec. 6), I had one mental re action: unmeasured incredu lity; and one vocal reaction: Really?

title: In Brief
description: William Saroyan has written a journal about Paris and Fresno and writing and getting on. It is slight and pleasant and touching in its randomness. Mr. Saroyan tells of sunflower shoplifting from a Paris public garden so there will be a big, bright blossom outside his win dow, along with the basil, tar ragon and rosemary he grows there to flavor Armenian dishes. He indulges in rhapsodic praise of turnip greens in lamb broth. He writes of his dentist, his ulcer and his children, his youthful endeavors as a newsboy, the grapevines of Cal ifornia, the notable men who died young, and the others like Shaw and Verdi, who still produced masterpieces in their seventies.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Things to Wear With Pants
description: The nation's merchants are hoping that millions of Amer icans this spring will respond with enthusiasm to pants, pants, pants, to accessories for pants, easycare fabrics, and a full spectrum of knitted garments from tex tured tops for women to knitted suits for men.

title: The Senate v. Alan and Margaret Mcsurely
Egyptian Criticizes U.S.
description: PARIS, Jan. 9Foreign Min ister Mahmoud Riad of the United Arab Republic said at a news conference here today that he had encountered very good understanding from the French, British and Soviet Gov ernments in his latest mission to persuade the Big Four to force Israel to withdraw from Arab territories she has occu pied since the war of June, 1967.

title: A NOVEL CONCERT BY BESSIE JONES
description: Bessie Jones, a leader of the Georgia Sea Island Singers, came north this weekend with Just one Georgia voice, Bessie Burk, to support her in her traditional songs, ring games, shouts and spirituals. But at a concert sponsored by the New York Pinewoods Folk Music Club on Friday night at the Oval Room, 13 Astor Place, that was all the support she needed.

title: Parsons College Decides To Drop Varsity Football
description: FAIRFIELD, Iowa, Jan. 9 (UPI)Parsons College officials anounced today that they would suspend all varsity foot ball competition effective Feb. 1.

title: Geibink, Wendy Naas Take Peru Cup in Orvis Slalom
description: BROMLEY, Vt., Jan. 9 (AP) Tim Geibink of Middlebury Col lege, Wendy Naas of Hartland, Wis., and James McCluskey posted victories today in the opening races of the 24th Louise Orvis slalom ski derby on Brom ley Mountain.

title: U.S. Says ATest Leak Caused No Harm to Life
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 9 (AP)A top Government sci entist says no humans, ani mals or plants were harmed by airborne radiation that drifted across 12 western states after an underground nuclear blast Dec. 18.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  As Presi dent Nixon's discussion of world affairs showed last week, where there's trouble in the world, there's usually some kind of understanding supposedly covering the conduct and mis conduct of contending nations. And where there's an under standing, there's trouble.

title: CAROLINA BLACKS PRESS DEMOCRATS
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 9 Negro political leaders in South Carolina laid the groundwork this week for a Black Demo cratic Caucus to provide a uni fied political voice for Negro Democrats in the state.

title: Bench Is Voted Player of Year And Will Get Mercer Award
description: Johnny Bench of the Cincin nati Reds, already voted the Most Valuable Player in the National League for 1970, was named the winner of the Sid Mercer Award yesterday as the player of the year by New York's baseball writers.

title: Flyers Top Seals, 53
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 (AP)  The Philadelphia Flyers downed the California Golden Seals, 53, today and remained in fourth place in the National Hockey League, West Division.

title: Balance of Payments: No Easy Solution
description: WASHINGTON  The United States balance of in ternational payments in 1970 was characterized by an other deficit, continued gravely worded discussion, but no crisis. The outlook for 1971 is more of the same.

title: RHODESIA'S ASIANS FIGHT HOUSING BILL
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 9 (Agence FrancePresse)  Asians and people of mixed race in Rhodesia plan to use every legal means at their dis posal to oppose the introduc tion in Parliament of a bill that would allow residents of predominantly white suburbs to petition the Government to evict Asians and persons of mixed race from the suburbs.

title: At Space Centers, Jobs Disappear
description: The economy here is not as had as people say, Paul Fusillo, a usedcar dealer in Melbourne, Fla., not far from the Kennedy Space Center, said recently. Now we just have to work harder. It used to come easy.

title: Herbert Hoover told Adolph Ochs to hire that man
description: Turner Catledge is alive and well and living, as he says, in a high degree of comfort in New Orleans. Although he won't be 70 until March, he is already a legend among news papermen. He is the best story teller in the profession, one of the top political reporters during his years in Washington and was, for 25 years, as assistant managing editor, managing editor and then executive editor of The Times, the mahout who prodded that sometimes reluctant elephant into a faster pace.

title: I Can Teach You All the Japanese You'll Ever Need to Know
description: I COULD only stare. If I hadn't known Felderbaum I wouldn't have believed it. Sure, I still remember some of my college French and a little high school Germanplus a few sentences of prekindergarten Spanish. But Japa nese? The man was incredible.

title: Illinois Wins With Sophomores
description: CHAMPAIGN, III., Jan. 9 (UPI)Illinois opened its Big Ten basketball season today by sending a largely sophomore team to a commanding 8961 victory over Michigan State.

title: Foreign Aid Off as Need Rises
description: WASHINGTON  United States foreign aid to develop ing nations in 1971 will drop below $31billion for the first time since the start of the cooperative global develop ment effort in 1961.

title: Brown Subdues Columbia On Mat, Taking 7 Bouts
Taxes: Pollution Waeapons
description: Besides money raising, the taxing power of governments can cut two ways, either encouraging or deterring cer tain actions by taxpayers. One area of activity where taxes are playing an increas ing role these days on Fed eral, state and local levels either as the carrot or the stickis the mounting battle against pollution.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: PRESIDENT NIXON called for expansionary economic policies, said 1971 would be a good year and 1972 a very good year. . . . Manufacturers inventories in Novem ber rose $600million to record $100billion but consumer installment credit fell sharply, reflecting Generals Motors strike.

title: A Short Educational Dictionary
description: alphabet A set of arbitrary (q.v.) signs which children are still often compelled to learn by rote*; usual ly taught, moreover, in an arbi trary order. For the (equally arbi trary) methods long prescribed in joining these signs, see spelling.

title: pope Condemns Kidnappings
description: ROME, Jan. 9Pope Paul VI today condemned the kidnap ping of diplomatS as shameful blackmail.

title: Royals Hire Buchannon
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 9 (UPI) Bill W. Buchannon, formerly public relations director of Troy State (Ala.) University, has been named publicity direc tor of the Cincinnati Royals of the National Basketball Assocition. Buchannon, 39 years old, succeeds Roger Ruhl, who recently accepted a similar job with the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Pentagon Spending, Despite Troop Cuts, to Head Upward
description: WASHINGTONThe de fense budget, after two years of decline, appears headed upward once again. But sen ior Pentagon officials insist the higher spending level will pay for fewer soldiers, planes, tanks and ships than have been maintained in recent years.

title: 76ers Down Suns, 123112
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 (UPI) A combined 64point per formance by Archie Clark and Bill Cunningham plus Bailey Howell's big final quarter en abled the Philadelphia 76ers to rally for a 123112 victory over the Phoenix Suns tonight.

title: Miserable Year in Chemicals
description: Allied Chemical: 2,500; Celanese: 2,000; du Pont de Nemours: 4,000; Monsanto: 1,300.

title: Ken Hudson, N.B.A.'s Smallest Referee: A Tree Stump in a Valley of Redwoods
description: Probasketball fans and players must have had a good laugh when Ken Hudson first took the court, but the laughter soon turned to cursing and booing, That's the way Ken Hudson likes it.

title: Professor Gets Jail Term
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 9 (AP)  A professor, Robert Hum phreys, 37 years old, a former member of the faculty at South ern Illinois University, has been sentenced to four months in jail for his action in an antiwar demonstration at an Edwards ville Selective Service board. He pleaded guilty last month to a charge of destroying Gov ernment property valued at less than $100, a misdemeanor.

title: Manhattan Loses, 7871
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 9George Groom, a 62 sophomore guard from Bellrose, L. I., scored a career high of 32 points to ead Fairfield University to their second victory of the sea son, 7871, over Manhattan tonight.

title: Mullin Hangs Up Brushes and Board After 10,000 Sports Cartoons
description: Willard Mullin, the Rem brandt of sports cartoonists and the father of the Brook lyn Dodger Bum, is packing his brushes and drawing board after a career that de picted the American sporting scene in 10,000 illustrations.

title: Stamps
description: BRITAIN'S remaining low denomination dec imal stamps will be issued Feb. 15Dec imilization Day. High denom ination stampsa 10, 20 and 50pence were released last June, and have been in use along with the old pence, shilling and pound stamps. The current 1 stamp con tinues valid.

title: Reader's Report
description: Samariah Wheeler bolts from a Missouri sodhouse when he is only a boy, and goes on to become a legend in his own timea stagecoach driver of Bunyanesque dimensions. Whip ping his mule teams through the second half of the 19th cen tury, Samariah (Sam plus Maria, a compromise name) crisscrosses the West for the predecessors of Wells Fargo, running into such celebrities as Ned Buntline, Buffalo Bill and Abraham Lincoln, and covering himself with the scars of his calling.

title: Miss Clark Coast Victor
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 9 (UPI)Col leen Clark, a 14yearold Ta coma, Wash., skater, won the intermediate women's crown yesterday in the Pacific Coast figure skating championships. Jimmy Demogines, 16, of Paco ima, Calif., took the senior men's title. He represented the Los Angeles Figure Skating Club.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: 8 STUDENTS LEAVE TO STUDY KIBBUTZ
description: Eight Lake Erie College stu dents left last week for a term of study, living and working in a kibbutz in Israel.

title: A Is Born in Guide Michelin
description: BOURTH  SUR  ITON, France There's a star shining in this small, previously unheralded town west of Paris. It is only one, but it has cast an unmistakable glow over this rural community.

title: Administrative Merger Set For Brown and Pembroke
description: PROVIDENCE, Jan. 9 (AP)  Merger of all administrative functions of Brown University and its sister institution, Pem broke College, effective July 1, has been approved.

title: Regional Rail Units Urged
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 (UPI) Senator Claiborne Pell, Demo crat of Rhode Island, has urged East Coast states to set up regional transportation agencies to operate passenger train ser vice under the governmentrun National Rail Passenger Cor poration. He advocated the step in a statement released in Philadelphia yesterday at a gathering of state and local officials meeting to discuss Northeast rail problems.

title: The Nation
description: SovietAmerican relations en tered a nasty phase last week. It culminated early Friday morn ing with a bomb explosion out side a Soviet cultural building in Washington.

title: 60% of Businesses in Area To Give King's Birthday Off
description: About 60 per cent of the businesses in the metropolitan area plan to give employes a day off next Friday to observe the birthday of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., accord ing to a spot check announced today by the Commerce and In dustry Association of New York.

title: NETS ARE BEATEN BY PACERS, 11688
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 9 (AP) The Indiana Pacers defeated the New York Nets, 11688, to night.

title: French Car Prises to Rise
description: PARIS, Jan. 9 (UPI)  The French Government has an nounced that automobile prices will increase 4 per cent Mon day. Car makers said the rise was necessary because profit margins had shrunk as a result of increases in the cost of raw materials.

title: CHINA TO ASSIST SOUTHERN YEMEN 8 Technical Teams Due 2 Loans Are Provided
description: ADEN, Southern Yemen, Jan. 9Although portraits of Mao Tsetung outnumber those of any other foreign leader, China has generally been slower than other Communist countries in establishing a physical presence here and in the hinterland of Southern Yemen.

title: Walsh and Bennett Elected CoCaptains of Brown 11
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 9 (UPI)Frank Walsh of Farm ington, Mich., a guard, and Steve Bennett of Indianapolis, a linebacker, have been elected cocaptains of Brown Univer sity's 1971 football team.

title: GRAND PRIX WON BY AN AUSTRALIAN
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 9 (UPI)Neil Allen of Australia won the 100mile Zealand International Grand Prix motor race at Pukehohe today by fourtenths of a sec ond from another Australian, Frank Matich.

title: Steel MakersVise Tightens
description: The conventional basic steel millwith the coke ovens, blast furnaces and other giant steelmaking facilitiesprob ably will never again be built in the United States, according to the chief execu tive of one of the leading American steel companies.

title: Child to the Cardozos
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Cardozo of Hartsdale, N. Y., on Dec. 25 in Mount Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Cardozo is the former Miss Nancy Caryn Cogut, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar W. Cogut of Manhattan. The child, the couple's second, who is named Sheryl Hart, is a granddaughter also of Mr. and Mrs. Harmon H. Cardozo of Hartsdale. The infant's father is a lawyer with Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn.

title: Swiss Team Gains Lead In 2Man Title Bobsledding
description: BERCHTESGADEN, Germany, Jan. 9 (AP)  Hans Candrian and Erich Scherer of Switzer land took the lead today after two legs in the European two man bobsledding champion ships. The run is being held at the artificial Koenigsee track near this Bavarian Alpine resort.

title: Chile Plans to Set Up Neighborhood People's Tribunals to Try Minor Crimes
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 9 (UPI)  Chile's new Marxist Government has announced plans to establish neighborhood people's tribunals to try minor offenses as a step in its program to convert this South American nation into a social ist state.

title: Vermont Track Official Terms Sunday Racing an `Albatross
description: Taxhungry politicians are squeezing horse racing so hard they eventually will have to operate the tracks themselves, a New England racing execu tive declared yesterday.

title: Mari T. Mennel Becomes Bride Of Edward Foss
description: Miss Marl Todd Mennel, a teacher of preschool education in the city school system, was married here yesterday afternoon to Ed ward Chandlee Foss, coordin ator of urban renewal and industrial development for the city's Economic Develop ment Administration.

title: A Newsman, Retired, Lists Joys
description: BALDWIN, L.I.  Four and a half years ago I stepped happily into retirement at the age of 70 after more than 34 years on the news staff of The New York Times. I told a group of wellwishing col leagues then that this was the realization of a longcher ished dream.

title: St. Louis Honors Dr. King
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 9 (UPI) Mayor Alfonso J. Cervantes signed a bill this week making Jan. 15, the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., a city holiday.

title: ISOLATION IS URGED FOR SOUTH AFRICA
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 9 (Agence FrancePresse)  Stu dent representatives from Com monwealth countries have con demned any resumption of British arms sales to South Africa and oppose all contacts with that country.

title: Detective Agencies Battle Sophisticated Industrial Crime
description: The Federal Bureau of In vestigation announced recent ly that crime in the first nine months of 1970 was up 10 per cent in the nation. At about the same time the William J. Burns International Detective Agency Inc., the country's largest private security organ ization, announced that its profits in the same period were up more than 15 per cent.

title: Despite Slump, a Stable Enclave
description: ATLANTA  The South east is anticipating signifi cant economic growth in the coming decade, even though achieving it may be more difficult than in resent years.

title: $500aPlate Dinner Is Set By Democrats for April
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI)  The Democratic National Committee will start raising funds for the 1972 Presidential Campaign at a $500aplate dinner in Washington April 21, according to National Chairman Lawrence O'Brien.

title: Disclosure of Mercury in Fish Is Hurting Sea Food Industry, a Survey of 11 Major Cities Indicates
description: Recent disclosures of pos sible mercury and other con tamination of tuna, swordfish and other fish have hit the sea food industries hard in scat tered areas of the country, with consumers generally ex pressing mild concern and some confusion.

title: Mailbox:
description: To the Editor: A glaring error was made in the roster of 1970 champions in The Times Dec. 20. The Uni versity of South Carolina bas ketballers were designated as the Atlantic Coast Conference champions.

title: Phone Rates to Alaska Cut
description: Reduced latenight telephone rates went into effect yester day for all stationtostation calls to Alaska from the 48 other continental states. The new rates, from midnight to 7 A.M., will range from $1 to $1.75 for the first three min utes and from 30 cents to 55 cents for each additional min ute, depending on where the call originates. The new rates are expected to save customers $354,000 annually.

title: Muskogee Okla., Model City in Country Music Song, Is Torn by a Police Rift
description: MUSKOGEE, Okla., Jan. 9 In the top country music song of 1970, Muskogee, Okla., was portrayed as the model city of the American silent ma jority.

title: Son to Mrs. Richmond
description: A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Stephen Richmond of Brooklyn on Dec. 6 at Mount Sinai Hospital. The child has been named Jeffrey Howard. Mrs. Richmond is the former Miss Marjorie Miller, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Miller of West Hempstead, L.I., Dr. Richmond is assist ant professor of medicine at Downstate Medical Center and director of adult electro cardiography at Kings Coun ty Hospital Center.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jim French, $3.40, Scores at Tropical
description: MIAMI, Jan. 9This is a great horse, Angel Cordero Jr., who rode Jim French today, said to Johnny Campo, the trainer, after the running of the $28,150 Dade Metropolitan Han dicap at Tropical Park.

title: Science
description: The human body has been likened, in the complexity of its functions, to a great city: dependent for survival on regulated input of food, wa ter and energy, on adequate discharge of its liquid and solid wastes, on a variety of internal transport systems and, above all, on smooth and efficient coordination and control of all these functions.

title: Detroit Wins, 7063
description: DETROIT, Jan. 9 (AP)The University of Detroit, led by Jim Jackson's 24 points, de feated Loyola of Chicago, 70 63, today after scoring 9 straight points late in the sec ond half.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Article 11  No Title
description: DALLAS, Jan. 9 (UPI)World Champion Tennis filled its 32 player group of contract pro fessionals today with the sign ing of Roy Barth of San Diego. Barth, 23, years old, replaced Earl Buchholz of St. Louis, who retired because of an arm injury.

title: Banking: Out of Turmoil, Promise
description: Nineteenseventy was, by all odds, the year that the financial community should of stood in bed.

title: Erik Bruhn, Recovered, Scores In Ballet Theater's Miss Julie
description: Erik Bruhn, now recovered from his recent illness, proved in exceptional form with his performance of Jean the Butler in Birgit Cullberg's ballet Miss Julie, given Friday night at the City Center by American Ballet Theater.

title: Outside the Economic Mainstream
description: To some people nonbasic services and goods are luxuries; to others they are almost as routine as the butter on their bread. At any rate, most such services and items have not been affected by the recession as much as had been expected.

title: Reader's Report
description: Margaret Forster, a specialist in salty, vital heroines (Georgy Girl, Miss OwenOwen) here comes up with an empty, vapid one. The title role in this novel is taken by the daughter of a Durham (England) realestate agent who is both beautiful and stupid to an absolute degree. Coddled and cossetted by an asinine father, Fenella reaches puberty with narcissim as her only outstanding character trait. It's nevertheless enough to propel her in and out of three marriages and a young lifetime of disappointmentsall of which she richly deserves because she is a horrid, horrid girl.

title: 3,000 Mourn Scot Victims
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, Jan. 9 (UPI)Nearly 3,000 Scots filled Glasgow Cathedral today for a memorial service for 66 persons killed in the collapse of a stadium crowd barrier after a soccer game last Saturday. Millions more watched the memorial service on television.

title: Gunman Slain in a Holdup Of Harlem Clothing Store
description: A gun battle between the proprietor of a Harlem clothing store and an alleged holdup man last night left the intruder dead and the proprietor's broth er in serious condition with a bullet wound in his stomach.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Stock prices will score sub stantial gains in 1971. I can say this, indeed I can an nounce it, with absolute cer tainty. I am not an econo mist. This doesn't make me an infallible authority, but it helps. I am a politician, or, rather, a former politician. And politics, more than eco nomics, sociology, astrology, or even phrenology, is the determinant these days for the upanddown movements of stock prices.

title: Detroit Spurs Aid to Poor and Blacks
description: DETROIT, Jan. 9Detroit's charity establishment has moved to funnel more money to the poor and the blacks and give less emphasis to activities such as scouting and the U.S.O.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Melinda Allen Bride in Darien
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 9 Miss Melinda Clark Allen, a junior at the University of Colorado, and Barton Eugene Bortles, a graduate of Colo rado, were married here this afternoon.

title: HYMAN BERMAN, LED IN ETHICAL CULTURE
description: Hyman Berman, a former president of the Brooklyn So ciety for Ethical Culture, died yesterday in his home at 30 East Ninth Street. He was 79 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Donates Wilderness Tract
description: A 44acre tract of woods and swamps was donated to the Town of Lewisboro in Westchester County yester day by a resident who hopes to see the land conserved as an untouched patch of wil derness.

title: Nationalist Aide Asks First Elections on Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 9A prominent official of the Na tionalist Chinese Government has called for elections in two national elective bodies to in crease the representation of na tive Taiwanese and bring in younger men.

title: City Says It Pays a Higher Percentage of Welfare Than Any Other Locality
