description: Accelerating its campaign to get more Federal and state money for welfare, the Lind say administration issued a re port yesterday saying that New York paid a higher percentage of welfare costs than any other city in the country.

title: Yes, Yes, Ruby!
description: THAT woman winoing with pain is the star of the show, a spoiled rotten dancer who has finally been floored by a fracture of the ankle. The other girl, the one twisting her hanky and rolling her eyes heaven ward, is the sweetest kid in the chorus, and she has been chosen to step in for the fallen star. On opening night. It's enough to give a girl the jitters, and it does. How on earth is she ever going to memorize all those lines and master those devilish dance steps?

title: At City Hall Blight Is Up, Ink Is Red
description: It may be a tired old clich, but the answer to a lot of New York City's problems is money. And the prospect of vast increases in funds for city services seems as dint as ever.

title: The Bank Lobbyists March on Washington in Platoons
description: WASHINGTONStanding in a Capitol corridor one day last fall, a veteran observer watched a crowd of well dressed men carrying expen sive attache cases press into a room where hearings were being held on a bill to regu late onebank holding com panies.

title: A trip to inner and outer space
description: Remember Stephen Rojack, the superstar of Norman Mailer's unfairly maligned 1965 novel An American Dream? Rojack is a war hero who has bad dreams, an expolitician whose personality was built upon a void, andscarcely credible touch  a professor of existential psy chology with the not inconsiderable thesis that magic, dread, and the perception of death were the roots of motivation. He tests this thesis by killing his estranged wife, the all American bitch, whom he loves, and by carrying on a secret frightened romance with the phases of the moon which keeps him close to madness and suicide through much of the novel.

title: U.S. Aide Who Led G.M. Pollution Case Removed From Post
description: A Federal prosecutor who most recently sought to enjoin General Motors from continuing pollution of the Hudson River said yesterday that he had been in effect dismissed.

title: Maureen Forrester Is Heard In Series of Lieder at Museum
description: If any art song lovers here remain unaware that Maureen Forrester is one of the finest recitalists in the business today, they must simply account them selves careless. Since her extra ordinary New York debut in 1956, the Canadian contralto has repeatedly demonstrated her affinity for song interpreta tion without wearing out her welcome.

title: Music
description: WILLIAM SCHUMAN had been head of the Juilliard School of Music less than a year when he decided that it should have a quartet in residence. His big problem: should he pick an established ensemble or create one with young people, who would be sympathetic to contemporary music. Progressiveminded, he opted for the latter course, and began looking around for qualified people.

title: Bolivia Opens Tin Refinery
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 9 (AP) President Juan Jos Torres opened Bolivia's first tin re finery today.

title: San Diego Game Set Nov. 20
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 9 (UPI) San Diego State College and the University of Arizona have agreed to play a football game in San Diego Stadium Nov. 20, Dr. Ken Karr, the Aztec athletic director, announced today.

title: On the Farm: Costs Up, Income Down
description: DES MOINES, IowaWhen they hear talk about infla tion of food prices these days, farmers smile wryly. The only inflation they are feeling is the inflation of their production costs. Net farm income is sagging and is likely to he considerably lower in 1971.

title: Mary Weiner Fiancee of Todd Peterson
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 9 The engagement of Miss Mary Christine Weiner to Todd David Peterson, on of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Peter son of Ridgewood, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John C. Weiner Jr. of Ridge?? wood and Stone Harbor. A wedding in June is planned.

title: DOCTOR UNIT CITED ON POLITICAL AID
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) A political arm for the Ameri can Medical Association poured nearly $700,000 into the 1970 campaigns without telling Con gress or the public which can didates got the money.

title: The Nation
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.  Perhaps the best thing that could happen to the President and the public, one Nixon aide said here last week, would be for somebody to stick a small television camera in the upper corner of the President's office, turn it on in the morning, leave it running all day, and not tell him about it.

title: Boating Courses Are to Be Offered Free to Public Starting This Month
description: Have you, as a pleasure boatsman, ever been faced with a situation where you didn't quite know what to do, where you were or even why?

title: Mary Christina Bucheit Plans Jan. 30 Wedding to Neil L. Diver
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 9Miss Mary Christina Bu chelt, an assistant to Herbert G. Klein, director of commu nications for President Nixon, plans to be married Jan. 30 in Washington to Neil Long fellow Diver, vice president and controller of the Urban Systems Development Corpo ration of Arlington, Va., a subsidiary of the Westing house Electric Corporation.

title: The World
description: LONDONA South Kensing ton couple turned on the radio news the other morning and heard, instead, a loud rock n roll song that began with two inspired words: Decimalization . . . . Decimalization . .

title: 5GAME MATCH WON BY SATTERTHW AITE
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Jan. 9 After standing 1 point from de feat in the fourth game, Frank Satterthwaite of New Haven, Conn., went on to defeat Sandy McAdoo, Princeton University's No. 1 player, 1715, 715, 1415, 1514, 157, today in the open ing round of the 10th William F. White Memorial Cup invita tion squash racquets tourna ment at the Merion Cricket Club.

title: Norway's Fleet Increases
description: OSLO, Norway, Jan. 9 (Reu ters)  Norways's merchant fleet increased last year by 1,280,000 tons to 19,887,000 tons, a record level, with a total of 2,869 ships, official statistics showed this week.

title: TENNIS RANKINGS HEADED BY RICHEY
description: The Davis Cup star, Cliff Richey, and Patti Hogan gained top seeding yesterday in the United States Lawn Tennis As sociation's 1970 recommended rankings. Excluded were such contract professionals as Ar thur Ashe, No 2 last year, and Richey's sister, Nancy, No. 1 in 1969.

title: Lefkowitz Proposes Hiring ExPolicemen in Drug Fight
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday pro posed hiring retired policemen to help local police departments fight narcotics traffic and drug addiction.

title: AIDE SAYS AUSTRALIA DOESNT SEEK BLACKS
description: LONDON, Jan. 9 (Reuters) An Australian state immigra tion minister has conceded that colored people are not encour aged to emigrate to Australia.

title: War Babies, Now of Age, Take Over
description: WASHINGTONThe, 1970 census found that the na tion's population growth had slowed markedly  the 13.3 per cent growth rate of the last decade was the second smallest in historybut the war babies have come of age, with a strong and in creasing impact on society and the economy.

title: SAMUEL PLEASANTS 2D
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L.I., Jan. 9Samuel A. Pleasants 2d, a New York lawyer since 1919, died yesterday in Southhamp ton Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 20 Dewey Lane.

title: New Hampshire Wins, 7967
description: DURHAM, N. H., Jan. 9 (AP)  New Hampshire, led by Dwight Peter's 15 points, regis tered a 7967 basketball victory over St. Anselm's today.

title: Federal Pay Protest Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) Kenneth T. Lyons, president of the National Association of Government Employes, today urged the Federal Government's 800,000 bluecollar workers to mark their pay vouchers in sufficient funds and mail them to President Nixon, who votoed a proposed 4 per cent pay raise for them a week ago.

title: Patricia Anne Gannon Is Engaged to Marry
description: SOMERS, N. Y., Jan. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence P. Gannon have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Anne Gannon, to Richard Strauss. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Strauss. Both families re side here.

title: TUPAMAROS SEND NO RANSOM WORD
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 9The Uruguayan urban guer rillas who kidnapped the Brit ish Ambassador here yesterday kept silent today on what part he Is to play in their campaign to overthrow this small count try's elected Government.

title: Florida Withdraws Sanction Of Mill to Dump Acid Waste
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 9 (AP)The State of Florida has withdrawn its certificate for ocean dump ing requested by a paper mill and has officially apologized to Georgia for its part in the mat ter.

title: WOMEN FIND HALT TO SMOKING HARD
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 9A Gov ernment smoking research proj ect, under way since 1966 in San Diego and Syracuse, N. Y., has concluded that women are less determined and far less successful than men in break ing the cigarette habit.

title: North U.S. Skipper, Better Position in Soling Standing
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 9 (Reuters)  Lowell North's chances of winning the Aus tralian Soling Class yachting championship were improved today when Jim Hardy of Aus tralia, one of the leading con tenders, finished eighth in the nexttolast heat.

title: Wrestling Keeps Hold on Football Pros
description: As Curley Culp, defensive tackle of the Kansas City Chiefs, moves in on a ball carrier, he remembers what his wrestling coach taught him. Culp, a member of the 1969 American Football League allstar team, is one of more than 40 professional football players who also made tackles on the colle giate mats.

title: Gambling Tax $58.4Million
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Jan. 9 (UPI)The Nevada State Gam ing Commission has reported that gamblers in the state paid $58.4million in direct Federal, state and local taxes during the fiscal year 1970, an increase of $10million over the previous year.

title: Sports of The Times
description: For New York's Day the crystal ball shows Notre Dame upsetting Texas in the Cotton Bowl and Stanford upsetting Ohio State in the Rose Bowl. What's that? You mean to tell me that those things already have happened? Oh, well, maybe I'm predicting at too fast a paceor too slow a one. But let's settle, down for .a more measured look at the year ahead, remem bering that every item hag a foolproof guarantee. Just clip the coupon and file at the nearest Dead Letter Office.

title: Letter to the Editor 6  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Coke: Atlanta's Money Tree
description: ATLANTAThe CocaCola Company's exposure during the last year had one side that will never be translat able to sales figures or profit realized.

title: About Pro Football
description: Sid Luckman, the Hall of Fame quarterback for the Chicago Bears, spoke recent ly at a dinner honoring John Unitas. Said Luckman, Sam my Baugh and I made an agreement a long time ago. He would always call me the greatest pro football play er of all time and I would always call him the greatest. I called Sammy this morning and told him I was sorry, but I had to break the agreement because I was going to a dinner to talk about a man who surely is the greatest pro football player of all time, Johnny Unitas.

title: European Notebook
description: Parisian Laureates

title: 3 U.S. SKATERS SET MARKS IN CANADA
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Jan. 9 (AP)  Competitors from the United States established three records in four events today and took a commanding lead into the final day of the Cana dianUnited States speed skat ing races.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BRUSSELSTo face the next ten years effectively while maintaining sufficient strength to encourage rea sonable negotiation with Moscow, it Is obvious that NATO strategy must substitute reliance upon qualitative improvement in weapons for quanti tative reduction in forces.

title: Arbitration: Fear Slowly Gives Way
description: Not too long ago, compul sory arbitration was viewed with considerable distrust by both management and labor in both the public and pri vate sector. Now, all that is changing.

title: Elmer Flick, 94, Baseball Star And Hall of Fame Member, Dies
description: BEDFORD, Ohio, Jan. 9 (AP) Elmer Flick, a member of baseball's Hall of Fame and one of the leading hitters at the turn of the century, died today at Bedford Municipal Hospital. He was 94 years old.

title: Two Jersey Girls Pace Senior Event In Eastern Skating
description: BOSTON, Jan. 9Two New Jersey girls were locked in a tight battle for the senior ladies title at the Eastern skating championships at the Boston Skating Club today.

title: Bridge
description: SHAKESPEARE inadvertently of fered some good advice for bridge players when he wrote the lines for the witches in Macbeth. Double, double, toil and trouble they chanted, and those who con sider doubling the opponents in a contract they clearly expect to make should heed this counsel.

title: Why They Burst Into Applause On the Beverly Hills Tour Bus
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. If, as someone once said, movie stars are our nobility, then Beverly Hills has got to be our Ver Sallies. Other cities may have homes as distinctive, residents as wealthy, schools as renowned, but none has the glittering cachet of this Los Angeles suburb. Tourists flock here because they hope to see Cary Grant walking his dog or, as the cover of the visitors bureau booklet shows, Doris Day riding her motorcycle. It's a sort of Forest Lawn for the living; indeed, the founder of that glamorous burial ground, Dr. Hu bert Eaton, after discovering that his home was within the boundaries of low ly Los Angeles, compelled the city to deed the whole block to Beverly Hills.

title: All About Hoyas
description: HOYAS, or oldfashioned wax plants, are fine vines to grow indoors. The original plant, Hoya carnosa, has thick green leaves and umbels of waxy starshaped flow ers. Other varieties, each one slightly different, are becoming popular.

title: Buddy Miles Group And the Holding Co. Heard on Rock Bill
description: Two incredible bands have emerged lately out of the chaos that jazz rock became. They are Eric Burdon's War and the Buddy Miles group.

title: A Boom in Housing Awaiting Subsidies
L'Affaire Bearnaise at Common Market: Oil on Troubled Sauce
description: PARIS, Jan, 9One prob lem the Comma Market will simply have to decide one of these days has nothing to do with applications for mem bershipalthough the Brit ish and others might well consider its implications be fore taking the plunge.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 9 (UPI)  Room and board fees at the University of Rochester and the Eastman School of Music will be increased next September, it was announced yesterday.

title: Dr. Leo Oliner, Internist, Dies; Authority on Nuclear Medicine
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9Dr. Leo Oliner, an internist, died yesterday at Holy Cross Hos pital in Silver Spring, Md., of an apparent heart attack. He was 45 years old and lived in Bethesda.

title: Coast Radicals Upset by Inquiry On Arizona Dynamite Purchase
description: VENICE, Calif., Jan. 9  A Federal grand jury session in Tucson, Ariz., to investigate West Coast radicals has already resulted in the imprisonment of five young people for con tempt, and future criminal indictments are expected.

title: Maurice Baring Restored
description: There is a delightful short novel,The Lonely Lady of Dulwich, several striking brief wartime episodes and a few good poems in this excessively long selection of the late Mau rice Baring's writing. Most of the book is made up of child hood memories, historical fan tasies,cultural essays, pieces about Russia, epigrams, a parody of Baring by Max Beer bohm and the introduction by Paul Horgan.

title: Company in the Black
description: Company, Harold Prince's Broadway musical hit, has earned back its entire invest ment of $550,000. as of Jan. 2. The musical will play its 300th performance tomorrow.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONForced inte gration of the suburbs. That phrase has become a rallying cry of late among those attempting to block suburban integration, and an epithet hurled at those who would open up the suburbs. Last week, it was at the heart of conflicting interpretations of the law by President Nixon and his Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, George Romney, on the one hand, and a Federal Court in Philadelphia on the other.

title: Volpe Hails Metroliner's Suburban Station
description: LANHAM, Md. Jan. 9The construction of a experimental suburban station here for use by Metroliner travelers appears to be a success.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: January is the month for store clearances, but the heaviest traffic has been generated by socalled white goods promotions. White goods is the retailer's eu phemism for sheets and pol lowcases, but today many more items are included.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Ten years ago the com puter clanked down Madison Avenue. What has this elec tronic monster wrought?

title: Henry Lorimer Weldon Weds Miss Angela May Hill, Editor
description: The marriage of Miss An gela May Hill, an associate editor with the American Heritage Publishing Coni pany, to Henry Lorimer Wel don, director of the Tutoring School of New York, took place in St. James's Episcopal Church here yesterday after noon. The Rev. Francis X. Cheney, rector of Trinity Episcopal Church in South port, Conn., performed the ceremony.

title: The World
description: LONDONSmoking Yourself to Death! exclaimed the front page of a British newspaper last week. Another headline said: Dying for a smoke. That's what is happening to nearly 30,000 Britons each year.

title: In the Consumer Age, F.T.C. Is Becoming a Guardian
description: WASHINGTONThe Fed eral Trade Commission, a rather passive quasijudicial agency for the first 55 years of its life, recently has been showing signs of becoming an aggressive guardian of consumer rights.

title: Coins
description: ANCIENT monies and other handmade me diums of exchange that have been used by man in past centuries, have long fascinated archeol ogists, students of history and collectors. Primitive pieces from Africa, the Far East, the Pacific Islands and North and South America hold prominent places in many of the world's mu seums. Many depict the life, economy and artistic skills of earlier man.

title: L.I.U. Downs Adelphi, 6035
description: GARDEN CITY, L, I., Jan. 9 Long Island University defeated Adelphi, 6035, tonight at the loser's gym. The Black Birds dominated the play with a tight defense which held Adelphi to 15 points in the first half. L.I.U.'s wonlost record is 74. Adelphi is 45.

title: For Young Readers
description: From A to Y, Hank Aaron to Carl Yastrzemski to be precise, here is a book that profiles 40 top American athletes from 11 spectator sorts. The choices seem right (Bill Russell, Paul Hornung, Cassius Clay, Bobby Orr, Jim Ryun, Denny McLain, etc.). Mr. Katz has chosen stars for their ac complishments in action rather than for their personalitiesthough every one does manage to come up smelling like roses.

title: Rexpointe White Knight Captures Top Award at Cocker Spaniel Futurity
description: Rexpointe White Knight, who by all the rules of knight er rantry had to bear the call name Lance, and did, became the New Year's baby among the country's young cocker span iels by becoming the main winner in the American Spaniel Club specialty yesterday.

title: Consumer to Pay For a Victory In Ecology War
description: LOS ANGELESI've looked over your shingles, and A you're going to need a whole new roof . . . . We've checked the foundations, and half the timbers have termites and dry rot .. ..

title: Movie of Slaying at Rock Fest Is Key Evidence in Coast Trial
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 9A 22yearold Hells Angel returns to the witness stand Monday in an unusual murder trial that has included repeated showings of a commercial film depicting the slaying he is accused of committing.

title: Title Bout Postponed
description: TOKYO, Jan. 9 (Reuters) The World Boxing Association's featherweight title match be tween the champion, Shozo Sai jo of Japan, and the American challenger, Frankie Crawford, was postponed today until Feb. 28. The bout was originally scheduled for Feb. 14, but was postponed at the request of Crawford, who suffered a leg injury while training in Los Angeles last month.

title: The World
description: LONDONA new flurry be gan last week over one of the oldest issues in British politics: ownership of industry.

title: Gentry, Ryan and Dyer Accept Met Pacts, Bringing Players Signed to Seven
description: The New York Mets an nounced yesterday the signing of Gary Gentry and Nolan Ryan, righthanded pitchers, and Duf fy Dyer, catcher, increasing the National League team's number of satisfied players to seven.

title: After Manhattan's Corporate Exodus, Companies Begin to Look Homeward
description: The sudden glut of office space in New York and the softening of the labor market are causing second thoughts among many top executives who have considered or ac tually gone ahead with mov ing their companies out of the city.

title: Consciousness
description: IN a lower Manhattan office a legal secretary returns from her lunch hour, sinks into her seat and says miserably to a secretary at the next desk: I don't know what's happening to me. A perfectly nice construction worker whistled and said, My, isn't that nice, as I passed him and suddenly I felt this terrific anger pushing up in me. . . . I swear I wanted to hit him!

title: St. John's Swimmers Rally To Beat Catholic University
description: St. John's University's swim ming team came on with a strong effort late in the meet yesterday to defeat Catholic University, 6447, at the Alumni Hall pool in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Profit Barometer Plummets
description: The inflationary recession, two words synonymous with profit squeeze, hit corporate profits last year harder than any other major barometer of the economy. Profit margins deteriorated to an annual rate of about 4.2 per cent, lowest since 3.05 per cent Was registered in 1938.

title: Living the Life of Maharajan Ease In India at NonMogul Prices
description: THE moment India pulled the magic carpet from beneath the rubystudded feet of her royal ty, took away their vast do mains and liberated their multitudes of servants and groveling subjects, it be came possible for us ordinary tourists to live the life of maharajan easeby the day and for the price of a normal hotel room.

title: Montclair State Triumphs
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 9 Montclair State College coasted to its eighth victory in nine starts tonight by downing the University of Delaware, 7760. It was the 200th victory for the Indians head coach, 0llie Gels ton, against 77 defeats in his 12year college coaching career.

title: Letters To The Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: The letter censuring Eu rope's stickyfingered con cierges end postal clerks who pocket the money given to them and fall to forward mail (Travel section, Dec. 6) calls for the reporting of a laud able exception. On a recent trip I handed over to the bell captain et en Istanbul hotel six picture postcards for mail ingI was leaving that day; it was Sunday, and no stamps could be purchased. I gave the captain 20 lire [about $125] and asked him to spend the 14 lire required for the total airmail postage on the cards. I hoped that the near33 per cent tip would bolster his honesty. The cards all arrived about a week after my own return a month laterby surface maileach bearing stamps worth 60 kurus. The postage on them amounted to a total expense of 3 lire and 60 kurus. The captain had thus elevated me to the status of a much more gen erous tipper than I had ever dreamed of becoming.

title: Political Pieties
description: IT was in January 1937 that Picasso accepted a commission from the Gov ernment of the Spanish Republic, then locked in a fateful civil war with the forces of General Franco, to paint a mural for the World's Fair scheduled to open in Paris in June of that year. He had not yet begun work on the project when, in the last week of April, news came of the destruction of the Basque town of Guernica by German bombers. He immediately set to work. By the 11th of May he had completed his outline of the picture on a 26foot canvas. He subsequently al tered the composition in some significant respects, but by June the workGuerni ca  was finished and promptly installed in the Spanish Government building at the Fair.

title: RUTGERS MAY END ELECTION RECESS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 9A Rutgers University committee recommended this week that the idea of a pre election recess, which in 1970 permitted college students to participate in the national elec tion campaign, be dropped.

title: For a Police Inspector Here, Vodka Symbolizes Soviet Diplomats Goodwill
description: On New Year's Eve, a bottle of Russian vodka was carried from the Soviet Mission to the United Nations, on 67th Street, across the street to the 19th police precinct.

title: Negro Gets Virginia Post
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 9 (AP)A Negro labor official, Miles E. Billups, 44 years old, has been named to the Virginia Port Authority by Gov. Linwood Holton. Mr. Billups is president of the Hampton Roads District Council of the International Longshoremen's Association. He is the first Negroand the first representative of organized laborever to be a member of the authority, which makes policy for the state's ports.

title: Point of View
description: Like many other American institutions the nation's foun dations are not expanding as fast or proliferating as rapid ly as they did over the last decade.

title: T. L. Gould to Wed Barbara Rosenblatt
description: FORT LEE, N. J., Jan. 9 Miss Barbara Rosenblatt and Thomas Lloyd Gould, a vice president of the Cross & Brown Company, real estate and insurance concern in New York, will be married March 14.

title: Cavaliers Triumph Over Braves, 11189,  to Halt SevenGame Losing Streak
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 9 (UPI) The Cleveland Cavaliers, who connected on 13 of 20 shots in the third quarter, posted their sixth victory of the sea son today by defeating the Buf falo Braves, 11189, in a na tional basketball association game.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: It was about 9 P.M. when a member of the Civil Aero nautics Board stepped off his plane into the Seattle dark ness. He had just flown in to address a local industry group and was looking around for familiar faces.

title: Kenya Warns on Witohcraft That Blocks Medical Effort
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 9 (Agence FrancePresse) Pres ident Jomo Kenyatta has warned against witchcraft prac tices that could hurt the Gov ernment's efforts to introduce modern and effective medical facilities.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: What Hits You Is the Total Human Waste
description: THE black convict who was born in a public toilet and the Washing ton, D. C., judge, son of a promi nent Republican Congressman, faced each other uncertainly in a class room at Shenandoah College, Va., last June.

title: Vietnam Veterans: A Battle for Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  The young man who manages to make it home from Vietnam still has one final battle to fight. He must find a job. ployment sterns from deliber ate Government policies to a very large degree.

title: Absolutely (This Time) The Caribbean's Last Undiscovered Isle
description: MARGARITA ISLAND, Venezuela Could this be truly the last of the undiscovered Caribbean islands? It depends of course, on who's doing the discovering.

title: COLUMBIA DOWNS BROWN, 79 TO 74
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. Columbia University, led by Larry Gordon and Foley Jones, edged Brown, 79.74, in an Ivy League overtime game tonight before more than 2,000 fans.

title: Blues Tie Canucks, 22
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 9 (UPI)Bill McCreary tied the game, for St. Louis and the Vancouver goalie, Dunc Wilson, held the Blues from further scoring for a 22 tie tonight in a game that had 98 minutes in penalties.

title: Ardsley Curler Is Stricken Fatally at Douglas Bonspiel
description: MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 9 The defending champion, the New York Caledonian Curling Club No. 1 rink, skipped by Vernon Hambly, reached the semifinals of the 36th annual Douglas Medal bonspiel today at the St. Andrew's Golf Club indoor ice rink, where one of the curlers, Ashley Thorndike, suffered a fatal heart attack.

title: Thai, Police Said to Capture Reds'
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 9 (Reuters)Thai border police men, supported by air strikes and heavy mortar fire, yester day captured a Communist jungle camp in southern Thai land, five miles from the Ma laysian border, police sources said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Other Americans
description: THE phrase other minoritygroup members can mean many things: in New York City, it's likely to mean Puerto Ricans; in California, Mex icanAmericans; in Florida, Cubans. But it is likely to mean much the same secondclass status in terms of jobs and income, whether the minority is the Eskimos of Alaska or North Dakota Indians.

title: Semper Fidelis to Crewcut
description: No man is wanted who does not come voluntarily to the standard of his country. So said the original Marine Corps recruiting regulations of 1847. New recruits there upon were given a bath, a close haircut and $6 per month.

title: Industry Hurting in Pollution Costs and Bethlehem Knows It
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa.We have just about reached the end of the line as far as spending large sums for pollution control is concerned. Something has to done with the tax laws as they now apply.

title: Isaksson Vaults 168 ; Leaves for U.S. Today
description: STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 9 (AP)Swedish pole vault er, Kjell Isaakson, jumped 16 feet 8 inches today for the second time this week in in door meets here.

title: METREVELI REACHES TASMANIA NET FINAL
description: HOBART, Tasmania, Jan. 9 (AP)Alex Metreveli moved into the final of the Tasmanian tennis championship with a hardfought 62, 64, 46, 64 victory over Phil Dent of Aus tralia today.

title: Pop
description: RAIN, black rain falling down 125th Street. Even the Apollo, lit up like a transAtlantic holiday liner, seems stranded in its garish pool of light. One hundred and twentyfifth Street is the main street in America's most sophisticated black community, but there is hardly a building over four stories and it looks like any other ghetto: rubbish every where, junked cars, boarded up shopfronts, decay and dis integrationwhat was that again about institutionalized racism? We make it across the street to the ticket booth, up the precipitous flights of stairs to the balcony, and catch the tailend of the movie show. The feature is a copsandrobbers, Zgrade; then Woody Woodpecker; then a badly dubbed black andwhite short of God knows how many years ago featur ing, would you believe, Alan Arkin (he of the multimillion dollar Catch 22) as a Puerto Rican dropout and made by (wait for it) the Maysles Brothers, lately of the Rolling Stones and Gimme Shelter. How have the unknowns grown. They needed to: by the time the movies flicker to a stop it is as tomblike in side the Apollo as it is tur bulent outside and I think, man, nothing will ever be able to wake this audience from the dead.

title: Harvard Tops Princeton
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 9 Dale Dover, Harvard's captain, sank a 15foot jump shot at the final buzzer today to give the Crimson basketball team a 62 60 Ivy League victory over Princeton.

title: Mailbox:
description: To the Editor: I beg to take exception to ranking college football teams after the postseason bowl games and establishing the national champion on the results of these games.

title: Miss Galey H. MacMullan Is Bride
description: MEDIA, Pa., Jan. 9  In Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Galey Holt MacMullan was married to William Pannell Wilson 3d by the Rev. William J. Alberts. The parents of the couple are Mrs. Henry Snow den Rigby of Media and Russell Jamison MacMullan of Washington and Mrs. Wilson Jr. of Wheeling, W. Va., and the late Mr. Wilson.

title: Amateur Racing Is Set Up By Motorcycle Association
description: WORTHINGTON, Ohio, Jan. 9The American Motorcycle Association has established a new department that will de vote its full efforts to amateur activities, both on and off the road.

title: Miss O'Gara To Be Bride
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Jan. 9The engagement of Miss Monica Catherine O'Gara to Gardiner H. Shattuck Jr., son of the Rey. and Mrs. Gardiner H. Shattuck of Wel lesley, Mass., has been an nounced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James O'Gara of Rockville, Centre.

title: Elderly See the Tarnish on the Golden Years
description: Do y ?? have money to make ends meet? Do you have trouble paying for hous ing costs  including taxes, rent, electricity, etc? Are you usually able to see doctor when you need one? Have you been the victim of a consumer fraud in the past year? Do you some times feel that you have noth ing h live for?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Hawks Top Bruins, 43, On 24th Goal by Bobby Hull
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 3 Bobby Hull's 24th goal of the season with three minutes to play in the second period tonight pro vided the deciding score asg the Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Boston Bruins, 43.

title: Conigliaros, Bucyk, Blanda Signedby Sportsmen's Show
description: BOSTON, Jan. 9 (AP)Tony and Billy Conigliaro from base ball, hockey's Johnny Bucyk and pro football's George Blanda were signed today to appear at the New England Sportsmen's and Camping Show Jan. 23 to 31 at Hynes Civic Auditorium.

title: KING OF CRICKET FIRST IN MALIBU
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 9 (UPI) King of Cricket held his speed all the way today to capture the 19th running of the $48,450 Malibu Stakes at Santa Anita, the first major test for horses that have just become 4 years old.

title: CRAFTY PANTS FIRST BY NECK AT LINCOLN
description: LINCOLN, R. I., Jan. 9 (AP) Crafty Pants, a 3yearold colt that won three races at Rockingham Park last season, scored his first Lincoln Downs victory today in the $5,000 North Scituate Purse.

title: News of Dogs
description: The barking of dogs will be heard once again on the parade grounds of Fort Wads worth, Staten Island, where for more than three centuries the sound of marching men has echoed.

title: Energy Producers Will Need All Their Strength
description: Despite the problems en countered last year by the Consolidated Edison Com pany of New York and others, the electric utility industry set records in the generating of power, and in generating capacity, sales and revenues. It was a had year, neverthe less, as far as many con sumers were concerned blackouts, brownouts and dangerously small reserves were common items in the news.

title: Indoor Track Record Book Is First Printed Since 1966
description: Indoor Track, 1970, a 48 page book devoted exclusively to indoor track, has been pub lished by Track & Field News. It is the first indoor track rec ord book published since 1966.

title: Brooklyn Victor on Foul Shot
description: Brooklyn College defeated City College, 6362, last night on a foul shot by Gerald Sea brooks with four seconds left in the game on the winner's court.

title: Mrs. T. L. Slovis Has Son
description: A son was born Dec. 23 to Capt. Thomas Laurence Slovis, Medical Corps, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Slovis at the Tucson Medical Center in Arizona. Mrs. Slovis is the former Miss Ellen Wimpf heimer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Wimpfheimer of New York. The child, the couple's third, is a grandson also of Dr. and Mrs. Reuben Slovis of Passaic, N.J.

title: Point of View
description: The new Securities Inves tors Protection Corporation is just the first step in a pro gram that will lead to reor ganization of the securities industry along more rational lines than it has had. The next steps will be directed toward development of a central marketplace suited to today's economic climate and toward a revenue structure that will allow brokerage firms to attract the perma nent capital they need.

title: U.S. Command Finds Nothing for a Report
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 9 (Reuters)The United States military command failed to issue a morning press release today for the first time in more than three years.

title: Reader's Report
description: Sunshine is a mingling of streamofconsciousness, fanta sy and firstperson narrative radiating from a precocious little boy named Freddy, who lives with his family on one of Florida's coasts. Freddy's folks are culled from the Southern lit erary tree that sprouted so many grotesques we have come to know and love. In Mr. Hagen's hothouse are Pooppa, a paralyzed big daddy in a wheel chair; mama, who is no better than she seems; Baby Ruth, a practical nurse and maid of all work; and JoJo, Pooppa's male orderly. As fil tered through Freddy's sensi tive perceptions, the members of this reallife quartet pursue one another in a Freudian round robin (complete with onceexotic sexual acts) that includes Mr. Talking Frog and Captain Jimobsessions from color TV. Freddy may be an overly sophisticated observer for a mere tadbut disbelief is suspended in the Caligari cabi net of imaginative distortions the author has created.

title: NEW TOKYO SYSTEM TO CURB POLLUTION
description: TOKYO, Jan. 9 (AP)Tokyo's Bureau of Environmental Pro tection is setting up a network of gauges, warning lights and radio lines to prevent factories from pouring too much sulphur into the air.

title: Rangers Defeat Stars, 10, On a Late Goal by Selling
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 9In a game marked by the brilliant goaltending of the Rangers Gilles Villemure and the Minnesota North Stars' Gump Worsley, the New York skaters gained a 10 victory tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.TAX PROPOSED ON FUEL SULPHUR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The Treasury Department and the Council on Environmental Quality have worked out a proposal to discourage air pol lution by imposing a penalty tax on the sulphur content of coal, oil and natural gas.

title: Discovery of Halo Around Comet Leads to Finding of Huge Hydrogen Cloud
description: Both discoveries were made with devices aboard Orbiting Geophysical Observatory 5 (OGO5) that are sensitive to ultraviolet light. The satellite is in an orbit that lies between 9,000 and 75,000 miles from the earth.

title: SPRY, 64, ACTRESS AND ENTERTAINER
description: Spivy, a retired International nightclub entertainer and ac tress, died Friday in the Motion Picture Home in Los Angeles at the age of 64.

title: The private life of a public figure
description: There are fundamentally two types of autobiography, the public and the private. The book world, these days, is piled high with the formerthose vast unmanageable tomes concocted by exPresidents or, worse still, by their wives, secretaries and personal assistants who regurgitate their lists of dinnerguests, spill out their short hand notes on tape for the name less publishereditors to package up for them in hard and soft covers. Such books lasso the headlines of the year before last, and pull themselves weightily up the bestseller liststhat strange class of oncebought never read volumes which are traditionally spoken about with hushed voices as documents of our time, which are seen in everyone's drawingroom, but which remain unopened, perhaps in deed unopenable.

title: Marian Carol McCarthy Plans Marriage to Thomas J. Bryan
description: Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Fran cis McCarthy of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marian Carol McCarthy, to Thomas James Bryan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Bryan of Rochester.

title: 2 Bodies Found on Track
description: CARLE PLACE, L. I., Jan. 9 The bodies of two men who had apparently been struck by a train were found on the Long Island Railroad tracks here early today. The bodies of the two, Richard C. Farren, 22 years old, an airline ramp handler, of 11 Audley Court, Plainview, and Brian Sullivan, 18, a laborer, of 10 Sussex Lane, Bethpage, were spotted by the conductor of a freight train at 2:55 A.M., 1,100 feet west of the railroad bridge at Glen Cove Road.

title: For The Economic Doldrums
description: On the other hand, this hasn't worked very well, either.

title: OLD WAYS REIGN IN COLUMBIA HALL
description: A new men's residence at Columbia University expects its members to be gentlemen scholars, requires them to wear coats and ties to dinner, restricts women to the first floor lounges, maintains no locks on its room doorsand has three times as many appli cants as it can handle from students who want to share the monastic life.

title: Tobin Rote Named Rice Aide
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 9 (AP)  Tobin Rote, one of the best quarterbacks produced at Rice University, has been named an assistant football coach at the school, the new head coach, Bill Peterson, announced today.

title: Author's Query
description: For a biography of the Amer ican psychologist, lawyer, liber tarian theorist and Mormon fighter Theodore Schroeder (18641953), I would appreciate any recollections, letter or memorabilia. My knowledge of his youth and early manhood in Wisconsin until 1889 is es pecially incomplete.

title: Albert Speer Was the Man to See
description: In the spring and summer of 1945 life was like being on a moving stair case which suddenly began accelerat ing at a manic pace. Within weeks Roosevelt, Mussolini and Hitler all were dead and Churchill was out of office. The Third Reich crumpled; instead of men of fearful power there remained only a few seedy thugs. The victors met at Potsdam; the bombs exploded; Japan surrendered; the armies were on their way home. So much history should have taken years.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The big question an Washington this month it is a very dull monthis, What is wrong with the White House press conference? the answer is simple. If we take a single question and look at the characteristic reply of each Presi dent from Truman to Nixon, the prob lem becomes clear. Thus:

title: Kaser Heads New Group For Auto Race Promotion
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., Jan. 9 Formation of General Racing, Inc., engaged in marketing, management, promotion and public relations in auto racing, was announced here this week by James E. Kaser.

title: No action, no climax, but realization
description: With this book Donald Keene and his students have almost doubled the number of No plays available in English. With the works available in German and French, especially those of Noel Peri in French, Ezra Pound and Arthur Waley in English, the Western world can now study, from a variety of points of view, one of the three most remarkable dramatic traditions.

title: Cougars Conquor Colonels
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. (AP)Lou Dampier of the Ken tucky Colonels broke the pro fessional basketball record for consecutive free throws to night, but his team lost, 130 125, to the Carolina Cougars in an American Basketball Asso ciation game.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Can it be that Americans are drinking as much Coca Cola, PepsiCola and other popular soft drinks as they possibly can?

title: KIPKE TO RECEIVE FOOTBALL AWARD
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 9 (AP) Harry G. Kipke, famed coach and threetime allAmerican at Michigan, has been named to receive the manoftheyear award from The Walter Camp Football Foundation.

title: Red Wing Upheaval
description: In one of the strangest denouements in the National Hockey League's history of frontoffice revolutions, Ned Harkness, the rookie coach from the Ivy League, sat in a new office yesterday.

title: ExTrading Post Still Rides Boom
description: CHICAGO  The Union Stock Yard & Transit Com pany will close its gates com pletely in February and what Chicagoans once proudly called the busiest square mile on earth will be noth ing more than an odorous memory.

title: Art
description: SO many tourists chickened out following the political disruptions in Guatemala early in December, that the country turned out to be one of the quietest spots on the sightseer's globe during the holiday season. Except for some bored military guards lounging around at the airports and an eleven o'clock curfew in Guatemala City, which doesn't offer much in the way of afterdark excitement anyway, the only unusual aspect of life apparent to visiting North Americans was the pleasant scarcity of their fellow countrymen. Even at Chichicastenango, the most popular tourist spot in the country, a big market day lured only one organized tour and a relative handful of independent travelers a week before Christmas.

title: Son to the Whitmores
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 9A son was born Dec. 7 to Mr. and Mrs. George M. Whitmore Jr. at the Green wich Hospital. Mrs. Whit more is the former Miss Pris cilla Norman, daughter of Mrs. Andrew G. Pierce 3d of Coconut Grove, Fla., and the late Bradford Norman Jr. of New York and Newport, R. I. Mr. Whitmore, son of the Rev. and Mrs. George M. Whitmore of Irvington, N. Y., is vice president of Cresap, McCormick & Paget, Inc., management consultants. The child has been named Stephen Bradford.

title: Leaf Rookie Gets 3 Goals
description: TORONTO, Jan. 9 (UPI)  Brian Spencer, a 21yearold rookie, enjoyed his biggest night in the National Hockey League when he scored three goals and Dave Keon added two, including a shorthanded goal which tied an N.H.L. rec ord, to pace the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 52 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight.

title: Wagner on Top, 9675
description: Wagner posted a 9675 vic tory over Kings Point on the winner's court in Staten Island last night. Gene Guerriero and Bob Clay paced Wagner with 20 and 18 points, respectively.

title: Letters To The Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR: Mr. Friedlander's dories about his journey around South America were interest ing, especially because they recall our own recent travels in the same area. His trouble with being caught at the time of departure from Peru with out Peruvian coinage to pay the exit tax reminds me of my own problems in Bar celona, on the way to G?? neva, when there was an un expected charge for over weight luggage. The airport branch bank would cash a traveler's check but could only give the remaining change In Spanish money. Then I had my inspiration. I went to a nearby airport shop that honored American Express credit cards and the proprietor readily made out a voucher for the amount of Spanish money I needed.

title: Letters To The Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR: In an article called Cali fornia Lode: Covered Bridges (Travel section, Nov. 15), Phillip King Brown stated incorrectlythat there are more covered bridges in the three Pacific Coast states (including eight he had vis ited in northern California) than in New Hampshire, Maine, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Maryland and Delaware combined. Ac cording to the last count, those nine states had a total of 161 covered bridges end the three Pacific Coast states had 93.

title: TENNIS MATCHES TO AID SYMPHONY
description: Tennis will be used as a means of fundraising, with metal racquets and champagne buffet dinners for purchasers of the more expensive tickets, next Saturday night at Hofstra University's Physical Fitness Center in Hempstead, N. Y.

title: The Nation
description: If you like Richard Nixon you'll love Robert Dole.

title: The Nation
description: The beleaguered states and cities, worried about where their next $20or30 billion will come from, got a strong sign from President Nixon last week that he hopes to throw them a fi nancial lifeline this yearone that will not only pull them out of some of their difficulties but perhaps also help pull him back into the White House in 1972.

title: Movies
description: MAYBE it's because he looks like a cuddly koala bear, or maybe it's because he seems to be so real, with that lumpy nose that everybody always wanted him to fix and that ethnic name that everybody always wanted him to change, or maybe it's because of the kind of part he's been play ing latelythe pathetic but lovable Jewish schlemiel, who carries the world around on his sagging shoulders while he vainly attempts to do something right for a change.

title: Hope May Sell Home
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (AP) Bob Hope says he will put his desert home near Palm Springs up for sale in about a years and Vice President Agnew is interested in buying it. Mr. Agnew often vacations in the Palm Springs area and spent the New Year's holiday there, The Vice President was a house guest of Mr. Hope over Thanksgiving. Mr. Hope val ues the home at $85,000 to $100,000.

title: FOREIGN AID CHIEF TO ASK FUND RISE
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 9 The Agency for International Devel opment will ask Congress for some increase in development assistance funds over this year's total of about $1.7billion.

title: Youth Councils Examine City's Antipoverty Work
description: More than 600 young people between the ages of 18 and 25 met at an allday session yes terday to assess the city's anti poverty programs.

title: Philippa Clarke Greene Bride of Andrew Kennedy
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 9Miss Philippa Clarke Greene, a granddaughter of Richard W. Clarke, who re tired last year as editor of The Daily News in New York, was married here this after noon to Andrew Sumner Kennedy.

title: CORELLI REPLACES AN AILING DOMINGO
description: One wonders how many opera houses could schedule Placido Domingo for a per formance and whe he became indisposed could replace him with Franco Corelli This is what happened at the Metro politan Opera on Friday night with Verdi's Ernani. When Rudolf Bing, the general man ager, came before the curtain to announce the change, the audience's groans at Mr. Domingo's defection were re placed by genuine cheers for Mr. Corelli's substitution, a reaction that rarely follows.

title: Miss Cook Fiancee Of Peter M. DiBari
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Jan. 9Mr. and Mrs. John Har mon Cook of Litchfield and Edgartown, Mass., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diana Elizabeth Cook, to Peter Michael DiBari. He is the son of Peter DiBari of Barrington, R.I., and the late Mrs. DiBari.

title: Making the most of lamb
description: Lamb and eggplant make a combination hard to beat. Add macaroni, homemade tomato sauce and cheese, and you have a casserole with a Mediterranean accent that is economical enough for family fare and tasty enough for a company buffet. When the mixture is used to stuff a crown roast of lamb, it is elegant enough for a formal dinner. One can save time and energy by making one full recipe of the eggplant and macaroni, using half to stuff a roast and the remainder as a luncheon casserole. It will keep a couple of days in the refrigerator and longer frozen.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jeffrey Weichel Becomes Fiance Of Sally Stone
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 9Miss Sally Wilson Stone and Jeffrey Robert Weichel will be married in May.

title: 3113 Victory at Mobile
description: MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 9The North utilized the speed of J. D. Hill of Arizona State and the passing and kicking of Dan Pastorini of Santa Clara to beat the South, 3113, in the 22d Senior Bowl football game to day.

title: To the Irish Sea for an Eyeful of Puffins
description: THE cool of our Manhattan apart ment was disrupted one day last summer by an urgent letter from a friend in Ireland. Knowing of our interest in puffins, guillemots and razorbills  those fabulous diving birds of the Irish Seahe sent up a London newspaper clipping that told of the mysterious disappearance last winter of the seabird colony of Holy Island. These members of the auk family  count less thousands of them  normally re turned like clockwork each January from their wintering in the open sea to their traditional nesting places on Holy Island's North Stack cliffs.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The Nixon Style: Friends Are Friends
description: WASHINGTONTo whom does Richard Nixon go for economic advicepersonal advisers, bureaucrats, ora cles, cronies?

title: A StreetCleaning Experiment Gets Mixed Reactions
description: A twomonth experimental streetcleaning program aimed at improving the Department of Sanitation's admittedly dis mal performance has met with mixed reactions from commu nity groups involved.

title: Mrs. Susan Copello Rewed in Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 9Mrs. Susan Stevenson Co pello, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walker W. Stevenson Jr., was married here this evening to Dr. Elliott Michael Badder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Balder of Philadel phia. Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's par ents.

title: Susan Rabin Will Be Airman's Bride
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Rabin of Boyden Avenue and Flor ence, Italy, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan H. Ra bin, to Sgt. Stuart Mason, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Mason of Bayside, Queens.

title: Penn State Tops Setan Hall
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 9Bruce Mello's 20foot jump shot at the buzzer gave Penn State a 7776 victory over Seton Hall University tonight in overtime.

title: St. John's Tops Hawaii, 8276;
description: Mel Davis, who admits he has been in something of a slump since the first game of the season, snapped out of it last night against Hawaii, scor ing 27 points to lead St. John's to an 8276 victory.

title: For Young Readers
description: The Hercule Poirot of the mouse world is Anatole the CheeseTaster, elegant, nimble, sagacious and brave, the hero of a popular picturebook series. His newest opponent is Bad Barat, who kidnaps Anatole's family (dear wife Doucette and six charm ing children) for the window of his Parisian toy shop. A pretty prison but a prison  and who can rescue them but Anatole, the mouse of honor and action?

title: Farmers Take Pigs to White House to Protest Low Pork Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  A number of pigs arrived at the White House today but failed to get in.

title: For Young Readers
description: Death and doom pervade the pages of these two shattering novels set in Nazi Germany. Both books are su perb, sensitive, honest and compel ling, symbolizing juvenile fiction at its best.

title: Newsman Is Fiance Of Terry Swayne
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Jan. 9 Miss Terry Swayne, a sen ior at Connecticut College, and Arthur Howell Napier 3d, who was graduated last year from Williams College and is a reporter for The Bulletin in Philadelphia, plan to be mar ried in June.

title: The World
description: UNITED NATIONS Dr. Gun nar Jarring, the tall Swede who is United Nations mediator in the Middle East, was back in action last week after four months of enforced inactivity.

title: TUFTS TOP WINNER AT EASTERN RELAYS
Governor of Puerto Rico To Honor Clemente Today
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. (UPI)Gov. Luis A. Ferre will present Puerto Rico's Golden Glove fielding award tomor row to the Pittsburgh Pirates star right fielder, Roberto Cle mente, at San Juan's Hiram Bithorn Stadium.

title: Love Wins Place in N.B.A.Hearts
description: This is basketball's Love story.

title: Sabich Takes Giant Slalom In First Race as Pro Skier
description: YORKSHIRE, N.Y., Jan. 9 (AP)Vladimir (Spider) Sabich Jr. of Kyburz, Calif., celebrated his 26th birthday today by win ning his first professional race, a giant slalom sponsored by the International Ski Racers Associ ation.

title: Take a Tip: Put Your Money In Tootsie Rolls
Horse Show News
description: The 54th annual conven tion of the American Horse Shows Association will be held at the SheratonPark Hotel in Washington next Thursday through Saturday.

title: Iowa State 7563 Winner Over Oklahoma State Five
description: AMES, Iowa, Jan. 9 (AP) Iowa State dissipated most of a 34point lead in the second half today, but hung on to beat Oklahoma State, 7563, in bas ketball.

title: For the Families of Congress's New Members, It Is the Start of a Different Life
description: WASHINGTONThe mov ing vans are busy these days in Washington. The defeated and retired are heading back to their old homes, and many of the 11 new Senators and 56 new Representatives are having their mail forwarded to addresses in the capital.

title: The odds were against him, but Jacky prevailed
description: As we all know, fictional accounts of growing up in America have become ever more frank and candid, partic ularly in their treatment of sexuality, but if you thought we had reached some kind of apotheosis in Portnoy's Com plaint, think again. Jacky, the young hero of A Garden of Sand, carefully plans and suc cessfully carries out the seduc tion of his mother, without the tiresome mistaken identity of Oedipus or Freudian guilt. What's more, it turns out to be an inescapably sensational but nevertheless believable and even touching event.

title: City Orders $240,000 LowPollution Gas Turbine Car
description: DETROIT, Jan. 9New York City has hired one of the fore most auto engineers here to build a car, powered by a gas turbine engine, that minimizes pollution. The action was taken under a program aimed at prodding the major auto makers to adopt an alternative engine.

title: Beat The Traffic Takes $28,300 Old Line Handicap at Pimlico by 1 Lengths
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 9 (AP) Simpac Stable's Beat The Traf fic did just that by displaying superior speed at the outset of of the Old Line Handicap at Pimlico today. The speedy 4 yearold held gamely in the stretch to win easily in the $28,300 feature.

title: ABDULLAH BARRED BY THE KASHMIRIS
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 9Sheik Abdullah, the leader of Kash mir's Moslems, and two of his aides were barred today from returning to Kashmir.

title: Saigon Newspaper Bombed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 9 (AP)A grenade was thrown into the offices of the Vietnamese newspaper Than Phong in central Saigon to night, wounding a 16yearold working there, the police said.

title: Art Notes
description: UNTIL very recently, if you'd breathed the word union to pro fessional staff mem bers at the Museum of Mod ern Art, most would have turned as white as their col lars. Yet thanks to a new employes' group rather cum bersomely known as the Pro fessional and Administrative Staff Association of the Mu seum of Modern Art (here by acronymized as PASAM MA), MOMA may soon have on the premises the first un ion of professional staff mem bers ever established at a privately financed museum. The association claims to speak for the 240odd non managerial employes of the museum not otherwise cov ered by union contracts.

title: State Courts Told to Speed Hearings for New Trials
description: State courts must schedule hearings within a month after ordering an inmate from a state prison to a county jail, the New York State Judicial Conference ordered yesterday.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: 2Nation Alliance
description: Alliance Tire and Rubber Company is a corporate name like any other except there is a difference.

title: Revenue Service Pays Phone Bill for Girl, 17
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Jan. 9 (UPI)  The Internal Reve nue Service is paying the telephone bill or Rita Ann Galyean, a 17yearold high school junior.

title: Garden Considers Halting Mail Orders On Ali Bout Tickets
description: At least $500,000 in tickets, and perhaps twice that amount, have been ordered by mail for the Muhammad Ali Joe Frazier world heavyweight title showdown March 8 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Letter to the Editor 7  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: Unless a youngster is given responsibility in a community and feels he is accepted by the community, he cannot carry with him a feeling of security in adult life. I real ize Steve did not feel this ac ceptance and responsibility.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: it is fascinating to find that the taste of those who were once considered old fashioned is now confirmed by no less a critic than Philip, Johnson [Philip Johnson Gazes Sadly on the City, Dec. 27].

title: Miss Fay Engaged To P. D. O'Sullivan
description: Mrs. John J. Fay, Demo cratic coleader of the 62d Assembly District here, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Rose marie Fay, to Patrick Declan tive in Venezuela.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: New York
description: When Michael J. Maya, the big, bluff leader of the city's firemen, strode out of the cavern ous meeting ball at Manhattan Center last Thursday morning, there was a smile on his round face.

title: Observer
description: WASHINGTON  Every time somebody is fired these days, prices go up, The econo mists can't understand it. They stand around gasping about it. The classic laws of economics aren't working, gasps one. They'll work classically in the end, Milton, like they always have, gasps another. Meanwhile, prices are going up between gasps.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: First Elected Governor Is Inaugurated in Guam
description: AGANA, Guam, Jan. 9 (UPI) Carlos Garcia Camacho was sworn in this week as the first elected Governor of Guam.

title: Che Guevara
description: The deification of Guevara is now complete. As happened to Lorca in his time, he has be come the touchstone and sym bol for the seventies, and thus the flood of Che biographies. The present volume is a rather sketchy essay on his life and thought, but it nonetheless has one distinct advantage over similar effortsGuevara emerges whole, with that un swerving dedication to the craft of revolution that served him and Fidel so well in the Sierra Maestra and failed him in such an ignominious way in Bolivia. Andrew Sinclair, the cotrans lator of the Bolivian diaries, begins with a breezy account of Che's youth in Argentina and the tentative participation in Bolivia and Guatemala in the years 195354. He is on much surer ground when analyzing the tactical realities behind Che's book Guerrilla War fare, along with the gradually changing ideological focus of the Cuban Revolution. The pos sible frictions between Fidel and Che, as occasionally evi dent in his magnificent letter of resignation to Fidel, are only barely suggested, and the whole Bolivian experience is dashed off in some four pages; but no matterthe basics are here, cogently presented and argued.

title: Junia Pendleton Is Wed to James Baker
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  Miss Junia Marion Pendleton and James Michael Baker, graduates of the American University here, were mar ried this afternoon in the National Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Thomas Stone.

title: Yale Beats Cornell, 7460
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 9  Yale held Cornell without a field goal for the first nine minutes and registered a 7460 victory over the Big Red tonight.

title: Education
description: It was not until 200 years after Harvard College opened that the first four women in America were admitted to college as degree candidates  at Oberlin, in Ohio, in 1837. For several decades afterwards, the major move ment to right the wrong of educational discrimination against females was the founding of women's col leges, pledged to offer wo men an education equal to that provided in the regu lar collegesfor men.

title: Prague's Calendars Mark Aug. 21 as Day of 1968 Aid
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 9 (AP)The day Sovietbloc troops invaded Czechoslovakia in 1968, gets special mention in this coun try's 1971 calendars.

title: Muskie Visits Kibbutzim
description: TIBERIAS, Israel, Jan. 9 (Reuters)Senator Edmund S Muskie, Democrat of Maine, to day toured Israeli kibbutzim, or collective settlements, on the banks of the Sea of Galilee with Deputy Premier Yigal Allon.

title: FIRING IN JORDAN SAID TO CONTINUE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan, 9 Fighting was reported continu ing in Jordan today between King Hussein's forces and Pales tinian guerrillas.

title: BAR UNIT OPPOSES A NEW COURT PLAN
description: An attempt to create a new appeals court for the state, which already has more ap pellate judges than England, seems headed for a major fight in the Legislature this season.

title: Music
description: TWELVE months ago I pulled out the crystal ball, filled it with blood (everybody knows that critics like to peer through blood; can't work without it), added eye of newt, etc. and made some guesses about the decade to come. The 1970's, said the c.b., will be an era of greater and greater compositional freedom, a decade in which composers will have dis carded the serial straitjacket in favor of an eclecticism verging on neoromanticism. This eclecticism may mani fest itself in environmental music. It will be of no par ticular school but will make use of all, from the Dada of Cage to the Sprechstimme of Schoenberg and so back to Gregorian chant. Multimedia elements will play a major part. Above all, there will be an effort at direct expressive communication, no matter how advanced or avantgarde the language. And nobody will be writing strict serial ism except a few diehards.

title: Headliners
description: Francois Duvalier has ruled Haiti since 1957, and seven years ago he was designated President for Life. His con trol has been so dominant that there has been virtually no discussion of what would happen when his life endseven though he is now 63 and has been ill periodically. But last week Papa Doc, as he is known to his people, brought the subject into the open. In his New Year's message, he said he would yield to youth when the time came. Then, quickly, the official organ of the regime and the army chief of staff endorsed the President's son, Jean Claude, a 20 yearold law student, as Haiti's future leader. Papa Doc, it seemed, had mada clear his plans for succession on his death.

title: Investor's Hope: Consumer Stocks
description: One thing about the Amer Icon consumerhe promises to become either the hero or the villain of the stock mar ket saga of 1971.

title: The Alternative
description: The Alternative does not suggest that communal living is everybody's alternative. Rath er it presents an unprejudiced view of life on several com munes scattered over the west ern part of the United States. Since both the author, William Hedgepeth, and the photogra pher, Dennis Stock, are young and hip enough to be part of the Movement, one wonders on opening the book whether they will idealize. They don't. Hedge peth doesn't believe all the com munes he visited are either good or will survive. In simpli fying their lives, these young people have accepted some harsh discomforts; and com munes not unified by a sense of purpose tend to split up.

title: For Modest Goals
description: mid1972. But, unfortunately, this is the case. In fact, it is by no means certain that we could achieve either goal in the next 18 months.

title: Andrea Holly Korothy Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Korothy of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss An drea Holly Korothy, to Ste phen Lee Senigo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark E. Senigo of New York.

title: DAVID SHEINKER, DISTILLER, IS DEAD
description: David W. Sheinker, a pioneer in the prepared cocktailmix industry, died Friday in Uni versity Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 400 East 57th Street.

title: Protectionism Gains Over Free Trade
description: WASHINGTON  The United States nearly made a significant reversal of a 35 yearold trade policy last year and the trend to protec tionism will not fade in 1971.

title: For Young Readers
description: From Caesar to Churchill the story of Britain may be seen as the story of great men. It is these movers and shakers that dominate R. J. Unstead's centurieslong narrative. Most of the brief chapters, especial ly the earlier ones, offer a portrait of some important figure of church or state and assess his contribution to the shaping of England and its civilization: Hadrian, St. Alban, Bede, Alfred, among the first; Charles II, William and Mary, Victoria, Churchill, among the last.

title: 707 and 2d Plane Collide Over Jersey; Jet Lands Safely, 2 in Other Craft Die
description: An American Airlines Boeing 707 and a light plane collided as the fourengine jet was ap proaching Newark Airport yes terday. The jet's pilot managed a safe landing at the airport as the light plane crashed nearby, killing its two occu pants, a flight instructor and a student pilot.

title: MRS. HENRY HADLEY, LYRIC SOPRANO, DIES
description: Mrs. Henry Hadley, who as Inez Barbour had been a wellknown concert lyric so prano, died on Friday at the Hospital for Joint Diseases. She was in her late eighties and lived at 15 West 67th Street.

title: Sob Along With Jenny
description: IT was with a certain amount of shock and surprise that, several weeks ago, I found my self liking Love Story, the current attraction at Loew's State I and Tower East Thea ters that may still be going strong come next Labor Day. Just several days before, I'd watched one of the late night TV talk shows, appalled, while Erich Segal, who turned his screenplay into the bestselling novel, shyly picked at his fingernails, kicked at the carpet, Gary Cooperstyle, and expressed the modest hope that he wouldn't be just another oneshot author like the man who wrotewhat was his name?  The Green HAT.

title: Gentleman's Agreement
description: The Spencer Haywood case has brought into the limelight the fouryear rule, which prevents pro fessional basketball and foot ball teams from signing a player until four years after he enters college.

title: Curtis Says He Will Run For Senate Again in 1972
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 9Sen ator Carl T. Curtis confirmed here today that he intended to seek a fourth term next year.

title: MICHIGAN CHECKS WISCONSIN, 9089
description: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 9 (AP) A goaltending call on Wis consin's Glen Richgels in the final five seconds today handed the Michigan Wolverines a 9089 Big Ten basketball vic tory.

title: TRACKS SEEK DATES IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: BOSTON, Jan. 9 (AP) Suffolk Downs has applied for the maximum 90day thorough bred racing meeting from April 3 to July 17, with no racing on April 9 (Good Friday).

title: Whites Found Returning to Night Clubs in Some Black Districts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  Whites who in recent years stopped going into ghetto areas at night have begun returning, a sign that racial tension in the ghetto has eased.

title: Iraqis Yearn for Days Of the Arabian Nights
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq  A nos talgia for the era of the Arabian Nights lingers in this city beside the Tigris River.

title: Miss Janet Alexander Becomes Bride
description: ROSS, Calif., Jan, 9Miss Janet Alexander became the bride today of Christopher Thomas Hartford Pell, son of Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, and Mrs. Pell, at a ceremony performed in St. John's Epis copal Church here.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: WAKE FOREST RALLY GAINS 8376 VICTORY
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 9 (AP) Sparked by Gil McGregor's 20 points Wake Forest rallied to beat North Carolina State, 8376, in an Atlantic Coast Con ference basketball game today.

title: LIMONGELLO WINS $75,000 BOWLING
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 9 (AP) Mike Limongello of North Babylon, L. I., defeated Teata Semiz of River Edge, N. J., 194 186, to capture the $75,000 first United States open bowl ing tournament today.

title: Kelly invites Cross to Parley Aimed at Ending A. A. U. N. C. A. A. Discord
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 9  John Kelly, president of the Amateur Athletic Union, has invited Harry M. Cross, president of the National Collegiate Ath letic Association, to meet with him hi hopes of reaching an agreement between the organi zations that have been feuding for years over control of United States amateur sports.

title: Israel Submits Peace Suggestions to Jarring
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 9Israel today submitted her sugges tions for a settlement in the Middle East to Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, and he agreed to con vey them to the Arabs.

title: MARKET TIES WORRY 18 AFRICAN NATIONS
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 9The 18 African nations associated with the European Common Market are worried about the future of their special relations with Europe.

title: The New fight Credo Libertarianism
description: PROFESSIONAL liberals find it extremely fashionable these days to wring their hands over the Nixon Administration's various abridgments of civil liberties. Yet the pet politicians of many of these liberals recently helped kill a Senate proposal that would have led to the abolition of the military draft.

title: Criminals At Large
description: I would not be surprised to learn that the published ad ventures of Sherlock Holmes have been subjected to more textual examination, extrapola tion, interpolation and specu lation than the writings of Shakespeare. By no means the least of such Holmesiana is SHERLOCK HOLMES: Ten Lit erary Studies (St. Martin's $7.95) by Trevor H. Hall. Mr. Hall exhibits broad familiarity with the Canonical commen tary he fluently offers amiable and imaginative views on such weighty matters as Holmes's birthplace, university, parental tragedy and love life, as well as on the curious omission of one story from the first edition of The Memoirs of Sherlock Holmes in 1894.

title: City to Allot $175,000 for School Sports Until April
description: Dr. Harvey B, Scribner, chancellor of the New York City public schools, announced yesterday that approximately 1$175,000 would be available on Feb. 1 to continue the Pub lic Schools Athletic League program through April. In ad dition, Dr. Scribner promised to make an effort to find ad ditional funds to support the athletic program through June.

title: New York
description: When Nathan Detroit sang in Guys and Dolls about the old est established permanent float ing crap game in New York, he could hardly have suspected that, years later, a Biblequoting law yer from Niagara Falls would try to remove the stigma of rascal ity from Nathan's furtive profes sion.

title: Ulbricht Again Proposes A Settlement on Berlin Issue
description: BERLIN, Jan. 9Walter Ul bricht, the East German leader, speaking at a reception for dip lomats, said today that the Ber lin issue should be settled in the interest of peace in Europe.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: MONEY, according to Wall Street pundits, makes the mare goand so the financial markets con tinued to move along rather briskly last week under the prodding of renewed reduction in key interest rates. The markets also had the benefit of the confidence that President Nixon exuded on the state of the economy and world affairs during his television con versation last Monday night, but it was basically the reality of stilleasier credit that fanned the flames of optimism along Wall Street.

title: A HIPPOCRATIC OATH BY SCIENTISTS URGED
description: LONDON, Jan. 9  Society should ask scientists to take a modified version of the doc tors Hippocratic Oath, a pro fessor has suggested here. It would be designed to make them consider the consequen ces of their work.

title: NIXON IS WEIGHING 2 PESTICIDE CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The Nixon Administration is study ing legislation that would give it two powerful new weapons to control the distribution and use of dangerous pesticides and hazardous chemicals.

title: Denver Judge Disqualifies Jurors as Being Too Old
description: DENVER, Jan. 9 (UPI) Juvenile Court Judge Ted Rubin this week disqualified 360 persons picked as jurors over the last six months be cause they were too old to be representative of the commu nity.

title: Point of View
description: Despite the historymaking civil rights struggle of the 1960's and the new move ment for women's rights, the economic role of the black woman in America remains more severely limited by dis criminationracial and Sex ualthan that of any other major group.

title: Hope Builds For a Burst Of Expansion
description: ACROSS the land, American businessmen and in vestors exhaled a huge sigh of relief when 1970, a year of trial, tension and turmoil, passed into his tory. It was notto put it bluntlya vintage year for either the economy or the financial markets.

title: What Is a Punter's Hang Time? Why Does a Receiver Seem to Run on Glass? How High Is a Cornerback's I.Q.?
description: IF there was one way to do it, this is the way I'd do it, said Red Hickey. He was sitting in a projection room at Indiana Univer sity in Bloomington, watching films of Indiana's football games against Colorado, West Virginia and Illinois, and talking about his job (Hardest thing to learn is how to take notes in the dark). He'd been up until 1 A.M. this Friday morning in a motel room in Columbia, Mo., finish ing reports on the players he'd just

title: STATE REVIEWING TEACHER CRITERIA
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9The State Education Department has be gun to study ways of revamp ing the system of certifying teachers with a goal of more clearly relating certification to competency on the job.

title: Daley Of Chicago
description: I suppose the Cook County Democratic machine will buy enough copies of this curious mixture of warm appreciation and reluctant criticism to make it pay out for the publisher. Certainly it's hard to imagine whom else the book might have been aimed at. In form, it focuses on the ghastly year of 1968 as it was experienced in Chicago  everything from Mayor Daley's shoottokill order during the riots follow ing the murder of Martin Luther King Jr. to his un leashing of the police and their clubs on the demonstrators outside the Democratic Con vention. Woven into the narra tive of the year are flashbacks which trace the career and achievements of Richard Daley, his political allies and enemies.

title: PRESLEY AND ZIEGLER HONORED BY JAYCEES
description: TULSA, Okla., Jan. 9 (UPI) Elvis Presley, the entertainer, who is 35 years old, and Ronald L. Ziegler, the Presi dential press secretary, who is 31, are among the United States Jaycees Outstanding Young Men of America for 1970.

title: Wallace Cooks Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Wallace L. Cook of New York on Dec. 15 in the New York Hospital. Mrs. Cook is the former Miss Daphne Prout, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Curtis Prout of Dover, Mass. The child, whose father is a lawyer here, is named Lawrence Peter.

title: Tottenham Upsets Leeds United, 21, on 2 Goals by Chivers
description: LONDON, Jan. 9 (Reuters) Leeds United, marching hope fully toward the English Soccer League title, was stopped in its tracks today by Tottenham Hotspur in their First Division clash.

title: STUDY FINDS RISE IN RADICAL JEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The emergence of a new type of ethnically conscious and com mitted Jewish college youth  strongly antiestablishment but firmly assertive about its Judaismwas reported here to day.

title: Queens Woman Joins U.S. Freighter as Mess Man
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 9 Mrs. Simonne Abboud joined 40 men aboard the freighter American Astronaut here this morning and became the first woman in recent history to serve as a member of a crew of a United States cargo ship.
