title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH everyone seems to recognize the need for ventilation in a bathroom (most com munities have codes that re quire a window or other means of ventilation in each bathroom), in most homes and apartments the only means of ventilation is a small window at one end. In cold weather this window is often fitted with storm sash (essential to conserve heat and minimize condensation problems) and the two win dows are seldom opened be cause of a natural desire to keep the bathroom warm  especially while bathing. In addition, many people find opening the windows and re membering to close them too much trouble.

title: Commodore Harry McClure, Headed Navy Training Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)  Harry A. McClure, a retired commodore who commanded 10 Navy ships and was head of the Naval Training Station at Nor folk, Va., during a long career, died Thursday at Bethesda Naval Center. He was 86 years old.

title: Canadiens Triumph Over Kings, 10, on Courn oyer's 21st Goal of Season
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 9 (UPI) Yvan Cournoyer scored his 21st goal of the season with 2:16 left to play this afternoon as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Los Angeles Kings, 10, for Rogatien Vachon's first shutout of the National Hockey League season.

title: More Americans Aware Of Interest on Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) The number of Americans who don't know how much interest they are paying on their home mortgage loan has been cut in half since the Federal truthinlending act went into effect, the Federal Reserve Board says.

title: U.S. CARS DAMAGED IN SOVIET ACTIONS
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 9  Two American diplomats cars were vandalized and an embassy of ficer was accosted today in the latest acts of retaliation against Americans for the harassment of Soviet personnel in the Unit ed States by militant Jewish organizations.

title: Offroadway: Economic Tragedy in Rehearsal?
description: The economics of the New York theater have just taken an irreversible turn for the worse. And that may just be the making of it.

title: The World
description: SAIGON  We do not have the right to play God, the let ter to President Nixon said. Se lecting particular pieces of land, calling them freestrike zones and declaring that life can no longer exist there. We have no right to destroy the ecology of any landaffecting generations of lifeas we have done with our defoliation program in Viet nam. We have no right to force unprotected villagers to spend months, even years, in caves and holes in the ground as our bombing program has done in Laos.

title: Sonies Beat Royals, 114110
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 9 (AP) Don Kojis scored 23 points in the second half as the Seattle Super Sonics erased an 11point deficit and posted a 114110 vic tory over Cincinnati tonight.

title: Photography
description: I USED to doubt it, but now I believe it is true: during World War II some highly respectable people really did sign the bombs that were dropped on the enemy. Margaret Bourke White, whose photographs of three decades are currently on view at the Witkin Gallery, was one of them, though she had qualms about it. I wasn't entirely happy about auto graphing the bomb, she wrote in her 1963 autobiog raphy, Portrait of Myself, but I knew the crew believed it would bring good luck. With the hazardous mission ahead I would not subtract one iota from the morale of the crew.

title: Sarah Lippincott Johnson Is a Bride
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 9  Miss Sarah Lippincott Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Johnson 2d, was mar ried hero this afternoon to Roy Randolph Rather, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Lamar Rather. The ceremony in the Palmer Memorial Episcopal Church was performed by the Rev. Charles WyattBrown.

title: Visiting Pottery Studios From Cork to Belfast
description: BALLYDEHOB, IrelandThis coun try is better known for its Aran sweaters, its tweeds, Waterford crystal and whisky, but there is another area in which the Irish and a few expatriates from other countries em ploy great skill  potterymaking. The wares of these craftsmen pack easily, they are useful when the traveler reaches home and the designs are a distinctive reminder of the country of their origin.

title: CONSIDINE TAKES SPEED SKATE LEAD
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 9 (AP)Metropolitan area skaters took leads today in the 39th annual Eastern States out door speed skating champion ships.

title: Court Won't Let Men Wed
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 9 (AP) Two homosexuals who want a marriage license were refused a court order for one in Hen nepin County District Court. Jack Baker and James Michael McConnell, who are challenging the constitutionality of a state law, had also been denied in an earlier court action for a li cense.

title: In Boeing Country, Some Hope Remains
description: SEATTLE, WashWell, they can't call Washington a one  industry state any longer.

title: Margaret Rudd To Wed in June
description: HASTINGS  on  HUDSON, N. Y., Jan. 9Miss Margaret Mary Rudd and Richard Belous plan to be married in June.

title: DEBBIE MAERKEL HORSE SHOW STAR
description: THREE BRIDGES, N. J., Jan. 9Debbie Maerkel of Somer ville, N. J., captured three events today at the Hunt Cap Farms minihorse show.

title: Penn, Shooting 54%, Trounces Dartmouth by 9277 for 11th Victory in Row
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 9  Pennsylvania's nationally ranked basketball team hit more than 54 per cent of its field goal attempts today to register a 9277 Ivy League victory over Dartmouth before 1,900 fans and a regional television audi ence.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Yes, Virginia, you could have made money in the stock market in 1970. Par ticularly if you had invested in some companies with underground assets.

title: CITY AND FIREMEN STUDY PROPOSALS
description: Negotiators for the city and the Uniformed Firefighters As sociation studied proposals on work rules and other noneco nomic issues yesterday in their contract dispute, which led to a job action by the 11,300 fire men that lasted six days.

title: Utility Stocks Benefit From Rate Cuts
description: While the DowJones In dustrial average registered its 1970 high in the final week of trading, prices also were turning brighter for a less noticed group of stocks the nation's utilities that supply electricity and gas, not to mention shareholder dividends.

title: VATICAN CONSIDERS PLEA ON CONFESSIONS
description: ROME, Jan. 9 (Reuters)A Vatican spokesman said tonight that the Holy See was studying the possibility of granting the request of many bishops in missionary posts to abolish the practice of individual secret confessions by applying a 1944 Vatican ordinance designed for use under exceptional war conditions.

title: Article 13  No Title
description: Two young disciples of the radical right argue that government should have no more than enough power to keep one man from attacking another. Anything more, they say, is regimentation.

title: Advertising: Squeeze on Profits Forces DollarStretching
description: Next year will he a new year, James J. McCaffrey, chairman of LaRoche, Mc Caffrey & McCall, said in the closing week of 1970, and time has proved him right.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 9 (AP)Virginia Wade of Britain captured her second title in the Western Province tennis championships today by routing inexperienced Elizabeth Truter of South Africa, 61, 60, in the final. Miss Wade shared the doubles crown yes terday.

title: Study Finds Private Mass Transit in a Cost Squeeze
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 9The day of the privately owned mass transit system capable of sup porting itself is rapidly ending, and unless most private rail and bus lines serving large American cities are subsidized with public funds, they can not continue their services even at their current levels.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONEver since he clipped the wings of the C5A transport program with charges of cost overruns, and then stunned the SST airplane project in the Senate, Democrat William E. Proxmire, the earnest, vocal backbencher from Wisconsin, has been looking around for a new economy cause to champion. Last week he found it, as he started jousting with the Defense Department over its military aid program.

title: Dog Club to Meet Tuesday
description: The Palisades K.C. holds its annual meeting Tuesday at 8:30 P.M. at the Swiss Town House, 3316 Hudson Avenue, Union City, N.J. After the election of officers, there will be an ex hibition of Afghans and Irish setters and a discussion on

title: MARYLAND TOPS SOUTH CAROLINA
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 9Maryland, which led by 43 at the half, scored 6 points in the last 14 seconds, including Jim O'Brien's jump shot at the I buzzer, to stun oncebeaten South Carolina, 3130, in over time tonight.

title: CITY GOLF PERMITS ISSUED FOR ELDERLY
description: City residents 62 years old and over or 17 and younger can pick up special permits for dis counts at city golf courses, the Parks Department has an nounced.

title: Growth the Key
description: The course of the Amer ican economy in the near term will require a decisive and massive stimulus to counter the present stretched out stagnation, and to move sales, production and employ ment rapidly to maximum levels.

title: Hockey Player Hospitalized
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 9 (UPI) Jack Taggart, a 20yearold rookie defensetnan for the Kan sas City Blues of the Central Hockey League, was hospital ized in serious condition today, following an automobile acci dent.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: For years the big striped bass in the surf off North Carolina's Outer Banks in November and December have defied, with few ex ceptions, all attempts of surf casters to catch them, but this fall it all changed.

title: State Men's Indoor Tennis Scheduled to Start Jan. 23
description: A new tennis tournament, the New York State men's cham pionship, has been added to the Eastern indoor schedule. It starts Jan. 23 at the Port Wash ington (L. I.) Tennis Academy, with a field limited to 32 play ers. Entries close on Friday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: COHAN LIFELINES OFFERED BY B.B.C.
description: LONDON, Jan. 9  Robert Cohan's Lifelines, shown last night by the British Broadcast ing Corporation, is the first moderndance work to be com missioned and transmitted by a British television system, It is a pleasantly straightforward work to introduce an Ameri caninfluenced dance style and technique to viewers more familiar with jazz dancing and classical ballet.

title: StreetSalting Ban Urged
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 9 (UPI)  State Representative Hugh Sandlin of Holdenville, Okla., said today that he would introduce a bill in the Legisla ture banning the salting of streets during snow and ice storms. He said the salt even tually reaches the state's rivers, where it causes pollu tion and kills fish and vegetation.

title: Headliners
description: After the assassination of Robert Kennedy, some of the people who had been backing the New York Senator's bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1968 switched their allegiance to Senator George S. McGovern, a soft spoken liberal dove from South Dakota. But in his largely symbolic bid at the Chicago convention, Senator McGovern was solidly defeated by Hubert Humphrey. Since then, the Senator has oscillated about seeking the nomination in 1972, but last week he made it clear he was running. Acknowledg ing that he would begin as an outsider, well behind Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, Mr. McGovern argued that this didn't upset him. Anyone who runs is a long shot, because you can't lock these things up the way they used to.

title: Royals List Haywood As No. 24Ineligible
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 9 (AP) The Cincinnati Royals list ed Spencer Haywood on the game program tonight as No. 24Ineligible Player and then protested their con test with Seattle when Hay wood showed up in full uni form.

title: June Wedding For Miss Mau
description: Miss Susan M. L. Mau, a senior at Finch College, and John L. Soong Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Soong of Hong Kong, plan to be married in June in Honolulu. The future bridegroom is a student at the Columbia University Col lege of Physicians and Sur geons.

title: LOURIA TOPS GRIFFIN IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 9 Don Louria of New York, the 1964 winner, defeated Ray Griffin of Williams to reach the semifinals of the 39th Luckenbach Memorial squash racquets singles competition at the Nassau Country Club today.

title: Wings Win for New Coach
description: DETROIT, Jan. 9 (UPI)  Gordie Howe, Nick Libett and Frank Mahovlich each scored a goal tonight in leading the Detroit Red Wings to a 32 triumph over the Buffalo Sabres, the victory marked Doug Bark ley's debut as a National Hockey League coach of the Wings.

title: Chamber Calls on Congress To Solve Welfare Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) The Chamber of Commerce of the United States has urged the incoming Congress to solve the country's welfare problem by taking positive, realistic steps.

title: Coral Snake Antidote Allotted After End of Commercial Sales
description: Government doctors have dis tributed coral snake antivenom to health departments in states where the red, black and yellow reptile exists naturally and where zoos, scientific institu tions, herpetologists and others keep the poisonous, nocturnal snake.

title: Ski Snowcasters How Do They Know?
description: ON a Friday night in January, 1968, after going off the air with a predic tion of snowbare slopes throughout most of New England, WINS ski re porter Stan Bernard set off for a meeting of winter sports reporters that was to be held that weekend in Sugarbush. At mid night, just as he was entering Vermont, a thick blizzard struck. Bernard, who likes to tell this story on himself, says he barely made his way to the base lodge. The next morning at 8 he awoke to find that the freak local storm had dumped 14 inches of snow on the area. Of the 35 media men expected, only six made it. Bernard recalls that skiing that weekend was superb. At Sugarbush, anyway.

title: INSKO PACER WINS YONKERS FEATURE
description: YONKERS, Jan. 9  Del Insko's Cold Well Senator and Randy Perry's Bethel raced nose to nose the final halfmile in tonight's $8,750 Henry Hudson Pace at Yonkers Race way, and it was by a nose Coldwell Senator triumphed in in 2:05 .

title: CALIFORNIA TO ASK SQUAW VALLEY BID
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 9 California will accept bids April 2 for the sale of its hold ings at Squaw Valley, the scene of the 1960 Winter Olympic Games and a source of much controversy over the expendi ture of public funds.

title: Lee Goldman to Wed Jill Ann Steinhardt
description: Dr. and Mrs. Roger W. Steinhardt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jill Ann Stein hardt, to Lee Goldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Gold man of Collingswood, N. J. The wedding will take place in March.

title: Arts: More Patrons, Wider Deficits
description: Wherever one turns, arts institutions are in financial straits.

title: Maria Pino Fiancee Of Richard V. Licata
description: State Supreme Court Jus tice Frank J. Pino, and Mrs. Pino of Brooklyn, have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maria Angela Pino, to Richard V. Licata, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Licata Jr., also of Brooklyn.

title: Hofstra Sets Back Acadia In Bluenose Final, 81 to 71
description: WOLFVILLE, Nova Scotia, Jan. 9 (Canadian Press)Hof stra University defeated Acadia University, 8171, tonight to win the Bluenose Classic bas ketball tournament.

title: Horses Die of Cold in Spain
description: LUGO, Spain, Jan. 9 (AP) Two hundred and eighty wild horses froze to death in the last two weeks in the Gistral mountain range of this north western Spanish province. Temperatures had dipped to 12 degrees.

title: Canadian Government Orders Makers to Enclose a Warning Notice in Packets of BirthControl Pills
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 9  All makers of birthcontrol pills in Canada have been ordered to include in each packet a notice that the product is potent and effective medication that can cause health complications.

title: Fund Will Purchase Tickets for Dream
description: The Theater Development Fund will buy up to $30,000 worth of tickets to the Peter Brook  Royal Shakespeare Company production of A Midsummer Night's Dream, which opens Jan. 18 at the Billy Rose Theater. The play is being presented for a limited run by the David Merrick Arts Foundation.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Westchester County, once regarded as a bedroom sub urb of New York City is con tinuing to develop as an em ployment center itself, ac cording to a study sponsored by the County Trust Com pany of White Plains.

title: OLD PHONE BOOKS POSE A PROBLEM
description: The New York Telephone Company, which has been get ting complaints for some time about its telephone service here, is now getting criticism about its telephone directories.

title: Shortages Of Energy Continue
description: Americans, a people ac customed to flipping a switch and getting instant heat and light, were startled and alarmed last year by the spec ter of a shortage of energy.

title: Jacksonville Wins, 12482
description: JACKSONVILLE, FIa., Jan. 9 (UPI)  Jacksonville blasted Miami, 12482, tonight.

title: DEAL IS CHARGED IN THE DAVIS CASE
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Jan. 9 (AP)A San Quentin inmate ac cused of murdering a judge in a shootout Aug. 7 at the Marin County Civic Center said in a court affidavit disclosed today that he was offered immunity if he would perjure himself to convict his black codefendant, Angela Davis.

title: The Three B's
description: To the Editor: Your recent review of Harold Schonberg's Lives of the Great Composers states in its head line that the author has added Berlioz as a fourth to the three B's. It would be more exact to say that he has re stored him as the original third. The fighting slogan Bach BeethovenBerlioz! . . . was first launched by Peter Cor nelius, in an article published in Berlin in 1854.

title: The Nation
description: From the halls of Montezuma to the shores of Tripoli, the United States Marine Corp is going to be leaner, tougher, more ready, more disciplined and more professional than ever before. That's what Marine Corps Com mandant Gen. Leonard F. Chap man Jr. said last week.

title: A Series of Strikes
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 9This industrial city, in which many major American corporations maintain their headquarters, was beset this week by a series of strikes and labor disputes that spelled anything but a happy new year.

title: City to Help Observe Amateur Hockey Month
description: The Amateur Hockey Asso ciation of the United States has set aside this month to honor its players and offi cials. The period will serve to highlight the value of hockey competition to youth, and will call attention to the thousands of volunteer work ers who supervise the ac tivity.

title: Money Supply: Less Trauma to Come?
description: WASHINGTON  For the nation's central bank, the Federal Reserve system, the year 1970 will undoubtedly go down in history as the year of Burns and the year of the money supply. The coming year, 1971, will again be a year of Burns, but the money supply will probably cause a good deal less trauma.

title: The Nation
description: I now declare publicly, before this court and before the people of this country, that I am inno cent of all charges which have been leveled against me by the State of California. I am inno cent, therefore I maintain that my presence in this courtroom today is unrelated to any crimi nal act. I stand before the court as the target of a political frame up which, far from pointing to my culpability, implicates the State of California as an agent of political repression.

title: Yankee Chief to Retire
description: STORRS, Conn., Jan. 9 (AP) J. Orlean Christian, 72 years old, first commissioner of the Yankee Conference, announced yesterday that he would retire June 30 from the post he has held since 1966.

title: Kentucky Purses Up
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 9 (UPI)The Kentucky State Racing Commission has raised the minimum purse on horse races in the state from $1,300 to $1,700. The rule change is effective Feb. 4. The commis sion left the minimum to be added to any stake race at 2,500.

title: BIG 3 AUTOMAKERS UNDER TRUST STUDY
description: DETROIT, Jan. 9 (UPI)A Federal grand jury is investi gating whether the Big Three automakers violated antitrust laws by cutting off discounts on fleet sales to large custom ers, a United States Attorney has disclosed.

title: 3 Children Killed As Fire Destroys Their Islip Home
description: ISLIP, L. I., Jan. 9Three Children burned to death here early today when fire destroyed a home at 55 Lynne Lane.

title: Chicanos'
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (UPI) More than 2,000 Mexican Americans massed in front of the city's downtown police headquarters today in a dem onstration that erupted into a window  smashing rampage down the main shopping street.

title: WagePrice Problems Haunt U. S.
description: WASHINGTONThe chief economic policy issue for President Nixon in 1971 is likely to be not how fast to try to expand the economy but whether to take significant new steps to influence the private wage and price process.

title: Richard Balzer And Eileen Hsu Wed in Illinois
description: EVANSTON, III., Jan. 9 Miss Eileen Yi Nan Hsu, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Francis L. K. Hsu of Evan ston, was married here today to Richard J. Balzer of Great Neck, L. I., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Balzer of Holly wood, Fla.

title: Olympic Medals Selling Well
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Jan. 9 (Reuters)Net proceeds from the sale of gold and silver commemorative medals minted for the 1972 Olympics here al ready total about $500,000. All receipts go to the Olympic Games Organizing Committee.

title: Movies
description: TWO of Hollywood's hot test young stars are out to send cold chills down our spines. Faye Dunaway and Frank Langella will costar in The House Under the Trees, a suspense film to be shot in Paris under the direction of Rene Cle ment. Ring Lardner Jr. is working on the screenplay, and producer Robert Dorf mann expects to set the shivers in motion later this month.

title: MEDICAL AGENCY TO EXPAND ANEW
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 President John Adams applied in 1798 what might be con sidered the first BandAid to the nation's health care system by signing a law creating the Marine Hospital Service for the relief of sick and disabled sea men.

title: Soviet Ship Rivalry Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) A maritime labor leader said Wednesday that the Soviet Union was dedicated to build ing the best oceanborne trans portation capability in the world, a goal holding jeopardy for the free world. Andrew Pettis, head of the Industrial Union of Marine and Ship building Workers of America, spoke at a meeting of the maritime trades department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of indus trial Organizations.

title: Women's Equality: Still in the Future
description: For women, 1970 was the year in which, if they were still making less money than men, they were talking about it more.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The total production of goods and services in the State of Washington last year was $16.7billion, a de cline of 0.22 per cent in cur rent dollars from the previ ous year and a decline of slightly over 5 per cent when the effects of inflation are considered, says the Bank of California, N.A.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Horrendous Decision At Columbia University?
description: FOR Christmas 1970 the Adminis tration of Columbia University handed its Theater Arts Division a death warrant. An antibonus, Ionesco might call it. The notice came giftwrapped in a proposal that offered the theater division a choice: Cut your budget for next year by 40 per cent, or else.

title: Business Leaders Chart Course in and Hard Times
description: Hard Times

title: About Motor Sports
description: Motorcycle racing, which has made considerable prog ress toward achieving public acceptance elsewhere in this country, is planning a major venture in a new areaNew York City. The occasion will be a program of indoor races Monday evening, Jan. 25, at Madison Square Garden. If it is successful it will he repeated once each winter for four more years. Indoor rac ing is scarcely representative of the spec trum of bike racing, but it should serve as an interest ing introduction for New Yorkers who have never seen motorcycle action. The races will be run on a slip pery concrete surface around a teardropshape course one tenth of a mile long. The turns are not banked.

title: TEACHERS TO MEET ON SCHOOL CHAOS
description: Julia Richman High School, which has been described as being in a frightening period of escalating violence and clearly on the brink of com plete chaos, will close at noon tomorrow to permit its teachers to hold a series of staff meetings.

title: TALKS BROKEN OFF IN L.I.R. DISPUTE
description: Federal mediators reported yesterday that no progress had been made during 14 hours of negotiations Friday night and early yesterday morning in the dispute between the Long Is land Railroad and three craft unions.

title: NEW ROWING PRIZE TO BE GIVEN HERE
description: A new trophy named in honor of the late Dutch Schoch, longtime Princeton coach, will be presented at the annual awards dinner of the National Rowing Foundation to be held here Jan. 22 at the Biltmore Hotel.

title: Squires Conquer Floridians
description: NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 9 (AP) Charlie Scott set a club rec ord by sinking eight consecu tive fieldgoal tries in the third period tonight as he led the Virginia Squires to a 135 114 victory over the Floridians. Scott finished with 34 points.

title: SENATORS PLANNING BIGCRIME HEARINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) The first major Senate inves tigation of organized crime in seven years will begin this spring with hearings on syndi cate traffic in stolen negotiable securities.

title: Sadat Urges Talks on Jordan
description: CAIRO, Jan. 9 (AP)Presi dent Anwar elSadat of the United Arab Republic sent messages to the Arab heads of State asking them to send en voys to Amman for talks to seek a solution to the de teriorating situation there.

title: Unions Say It's Our Turn
description: It's our turn to roll the dice in the oldest established permanent floating crap game in America, and we're not going to stand still for the While House or anyone else.

title: Federal Officials Consulting
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9Fed eral officials were reported con sulting over the weekend on ways to improve protection of foreign diplomatic installations.

title: U.S. Weighs Bond Issue To Finish Work on SST
description: Some old proposals that would alter the method of fi nancing the supersonic trans port are getting sudden new at tention from Administration officials.

title: Convert to What? Aerospace Men Ask
description: LOS ANGELESJust down the road from where the Queen Mary is being con verted into a hotel in Long Beach, Calif., 125foot towers that were designed to as semble the rockets that put man on the moon are in use only part of the time.

title: TUNISIA RETREATS ON COLLECTIVISM
description: TUNIS  Tunisians are try ing to salvage something without losing facefrom their shattered experiment in collec tivism.

title: In '71, the Big Number Is '72
description: WASHINGTONFor Richard Nixon's economic pol icy in 1971, the most important statistic will be 1972. In the mind of the President and his politi cal operatives, it is as simple as that: More than anything else, reelection next year depends on adequate recovery this year.

title: My Problem Is This. . .
description: MANY of our citizens never attain that deep and abiding interest in the specifics of horticulture. Homeowners can appreciate a completed landscape planting, when it's flourishing and growing, hut whether their grounds have trees or hushes, they don't much care. And if a tree is a pop lar, oak, birch or hemlock, that never matters. All that terminologylimbs, roots, trunks, branches, etc.well that's for someone else.

title: In Praise of Quiet
description: To the Editor: Re the three antinoise books David Cort covered in your Nov. 29 issue, Theodore Ber land's The Fight for Quiet, Robert Alex Baron's The Tyr anny of Noise, and Henry Still's In Quest of Quiet. . . The advancement of this goal is now being expedited by the resolve of companies such as ours (IngersollRand) never to sell another unmuffled pave ment breaker.

title: 3 Poles to Run Here
description: WARSAW, Poland, Jan. 9 (Reuters)Three Polish track men will compete in indoor meets in the United States later this month and in February, according to Pap, the official press agency. Andrzej Badenski and Andrzej Kupczyk, sprinters, and Henryk Szordykowski, a middle distance runner, will fly to Philadelphia Jan. 19 for an indoor meet there. They will wind up their visit by taking part in the United States in door championship in New York on Feb. 26.

title: India Splits Red Carpet For Heath and Trudeau
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 9Ed ward Heath and Pierre Elliott Trudeau, Prime Ministers of Britain and Canada, landed in India today, at airports 120 miles apart to relieve the In dian Government of protocol problems.

title: Women in Greek Town Sample Husbands'
description: MONOCLISSIA, Greece, Jan. 9 (Reuters)Women in men's clothes strolled the narrow streets here yesterday smok ing, drinking and relaxing while their husbands, clad in dresses, stayed home and did the housework.

title: MARQUETTE TOPS XAVIER, 91 TO 60
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 9 (AP) Dean Meminger scored 29 points to power Marquette to a 9160 victory over Xavier of Ohio to night.

title: U. S. May Pull Out 20,000 SaigonArea Troops
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The United States plans to with draw 20,000 more combat sol diers from the Saigon area over the coming four months, ac cording to reliable reports here. This will virtually end United States combat opera tions in the military region around Saigon.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The author replies:
description: Several of these writers have misunderstood my article. I have nothing but respect and affection for Bayonne. Of course, it has its foibles, but that is part of its wonderfully rich character. As for my class mates, I never said that the salesmen and dentists, insur ance agents and accountants, were a problem, as Mr. Rog ers asserts. I merely said they were there, living lives full of the same joys and frustrations that concern most Americans. It is true that I now live in a world of strivers, achievers, but I did not say they were superior to my classmates, only different. In fact, many of my old friends have a decency and humaneness that the with it crowds in Man hattan or Hollywood do not begin to understand.

title: FAMILY COST IN U.S. SET AT $126 A WEEK
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 9 An average American family of four now think they need $126 a week to make ends meet, according to a study by the American Institute of Pub lic Opinion headed by George Gallup.

title: Cannon and Oxton to Race For STP in Tasman Series
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 9The addi tion of John Cannon of Canada and David Oxton of England to the STP Racing Team's activi ties in the Tasman Series of New Zealand and Australia was announced here this week by Anthony (Andy) Granatelli, the president of the STP Corpora tion.

title: U.S. REPORTS F105, TRACED BY RADAR, RAIDED SAM SITE Says Jet Moved Into North Vietnam After Locking In on Enemy's Screen CALLS ACT PROTECTIVE Plane Was Escorting B52 Attack on Ho Chi Minh Supply Lines in Laos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 9The United States command announced today that an Amer ican F105 fighterbomber at tacked a missile site in North Vietnam yesterday after the pilot found his plane locked in by enemy radar.

title: Sonnies 8568 Victors
description: OLEAN, N.Y., Jan. 9 (UPI) Greg Gary sparked 11thranked St. Bonaventure to an 8568 vic tory over Kent State tonight. The Bonnies captain hit on 10 of 21 shots, scoring 27 points and collecting eight rebounds.

title: State P.S.C. Seeking Role In Regulating Cable TV
description: In the belief that the bur geoning cable television in dustry is evolving into a public utility, the state's Public Serv ice Commission asked yester day, for authority to join Fed eral and local agencies in regulating the growth and op erations of cable systems across the state.

title: A Popular Chicago Interior Designer Hints at the Reasons for His Success
description: CHICAGO  Richard Himmel, Chi cago's most successful interior designer, explains his decorating approach to clients this way:

title: A helpless helping hand to Latin America
description: On March 13, 1961, President John F. Kennedy assembled the Latin American diplomatic corps at the White House to announce the birth of a new Alliance for Progress  a vast cooperative effort, unparalleled in magnitude and nobility of purpose, to satisfy the basic needs of the American people for homes, work and land, health and schools  a plan to transform the 1960's into a historic decade of democratic progress.

title: In Brief
description: The story of how Pygma lion, the George Bernard Shaw play on which My Fair Lady was based, was first produced is a quick, enjoyable read. The author, an English actor who presented a stage version of his book at the Edinburgh Festival in 1968, has done admirable research, even digging up the first person in the queue for unreserved tickets to the opening night.

title: Wolf Moon
description: What we speak of as January's full moon occurs to morrow night. The Indians knew it, and the lunar month it marks, as the Wolf Moon. It was a time when the fangs of winter hit deep and the fangs of the pack were eager, when hunger drove the wolves. Unfortunately, few wolves remain, most of them in the Far North, but the fangs of winter do persist. January is cold, and no mis take about that. January's full moon marks a time of bitter temperature and biting wind. The ice now lies deep, the drifts are piled high in the woods.

title: '70 Economic Calendar: Inflation, Unemployment and a Bear Market
description: Following are the highlights and a chronology of some major economic events of 1970:

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: I dispute Harry L. Langer's letter of Nov. 29, which charged that the agreement which the Metropolitan Trans portation Authority has ne gotiated with Penn Central for the Harlem and Hudson divisions is disadvantageous to the public.

title: Susan Elizabeth Day Is Married
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Jan. 9  The First Presbyterian Church was the setting here this afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Susan Elizabeth Day, daughter or J. Houston Day of Dallas and Mrs. Don ald Davis of Virginia Beach, to Robin Sheldon Balding. He is a son of Mrs. Martin Quirk of Rumson, N. J., and the late Gerald M. Balding of Melton Mowbray, England. The Rev. Jule Ayres per formed the ceremony.

title: Bank Holding Battles Are Only Begun
description: A twoyear battle over the future shape of the business of banking ended on New Year's Eve, when President Nixon signed H.R. 6778, offi cially known as the Bank Holding Company Amend ments of 1970.

title: RILES REASSIGNS TOP SCHOOL AIDES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 Wilson C. Riles, the new Cali fornia Superintendent of Public Instruction, began this week to dismantle the organization left behind by his predecessor, Dr. Max Rafferty, citing the Peter Principle in passing as he an nounced some changes.

title: Sharp Drop in Auto Deaths Reported by the Government
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) The Government reported this week a sharp decline in the na tion's traffic death toll last year.

title: The Horatio Alger Thing Is Dead
description: WITH its strewn volumes of Kurt Vonnegut Jr., Tom Wolfe and Hermann Hesse, and with the constant blare of George Harrison's new record coming from the stereo sys tem, the cellar apartment on West 108th Street radiated the freedom of action of today that Charles A. Reich has called Consciousness HI.

title: Point of View
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The American railroads and the United States Congress are in a bad fix. Together they have some tough work to do in the next year. And regardless of how well they do it, there will be be many more years of difficult work ahead.

title: Canadian Five Crushed
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 9 (AP)  St. John Fisher College's basket ball team routed Queens Col lege of Ontario today, 10270.

title: Miss Gloria Etzbach Plans Nuptials to Scott P. Garvey
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., Jan. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Etabach have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Gloria Etzbach, to Scott Pearson Garvey, son of Mrs. Anabel Schnack Hunger ford of Honolulu, and Clar ence Garvey Jr. of St. Louis.

title: Men and women at war with their environment
description: These 16 stories were written over the last 25 years, but Jessamyn West's muse is un commonly stable, so there is no perceptible change in technique or themes. This collection has, In fact, more unity than most. Miss West writes in a classic tradition that imposes a dis cipline almost as rigid, and as fecund, as the sonnet form. And her ideas are as consistent as her methods. Some readers may feel a want of variety; more will welcome the cumulative, and coherent, revelation of her view of the world and of art. Collections of short stories are not often bestsellers these days; it may be because they too often lack precisely the coherence so remarkably evi

title: CANADIANS REGISTER 2 SLALOM TRIUMPHS
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N. H., Jan. 9 (AP)Doug Woodcock and Diana Gibson, Canadian skiers, won the opening slalom races today in the twoday competition for the Corcoran Cup on Mount Tecumseh.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: The criticism of measures taken to prevent hijacking of planes made in P.H. Alspach's letter Is Frisking Neces sary? (Travel section, Dec. 6) suggests to me that sev eral other inconveniences could be eliminated. How about doing away with life boat drill on passenger ships, to say nothing of lifejacket demonstrations on over water aircraft? That oxygen mask show ought to be looked into, too; the stew ardesses could be serving an other dozen martinis for the time it takes.

title: N.Y.U. Wrestlers Triumph
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 9 New York University's wres tlers ran their wonlost record to 102 today with a 1918 vic tory over Hofstra. Mike Jac, ques, a heavyweight, clinched the match with a 49second pin as Hofstra suffered its third defeat against five victories Mark Gottwald and Bill Stauffer registered pins for the Flying Dutchmen.

title: WARNINGS IN ITALY STIR UNION ANGER
description: ROME Jan. 9Worried calls for hard work and fewer strikes have warmed up the political climate and brought new ten sions here.

title: Cowboys Morton Gets 2Day SilentTreatment
description: DALLAS, Jan. 9 (UPI)  Team doctors imposed today a gag rule on the Dallas Cowboy quarterback, Craig Morton, to insure his recovery from a throat ailment that reduced his voice to a whisper earlier in the week.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR.

title: EastBloc Reform
description: A cynical Eastern Euro pean slogan, Communism Is Better Than Working, may be in for a new lease on life as a result of the Polish dis turbances that toppled Wlad yslaw Gomulka, the Commu nist party leader.

title: FORDHAM DOWNS HOLY CROSS, 10278
description: A couple of husky Fordham fans carried Coach Richard (Digger) Phelps off the court last night after the undefeated Rams had routed Holy Cross, 10278.

title: All Together Now, Over the Language Barrier
description: TIRRENIA, Italy  This small re sort on the Mediterranean in northern Italy seems to bo a well kept secret. Our Italian friends in Rome had never heard of it. Travel agencies in London, where we were liv ing when we decided to come here, did not know it existed. And, despite the presence of a United States Army base three miles from town, an American military attach was mystified when we mentioned the name.

title: Stamps
description: CANADA'S Postmaster General Eric Kierans has announced a stamp  issuing pro gram for 1971 that includes a memorial issue for Pierre Laporte, the Quebec Cabinet Minister who was assassinat ed by terrorists last October. It will be one of 15 stamps to be issuedunless there is a multiple  issue Christmas series similar to the 1970 program. Another feature of the 1971 program will be four stamps featuring the Maple Leaf in designs con current with the changes in season.

title: Arms Aid Unlimited
description: Under the Food for Peace program foreign govern ments bought nearly $700 million worth of arms over the last five years. Nicholas Katzenbach, Under Secre tary of State during part of that period, is shocked at this revelation. Senator Proxmire calls the situation Orwellian and suggests caustically that the program is really Food for War.

title: Subsidy Cuts Hit Big Cotton Farmers
description: CORCORAN, Calif.High way 43 winds north through flat, brown country. The mon otony of the landscape is broken occasionally by fields of cotton stalks with their opened white bolls. The road makes its way up the San Joaquin Valley to Corcoran, headquarters of one of the country's largest cotton farms.

title: SYRACUSE TO RAISE ITS TUITION AND FEES
description: SYRACUSE, Jan. 9 (AP) Syracuse University announced yesterday that undergraduates would be required to pay an average increase of 5 per cent in tuition and fees for the 1971 72 school year.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTON  In separate remarks last week on opposite sides of the Atlantic, President Nixon and Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird addressed them selves to the next milestone along the road to American dis engagement from the war in Indochinathe end of the United States ground combat role in South Vietnam.

title: Shrinking Bride Deferred
description: The Shrinking Bride, Jona than Levy's comedy, with songs by William Bolcom, has post poned its opening until Sunday, Jan. 17, at the Off Broadway Mercury Theater.

title: Famine In Yemen Ending; More Food Due to Arrive
description: SANA, Yemen, Jan. 4The famine that last summer affect ed nearly two million people, twofifths of the population, in Yemen is now nearly over. It is hoped that the largescale international relief operation, which helped to avert a catas trophe, will soon no longer be necessary.

title: LAVER AGAIN VICTOR IN RICH NET SERIES
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 9 (UPI) Rod Laver defeated John New combe tonight in a 3hour15 minute match of the $210,000 Tennis Champions Classic. The scores were 64, 62, 46, 57, 64.

title: Unbeaten U.S.C. Wins 12th From Washington, 7972
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (AP) Dennis Layton and Paul Westphal combined for key bas kets late in the second half today to turn back Washington, 7972, in a PacificEight basket ball game.

title: Pirates Shift Farm
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 9 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Pirates will operate their International League club next year at Charleston, W. Va. The Pirates said the team, which operated in Columbus, Ohio, in recent seasons, would be run by General Manager Jim Mills. Mills served several years ago as general manager of the Pirates farm at Asheville, N. C.

title: Detroit Insists the Future Will Be Cars, Cars, Cars
description: DETROIT  As far down the freeway as anyone in the motor capital can see there are automo biles.

title: Sports World Keeps Running, but
description: For a character who never kicked a field goal, made an unassisted double play or rode a derby winner. Alice's Queen had just the right words to su?? up the world of sports in the recessive year of 1970. Consider the evidence:

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Scranton Deals St. Francis 6763 Basketball Setback
description: St. Francis College of Brook lyn dropped a 6763 decision to the University of Scranton last night at the 69th Regiment Ar mory. Douglas Kohler led the victors with 23 points. Mike McDermott paced St. Francis with 22.

title: Health Care, Too, Will Cost More
description: WASHINGTON  Ameri cans, who already have the world's most costly health care system, can look forward to rising costs in 1971.

title: Environmental Institute Is Founded
description: The establishment of the In ternational Institute for En vironmental Affairs, with head quarters in New York and a charter providing for an inter national board of directors and an international staff, was an nounced yesterday.

title: Union Leader Of Militants
description: CHARLES LESLIE DENNIS . . . from the county poor farm to the presidency of the largest and most mili tant union involved in the railroad dispute, the Brother hood of Railway and Airline Clerks . . . He's survived pres sure before . . . He was dis missed from a Chicago biscuit company where at 18 he tried to organize a union and called a strike that failed . . . Now he's under pressure again . . . from the Teamsters who are trying to raid his membership through juris dictional contests . . . and from the Clerks union itself . . . the 320,000 men who know him as Les, C. L, or just The Chief . . . the men who want a big settlement after the Teamsters' July coup, a $1.85anhour increase over 39 months . . . husky, 62 years old, thick glasses . . . with a generally quiet bar gainingtable manner . . . a onetime freight handler who lives with his wife in Des plaines, Ill.

title: Television
description: I WOULD like to be the first to contribute to Martin Williams's tele vision museum, the insti tute he suggested in his re cent article, Move Over, Hamlet, Here's Ironside. I'm a little short at the moment, what with the holidays and the recession, but Mr. Wil liams will find my check in the mail at the earliest oppor tunity.

title: Mailbox:
description: To the Editor: Noting in The Times of Dec. 30 that Brutus Hamilton, who coached track at the University of California for 32 years, died Dec. 28 in Oakland, Calif., at the age of 70, I am prompted to make one point about this remarkable man among the many that might be made upon his passing.

title: UNION VOTES PAY CUT TO HELP EMPLOYER
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Jan. 9 (UPI)  The 1,200member Hamilton Watch Workers Union has vot ed to accept a 10 per cent re duction in pay until June to help the Hamilton Watch Com pany out of a financial bind.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Mel Gussow has done it again. After condemning the most exciting theater to come to our city this year, Orlando Furioso, Gussow has pronounced the Perform ance Group's Commune disappointing. He bases his misevaluation upon two points: the acting and the meaning of the evening.

title: New York
description: And in this corner, weigh ing 220 pounds  Michael Maye.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Virginia's Division of In dustrial Development reports that, all things considered, its 1970 box score on new or expanded corporate plant was a reasonably satisfac tory one.

title: Norwich Five Tops Hamilton
description: NORTHFIELD, Vt., Jan. 9 (AP)Ray Schwartz scored 25 points and Paul Wysocki added 21 today in leading Norwich to a 9474 basketball victory over Hamilton.

title: Minor Hockey Lauds Dyte
description: ORILLIA, Ontario, Jan. 9 (Canadian Press)Jack Dyte, a former player with Chicago Black Hawks of the National Hockey League, will he honored tomorrow for his service to Minor hockey in this com nunity. For 17 years he coached 10 individual teams. He also acted as head coach of the Orillia Minor Hockey Associa tion.

title: Photography
description: THE Vivitar 98PM Super 8 Macro movie camera recently introduced is probably the only cam era of its type that has a zoom lens which can focus down to zero (lenstosubject distance). In other words, it can focus on a small object that is so close it is actually touching the lens. Marketed by Ponder & Best, Inc., 11201 W. Pico Boulevard, Los An geles, Calif., 90064, the cam era has a 7.560mm Vivitar Cine Macro loom lens with two focusing ranges  one that goes from infinity down to four feet, and another which ranges from four feet down to zero.

title: Trouble Abounds For Insurance Men
description: The insurance industry caught in a series of national problems not of its own mak ing made few friends last year. This year may bring more of the same.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: JOHN W. HECK
description: SEA CLIFF, L.I., Jan. 9  John W. Heck, a retired chief engineer for the American Bu reau of Shipping, 55 Broad Street in New York, died to day of a heart attack at his home. He was 55 years old.

title: SCHUYLER J. BERGEN
description: CUTCHOGUE, L. I., Jan. 9 Schuyler J. Bergen, a member of the New York Stock Ex change from 1924 to 1965, died yesterday at his home at Nassau Point. He was 75 years old.

title: Daring Step Rallies in Stretch to Take Tuscarora Handicap at Liberty Bell
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 After a slow start, Greystone Manor Stable's Daring Step rallied to a onelength victory over Five Corner Stable's Bat tle Message in the $34,600 Tus carora Handicap today at Lib erty Bell race track.

title: ARBITRATOR CHOSEN IN THEATER DISPUTE
description: Robert Feinberg, a profes sional labor arbiter and a mem ber of the permanent panel of arbitrators of disputes between Actors Equity and the League of New York Theaters, has been chosen to adjudge the dif ferences between Equity and representatives of OffBroad way theaters.

title: MEXICO CITY SETS DRIVE ON CRIME
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 9 (UPI)  This capital's two in dependent police forces will soon share the same uniform and the same objectives in a campaign against an increase in crime.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON  In Haup pauge, N. Y., a young house wife was arrested for flying an American flag upside down to protest the Vietnam war. No action was taken against a neighboring Amer ican Legion post that in verted its flag to protest the Government's dovish response to the Pueblo incident.

title: Movies
description: WHAT can you say about a Love Story that ten million people have read and loved? That its Beauty consists in manipulating the reader's heart  long untouched by contemporary novelists  as mechanic ally as a Pacemaker. That its Romanti cism consists in exploiting a vital fam ily conflict without really exploring it. And that, no matter what any critic may say against it, twice as many peo ple will probably go to see the Para mount movie version of Erich Segal's phenomenal weepie.

title: Barbara L. Muckerman Is Bride of Lieutenant
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 9Miss Barbara Lee Mu??erman and Second Lieut. Alfred Joseph Fisher 3d, U. S. A., were mar ried here this evening in Our Lady of the Pillar Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Bernard A. Kramer, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Attorney Gets F.T.C. Post
description: Richard A. Givens, a 38year old assistant United States at torney, has been appointed the attorneyincharge of the Fed eral Trade Commission's office here. Mr. Givens has been chief of the consumer fraud unit in the United States Attorney's of fice here for the last four years.

title: John Elmendorf Fiance of Fenton Hetherington
description: GLADSTONE, N. J., Jan. 9 Mr. and Mrs. James A. Hetherington 2d of Glad stone and New York have announced the engagement of Mr. Hetherington's daugh ter, Miss Fenton Hethering ton, to John Tarleton Elmen dorf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Elmendorf of Libertyville, Ill

title: Villagers Say Saigon Perils Their Lives
description: BACHUC, South Vietnam, Jan. 6Vietnamese civilians in this village near Cambodia charge that they are being forced by South Vietnamese military of ficials to risk their lives clearing a heavily mined wooded area that is repeatedly fired on by the Vietcong.

title: New York
description: After the October riots in the Long Island City Men's House of Detention, affidavits taken from prisoners read this way: In mates were hollering, We give up. I heard people screaming things like, Don't hit me no more.' ... I saw many inmates, naked, being beaten in the day room. A newspaper reporter on the scene wrote: Another man was pushed out, his hands above his head. A bat caught him in the stomach and he doubled over. More clubs came down on his spine. Eight guards were slugging away at one time.

title: Tokyo Aide Planning Parley Of World's BigCity Mayors
description: TOKYO, Jan. 9 (AP)The Governor of Tokyo, Ryckichi Minobe, says he plans to call a conference of mayors of the world's five largest cities Tokyo, New York, London, Par is and Moscowto discuss big cities problems if he is re elected.

title: Walkout In Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 9More than 400 employes of the Cleveland Metropolitan Hous ing Authority are staying away from their jobs to show their sympathy for Irving M. Kriegs feld, dismissed as the author ity's director earlier this week.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Producers Edge Corp., pre senting Marguerite Duras' highlyacclaimed play, A Place Without Doors, almost literally has removed the doors to the theater by setting a single ticket price $8.

title: Mrs. Morton Has a Son
description: A son was barn Jan. 2 to Mr. and Mrs. William W. Morton of New York and Southampton, L. I., in Doc tors Hospital. Mrs. Morton is the former Miss Rabin Roche, daughter of Mrs. Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York and Southampton and J. Jeffrey Roche of New York. Her hus band is president of Tennis Ventures, Inc., manufacturers of synthetic tennis courts. The child, who has been named Nicholas Murray, is a great  great  grandson of Thomas E. Murray, the in ventor.

title: Education
description: sally, Charlie Brown's sis ter in the comic strip Pea nuts, recently took pencil in hand and wrote her school board demanding payment, as a required educational cost, for a mitten she had lost on the way to school.

title: Unemployed Man Gives to the Neediest
A Crackdown Is Decreed On Drug Words in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 9 (AP) In a move to halt the spread of narcotics in Brazil, the fed eral censorship department has announced that it will ban ref erences to drugs in newspapers, magazines and books and on the air.

title: Harvard Aids 2 New Black Sheriffs in South
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 9 Within two weeks John Hew lett and the Rev. Thomas Gil more will become two of the most powerful elected officials in their home counties in Alabama, but until then, they will still be outside a very old, very closed system.

title: Stamps
description: ROBERT GALLEY, Min ister of Posts and Telecommunica tions, has announced France's 1971 stamp  issuing programwithout a memo rial issue for her late presi dent, General Charles de Gaulle. General de Gaulle had been pictured on stamps of other countries while he was alive, but France (ex cept for the World War II Vichy regime) follows a practice, also observed by the United States, of not pic turing living persons on its stamps.

title: Royals Rehire Malmberg
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 9 (UPI) The Kansas City Royals to day rehired Harry Malmberg as manager of their Elmira, N. Y., farm club in the class AA East ern League.

title: The Nation
description: It was on June 2, 1967three and a half years agothat Luis Jose Menge, a convicted mur derer, was put to death in the gas chamber at Colorado State Prison. He was the last man to be executed in the United States. Since that time, the death row population in the 37 states that still have on their books statutes authorizing the death penalty has steadily mountedto 620 men and three womenyet the gas chambers, the electric chairs, the gallows have grown dusty with disuse,

title: Antipoverty Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) Howard Phillips, former dep uty executive director of the President's Council on Youth Opportunity, has been named special assistant to Frank Car lucci, acting director of the Office of Economic Opportunity.

title: ARGENTINE RENTS DUE TO BE RAISED
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 9 (AP) For thousands of Argentine tenants, basic rents have been unchanged since 1943. No Gov ernment had the courage to allow them to be raised. Land lords were irate, but tenants were happy.

title: Another Benefit Committee Meeting? Under the Circumstances, Hardly
description: What with all the confusionselecting a favorite Blackglama from among the $100,000 worth sent over by the Great Lakes Mink Association, checking the makeup and squeezing past the Pinker ton guards to board the doubledecker busnot one of the nine committee women thought to bring along a gavel.

title: Old Hat was a vicarious rebel
description: First we had studies of Joyce's works; then came the first biography (Herbert Gorman's); then reminis cences by those who had known Joyce; then the second, definitive biography (Richard Ellmann's), which failed to stop the flow of reminis cences; now, incredibly, we are faced with a biography of someone whose chief claim to our attention is that she was for many years Joyce's fi nancial angel.

title: Report on Lunokhod's Haul
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 9 (UPI) The Soviet Union's Lunokhod moon car dug up samples of aluminum, iron, calcium and other earthlike substances during its mobile probing of the ??unar surface, scientists said today. A report carried by the newspaper Izvestia said the roving studies of the vehicle showed that the soil in the area under investigation resembles the basic rocks of the earth and is close to basalts.

title: Minorities Fight Plan for 1976 Bicentennial Fair
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9  A black leader said today that the racial minorities and the poor in Philadelphia would block the country's 1976 bicentennial celebration in every manner short of bombing the buildings or site unless present plans were changed.

title: Apollo 14 Crew Is Ready For Jan. 31 Moon Flight
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 9  At the age of 47, when most men get winded running for a bus, Capt. Alan B. Shepard Jr. of the Navy declared himself physically fit today and happy to be back in business again as the com mander of the Apollo 14 moon flight scheduled to start Jan. 31.

title: Books: On the Rat Race
description: For the tired, the puzzled, the frustrated, this book by a management consultant may offer some answers to problems or spark some new ideas. Its range is wide. The author stresses the impor tance of a full, wellrounded life as the best way to suc ceed in business.

title: BLAZERS SET BACK KNICKS, 114 TO 96, ON 2DHALF SURGE
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 9 The Portland Trail Blazers, looking not at all like the first year team that they are, wal loped the New York Knicks, the National Basketball Associa tion's defending champions, 11496, tonight before 11,808 fans, Portland's largest crowd of the season, at Memorial Coli seum.

title: Births in West Germany Show Sharp Drop of 100,000 for '70
description: BONN, Jan. 9The birth rate in West Germany dropped sharply last year, leaving ex perts to search the effects of the affluent society, the pill, women's lib, improved televi sion programing and a variety of other factors for the prob able cause.

title: The Terrible Swift Sword
description: RALPH NADER, the incor ruptible in the corrupt ing society . . . the fiery sword, the zealot breaking down the doors of the cor porate state . . . with no mercy for his enemies, the manufacturers or public of ficials who he believes have lost sight of the public inter est . . . He is tall, loose, with a boyish smile, like a small college basketball player. . . He holds up the one ideal of today's young: no compro mise. Ralph Nader humbled General Motors, and made the nation safety conscious . . . then formed his own power base  commando teams that strike every where . . . job safety, tobac co, pollution, fish, baby food, banks, stagnant goYernment bureaus . . . If he has a nice word for any business or government agency, it has been missed by his chronic lers, and when Detroit, or anyone, says, We are doing the best we canand often they areRalph Nader is there to publicly proclaim his disbelief.

title: Unity Of Opposites
description: To the Editor:

title: New York
description: For Mayor John V. Lindsay, it seemed the ideal solution to New York City's current  and re curringtaxi problems, problems that exploded last month into a 15day taxi strike. The Mayor's plan, which requires approval by the City Council, was in two parts:

title: Beame Urges Legislature To Abolish Garnishments
description: The Legislature should abol ish wage garnishments, City Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

title: IOWA STATE BEATS LEHIGH WRESTLERS
description: BETHELEM, Pa., Jan. 9Iowa State, the National Collegiate wrestling champions, rallied to night and defeated. Lehigh, 2012, before 3,300 fans.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Grand Prix of Mexico Deprived of Sanction
description: PARIS, Jan. 9 (UPI)A spokesman for the Inter national Sports Committee C.S.I.) of the International Automobile Association said recently the Grand Prix of Mexico had been eliminated from the list of racing events leading to the 1971 world driving championships.

title: Fateful Meeting on Oil
description: Top representatives of the major international oil com panies will be in Teheran, Iran, this week for what may be one of the most porten tous meetings in the indus try's history.

title: Blacks Debate Black Capitalism
description: In economic terms, the cry of Black Power still rings hollow; the clenched fist of militancy has broken down few boardroom barriers.

title: Controls Needed
description: In its first half term of trial, Nixon economic policy was an embarrassing failure. No politician admires a game plan that generates rising un employment, wage and price pressure, brokerage house failures, shrinking profits and housing doldrums.

title: The Nation
description: The nation last week received another large dose of bad eco nomic news: Unemployment for December climbed to 6 per centthe highest rate in nine years. Longterm unemploy ment continued to climb. The number of persons out of work for at least 15 weeks passed the million markthe highest level since 1964. Layoffs, especial ly in key industries, continued to rise. The Chrysler Corporation announced that it planned to fur lough 1,275 employes in an ef fort to bring overall production into line with the current market demand.

title: Athens to Show 3 Frescoes From Thera, Destroyed in 1520 B.C.
description: ATHENS, Jan. 10  Three frescoes of delicate workman ship painted by unknown ar tists who lived 3,500 years ago will be the highlight of an unusual archeological exhi bition in Athens next spring.

title: Price to Play in Godot
description: Paul B. Price has signed to play Estragon in the Off Broad way revival of Samuel Beckett's Waiting for Godot, due at the Sheridan Square Playhouse next month. The play had its Broadway premiere in April, 1956. The actor has been seen here in A Cook for Mr. Gen eral, Medea and other works.

title: Campus Styles Mirror Seven Decades of Change
description: Within the last decade the campus mood has changed so rapidly and so often that some have questioned whether the traditional underpinnings of the uni versity still exist.

title: Calley Trial to Recall Meadlo to Stand
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 10 A critical hour in the murder trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. may come soon after the courtmartial reconvenes to morrow after a long holiday recess.

title: Class Polarization a Challenge
description: The big cities of the coun trythose over 300,000 in populationare in deep trou ble, educationally speaking. Until just a few years ago the best high schools were generally to be found in such cities. Now few of the most successful schools and many of the most problemridden are there.

title: TIMES PLANS BOOKS ON CURRENT ISSUES
description: The New York Times an nounced yesterday that It will publish a series of books on major public issues to be titled, The Great Contemporary Is sues, A New York Times Re source ??

title: Amid Turmoil, It Is Easy to Forget the Strides That Have Been Taken
description: Whenever education fails to live up to people's demands and expectations, there is an outcry for instant change and prepackaged utopia. Those who ask for, and those who promise, such magic are, in fact talking, not change, but revolution.

title: Schools Look Afield For Fresh Managers
description: Tom McColleugh of Colum bus, Ohio, has decided at the age of 41 to change careers. Until last Nov. 1, he was an executive with a pharmaceu tical company. Now he is the first enrollee in a new proj ect that may put him, after a year or two, in a key role in a school system somewhere in the United States.

title: Cotton Body Changes Name
description: The Cotton Producers Insti tute, the research and promo tion arm of the cotton industry, has changed its name to Cot ton, Incorporated, J. Dukes Wooters, executive vice presi dent announced over the week end.

title: COLUMBIA ORDERS 5YEAR AUSTERITY
description: Columbia University, whose operations have incurred mount ing deficits over the last five years, called its institutional growth to a virtual halt yester day by announcing a fiveyear austerity plan designed to balance its budget.

title: Sesame Street May Be Path for Other Technologies in Teaching
description: In 1965 many parents or preschool children must have been sharing my experience. Sarah was three years old and already an avid watcher of television. She knew the programs she liked, would ask what the time was so that she could turn the set on, and was already able to tune her favorite channels. On occa sion we would wake up in the morning to find Sarah in front of the television set staring at the station iden tification signal before the regular programs started.

title: CITY SUSPENDS 4 IN TOMBS DEATH
description: Four city correction officers were suspended yesterday after another guard reversed his story and accused them of beat. a prisoner, who was later found hanged.

title: Bulls Beat Braves, 141113
description: Chicago, Jan. 10 (AP)The Chicago Bulls, behind the scor ing of Bob Love and Jerry Sloan and a tight defense, broke open a close game in the third quar ter and went on to a 141113 triumph over the Buffalo Braves today.

title: Miss Clifford Goes Home
description: GRINDELWALD, Switzer land, Jan. 10 (AP)Betsy Clif ford of Canada, the world giant slalom champion, left the Alpine ski circuit today and flew home because of psychi cal depressions and family problems, Peter Franzen, her coach, said.

title: Advertising:
description: Benjamin Page, long presi dent of Transportation Dis plays, Inc., has retired. His place at the International Telephone and Telegraph Cor poration subsidiary has been taken by David C. Esty, who will also be chief executive officer. Mr. Esty joined the company last year from J. Walter Thompson.

title: Teacher Is Gone, but Meditators Multiply
description: The Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, remember?

title: Maryland Hero Proves Answer To an Adman's Wildest Dream
description: Lofty Driesell has learned it pays to advertise.

title: Simon, English Cocker, Named Best at Spaniel Show for 2d Time
METREVELI GAINS 3D AUSSIE CROWN
description: HOBART, Tasmania, Jan, 10 (AP)  Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union scored his third major tournament victory in Australia when he defeated John Alexander of Australia, 76, 63, 46, 63, in the final of the Tasmanian tennis cham pionship today.

title: For Many, a Degree Is No Answer
description: The growing demand for an opendoor policy In pub licly supported colleges, cou pled with widespread attacks on the selective admissions practices in private ones, poses a dilemma for educa tors.

title: 96 Offtrack Employes Furloughed
description: The New York City OffTrack Betting Corporation, which won't be taking bets for an in determinate time, has fur loughed 96 of its 104 sellers.

title: Public Library Seeks to Attract Students and Funds
description: A threeman management team is reorganizing the New York Public Library to provide new work space for doctoral degree candidates and under graduates, expanded programs for adults and additional study facilities for neighborhood youngsters.

title: A Right to Intelligence
description: Consider the plight of the United States Army. Called to emergency service in support of the civil author ity when Detroit was a shambles from the savagery of its own people, super Vised by the Mayor of Detroit, the Governor of Michigan and the Deputy Secretary of Defense, sent in with un loaded guns to face the ghetto snipers, it is now pilloried for assembling in formation about friend and foe in the performance of this distasteful duty.

title: Albany to Get Sunday Racing Bill Today;
description: A bill to legalize Sunday racing at the state's thorough bred and harnessracing tracks will be introduced today by State Senator A. Frederick Meyerson. The Democrat from Brooklyn says, The time is ripe. Stanley Fink, also a Democrat from Brooklyn, Will introduce the bill in the As sembly at the same time.

title: Susquehanna Loan Rouses Opposition
description: A group of stockholders of the Pan American Sulphur Company has filed a petition with the Securities and Ex change Commission opposing the company's announced plan to lend $36million to the Sus quehanna Corporation.

title: $65Million U.S.Slum Aid Snarled in City Red Tape
description: Snarled for 19 months in its own red tape, New York City has been able to spend only half of its $65million grant of Federal Model Cities funds. The city expects to have $32million still unused at the end of this month.

title: LAWMAKERS PUSH STATE VOTE AT 18
description: Rapid, final legislative ap proval this week of the pro posed state constitutional amendment to lower the voting age in state and local elections to 18 years of age was pre dicted yesterday by State Sen ator Earl W. Brydges, the Re publican majority leader.

title: 76ers Subdue Celtics, 115107;
description: BOSTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) Billy Cunningham and Archie Clark combined for 55 points to lead Philadelphia to 115107 victory over the Boston Celtics today and lift the 76ers into a tie for second place in the Na tional Basketball Association's Atlantic Division.

title: Arabs Urge U.N. to Bar Israelis From Building in Occupied Land
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 10Jordan and the United Arab Republic have appealed to the United Nations and the Big Four powers to enjoin Israel from further changing the character and demographic composition of the Arab ter ritories under her occupation.

title: Surprise Friend for Passengers
description: The most remarkable aspect of the Interstate Com merce Commission's attack on the inadequacy of the projected national railroad passenger network is the source of the criticism itself. The I.C.C. has a spotty, not to say imperceptible, record as a public defender of pas senger service. It often seemed more accommodating to the railroads desire to discontinue trains than to the passengers need to ride on them.

title: EXU.S. AIDE TO SEEK ROLE IN G.M. HEARING
description: John M. Burns 3d, who says he was ousted as executive assistant United States At torney, said yesterday he hoped to be admitted as a friend of the court at next month's Federal Court session evaluat ing General Motors antipollu tion moves in North Tarry town, N. Y.

title: CLARENCE SCOTT JR., SECURITY OFFICER, 52
description: NYACK, N. Y., Jan. 10 Clarence L. Scott Jr., an expert on identification practices, died of a heart attack yesterday at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Sharon L. Scott, in Monroe. He was 52 years old and lived at 16 Aldine Park here.

title: Greece Ends Red Cross Visits to Political Prisoners
description: ATHENS, Jan. 10The Greek Government has decided to deny the International Commit tee of the Red Cross further privileged access to political prisoners.

title: N.C.A.A. Deprives California Of Track Title on Ineligibility
description: HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 10 The University of California was stripped of its 1970 out door track and field team championship by the National Collegiate Athletic Association today for having used an in eligible runner.

title: Dangerous Boondoggle
description: Judge Richard B. Austin of the United States District Court in Chicago may well be right when, in dismissing the suit against the Army's ventures into political sur veillance, he called such sleuthing a typical Washing ton bureaucratic boondoggling. But fundamental ques tions remain.

title: Zane's Powerboat Wins
description: MIAMI, Jan. 11 (UPI)The powerboat team of Bright Ste venson Jr. of Columbia, S. C., and Bill Zane of Miami won the Orange Bowl 250 speed classic today, leading on all but the first lap.

title: Oil Spill Cleanup Continues
description: PITTSBURGH, Calif., Jan. 10 (AP)Sweeper craft and six trucks using suction hoses were progressing at a reasonable rate today in cleaning up the San Francisco BayDelta's larg est oil spill, the Coast Guard reported. The Hoegh Belmar, a Norwegian ship, spewed about 12,000 gallons of fuel oil early Thursday at a Pittsburgh dock where she was taking on a cargo of coke.

title: Nixon Program Still Undefined
description: For most of the Nixon Ad ministration thus far, the Of fice of Education has operated like an army without either generals or a battle plan that the troops understood.

title: TILFORD W. MILLER
description: WILTON, Conn., Jan. 10 Tilford W. Miller, retired trea surer of the Seaboard Surety Company of New York, died today at his home on Belden Hill Road. He was 80 years old.

title: Rangers Down Blues, 42, on ThirdPeriod Spree;
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10A three goal outbreak within 3 minutes 10 seconds in the third period tonight enabled the New York Rangers to beat the St. Louis Blues, 42, and extend their winning streak to five games..

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ARDSLEYONHUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 10The Winchester, Mass., Curling Club No. 1 Rink, skipped by George Whitten, defeated Plainfield, N.J., C.C., skipped by Jack Gabrielson, 104, today to win the Ardsley Curling Club's first international mixed bon spiel.

description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 10 (UPI. Ray Elder of Carruthers, Calif., drove his 1970 Dodge to victory today in the ninth an nual Motor Trend Riverside 500 Grand National stock car race at Riverside International race way.

description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 I'm so happy I could cry, and I probably will, said Bob Lunn after he defeated Billy Casper in a fourhole playoff to win the Glen CampbellLos Angeles Open golf tournament today.

description: MIDDLE ISLAND, L. I., Jan. 10  Dutch Dice, owned by Hollandia Farms of St. James, L. I., and ridden by Harry De Leyer, captured the intermedi ate jumper championship with 10 points today at the Middle Island Arena Horse Show.

description: When the National Educa tional Finance Project held a conference of educators from every state recently, it found that they agreed on at least one point.

description: DOVER, England, Monday, Jan. 11 (UPI)Two ships, one of them the 13,604ton Pana manian tanker Texaco Carib bean, collided early today in the English Channel, radio re ports said.

description: Tickets may be obtained at the public desk, main lobby, United Nations Headquarters. Tours: 9:15 A.M. to 4:45 PM.

description: BUFFALO, Jan. 10 (AP)  Gerry Meehan's goal midway in the final period gave the Buf falo Sabres a 22 tie with the Los Angeles Kings tonight.

title: QUARTET EXTENDS BLUEGRASS RANGE

title: The Vietnam War From Ward 2B
description: The first American was killed in Vietnam combat in 1961. And so January of 1971 marks an uncele brated event: the beginning of the second decade of American casualties (over 44,000 dead, nearly 300,000 wounded) in this undeclared war that still crisscrosses four nations in South east Asia.

title: Mother and Baby Son Are Killed In Garden Apartment in Queens
description: A 25yearold mother was stabbed to death and her 17 monthold son strangled yester day in their garden apartment in Glen Oaks, Queens.

description: ATLANTA, Jan. 10 (UPI) Phoenix sank 46 of 51 shots from the freethrow line in scor ing a 116105 victory over At lanta tonight. The victory snapped the Suns twogame losing streak and extended At lanta's losing string to five games.

title: Advertising:
description: N. W. Ayer & Son is hold ing on to the Army Recruit ing account.

title: Experimental School in North Dakota Trains Teachers to Transform Classrooms
description: The New School, an ex perimental college at the Uni versity of North Dakota, has been in a unique position to question a good many of our educational presuppositions. Founded in June, 1968, its major charge was to estab lish a new kind of prepara tion program for prospective and experienced elementary school teachers and to initi ate constructive change in the schools of North Dakota.

title: Major Arguing With G.I.'s Shot to Death in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 10One United States Army major was killed and another wounded Friday fol lowing an argument between several black enlisted men and the two officers, both white.

description: BASEL, Switzerland, Jan. 10 (AP)Full employment must have priority over the battle against inflation throughout the world, the central hankers of major financial nations con cluded today. They attended the monthly meeting of the Bank for International Settle ments.

description: What is It like being a college teacher these days? What is it like being a col lege teacher any days?

title: Hooligans, U.S.S.R. and U.S.
description: It is difficult to understand what Messrs. Brezhnev and Kosygin think they are gaining by their carefully organized campaign of crude hooliganism against Amer icans in Moscow. Even before this past week's inci dents, no reasonable person doubted that the Kremlin could make life miserable for United States diplomats, journalists and businessmen in Moscow whenever it wished. That proposition was selfevident even before gangs of Soviet secret police thugs began threatening individual Americans, smashing the windshields of their automobiles, or slashing their tires. These incidents are so disgraceful and senseless that it is understand able why the men who ordered them have also made sure that these synthetic expressions of popular anger go unmentioned by the Soviet press.

title: INVENTORY BUYING IN STEEL GROWING
description: PITTSBURGH  Jan. 10  The steel inventory boom was picking up steam last week.

description: Most people who think about the matter at all seem to agree that something is wrong with schools and edu cation, but opinions differ sharply about the diagnosis of the ailment and even more sharply about the cure.

description: MONTREAL, Jan. 10 (UPI) Bill Lesuk, a rookie, scored two goals today, including the decid ing tally, as the Philadelphia Flyers overcame a twogoal deficit and defeated the Mont real Canadiens, 32.
