description: Nelson Freire, the young Brazilian pianist whose record ed playing created a stir when his first two disks were re leased here in 1969, made his New York debut a year ago as soloist with the New York Philharmonic. He played Rach maninoff's Fourth Piano Con certo at that time and, partly because the work itself is not a surefire winner, seemed a bit less impressive than might have been expected.

description: ATLANTA, Jan. 10  When Lester Garfield Maddox became Governor four years ago, the moans of liberals and moderates were heard from one end of Georgia to the other.

description: With little fanfare, sub santial numbers of colleges and universities have ven tured voluntarily into a sys tematic restructuring of high er education through the de velopment of cooperative ar rangements. Where formal ized, such groups are called consortia.

description: WARSAW, Jan. 10A con sumers charter intended to correct the major economic mistakes of the Gomulka re gime in Poland was outlined today in Warsaw newspapers.

description: The external degree, a new idea in higher educa tion whose time seems to have come here, is actually an old one with which other countries have had long ex perience.

description: CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (UPI) The Minnesota North Stars, sparked by the goaltending of Gilles Gilbert, beat the Chi cago Black Hawks, 32, on two thirdperiod power play goals tonight.

description: SAN ANTOMIO, Tex., Jan. 10 (AP)Ernie Caceres, who play ed with the big jazz bands of Benny Goodman and Glenn Mil ler in a career that spanned a quarter of a century, died to day in a local hospital after a long illness. His age was 59.

description: One of the first things a wellmeaning outsider is likely to ask the distaff half of a retired couple is: How did you ever get used to having Harry (or Bill, or John, etc.) underfoot all day long?

description: The bright, ringing sound of Earl Scruggs's fivestring banjo throbbed and sang all through Earl Scruggs: His Family and Friends, a 90 minute special seen (last night on Channel 13. It was an ap propriately American musi cal sound for a program that was filled with vivid slices of Americana as it traced the early career of this country music virtuoso.

description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 10The Central Committee of tic World Council of Churches opened a 12day policymaking session here today with rites at the Holy Trinity Cathedral.

description: Recent discoveries by Dr. Hans Moldenhauer have consid erably augmented the meager 31 opus numbers left by Anton Webern at his death in 1945. Two of these posthumous works, both for cello and piano, were introduced to New York by Lin coln Center's Chamber Music Society at its concerts Friday and Saturday nights.

description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 10 Elliot Berry, a senior from the University of Pennsylvania, won the Luckenbach Memorial Squash Racquets Tournament at the Nassau Country Club today. He beat George H. (Pete) Bostwick Jr., 158, 1511, 1715.

title: MABEL A. HASTIE

title: Bridge: Correct View of a SideSuit Is Very Important Decision
description: A player can often make an important decisicin cor rectly if he inspects his hold ing in his partner's sidesuit. Once a fit has been estab lished, a doubleton in part ner's sidesuit, or a singleton, is very much superior to a holding of three small cards. Establishment of the suit by ruffing becomes a possibility, and the danger of having an unavoidable loser is dimin ished.

title: Arts Abroad
description: PARIS  The death of great men creates a vacuum, which books try to fill. One of the first and easily the most monumental of the vol umes devoted to France's late President is Charles de Gaulle by Georges Suffert, an editor in chief of L Ex press. The journalist must travel fast, and to travel fast he has to travel light: when one whizzes along a highway, one can only read signposts, not lengthy mes sages.

title: Tayninh Clash Reported
description: SAIGON, Monday, Jan. 11 (AP)South Vietnamese head quarters reported heavy fight ing today northeast of Saigon near the provincial capital of Tayninh. It also announced a new drive into eastern Cam bodia by a force of 2,000 men.

description: BERCHTESGADEN, Germany, Jan. 10 (UPI)Horst Floth and Pepi Bader of West Germany, the world champions, captured the European twoman bobsled tiltle today at the Koenigsee course.

title: The Other Pollution  Internal
description: LONDONThe public has at last become conscious of the nearcata strophic proportion of the pollution problem. Few, however, are concerned as yet with the emerging reality of comparable trend in our internal envi ronmentour bodies.

description: Pressure from taxpayers and parents for accountabil ity among educators gave a strong impetus last year to the growth of performance contracting, the system that introduces the profit motive to the classroom.

description: The Rev. Dr. Frederic Sutter, chairman emeritus and former president of the board of trust ees of Wagner College, Grymes Hill, S. I., died yesterday in Staten Island Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived at 332 St. Paul's Avenue, Stapleton, S. I.

description: Once there was a time when the people of England's Midlands could survey a land scape devastated by the advent of industrialization and console themselves by saying:

description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Jan. 10Fletcher Martin, who retired in 1966 as secretary and house counsel of the Mer rittChapman & Scott Corpo ration, died yesterday in South Nassau Communities Hospital, Oceanside. He was 69 years old and lived at 311 Burtis Avenue.

title: DeLury Warns the City On Inhuman Conditions
description: The head of the sanitation men's union warned yesterday that unless the city improved sanitary facilities in 500 sanita tion garages and other installa tions the men would take a job action that would drastically cut garbage collections.

title: AMERICAN STANDARD SAYS '70 PROFIT FELL
description: American Standard, Inc., es timates that last year's earn ings dropped 55 per cent per cent to $16million from 1969's net income of $34.7million be fore extraordinary credits. Final figures are expected to be available in February.

title: Israelis Blame Guerrilla Threat For Strike Idling Town of Gaza
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 10A strike closed the Israelioccupied town of Gaza for the second successive day today. Shops were shuttered, schools closed and public transportation idle.

title: The BestDressed List, Once Again
description: No question about it. The men are catching up in fashion; they even have their own bestdressed list.

description: Frank C. Graham Jr., has been nominated to a third one year term as chairman of the board of governors of the American Stock Exchange.

description: Philosophical problems do not resolve themselves by being ignored, the his torian Lawrence A. Cremin wrote in 1965, and it will do Americans little good to quicken their pace in education if they do not know where they are go ing.

title: GYM GIVES THEME FOR MODERN DANCE
description: The gymnasium, long dis dained by older modern dancers as a skeleton in their perform ing closets, has found new favor with younger choreographers. On Saturday evening Seamus Murphy directed a team of dancers through the halls and pool of Queens College's gym nasium, in a work called Fab rication: An Image Fracture.

title: CITY DRAFTS PLAN FOR LOFTS IN SOHO
description: The City Planning Commis sion is ready to approve a revised plan to legalize residen tial use of industrial lofts by artists in a 43block area of Lower Manhattan, commission sources said over the weekend.

title: Queens Minister's Son, 10, Found Dead at Gas Station
description: A 10yearold Creedmore boy was found dead in the rear parking lot of a St. Albans, Queens, gasoline station yester day. The youth was identified as William Johnson, son of the Rev. and Mrs. William P. John son, of 18719 Pineville Lane.

description: The McDonnell Douglas Cor poration announced yesterday it has awarded a subcontract for about $38million to the Bendix Corporation, navigations and control division, Teterboro, N.J., to provide avionics test equipment for the Air Force F15 air superiority fighter.

title: Reform Drive Now Key Issue In Education
description: For some years, a small but passionate band of critics has been arguing that most American schools systematically stifle, bore, confound, oppress and often fail to educate children. A number of teachers, par ents, students and school officials have tended to agree.

title: Explosion in Village Injures 7 Firemen; Glass Cuts Civilian
description: Seven firemen and a civilian were injured last night when an explosion racked the base ment of a building in Greenwich Village.

title: Dance: Ballet Theater Adds to Assets
description: We see more of American Ballet Theater in New York than we used to, but we still don't see enough, and it is therefore always disap pointing when its seasons end. At the City Center last night the company ended a threeweek engagement that had been notable for a new partnership between Natalia Makarova and Erik Bruhn, enthusiastic audiences and a great deal of delightfully ex uberant dancing.

title: Campuses Retrench in Funds Crunch
description: It has been customary to seek solutions to the finan cial problems in higher edu cation by looking for more in come. Wealthy alumni or sympathetic legislators could bet counted on for extra funds, and of course tuition could al ways be raised.

title: Sloan Foundation Elects
description: William B. Mebane, who has been associated with the treas urer's office of the General Motors Corporation for 16 years, has been elected secre tary and treasurer of the Al fred P. Sloan Foundation. The foundation, established in 1934, has interests in science and technology, education, manage ment, and related problems of society. Mr. Mebane, who lives in Short Hills, N.J., succeeds Joseph W. Brinkley, who has joined the Asia Society in an administrative position.

title: Era of Affluence at an End
description: The next great force for change in higher education appears to be a deepening fi nancial crisis.

title: Okinawans Attack U.S. Base Over Plan to Move Poison Gas
description: NAHA, Okinawa, Monday, Jan. 11 (UPI)Okinawan dem onstrators charged into a Unit ed States military chemical area today and smashed windows in barracks and offices to protest American plans for removal of poison gas from the island.

title: Caledonian Club No. 2 Rink Captures Douglas Bonspiel
description: MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 10  The New York Caledonian Curling Club No. 2 Rink, skipped by Joseph Milano, won the Douglas Medal bonspiel to day, succeeding the club's No. 1 rink. Milano skipped his four some to a 137 victory over Brae Burn Curling Club of West Newton, Mass., skipped by Howard (Bud) Chandler, in the 12end final at the St. Andrew's Golf Club indoor ice rink.

title: Chanel, the Couturier, Dead in Paris
description: PARIS, Jan. 10Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel, one of the greatest couturiers of the 20th century, died tonight in her apartment at the Ritz Hotel. She was 87 years old.

title: Halifax Victor in Rugby
description: LONDON, Jan. 10 (Reuters)  Halifax beat York, 3513, today in a Rugby League match,

title: Survey Finds Private Colleges Must Have Significant Aid to Offset Expected Deficits
description: A survey of 75 per cent of the country's 762 private, ac credited fouryear colleges and universities shows that nearly half expect operating deficits in the current fiscal year total ing about $87million.

title: They Opted for P.S. 41 And Don't Regret It a Bit
Are Our Schools too Conservative to Teach Minorities Effectively?
description: For almost 25 years, hang ing near my desk has been print of the beautiful draw ing by Thomas Hart Benton that he aptly titled Instruc tion. In this sensitive draw ing an old black man with his tattered books, papers, clothing and surroundings is depicted helping a young black child to learn.

title: Orange Bowl Gets Soccer
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 10The Na tional Collegiate Athletic As sociation's soccer championship semifinals and final will be held in Miami's Orange Bowl the week before the Orange Bowl football game the next three years.

description: The head of the Jewish De fense League said yesterday that his group was forming teams to follow, question and harass Soviet diplomats in the city.

title: Congress Expected to Give Draft Issue Urgent Priority
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10As one of its first orders of busi ness, the new Congress must decide whether to abolish, re form or continue the military draft system.

title: The Talk of Cortland
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.There is a saying in this city that goes: All you have to do is find a problem and an or ganization will be formed to deal with it.

title: Ladgham Asks CeaseFire
description: CAIRO, Jan. 10 (Reuters) Bahi Ladgham, leader of the truce committee in Amman, ap pealed tonight for an immedi ate ceasefire and said this would be a condition for con tinuing his mission in Jordan.

title: Dr. Hollington Tong Dies at 83;
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Jan. 10 Dr. Hollington K. Tong, Am basador of Nationalist China to the United States from 1956 to 1958, died last evening in a nursing home here. He was 83 years old.

title: French Basque Life Is Peaceful
description: HENDAYE, France, Jan. 6 The French repression is nice, a pharmacist here in this small Basque region in the southwestern corner of France says of the national attitude toward Basques.

title: Lots for Little Shop, Where Bargain Items Aid Charities
description: It's the thrift shop where the Ford girls (and you know who they are) donate things Charlotte said, Yes, we periodically drop things off there. Where a famous ac tress's evening dress is on sale in the window. And where a red steamer trunk arrived Just the other day filled with clothing and three fur coats from Louisiana, of all places.

title: Lakers Fall, 118109, to Pistons
description: DETROIT, Jan. 10 (AP)The Detroit Pistons broke away in the final quarter to whip the Los Angeles Lakers, 118109 today.

title: Flexibility Is the Rule At Hampshire College
description: Educational Innovation Is easier dis cussed than achieved. Even the most progressive of colleges are largely locked into traditional programsby profes sors with tenure, costly buildings and laboratories, rigid academic departments and courses, grading systems, and a whole range of vested interests, not the least of which is a conservative body of alumni and donors.

title: Dickens Described a Bureaucracy
description: To some observers, the city's tangled bureaucracy is remi niscent of the classic description given by Charles Dickens in his book Little Dorrit, of the Circumlocution Office whose motto was How not to do it.

title: John Lindbeck, Expert on China, Dies
description: Dr. John M. H. Lindbeck, di rector of the East Asian Insti tute at Columbia University since 1967, died of a heart attack Saturday in Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in North Tarrytown, N.Y., and New Fairfield, Conn.

title: At Portland, Ore., a Model Is Molded for High Schools
description: All institutions have a built in resistance to change, but few have been so impervious to the winds of reform as the urban high school. The ob stacles to reform have been considerable, for the princi pal of a typical urban high school has neither the lati tude nor the resources to in itiate substantial change.

title: Chafee Trip Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10A Defense Department spokes man acknowledged tonight that Secretary Chafee would be in Puerto Rico tomorrow. He would not say whether Mr. Chafee would have an an nouncement but he did say, Disctissions are being con ducted between the Navy and Culebrans in a cooperative ef fort to address the Culebra situation.

title: MISS MURRAY VICTOR IN EASTERN SKATING
description: BOSTON, Jan, 10  Suna Murray of West Orange, N. J., won the senior women's title in the Eastern skating cham pionships at the Boston Skating Club today.

title: Young Professionals Turning Activist
description: Unhappy about spending three years of apprenticeship doing drafting in a large architectural office, three young architecture graduates have set up shop in a color fully painted storefront along a narrow side street in Cam bridge, Mass.

title: Chess: Fischer's Routine Unusual In Victory Over Rubinetti
description: An attack by pawns on opposite wings usually insin uates excitement in the com mon Sicilian Defenses. When Grandmaster Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles played the white side against Jorge Rubinetti of Argentina, how ever, he shattered orthodox routine. The game Is from the recent Palma, Majorca, event.

title: Two Poets Share Bollingen Award
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 10 Two poets, highly regarded yet poles apart in the volume of work they have done and the recognition they have re ceived, have been selected to share the prestigious Bollin gen Prize in Poetry.

title: BUCKS RUN WILD IN 151TO99 ROUT
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 10 (UPI) The Milwaukee Bucks went on a record spree tonight and demolished the Baltimore Bul lets, 15199, in the National Basketball Association.

title: JOINT CHIEFS HEAD TO VISIT CAMBODIA AND ASSESS CRISIS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 10Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird is sending the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to Pnompenh amid in creasing concern here over the plight of the Cambodian Gov ernment.

title: Queens Skaters Capture Eastern Speed Crowns
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Jan. 10 (AP)Ron Peters of Queens, with a strong showing in the sprint events, rallied to capture the annual Eastern States outdoor speed skating championship.

title: Teachers in Pittsburgh Ratify Contract and End 7  Day Strike
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 10 (UPI) Striking teachers voted to night to accept a $900ayear pay increase from the city's School Board, ending their walkout a week after it began.

title: Sports of The Times
description: A shrewd and skeptical observer commented the other night at a Howard Samuels sideshow at Yonkers Raceway that if every State Assembly District had been assigned a betting shop hooked into the tote board of a race track, offtrack betting would be opening today, as once promised. But such a small, neat system, relatively inexpensive and controlled by the tracks, would require little in the way of construction and computers and jobs for vice presidents. No deal. Samuels, who rarely blinks, replies that there is no longterm value in such a smallfry system, not when a big system will eventually wipe out organ ized crime, turn on the met ropolitan area to gambling and show the country how a Government agency can make money for the people. But before even this big system will turn a profit worth the investment, ad mits Samuels, baseball, foot ball and basketball will have to be made into legalized betting games, and gam bling winnings will have to be declared untaxable, which should please people who work for their money.

title: Vatican Considering a Reform of Confessions for Venial Sins
description: ROME, Jan. 10The Vatican said today that it was consider ing a reform that would allow some priests to absolve groups of Roman Catholics from their venial sins without individual, secret confessions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Francescatti, Casadesus Are Partners in Brahms
description: Important artists never lose the capacity for surprising you. Just when the man who has known for years the elegant and aristocratic playing of Zino Francescatti and Robert Casa desus, and comes prepared for a certain kind of excellence, just then do they rise up and bring off the Brahms Sonata in D minor with hot abandon, risk ing everything including accu racy to give the finale its proper agitation and excitement.

title: `Now Generation Can't Afford Price of Forgetting
description: Once in the midst of a college sem inar, I was interrupted by a student heckler who demanded to know, What is the relevance of evolution? I shud dered momentarily, envisioning three billion years of mysterious cosmic effort flung aside by a single youth.

title: Many Gains Simply Beget New Failings
description: It is the fate of the American college and university to be Constantly picked as a target of reform but seldom per ceived as a product of reform.

title: 3 U. S. Correspondents in Moscow Latest Retaliation Victims
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 10  Three American correspondents are the latest victims of the Soviet Union's campaign of retaliation for the harassment of Soviet representatives in the United States by militant Jewish or ganizations. The cars of all three were vandalized in public.

title: Problems Mount for Italy's Giant Montedison
description: MILAN, ItalyMontecatini Edison, the largest mining and chemical corporation on the European continent, struggled under three chairmen last year while executive factions and behindthescenes power brokers fought to control the sometimes baffling con glomerate.

title: Man in the News
description: To excavate, says Prof. Spyridon Marinatos, is to open a book written in the language that the centuries have spoken into the earth. But it is a language you can only read once: while you are digging.

title: MRS. HERBERT A. BAKER
description: Mrs. Ethel Andem Baker, widow of Herbert A. Baker, former president of the Ameri can Can Company, died yester day in Point Pleasant Beach (N.J.) Nursing Home. She was 82 years old.

title: NIXON CONSIDERS AGENCY SHAKEUP
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 10A major overhaul of the executive branch of the Fed eral Government, including the creation of four new Govern ment departments, has been proposed to President Nixon.

title: Uruguay Leader Asks Suspension of Rights
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 10 (UPI) President Jorge Pacheco Areco asked Congress today to suspend constitutional rights for 90 days as thousands of police men and troops search for three kidnapped foreigners.

title: How Does a College Formulate Its Courses For the Unforeseen?
description: Campus turmoil has monopolized the headlines in recent years. As a result many significant changes that have been implemented have not attracted the public attention they deserve. I would like to predict that the last five years will be noted by historians as a period of major constructive change on the university campuses.

title: Most Major Cities Will Ignore Birthday of Dr. King on Friday
description: Fortytwoyears ago this Fri day, the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was born. On April 4, 1968, he was killed by a sniper's bullet in a Memphis motel after he had received the Nobel Peace Prize and had been acclaimed as one of the world's leading human rights figures.

title: 3 Elements Pivotal In City Education
description: In the fall of 1966 a group of parents and other neighborhood residents dem onstrated outside Intermediate School 201, a massive, windowless, aircondi tioned structure that stands on concrete stilts in the squalor of East Harlem.

title: Ashley Thorndike, Served With Harris Upham &
description: ARDSLEYONHUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 10  Ashley Thorndike, a vice president of Harris Up ham & Co., Wall Street broker age house, died yesterday in Dobbs Ferry Hospital after having suffered a heart attack while playing in a match for the Ardsley Curling Club. He was 61 years old and lived at Field Terrace here.

title: Power to the People
description: President Nixon now seems more firmly committed to a form of Federal revenuesharing than ever before, but Governor Rockefeller emerged last week, In his State of the State message, as perhaps the most articu late spokesman for that doctrine.

title: Focus Shifts to Social Issues
description: Most schools have long been skittish about becoming immersed in tumultuous situ ations. But more and more students and teachers are now involving themselves in the human and ecological problems, the social tensions the socalled gut issues that have lately permeated so many campuses with a sense of angst.

title: PRESIDENT MOVES TO PARE BILLIONS IN BUSINESS TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  The Nixon Administration, in the hope of reversing the cur rent business downturn, is planning an immediate reduc tion of several billion dollars in the taxes paid by business a reduction that it will put into effect without waiting for Con gress to act.

title: Books of The Times
description: Three books about professional football one the story of a famous coach's last season in the sport, one a collection of re membrances by his associates, and one the autobiography of a dropout from the game. And if your inclination is to yawn and turn away because you don't happen to be in terested in football, then resist the tempta tion for a moment. For side by side, these books may shed some light on why you don't like the game, or why you do. And together they can be read as a debate on certain profound values in the American culture.

title: V. K. SHUTTLEWORTH
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 10 Vernis K. Shuttleworth, a re tired executive of the American Can Company, died yesterday at High Ridge House in Bedford Hill. He was 75 years old and lived at 34 Drake Road here.

title: Dow Jones &
description: Warren H. Phillips has been named editorial director of Dow Jones & Co., pub lisher of The Wall Street Journal and other publica tions and news services.

title: City Notes Unemployment Rise, But Looks for Economic Growth
description: New York City has begun to feel the squeeze of the national recession, the city's Economic Development Administrator said yesterday. But he held that an office construction boom and an increased industrial park program would ease the city's problems.

title: Buckingham, British Bass, Sings Songs From Handel to Rodgers
description: Raymond J. D. Buckingham was at Carnegie Hall Saturday for what was variously billed as a virtuoso concert and a night you will always remem ber.

title: Restructuring Deemed An Urban Imperative
description: As educational and social institutions, the schools of bigcity America are in serious trouble.

title: Everything She Touches Turns to Dolls
description: LOS ANGELESFor the husband whose wife is always complaining that her husbands gifts are on the practical side, Pamela Weir offers what may well be one of the most romantic presents arounda 6footdollwith an equally romantic price tag, about $100 a foot.

title: LENDER TRIMS RATE ON F.H.A. MORTGAGES
description: The Home Federal Savings and Loan Association of Wor cester, Mass., has reduced its maximum interest rate on Fed eral Housing Administration and Veterans Administration loans to 7 percent from 8 percent, Edward C. Maher, pre sident of the institution, an nounced over the weekend.

title: AN ATTEMPTED COUP REPORTED IN BOLIVIA
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Monday, Jan. 11 (UPI)The Minister of Interior, Jorge Gallardo, said early today that fascist ele ments had attempted a coup d'tat against the military Government of Gen. Juan Jos Torres, but had failed.

title: Kayhko Leaps 238 and 249 Feet To Capture Lake Placid Honors
Sports Cost, Income Study
description: A survey by the University of Missouri has shown that athletic income matches athletic costs only at colleges with largescale football programs, and that expenditures have tended to increase faster than income for colleges as a whole.

title: Navy Reported Set to Yield in Fight With Culebra
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 10 The United States Navy has apparently run up the white flag in its efforts to acquire more land and intensify gun nery practice operations on the tiny Puerto Rican island of Culebra.

title: Coed Dorms In With Nary a Ripple
description: Coeducation is the biggest thing in college dormitories since the hotplate. It's spread ing so fast that not even the Association of College and University Housing Officers can tell how far it's gone in the roughly two years since it began its current life.

title: An Old Grad Returns to P.S. 144
description: Since I still owed the place a geogra phy paper, which was due in 1935, it was with some apprehension that I re turned one recent wet December afternoon to P.S. 144 in Forest Hills. I felt like a salmon swimming upstream to the waters that spawned him.

title: A City Aide Assails Discharging Addicts From the Military
description: The city's deputy chief medi cal examiner charged yesterday that the armed forces were returning narcotics addicts to civilian life to steal, indoc trinate other persons and be come problems for communities that cannnot treat them.

title: NORTH STARS WIN AMERICAN BOWL
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 10 (UPI) Leo Hayden of Ohio State and aul Staroba of Michigan scored two touchdowns each today as the North posted a 392 victory over the South in the American Bowl allstar football game.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The following is a list loans and other aid extended last week by the United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: THOENI TRIUMPHS IN SPECIAL SLALOM
description: MADONNA DI CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Jan. 10 (AP)Gustavo Thoeni, 19yearold Italian ski ing ace, dominated both heats of the Tre Tre special slalom today for his first World Cup victory of the season.

title: Oil Slick Wasn't Oil
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 10 (UPI)  An oil slick that washed onto the beach near Seaside, Ore., wasn't oil at all. Chemists of the Federal Water Quality Administration report that it was some form of chloro phyll, possibly formed by sea weed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: American Symphony Introduces Amram Concerto
description: One of the movements of David Amram's Triple Concerto for Wind, Brass and Jazz Quintets and Orchestra is marked Allegro robusto. Aptly, because the chief quality the whole piece communicates is a sort of healthy, roundhouse robustness and not much else.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Jan. 10Edward Heath is traveling to Singapore this week, for the Conference of Commonwealth Prime Ministers, with considerable con fidence that disaster will be avoided. Disaster would be dissolution or frag mentation of the Commonwealth over the issue of arms sales to South Africa.

title: 2 STUDIES CHEER CAPITAL OUTLOOK
description: Two detailed studies of the sources and uses of funds in 1971 just published give com forting arguments that there will be enough money to go around this year. Interest rates should decline further.

title: DONALD M'LACHLAN, LONDON NEWSMAN, 63
description: LONDON, Jan. 10  Donald McLachlan, editor of The London Sunday Telegraph from its inception in 1961 until 1966, was killed in a road accident in Elgin, Scotland, today. He was 63 years old.

title: Disciplined Ecumenism
description: In a recent religion class at Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx, the Rev. William Rooney was discus sing the death of Christ and the question of blame.

title: Snow Cancels Ski Meet
description: BOZEMAN, Mont., Jan. 10 (UPI)A weekend ski meet was canceled because of too much snow. The United States Ski Association Northern Divi sion called off a twoday meet at nearby Bridger Bowl because three feet of new powder made the course impassable for the 130 skiers.

title: FamilyPlanning Breakthrough
description: American leadership in the worldwide effort to curb the population explosion should be substantially strength ened by the new $382million family planning bill which President Nixon recently signed into law.

title: Giunti Dies Alter Auto Crash; Porsche Wins Argentine Race
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 10 (Reuter)Ignazio Giunti, an Italian racing driver, died today after being badly burned in a crash during the Buenos Aires grand prix.

title: Bombs Explode In Singapore As Prime Ministers Arrive
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 10 (AP) Two bomb blasts badly dam aged a British jeep at a down town military police post to night as prime ministers began arriving for the conference of Commonwealth leaders.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Caso Sees Nassau Spending Cut As Likely If Tax Receipts Fall
description: County Executive Ralph G. Caso of Nassau warned yester day that a second acrossthe board cutback in outlays for county government might be necessary within the next few weeks.

title: Day Care Plans Stress Education Role
description: The need for child care services outside the family, an obscure theme less than a decade ago, is in the fore front of the nation's con sciousness today.

title: Canada Runs Into Delay Of Development Agency
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 10Creation of a Canada Development Cor poration, a Governmentowned holding company intended to diminish United States eco nomic influence in Canada, has been delayed by the refusal of a number of leading business men to head the agency.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 (UPI)  I've got my wheels back, said Mrs. Billie Jean King with a grin after her 63, 64 victory last night over Rosemary Casals in the final of the British Motors women's professional tennis tournament.

title: Inflation Cuts Weekly Income $1.72
description: In the New York, North eastern New Jersey area, in flation in the last year has reduced real spendable earn ings by $1.72 a week for a factory worker with three de pendents, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics said yes terday.

title: 2 Galaxies Found Near Earth's
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 10 Two massive galaxies next door to the earth's own gal axy, the Milky Way, have been detected by California astron omers.

title: Black Candidates in Race For Delegate in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 Suddenly, there are two sets of political headliners in Washing ton. One is familiar: Nixon, Ag new, Kennedy, Mansfield. The other means little outside the District of Columbia: Yeldell, Phillips, Fauntroy.

title: U.S. Lists 91 Beaches As Closed or Polluted
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)A preliminary survey conducted by the Environ mental Protection Agency showed today that 91 beaches in the United States had been closed or posted as polluted.

title: Prep Schools, Pressed, Going Coed
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass. Nathan Fuller came to this Connecticut Valley town from New Orleans in September, 1968, to take over as head master of the Northampton School for Girls.

title: Muskie Arrives in Cairo, Will Confer With Egyptians
description: CAIRO, Jan. 10Senator Ed mund S. Muskie arrived in Cairo tonight for a threeday visit that is to include talks with President Anwar elSadat, Premier Mahmoud Fawzi and other officials.

title: 100 SEEK CLEANUP OF FLUSHING RIVER
description: The Flushing River winds south for less than a mile from Flushing Bay to a dam where the old World's Fair site begins in Queens. It is not much of a river, compared with the Hudson, but about 100 Flush ing residents demonstrated their concern for it yesterday afternoon.

title: LEAFS LATE GOAL SINKS WINGS, 32
description: DETROIT, Jan. 10 (UPI)Bill MacMillan's thirdperiod score and superb goaltending by Bruce Gamble tonight helped the Toronto Maple Leafs post a 32 National Hockey League victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Sam Howe Captures Cup In Merion Squash Racquets
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Jan. 10 Sam Howe, former United States squash racquets cham pion, regained the William F. White Memorial Cup by defeat ing Palmer Page, the No. 1 play er of the University of Pennsyl vania, 1514, 1510, 157. in the final of the annual invitation tournament at the Merion Cricket Club today.

title: An Appraisal
description: Once again, the Bollingen people have split their award between two poets, though the differences, equally great, are more subtle and not so dramatic as those that sepa rated the work of John Berry man and Karl Shapiro, win ners of last year's prize.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: M'MULLEN VICTOR IN TWO JUMPOFFS
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 10Lieut. Andre McMullen, visiting at his Somerset, N.J., home before reporting this week to a new United States Army assignment in Fairbanks, Alaska won his second tourney in two days by taking the New Jersey State ski jumping champ ionship before more than 26, 000 today. The meet was spon sored by the Odin Ski Club.

title: Does Any body Have Fun on Campus Any More? It's All Matter of Relativity
description: When the alumni returned to Bethel College in McKen zie, Tenn., for homecoming this year, they were im pressed by the new field house, awed by the new fine arts buildings and rather puzzled by the students on the trim, tiny campus.

title: Bruins Top Seals, 74
description: BOSTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)Ken Hodge and John Bucyk scored two goals each tonight to lead the Boston Bruins to a 74 vic tory over the California Golden Seals.

title: This Period of Ferment May Be a Turning Point
description: Fifty or a hundred years hence his torians may well call the decade from 1965 to 1975 a turning point in the history of American education. In any case, the pressures for change seem unprecedented. We may now be living through a time of ferment as significant as the common school revival of the mid19th century or the progressive education movement that emerged in the early 20th century.

title: Calle Takes 10Mile Run Through Streets of Bronx
description: Augustin Calle, a former South American champion now living in Brooklyn, won a 10.6 mile race through the Bronx streets yesterday.

title: Lunokhod Moves Again
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 10 (Reuters) The Lunokhod, the Soviet Union's automatic moon vehi cle, has started moving again after sitting out a second cold, long lunar night, the official press agency Tass reported to day. The vehicle moved 140 yards yesterday during a 4 hour communication session with ground control, Tass said.

title: PACTS IN JORDAN NOW SEEM ENDED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 10 The agreements that ended the Jordanian civil war last Septem ber appeared to have broken down today as fighting was re Ported in and around Amman, the capital, the the third con secutive day.

title: NET INCOME SOARS AT BANKERS TRUST
description: A sharp increase in the fourth quarter swelled last year's profit of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation to a rec ord, both before and after se curities transactions, according to the 1970 results issued yes terday.

title: Minetto Scores in 3 Classes At New Jersey Horse Show
SCHOOLS IGNORE BREAKFAST FUNDS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10The New York City Board of Education and all but one of the city's 31 community school boards have failed to apply for funds avail able since last fall under a state program to finance free and very lowcost breakfasts for needy children.

title: B'nai B'rith Assails Kahane
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11The board of governors, the ruling body of the 500,000member B'nai B'rith, the largest Jewish organization in the world, to night adopted a resolution de nouncing the threat by Rabbi Kahane as a pernicious and senseless vendetta which will only cause greater anguish for Soviet Jewry.

title: TV: Bawdy First Churchills Bows
description: Even if The First Church. ills weren't coining at us with humor, bawdiness and taste and with equal amounts of petticoat and epee  which they are  the return of Alistair Cooke as a week ly TV visitor would be enough reason to rejoice at the British Broadcasting Corporation's latest export,

title: Broadcasters'
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) Paul Haney has been named executive vice president for public relations of the National Association of Broadcasters. Mr. Haney left his job as a pub lic affairs executive with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in 1969 to work for the Houston Sports As sociation. He was known for his reports on the progress of manned space flights while serving with NASA.

title: Changes in Food Safety Rules Scored
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Two lawyers critical of the Food and Drug Administration charged tonight that proposed changes in the agency's rules would weaken efforts to protect the public from potentially harmful chemicals in food.

title: The Perfectibility of Man Is Really All We Have to Sustain Us
description: When Christopher Jencks and David Riesman published the first of a pro jected twovolume study of American colleges and universities three years ago, they called it The Academic Revolu tion. What they meant by revolution was the change of emphasis in our uni versitiesfrom undergraduate general education to graduate school profes sionalism; from teaching to research.

title: Hodgins Memorial Friday
description: A memorial service will be held for Eric Hodgins, author and advertising executive, at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at 50th Street, on Friday at 2 P.M. Mr. Hodgins, the author, of Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House and Episode: Report on the Accident Inside My Skull, died Thursday at his home, 150 East 50th Street, at the age of 71.

title: Planners Vote Industrial Sites On 129 Acres Along Gowanus
description: More than 20 blocks129 acresof predominantly vacant or underutilized land along the Gowanus Canal in South Brooklyn were designated as an industrial development area by the City Planning Commis sion yesterday.

title: ExPoliceman Describes ShootOut to Panther jury
description: Joan Bird, one of 13 Black Panthers on trial in State Su preme Court here for an al leged bombing conspiracy, was at the wheel of a car whose two passengers engaged in a shootout with the police, a former patrolman testified yes terday.

title: STRIKE BAN ON L.I.R. EXTENDED TWO DAYS
description: A threatened strike of the Long Island Railroad was post poned yesterday when a Fed eral judge in Brooklyn again extended a restraining order forbidding the walkout.

title: Justice Philip M. Kleinfeld Dies; Served on State Supreme Court
description: Philip M. Kleinfeld who re tired at yearend as Justice of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, died of a heart ailment yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 76 years old and resided at 136 East 56th Street.

title: City Ballet to Give Three Premieres; Kodaly Thursday
description: The New York City Ballet will present its second premiere of the season, John Clifford's Kodaly Dances, on Thursday night at the State Theater. Two other new works, Concerto for Two Pianos by Richard Tanner and Four Last Songs by Lor ca Massine, will have their first performance on Jan. 21.

title: Rep. Udall Says He Leads Race for Democratic Post
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI)  Representative Morris K. Udall, Democrat of Arizona, said today that an independent survey of House Democrats showed that he was the front runner, clearly ahead in the race for election as House Democratic leader.

title: Thomas at 35 Looks Forward To Running Behind Condon, 18
description: Albie Thomas, who seldom saw the back of a rival run ner in a distance race, asked Chris Condon to turn away yesterday at the weekly luncheon of the Track Writ ers Association of New York.

title: High Court to Rule If Ali Is Entitled to Deferment as Conscientious Objector
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 The Supreme Court agreed to day to decide whether Muham mad All, the former world heavyweight boxing champion, was entitled to be deferred from military service as a con scientious objector.

title: 2 UMPIRES LOSE APPEAL TO COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) The Supreme Coutt refused, 8 to 1, today to take a new look at its nearly halfcentury old doctrine that baseball, un like other bigbusiness team sports, is not subject to Fed eral antitrust laws.

title: TV: Are Racism and Bigotry Funny?
description: Tonight the Columbia Broadcasting System Tele vision Network will find out if Americans think bigotry and racism, as the prime ele ments of a situation comedy, are funny.

title: STATE BILL TO ASK A PUSHER BOUNTY
description: A bill to pay a taxfree bounty of up to $2,500 to peo ple who turn in narcotics push ers will be introduced in the Legislature to help stamp out addiction in schools.

title: Mrs. White and Jenssen Win Snowmobile Honors
description: PETERBOROUGH, Ontario, Jan. 11 (Canadian Press)Mrs. Pat White of Peterborough and Roger Jenssen and his American team won the major honors as the Kawartha Cup 1971 snow mobile races ended today.

title: Israel Marks Milestone : Population at 3 Million
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 11 Is rael's population officially passed the threemillion mark tonight. Honored at Lydda Airport as the arrival who brought the figure to this milestone was Natan Cherolinkov, an emigrant from Leningrad.

title: ALBANY PRESSING JOBLESS AID BILL
description: ALBANY, Jan. 11Prodded by an announcement today that unemployment of insured work ers had climbed to more than 4 per cent, the Legislature moved with unaccustomed speed on a measure extending state unemployment insurance benefits to 39 weeks from 26.

title: Man in the News
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 11One recent afternoon as Derek Curtis Bok, dean of the Harvard Law School, was lunching with friends in the student cafeteria he won dered out loud why it wasn't possible to make a hamburg er that did not taste like plastic and still sell for less than a dollar. Soon the person able 40yearold dean, who has a degree in eco nomics, was pour ing over figures with the caf eteria manager. The result was an edible and economi cal hamburger and a big rise in sales at the deficitridden cafeteria.

title: Oklahoma Bans Paroles For Narcotic Pushers
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 11 (UPI)Gov. David Hall is sued an executive order to day, prohibiting paroles for adults convicted of illegally selling or giving drugs to minors. Governor Hall had been in office about an hour when he signed the order.

title: Books of The Times
description: COMMON AND UNCOMMON MASKS. Writ ings on Theater, 19611970. By Richard Gilman. 321 pages. Random Press. $8.95.

title: Theater: Yegor Bulichov Given at Long Wharf
description: NEW HAVEN The Long Wharf Theater in New Haven is making something of a specialty of the plays of Maxim Gorky. Last season it produced, very successfully, Gorky's Country People, and this season it has given Gorky another American pre miere, Yegor Bulichov.

title: Cowboys Rookie Finds Fame Is Name of Game
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 11 (UPI)Bob Asher, a rookie offensive lineman for the Dallas Cowboys, got his first look at the large num ber of newsmen here for Sunday's Super Bowl game and grumbled about them.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Dec. 30 news ?? entitled Rail Service Plan Assailed by I.C.C. is a classic tale of the archaic think ing of the Congress and the govern mental agencies with respect to the railroads.

title: Pompidou Supports Art Show To Return Mastery to France
description: PARIS, Jan. 11  President Georges Pompidou is behind an ambitious project for a giant exhibition of contemporary art produced in France by artists of all nationalities. The show is to be on display in the spring of 1972 at the Grand Palais.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I thought I must write this letter be fore the plight of the city's prison population, like integration and In dians, is out of fashion.

title: Uruguay Granted Special Police Powers by Congress to Hunt Guerrillas Who Kidnapped British Envoy
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 11  President Jorge Pacheco Areco today asked the Uru guayan Congress for a three month grant of special police powers to hunt for the kid nappers of Britain's Am bassador here.

title: BIG BOARD PLANS STUDY OF ITSELF
description: The New York Stock Ex change is planning to set up a special study group to make a detailed investigation of the structure and operations of the exchange. The study is expect ed to produce recommendations for farreaching changes in the workings of the exchange.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11Down in Greene County, Ala., a threejudge Fed eral court has just found a Southern public official guilty of criminal con tempt in a civil rights case. It wasn't because of some big, nationally pub licized incident, and the penalty, while severe, was not spectacular; but never mind. It was still the first finding of criminal contempt against a Southern public official since the Brown decision of 1954 opened the contemporary racial revolution.

title: Nassau Wonders If Its Police Are in a Job Action
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 11 Nassau County and the Patrol men's Benevolent Association, which have been unable to agree on a new contract, dif fered today on whether the po lice were engaged in a job ac tion.

title: WHEAT FUTURES HAVE MIXED DAY
description: Future prices of commo dities traded on the Chicago Board of Trade opened on an irregular tone yesterday, weakened and then rallied about midsession to close mixed.

title: Teachers Demand Suspension of Richman High Principal
description: A resolution calling for the immediate suspension of the principal of troubled Julia Rich man High School in Manhattan was adopted yesterday morning by the school's chapter of the United Federation of Teachers.

title: A TAXI COMMISSION URGED BY MURPHY
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy urged the City Coun cil yesterday to create a Taxi Commission to regulate the in dustry and set reasonable rates.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market was firmer yesterday in moderate trading, with selective buying of leading issues.

title: Comment by O'Brien
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI) The chairman of the Demo cratic National Committee, Law rence F. O'Brien, said his course of action in response to the suit would depend on advice of the committee's attorneys. He added: I have said repeatedly over the years that major re form of this country's political campaign financing is long overdue.

title: MendesFrance Weds Count's Widow
description: PARIS, Jan. 11  Pierre MendesFrance, the former French Premier, recently mar ried Mrs. MarieClaire de Fleuricu, it was learned here today.

title: HOWE IS SELECTED ALLSTAR 22D TIME
description: Gordie Howe, in his 25th season, was selected yesterday for the National Hockey League's AllStar game for the 22d time.

title: EXPERT PREDICTS IMPROVED GRAINS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 11Prospects of a major breakthrough in increasing pro tein yields from grains were forecast today by Dr. Norman E. Borlaug, who won the 1970 Nobel Peace Prize for his de velopment of new wheat strains.

title: Jacksonville Wins by 9567
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 11 (UPI)  Jacksonville University grabbed a 10point lead in the opening minutes tonight and romped to a 9567 victory over Oklahoma City University.

title: Advertising:
description: Having a degree in anthro pology and psychology from the University of London and being a founder of a com puter software company hardly sound like the proper credentials for a magazine publisher. But then, what are?

title: Harlem School Gets $50,000
description: The Harlem Preparatory School, Eighth Avenue and 139th Street, a tuitionfree school founded by the Urban League in 1967 to prepare high school dropouts for college, re ceived a $50,000 grant from the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) yesterday, the company announced.

title: A Slap at Seniority
description: Democrats of the incoming House of Representatives are primed to make a dent at long last in the seniority eystembut probably no more than a dent. Gratifying as the prospect is, it should not be confused with the essential reform of ridding the House once and for all of the tradition that mere political longevity warrants arbi trary control over the legislative life of that chamber. For even if the party caucus adopts in full the recommen dations of its special study committee headed by Repre sentative Hansen of Washington, the oligarchy of tenure will remain almost intact.

title: N.C.A.A. Urges Fewer Scholarships
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 11The National Collegiate Athletic Association urged member schools today to put into ef fect a threepoint plan aimed at cuting costs of intercolle giate athletics, particularly football and basketball.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  At the first hint of a snowfall Washington is salted down like an immense animal hide. The theory is that people would rather be saltbound than snowbound. The salt melts the snow and keeps the streets dry for our sensitive automo bile tires, which express their grati tude by getting us to the office, the supermarket, the school and all those other marvelous places on time.

title: 700 Demonstrate Over Plan to Close A Welfare Center
description: Seven hundred people pick eted the offices of the Mott Haven Welfare Center, at 329 East 149th Street, yesterday to protest the planned closing of the center and the transfer of its 5,500 cases to three other welfare centers in the Bronx

title: Rates on Bills Decline Sharply At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 Treasury bill rates declined sharply at today's aucion from last week's levels, the Govern ment reported late this after noon, to their lowest levels in nearly three years.

title: Surgeon General Urges Battle To Dissuade Women Smokers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11The Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service called today for a major cam paign to persuade women of the dangers of cigarette smok ing.

title: Biscayne Edges Iona
description: Biscayne College overcame a 33point performance by Art Wiggins and defeated Jona Col lege, 6864, last night at Mount St. Michael Academy in the Bronx.

title: CHILE TO RECEIVE 70 IN BRAZILIAN RANSOM
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 11 (Reuters)The Brazilian Gov ernment said tonight that it would fly to Chile all 70 politi cal prisoners it is freeing as ransom for the kidnapped Swiss Ambassador, Giovanni Enrico Bucher.

title: Syria Offers to Mediate
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 11 Syria, in an unusual move, of fered today to mediate to end the fighting between the Jor danian Army and the Pales tinian guerrillas.

title: Trial Does Not Resume
description: MOSCOW, Jan, 11 (Reuters)  The trial of nine Leningrad Jews accused of antiSoviet activity apparently did not re sume today. It was postponed Wednesday.

title: BLAST HURTS 27 G.I.'S DURING VIETNAM RIOT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 11 (UPI)  All United States Army enlisted men's clubs at Tuyhoa, 240 miles northeast of Saigon, were ordered closed today in a move to cool tem pers following a riot in which a handgrenade blast wounded 27 Americans.

title: Strange Particles Found In Apollo Lunar Samples
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 11Scien tists reported here today that they had discovered in moon soil exotic components that they believed were fragments from a primitive crust that cov ered the moon 3.5 billion years ago.

title: About Pro Hockey
description: With consecutive road vic tories over the weekend, the Rangers continued a surge that has lasted more than a monthand hasn't got them any closer to first place in the National Hockey League's East Division. In their last 22 contests, the New Yorkers have lost only twice. They began the stretch one point be hind the over bearing Boston Bruins. They are one point behind them today. Of course, the rest of the division has fallen far bhind. The others won't get much closer than they are now, unless the Rangers or Bostonians nosedive. The Rangers, who can move into first tomorrow if they defeat the Canucks at Vancouver, have 37 games remaining 19 at home. Twenty of their final contests will be against expansion clubs.

title: LUNAR ORBIT WINS SPRINT BY A NOSE
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 11 The Cerulean Farm's Lunar Orbit took the featured Swaps Purse at Pimlico by a nose today.

title: Gregory James Leads a Sweep By Anzac Pacers at Raceway
description: YONKERS, Jan. 11The pa rade of Anzac horses to the winner's circle continued to night when the first three fin ishers in the featured Pelham Pace carried the New Zealand banner.

title: Armed Guard on Court
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 11 (UPI)Brenda Kirk and Laura Roussouw, South African tennis players, broke down and cried today when antiapartheid dem onstrators disrupted play in the New South Wales champion ships at the White City courts.

title: Basketball Poll
description: The leading college basket ball teams, with points tabu lated on a 10987654321 basis (firstplace votes in paren theses) and wonlost records through games of last Sunday:

title: MARY ANN WELLS
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 11 (AF) Mrs. A. Forest King, a ballet instructor whose former pupils included Robert Jaffrey of New York's City Center Jaffrey Ballet, died Saturday after suf fering a stroke three weeks ago. She was 76 years old.

title: EXBROWN STAR SEES NO N.F.L. BLACKLIST
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 11 (AP) Bill (Dub) Jones, former Cleve land Browns star, said today he had told a Federal grand jury he didn't think that black listing or racial discrimination existed in the National Foot ball League.

title: BLANDA IS SELECTED MALE STAR OF YEAR
description: George Blanda, the 43year old subquarterback and kicking specialist of the Oakland Raid ers football team, was named yesterday male athlete of the year by The Associated Press. He beat out much younger play ers for the honor.

title: Kentucky Tops Georgia, 7966
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 11 (AP)  Kentucky solved Geor gia's slowdown offense midway through the first half and cruised to a 7966 Southeastern Conference victory tonight.

title: Western Kentucky
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ky., Jan. 11 (AP)Western Kentucky in creased its lead in the Ohio Valley Conference tonight with an easy 8563 victory over Morehad State University. The Hilltoppers now have a 40 record in the OVC and a 121 mark for the season. Morehead is 04 in the conference.

title: All Seeking Jersey Home
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 (AP) Muhammad Ali reportedly is seeking to purchase a $150,000 home in nearby Cherry Hill, N.J., that would provide ample space for a training camp for his fight with Joe Frazier.

title: She Made Certain It Honored Lincoln
description: When anything is missing In the Don Hewitt household, 4yearold Lisa is automati cally the culprit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: LINDSAY DEFENDS MODEL CITIES AID
description: Mayor Lindsay defended New York's record in the Federal Model Cities program yester day, contending that his ad ministration had cut red tape in the last year and reduced the average time of delay for implementing new projects from nine to five months.

title: Retailers Mark Up Expectations for 1971
description: The entire new year will he better than 1970, but I'm afraid spring won't be, Da vid Suskind, a Virginia re tailer, asserted yesterday. The senior vice president and treasurer of Miller & Rhoads, Richmond, added, The strong Christmas wind up is to me a definite augury for a good tempo in 1971, even though it apparently won't occur right away.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL RAISES PRICES 12% ON BUILDING ITEMS
Poles Visit East Germany
description: BERLIN, Jan. 11  Poland's new Communist leaders, Ed ward Gierek, the party chief, and Premier Piotr Jaroszewicz, met today in East Berlin with East German leaders.

title: 3 ONONDAGA AIDES WORK MINUS PAY
description: SYRACUSE, Jan. 11Three top Onondaga County officials worked without pay today be cause of a legal question over the length of their terms of office.

title: N.C.A.A. PANEL URGES USE OF MOUTHPIECES
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 11The Na tional Collegiate Athletic Asso ciation Football Rules Commit tee was asked today to make it mandatory for college football players to use mouthpieces.

title: Wilkins Tells N.A.A.C.P. Elections Show Blacks Working Within System
description: Roy Wilkins, executive di rector of the National Associa tion for the Advancement of Colored People, said yesterday that the November elections proved that millions of Negro Americansthe overwhelming majorityhave chosen to work within the framework of the American system.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 11 (AP)  Tennessee bombarded the basket from long range to night and turned back Florida, 8575 in a Southeastern Confer ence basketball game. The vic tory gave the Volunteers a 31 wonlost record in the league. Florida is now 24.

title: Advertising:
description: Among the 53 pages of ad vertising in the debut issue of On The Sound, the maga zine created by Life alumni, will be one from alma mater.

title: 4 Bronx Young G.O.P. Units Defect to Democrats
description: The defection of four Young Republican clubs in the Bronx to the Democratic Reform movement was announced yesterday.

title: Students Barricade Dorm
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 11 (AP)Students barricaded on the fourth floor of a dormi tory at American International College have refused to talk with administration officials un til their demands are met. The 33 students set up the barri cades Friday.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES POLITICAL FUNDING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 Common Cause, a new public interest lobby, began a dr?? today for the reform of po litical fundraising laws that it said had allowed campaign costs to soar and fraud and humbug to flourish.

title: LADY CUMMING
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 11 Lady Cumming, the former Nancy Acheson Houghton of Shippan Point, wife of Sir Duncan Cumming, the last British chief administrator of Eritrea, died yesterday in Lon don after a long illness. She was 64 years old.

title: Nixon Condemns Attacks
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 11 (UPI)President Nixon condemned as morally wrong today the bombing attacks on Soviet facilities in the United States.

title: Merger News
description: TRW, Inc., an aerospace and automotive parts manufacturer, announced yesterday it had agreed to acquire the General Battery Corporation, makers for replacement batteries main ly for automobiles, aircraft, ma rine and trucks.

title: Bolivian Revolt Called Rightist Attempt
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 11 (AP) President Juan Jos Torres charged today that leaders of an unsuccessful army uprising had sought to impose a dic tatorship of the right.

title: Early Slates Stunt Growth of 3 Ivy Fives
description: The expected: The Univer sity of Pennsylvania's 11 straight basketball victories and its ranking among the nation's top 10 teams.

title: YIELDS ON BONDS CONTINUE DECLINE
description: Interest rates continued to move lower yesterday, and a smaller highgrade utility bond issue was priced to yield 7.60 per cent  down from 7.75 per cent last week,

title: U.S. Group Visits Geneva To Seek Help for P.O.W.'s
description: GENEVA, Jan. 11 (Reuters) A fivemember group represent ing the Concern for Prisoners of War organization based in San Diego, Calif., arrived here today to see the International Red Cross Committee about prisoners of war in Vietnam.

title: Norell Trims Prices for the First Time
description: Norman Norell's spring show was more than half way over last night when a girl swung out in a green, blue and red plaid taffeta skirt. It even rustled. She wore it with a navy shirt with little tucks on it and her waistline was trimly belted.

title: Flight Security May Stiffen in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI)United States domes tic flights will have to be as thoroughly screened as inter national flights if airplane hi jackings continue, the chief of civil aviation security said today.

title: HARRY R. BRETTER
description: Harry R. Bretter of Zucker man, Smith & Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange, died Sunday of a heart attack in the Presbyterian Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 930 Fifth Avenue.

title: New Harvard Head Will Seek Unity
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 11  Derek Curtis Bok said as he was officially elected president of Harvard Univer sity today that the task of unifying the school would be of highest importance.

title: Airline Pilot Rehired In Fuel Dumping Issue
description: MIAMI, Jan. 11 (AP)An Eastern Airlines pilot who was dismissed after he re fused to dump excess fuel in midair has been rehired as a pollution consultant, the company announced today.

title: Army Trounces Kings
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 11 (AP)Army rebounded from a sluggish first half, and, sparked by Doug Clevenger's 23 points, routed Kings College of Penn sylvania, 6432, tonight.

title: NEW RULES SPUR MEDICAID QUERIES
description: Hundreds of poor people lined up forlornly for hours yesterday from 330 West 34th Street west toward Ninth Ave nue as the City Department of Social Services tried to explain new Medicaid requirements. Under the requirements Medic aid enrollees who are not on welfare must pay 20 per cent of their outpatient bills.

title: Chotiner Leaving White House to Aid Nixon's 1972 Race
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  Murray M. Chotiner, one of President Nixon's key political aides, will leave the White House staff soon to begin organizing Mr. Nixon's cam paign for reelection in 1972.

title: Blake Bids Churchmen Widen Talks With Jews
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 11 The Rev, Dr. Eugene Car son Blake, general secretary of the World Council of Churches, called today for increased con tacts between his organization and Jewish religious leaders, in cluding talks in the sensitive area of the content of religious belief.

title: MGM Earnings Gain Ground For the Latest Fiscal Quarter
description: The financial fortunes of Metro  Goldwyn  Mayer, Inc., have taken a turn for the better with earnings for the first fiscal quarter ended Nov. 21 mark ing the best since the second quarter of fiscal 1968, the re port of James T. Aubrey Jr., president, disclosed yesterday.

title: Envoy Off to Consult
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP)  Ambassador Anatoly F. Do brynin left for Moscow yester day for consultations, State De partment officials said today.

title: Bonn Asserts East Seeks to Sabotage A Solution on Berlin
description: BONN, Jan. 11The West German Government accused East German leaders today of seeking to sabotage attempts to ease EastWest tensions on the Berlin issue.

title: Vietnam Spurs Cambodian Road Push
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 11 (UPI)South Vietnamese soldiers were reported moving on two fronts today to try to help Cambodians clear enemy forces from key highways to Pnompenh.

title: Trial Is Told That Hutto's Mylai Job Was to Walk in and Shoot
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Jan. 11The defense attorney for Sgt. Charles E. Hutto contended today that the infantryman had entered the hamlet of Mylai 4 on a combat assault without any intent of killing civilians.

title: 4 Reported Killed in Amman As Army and Guerrillas Clash
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 11 Three civilians and a police man were said to have been killed in shooting incidents here today, but calm was reported in the countryside where there had been clashes in recent days between Government troops and Palestinian guerrillas.

title: FOOTBALL DROPPED BY BUFFALO STATE
description: BUFFALO,, Jan. 11 (UPI)  Faced with a $400,000 deficit accumulated in the last four years, the State University of Buffalo announced today it was dropping intercollegiate foot ball.

title: Webster Named Top Coach
description: Alex Webster of the Giants was named the United Press International coach of the year in the National Football Con ference yesterday. He received 10 votes from the panel of 36 writers in the 13 league cities to beat Charlie Winner, the de posed coach of the St. Louis Cardinals, who received eight votes. Dick Nolan of the San Francisco 49ers received six votes.

title: Loyal Friends Assist Hospital
description: Leo Culhane, who retired six years ago as Roosevelt Hospitai's chief ambulance driver, got to know members of the medical staff when they were internes.

title: SHOWDOWN IS SAID TO BE NEAR AT I.O.S.
description: GENEVA, Jan. 11The fight for control of Investors Over seas Services seems to be near ing a final showdown, sources close to the troubled mutual fund complex said today.

title: Nevada Welfare Cut
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Jan. 11 (AP)Nevada has dropped 22 per cent of its welfare recipi entsabout 3,000 men, women and childrenon grounds that they have been cheating the state at a rate of about $1mil lion a year, according to George Miller, the state welfare direc tor.

title: ExG.I. Says He and Calley Shot Civilians at Mylai Under Orders
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 11 Former Pfc. Paul D. Meadlo testified today that he and First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. shot more than 100 unarmed South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai 4 but that they were only do ing their job

title: Air Strikes Reported
description: SAIGON, Jan. 11 (AP)The United States command an nounced new air strikes in Laos and Cambodia today to thwart infiltration of North Vietnam ese men and supplies.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW SUM GAINS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange firmed somewhat yesterday as the list made a slight advance on moderate trading.

title: Only Thing on Ali's Mind Now Is Beating Frazier
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 (UPI) Muhammad Ali said today he was glad about the Supreme Court's decision to hear his case on draft evasion. But he added that the one thing on my mind and the only thing now is Joe Frazier.

title: Chemical and Charter Report Big Increases in Net Income
description: Two more of New York City's giant moneymarket banks reported yesterday substantial increases in net income for the fourth quarter. The Chemical New York Corporation, the onebank holding com pany for the Chemical Bank, said its fourthquarter net soared 44.5 per cent, raising its profit for the year to a gain of 13.4 per cent.

title: Shipping Group Accuses Onassis of Vilification
description: An independent shipping group charged yesterday that the Aristotle Onassis empire of various corporate artifices legally referred to as the A. S. Onassis group of shipping companieshad sought to de stroy potential competition by a worldwide campaign of vilif ication and disparagement.

title: ISAAC YOHANNAN, 96, A PRIEST SINCE 1903
description: YONKERS, Jan. 11The Rev. Isaac Yohannan, a retired Epis copal priest who had been asso ciated with St. John's Church in Getty Square since 1917, died Friday in the Hudson View Nursing Home after a long ill ness. He was 96 years old.

title: Lively and Innovative Bronx Arts Council Promotes Cultural Fare on a Shoestring
description: To Mrs. Irma Fleck, Gerald Klot is the Sol Hurok of the Bronx. It is not that he does things on a Hurokian scale, but that he knows how to make something a sym phony orchestra, for instance out of nothing. When he has a little bit, he can make a great deal of it.

title: Fairfield Subdues Canisius As Groom, Kelley Star, 6563
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11 (UPI)  George Groom scored 22 points and Bob Kelley 16 tonight as the University of Fairfield defeated Canisius College, 6563.

title: Adderley Expects to Be Busiest
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 11  Herb Adderley, a vital link in the Dallas Cow boy defense at left cornerback, expects that John Unitas, the Baltimore Colt quarterback, will be picking on him in the Super Bowl game on Sunday. Adderley is ready.

title: Soccer Player Is Kicked To Death by Opponents
description: PUEBLA, Mexico, Jan. 11 (UPI)  An amateur soccer player was kicked to death yesterday by members of the opposing team during a free forall in the second half of a game.

title: Strong Enforcement of Welfare Laws Provokes Conflicts Between U.S. and States
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11A number of states appear to be headed for major conflicts with the Federal Government over the administration of rising welfare costs.

title: Assembly Democrats Lose Bid To Put End to Phantom Voting
description: ALBANY, Jan. 11How can a vote be recorded in the name of a state legislator at the in stant he is miles away, playing on a golf course?

title: Illegal Explosives Reported Used in Mine Where Blast Killed 38
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 11 A miner has testified that he saw illegal dynamite and ex plosive primer cord used on Christmas Eve in the Finley Coal Company mine where an explosion killed 38 miners six days later.

title: HARYOU GIVES TYLER VOTE OF CONFIDENCE
description: State Supreme Court Justice Andrew R. Tyler, who has re signed as chairman of the board of HaryouAct, the Harlem anti poverty agency, was given a vote of confidence by the agen cy's board last night.

title: 70 STRIKE LOSSES HIGHEST SINCE 59
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI) Work time lost by strikes rose last year to the highest level in more than a decade, the Labor Department said to day. The 71day General Mo tors strike accounted for a fourth of the time lost.

title: POLLUTANT FIGHT IN AUTOS HAILED
description: DETROIT, Jan. 11  The job of eliminating air pollution from the automobile is over the hump, Dr. A. J. Haagen Smit, one of the nation's fore most authorities on air pollu tion, said today in an inter view.

title: Pollution Accusations Against G.M. Dismay North Tarrytown
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 11Officials of this vil lage, where the huge General Motors assembly plant pays half the local taxes, expressed surprise and dismay today that their small Hudson Riv er community of 8,800 people had apparently become a bat tlefront in the fight against pollution.

title: Chicago Teachers Vote for a Strike Of Schools Today
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (UPI) The Chicago Teachers Union house of representatives voted tonight to go on strike tomor row against the nation's second largest public school system.

title: PETER A. CAMPBELL, A LAWYER HERE, 52
description: Peter A. Campbell, a lawyer and management consultant, died Sunday at St. Luke's Hos pital. He was 52 years old and lived at 171 East 94th Street.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Plea Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) The Justice Department re jected today a plea from a civic rights group that it seeks a re hearing of the Supreme Court's decision striking down a Fed eral law giving 18yearolds the right to vote in state and local elections. The group, the Na tional Association for the Ad vancement of Colored People, had urged a rehearing, contend ing that the Court had appar ently not considered the argu ment that Congress did have the power to set voting ages in state and local elections.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Now that the migratory waterfowl hunting seasons are over in most states and drawing to a close in others, many sportsmen will forget all about ducks and geese until next fall, and this is a mistake.

title: MARKET RECOVERS FROM EARLY LOSS
description: Machinetool Issues suddenly became the glamour group of the stock market yesterday, thanks to wellpublicized re ports that the Nixon Admin istration would liberalize de preciation rules for new ma chinery and equipment.

title: Kentucky Folk Returns $219.80 at Tropical for First Triumph Since 1968
description: MIAMI, Jan. 11 (UPI)Ken tucky Folk, a 1081 shot, moved up with a rush in the final strides at Tropical Park today to win a $10,000 handicap race at one mile on the Tartan track.

title: Sargent Seeks Vote at 18
description: BOSTON, Jan. 11 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent said today he would seek to amend the state constitution to allow 18 yearolds to vote in state elec tions. Governor Sargent made the announcement in a state ment proclaiming January Youth Voter Registration Month.

title: Supreme Court to Weigh Curb on Judges Power
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11The power of judges to mete out punishment for criminal con tempt against persons who dis turb their courtrooms will be considered by the Supreme Court later this year.

title: MORRIS M. SCHEINBERG
description: Morris M. Scheinberg, board chairman of Girdlecraft Fashion Company, a manufacturer of women's foundation garments, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Sunday at Brookdale Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 72 years old and lived at 1433 49th Street, Brooklyn.

title: International Paper Lifts MultiUnit Carton Prices
description: The MultiPak division of the International Paper Company announced yesterday price in creases of about 7 per cent on all multiunit cartons sold to soft drink bottlers throughout the United States, effective Feb. 1.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: B'NAI B'RITH CUTS BUDGET FOR 1971
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 B'nai B'rith adopted a budget today that for the first time since the Depression was lower than the previous year's budget.

title: Laird Expects Wider Pullout of Troops
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 11Secretary of Defense Mel vin R. Laird said tonight that South Vietnamese forces were improving so rapidly that addi tional thousands of American troops could be withdrawn this year.

title: JOHN A. SANDERS
description: HAMDEN, Conn., Jan. 11 John A. Sanders of 369 Circu lar Avenue, president since 1965 of Mission of California, Inc., a New Haven soft drink concern, and a vice president of another, the Cott Corpora tion, died yesterday in Yale New Haven Hospital after a brief illness. He was 59 years old.

title: FERRARI WITHDRAWS ARGENTINA ENTRIES
description: MODENA, Ialy, Jan. 11 (AP) The Italian Ferrari racing factory announced today it was withdrawing from the Grand Prix of Argentina Formula One auto race scheduled Jan. 24.

title: Horse Sales Drop Sharply On Keeneland's First Day
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 11 (UPI)The opening session of the twoday Keeneland January horse sale saw 171 head bring $770,100 today, well below last year's opening day mark of $2,373,000 for 152 head.

title: Federal Share of School Expenses at 6Year Low
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) The National Education Asso ciation reported today that it would cost a record total of $42.4billion in 197071 to run the nation's public schools but that the Federal Government's share would drop to its lowest percentage level in six years.

title: Stretch Comeback By Hark The Lark Wins at Liberty Bell
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 Larry Boyce's Hark The Lark broke dead last in a field of seven but charged through the stretch to overtake Roland Aristone Sr.'s Smidge Boy and won the featured Millrift Purse by a halflength at Liberty Bell Race Track today. Three lengths back was G. F. Veir man's Evie's Beau.

title: Met Lists Two Tenors
description: The Metropolitan Opera has announced that Franco Corelli, tenor, will appear in the title role of Giordano's Andrea chnier Thursday night, and that John Alexander will take the tenor role of Edgardo in Donizetti's Lucia di Lammer moor Friday night.

title: Israelis at Odds Over Expansion of Jerusalem Into Surrounding Arab Areas
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 11  The longsmoldering issue of Israeli expansion into the hills and valleys of Arab Jerusalem has finally burst into the open, in a conflict between Israeli lib erals and conservatives within the City Council, and between the municipal government and Israeli national authorities.

title: Britain Edges Toward the Market
description: President Pompidous assertion that the differences over the terms for Britain's entry into Europe's sixnation Common Market are reconcilableand will be recon ciledgreatly increases London's chances of gaining membership.
