description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The 1970 rise in Christmas retail sales was far stronger than in 1969, the chief Commerce De partment economist reported today.

title: Accounting Inquiry Is Set
description: New York State Attorney General Louis J. Lefltowitz or dered yesterday an investiga tion into the accounting meth ods used to prepare Wall Street financial statements.

title: U.S. Embassy Gets Protest From a Rabbi in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 12Yehuda Leib Levin, the Chief Rabbi of Moscow, signed a petition to day accusing militant Jewish groups in the United States of emulating Fascists in their tactics. The petition said Soviet Jews did not want such un solicited protectors.

title: 2 Productions Scheduled
description: Two productions have an nounced playing dates. At the Other Stage, in the Public The ater, Robert Montgomery's Subject to Fits will be seen Jan. 20 to 24 and Jan. 27 to 31. John Guare's House of Blue Leaves, stymied by the recent OffBroadway strike, will bow on Feb. 7 at the Truck and Warehouse Theater.

title: 3 ANCHORMEN VIEW STATE OF NEWS ON TV
description: Anchormen for the three ma jor television networks agreed yesterday that the networks have not been intimidated by Vice President Agnew; that they were professionals com mitted to objectivity and fair ness, and that President Nixon is an adept television per former.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. King Aide Takes Lead in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Jan. 13The Rev. Walter E. Fauntroy, a 37yearold Baptist minister who rose to promi nence as an aide to the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., took a long stride yesterday toward becoming the District of Columbia's first nonvoting dele gate to Congress in more than 90 years.

title: PETER S. BOYNTON, 51, WRITER AT WESLEYAN
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 12Peter S. Boynton, senior tutor and cochairman of the College of Letters at Wesleyan University, died last evening in Honolulu, where he had been visiting his mother, Mrs. Peter Boynton.

title: Algerian Oil Problem Plagues Pompidou
description: PARIS, Jan. 12President Pompidou's policy of building up French prestige and power in the Mediterranean is in trouble at one of its principal points of application, Algeria.

title: DR. SIMON MILLER
description: YONKERS, Jan. 12  Dr. Simon Miller, a dentist for 55 years, died today at his home after a long illness. He was 83 years old and lived at 257 Bal lantine Lane.

title: N.A.M. Criticizes New Record Setup On Minority Hiring
description: The Federal Government is taking steps to speed up in dustry's extremely slow rate of progress in hiring and pro moting minority workers, but the National Association of Manufacturers does not like the way it's being done.

title: Bretons End School Boycott
description: RENNES, France, Jan. 12 (Reuters)Breton parents at Quimperle, near here, have voted to send their children back to school after a boy cott because the teacher had married a divorced man.

title: UNITED NATIONS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 12 The first problem in the critical nego tiations here for peace in the Middle East is to get rid of the threats and maneuvers that make serious negotia tion impossible.

title: Wider Bank Role Called Threat
description: The furor over the grant ing of credit and the increas ing role of bank credit cards are causing many merchants to wonder if they can still regard credit as the retail er's best friend.

title: CUT IS WEIGHED IN SAVINGS RATES
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 A regulated rate reduction in interest paid to savers is quiet ly being considered in the sav ings and loan industry.

title: Egypt's Conditions for Peace
description: CAIROA question that I am al most invariably asked by foreign vis itors to my office in Al Ahram is: What is the ultimate Egyptian posi tion for a peaceful settlement of the conflict with Israel?

title: JERSEY CITY SEEKS A 2% PAYROLL TAX
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 12 Mayor Thomas J. Whelan called on the state today to help meet Jersey City's expected $18mi1 lion deficit by allowing the city to impose a 2 per cent payroll tax.

title: Theft of Arms Laid To Retired General
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12A retired Army general, named during an extensive Congres sional investigation of military corruption, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of illegal firearms trans actions and income tax evasion.

title: Steel Executives Believe Nixon Wasn't Well Briefed on Rises
description: Unofficial reaction in the steel industry yesterday to the White House denunciation of price increases was a feeling that President Nixon must have been imperfectly briefed on the reasons and the need for the rises.

title: Dutch Bishops Yield to Vatican On Appointment of Conservative
description: THE HAGUE, Jan. 12Roman Catholic Bishops in the Nether lands yielded to Vatican pres sure tonight and decided to ac cept the controversial 39year old Dr. Adrien Simonis as the new Bishop of Rotterdam.

title: JEANNINE MORAND HAS LOCAL DEBUT
description: It seems unreasonable, even unfair, that the Canadian so prano, Jeannine Morand, should not have sung in New York be fore her Alice Tully Hall recital on Monday night.

title: U.S. JURY STUDIES '65 CITY CAMPAIGN
description: The books of several labor unions and business concerns nave been subpoenaed by the Federal grand jury that for six months has been investigating the sources of some contribu tions to the campaigns of both major sets of candidates in this city's 1965 municipal elections.

title: Bubba's Ready to Pounce on Morton
description: MIAMI, Jan. 13  The bigger they are, the harder they fall  on a quarter back. But if Bubba Smith, the biggest of the Baltimore Colts, is to fall on Craig Mor ton, the Dallas Cowboys' quarterback, in the Super Bowl game Sunday, the Colt defense must create passing situations by controlling the Cowboys' running game.

title: Personal Finance
description: What's the price of a wife? In past years in this country a woman was expected to bring her husband some sort of dowry when they married. It might be some cows, which were once a sign of wealth, some real estate or a bank account.

title: Brown Sets Mark in 3Mile Run at Metropolitan A.A.U. Title Meet
description: After driving 150 miles by car, Barry Brown ran the fast est three miles on an unbanked indoor track last night at the 80th annual Metropolitan Ama teur Athletic Union track and field championships.

title: Navy Honors Bob Hope
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 13 (UPI)Bob Hope received yes terday the Navy's highest civ ilian honor, the Distinguished Public Service Award, fdr con spicuous generosity in enter taining American servicemen for 30 years.

title: Fateful Commonwealth Meeting
description: A meeting that begins today in Singapore may decide whether the Commonwealth of Nations breaks up over Britain's determination to resume arms sales to South Africa. Prime Minister Heath will not announce the decision at the Commonwealth gathering but he doubtless will indicate whether he is willing to modify his plan to sell ships and aircraft to Pretoria.

title: SNOW FALLS ON CITY; BLIZZARDS IN WEST
description: Snow began falling here last night at about 8 o'clock. It was expected to change to freezing rain this morning, and danger ous driving conditions were forecast for the morning rush hour.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
AGNEW AND GIBSON DIFFER ON AID PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13  Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark said today that Vice President Agnew had assured him President Nixon would not reduce existing Federal aid pro grams to produce funds for his expanded proposal for revenue sharing with the cities and states.

title: West Accuses Soviet in Berlin Talks
description: BERLIN, Jan. 13  Four power talks on Berlin got off to a difficult new start today as Western officials asked the Soviet representative for an explanation of the latest ha rassment of allied access to West Berlin.

title: Monmouth College Elects
description: Dr. Richard J. Stonesifer, 47 years old, dean of the College of Liberal Arts at Drew Univer sity in Madison, N. J., has been named the new president of Monmouth College in West Long Branch. He will succeed Dr. William G. Vannote, who is retiring this June.

title: McGrath Pleased With Repairs to Jail
description: The city's Correction Com missioner, George F. McGrath, toured the Queens House of De tention yesterday morning to inspect the progress of repairs to $750,000 worth of damage caused by inmates when they rioted for three days last October.

title: New Chairman Vows to Speed L.I. Nuclear Power Hearings
description: PORT JEFFERSON STATION, L. I., Jan. 13The 17weekold Atomic Energy Commission hearing on an application to build Long Island's first nuclearpower plant was taken over today by a new chairman, who announced that the hear ing would be considerably speeded up.

title: G.O.P. in Albany Asks U.S. For TaxSharing Measure
description: ALBANY, Jan. 13Republi can leaders of the State Legis lature called today for an amendment to the United States Constitution providing for the sharing of Federal revenues with the states.

title: POTATO FUTURES REGISTER A GAIN
description: Most potato futures options showed a gain yesterday on the New York Mercantile Ex change after a Government re port said there was a dis appearance of 103.5 millior hundredweight of potatoes from the time of harvest in October last year until Jan. 1, 1971.

title: Sports of The Times
description: An advertising executive pointed at Gil Hodges posing for a cigarette poster and said: Quality men use quality products. If Hodges smokes Viceroy, it might do some thing for you, too. That was in 1962, two years before the Surgeon General's report and six before Hodges's heart attack. Finely conditioned athletes who objected to smoke blown in their faces were generally considered health freaks. Stars who smoked would cup their burning ciga rettes and put their hands behind their backs when pho tographers appeared. The stars, many of whom had break fast cereal accounts to protect, would piously intone, The kids shouldn't see me smoking. Then, as now, the sports industry itself had relatively few restrictions about ciga rettes. Many playbyplay broadcasts were sponsored by tobacco companies. There were billboards inside ball parks. And although baseball players were forbidden to smoke in the dugout during a game, they could endorse cigarettes as long as they did so out of uniform, The lack of professional smokers among professional athletes these days, according to a spokesman for the tobacco industry, is purely a result of the cigarette companies' selfregulation.

title: Eligible Unemployed Urged To Register for Benefits
description: An estimated total of 35,000 jobless workers throughout the state who are eligible for the extended unemployment insur ance benefits under new state legislation approved by Gover nor Rockefeller Tuesday were advised yesterday to register next week at their unemploy ment insurance offices.

title: Alaska Pipeline Is Upheld By Interior Agency Study
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The Interior Department re ported today that an oil pipe line across Alaska would create unavoidable environmental damage, but it recommended that the line be constructed be cause the oil was so crucial to the country.

title: UNDEFEATED PENN TOPS ST. JOSEPH'S
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 (AP) Dave Wohl and Steve Bilsky, held in check through most O the game, rescued Penn tonight as the fourthranked Quakers heldoff their crosstown rivals. St. Joseph's, in the second game of a Palestra doubleheader to win, 6258.

title: BOMBS RIP HOME OF AIDE IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Jan. 13  Two bombs exploded last night at the home of the Minister of Employment, Robert Carr, To day the incident raised wide spread concern that political violence, which has missed Britain so far, may be erupting here.

title: BERRIGANS DENY KIDNAPPING PLOT
description: DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 13 From a counsel room in the Federal prison here, the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and the Rev. Daniel Berrigan issued today a statement denying that they had any part in an alleged plot to kidnap a Presidential assist ant and damage Federal build ings.

title: McCracken Aide Comments
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 A spokesman for Mr. McCracken, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, confirmed tonight that Mr. Cart, chairman of Bethlehem Steel, had met with Mr. McCracken here Mon day night and informed him of the increase in steel prices.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: German Talks to Resume
description: BONN, Jan. 13At the initia tive of East Germany, a new attempt to resume the talks between the two parts of Ger many will be made on Friday, the West German Government announced today.

title: 3DPARTY BACKING RESTRICTED ON L.I.
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., Jan. 13 The chairmen of the Suffolk County Republican and Demo cratic parties agreed today to forbid their candidates to ac cept endorsements from parties other than their own.

title: JAMES R. SCOTT
description: RED BANK, N. J., Jan. 13 James R. Scott, a retired hosiery manufacturer, died yes terday in Riverview Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 122 North Riverside Avenue here.

title: Police End Sick Strike
description: NEWARK, Ohio, Jan. 13 (UPI) The 66man police force voted today to end a sevenday sick call strike and return to Work if negotiations continued with the city.

title: C. W. Post Students End 45Day SitIn At Station WCWP
description: BROOKILLE, L. I., Jan. 13 A 45day student occupation of the campus radio station of C. W. Post College ended to night following an ultimatum to the students to vacate the station or be forcibly evicted and face disciplinary action.

title: Chad to Get Soviet Station
description: FORT LAMY, Chad, Jan. 13 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Soviet Union is to set up a satellite observation station in Chad, the official Chadian News Agency reported today. The move follows the signing of an agreement between the Chadian Government and the Soviet Academy of Sciences. The news agency said the station would need only one Soviet scientist to man it.

title: 4 BECOME JUDGES OF CRIMINAL COURT
description: Mayor Lindsay swore in four new Criminal Court judges yes terday.

title: Namath, After Testifying at Inquiry, Says N.F.L. Violates Antitrust Law
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 13 (AP) Joe Namath, the New York Jets' quarterback, said today that he thought the National Football League was guilty of antitrust violations.

title: GEORGE T. SWEETSER, AD AGENCY OFFICER
description: HENDERSONVILLE, N. C., Jan. 13George T. Sweetser, who retired here in 1966 as a vice president of N. W. Ayer & Co., died today after a short illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Stram, Chiefs' Coach, Reported Receiving a 10Year Contract
description: MIAMI, Jan. 13 (UPI)Coach Hank Stram and Lamar Hunt, the owner of the Kansas City Chiefs, were reported today to have reached agreement and shaken hands on a new 10 year contract that made Stram one of the highest paid coaches in professional football.

title: Census Expert Discounts Population Growth Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13The Government's chief profes sional demographer took public issue today with the view that population growth is the major challenge to the quality of life in America.

title: Gunman Wounds Physician In Front of Victim's Home
description: A 36yearold Brooklyn phy sician received a superficial flesh wound yesterday when he was shot by one of three men who approached him in front of his home in the East New York section.

title: Meriweather Files Entry For Millrose Meet Jan. 29
description: Dr. Delano Meriweather, who started running less than a year ago, filed an entry yesterday for the Milirose Games Jan. 29 at Madison Square Garden. The meet will be the first of four in the Garden this winter.

title: JERSEYAN TO HEAD SHIPBUILDING PANEL
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 13 (UPI)Albert G. Mumma of Short Hills, N. J., chairman of the Worthington Corporation, was appointed today by Presi dent Nixon as chairman of the Commission on American Ship building.

title: Offensive Defense
description: The contemptible tactic of harassment perpetrated against Soviet citizens in this city by the young toughs of the socalled Jewish. Defense League only puts them on the same planeand it is a low oneas the thugs employed, by the Soviet Government to harass Americans in the streets of Moscow. The difference is, of course, that the Russians in Moscow are entirely controlled by government orders while their American counterparts are acting directly contrary to both the letter and spirit of American law.

title: Commonwealth Opens Talks Today Split by Arms for South Africa
description: LONDON, Jan. I3The Com monwealth, whose 31 member nations begin a nineday meet ing of heads of government in Singapore tomorrow, is dissolv ing. Or is it developing?

title: Guerrillas Mount Attacks in North Jordanian Areas
description: AJLUN, Jordan, Jan. 13  Arab commandos mounted at tacks in the far north of Jordan today while their comrades here in their former stronghold reported that army pressure had caused them hunger and privation and had turned the populace against them.

title: Capt. Joseph W. Jung, 52, An Engineer and Lawyer
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 13 Capt. Joseph W. Jung of 108 Weyford Terrace, an engineer and lawyer who was retired from the Navy and the New York Police Department, died yesterday of a cerebral hemor rhage on a business trip to Sacramento, Calif. He was 52 years old.

title: 3 Arraigned in Baltimore
description: Three of the six persons charged with plotting to kid nap Mr. Kissinger were ar raigned on $50,000 bail each yesterday in Baltimore and were then taken to Harrisburg, Pa., where the indictments had been issued.

title: Shooting of Black by Police Sets Off Tampa Disturbance
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 13 (UPI) Blacks smashed windows and burned cars in Tampa's Central Avenue district last night after an offduty policeman shot and killed a young black who at tacked him outside a bar.

title: Major Leagues Go Far Afield In Annual Draft of Free Agents
description: Major league baseball teams dipped into such noted educational institutions as Yavapai, Valencia, Seminole and American River yester day and selected 272 players in their sixth annual winter freeagent draft.

title: HELEN DAY EDITOR OF SEARCHLIGHT
description: Helen Herries Day, a blind woman, who edited The Search light, a Braille magazine for blind children, from its found ing by the Lighthouse until her retirement in the nineteen forties, died Sunday in Jacobi Hospital, the Bronx. She was 80 years old and lived at 2147 Starling Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Glen Oaks Village Tenants Picket for More Protection
description: More than 200 women who live in the Glen Oaks Village garden apartments in Queens picketed the development's management office yesterday to demand additional protec tion.

title: LIBERAL DEMOCRATS SEEK HOUSE REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) Democratic liberals moved today to turn next week's ex pected minor reforms in the House seniority system into a major overhaul.

title: Ecuador Seizes Tuna Ship
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) A United States tuna vessel has been seized 55 miles off the coast of Ecuador and es corted to the port of Salinas, Ecuador, Representative Ed ward Garmatz, Democrat of Maryland, reported today. Mr. Garmatz, chairman of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, said that the tuna boat Lexington was seized Jan. 11.

title: CURB ON EXPLOSIVES IN FORCE ON FEB. 16
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) The Internal Revenue Service will impose the first Federal re strictions next month on dis tribution and use of explosives in a crackdown on bombings.

title: Sketches of 13 Involved in the Alleged Conspiracy
description: Following are sketches of those indicted in connection with an alleged plot to kid nap Henry A. Kissinger, as sistant to the President, and to blow up heating systems in Federal buildings, and of those listed as co  conspira tors but not indicted, as com piled by The Associated Press and The New York Times:

title: Penn Central Allowed To Issue Certificates
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 (AP)United States District Court Judge John P. Fullam authorized the Penn Central Transportation Company to day to issue $100million in certificates guaranteed by the Government.

title: Executive Corps Elects
description: William S. Renchard, Chemi cal Bank chairman, has been elected to the board of the In ternational Executive Service Corps. This group recruits American businessmen, usually retired, as volunteer manage ment advisers to enterprises in developing nations.

title: ISRAELIS' POSITION SAID TO ENVISAGE SOME PULLBACKS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 13A strong Israeli com mitment to the principle of withdrawal from some occupied Arab territories was reported today to have been among the ideas presented last weekend in Jerusalem to Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations in termediary in the indirect peace talks.

title: New Era in Georgia
description: Even were the Administration's Southern strategists deaf to moral principles, they would have good cause to reassess their prosegregationist tactics on practical grounds alone. Evidence has been building up that the selfdestructive legacy of prejudice in the politics of the South is being rejected by a new generation, not only of youth but of politicians.

title: Lunar Robots Urged
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 13 (Reuters) An American lunar scientist came out today in favor of sending large Sovietstyle un manned spacecraft to the moon, asserting that the astronauts don't pick up interesting rocks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rome Acts to Shift Functions to Regions
description: ROME, Jan. 13  The Gov ernment moved today to trans fer some state functions to the regions established last June. Three of the regions are Com munistcontrolled.

title: Dance Theater of Israel Returning to City Center
description: The Inbal Dance Theater of Israel, which previously ap peared here in 195859, will open a twoweek engagement at the City Center Feb. 9.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Crompton & Knowles Corporation has an nounced that William J. Ferracone, formerly presi dent of the Marschall division of Miles Laboratories, Inc., has joined the company as president of its chemicals group.

title: Inventories Show $500Million Rise As Sales Dip Again
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 Total business inventories rose $500million in Novem ber, while sales again de clined, the Commerce Depart ment reported today.

title: WELFARE OFFICIAL RULES OUT RAIDS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 13  State Commissioner of Social Services George K. Wyman said today that there would be no mid night raids by social workers to search out ineligible relief recipients.

title: Italy Looks Into Soccer Club Finances
description: ROME, Jan. 13Professional soccer, which impassions mil lions of Italians Sunday after Sunday, is receiving a fiscal scrutiny.

title: AUTO SALES RATE SHOWS AN UPTURN
description: DETROIT, Jan. 13The automobile industry broke out of its doldrums in the first third of January With all four major manufacturers reporting higher sales rates compared With last year.

title: LEO R. O'BRIEN
description: WINTER PARK, Fla., Jan. 13 Leo R, O'Brien, a retired New York investment broker and contributor to Roman Catholic publications, died yesterday after a sudden illness. He was 68 years old.

title: Member Countries
description: LONDON, Jan. 13 Follow ing are the member coun tries of the Commonwealth, meeting in Singapore:

title: Role for Sandy Dennis
description: Sandy Dennis will costar with Phil Silvers in Alan Ayck bourn's London hit comedy, How the Other Half Loves, which is to be presented by Michael Myerberg, Peter Bridge and Eddie Kulukundis in asso ciation with Lawrence Shubert Lawrence. It is expected the last week in March at the Royale Theater.

title: Defense Rests in the CourtMartial of Sergeant Hutto
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Jan. 13The defense rested its cas today in the courtmartial of Sgt. Charles H. Hutto who is accused of assault with intent to murder at least six South Vietnamese in the hamlet of Mylai 4.

title: Market Place: Full Disclosre And GAC View
description: Just how far business must go in order to meet disclosure requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission is a matter of some debate.

title: Crashes Stir Debate on Channel Rules
description: LONDON, Jan. 13  Contro versy developed today over the safety of shipping in the crowd ed English Channel as a result of two accidents in which 30 died in two days.

title: My Fair Lady on Screen Begins Rerun Next Week
description: My Fair Lady will start a revival engagement next Thurs day at the Criterion Theater on Broadway. The Warner Bros. screen version of the musical, in its first stay, played 87 weeks at the Criterion, closing on June 20, 1966.

title: CONSUMER OPTIMISM VIEWED ON UPSWING
description: Consumer optimism about future prospects has apparently improved somewhat, according to the latest survey by the Conference Board. However, the consumer still holds pessi mistic views that will tend to slow down purchases of large ticket items.

title: Advertising:
description: Newspaper Ads More Ef fective at Less Cost in At lanta, Ga., Test Against Ra dio and Television.

title: COLUMBIA VICTOR OVER HOYAS, 8068
description: Columbia University's basket ball team headed into a two week break for examinations by concluding the nonIvy League portion of its schedule last night with an 8068 victory over Georgetown University at University Hall.

title: Harassment Disrupts Lives, Russians Say
description: The families of Soviet diplo mats say harassment by the Jewish Defense League has al tered their lives and made them feel at times that they are liv ing under enemy occupation.

title: State Church Body Assails Casino Bill as a Con Game
description: ALBANY, Jan. 13The New York State Council of Churches announced its opposition today to the legalization of gambling casinos in the state, which was proposed last week by Earl W. Brydges, the Senate Republican leader.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Jan. 13 (UPI)Coach Joe Paterno of Penn State said today he talked to the Green Bay Packers on Monday about their coaching vacancy.

title: CAREER RESUMED BY TAMIKO JONES
description: It was only a little over three years go that the lithe girl who now swings sinuously around the floor of the Rainbow Grill like a friendly panther as she sings her songs there each eve ning was paralyzed from the waist down by an attack of polio.

title: Mrs. Harold J. Grossman, An Authority on Wines, 70
description: Mrs. Florence Levy Gross man, widow of Harold J. Gross man, a leading authority on wines and spirits, died Monday in Doctors Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived at 460 East 79th Street.

title: Dr. King Aide Wins Capital Primary
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The Rev. Walter E. Fauntroy is all but assured of election as the District of Columbia's first representative on Capitol Hill in this century.

title: The Case for the Space Program
description: A generation ago people growing up in America were imbued with the idea of progress, that mankind could continuously improve not only the material conditions of life, but man kind itself. One of, the important ele ments of that belief is that there are no visible limits that we could not surpass. I was shocked when in a college philosophy course I first dis covered that many philosophers called this view of life naive optimism.

title: Thomas Boyle, Lecturer, Weds Margaret Taylor
description: The marriage of Miss Margaret Barton Taylor to Thomas F. Boyle took place in the Chapel of Peace at the Community Church of New York last evening. The Rev. Chadbourne A. Spring per formed the ceremony.

title: Egypt Suggests Big 4 Forco
description: CAIRO, Jan. 13 (AP)The United Arab Republic is pro posing a Big Four peacekeep ing force for the Middle East, a semiofficial Cairo newspaper said today.

title: Dollar Rate of the Pound Rises on Heavy Demand
description: LONDON, Jan. 13 (Reuters) The pound sterling's new role as the world's most wanted foreign currency today pushed up its dollar rate from 2.4001 to 2.4021.

title: HARRIMAN PAYS VISIT TO GROMYKO
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 13W. Ave rell Harriman said today, after a meeting with Foreign Minis ter Andrei A. Gromyko, that he was confident, despite cooler winds that the United States and the Soviet Union could reach agreements on arms lim itations, the Middle East and Berlin.

title: GEN.LAMMERDING,65, 1944 WAR CRIMINAL
description: BAD TOLZ, Germany, Jan. 13 (AP)  Heinrich Lammerding, the former SS general sen tenced to death in absentia in France for his role in the 1944 massacre at Oradour, died to day after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Signet's Inadvertent Payout May Not Come Off Next One
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 13 (UPI)  The Signet Corporation, which inadvertently paid a double dividend to its share holders on Jan. 2 said today it might not charge the overpay ment against the next quarterly dividend.

title: The Theater: A Timely Doll's House
description: There are some scenes that become acid tests of great acting  as infallible and as merciless as litmus paper. One of them occurs in Ibsen!s now strangely timely A Doll's House, which last night was given a superla tive revival at the handsome Playhouse Theater.

title: Task Force Chief Reported Mylai Action as Well Executed and Successful
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 13 Nearly two weeks after the alleged massacre of South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai, the American commander of the attack force filed a report to his brigade commander de scribing the action as well planned, well executed and successful.

title: About Pro Football
description: MIAMI, Jan. 13A suit aimed at lifting the local tele vision blackout of the Super Bowl game here on Sunday was dismissed today. It had been brought by a local lawyer, Ellis Rubin. He reasoned that since the game was sold out, the 2.5 million set owners in the area deserved to see it, espe cially since the City of Miami was spending tax money in helping to stage the game in the cityowned Orange Bowl.

title: 10 OilProducing Nations Say Companies Balk on Price Rise
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 13 (AP)  Representatives of 10 major oil producing nations accused a delegation from Western toil companies today of refusing to negotiate on price increases and left Teheran. If the talks collapse, 85 per cent of the non Communist world's oil produc tion would be imperiled.

title: Bridge:TriState Regionals to Mark Step Toward '74 Area Team
description: Tournament enthusiasts have several obvious oppor tunities and one longterm prospect in the TriState Regional Championships, which begin today at Gross inger's in the Catskills with the following schedule: to day, Men's Pairs and Wom en's Pairs, 2:30 P.M. and 8:30 P.M.; tomorrow, Mixed Pairs, 2:30 P.M. and 8:30 P.M.; Saturday, Open Pairs, 2:15 P.M. and 8:30 P.M., and Sunday, Swiss Teams, noon and 5 P.M.

title: Bus Crash Kills Woman
description: NEWCOMERSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 13 (UPI)  A Greyhound bus skidded on an icy road today and crashed down an embankment, killing one wom an and injuring seven other persons aboard. The dead woman was identified as Mrs. Ray Jacqueline Miller, 38 years old, of Cleveland.

title: Connecticut Seeks a Way Out of Mire of Unemployment
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 13Five hundred persons laid off at the Olin Corporation in New Haven, three hundred at the Anaconda American Brass Company in Ansonia, 200 more at the Sikorsky division of the United Aircraft Corpo ration in Stratford.

title: Action on Air Fares Urged
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 13 (UPI) Senator Stuart Symington, Missouri Democrat, said today that the Government must quickly authorize commercial airlines to increase fares or face a disaster in the transpor tation industry. In a statement, he urged the Civil Aeronautics Board to speed a decision on the domestic airline rate in vestigation begun Jan. 29, 1970.

title: XRays Find Trove of Artifacts Imbedded in Egyptian Mummies
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 13 The unexpected discovery of valuable artificacts imbedded in royal mummies at the Cairo Museum was announced today by a team of scientists at the University of Michigan.

title: PARENTHOOD GROUP HONORS CANFIELDS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Cass Canfield were honored at a private testi monial dinner last night spon sored by the United Planned Parenthood Campaign, the New York City fundraising arm of the local, national and interna tional Planned Parenthood Fed erations.

title: Man In the News
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 During the nineteensixties, the Rev. Walter Edward Fauntroy shared the dream of the civil rights movement that a coalition of blacks and whites could topple the cen turyold mountain of official public segregation in the South. Nobody but he and his supporters be lieved that the same coalition could put to gether a political victory yesterday in the District of Columbia. But it worked. Mr. Fauntroy, a Baptist minister, won the Democratic primary and is expected to become the city's first member of the House of Representatives, as a nonvot ing delegate, in a hundred years, and the top local Democrat.

title: Paganini's Concerto No. 3 Rediscovered
description: An unpublished violin con certo by Niccol Paganini, the legendary 19th century virtuoso and composer, has come to light in Italy and is scheduled to be recorded next week in London.

title: Carson Considered a Dynamic Figure in Capitol
description: Robert Trebor Carson, ad ministrative assistant to Sena tor Hiram L. Fong, was once a crusader for brokerage and bank reform, friends recalled yesterday in Honolulu after his indictment here for con spiracy to fix a Federal crimi nal securities case.

title: Smith Paces Kentucky State
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 13 (UPI)Elmore Smith scored 38 points and grabbed 24 rebounds to pace Kentucky State, the nation's topranked smallcol lege team, to a 13190 victory over Knoxville tonight.

title: She Championed Day Care Long Before Women's Lib Was Born
description: When Elinor Guggen heimer accepted the National Council of Jewish Women's Hannah G. Solomon Com munity Service Award this week, she had with her a needlepoint bag that she had whipped up. On one side were the names of close friends, on the other, the names of places and things she likes.

title: Architect or Plumber?
description: It will be a while until spring, but the first signs of an Ice Age thaw have appeared in Washington. The report of a study of the Capitol, ordered by Congress, says that the West facade is not about to come tumbling down, as declared by the late Architect of the Capitol, and that the $45million facelifting he promoted is not only unnecessary but undesirable. Until now, critics of the profligate plan have faced the glacial insistence of the office of the Architect of the Capitol that the building could only be kept standing if buttressed with a new extension (even more monstrous than the East front ad dition) and tons of marble.

title: Soon Ends Brief Run
description: Soon, the rock musical, closed last night at the Ritz after three performances.

title: Samuel Hay Kauffmann Dead; Led Washington Evening Star
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13  Samuel Hay Kauffmann, presi dent of The Evening Star News paper Company from 1949 to 1963, died last night in George Washington University Hospital after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: STOCKS ARE FIRM ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market was firm yesterday following Wall Street's advance Tuesday, but there was no followthrough in London and prices reflected it.

title: INTREPID DONATED TO RESEARCH UNIT
description: Intrepid, the most famous cur rent racing yacht in the world, will be devoted to oceanograph ic research henceforth, thus re moving her from the America's Cup competition for which she was built and in which she gained international distinction.

title: Lupo!' Reflects Life in Tel Aviv
description: Although "Lupo!", which opened yesterday at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, is an English-speaking Israeli comedy set in contemporary Tel Aviv, its heart belongs to Yiddish-speaking Second Avenue. It doesn't have to be criticized, just stamped with approval.Lupo, a widower, is a second hand furniture dealer who, with indefatigable friendliness, fights urban renewal projects, outwits City Hall, wins over his daughter's wealthy, future in-laws (by forcing them to recall their own humble origins), while he himself is bagged by a rather noisy widow who sells blintzes.Menahem Golan, who produced "Sallah," wrote and directed the movie, which stars Yuda Barkan, a 25-year-old Israeli, as the middle-aged Lupo. Under all those layers of make-up and charm, Mr. Barkan is, I suspect, an actor of real talent. The movie is harmless but, just to be safe, for the duration of its run, I'd advise people with blood-sugar problems to give the Carnegie Hall Cinema a wide berth.

title: New Evidence Promised To Win Support for SST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe said today that new evidence would be pre sented to Senators who had op posed the supersonic transport program and to new members of Congress in the hope of ob taining funds to build two pro totype aircraft.

title: Federal Food Stamp Programfor Poor Gains Wide Popularity With Students
description: The Federal food stamp pro gram, designed to help the poor, is becoming increasingly popular with the nation's col lege students.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports on changes in ownership of their listed securities by directors, offi cers and major stockholders. The lists included the following:

title: Accused Detective Helps Seize Suspect in Fatal Holdup in Bar
description: A suspended city detective Working as a bartender helped capture a man who allegedly killed a patron during a holdup of the bar early yesterday, the police said.

title: Kittle Named Astro Coach
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 13 (AP) Hub Kittle, manager of the Oklahoma City team in the American Association last sea son, was added today to the coaching staff of the Houston Astros.

title: Changed Atmosphere Seen
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 13 Israel's policymakers now be lieve that perhaps the Arab Governments are becoming per suaded of a genuine Israeli desire to negotiate an equitable peace.

title: Blue Flu Hits Policemen
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 13 (AP) Some police patrolmen, deadlocked in contract talks with the city, developed blue flu tonight and called in sick for their regular shifts. The first shift to be affected was the midnightto8 A.M. shift. The number of men with blue flu was not immediately re ported.

title: MONSANTO SEES AN EARNINGS DROP
description: The Monsanto Company, the nation's third largest chemical producer, showed a decline of about $1 a share from operat ing earnings in 1970 from the year before, primarily reflect ing the sharply lower operating income in the final quarter.

title: Rummaging Yields a Program Of Mozart for Clarion Concert
description: Mozart's Greatest Hits, it wasn't. But the Clarion Con certs program at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night turned out all the better for that. A conductor with an unusual en thusiasm for rummaging in the closets and attics of musical history, Newell Jenkins dug out for this allMozart program some barely worn items: the Incidental Music to Tobias Phil ipp von Geblers play, Thamos, King in Egypt (K.345); the An dante from the Divertimento (Cassation) in G (K.63); Te Deum (K.141), and several rela tively obscure arias.

title: Jobless Father of 4 Faces Loss of Most Of $100,000 Prize
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 13An unemployed tobacco worker who Came here from Puerto Rico five years ago will not have much left of the $100, 000 prize he won in Decem ber from the New York State lottery after the Connecticut and Federal governments take theirs shares.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13  A boy and a girl once met at a Washington cocktail party. His name was Romeo and hers was Juliet.

title: Postmaster General To Remain as Chief Of Postal Service
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 Postmaster General Winton M. Blount was named today to head the new United States Postal Service, which is sched uled to take over the nation's mail deliveries on July 1.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan, 13 (UPI)  A fire begun by arson de stroyed three highway depart ment trucks yesterday in a city garage. The blaze caused $15,000 in damage. Fire Chief Harry Sherer said the rear doors of the garage had been forced open and gas caps re moved from all eight trucks in the garage.

title: End of Its Costume Ball Upsets Virginia College
description: LEXINGTON, Va., Jan. 13 They're screaming bloody murder here because Wash ington and Lee University has given up its Fancy Dress Ball, an annual endofJanu ary event since 1907.

title: Furniture Sales for '70 Cheer Retailers
description: Buying enthusiasm per vaded the New York Furni ture Exchange this week. Retailers at the winter show ing here liked the look of the year ahead, They had good reason because for many of them sales volume in 1970 held up well.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13When Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia took his oath of office and made public pronounce ment that the time for racial discrimi nation is over, the South was hearing at last what needed saying years ago, and what might have been said then with less political risk than generally supposed.

title: Council Unit Approves 33 Minischools
description: The City Council's Finance Committee yesterday approved an amendment adding $5.6mil lion to the current capital budget to build 33 socalled minischools.

title: CHARGES BY DELURY GO TO ARBITRATION
description: John J. DeLury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, said yesterday that he had notified an arbitrator of some work locations where the union charged there were unsanitary and inadequate fa cilities.

title: Parolees Win Right to Have Lawyer at Hearing
description: ALBANY, Jan. 13The State Court of Appeals, in a 4to3 decision, ruled today that paro lees had a constitutional right to have their attorneys present at hearings weighing revoca tion of their paroles.

title: Swiss Give Funds 6 Months to Meet Strict New Rules
description: GENEVA, Jan. 13Foreign mutual funds operating in or from Switzerland will be given six months to conform to dras tic new regulations that are to go into force Feb. 1, it was announced today.

title: RATES FALL AGAIN IN CREDIT MARKET
description: The credit market's redhot drive toward lower interest rates became even more power ful yesterday as the supply of money seeking fixedincome se curities seemed almost limitless.

title: Shaw Loses Plea to Delay Perjury Trial in Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 13 (UPI)The Louisiana Supreme Court refused today to delay the perjury trial of Clay Shaw, the New Orleans businessman found innocent two years ago of plotting to assassinate Presi dent Kennedy. Mr. Shaw's trial is scheduled to begin Monday.

title: Books of The Times
description: SELECTED ESSAYS OF DELMORE SCHWARTZ. Edited by Donald A. Dike and David H. Zucker. 500 pages. University of Chicago. $10.

title: HARLEM HOSPITAL FOCUS OF DISPUTE
description: A Harlem mothers' group yesterday protested the nam ing of a new hospital pavilion after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL DEFIES PRESIDENT, KEEPS PRICE RISES
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corpo ration defied President Nixon last night and insisted that it would go ahead with plans for price increases of about 12 per cent on some major products.

title: Red Wings Trade Mahovlich to Canadiens for Redmond, Collins and Charron
description: DETROIT, Jan. 13 (AP)The Detroit Red Wings of the Na tional Hockey League traded Frank Mahovlich, a left wing, to the Montreal Canadiens to day for two right Wings, Mickey Redmond and Bill Collins, and a left wing, Guy Charron.

title: Laird Bars Airlift Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 A recent request by the Joint Chiefs of Staff that American transport planes and helicop ters be permitted to help ferry ammunition and South Vietna mese reinforcements to Saigon's forces operating deep in Cam bodia has been rejected by Sec retary of Defense Melvin R. Laird.

title: Rostropovich Drops 2 Helsinki Concerts Amid Air of Mystery
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 13 (AP) Mstislav Rostropovich, the cellist, today canceled two concerts in Finland amid specu lation that Soviet authorities are punishing him for his public defense of the novelist Al eksandr Solzhenitsyn.

title: Leafs Tie Seals, 11
description: TORONTO, Jan. 13 (UPI) A goal by Paul Henderson at 13:18 of the third period en abled the Toronto Maple Leafs to tie the California Golden Seals, 11 tonight. Gerry Eh man had scored for the Seals at 4:46 of the final period.

title: REV. THOMAS SWARBRICK
description: The Rev. Thomas J. Swar brick, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart, East Glendale, Queens, since 1966, died Tuesday in the rectory. He was 64 years old.

title: Penguins Top Kings, 42
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 13 (UPI) Dean Prentice scored a goal and set up another in the sec ond period to give the Pitts burgh Penguins a 42 triumph over the Los Angeles Kings to night.

title: Most Store Thefts Laid to Employes
description: Despite the wide publicity over shoplifting, a security di rector of a Chicago store yes terday told a merchants' con vention here that dishonest em ployes were stealing twice as much merchandise as lightfin gered consumers.

title: Garden State Traffic Rose In '70 as Mishaps Declined
description: WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Jan. 13 (UPI)The Garden State Park way carried a record volume of 158 million vehicles in 1970, but traffic accidents and in juries were reduced to a level below that of 1969.

title: Gen. George Grunert, 91, Dies; Led Inquiry on Pearl Harbor
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 13 (UPI)Lieut. Gen. George Gru nert, who directed the Army's investigation of the Japanese attack on Peari Harbor, died to day in Brook General Hospital, He was 91 years old.

title: Vermont Unemployment Up
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. 13 (AP)Vermont's insured unem ployment rate rose to 7.7 per cent last week, its highest point in six years, the state Depart ment of Employment Security announced today. This was full percentage point higher than the previous week's rate, the department said.

title: 31 of Foe Reported Killed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 14More than 13,000 South Vietnamese and Cambodian troops pushed for ward today in a drive to reopen Highway 4, Pnompenh's only route to the sea, the South Vietnamese headquarters an nounced.

title: Indians Jailed in Protest
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 (UPI) A dozen Indians who locked themselves in the Southwest Museum to protest an Indian lore exhibition were arrested last night after the police forced their way into the building. Stella Montoya, 25 years old, who remained outside the build ing as a spokesman for the protesters, said, How would you feel if the bones of your ancestors were on display?

title: Fog Grounds 2 Astronauts
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 13 (AP) Two astronauts who have been to the moonCol. Edwin E. Aldrin Jr. of the Air Force and Capt. James Lovell of the Navycould not get off the ground today at Wright Patter son Air Force Base here. The astronauts went to the base for a flight on the Air Force's only total inflight simulator aircraft, but rain and fog prevented the flight and they had to settle for a briefing on space shuttling techniques and other experi mental systems.

title: Jawboning Steel
description: President Nixon's statement through his press secretary that he is deeply concerned over the 12 per cent price hike announced by Bethlehem Steel on construction industry products did not prevent Bethlehem's chairman from reaffirming the move last evening. But Mr. Nixon's comment surely caught the steel industry by surprise. Just the day before, the President's Council of Economic Advisers had said that there had been no change in the Administration's policy of refraining from comment on individual price actions.

title: G.I. Charged With Murder Of a Major in Vietnam
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 13 (AP)  A 24yearold American soldier was charged today with murder and at tempted murder for the shoot ing of two majors during an argument over a loud phono graph. An Army spokesman said the charges were filed against Specialist 4 Alfred B. W. Flint of Haines City, Fla. No trial date has been set, he said.

title: Union President Convicted Of a Kickback Conspiracy
description: A Federal Court jury here convicted a labor union pres ident yesterday of conspiring to get a $3,000 kickback on a wel fare fund loan for an apartment project in Garland, Tex., known as the Orchard Hills Apart ments.

title: MARKET DECLINES AS VOLUME SOARS
description: The DowJones industrial average fell 3.08 points 841.11 yesterday as volume on the New York Stock Exchange set a 1971 record at 19.07 mil lion shares.

title: City Ballet Puts On Parade of Its Style In Adult Repertory
description: Five weeks of divinely inter minable sugar and spice Nut cracker performances were re placed on Tuesday evening by the New York City Ballet's re turn to repertory. Audience eyes softly glazed with Christ mas visions were rinsed clear with the bracing appearance of the regular adult fare ordinarily offered at the State. Theater. The company presented sharply chiseled performances of Mon umentum Pro Gesualdo and Movements for Piano and Or chestra, along with the spar kling Who Cares? and a bouncy Tchaikovsky Suite.

title: Buckley Entering Senate Role With a WaitandSee Approach
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13In contrast to many new members of Congress who arrive at the Capitol with stacks of proposed laws, Senatorelect James L. Buckley said today that he would hold off for the time being on preparing proposed legislation.

title: DR. OLDS RESIGNING AS DELEGATE TO U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 13 Dr. Glenn A. Olds, United States representative to the Economic and Social Coun cil, said today that he had re signed his post, effective at President Nixon's pleasure.

title: RISE REGISTERED BY AMEX SHARES
description: The American Stock Ex change scored its third con secutive advance yesterday in heavier trading.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 (UPI) Coach Tommy Prothro added three aides to his Los Angeles Rams staff today. Two were former assistants of his at the University of California, Los Angeles, and one a holdover from the George Allen regime.

title: SCRIBNER INTENDS TO REVIEW BUDGET
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner said yesterday that he would restudy budget requests affecting mentally and physi cally handicapped students.

title: Hawks Sink Sabres, 42
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (UPI)  Pit Martin scored the tiebreak ing goal in the second period and Dan Maloney added anoth er score in the third period to give the Chicago Black Hawks a 42 victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight.

title: $50 Window: PeopleWatching Outpost
description: YONKERS, Jan. 13  Al Singer removed his square toed Florsheims and put on his space shoes as he settled himself at the $50 window tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Phone Company Accepts F.C.C. Rate Rise Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced today that it would file for interim increases in its charges for interstate telephone calls at a rate structure proposed yesterday by the Federal Com munications Commission.

title: BAILEY L. BROWN
description: AMHERST, Mass., Jan. 13 Bailey Lefevre Brown, emeritus professor of mathematics at Amherst College, died yester day in Northampton. He was 67 years old.

title: Cigarette Ad Warning Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13, (Reuters)Senator Frank E. Moss, Democrat of Utah, an nounced today that he would introduce legislation to require a health warning in all cigar ette advertising and on vending machines. He said in a state ment that the warning would be the same as the one that ap pears on cigarette packages, saying the Surgeon General of the Public Health Service has determined that cigarette smok ing is dangerous, and also would require cigarette pack ages and advertisements to carry a statement of tar and nicotine levels.

title: Trust, Policy Challenged On Conglomerate Deals
description: Lee Loevinger, who headed the Justice Department's anti trust division under President Kennedy, yesterday challenged the Nixon Administration's anti trust policy as it is being ap plied to conglomerate mergers.

title: Laver Rallies to Beat Roche In $10,000 Boston Tennis
description: BOSTON, Jan. 13 (UPI)Rod Laver had to fight back tonight to beat Tony Roche for his third straight $10,000 victory in the Tennis Champions Classic tour.

title: Massena Sets Chilly Record
description: MASSENA, N. Y., at 37 de grees below zero, was the cold est city on the United States mainland yesterday.

title: AUSTRIAN MINISTER IN POLAND FOR TALKS
description: WARSAW, Jan. 13The Austrian Foreign Minister, Dr. Rudolf Kirchschlger, arrived here today to begin three days of political and trade talks.

title: Investigation Continues
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13The Justice Department disclosed today that the Federal grand jury in Harrisburg is still look ing into the alleged plot. A spokesman said that it ques tioned witnesses today in a continuation of the investiga tion.

title: Jersey Policeman Injured
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 13 (UPI)  Patrolman George Puter baugh suffered minor injuries today when a bullet fired by an unknown assailant bounced off his helmet and knocked him off his motor scooter.

title: Advertising:
description: Having parted with Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, Dow Chemical has moved four products from its con sumer products division to W. B. Doner, Detroit.

title: U.S. Says Hot Dog Makers Are Observing Limit on Fat
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) Agriculture Department offi cials say the limit of 30 per cent fat in hot dogs in force since October, 1969, is being observed scrupulously by most manufacturers.

title: Prices Cut on Coffee Lines
description: The Institutional Food Serv ice division of the General Foods Corporation announced yesterday that it would cut prices on its lines of ground coffees for institutional vend ing customers, beginning Mon day.

title: Mississippi Democrats to Sue
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) The biracial Democratic party of Mississippi said today it would file Federal and state suits to challenge revisions made in the state's election laws. Aaron Henry, black chairman of the group, said the suits would charge that the Mississippi Legislature had vio lated the 1965 Civil Rights Act by abolishing party primaries in future elections.

title: Hofstra Defeats Iona
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 13 Hofstra College ran its won lost record to 73 tonight with a 7161 victory over Iona. Dave Bell had 20 points and 20 re bounds for Hofstra, Art Wig gins led Iona with 26 points.

title: Rise in Mercury Is Found In Eaters of Certain Fish
description: The chemist whose findings last month led to the recall of mercurytainted tuna and swordfish reported yesterday that he had found as much as five times the mercury in per sons who ate those fish regu larly compared with those who did not.

title: SCHOOLS TO CLOSE TO HONOR DR. KING
description: New York City's public and parochial schools and the City University's colleges will close tomorrow to commemorate the 42d birthday of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the late civil rights leader.

title: YOUTH,16, CHARGED IN FIRE FATAL TO 28
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 13 (Reu ters)A 16yearold youth was charged today with arson and 28 counts of murder stemming from a fire that destroyed a hotel and killed 28 guests last month.

title: Bills in Albany Die Hard, if At all
description: ALBANY, Jan. 13  They're known as old chestnuts, old turkeys, retreads and peren nials in the legislative trade.

title: BREAKDOWN DELAYS LEXINGTON AVE. IRT
description: Southbound express service on the Lexington Avenue IRT between the Grand Central and Brooklyn Bridge stations was disrupted for nearly two hours yesterday morning, forcing all trains to use local tracks and to run 20 minutes behind sched ule.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: EDWARD J. DAHILL, ENGINEER, 82, DIES
description: Edward J. Dahill of 21120 34th Road, Bayside, Queens, an engineer who pioneered in de veloping corrugated paper packaging for fruit and pro duce, died on Tuesday in New York HospitalCornell Medical Center after a short illness. His age was 82.

title: Juilliard Group Gives Concert
description: Like all musicians worth their salt, graduate students at the Juilliard School want to make music together. The latest such group to appear here is called Interaction. Its members are Yuval Waldman and William Henry, violins; Jonathan Abramowitz and James Kreger, cellos, and Paul Posnak and Daniel Ep stein, pianos. They have been playing together for about a year, often in schools and colleges.

title: Merger News
description: Borden, Inc., a major proces sor of dairy food and chemical products, announced yesterday plans to enter the apparel in dustry through the proposed $221million acquisition of the KayserRoth Corporation.

title: Panther Aided the Police Despite Fear, Trial Is Told
description: Joan Bird was afraid her blood would be spilled and her family's blood would be spilled if she cooperated with the po lice following her arrest after an alleged Black Pantherpo lice shootout, a detective tes tified yesterday.

title: Chanel's Funeral Draws Throngs to Paris Church
description: PARIS, Jan. 13 (AP)  Hundreds of Parisians, includ ing many women wearing her worldrenowned fashions, thronged the columned Church of the Madeleine today for the funeral of Gabrielle (Coco) Cha nel who died Sunday at the age of 37.

title: Aldrin, 2d Man on Moon, Quitting as Astronaut
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 13 (AP) Col. Edwin E. Aldrin Jr., the second man to walk on the moon, is retiring as an astro naut and returning to active duty in the Air Force.

title: J. Glenn Beall, 76; Father of Senator Was in Both Houses
description: FROSTBURG, Md., Thursday, Jan. 14 (AP)J. Glenn Beall, who served five terms in the House of Representatives and two terms in the Senate, died early today, He was 76 years old.

title: SEAT BID IS FILED BY DREYFUS CORP.
description: The Dreyfus Corporation, in an attempt to break a long standing Wall Street tradition, has become the first mutual fund organization to apply for membership on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: PAKISTAN GETS LOAN FOR RECONSTRUCTION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The International Development Association, an arm of the World Bank, announced today that it would extend a $25 million credit to Pakistan to help rebuild the areas of East Pakistan that were ravaged by a cyclone and tidal wave last November.

title: N.L.R.B. Examiner Rules Out Overton Tie With Harlem Union
description: A trial examiner for the Na tional Labor Relations Board has ruled that L. Joseph Over ton, the Harlem labor leader who led an 18month strike against a cooperative super market, was involved in a con flict of interest because he took at least $25,000 from a com pany that represented other food markets in Harlem.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Stage: John and Abigail
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Since Ford's Theater was re stored as a living theater in 1968, it has played host to everything from a Sound and Light reconstruction of the death of Lincoln to a revival of Arsenic and Old Lace, the last previous occupant before William Gibson's John and Abigail opened last night.

title: Phone Company Rejects Demand by Union to Send Back OutofTown Help
description: The New York Telephone Company last night rejected a demand by officials of the Communication Workers of America that it send home 1,000 technicians it had brought in from out of town to improve phone service here.

title: NEWS DEALER WINS REPRIEVE ON LICENSE
description: A 69yearold news dealer Was given a reprieve yesterday in the State Supreme Court from a revocation of his license sought by Mrs. Bess Myerson Grant, City Commissioner of Consumer Affairs.

title: Lindsay and Burke Discuss Traffic Problems at Stadium,
description: Mayor Lindsay and Michael Burke, president of the New York Yankees, met yesterday at City Hall for the fifth time to discuss problems of traffic and limited parking facilities around Yankee Stadium.

title: EASING PRESSED ON DEPRECIATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The Treasury said today that the recently announced major changes in the tax rules in volving depreciation of busi ness equipment have been made effective even though a procedure involving written comment and public hearings will delay the formal adoption of the necessary regulations.

title: Neediest Cases Require $175,000 to Meet '70 Total
description: Since the start of its 59th annual appeal Dec. 6, The New York Times Fund for the Neediest Cases has re corded contributions totaling $778,015.98.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: An Expert on WineThe Drinking Thereof, Investing Therein
description: MONTAUK, L.I.There was a roaring fire in the fireplace in a cottage at Gur ney's Inn by the sea while outside the surf came rolling in under a cloudless and piercing blue sky. There was Brie cheese from France and a subtle, rich goat cheese wrapped in grape leaves from Greece, and sausages and cham pagne. Wellchilled bottles of Jamin, a good and inexpensive brand from the Roederer cellars. There were also a few bottles of lightly chilled Beaujolais, which the host was extolling as the best of all possible wines for everyday drinking.

title: AMOSKEAG TO SEEK OPERATING STATUS
description: BOSTON, Jan. 13 (AP) Stockholders of the Amoskeag Company voted overwhelmingly today at their annual meeting to allow its officers to ask the Securities Exchange Commis sion for permission to become an operating company. The vote was 636,307 shares in fa vor to 9,300 against.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: WALKER'S CAY, Bahamas Flying 150 miles northeast from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., over the Northwest Provi dence Channel and the west end of Grand Bahama Is land, we circled remote, 100acre Walker's Cay, the northernmost of the outer Bahamas. Then Capt. Andy Stinis landed our Grumman Mallard in a sparkling shower of green water, and our quest for barracuda had begun.

title: Grand Jury Will Hear Charges Against Jewish Defense League
description: The New York County Dis trict Attorney's office informed the Jewish Defense League yes terday that it was putting be fore a grand jury four criminal cases involving the organiza tion or its leader, Rabbi Meir D. Kahane.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: AARON G. LANIER
description: Aaron G. Lanier, controller of the New York Mets, died Tuesday in Clearwater, Fla., where he maintained a winter apartment. He was 65 years old.

title: Flu Shuts Upstate School
description: MORRISTOWN, N. Y., Jan. 13 (AP)  School officials today closed the only school in this St. Lawrence River village for the remainder of the week, say ing an influenzalike illness had caused about a fourth of the pupils to be absent. The school, with grades from kindergarten through 12, has 500 pupils.

title: Manson Prosecutor, in Closing, Assails Defense
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13  Prosecutor Vincent T. Bugliosi used his closing argument to the TateLaBrianca jury today to sharply criticize the lawyers who defended Charles M. Man son, the hippie leader, and his three women codefendants in the sevenmonthold trial.

title: CZECH VISITORS GIVE CONCERT AT MUSEUM
description: Since the Czech Chamber Orchestra is making its first visit here, it is unfortunate to have to report that its concert at the Metropolitan Museum on Tuesday night was rather dis appointing.

title: Briton Arrives in Uruguay For Talks on Kidnapping
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 13A British diplomat with a reputation for highlevel troubleshooting arrived today to deal with questions arising from the kidnapping of the British Ambassador here.

title: THREATENED STRIKE ON L.I.R. POSTPONED
description: Federal Judge John R. Bartels yesterday recessed until today a hearing on a preliminary in junction to head off a threat ened strike of the Long Island Railroad.

title: U.A.W. Strikes All Plants Of International Harvester
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (UPI) Members of the United Auto mobile Workers struck the In ternational Harvester Company today, and Harvester plants throughout the country were expected to shut down.

title: Prep School Enrollments Are Declining
description: Enrollment decreased last fall in all major categories of col lege preparatory boarding Schools, especially military academies, according to a sur vey just published by the Na tional Association of Independ ent Schools.

title: MISS GOOLAGONG UPSET IN TENNIS
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 13 (AP)Evonne Goolagong was upset today in the third round of the New South Wales tennis championships.

title: MANHATTAN BOWS TO JACKSONVILLE
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP)Manhattan tried to upset seventhranked Jackson ville with a slowdown tonight but the Dolphins got a remark able oneman performance out of 7foot2inch Artis Gilmore to crush the Jaspers, 6740.

title: Colonels, Paced by Issel, Down Floridians, 133117
description: LOUISVILLE, Jan. 13 (UPI) The Kentucky Colonels, led by Dan Issel's 31 points, beat the Floridians, 133117, tonight to halt a threegame losing streak in the American basket ball Association.

title: Early Apollo Countdown
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 13 (Reuters)  A preliminary countdown for launching Apollo 14 to the moon on Jan. 31 went into its second day here today and was described by space agency officials as going very well.

title: AILEY REINFORCED BY LYNN SEYMOUR
description: Lynn Seymour, a principal dancer with Britain's Royal Ballet, will be guest artist with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, the first of nine com panies to appear at the ANTA Theater beginning Monday as part of the City Center Amer ican Dance Season.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Afri ca, Jan. 13 (AP)Arthur Ashe, the American Negro star, has not applied for and will not be invited to take part in the South African open tennis champion ships in April, Owen Williams, tournament director said today.

title: The Cancer of Growth
description: I believe in the essential sanity of man, writes John Fowles. What fol lows presumes that humanity must count on this sanity to counter the rapid, seemingly inexorable changes taking place in its physical, chemical and biological home.

title: Archdiocese to Seek $11Million To Aid Welfare and Education
description: An $11million fundraising campaign to expand the welfare and educational services of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York was announced yes terday by Cardinal Cooke.

title: Approval Is Sought for Family Car Train
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The first formal step was taken today in a plan aimed at pro viding a new way of traveling from the Northeastern states to Florida, a train that will carry the family car as well as its occupants.

title: 24 Arrested as Police End Feminist Demonstration
description: Twentyfour women were arrested yesterday as the po lice broke up a demonstration outside an East Village building occupied for 12 days by a group of feminists.

title: BRAZIL FREES 70, WHO FLY TO CHILE
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Thursday, Jan. 14The Brazilian Govern ment freed 70 political prison ers and put them on a plane to Chile today in exchange for the release of the kidnapped Swiss Ambassador, Giovanni Enrico Bucher.

title: Macy's Top Management Gets Major Realignment
description: R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., an nounced yesterday a major re organization of management in which Donald B. Smiley, chair man, was also named chief ex ecutive officer and two vice chairmen were appointed in lieu of the selection of a new president.

title: MINORITY PARLEY FINDS UNITY GAIN
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 13 Blacks from Watts, Puerto Ri cans from Harlem, orientals from San Francisco, Chicanos from Arizona, and Indians from the Southwest banded together here to talk about their com mon problems in a threeday meeting that ended today.

title: Pace Names Chairman
description: Charles H. Dyson of Scars dale, N. Y., has been elected chairman of the board of trust ees of Pace College, it was an nounced last night by Dr. Ed ward J. Mortola, president of the college. Mr. Dyson, chair man of the board of the Dyson Kissner Corporation, an invest ment company, replaced Dr. Samuel Miller of Bronxville, N. Y., who retired after 16 years as board chairman.

title: N.C.A.A. MAY CALL SPECIAL SESSION
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 13  The National Collegiate Athletic As sociation, which failed to act on the rising costs of college sports during its annual con vention this week, will prob ably be called into a special session this spring to move on college athletic economies.

title: Health Emergency Declared In Pittsburgh Refuse Strike
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 13 (AP)  The Allegheny County Health Department declared to day a general health emergency throughout the city, where most garbage has gone uncol lected for more than a week because of a strike of municipal workers.

title: News of Skiing
description: WOODRIDGE, N. Y., Jan. 13  A nowait system for its new double chairlift has been introduced at the Big Vanilla at Davos ski area and the idea is proving popular in these southern Catskills.

title: News of Dogs
description: When two golden liver dogs were paraded across the ring at the American Spaniel Club's national specialty in the Statler Hilton last Sun day, there was a stir among the spectators. Most were seeing Sussex spaniels for the first time. So rare is the Sus sex in America that only three have been regis tered with the American Kennel Club in the last decade. Of the 116 breeds in the A.K.C. studbook, the Sussex stands at the bottom.

title: Gulf of Tonkin Resolution Is Repealed Without Furor
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 14 (UPI)The Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, regarded by Presi dent Lyndon B. Johnson as his authorization for United States intervention in Southeast Asia, has been repealed without any of the controversy it once stirred.

title: MESKILL SUPPORTS LEGALIZED BETTING
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 13 (AP) Gov. Thomas J. Meskill said today that he favored legalized offtrack and ontrack betting in Connecticut as well as as a state lottery.

title: Washington Notes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 President Nixon, faced with both liberal and conservative opposition to his welfare re form plan, will ally himself with the conservatives in a bid to win early approval of the proposal in Congress this year. White House officials said that Mr. Nixon's strategy would be to stiffen the workfare and antifraud provi sions of the meas ure, in hopes of attracting the sup port of key conservatives. The President chastised the 91st Congress last week in a stern statement outlining its failure, to enact the Family Assistance Plan and other Administration programs before adjourning.

title: Jersey Major Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today that Maj. Cor nelius H. Ram of the Marine Corps, of Brick Town, N. J., had been killed in action in ??

title: $675,000 Is Granted For Training in Films
description: A grant of $675,000 to con tinue a training program in films and television for young people of minority groups and lowincome areas has been given to the Commu nity Film Workshop Council by the Office of Economic Opportunity.

title: Navy Gains 7653 Victory Over Washington and Lee
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 13 (AP)An early 13point surge put Navy in front and sent the middies to a 7653 victory over Washington and Lee University today.

title: Aeroflot Has Its Ups (in the Air) And Its Downs (on the Ground)
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 13 (UPI) Two travelweary Soviet jour nalists have described the So viet airline Aeroflot as a dream in the air but a nightmare on the ground, where delays and inefficiency set air travel back to the nineteentwenties.

title: BETTER INQUIRIES ON DEATHS URGED
description: The growing trend toward violent social action has height ened the need to better investi gate deaths that require both medical and legal inquiries, a Harvard University expert on legal medicine says.

title: 2 Stars in an Evening of Lieder
description: There are such things as double stars in the heavens, and they exert an incredible gravitational pull. Thus it was in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, when two stars revolving around each other pulled in everything within sight. Every seat in the house was taken, and the stage itself was jammed with listeners eager to bathe in the art of Dietrich Fischer Dieskau and Daniel Baren boim.

title: Remington Rand to Lay Off Fourth of Plant in Elmira
description: ELMIRA, N. Y., Jan. 13 (AP) The Remington Rand Cor poration said today it would lay off about one fourth of its 1,200 employes here within the next few weeks.

title: MINNESOTA COURT REALIGNS SENATE
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 13  The Minnesota Supreme Court ruled today that Lieut. Gov. Rudolph G. Perpich exceeded his con stitutional powers when, in pre siding over the State Senate, he made parliamentary decisions that gave control of the upper house to his own Democratic FarmerLabor party.

title: Informative Food Labels Are Coming, Once the F. D. A. Decides How to Do It
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 Consumers may soon have new clue to unraveling the value of many of the 10,000 or so food products in the average supermarketa label on packages listing the nutrient value of the con tents.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Senator Fong's Assistant indicted on Bribe Charge
description: A special grand jury indicted the administrative assistant to Senator Hiram L. Fong of Hawaii and two New York resi dents yesterday on charges of conspiracy to quash a Federal stockfraud case that involved organized crime.

title: Chess: Browne Registers a Sweep In Taking New York Tourney
description: Grandmaster Walter Browne of Australia captured first place in the recent Greater New York Adult Chess Championship, at the Hotel McAlpin. Browne scored 50 in the fiveround Swiss sys tem tournament. The two appended key games show Browne combining positional acumen with tactical flair.

title: Braves Triumph, 119113
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 14 (UPI) Led by Bob Kauffman's 30 points, the Buffalo Braves beat the Portland Trail Blazers, 119 113, tonight. Kauffman scored 17 of his points in the second half after the Braves took a 5954 lead.

title: Counter Quote System Unveiled
description: TRUMBULI Conn., Jan. 14  A $25million quotation system for overthecounter securities was unveiled here today by the BunkerRamo Corporation, its builders. De signed to bring greater ef ficiency to the third most important market for stocks, the new system is expected to have a major impact on the securities industry.

title: NAUMBURG CONTEST WILL END ON SUNDAY
description: The Walter W. Naumburg Foundation Piano Competition, which begins today at the Juil liard School, will end Sunday with public finals to be held at 3 P.M. in Paul Hall.

title: Chi Cheng Is Chosen Woman Athlete of 1970
description: POMONA, Calif., Jan. 14 (AP)The years of frustra tion and anonymity are over for Chi Cheng, who has lit erally hurdled obstacles to become the world's greatest female athlete.

title: A.T. &T. REQUESTS PHONE RATE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed today higher rates for long distance calls, to go into effect next Thursday.

title: Rangers Revise Start Of Jan. 24 Game Here
description: The New York Rangers have revised the starting time of their game against the Minnesota North Stars at Madison Square Garden on Sunday, Jan. 24. The con test will get under way at 1:05 P.M., instead of at the originally listed time of 7:05.

title: Federal Curbs on Strip Mining Are Urged by Head of U.M.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The United Mine Workers of America today joined the grow ing number of conservationist individuals and groups demand ing Federal regulation of strip, or surface, mining of coal.

title: Carpets: Irish Sheep, Indian Money
description: DUBLINAt first glance, It seems incongruousthe colorful peacock of India em blazoned on the facade of a factory in the heart of Ire land's horse breeding and racing country at Newbridge in County Kildare.

title: Soil Analysis by Soviet Finds Lunar Seas Alike
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 14A prom inent Soviet scientist an nounced here today the first results of an analysts of soil returned from the moon by the unmanned Luna 16. The results indicate that all the lunar seas are similar in com position and origin.

title: Pack Up, Black Man
description: JOHANNESBURGAmericans who are repelled by a color bar, but are at least prepared to consider that the South African separate development political philosophy of apartheid may be something other than Jim Crow legislation under another name, have told me that they did not know what to think of the South African Govern ment's resettlement schemes for blacks. Living so far away, ignorant of local conditions, is one qualified to judge?

title: Lon Nol to Go to Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnamese, Jan. 14Premier Lon Nol of Cambodia is scheduled to fly to Saigon next week for meet ings on future South Vietna mese military support for his embattled country.

title: Women's Lib in Bonn: Pension for Hausfrau
description: BONN, Jan. 14West Ger many, which already ack nowledges the profession of a housewife to be legally equivalent to that of a long shoreman or an engineer, is planning to institute a na tionwide pension program for her.

title: President Proves to Be a Fast Man With a Snowball
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 14  President Nixon called on young and old alike today to forge an alliance of the gen erations and as evidence of his commitment to that goal, pro posed setting up a new Gov ernment agency to enlist the energies and idealism of youth.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW PRICE DROPS
description: After advancing about 8 cents a bushel in the previous four sessions, soybean futures prices dropped yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
