title: Television
description: LEADING into a combined review of The New Andy Griffith Show (CBS), Strange Report (NBC) and The Great American Dream Machine (NET) is about as easy as ex plaining why anyone would attempt in the same book review to deal with a volume of remembrances of Warren Gamaliel Harding, a James Bond novel and a col lection of sociosatirical essays on Amer ican society edited by Tom Hayden and packaged by Marshall McLuhan. Of course, it's a very chic, poplit, new journalese thing to do. But, really, about the only fact that makes them hang together is that they all premiered dur ing the same week. Except

title: EDITH LODGE
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Jan. 18 The death here on Dec. 21 of Miss Edith Lodge, daughter of Ambassador John Davis Lodge and Mrs. Lodge, at the age of 28, became known today with the disclosure of records at the Fairfield Town Clerk's office.

title: Ruth Corine McBride to Be Wed
description: Robert H. McBride, Ambas sador to Mexico, and Mrs. McBride of Mexico City and Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Corine McBride, to Oscar L. Powers 2d. He is the son of Mrs. Oscar S. Powers of Durham, N. C., and the late Dr. Pow ers, who was a professor of classics at the University of Texas.

title: The World
description: AMMAN, JordanFresh bullet pockmarks flowered on one wall of the American Embassy here last week and a ricocheting slug slammed into a mirror in the residence of the American Am bassador, I. Dean Brown. The gunfire rang through Amman's stony hills and though it left Ambassador. Brown and his staff unscathed, it paralyzed the town with fear. Pedestrians fled. Shops closed. Even police in flak jack ets inched warily through the center of town.

title: FRED WAY TAKES SKI JUMP TROPHY
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 16Fred Way of the Mount Beacon Ski Club lost out by fivetenths of a point to Larry Stone of Salisbury, Conn., in the regular Swedish Ski Club jumping competition today. But Way came right back to win the John Wictorin Memorial Trophy with a leap of 155 feet before more than 12,000 fans.

title: Pittsburgh Pressmen Settle
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 16 (UPI) Members of Printing Press men's Local 9 accepted a new twoyear contract today ending a strike that shut down The Pittsburgh Press and The Post Gazette two weeks ago. Publi cation resumes Monday.

title: Czechoslovakia Since World War
description: The history of Czechoslovakia is one that should plague the Western liberal conscience. It does not. In deed, Western democrats have consistently ignored the only Central European state which has, over the last 50 years, thrice managed to pro duce rational and humane forms of government. A great merit of Tad Szulc's exhaustive survey of the country is to deplore this myopic lack of concern.

title: Norma Gow Fiancee Of Damas Thoman
description: WYCKOFF N.J., Jan. 16 Miss Norma Holly Gow and Damas C. Thoman plan to be married Aug. 21.

title: The World
description: SAIGONThose who have long boasted of the progress of the South Vietnamese forces are viewing with some pride the re cent forays by Saigon's troops into Cambodia. The student seems to have learned the les sons well, and is now hard at work helping out the kid next door.

title: Holy Cross's Coach In Doable Jeopardy
description: WORCESTER, Mass., (UPI) The Holy Cross basketball coach, Jack Donohue, was unhappy with the officiating in a recent game.

title: GREENBURGH PLAN FACES OPPOSITION
description: ELMSFORD, Jan. 16Green burgh, the fifth largest town in New York, will unveil Mon day night at a special public meeting of the Town Council a master plan that is expected to stir considerable contro versy.

title: COLUMBIA SENATE BACKS DAILY ON TAX
description: The Columbia University Sen ate unanimously passed a res olution yesterday endorsing The Columbia Daily Spectator, the daily campus newspaper, in dts dispute with the Internal Revenue Service.

title: DETROIT RADICALS FACE BOMB TRIAL
description: DETROIT, Jan. 16The only disruptions at the pretrial hear ing this week for three mem bers of the White Panther party charged in the bombing of a Central Intelligence Agency of fice have been caused by a baby and small children.

title: RUMANIAN TEAM TAKES SLED TITLE
description: IGLS, Austria, Jan. 16 (UPI) Ion Panturu of Rumania and his crew fought off stiff chal lenges today from two tough West German teams to win the European fourman bobsled championship in the most thrill ing finish seen on this Olympic track.

title: POULSEN SCORES IN TROPHY SKIING
description: STOWE, Vt., Jan. 16It was 22 degrees below zero this morning as 138 men and women started competing in the second annual Starr Trophy downhill race. Despite the frig id temperatures, the interna tional event was concluded on schedule without a mishap.

title: The Nation
description: FORT BENNING, Ga.  Who gave the orders? Who knew what was going on? Was any attempt made to stop it? Who is responsible?

title: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Laird Sees Critical Period
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, returning from a trip to Southeast Asia, says that the next few months will be criti cal for Cambodia but sees nothing to slow the rate of United States troop with drawal from South Vietnam.

title: Child to Mrs. Wheeler
description: A daughter was born on Dec. 29 to Dr. and Mrs. Maynard Boynton Wheeler at Sloane Hospital here. The child, who has been named Kate Stuart, is a grand daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Lade of Weston, Conn., and of Dr. and Mrs. Maynard Cattron Wheeler of New York. The child's father is a resident in ophthalmology at the Eye Institute, Co lumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, and her grandfather is clinical professor emeritus of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia Uni versity.

title: Purdue Wins In Overtime
description: LAFAYETTE, Jan. 16 (UPI) Larry Weatherford scored 9 points in an overtime period today to lead Purdue to its third Big Ten victory, edging Min nesota, 9792.

title: 8TH SERIES OPENED BY DANCE UPTOWN
description: The Dance Uptown series, which started tentatively in 1967 at Barnard's Minor Lath am Playhouse with two pro grams, has burgeoned into regular outlet for young choreagraphers. The stage is small and the house intimate but the guiding ambition is large and 25 choreographers have been invited to show their works in the last four years.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Lumber manufacturers are miffed at a recent statement by George Romney, Secre tary of Housing and Urban Development, that he expects new materials to overcome present shortages of lumber.

title: Paul Gekker, Soviet Expert With the Federal Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16Paul Gekker, the Federal Reserve Board's specialist in Soviet and eastern European economic and financial systems, died today of a heart attack at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 53 years old.

title: MSGR. LOMBARDO, 84, BRONX PASTOR, DIES
description: Msgr. Pasquale T. Lombardo, founder and pastor emeritus of St. Lucy's Roman Catholic Church, Mace and Bronxwood Avenues, in the Williarnsbridge section of the Bronx, died Thursday in the rectory. His age was 84.

title: MISSISSIPPI GETS LEGAL AID GRANT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The Office of Economic Opportunity announced today a $200,000 grant for a legal services pro gram for the poor in Jackson, Miss.

title: John T. Hoyt, an Executive Of Metropolitan Life, 62
description: John T. Hoyt, a vice presi dent in the personal insurance division of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died yesterday of a, heart attack in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 16 West 16th Street.

title: HOLMBERG IS NAMED ARMY TENNIS COACH
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 16 (UPI)  Ron Holmberg, a former member of the United States Davis Cup team and once ranked among the top 10 players in the nation, was named tennis and squash racquets coach today at the United States Military Acad emy.

title: TENNESSEE TOPS KENTUCKY, 7571
description: KNOXVILLE, Jan. 16 (UPI) Tennessee jumped to an early lead and held it most of the way to upset nationallyranked Kentucky, 7571, today.

title: About Motor Sports
description: How do American drivers stack up against the interna tional stars who compete for the World Championship of Drivers? Which is quicker, the international Formula One car with its 3liter racing engine of exotic design, or the domestic Formula A, the 5liter stockblock racer? The questions may be answered in what should be an interesting mix of classes on March 28 at Ontario Motor Speedway in California.

title: PHONE TALKS FAIL; DISPUTE SPREADS
description: Efforts by a Federal judge to mediate the strike of telephone installers and repairmen fell through yesterday. The strike, which began here six days ago, has spread through most of the state.

Appointments may be arranged by calling Philip Her shaft at TR 39669. The orches tra rehearses on Mondays from 7:30 to 10 P.M. at the Jesse Strauss Adult Evening Com munity Center, 270 West 70th Street.

title: Alyssa Preston Plans Wedding

title: Storm Trysail Club Waives I.O.R. Rating for Race Week
description: Nobody will be excluded from the Block Island Race Week sailing in June because his cruising yacht has not been measured to the International Offshore Rule, the new world wide formula for rating yachts in major distance competition.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Jan. 16 (Reuters)  Bob Maud said today that South Africa's exclusion from the Davis Cup had prompted him to turn professional. He cabled his acceptance of an offer from Dallasbased World Champion ship Tennis, and will make his debut as a contract pro in Philadelphia next month.

title: R. C. Cowells Have Son
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan 16  A son was born on Jan. 4 at the Good Samaritan Hos pital in West Palm Beach to Mr. and Mrs. Richard Cox Cowell of Palm Beach and New York. The child has been named for his father. Mrs. Cowell, the former Miss Melissa Tomlinson, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Prout Tomlinson of Princeton, N. J. The child's father is president of the Cowell Corporation, a real estate development concern here.

title: Youth Dies During Game
description: KENT, Wash., Jan. 16 (UPI) Robert Paul Osborne Jr., 16 years old, collapsed and died last night during a high school basketball game. Osborne called for a timeout two minutes after the game started and told the coach he believed he was going to faint. The youth collapsed and was taken, to Valley General Hos pital, where he was dead on arrival.

title: Smoking Increases in Japan
description: TOKYO, Jan. 16 (Reuters) The number of cigarettes sold in. Japan last year was 219 bil lion, 5.4 per cent more than the previous year, the state monopoly has announced. It estimated the number of smok ers in Japan totaled 31.5 mil lion, or about 300,000 more than in 1969.

title: Connie Francis Is Bride
description: CALDWELL, N. J., Jan. 16 (AP)Connie Francis, the pop singer, was married here today to Izzy Marion, the owner of several beauty salons in Las Vegas and Lake Tahoe. The wedding took place at St. Alyo sius Church and was followed by a reception at the bride's home in Essex Fells. It is the second marriage for both Miss Frances, 32 years old, and Marion, 38.

title: Fire Aboard a Freighter At Sea Allowed to Burn
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 16 (AP)The Coast Guard said today that a fire aboard the freighter San Gus, started by an explosion 40 miles at sea, was being allowed to burn it self out.

title: News of Dogs
description: The poodle, leading breed in the country in American Kennel Club registrations, also is the leading breed in Westminster Kennel Club show entries, according to a tabulation of the 3,035dog list issued by the club. The event will be in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 15 and 16. The three varieties of poo dles number 222 dogs. Oddly enough, the num ber in each va riety is almost the same and all three have advanced substantially from last year. There are 77 of the minia ture variety, up from 52; 73 standards from 46 and 72 toys from 49.

title: OREGON COURT RULES BIAS CAUSES ANGUISH
description: SALEM, Ore., Jan. 16 (AP) The Oregon Court of Appeals has ruled that mental anguish is one of the effects of racial, discrimination and can be com pensated by a money award.

description: THE fervor of revolutionary stu dents describing the violence they experience and expect has shocked even those who take refuge in agreeing with their aims but not their methods. Yet these students, however fervid, however forceful, have remained essentially anonymous.

The child, the couple's second, is named Laura Brewster. Mr. White is an architect with Roy Banwell, Inc., in Han over.

title: In Mexico's Cradle of Independence
description: QUERETARO, MexicoSome guide books recommend that you drive right past this old colonial city, and you could easily do it by mistake. From a distance, Quertaro is hidden behind the viaducts and over passes of the new toll road from Mexico City, and when it does briefly appear a romantic dream of bubble domes and towers  it seems more like an aban doned movie set than a real town where people actually live. But be not de ceived. Though its outskirts are clogged with motels, gas stations, bottling plants and other necessities of modern civiliza tion, Quertaro's colonial heart beats with a more authentic life than you will find in a dozen Williamsburgs.

The reason is that you may have to go through the somewhat nerve racking experience of clambering up or down between a cruise ship and a small, bobbing harbor tender; you will also find that small, bobbing donkeys and mules are a principal mode of trans portation on many of the islands.

description: Bill Vanevar presents a very deceptive front as a folk musi cian.

Certainly not to travelers from the West.

Every Big Ten team ex cept Purdue and Ohio State will play 11 games in 1971, and the Big Ten has ruled that all con ference teams must play eight league opponents.

In addition, of course, many travelers shy away from Jordan for political reasons or simply because they do not wish to get caught in the midst of any resurgence of the Jordanian civil war or in the crossfire of the ArabIsraeli war.

title: France Is 3d in Arms Sales, After the U.S. and Soviet

title: Movies

The question seems to rouble the makers of Alex in Wonderland too, though their film is itself a depressing answer to the question. What's happened is that mov ies have gone personal.

He had himself studied Talmud, at the Flatbush Yeshiva, and now, in August, 1968, Meir David Kahane was the rabbi of a small synagogue in Queens. He had followed the family tradition, but Rabbi Kahane felt he had a spe cial mission.

They are being held as hos tages in a stalemated contest of political wills between the Tupamaros, the urban guerrillas who kidnapped them, and the elected Government of Uruguay.

description: CROMWELL, Conn., Jan. 16The engagement of Miss Cornelia Banks Oppenheimer to Peter G. D'Oench has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Martin G. Oppenheimer, par ents of the future bride.

description: DALLAS, Jan. 16 (AP) Southern Methodist today ex tended the contract of Hayden Fry, head football coach and athletic director, through 1974.

description: DETROIT, Jan. 16 (UPI) Bob Kelley and Cliff Schmautz scored two goals apiece tonight to give the Philadelphia Flyers a 42 triumph over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Art
description: PRACTITIONERS of the visual arts, whether painters, sculptors or graphic artists, whose work encompasses a strong literary element have not fared very well in modern canons of taste. The tendency of modernist taste has been to exalt the purely visual, and the very notion of literary ideas in a work of visual art is often assumed to be an impediment to esthetic reali zation. Yet there remain cer tain artistsartists of genu ine originality and striking achievementwhose vision is inseparable from a specific literary content and whose work speaks to us, if it speaks to us at all, with an impera tive that can never be re duced to the specifications of purely visual discourse. Such artistslet us call them artistpoets  tend not to work in the major genres or on a large physical scale. Their work exists, more often than not, at the opposite pole from those large decorative statements that have come more and more to dominate our sense of what art essen tially is. There remains some thing ineluctably private and interior in such work that in hibits its projection on a pub lic scale.

title: Margaret can make a human being
description: So here is another mad housewife one of those upper middleAmerican products of suburbia and the Seven Sister Colleges who checked out of the brutal, New York career rat race and into the safe harbor of mat rimony and motherhood, only to find it a snare and a tedium.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Employes' willingness to take a reduction in pay has paved the way for Swift & Co. to reverse an earlier de cision and keep its old meat packing plant open in San Antonio.

title: Udall Is Arrested In Dispute in Store Involving 3 Cigars
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 Stewart L. Udall, Secretary of the Interior in the Johnson and Kennedy Administrations, was arrested today on a shoplifting charge in a dispute involving three cigars worth 95 cents.

description: CARACAS, Venezuela  If anyone had asked a foreign businessman a month ago to name the Latin American land with the best climate for investment, the answer undoubtedly would have been Venezuela.

title: Child to Mrs. R. S. Travis

title: Architecture
description: ONE of New York's worstkept secrets and bestmanipulated stat istics is the exodus of major corporations. City Hall shivers for its tax base with every new company count.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONPresident Nixon's appeal to young Americans at the University of Nebraska was one of the best speeches he has madewise, understanding, yet challenging. As such, it became more nearly an appeal to all Americans. The destiny of this nation is not divided into yours and ours, he said to the Nebraska stu dents. It is one destiny.

description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  When Rep resentative Carl Albert was asked last week about President Nixon's plan to share Federal revenues with the state and lo cal governments to use as need ed, the Oklahoma Democrat, who is likely to be elected the next Speaker of the House, said: He wants to hand out money we don't have, to states and locali ties, with no strings attached. Wherever a local government is foundering for inefficiency or some other reason, we will be expected to shore it up. I don't see much in that for us; we levy the taxes and somebody else spends the money.

title: A hidden Dream of Sex and Love
description: For generations of theatergoers, A Mid summer Night's Dream has meant danc ing fairies, wooded greens and gossamer wingsOberon, Titania and Puck flitting about, casting their magic spells with sweet sentimentality. From Garrick to Max Reinhardt, directors have leaned heavily upon this tradition of cloying romanticism and few have had the temerity to break it. Finally, Peter Brook has. His new produc tion of A Midsummer Night's Dream, arriving at the Billy Rose on Wednesday, is a deliberate departure from convention contemporary in design, Freudian in tone and, at the same time, faithful to the Shakespearean text. Here are no winged fairies, fake moons or silver sequins, but pristine and sensuous visiona joyful trib ute to Shakespeare's the poet, the lunatic, the lover.

title: Hitler makes his move
description: There can be few readers who are not already familiar with the climactic event of this bookthe early afternoon of Nov. 9, 1923, when Adolf Hitler attempts his Munich putsch. The scene has been written again and again. The column of several thousand men tramping up the narrow Residenz Strasse on their way to the district military head quarters which has already been seized by Hitler's follow ers. The S.A. stormtrooper com panies, singing Deutschland Koch in Ehren and waving swastika banners. At the head of the column march the lead ers of the putsch including Gen eral Ludendorff. Captain Goer ing, the antiSemitic theorist Scheubner  Richter, and of course, Adolf Hitler who trig gered off the whole thing in a beer hall the night before.

title: Seton Hall Wins, 7469

title: BirthControl Policy Succeeds in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, TaiwanFor years a traditionalist faction in the Government of Nationalist China blocked the adoption of an official birthcontrol program. The ideal of a large family is a fundamental value in Chinese culture, they argued, and besides, Taiwan needs a large population for the task of recovering the mainland.

description: The transSiberian airline routs from Tokyo to Western Europewhich began last March  has apparently proved kinder to some car riers serving the run than others, judging by statistics furnished by Japanese sources.

title: Stuart F. Louchheim, Who Saved Philadelphia Music Shrine, Dies
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 Stuart F. Louchheim, president of the Academy of Music, who led the fight to save and re store the centuryold auditori um, died today following short illness.

title: BONN'S EASTERN TIES ENDORSED BY MUSKIE
description: BONN, Jan. 17Senator Ed mund S. Muskie today endorsed Chancellor Willy Brandt's policy of seeking cooperation with the Communist countries of east ern Europe.

title: Vesco Is Catalyst in I.O.S. Deal
description: GENEVA, Jan. 17Robert L. Vesco, president of the International Controls Cor poration of Fairfield, N. J., was the catalyst in the sec recyshrouded deal that saw Bernard Cornfeld renounce all his connections with the Investors Overseas Service mutualfund complex that he founded.

title: MotherSon Strife Is Theme of Dance In Barnard Series
description: Three new works made up the second program of the weekend Dance Uptown series at Barnard College's Minor Latham Playhouse Saturday night.

title: 100% Rise in office Jobs Expected in City Region by Year 2000
description: Office jobs in the New York region are expected to double in number by the end of the century, requiring new office construction equal to 300 Em pire State Buildings, the Re gional Plan Association said yesterday.

title: GORDON S. MILLS
description: NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 17 Gordon S. Mills, a director of American Airlines, died yester day at Norwalk Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived on Old Stage Coach Road in Weston.

title: Enclave of Low Prices
description: SINGAPORE  Inflation, unemployment and high tax es, triple plagues of the United States economy, are problems with which this ministate's government seems to be dealing effectively.

title: South African Sloop Holds Lead in South Atlantic Race
description: CAPETOWN, Monday, Jan. 18 (Reuters)  The South African Navy sloop, Voortrekker, led the fleet in the Capetown to Rio de Janeiro race, according to a report issued by the race committee early today.

title: CAR DEALERS FIND HIGH IMPORT TIDE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 American auto dealers are be ginning to doubt their new minicars will roll back the flood of imported vehicles, now winning a seventh of the United States automobile market.

title: and Seniority Under Siege
description: Today, Mr. Gardner is to be one of the leadoff wit nesses in two days of special hearings on the seniority problem presided over by Senators Mathias, Republican of Maryland, and Harris, Democrat of Oklahoma. The purpose of the hearings is to document the deadening power of seniority.

title: For Mao, or for the Hong Kong Dollar
description: HONG KONGIn Communist China, as officials there stress repeatedly, politics is in command. For the worker, this means physical labor is con stantly accompanied and often governed by sociopolitical activities, responsibilities and surveillance that add a special dimension to his existence.

title: Nepalese Industry Tries to Catch Up
description: NEW DELHI  One of the biggest industrial units in Nepal is an ice cream and soda plant in Katmandu.

title: LISBON ACTS TO CURB STUDENTS' PROTEST
description: LISBON, Jan. 17Portuguese university authorities an nounced today that Lisbon's Advanced Technical Institute would be closed tomorrow.

title: A Discussion
description: AN arc of little more than 90 degrees, with its pivot at Hong Kong (or across the line in Canton), would take in Taiwan, Singa pore, Malaysia, tormented Indochina and the Philippines. Till man Durdin, The New York Times's correspondent in Hong Kong, gathered four authorities on this area of the world and asked them to discuss the countries in the arctheir hopes, their achievements, their problems, and the enigmatic presence of China, the giant to the north.

title: REPERTORY CLASSICS PRESENTED BY ARRAU
description: Claudio Arrau, who next month will be celebrating the 30th anniversary of his New York debut, filled Hunter Col lege Assembly Hall Saturday with a recital of keyboard staples by Beethoven, Debussy, Chopin and Liszt.

title: Schlusselberg Wedding
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., Jan. 17Miss Marilyn Schlus selberg, daughter of Mr. and Albert Schlusselberg of Great Neck, was married here this evening to David H. Bern stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max B. Bernstein of Law rence and Hallandale, Fla. The bride is a psychologist. Her husband is a vice presi dent of HelmsleySpear, Inc., the New York real estate firm, Rabbi I. Usher Kirschblum performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple.

title: Editor and Photographer Are Killed in Auto Crash
description: Stephen Bronz of 77 Jane Street, editor, historian and au thor, and Martin J. H. Weaver of 440 Riverside Drive. English born photographer whose work appeared in books and maga zines, died Friday in an auto mobile collision at Taos, N.M. Each was 29 years old. Two teenagers, Manuel Romero and another youth, also died in the accident.

title: Pakistan, a House Divided
description: KARACHI, PakistanGeo graphically a house divided, Pakistan is increasingly be coming so politically as well.

title: Baltimore Field Goal in Last 5 Seconds Defeats Dallas in Super Bowl, 16 to 13
description: MIAMI, Jan. 17The Balti more Colts beat the Dallas Cowboys, 1613, and won the Super Bowl game today. The National Football League head quarters will soon be sending the winners their $15,000 checks. But it will be difficult to convince the Cowboys and many of the viewers that any body won this game, the cli mactic contest of the pro football season.

title: Nixon Steel Tactic: Put Off Import Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17A key White House tactic in its confrontation with the steel industry over prices last week was cancellation of a negotiat ing session scheduled with foreign countries aimed at con tinuing an arrangement that limits steel imports.

title: Mutiny Against the Law
description: The city's striking policemen are not only irresponsibly endangering New York's safety; they are undermining their own future capacity to enforce the laws, Com pliance with legal rulings is essential to an orderly society. Defiance of the courts or of civic authority by public employes erodes a community's ability to govern itself. Thus, when uniformed guardians of the law scoff at the courts, they engage in mutiny against their own ultimate interests.

title: House Democrats to Pick Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17As the most intense House Demo cratic leadership struggle in 30 years nears the day of decision, the problem faced by the candi dates is perhaps best pointed up by a remark by a North eastern Congressman.

title: HOUSING INDUSTRY SEES STRONG YEAR
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 17  This will be a good year for housing, the president of the National Association of Home Builders said here today.

title: The President's Plea to Youth
description: Mr. Nixon appeared before the students of the Univer sity of Nebraska wearing, as he might put it, his Presi dential hat. It is an infinitely more suitable attire than the hard hat sported by the President and his associates during last fall's campaign.

title: Teachers in Chicago Approve Contract
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (UPI) Chicago teachers accepted to day a new twoyear contract that makes them the highest paid teachers in any large city in the nation.

title: Laver Qualifies to Play Ashe Here on Thursday
description: Rod Laver's victory Satur day night in the fourth match of the $210,000 Tennis Champions Classic qualified the Australian star to face Arthur Ashe in the fifth match of the series Thursday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Army Spied on 18,000 Civilians in 2Year Operation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The United States Army fed the names of about 18,000 Ameri can civilians into its computers, dossiers and files in a wide ranging intelligence operation during the tumultuous days of civil disturbances from the summer of 1967 through the fall of 1969.

title: The Kremlin's Arabian Nightmare
description: Success or failure of the renewed Middle East peace talks will depend in important degree on the role of the Soviet Union. Officials in Washington and Jerusalem, still shaken by the Suez missile crisis that interrupted negotiation last September, are anx iously watching for some sign that the Russians have at last decided to use their influence to prod the Arabs toward a compromise settlement.

title: Two Toscanini Works Presented to La Scala
description: MILAN, Italy, Jan. 17 (Reu ters)Two previously un known compositions by Ar turo Toscanini were present ed to Milan's La Scala opera house last night to mark the 14th anniversary of his death.

title: Buckley Will Ask Senate Listing as ConservativeRepublican
description: James L. Buckley, who as sumes his seat as the new junior Senator from New York State on Thursday, said yes terday that he would ask edi tors of the Congressional Directory to list him as Con servativeRepublican.

title: Municipal Panel Suggested
description: WASHINGTON, Pan. 17 (AP) Representative F. Bradford Morse, Republican of Massa chusetts, said yesterday that he had asked President Nixon to create a White House Council of Municipal Advisers to focus toplevel attention on urban problems. Mr. Morse suggested, in a letter to Mr. Nixon, that three distinguished Americans with extensive practical experi ence at the municipal level of government be named to a panel fashioned along the lines of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

title: F.T.C. May Ease Auto Price Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The Federal Trade Commission, after two days of public hear ings, is apparently backing away from a proposal to pro hibit what the commission re gards as unrealistically high sticker prices for new cars.

title: Matson Wins at 6710
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 (AP)  Randy Matson of the Hous ton Striders says he uses the indoor track season as training for shotputting outdoors, but he might have trouble convinc ing the crowd of 11,234 that saw him equal an indoor world record.

title: Colts' Smith, Orr Retiring; Began as Pros Together
description: MIAMI, Jan. 17  Billy Ray Smith and Jimmy Orr, two of the Baltimore Colts' elder states men, announced their retire ment following today's Super Bowl game.

title: Jobs in Japan Hunting for People
description: TOKYOAny assessment of Japan's economic prospects must take into account a labor shortage that certain to become more acute during the nineteenseventies.

title: New Chilean Political and Economic Policies Generate Conflict
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 17 The efforts of President Salva dor Allende Gossens' leftist Government to strengthen its political and economic control over Chile are generating grow ing conflict at many levels.

title: John Dall, 50, Oscar Nominee For Corn Is Green Role, Dies
description: HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 17 (AP John Dall, a stage and screen actor, died Friday in his home at the age of 50. Friends said Mr. DaII had died of a heart attack.

title: 76ers Beat Rockets
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 17 (UPI) Hal Greer dropped in 6 points in the last 75 seconds to help the Philadelphia 76ers gain a 106105 victory over the San Diego Rockets tonight. It was San Diego's sixth straight de feat.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Point of View
description: HONG KONGEach year pessimists find new reasons to issue economic warnings and each year the exporters confound their predictions, a Hong Kong businessman commented recently. And in deed this British colony end ed last year with exports at a record level.

title: An Afghan Success: Coats
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A businessman is someone who sells everything, said Nudjib Zekrya, a businessman. I handle carpets. If I hear coats are selling, I sell coats.

title: Tokyo, Sydney's New Friend
description: SYDNEY, Australia  As economic relations between Australia and Japan continue to expand, the partnership is assuming significant new directions that go beyond the field of trade.

title: One Cowboy Wins: Howley Gets Award
description: MIAMI, Jan. 17Chuck Howley, the Dallas Cowboys' linebacker, was the surprise winner today of Sport Maga zine's award of a 1971 Dodge Charger as the outstanding player in the Super Bowl game.

title: Sports of The Times
description: MIAMI, Jan. 17According to the ad vance billing this was the Super Bowl, a titanic contest between two super teams playing super football. But this one came up strictly from hunger, a sandlot exhibi tion between a couple of ball clubs of Lilli putian dimensions and miniscule skills. The Baltimore Colts defeated the Dallas Cow boys in the final 5 seconds, 1613.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 17 (UPI) Dick Duff tipped in Gerry Meehan's slap shot with 15:38 gone in the third period tonight to give the Buffalo Sabres a 44 tie with the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Tennessee Society Dances In New Governor
description: Tennessee's upper crust may have waited 50 years to dance to a Republican Gov ernor, but those who sur vived Nashville's weekend of inaugural celebrations will tell you there hasn't been as much social excitement in the Athens of the South since Lafayette came to dine in 1825.

title: MAXIMINION GAINS HUNTER LAURELS
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 17 Robin Reade's Maximinion, making his second appearance in the ring, captured the green working hunter championship and took the reserve title for regular fox chasers today at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club's in door horse show.

title: TENNIS FINAL WON BY KATHY HARTER
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 17 (AP)Kathy Harter of Seal Beach, Calif., captured the Women's final in the Auck land tennis championships to day by overwhelming Shelly Monds of New Zealand, 61, 60. The American also teamed with Patsy Stevens of New Zealand for a 63, 62 victory over Anne Stevens and Mrs. Elaine Stephan, both of New Zealand, in the doubles final.

title: OilExploring Venture Set
description: The American Independent Oil Company, a subsidiary of R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., and the White Shield Indonesia Oil Corporation, a subsidiary of the White Shield Corporation, announced yesterday they had entered into a petroleum off shore exploration and develop ment agreement in Indonesia.

title: 3 TEAMS UNBEATEN IN INDOOR SOCCER
description: New York Hota, the Philadel phia Nationals and New York Hungaria triumphed twice at the indoor tournament of the German  American Soccer League, held at the Westches ter County Civic Center yester day and Saturday night. The tournament will be completed next Sunday.

title: Immigrants to Australia
description: CANBERRA, Jan. 17 (UPI) Australia attracted 185,099 im migrants during the last fiscal year, Immigration Minister Phillip Lynch said today. Of these, 3,300 were nonEuro peans including Indians, Malay sians and Chinese, and 6,000 were of mixed European and nonEuropean descent, Mr. Lynch said.

title: Bridge:
description: An unusual double was achieved by Val Habicht of Wakefield, Mass., in the TriState Regional Cham pionships, which ended yes terday at Grossinger's in the Catskills. She captured the Women's Pair title with Shirley Petty of Andover, Mass., and then the Mixed Pair title with R. Jay Becker of New York.

title: Advertising:
description: The nation's leading brew er is getting into the fast growing malt liquor field.

title: 3 SEIZED IN SALE OF LICENSE TEST
description: The breakup of a ring en gaged in the theft and sale of state licensing examinations for chiropractors was reported yes terday by Bronx District At torney Burton B. Roberts. As a result, the state canceled tests scheduled for today for more than 400 candidates.

title: Boston Raises Ruled Out
description: BOSTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)  Mayor Kevin H. White said to day that city employes would not be given a costofliving pay raise this year because of the city's financial problems. Admitting that it was poor politics for a man seeking re election Mr. While said we simply can't afford the in creases.

title: PUSEY FINDS GAINS DESPITE DISRUPTION
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 17 (AP)Nathan M. Pusey, retir ing president of Harvard Uni versity, said today that despite disruptions by dissident stu dents and threats, the educa tional advances in 196970 were little short of remarkable in both number and quality.

title: Senate Panel on Aging, After a 2Year Study, Says Retirement Income Problem Has Reached Crisis Stage
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 The retirement income prob lem in the United States has become a retirement income crisis, a Senate report de clares.

title: Israel Bond Drive Sets a Goal Of $400Million for U.S. Jews
description: American Jews were asked yesterday to contribute more than $400million to help Is rael consolidate her economic framework and develop a net work of new settlements.

title: Demonstration Near Hamburg
description: BONN, Jan. 17 (Reuters)  About 300 young demonstrators tried to lay a wreath today at Bismarck's last home near Ham burg and clashed with about 500 counterdemonstrators. No one was injured.

title: Roster of U.S. Agencies Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17In 1781 the Continental Con gress established a Department of Foreign Affairs, the progenitor of the State Department, to carry out all cor respondence and business with other nations. It was authorized to hire one or more clerks.

title: O'Brien Asks Network Aid In Equalization of Air Time
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) The chairman of the Demo cratic National Committee, Lawrence F. O'Brien, who for months has been protesting that the Republicans as the party in power take unfair ad vantage in the use of political air time, asked the networks today to help change things.

title: TOUGHER BRAKE CODE FOR TRUCKS PLANNED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI) Douglas A. Toms, director of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said to day that the Government would require heavily loaded trucks to have brakes that can stop them as quickly as passenger cars.

title: Japan Slows Down To 11% Growth
description: TOKYOJapan is expect ing a levelingoff this year in its growth rate after a five year economic boom, but even if the predicted slowdown occurs, it will still leave the country with a rate higher than that of any Western country.

title: Tea Sales Steady
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon  1970 has proved a good year for Ceylon tea but a bleak year for rubber. Tea is responsible for 65 per cent of the for eign exchange earnings of the country and rubber for 15 per cent.

title: NEW STRIKE PERIL IS SEEN IN GDANSK
description: GDANSK, Poland, Jan. 17 Workers in Gdansk's Lenin Shipyards, where last month's antiGovernment riots began, were reliably reported tonight to be planning a work stop page tomorrow if economic de mands were not met.

title: Among the Sheep, Minerals
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand The New Zealand economy has broken tradition.

title: Train Derailed on Coast
description: REDDING, Calif., Jan. 17 (UPI)  A Southern Pacific Company passenger train with 123 passengers aboard derailed early today about 28 miles north of here. The railroad said there were no serious injuries in the accident involving the southbound Cascade, on the way from Portland to San Francisco.

title: WILLIAM D. KAUFMANN
description: CARLE PLACE, L. I., Jan. 17 William D. Kaufmann of 40 Garden Avenue, who retired last year as assistant to the head of the avertising accept ability department at The New York Times, died last night in Mount Sinai Hospital, New York. He was 66 years old.

title: Man in the News
description: Two years ago, the contro versial but benevolent multi millionaire who owns the Baltimore Colts planned a big Super Bowl celebration party at his home in Golden Beach, Fla.

title: Indians Ache With Poverty
description: NEW DELHI  The wife of the Indian Ambassador to the United States, Mrs. L. K. Jha, suggested a novel cure for India's woes recently. Very few Indians are hun gry, she said in an inter view, but many have aches and pains. If you stand on a street corner with aspirins, you could soon have 600 peo ple around you.

title: Auto Union and Chrysler Meet in Face of Deadline
description: DETROIT, Jan. 17 (UPI) The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Work ers, facing a unionimposed Tuesday morning strike dead line, met through the weekend in an attempt to reach terms in a new contract for the auto company's 120,000 hourly and salaried workers.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: DETROIT, Jan. 17 (AP)Tom Williams and Danny Grant did the scoring and Cesar Maniago handled the goalkeeping to night as the Minnesota North Stars beat the Detroit Red Wings, 20, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ALCINDOR GETS 44 AS BUCKS TRIUMPH
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 17 (AP) A 44point contribution by Lew Alcindor helped Milwaukee to a 120113 victory over the Bos ton Celtics tonight, raising the Bucks' National Basketball As sociation winning streak to nine games.

title: Malaysia to Spur Jobs for Malays
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia Active intervention in the private sector is planned by the Government to rectify the economic disparity between Malays and nonMalays.

title: South Korea Growth Slows
description: SEOUL, South KoreaThe South Korean economy con tinued to climb in 1970, al though the rate of growth began to slow, partly because of a Government policy to check it.

title: Arts Abroad
description: VIENNAFew avantgarde composers have lived to be cheered by Vienna audiences. Frank Martin, who was 80 in September, just made it at the turn of the year with his new piano concerto.

title: Judith Nancy Horwitz Married
description: OSHKOSH, Wis., Jan. 17 In Temple B'nai Israel here at noon today, Miss Judith Nancy Horwitz, a fashion publicist, was married to Philip Aaron Schaefer, a stockbroker with CBWLHay den Stone, Inc., in New York. The ceremony was per formed by Rabbi Jonathan J. Prinz, also a stockbroker and business partner of the bride groom.

title: Vietnamization Plus American Forces
description: SAN DIEGO  Vietnamization has become a household word in the United States. We understand that the Vietnamization program is succeeding and that the rate of withdrawal of our ground combat forces may be ac celerated. We hear that the ground combat role may be assumed com pletely by the South Vietnamese some time toward the end of this year. Less well known and given little emphasis is the continued need for other combat forces in Southeast Asia, even after the Vietnamese take over the ground combat function.

title: TEAMSTER STRIKE CLOSES 4 DEPOTS FOR PRODUCE HERE
description: The four produce markets that handle most of the city's fresh and frozen fruit and vege tables were closed yesterday by a teamster strike.

title: Slump Perplexes OnceSuccessful Thailand
description: BANGKOK, ThailandThis nation, once an Asian success story, is on the verge of a slump that is perplexing the economy's mainly conserva tive administrators and frus trating the younger techno crats who have been warning that all was not as rosy as it seemed.

title: A Reappraisal
description: The new mediumsize theaters in the Broadway area do offer great possi bilities to Broadway and also a fresh and valid alternative to Off Broadway. Happy Birthday, Wanda June, by Kurt Vonnegut Jr., is un happily, a little too bright, sophisticated and interestingly flawed to survive in the ordinary Broad way jungle, But now, having moved from the Theater de Lys downtown to the Edison Theater uptown, it has the chance to dazzle and enchant that stillselect audience whose concept of comedy goes further than pratfalls and standup one liners.

title: Blimp, Jets, Balloons Rise Over Miami
description: MIAMI, Jan. 17Through out the Super Bowl game to day, the Goodyear blimp circled the Orange Bowl sta dium with six spectators aboard.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Jan. 17Ten years ago this week, John F. Kennedy became President. It seems like yesterday in some ways. The snowy night before in Washington, the cold clear morn ing on the Capitol Plaza, that con fident young Bostonian voicethe memories are sharp.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bacallao and Holmes Win Crown in Squash Tennis
description: Dr. Pedro Bacallao and Joe Holmes won the national squash tennis doubles cham pionship yesterday by defeat ing Aaron Daniels and William Riesenfeld, the defending cham pions, 158, 156, 1512, at the City Athletic Club.

title: Labor Unrest Distresses New Zealand
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  In spite of free spending and full employment, 1970 was an uneasy year for New Zealand. Many countries have experienced similar inflation and a wageprice spiral.

title: Growing Coconuts, Way of Life
description: SANTA CRUZ, the Philip pinesWhen Alejandro Tope started growing coconuts here with his father a half century ago, their share of the earn ings amounted to 35 pesos a year. Now, on the same hold ing with the same number of trees, they are up to 280 pesos a year, or about $45.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
State Enterprises Pace Taiwan's Growth.
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  State enterprise is showing a marked upsurge after declin ing for many years as a pro portion of Taiwan's flourish ing total economy.

title: STEPHEN MIZWA, KOSCIUSZKO AIDE
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 17  Dr. Stephen P. Mizwa, who served the Kosciuszko Foundation from its formation in 1925 un til his retirement as president last year, died yesterday at the age of 78.

title: Former Retail Executive Buys Tennis Goods Shop
description: Stephen J. Feron, Inc., a racquet and tennis goods shop at 55 East 44th Street, has been purchased by John A. Blum, former senior vice presi dent of R. H. Macy & Co.

title: 3 IN NEONAZI PARTY ARRESTED IN FIGHT
description: James H. Madole, leader of the neoNazi National Renais sance party, and two of his fol lowers were arrested yesterday after they became involved in fight at 3:30 P.M. on the main concourse of the Port of New York Authority bus terminal, where they and two other party members were distributing par ty leaflets.

title: Sterilization Is An Answer for Many
description: Not long ago, people who talked about sterilization usually found themselves huddled in a corner some where, speaking in hushed tones. Men associated the operation with castration. Women felt it would make them less of a woman.

title: Nobody Could Have Stopped It
description: No, sir, I ain't working. That was Patrolman Wal lace Page's response when the desk officer in the 43d Precinct in the quiet Park chester section of the Bronx started calling the roll for the 4to12 shift Thursday afternoon.

title: COHAN RETAINS LEAD IN DRAGON SAILING
description: HOBART, Australia, Jan. 17 (UPI)Don Cohan of the Uni ted States retained his lead to day in the Prince Philip Cup race for Dragon Class boats despite a thirdplace finish in the fifth heat of the interna tional yachting competition.

title: 2 Charged In Bombing
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 17 (AP)Two men, aged 19 and 23, will appear in court to morrow in connection with an explosion today that shattered windows in the Soviet Embassy here.

title: Point of View
description: IT is becoming fashionable to predict that the 21st century will belong to Japan, in the sense that the 16th be longed to Spain, the 17th to Louis XIV's France, the 19th to Britain and the 20th belongs perhaps to the United States.

title: Calle Takes 12Mile Run For 2d Straight in Series
description: Agustin Calle of Brooklyn won the Road Runners of New York 12mile race through the West Bronx streets yesterday. It was the second of a four race series and Calle has won twice.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Peterson May Get White House Post On Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Peter G. Peterson, head of the Bell & Howell Company of Chicago, was reliably reported today to be in line for the chairmanship of a new White House policy council oversee ing foreign economic affairs.

title: Levine Aids Yale Theater
description: Joseph E. Levine, the film producer, has made an unspec ified first installment on his pledge of a $100,000 grant to the Yale Repertory Theatre for the operation of a resident pro fessional company at the uni versity.

title: Stage: Shrinking Bride
description: Jonathan Levy's The Shrinking Bride, which opened last night at the Mercury Theater, takes place in one of those stately Eng lish mansions where the master of the house serves Darjeeling, rides to hounds, and keeps polo ponies. The difference is that this man sion is a phony castle on the Hudson River and the master is a selfmade Jewish mil lionaire who began by ped dling soft goods from a pushcart. The Darjeeling, if ever served, would be a glasstea.

title: Disaster for Pakistanis Takes Many Shapes
description: KARACHI, PakistanEven before the cyclone and tidal wave devastated parts of East Pakistan late last year, this country was experiencing eco nomic difficulties.

title: Air Passengers Facing New Increases in Fares
description: Americans began paying almost $500,000 a day more for their airline tickets last week and before long, they'll almost certainly be paying much more.

title: DR.HERBERT B.DORAU, ECONOMIST, WAS 73
description: Dr. Herbert B. Dorau, who retired as professor of eco nomics and chairman of the department of real estate and land economics at New York University in 1962, died yes terday at his apartment in the Cambridge Apartments in Washington. He was 73 years old and lived in Fort Lauder dale, Fla.

title: BigBlock Trading On Exchange Set Peaks Last Year
description: Block trading on the New York Stock Exchange set rec ords in 1970, the exchange re ported yesterday. A total of 17,217 blocks of 10,000 or more shares were traded, involving 451.4 million shares.

title: Foreign Policy: Decision Power Ebbing at the State Department
description: After two years in office, President Nixon has fashioned his own style in foreign policy and in the use of his staff. Correspondents of The New York Times have explored this foreign policy machinery, the power of the President's ad visers and the impact of Wash ington's major institutions on foreign policy decisions. The role of the State Department is explored today in the first of a series of articles.

title: JOHN A. COLLINGS, T.W.A. EXECUTIVE
description: SALEM, Va., Jan. 17John A. Collings, former executive vice president of Trans World Airlines, died yesterday in the Community Hospital at Roan oke. He was 67 years old and lived here.

title: Pass Reported Taken
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Mon day, Jan. 18 (Reuters)  The Cambodian command said to day that Government troops had reached and retaken the crucial Pich Nil Pass on High way 4, Pnompenh's only route to the sea.

title: To Japanese Consumers,Import Means European
description: TOKYOJapan's skyrock eting economic growth has created an expanding market in this country that is only beginning to attract the at tention of foreign manufac turers of consumer products.

title: THOMAS CONDUCTS UNUSUAL PROGRAM
description: Michael Tilson Thomas seems to be making it clear that as long as he is around the Boston Symphony Orchestra, its pro gramsor those he is respon sible for, at leastwill not fall into dreary routine. After giving prominent play to music by Webern and Dahl in a con cert here last Wednesday, he took up the cause of Karlheinz Stockhausen Saturday night at Carnegie Hall.

title: U.S.C. Five Keeping Pace With U.C.L.A.; Tennessee in Upset
description: Southern California is having trouble finding an identity.

title: Plague of Laos War Stifles All Growth
description: BANGKOK, Thailand  About this time of the year, the Pathet Lao, the Commu nistbacked guerrilla force, collects what it considers its share of the Laotian rice harvest.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 22 THEATER GROUPS GET FEDERAL FUNDS
description: A total of $207,500 in grants to experimental theaters and workshops will be awarded to 22 groups in eight cities by the National Endowment for the Arts. The awards, the fourth in a series initiated in 1967 to aid in the development of new playwrights, new plays and new theater techniques, will range from $2,500 to $20,000 each, according to Nancy Hanks, chairman of the endow ment.

title: Australia: Bright, but Not Cloudless
description: SYDNEY, AustraliaDe spite the falloff in stock trad ing, weaknesses in the agri cultural sector and mounting concern over possible infla tionary influences, the eco nomic outlook for Australia shines brightly in forecasts for 1971 and future years.

title: ERIC A. REID
description: Eric A. Reid, a cofounder in 1922 of TelAnswerPhone, died Saturday of a heart attack here. He was 74 years old and lived at 415 East 52d Street.

title: Screen:Projectionist
description: Although you may have been expecting somebody sur real, out of Kafka or Borges, the hero of The Projection ist, which opened yesterday at the Kips Bay, is a guy who shows movies in a Manhattan theater. Unlike others of his profession, who are content to pass their happy hours in neglecting reelchange clues, misframing, ignoring focus, forgetting to trim their car bons, and failing to adjust their sound level, this pro jectionist also projects him self into the movies. So he is really not so far from the flights of Kafka or Borges or H. Rider Haggard or other great masters of the imagi nation.

title: Doing as the Romans Do Means Wearing Shorts
description: ROME, Jan. 17  Fashion still has its charm here. Last July, Roman women stepped out en masse in long skirts, jumping the gun on the fall couture openings. By the time winter arrived, the long skirts were so numerous no body bothered to turn around and look.

title: Pastor of St. Patrick's Preaches At 5th Ave. Presbyterian Church
description: For the first time, a Roman Catholic priest preached yester day in the pulpit of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at 55th Street.

title: Cowboys: Thomas Fumble Hurt
description: MIAMI, Jan. 17  When the Dallas Cowboys returned to their dressing room today, what did Tom Landry say to them?

title: Oil Nations to Meet Saturday On a New Offer by Companies
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 17 The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will hold an emergency meeting Satur day to consider a new offer by the international oil companies.

title: Hawks Top Rangers, 43, After Trailing by 30;
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 17For the first period of the National Hockey League game in the Chicago Stadium today, the capacity crowd of 16,666 and the fans who viewed the match on national television must have wondered why the Chi cago Black Hawks even both ered to show up to oppose the New York Rangers. For before the session ended the Broad way Blues enjoyed a 30 lead and there appeared no end to their goal production against the local netminder, Gerry Des jardins.

title: Jessie Shambaugh Dead; A Founder of 4H Clubs
description: CLARINDA, Iowa, Jan. 17 (AP)Jessie Field Shambaugh, a principal founder of the 4H Clubs of the United States, died in a hospital here Friday after a fall. She was 89 years old.

title: Business in Saigon Is Red Tape, Frustrationand Profit
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Doing business in Saigon, say the men who try, requires the patience of Job, the scruples of Machiavelli, a sense of humor and a bit of spare change for crossing the right palm.

title: KAISER FOLLOWS U.S. STEEL MOVE
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said last night it planned to raise prices on some major con struction products, matching the increases of about 6.8 per cent that were initiated Satur day by the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest producer.

title: Two Police Trainees Assist In Arrest of Bronx Man
description: The work of two police trainees and two detectives pressed into service by the patrolmen's job actionre sulted Saturday, in the arrest of a Bronx man in connection with a bomb scare, the police said.

title: Interception by Curtis Turning Point: Colts
description: MIAMI, Jan. 17  Jim O'Brien learned today the meaning of a dream he had about 10 days ago.

title: FIRE AND SANITATION UNIONS REBUFF CITY ON A 17.4% 3YEAR WAGE OFFER
description: The city virtually doubled its pay offer to firemen and sani tationmen yesterday, raising it to a 17.4 per cent increase over three years provided they agree to work rule changes for improved efficiency. The unions promptly rejected it.

title: Actors With Voices in Their Hands Begin a Tour
description: Among the people who hear with their eyes, it is sometimes said that Bernard Bragg has a golden voice in his hands,

title: TRANSIT UNIT PUTS WALKOUT AT 25%
description: About 25 per cent of the Transit Police force on the 4 P.M.tomidnight shift yesterday refused, in sympathy with the police walkout, to go out on patrol, the Transit Authority said.

title: Lawyer Without Mining Experience Getting Job as Federal Safety Enforcer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17A lawyer and former city judge who has worked as a Republi can party fund raiser, a cam paign consultant and a lobbyist for the Iowa Association of Coin Operated Laundries is be ing given the $30,000ayear job of enforcer of Federal coal mine safety standards in the Bureau of Mines.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI) Senator Muskie returned tonight, completing a tour of the Middle East, Europe and the Soviet Union.

title: Carolina Political Leader Foils Abduction Attempt in ShootOut
description: BENNETTSVILLE, S.C. Jan. 17An apparent attempt to kidnap several Marlboro County political figures and members of their families last night ended with the wounding of the wife of a State Senator and one of two intruders in a shootout in the home of a former state legislator near this eastern South Carolina town.

title: Nixon Watches Bowl Game
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 17 (AP) President Nixon watched the Super Bowl professional foot ball championship game on tele vision today, and then flew back to the White House from a quiet weekend at Camp Da vid, Md. Mr. Nixon spent most of the weekend working on his State of the Union Mes sage, but took time out yes terday for a stroll with Mrs. Nixon.

title: EXIMBANK SEEKS SPUR TO EXPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The ExportImport Bank, given Con gressional approval of legisla tion affecting the bank's budg et, is planning a major innova tion in the field of shortterm export credit.

title: Antigovernment Plot Charged
description: VALPARAISO, Chile, Jan. 17 (UPI)  Interior Minister Jose Toha Gonzalez said today that reactionaries were plotting to disrupt the leftist Government of Dr. Allende.

title: Chess:
description: Too many draws in key games was the reason many pretournament favorites did not qualify in the recent in terzonal at Majorca, Spain. Grandmaster draws or other tame and insipid con clusions have upset many a score, but the appended games were far different in character.

title: DR. FITZHUGH BOGGS, ORDNANCE EXPERT, 59
description: FLEMINGTON, N.J., Jan. 17 (AP)Dr. Fitzhugh W. Boggs, professor of engineering science at Pennsylvania State Univer sity and chief scientist of the Ordnance Research Laboratory there, died of cancer yesterday in Hunterdon Medical Center here. He was 59 years old and lived in nearby Hampton.

title: Campaign Expenditures
description: Common Cause, the citizens' lobby organized by John W. Gardner, is leading the attack on two serious abuses in the nation's political lifethe seniority stranglehold on Congress and the debasing power of money in political campaigns. In an effort to correct the latter abuse, the organization has filed suit in the Federal District Court in Washington to have present political spending practices declared illegal and the behavior of the parties brought under court supervision.

title: Point of View
description: DESPITE the security na Dture of American involve ment in the Far East since World War II, our tradition al role in that part of Asia has been commercial.

title: Mrs. King Advances
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 17 (UPI)Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach turned back Mrs. Ann Haydon Jones of England, 62, 60, and Rosemary Casals of San Francisco defeated Mrs. Nancy Richey Gunther of San Angelo, Tex., 63, 61, in the semifinals of the Billie Jean King invitation last night.

title: News Analysis
description: ALBANY, Jan. 17A year or two ago, only legislators with the most liberal constit uencies, such as Manhattan's West Side, would stick their political necks out by propos ing a new look at the penalties for possessing and selling marijuana. Yet, in the last 10 days, a bipartisan state com mission, which has been working closely with Gov ernor Rockefeller's staff and the New York State Dis trict Attorneys Association, has recommended sharp reductions in the marijuana penalties.

title: Indian Price Rises Dampen Spirits
description: NEW DELHI  At a time when it was expected to pick up momentum, the Indian economy slowed down last year.

title: CITY WINS DELAY ON MEDICAID BILLS
description: State welfare officials have had to grant New York City's new Health and Hospitals Cor poration an extra six months to submit 35,000 overdue Medi caid bills worth $29million in state and Federal aid.

title: Britons Protest for Dutschke
description: LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP)  More than 3,000 students from 11 English universities marched through London today in pro test against the Government's refusal to let Rudi Dutschke, a former West German student leeader, sta yin Britain.

title: Steel Users Relieved
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 17Steel users are breathing a little easier now.

title: 7 Chicago Negroes Acquitted in Killing Of Gang Detective
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) Seven members of the Black P Stone Nation were acquitted today of murder in the sniper slaying last Aug. 13 of Detec tive James A. Alfano Jr.

title: PalmFringed Ceylon Promotes Tourism
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon Since 1966, when the Government decided to seek to attract tourists, the growth in the number of visitors to this scenic island has been gradual but satisfactory.

title: CEYLON COMPLETES DRAFT CONSTITUTION
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 17 A draft of Ceylon's proposed new constitution, pledging the progressive advancement to ward the establishment of a socialist democracy, was made public today by the Constitu tional Affairs Minister, Dr. Col vin R. de Silva.

title: Olvera Beats Belkin
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 17 (AP) Miguel Olvera, Ecuador's No. 1 amateur tennis player, upset Mike Belkin of Toronto, Can ada's No. 1 seeded player 62, 75, in the Florida State tennis championships today.

title: Y Group Gives Concert
description: The Symphonic Workshop of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association presented its annual winter concert yesterday at the Kauf mann Concert Hall under the direction of Maurice Levine. The soloist was Tadeusz Kerner, who played Liszt's Piano Con certo No. 1 in E major. Other works performed were the world premiere of Arthur Har ris's Bintel Brief and the Festival Overture by Shosta kovich.

title: Man Dies in Hotel Fire
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 17 (UPI) Hyman Schulte, about 60 years old, was killed and sev eral other guests were injured today in a hotel fire on the city's east side. Mr. Schulte was pronounced dead at St. Vincent Charity Hospital. Several guests were treated for smoke inhala tion and released.

title: A Kite Record Falls in the Face of Apathy
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Jan. 17 A sports milestone was quietly reached today 200 miles northwest of the vio lence at the Super Bowl.

title: Unitas Could've Played If They Needed Me
description: MIAMI, Jan. 17Johnny Unitas was injured today when George Andrie, a Cow boy defensive end, tackled him in the act of passing.

title: U.S. REPORTS RAID ON 2 MISSILES SITES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Mon day, Jan. 18 (AP)United States fighterbombers attacked two surfacetoair missile sites in North Vietnam yesterday in the third straight day of protec tive reaction strikes inside the enemy's borders, the United States command announced to day.

title: WOMAN TO POLICE CONSUMER FRAUDS
description: Patricia Mary Hynes, a petite 28yearold blonde, takes over today as the principal Federal prosecutor of Consumer Frauds here.

title: Station RollCall Draws an I Refuse, Sir
description: Like generals without an army, the police supervisors at the West 54th Street station last night did what they could.

title: 60 U.S. Guards, Asked by Lindsay in Police Strike, Begin Protecting Soviet Mission
description: About 60 Federal guards sent from Washington to help city policemen guard the So viet Union's mission to the United Nations during the wild cat strike by patrolmen began standing watch there yesterday.

title: The Barriers Drop Slowly
description: TOKYO  The consensus among foreign observers here is that Japan's capital and trade liberalization programs are moving in the right direc tion, but far too slowly to satisfy foreign businessmen.

title: Canucks Space Out Tallies To Vanquish Seals, 3 to 1
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 17 (UPI)  Danny Johnson, Ray Cullen and Rosaire Paiement scored tonight to send the Van couver Canucks to a 31 tri umph over the California Seals in the National Hockey League. The goals came in each period.

title: Technical Age Compounds Asia's Plight
description: A New York Times correspondent, Mr. Shabecoff returned recently from Asia where he covered economic as well as political and other events. He is now with the Washington Bureau of The Times.

title: NETS OVERCOME COUGARS, 120112
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Jan. 17 (AP) The New York Nets scored the last 8 points of the game to beat the Carolina Cou gars, 120112, tonight to gain sole possession of third place in the East Division of the American Basketball Associa tion.

title: Cracking the Seniority Wall
description: WASHINGTONThe best opportu nity in several decades to make Con gress more responsive and responsible will present itself tomorrow when the 92nd Congress Democrats hold their organizational caucus and review the seniority system.

title: Mir Defeats Jay for Title In Open Squash Racquets
description: Farooq Mir of the City Ath letic Club won the Metropoli tan open squash racquets tour nament yesterday by defeating Nelson Jay of the Harvard Club, 1315, 158, 1614, 158, at the Harvard Club.

title: Ulster Leader to Go to London To Ask More Help in Disorders
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 17Prime Minister James ChichesterClark announced to day that he would confer with Britain's Home Secretary, Reg inald Maudling in London to morrow to discuss tougher se curity measures to deal with new disorders in Northern Ire land.

title: Shots Strike Exiles' Cars
description: MIAMI, Jan. 17 (AP)The parked cars of four leaders of the Cuban exile organization Alpha 66 were struck today by gunfire. The group, dedicated to the armed overthrow of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba, blamed terrorists they said were trying to intimidate the movement's officials.

title: Bullets On Top, 11196
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 17 (AP)  Paced by Fred Carter's 22 points, the Baltimore Bullets defeated the Seattle Sonics to night, 11196.

title: Indonesia: Success Means a Standstill
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  In donesia continued in the last year her energetic race to ward an elusive targeta level of economic develop ment that will provide work at a living wage for the rapidly growing population.

title: PRIESTS' STRESS IS FOUND SEVERE
description: SOUTH PEND, Ind., Jan. 17 (UPI)More than 40 per cent of young Roman Catholic priests polled in a nationwide survey felt they were under such severe stress that they would consider quitting the priesthood, according to a Uni versity of Notre Dame soci ologist.

title: Peking Outlook Best in Years
description: HONG KONGCommunist China moved into a new eco nomic phase in 1971 marked by the beginning of the coun try's fourth fiveyear plan and improved  though still uncertain  prospects for development.

title: N.B.C. Weighs Bids for Sale of 12 Radio Stations
description: Fortyfour years ago, full page advertisements proclaimed the founding of the National Broadcasting Company as the first regular nationwide radio network to offer programs in the interest of the listening public.

title: POLICE STRIKE TALKS DEADLOCKED;
description: Negotiations to end the city wide policemen's strike were reported to be gravely dead locked yesterday as the wild cat walkout deprived New York of 85 per cent of its pa trolmen for a fourth successive day.

title: NASSAU POLICE PACT SAID TO BE IMMINENT
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 17 Nassau County negotiators and the Nassau Patrolmen's Benevo lent Association were reported today to be close to an agree ment on a twoyear contract granting an 8 per cent raise the first year and 10 per cent the second.

title: News Analysis
description: LONDON, Jan. 17  The in terests of the oil consuming countries will be represented for the first time in the major confrontation taking shape be tween the international oil corporations and the Arab and other oil producing countries.

title: Mrs. Court Takes Crown
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 17 (AP)  Mrs. Margaret Smith Court of Australia beat Olga Morozova of the Soviet Union today in the women's singles final at the New South Wales tennis championships. The scores were 62, 62.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jo Ettinger Bride Of Stanley Barrish
description: Miss Jo Ettinger and Stan ley Barrish were married here yesterday afternoon in the Rainbow Grill by Rabbi Norman Kahane.

title: West Germans Set 60% Growth in Aluminum
description: BONN, Jan. 17  Defying the notion that this is the age of plastics, West Ger many's growthminded alumi num industry entered the new year with a production ca pacity 60 per cent higher than that at the start of 1970.

title: EITEL RIESENKONIG
description: Eitel Riesenkonig, vice presi dent, treasurer and a director of the Lithoprint Company of New York, 145 Hudson Street, who was also an antique dealer in Chappaqua, N. Y., died Satur day in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, N. Y. He was 61 years old and lived at 926 Hardscrabble Road, Chappaqua.

title: Israel Condemns Terrorism in U.S. in Support of Soviet Jews
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 17  The Israeli Government today con demned acts of terrorism in the United States in the cam paign to force the Soviet Un ion to allow Soviet Jews to em igrate to Israel.

title: Ransom and Release in Rio
description: The safe return of the kidnapped Swiss Ambassador in Brazil is a cause for relief and rejoicing. Unfortunately, however, Brazil's actions to effect the release of Ambas sador Bucher contribute little to resolving the problem of political kidnappings in the Americas or anywhere else.

title: Floating Peso Cheers Manila
description: MANILADespite the dev astation of the typhoon that struck the Philippines in November, hopes remained high that 1970 marked an important forward step in the economic development of the country.

title: Desmond Will Advise Correction Board
description: Charles S. Desmond, retired Chief Judge of the state Court of Appeals, has been retained by the city Board of Correction to give an opinion on whether it has power to subpoena wit nesses in its watchdog role for city jails.

title: Palmer Wins Special Slalom
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 17 (AP)Tyler Palmer, 20 yearold rookie from Kearsage, N. H., gave the United States its first World Cup victory of the Alpine ski season today by winning the Lauderhorn spe cial slalom.

title: The Talk of Blackjack
description: BLACKJACK, Mo., Jan. 14 Up until about five years ago, the rolling Missouri hills crept right up to the back door of the general store and the handful of clapboard farm houses scattered around the crossroads here. Life in Blackjack was very quiet and very pleasant.

title: UNION AIDES BACK TELEPHONE STRIKE
description: Presidents of 27 of the 28 locals of telephone repairmen and installers in New York State voted last night to con tinue their weekold work stop page despite mounting fines that will total $501,750 today.

title: Thompson and Miss Budge Win Slalom Races in Trophy Skiing
description: STOWE, Vt., Jan. 17It is generally felt that Westerners race better on the soft snow usually found in their part of the country than they do on the hardpacked and often icy surfaces prevalent in the East.

title: GERMANS OBSERVE 2D REICH FOUNDING
description: BONN, Jan. 17 Germans, East and West. are marking the centennial of the founding of the Second German Empire with a variety of sentiments.

title: Little Lamp Is Designed To Oscillate
description: There was George Kovacs, who designs lamps, manu factures lamps and sells lamps, doodling away when suddenly it hit him: he had before him another barebulb lamp.

title: Kings Beat Flyers, 41
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 (UPI)  The Los Angeles Kings posted their first victory in seven games, a 41 decision over the Philadelphia Flyers to night.

title: STONE TRIUMPHS IN JUMPOFF FINAL
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 17  Larry Stone of Salisbury, Conn., captured the Mount Beacon tournament today with a flight of 162 feet from the 50meter hill in a jumpoff.

title: Skyline of Seoul Rises Proud and Gleaming
description: SEOUL, South Korea  This 576yearold capital, re membered by thousands of G.I.'s as a city of ruins and dusty roads, is rapidly being transformed into a metropo lis of highrise buildings, wide streets, elevated roads and sprawling suburbs.

title: Hussein's Overthrow Again Called for by Leftist Guerrilla Leader
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 17 Dr. George Habash, the left wing Arab guerrilla chief, un derscored the latest split in the Arab commando movement to day by calling for the over throw of King Hussein of Jor dan.

title: Point of View
description: WE are in deep trouble in our foreign trade policy. Faced with high rates of un employment and inflation, key sectors of American labor and industry are clamoring for import quotas. Our com petitive position has deterio rated. The internationalist constituency, which once sup ported the liberal trade in itiatives necessary for Amer ica's world leadership, has been demoralized and divided by Vietnam.

title: Market (Mostly) Floats
description: BANGKOK, ThailandJust as the Thai Government is urgently promoting tourism, progress is threatening to scuttle one of the nation's most popular attractions the Floating Market.

title: Personal Finance
description: How would you like to get stock in the company you work for without having to put up any money?

title: Cambodia Economy Is Hard to Find
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia  When the Vietnam war final ly boiled over into Cambodia, the leaders of the new Gov ernment here realized how badly the deposed Prince Norodom Sihanouk had pre pared the army for war.

title: RATES EXPECTED TO KEEP FALLING
description: Interest rates will keep com ing down this week because they have no good reason not to.

title: Shaw's Final 70 for 278 Beats Palmer by 2 Strokes in Crosby Golf
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 17A year ago in the Bing Crosby proamateur golf tourna ment, Tom Shaw tied Arnold Palmer for 44th place. Last Sunday, in the Glen Campbell Los Angeles open, the 28year old Oregon professional dead locked Palmer again for 19th.

title: TWO PIANISTS SHARE '71 NAUMBURG PRIZE
description: Zola Shaulis, 28 years old, of Stockton, Calif., and KunWoo Paik, 24, of Korea, have been named to share the 1971 Naum burg Award, this year for pianists.

title: Czech Mission's Car Stolen
description: A 1971 Cadillac belonging to the Czechoslovak Mission to the United Nations was stolen early yesterday morning from in front of mission headquar ters at 1109 Madison Avenue, near 82d Street.

title: Frog Fight Reported After 2Month Truce
description: PENANG, Malaysia, Jan. 17 (AP)  Malaysia's warring frogs were reported to have hopped to another bitter clash today, leaving 50 dead or wounded, after two months of truce.

title: Lucky and Canny Now Prosperous
description: SYDNEY, AustraliaIn a corner of this country that had been written off for a century and a half as barely fit for cattle, Hamersley Iron, a company now only eight years old, has established an iron ore industry that has given Australia a new basis for prosperity.

title: MRS. WILLIAM T. WHITE
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 17 Mrs. Augusta Henrietta Roe bling White, widow of William Townsend White and last sur viving grandchild of John Au gustus Roebling who designed the Brooklyn Bridge, died today at her farm, Hilltop. She was 95 years old.

title: BROOKLYN BABY DIES FROM MALNUTRITION
description: A 7monthold Brooklyn baby boy was found dead, appar ently from malnutrition, yes terday and three other children in the same family were ?? at Kings County Hos pital. where one was reported in critical condition. The un married mother of the four children, Joyce Bryan, 27 years old, was arrested at the Miller Avenue station on a charge of criminal neglect.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bruins Trounce Leafs, 91
description: BOSTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)  The Boston Bruins ran their East Division lead in the Na tional Hockey League to 3 points tonight as Don Marcotte led eight scorers in a 91 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Soviet Mooncraft Roams
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 17 (AP)  Lunokhod 1, the Soviet Union's remotecontrolled moon vehicle, crawled 833 feet across the lunar surface today. The official Soviet press agency, Tass, said the vehicle moved for two hours and 32 minutes in a northwesterly direction across the Sea of Rains, negotiating craters and transmitting pano ramic photographs back to Soviet ground control.

title: $1Million Is Given College
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 17 (AP) Canisius College announced last night that it had been given $1million by the Greater Buf falo Press, Inc., one of the country's largest printers of color supplements. The college said it would respond to the gift by naming the new ath letic center for J. Walter Koes sler, founder of the company.

title: Hanoi, Many Experts Say, Can Sustain Endless War
