description: WASHINGTON  North Vietnam's economy  bol stered by what are said to be significant foodproduction in creases last year, the rebuild ing of some of its industries destroyed in the American bombings between 1965 and 1968 and the annual flow of more than $1billion in aid from its Communist allies  appears to be relatively sound, according to sources in Wash ington.

title: Advertising:
description: Another business leader has called for his fellows and their ad agencies to answer the demands of the consumer or face Government action.

title: Prison Adviser Urges Authority for Convicts
description: BOSTON, Jan. 17 (AP) The director of the Massa chusetts Council on Crime and Correction called to night for the development of Con Power for inmates as a necessary step toward needed reform of the state's prison system.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE FORGOTTEN SOLDIER. By Guy Sajer. Translated from the French by Lily Emmet. 465 pages, Harper & Row. $8.95.

title: Women of India: Two Paces Behind Men
description: NEW DELHIThe modern feminist movement has not yet taken a firm hold in India, which para doxically is the largest country in the world with a woman as head of the government.

title: WALL ST. LEANING TO FUNDS' ACCESS
description: Wall Street apparently is be ginning to reverse its tradition al position against institutional membership on the New York Stock Exchange. The reversal, if it actually comes about, would have a profound impact on the securities industry.

title: An Outing Beneath Tokyo
description: TOKYO  Subways may be for commuting or even for sleeping, but in Tokyo, some subways are for walking.

title: Opera: Pristine Strauss
description: It happens very often that a new Metropolitan Opera production looks like a Sal vation Army thrift shop re ject after three or four sea sons. The sets suddenly be come shabby and limp, and the singers forget the ori ginal direction.

title: Swift Soviet Naval Gains Worry U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  United States Navy analysts are increasingly concerned over what they see as the swift and potentially menacing growth of advanced Soviet naval tech nology.

title: Albany Notes
description: ALBANY, Jan. 17  This dowdy, snowheaped, frigid capital city is back to normal. It awoke from its torpor on Jan. 6 when the 194th State Legislature con vened. The streets are ice clotted snares sometimes covered with deceptive pat inas of new powdery snow that entice the unwary into for swearing the mincing, precar ious footwork that usually keeps one upright. In the evenings, the restaurants are crowded with legislators, staff aides, power brokers, public relations men, secretaries, lobbyists  all of them creating a babble of political gossip.

title: Quarrie's 9.3 for 100 Clips World Indoor Mark
description: POCATELLO, Idaho, Jan. 17 (UPI)Jamaica's top sprinter, Don Quarrie, broke the world indoor record for the 100yard dash with a clocking of 9.3 seconds last night at the Idaho State University invita tion meet.

title: Audi Squash Racquets Victor
description: Al Audi of the Heights Ca sino won the Class B invitation squash racquets tournament yesterday by defeating Ames Brown of the Seventh Regiment, 815, 157, 1015, 1615 1512, at the City Athletic Club.

title: I.O.S. SUED IN GENEV A BY REALTY CONCERN
description: Investment Properties Inter national Ltd., an international realty corporation based in Geneva, announced yesterday that it had filed a $35million suit against the Investors Over seas Services organization in Geneva. I.P.I. was originally formed by I.O.S., which owns the only voting shares in the concern.

title: State Senate Gallery Gets Bulletproof Shield
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18The in stallation of bulletproof clear plastic shields that will cost $80,000 began today in the State Senate's spectator gal lery.

title: Man in the News
description: State Supreme Court Jus tice Irving H. Saypol, who will preside at the trial of the parity issue that is the core of the patrolmen's dispute with the city, has been in volved both as lawyer and judge with an ample share of the cases that have stirred public interest in recent years. As United States Attorney for the South ern District, he served as the Federal prosecu tor in the 1951 sabotage conspiracy trial of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg. The same year he was elected to his first 14year term on the State Supreme Court bench.

title: 35 Killed as Bulgarian Airliner Crashes on Landing at Zurich
description: GENEVA, Jan. 18 Thirty five persons were killed today when a Bulgarian airliner crashed in heavy fog while try ing to make an instrument landing at Zurich airport. The plane hit the snowcovered ground just outside the airport, disintegrated, and caught fire.

title: Marylebone Plays Draw
description: NEWCASTLE, New South Wales, Jan. 18 (Reuters)The Marylebone Cricket Club drew its threeday match against a Northern New South Wales country cricket team today. Marylebone had 355 runs for four wickets declared and 322 for four and the Australian team, 171.

title: CRIME WAVE HITS MILANTURIN AREA
description: MILAN, Italy, Jan. 18  A wave of bank robberics, hold ups and burglaries in the Milan Turin area is causing alarm and demands for better police pro tection.

title: About Pro Basketball
description: Overlooked during the Spencer Haywood fuss last week was the vigorous stand the National Basketball Asso ciation took against any sort of merger with the American Basketball Association.

title: NINE SOVIET STARS ENTER U.S. MEETS
description: Nine track and field athletes from the Soviet Union will compete in three indoor meets in the United States next month, including the Olympic Invitation Feb. 19 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Thant Condemns Violence
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 18Asked for his reaction to the activities of the Jewish Defense League and the bomb ing of the Egyptian mission last night, U Thant, Secretary General of the United Nations, replied that such acts of vio lence strengthened the argu ments of governments that wanted to move the headquar ters of the world organization to another country.

title: Clemson Scores Upset
description: CLEMSON, S. C., Jan. 18 (UPI)Dave Thomas scored 15 points to lead Clemson to its first Atlantic Coast Conference victory, a 5950 upset of North Carolina State tonight.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Daily News Reporter Wins Award for Crime Articles
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) Donald Singleton, New York Daily News reporter who wrote a series of 20 articles on crime last year, was named recipient today of the 1970 Heywood Broun Award.

title: DELURY BIDS CITY FISH OR CUT BAIT
description: John J. DeLury, head of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's As sociation, used the occasion of a brief, but legal job action by 50 union men yesterday to hint at a serious work stoppage if a satisfactory contract with the city is not achieved by Feb. 1.

title: European Monetary Agreement Comes Under U.S. Reappraisal
description: PARIS, Jan. 18The existence of an organization that traces its origins to the Marshall Plan days when an im poverished Europe was being fed a recovery diet of dollars has been called into question because the United States now wants some of those dol lars back.

title: POWER IS CUT 5% IN STATE BY COLD
description: A statewide electric power cutback, ascribed to exceptional power demands for heating equipment in the face of bitter cold weather, was put into ef fect for three and a half hours yesterday afternoon.

title: GRISSOM'S WIDOW ASKS $10MILLION
description: TITUSVILLE, Fla., Jan. 18 (UPI)The widow of Lieut. Col. Virgil I. Grissom filed suits to day in Circuit Court seeking $10million in damages from the builders of the Apollo space craft for the death of her hus band in a launching pad fire four years ago.

title: Brydges Will Seek A Study on Casinos In Lieu of Bill Now
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18  Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges said today that he would not press for passage this year of his bill to legalize gambling casinos under strict state super vision. The Niagara Falls Republi can said in an interview that instead he would seek approval to set up a state commission to study the gambling casino proposal this year with the hope of legislative action next year.

title: U.S. Copter Carriers Operate Off Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 18The United States com mand said today that two American helicopter carriers had taken up positions off the Cambodian coast and were staging missions for the inter diction of enemy lines and the supplying of allied forces fight ing in Cambodia.

title: ATEST PILOTS' DEATH IS LAID TO LEUKEMIA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) An article in the February issue of The Atlantic Monthly says two military pilots who monitored aboveground weap ons tests by the Atomic Energy Commission in Nevada in 1953 later were stricken with leu kemia and died.

title: Women's Revolt? Harris Poll Detects Real Storm Signals
description: An elevator starter smiled at a group of people waiting for an elevator at the Hotel Pierre yesterday and said:

title: Capt. Mario Taddei, Head Of 2 Shipping Companies
description: Capt. Mario Taddei, president of two shipping companies at 19 Rector Street, died Satur day in GenoaNervi, Italy. He was 83 years old.

title: London and Belfast Agree On Action Against Rioting
description: LONDON, Jan. 18 (Reuter) The governments of Britain and Northern Island declared today their determination to end riot ing in Northern Ireland and to arrest those who foment it.

title: No Intention to Serve Third Term, Thant Says
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 18Secretary General Thant said today that he had no intention whatsoever to serve another term when his present fiveyear term expires at the end of the year.

title: Bowles Criticizes U.S. On Foreign Arms Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)Former Under Secre tary of State Chester A. Bowles sharply criticized United States sales of weap ons to foreign nations today, asserting they disrupted re gional power balances and created situations over which Washington had no control.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Much Capacity Aloft
description: Trans World Airlines recently asked the Civil Aero nautics Board for authority to work out joint agreements with other airlines to reduce excess passenger capacity. A somewhat similar proposal made last August by T.W.A., American and United ran into objections from both the C.A.B. and the Justice Department.

title: Yonkers G.I. Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) The Pentagon today identi fied 16 servicemen as having been killed in the war in South east Asia, including Pfc. Lee W. Clore of Yonkers, N. Y., of the Army.

title: Kosygin Meets in Kremlin With Peking's New Envoy
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 18 (AP)  Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin met today in the Kremlin with Ambassador Liu Hsinchuan of Communist China.

title: Vincent P. Kassenbrock Is Dead; Educator and Bay Ridge Leader
description: Vincent P. Kassenbrock, a member of the New York State Higher Education Assistance Corporation and a leader in civic affairs, died Sunday in Victory Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 65 years old and lived at 319 85th Street, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

title: Tanker Collision Dumps a Huge Oil Spill in San Francisco Bay
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 Two large tankers owned by the Standard Oil Company of California collided early this morning in a dense fog, spilling an estimated half million gal lons of oil on the choppy waters of San Francisco Bay.

title: Black Rule Begins in Alabama County
description: EUTAW, Ala., Jan. 18Amid repated calls for black and white cooperation  some speakers used the qualifier if it's pos sible  six black elected coun ty officials were installed today in a holiday atmosphere here in rural Green County.

title: League Backs Penguins
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18 (UPI)The National Hockey League said today it would continue to un derwrite its financially troubled Pittsburgh Penguin franchise for the current season and was considering several offers to purchase the club and keep it in Pittsburgh.

title: Protesters on Culebra Scuffle With Marines
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 18 About 50 young Puerto Rican independence advocates and American pacifists scuffled briefly today with a detach ment of 14 marines on the island of Culebra. No injuries were reported.

title: F.D.A. Says Tests Found 14% of Drugs Ineffective
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) More than 14 per cent of some 16,000 drugs tested for the Food and Drug Administra tion were found to be ineffec tive, the agency's commis sioner said today.

title: Selassie Charges Outsiders Back Rebels in Eritrea
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 18  Emperor Haile Selassie charged today that outside na tions and groups are attempt ing to dismember his empire by backing rebel guerrillas in the northern province of Eritrea.

title: Faulty Fueling Delays Practice Apollo LiftOff
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 18 (Reuters)The Apollo 14 rocket went through a make believe launching tonight in the beginning of a major countdown test that ran into some technical difficulties.

title: COURT EXAMINES JUDGE'S CONDUCT
description: The Appellate Division of the state Supreme Court said yes terday that it was investigat ing a charge of misconduct brought against Queens Civil Court Judge Kenneth N. Browne.

title: FRANK S. MAYER
description: Frank S. Mayer, a former member of the technical staff of Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N J., died Saturday in Long Island Doctors Hospital, Roslyn Heights. He was 74 years old and lived at 3620 Bowne Street, Flushing, Queens.

title: Advertising:
description: Schenley Industries is moving five brands billing about $2.5million out of N. W. Ayer and spreading them through its three other agencies.

title: 3 City Banks and Reserve Trim Rates
description: The broad downward sweep in interest rates gained added momentum yesterday with re ductions in the two key rates administered by banking offi cials:

title: OLIN'S '70 INCOME DECLINED SHARPLY
description: The Olin Corporation, a di versified industrial company, suffered sharp reverses last year and is taking extraordi nary charges of $26million aft er taxes for 1970, which in cludes $10million announced last July for the closing of its sodaash operations in Saltville, Va.

title: POLICE DEFY APPEALS TO RETURN; JUDGE SETS PARITY TRIAL TODAY;
description: Spurning renewed appeals for an end to their wildcat strike, defiant New York City patrolmen continued to refuse patrol duty yesterday, drawing support in increasing numbers from other municipal patrol men assigned to transit, hous ing and welfare.

title: Bonnanno's Son Surrenders
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (UPI)  Salvatore Bonanno, son of Joseph (Joe Bananas) ?? the reputed crime syndicate leader, surrendered to United States marshals here today to begin serving a fouryear prison sentence for mail fraud. Bo nanno was convicted in New York on charges connected with the illicit use of a Diners Club credit card.

title: DR. ALTON B. DALEY
description: ATHENS, N. Y., Jan. 18Dr. Alton B. Daley, a physician here for 53 years until his re tirement in 1966, died last night in Greene County Memo rial Hospital, Catskill. He was 84 years old.

title: CRITICS GIVE PRIZE TO FIVE EASY PIECES
description: Awards to the winners of the 36th annual poll of the New York Film Critics for out standing movie achievement last year were presented on Sunday at a reception at ?? Restaurant on West ?? Street.

title: Text of Announcement by McGovern on 1972 Race
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (A P)Following is the text of Senator George S. McGovern's Presidential announce ment as prepared for delivery over television in South Dakota and as released here today:

title: MISS EDINGER PLAYS BLACHER CONCERTO
description: A restless, pressing, driving Violin Concerto in D minor by Boris Blacher was given a hear ing at the Musica Aeterna con cert Sunday night at Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum.

title: G.N.P. Down for First Year Since'58;
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The nation's total output of goods and services declined, as expected, in both the fourth quarter of last year and for the year 1970 as a whole, the Government reported today. But construction of new houses surged upward in December to its highest level in 20 years.

title: LEWIS S. MUNSON JR., DELAWARE BANKER
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 18 Lewis S. Munson Jr., chair man of the board of the Wil mington Trust Company, died today after a brief illness. He was 64 years old.

title: FORUM TRIUMPHS IN HIALEAH DASH
description: MIAMI, Jan. 18 (UPI) Forum made his Florida win ter debut a winning one at Hialeah today with a victory in an $8,000 allowance feature at seven furlongs.

title: Who Cares? Offers Major Cast Shift At the City Ballet
description: Who Cares?, George Bal anchine's busy, buzzy and witty ballet set to the tinkle of Gershwin show tunes, was the recipient rather than the beneficiary of a major cast change Sunday evening at State Theater.

title: News Analysis
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18Almost exactly three years ago Gov ernor Rockefeller refused May or Lindsay's request for Na tional Guard intervention in the New York City sanitation strike.

title: PATRICK DWYER, 89. BUILDER IN BRONX
description: Patrick J. Dwyer, of 5400 Fieldston Road, Riverdale, the Bronx, a retired builder, died Saturday night in Memorial Hospital, Hollywood, Fla., after a short illness. He was 89 years old.

title: DUQUESNE UPSETS IRISH IN OVERTIME
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 18 (AP) Mickey Davis put in 5 points in overtime and Gary Nelson 4 tonight as unranked Duquesne upset ninthranked Notre Dame, 8178, in college basketball.

title: Laotians Report Attacks
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 18 (UPI)North Vietnamese forces overran three Laotian Govern ment defensive positions in the Boloven plateau over the week end a Defense Ministry spokes man said today.

title: Market Place: Woes continue For Conductron
description: Shed a tear for the poor shareholder in Conductron who has had nothing but bad news of late.

title: Wheat Parley Names Head
description: GENEVA, Jan. 18Ronald Moore, formerly executive sec retary of the International Wheat Council, was elected chairman of a United Nations wheat conference at its open ing session today. The confer ence was called at the request of the International Wheat Council to renegotiate the In ternational Grains Arrangement of 1967, which will expire on June 30. About 40 countries are now represented, ?? an other 30 or 35 are expected to send representatives before the conference completes its work in midFebruary.

title: U.S., RUSSIA DISCUSS JOINT SPACE EFFORT
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 18 (Reuters) American and Soviet space scientists opened discussions to day on possible areas of co operation, with weather ob servation and space medicine high on the agenda.

title: Downtown Scene: A Display of Bones
description: Ever since Marcel Du champ had the courageous effrontery to take a urinal, bicycle wheel and a bird cage into a museum and proclaim them works of art, some art ists have been arrogating to themselves the right to pro claim this, that and every thing as art. They feel that many of us harbor very lim ited conceits as to what con stitutes a work of art and that those conceits should be radically amplified. It is their idea that ounce we accept their proclamations  and their art  we shall be more acutely sensitized to more artistic experiences and our lives, subsequently, will be much more complete. His tory, however, has taught us, despite proclamations and humanitarianism, that artis tic experiences are few.

title: Books of The Times
description: LOUIS XI. The Universal Spider. BY Paul Murray Kendall. Illustrated. 464 pages. W. W. Norton & Co. $10.

title: Elliott and Miss Rockwell Win National Skiing Titles
description: DURANGO, Colo., Jan. 18 (AP)Mike Elliott of Durango, Colo., captured the men's 15 kilometer crosscountry and Martha Rockwell of Putney, Vt., took the women's 10kil ometer event today in the United States Ski Association national championships.

title: 2 Rookies: First Time On the Beat
description: Four days ago Frank Jones and Paul Casiero were attend ing classes with the city's other probationary patrolmen, learn ing how to make arrests, take fingerprints and handle basic police procedures.

title: Advertising:
description: The Peace Corps' desire to recruit more skilled workers will be reflected in the first campaign by its new ad agency, Geer, duBois.

title: Trouble in Paradise
description: Manuel Luis Quezon, the Filipino nationalist, once remarked: I prefer a government run like hell by Filipinos to a government run like heaven by Americans.

title: SAMMARTINO LOSES BEFORE 21,106 FANS
description: A record crowd of 21,106 saw Bruno Sammartino lose his WorldWide Wrestling Feder ation heavyweight title at Madison Square Garden last night. Ivan Koloff, 298 pounds of the Soviet Union pinned the 34yearold Italian strong boy in 14 minutes 55 seconds of the exhibition.

title: 93 Year Old Wimbledon Adopts 12 Point Tiebreaker in First Scoring Change
description: WIMBLEDON, Englad, Jan. 18 (AP)The AllEngland Ten nis Club announced today that a tiebreaker would be used in this year's Wimbledon tennis championships. It is the first change in scoring since the tournament began in 1877.

title: Chad Rebels Sign Peace
description: FORT ARCHAMBAULT, Chad, Jan. 18  President Francois Tombalbaye signed a peace agreement today with several leaders of a sixyearold rebel lion.

title: Suit Filed Over Leafleting
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18 (UPI)A suit accusing Cambridge offi cials and the police of violat ing constitutional rights by in terfering with the distribution of leftwing literature in Har vard Square was filed today in United States District Court. The Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts filed the suit in behalf of four members of the Socialist Workers party of Massachusetts.

title: Rebels in Oman Report Attacks on Sheikdom
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 18 (AP)Rebel action in the Sultanate of Oman, on the eastern tip of the Persian Gulf, has spread to the near by sheikdom of Ras al Khaima, threatening Western oil installations, a rebel state ment said today.

title: Chrysler and Union Bargaining To Avert Strike Set for Today
description: DETROIT, Jan. 18  The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers bargained intensively today un der a strike deadline of 10 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Problems Seen for TaxExempt Bonds
description: The taxexempt bond market will not be able to provide all the money states and cities want to borrow during the nineteenseventies, a high of ficial of the Federal Reserve System warned yesterday.

title: Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: DORIT K. WEIGERT
description: Dorit K. Weigert, who taught many of the leading debutantes of a generation ago the art of gourmet cooking, died yester day in the Sanger Nursing Home, 500 West 57th Street, after a long illness. She was 86 years old.

title: Produce Handlers Arrive At a Tentative Agreement
description: Negotiators for both sides in the produce handlers' strike reached a tentative agreement early this morning that will be presented to striking union members later today.

title: Bridges Reported Blown
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 18 (UPI)A spokesman in Damas cus for Eritrean liberation forces said three bridges and several cars were recently blown up between Asmara and Ethiopia's border with the Sudan.

title: Ashe vs. Laver: Relaxing Is the Key
description: I'm fairly eager, said Arthur Ashe, if that counts for any thing. I'm mentally rested. Be tween now and Thursday, I'll go easy on the pie and cake. We'll see what happens.

title: TATE JURY DENIED DEATHSITE VISIT
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. I8The TateLa Bianca jury interrupted its deliberations today with a surprising request for permis sion to make an afterdark visit to the sites of the murders for which Charles M. Manson and his women codefendants are being tried.

title: Podgorny, on Egyptian TV, Pledges Continued Support
description: CAIRO, Jan. 18 (Reuters) President Nikolai V. Podgorny today asserted full Soviet sup port to Egypt for a just politi cal solution to the Middle East crisis.

title: VIOLA, CONTRALTO EXCEL IN CONCERT
description: Walter Trampler's sweet toned viola and Maureen For rester's burnished contralto dominated the thoroughly be guiling musical textures con jured up in Tully Hall late Sunday afternoon by Lincoln Center's Chamber Music So ciety.

title: Bill Rates Register Sharp Drop At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Treasury bill rates declined sharply again at today's auc tion from last week's results to their lowest levels since the summer of 1967, the Govern ment reported today.

title: College Sports Notes
description: Manhattan's basketball team made a trip to Florida last week that was anything but a vacation. The Jaspers tried a slowdown, led at halftime but lost to Florida State. Two days later things got sticky when Coach Jack Powers had his team try the same tactics at JacksonVille. The Jas pers were lucky to get out of that town without se rious incident. Powers said,  We had no chance against either team unless we did that, particularly against Jackson ville with Artis Gilmore. Gilmore is the 7foot2inch star of the Jacksonville team.

title: Justices to Weigh a Dismissal For Refusal to Work on Sunday
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether companies vio late the civil rights law's pro hibition against religious dis crimination when they dis charge workers who refuse on religious grounds to work on Sundays.

title: Enjoy Cuts Price Of Polypropylene
description: The Enjay Chemical Com pany, a unit of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), an Inounced yesterday that it had reduced the price of two of its flameretardant grades of polypropylene by 6 cents a pound. The company said that the cut reflected the lower cost of antimony oxide.

title: Penn Central Seeks June 1 As Creditor Claim Deadline
description: Trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company yes terday asked the Federal Dis trict Court in Philadelphia to approve a June 1 deadline for creditors to file claims against the railroad.

title: U.S. Aide Meets Shah
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 18 (AP) John N. Irwin 2d, met with the Shah of Iran today on the first working day of the American's mission as President Nixon's special envoy to seek a solu tion to a price crisis between oilproducing nations and Western companies.

title: TURBOTRAIN SLATED FOR IMPROVEMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Department of Transportation signed a $3.8million contract with the United Aircraft Corpo ration today to continue and improve the Turbotrain service between Boston and New York for another two years.

title: No Crime Rise Reported, But Side Effects Are Noted
description: The city's District Attorneys, its Medical Examiner, private detectives, department stores and police statistics all indicated yesterday that the pattern of crime in New York City had not yet been signifi cantly influenced by the police strike.

title: Marshal's Memoirs Praise Khrushchev
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 18  Nikita S. Khrushchev, who has gone unpraised in the Soviet Union since his fall from power six years ago, is described as a hardworking and sensitive wartime leader by an old as sociate, Marshal Ivan K. Bagramyan, in a book of memoirs just published.

title: Greek Bank Gets Loan
description: ATHENS, Jan. 18 (Reuters) A consortium of eight Euro pean banks and the Bank of America has agreed to grant $5million loan to the Greek Investment Bank.

title: MILWAUKEE PUTS MARQUETTE NO. 1
description: Frank Mulzoff and Digger Phelps found out last week in Milwaukee that winning can do wonders for college basketball interest and attendance even when there is an outstanding pro team in the same city.

title: Most Airlines Lag on Abating Smoke
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Most of the nation's airlines are slightly behind schedule in in stalling new combustors for eliminating smoke emissions from the engines of Boeing 727's and 737's and McDonnell Doug las DC9's.

title: Chicago Pupils Return
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP)Chi cago's 577,000 elementary and high school pupils returned to classes today, but the 39,000 students enrolled at seven city colleges were out again because of their teachers' strike. Mem bers of the Chicago Teachers Union reported to work after accepting a new contract. The Cook County College Teachers Union voted to resume its strike.

title: CASEY A POSSIBILITY TO SUCCEED BUDGE
description: The name of William J. Casey has been placed on the roster of possible choices to succeed Hamer H. Budge as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Budge resigned Dec. 31.

title: VIOLATIONS ARE LAID TO BROKER IN TULSA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today ad ministrative proceedings against the First General Corporation based on staff accusations of violations of the registration and antifraud provisions of Federal law.

title: U.S. Britain and France Seek Backing for Firm Line in Oil Talks
description: PARIS, Jan. 18The United States, Britain, France and the Netherlands are seeking to widen the diplomatic support for their oil companies as the companies negotiate new price agreements with Arab and other producing states.

title: STOCKS REGISTER ANOTHER ADVANCE
description: Wall Street's new hull mar ket refused once again yester day to he penned up.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Jan. 12.

title: Michigan U. Workers Strike
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Tuesday, Jan. 19 (AP)About 2,700 Uni versity of Michigan service and maintenance employes walked off their jobs at 12:01 this morning when contract talks, with university officials failed to produce a wage increase agreement.

title: B'nai B'rith Award Goes To Schwartz on Saturday
description: Richard J. Schwartz has been named man of the year by Sports Lodge of B'nai B'rith and will receive its gold medal at the annual Bill Corum awards dinner, Satur day at the Roosevelt Hotel.

title: Arabs Denounce Hijacking
description: CAIRO, Jan. 18 (AP)The Arab Civil Aviation Council has denounced airplane hijacking and has classified it as an ille gal perpetration.

title: EGYPT'S RESPONSE IS GIVEN TO ISRAEL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 18Indirect ArabIsraeli peace talks continued today as Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations intermediary, transmitted to Israel an Egyp tian response to suggestions made by Israel 10 days ago.

title: P.H.S. Hospital Review
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) Special teams wil be sent by the Nixon Administration to visit and recommend whether to close eight Public Health Service hospitals, Congres sional sources said today. The hospitals are in Boston, Balti more, New Orleans, Seattle, San Francisco, Staten Island, N.Y. Galveston Tex., and Norfolk, Va.

title: MAJ. GOSS L. STRYKER
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 18 (AP) Maj. Goss L. Stryker, who served 36 years as secretary treasurer of the Maryland Horse Breeders Association, died yes terday morning in his sleep. He was 93 years old.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: WALKER'S CAY, The Ba hamasHaving completed our duties in a project to capture barracuda and ship them back alive to the New York Aquarium, Dr. Jay Hy man, a Manhattan veterinar ian, and I went bonefishing on the flats of nearby Grand Cay.

title: FONG'S AIDE SAYS HE IS NOT GUILTY
description: Robert T. Carson, the admin istrative assistant to Senator Hiram L. Fong, Republican of Hawaii, pleaded not guilty in Federal Court here yesterday to charges that. he had con spired to fix a stockfraud case involving reputed leaders of organized crime. The tall, slender, 64yearold senatorial aide, his face etched in a frown and his eyes shielded by tinted glasses, appeared be fore Judge Constance Baker Motley, who permitted his re lease on $15,000 bail.

title: HAWKS TURN BACK BRAVES BY 123113
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 18 (UPI) Pete Maravich scored 41 points, his highest total as a pro, to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 123113 victory tonight over the Buffalo Braves.

title: Public Interest Hurt By Strike, Thant Says
description: The wildcat strike by the city's patrolmen was de scribed yesterday as being against the public interest by U Thant, Secretary Gen eral of the United Nations.

title: State Will Pay Legal Fees To Defend Mrs. Crimmins
description: Mrs. Alice Crimmins, who faces trial Feb. 22 in the deaths of her two children in 1965, was granted permission in Queens Supreme Court yesterday to hire defense experts at public expense because she is finan cially destitute.

title: Sports of The ??
description: MIAMI, Jan, 18Maybe the experts are too expert. Most of them were so appalled by the bushleague performances displayed by both teams in the Super Bowl yesterday that they were inclined to regard this unfunny comedy of errors as not only a smear on football but as an inadvertent boost for baseball.

title: POLICE IN CAROLINA STUDY KIDNAPPINGS
description: BENNETTSVILLE, S. C., Jan. 18 (UPI)The police sought to tie up some loose ends today in an apparent plot by two black men to kidnap all the rich people in this little to bacco town and hold them for ransom.

title: Delay in Refunds Seen On Some Tax Returns
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service said today that some early returns from taxpayers did not carry the taxpayers' mail ing label addresses and that this might delay refunds.

title: New York's Finest
description: The sobriquet New York's finest has become a bitter irony when applied to the patrolmen of this city who have gone on strike in contemptuous disregard of their fellow citizens, of their own leaders and of the law they are sworn to uphold. Neither the Mayor nor the people of New York can afford to temporize much longer with the anarchic job action that is threatening to destroy whatever public confidence still remains in the city's police force.

title: Mrs. John D. Chequer Dies; A Retired Church Organist
description: Mrs. Ethel Cleo Stevens Cheq uer, a retired piano teacher and former organist and choir di rector at several churches in Westchester and New York City, died yesterday at the House of the Holy Comforter, 2751 Grand ?? the Bronx, after a long illness. Her age was 75.

title: Detectives on Job
description: Police detectives have con tinued to work during the pa trolmen's strike because they are supervisory officers of higher rank than patrolmen. Plainclothes men have not worked, because they are pa trolmen.

title: Met Appeals for Return ?? Schicchi Set
description: Will the thieves who stole the truck containing the Metropolitan Opera Studio's sets and costumes for Puc cini's Gianni Schicchi please call the company? The Studio, a wing of the Met, would be happy to buy the production back.

title: G.I. IN GERMANY LIED AT TRIAL, ARMY SAYS
description: BONN, Jan. 18The United States Army has preferred charges of perjury against the key prosecution witness in a controversial case involving ra cial violence at a training ground, it was disclosed today.

title: Pennsylvania U. Raises Fee
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 (AP) The University of Pennsyl vania has raised its tuition for the fourth consecutive year. The latest increase, announced today, sets yearly tuition and fees at $2,750, an increase of $200 over the rates for the 197071 academic year.

title: PRIME RATE CUT HELPS AMEX LIST
description: A further reduction in the prime rate helped send most prices higher on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in brisk trading.

title: BETHLEHEM CUTS STEEL PRICE RISE TO 6.8 PER CENT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The Bethlehem Steel Corpora tion today cut nearly in half a price increase announced last week on structural steel. The Government, meanwhile, turned up the heat on huge wage in creases in the construction in dustry.

title: 1973 Cars to Have ShockAbsorbing Front Bumper
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 Car makers will put shockab sorbing front bumpers on their 1973 models.

title: Couturiers Bring Back 40's Look
description: ROME, Jan. 18The milk maids and the peasants and the dance hall hostesses of last season have all faded into fashion limbo. The languid elegance of the early nineteenthirties has been traded in, too.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Russel Wins Giant Slalom, but Loses Cup Lead to Thoeni
description: ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 18 (Reuters)  Patrick Russel of France swept to vic tory in a giant slalom race to day, but lost his lead in the World Cup standing to Gustavo Thoeni of Italy.

title: HOFSTADTER ROOM SET FOR COLUMBIA
description: A new history reading room dedicated to the memory of Richard Hofstadter and con taining 5,000 volumes of his personal library will be set up at Columbia University, where the late historian of American affairs taught for 24 years.

title: African Suspects Saigon Plan In the Sending of Wrong Girl
description: BANGUI, Central African Re public, Jan. 18 (Reuters)In terior Minister Louis Kpado said last night that French agents and the South Vietnamese po lice in Saigon invited a 20 yearold Vietnamese girl to change her name to that of the longlost daughter of President Jean Bedel Bokassa of the Cen tral African Republic.

title: Mellons Set Up a Family Concern
description: The family of the late Richard King Mellon an nounced yesterday the for mation of an investment management firm to repre sent its interests in business, philanthropic and civic ac tivities.

title: Kansas Easy Victor
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Jan. 18 (AP)Fifthranked Kansas, en joying a height advantage, opened its Big Eight Conference season with an 8357 romp over Iowa State tonight.

title: An End to Violence?
description: This communication does not ac company a bombing or a specific ac tion. We want to express ourselves to the mass movement not as military leaders but as tribes at council. It has been nine months since the townhouse explosion. In that time, the future of our revolution has been changed deci sively. A growing illegal organization of young women and men can live and fight and love inside Babylon. The F.B.I. can't catch us; we've pierced their bulletproof shield. But the town house forever destroyed our belief that armed struggle is the only real revo lutionary struggle. It is time for the movement to go out into the air, to organize, to risk calling rallies and demonstrations, to convince that mass actions against the war and in support of rebellions do make a difference. Only acting openly, denouncing Nixon, Agnew and Mitch ell, and sharing our numbers and wis dom together with young sisters and brothers will blow away the fear of the students at Kent State, the smack of the Lower East Side and the na tional silence after the bombings of North Vietnam.

title: Text of 14 Purported Israeli Suggestions for Settlement in Mideast
description: PARIS, Tuesday, Jan. 19  Following, as published in French and English by the news magazine Jeune Afrique, is a peace proopsal that the magazine says Israel presented to the United Na tions mediator, Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, after his visit to Israel on Jan. 8:

title: Catherine Calvert Dead at 80; Was in  Alias Jimmy Valentine
description: Catherine Calvert, a noted actress of the early part of the century, died last evening in the Patterson Home for Nassau County Aged and Infirm in Uniondale, L. I. She was 80 years old.

title: Greenwich Woman Named To Sarah Lawrence Post
description: Mrs. Frank Y. Larkin of Greenwich, Conn., has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of Sarah Lawrence College.

title: Shrinking School Subsidy
description: To the nation's schools, President Nixon's new Feder alism is a tantalizing mirage. The promise of a brighter future comes at a time when the Federal subsidy to public education has actually been shrinking. From its highest point of 8 per cent of the total expenditure 1967, it is expected to decline to just below 7 per cent in the current fiscal year. The National Education Association, in disclosing these estimates, suggests that a fair sharing of school costs would call for equal contributions by local com munities, the states and the Federal Government. Since this would mean a raising of Washington's share from just below $3 billion to about $14 billion, so dramatic a change is clearly wishful thinking given the Adminis tration's present state of mind and purse. But it is also evident that neither the localities nor the states are currently in any position to fight more than a holding action against the deterioration of the public schools.

title: Suns Down Royals
description: OMAHA, Neb. Jan 18 (UPI) The Phoenix Suns with Paul Silas setting a team rebound record, defeated the Cincinnati Royals, 11899, tonight.

title: Rangers and Bruins Become Allies in Boston Tonight for 24th AllStar Game
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18For those who find amusing the prospect of Phil Esposito passing to Dave Balon, or want to see if Bobby Orr will hug Brad Park after a goal, the National Hockey League's 24th AllStar game tomorrow night may prove to be one of the most unusual.

title: 100 Seeking  Decent Education Invade Forest Hills Junior High
description: About 100 pupils from Inter mediate School 142, accompa ?? by 25 adults, invaded ?? High School 190 and stayed ?? several hours yesterday morning because they said they could not get a decent edu cation at their own school. Both institutions are in Queens in Community School District 28.

title: U.S. Federal Unit Issues Guidance on Defectors
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) The National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administra tion has directed its ship cap tains to give asylum to foreign defectors, but not to resist any attempt by force of arms to take them back.

title: RESERVE UNIT VOTED FOR EASING CREDIT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (Reu ters)  The Federal Open Mar ket Committee voted in October to promote some easing of con ditions in credit markets and moderate growth in money and attendant bankcredit expan sion for the months ahead.

title: Graduates' Job Prospects Held Better Than Expected
description: A College Placement Council study of almost 1,000 major employers, including the United States Government, indicates that employment prospects for 1971 college graduates are bet ter than rumored.

title: Britain Prepares to Meet Postal Strike
description: LONDON, Jan. 18  The Government cleared the way for the use of private mail services here today as the deadline for a national postal strike approached.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau Police Agree to Terms; 2Year Pact Put at $13.8Million
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Tuesday, Jan. 19Nassau County Exe cutive Ralph G. Caso an nounced early this morning that the county and the Pat rolmen's Benevolent Associa tion had agreed on terms for a new twoyear contract that will cost $13.8million.

title: FALTERING KNICKS GET EXTRA DRILLS
description: The Knicks, who carry a dis turbing fourgame losing streak into their contest tonight against the San Diego Rockets at Madison Square Garden, are in for a spell of hard work.

title: Bridge: Eight Straight Victories Give Roth's Group Swiss Team Title
description: The TriState Regional Championships at Grossinger, N.Y., ended Sunday in a Swiss Team victory for a foursome headed by Alvin Roth of New York. His team, including Alan Sontag of New York, Bernard Chazen of Fort Lee, N.J., and Bar bara Rappaport of East Or ange, N. J., scored eight straight victories in a field of 164 teams.

title: Spartan Missiles Intercept Two Targets in Test Shot
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) Two Spartan missiles, fired seconds apart from their mid Pacific launching site, have suc cessfully intercepted highalti tude targets in tests involving key elements of the Safeguard antimissile system, the Penta gon announced today.

title: Disruptive TV Commercials In Game Anger McGuire
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 18 (AP) Coach Al McGuire, whose Mar quette University Warriors are the nation's secondranked team, has complained that the timeconsuming breaks for tele vision commercials are becom ing too disruptive to basketball.

title: Senate Reform Hearing Gets Plea to Modify Seniority Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Appeals for Congressional re form echoed off the marble walls of the Senate Caucus Room today as Senators and private citizens said that Congress faced a crisis of public confidence.

title: Mrs. King 61, 62 Victor Over Miss Casals in Final
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 18 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King crushed Rosemary Casals of San Francisco, 61, 62, in the final of the $14,000 women's professional tennis tournament named for her in her home town last night.

title: Colonels Conquer Squires As Issel Stars, 124114
description: HAMPTON, Va., Jan. 18 (UPI)The Kentucky Colonels, ?? by Dan Issel's 33 points, cut Virginia's lead in the East Division of the American Basketball Association to 5 games tonight with a 124114 victory over the Squires. The victors hold second place.

title: Soybean Contracts Show a Decline; Wheat Also Down
description: Liquidation was the rule yes terday on the Chicago Board of Trade as prices in all the ma jor commodities futures traded there tumbled.

title: Wallace, at Inauguration, Hints a New Race in 1972
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 18 George C. Wallace took the oath of office today as Gover nor of Alabama for the second time and broadly hinted that he would run for President again next year.

title: COMPUTER TESTING OF DOCTORS STUDIED
description: Two foundations announced yesterday a threeyear experi ment at five medical schools to see if a computer can be used both to teach and to test medical students.

title: Adviser Runs a Growing Committee Complex
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Dr. K., as the White House staff sometimes call Henry A. Kissinger, runs a complex and growing system of com mittees to manage United States foreign policy.

title: Hearing Starts on Smith Plea in Jersey Slaying
description: NEWARK, Jan. 18Testi mony began here today in a hearing to determine whether the confession of Edgar H. Smith, who has been on Death Row longer than anybody in American penal history, was obtained by constitutional means.

title: New Hampshire Move ??
description: CONCORD, N. H., Jan. ?? (AP)New Hampshire support ers of Senator McGovern said today they would enter him in the state's Presidential prefer ence primary.

title: ELAINE MAY SUING TO HALT NEW FILM
description: Elaine May has filed suit in Supreme Court here to enjoin Paramount Pictures from re leasing A New Leaf, a fea ture film comedy she directed from her own script and in which she costars with Walter Matthau. The film is sched uled to have its local premiere at the Radio City Music Hall this spring.

title: Villanova Wins No. 14
description: OLEAN, N. Y., Jan. 18 (UPI) Howard Porter led Villanova to an 8067 victory over St. Bonaventure tonight.

title: Merger News
description: Shareholders of the White Motor Corporation and White Consolidated Industries, Inc., yesterday approved the merger of White Motor into White Con solidated. They voted at sepa rate meetings.

title: The City's Mood in Police Strike Is Veneer of Hard Nonchalance Over Deep Disquiet
description: The door to the West End Florist was pocked with BB pellets, fired in the days when the police weren't on strike. The door was also un locked, and inside, at a table in the rear, Gus Poulos was putting daisies in a vase.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Some people are not opposed to wiretapping because they believe only criminals and subversives will be tapped, and anyway they think they have nothing to hide.

title: Assembly Approves Bill Extending Life of City's Interim School Board a Year
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18A bill ex tending the life of New York City's appointed Board of Edu cation for another year received final legislative passage today with the unanimous approval of the Assembly.

title: A PartTime Rabbi Held in Theft, Sale And 2d Theft of Car
description: A parttime rabbi was ac cused yesterday of stealing a rented automobile, selling to a friend and then restealing it for further sale.

title: Luddy Announces He Will Quit Democratic Post in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 18 William F. Luddy, chairman of the Westchester County Demo cratic Committee for more than 14 years, announced today that he would resign Feb. 2.

title: Deltec Forecasting Profit for All Units But Meat Exporting
description: Clarence Dauphinot, presi dent of Deltec International, Ltd., told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that operations in the first fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31 were expected to show some profit, excepting the company's Ar gentine meatexport subsidiary, which was shut down in Sep temper.

title: Quebec Acts on Languages
description: QUEBEC, Jan. 18 (AP)The Quebec provincial government has made it compulsory for Englishlanguage schools to teach French as a second lan guage. Englishspeaking Que beckers have voiced no disap proval of the regulations, Guy SaintPierre, the Education Min ister, said at a news conference.

title: U.S. PLANS TO USE ALL AIR WEAPONS IN CAMBODIAN WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Defense Department said today that the United States intended to employ the full range of its air combat power throughout Cambodia against enemy troops and supplies that ultimately might threaten American mili tary men in South Vietnam.

title: Judy Carne, at Club, Sings It to Them
description: A reputation based on an ability to take a bucket of water in the face poses prob lems for a performer who wishes to capitalize on this fame. When Judy Carne moved out of her sockit tome role on television's LaughIn to play the lead in the Broadway revival of The Boy Friend last season, there was no question about what she would do because the role was already estab lished (she had played it sev eral years ago when she re placed Julie Andrews in the London company).

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market closed lower yesterday, with an impending postal strike the main cause of the decline.

title: 3 Freed in Reduced Bail In Kidnapping Plot Case
description: HARRISBURG, Pa. Jan. 18 (AP)Three men, two of them priests, were freed in bail to day in the custody of a Roman Catholic Cardinal, in connec tion with last week's charges of a plot to kidnap Henry A. Kissenger, the Presidential as sistant.

title: CHRYSLER UNIT SIGNS CONTRACT WITH PERU
description: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 18 (AP) Chrysler del Peru, the Peruvian subsidiary of the United States auto maker, has signed a con tract with the military Gov ernment calling for production of two types of cars and three types of trucks.

title: GEORGE M. ROSENFELD
description: George Maurice Rosenfeld, vice president of the Baldwin Paper Company of New York, died yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 65 years old and lived at 201 East 77th Street.

title: McGovern Enters '72 Race, Pledging Troop Withdrawal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Senator George S. McGovern of South Dakota opened his Presidential campaign today, 22 months before Election Day, 1972, with a pledge to with draw every American soldier from Southeast Asia if he reaches the White House.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The award for the angriest letter to an editor in the month of January goes to Wilt Collar of Spectral Caves, Mo., for the following:

title: Aid to LowCost Housing Seen Rising by Romney
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 18The Fed eral Government will subsidize as much as 15 per cent more lowcost housing this year than last, George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urhan Develop ment, said here today. In 1970, the program financed 470,000 units.

title: Actress to Be Honored
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon will present a certificate tomorrow ?? Mercedes McCambridge, re formed alcoholic and actress for her volunteer work for the National Council on Alcohol ism, the White House said to day.

title: Highway Safety Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)  President Nixon ap pointed Douglas W. Toms to day as administrator of the Na tional Highway Traffic Safety Administration. He had been serving as director of the Na tional Highway Safety Bureau, a position that has been abolished.

title: A RENEWED DRAFT OF DOCTORS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)  The Defense Department's health chief has recommended a renewed doctor draft this year because too few medical school graduates have volun teered for military service, the Pentagon said today.

title: General Analytics Acts
description: Directors of General Analy tics Corporation, a computer software developer, announced last night they had authorized Leonard N. Hecht, president, to take such action as he deems advisable under state or Federal bankruptcy or insolvency stat utes or regulations. The move followed a report by Mr. Hecht that the company's liabilities far exceed its assets, the board said.

title: Two Federal Judges Retire
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) Pesident Nixon announced today the retirements of two United States Appeals Court judges, Leonard Page Moore, of the Second Circuit, in New York, and William H. Hastie of the Third Circuit, in Phila delphia.

title: JACOB CANGRO
description: Jacob Cangro, who had been a mailer in the mailroom of The New York Times for more than 40 years when he retired on Aug. 1, 1959, died Friday. He was 80 years old and lived with a daughter, Mrs. Virginia De Luca, at 3821 Crescent Street, Astoria, Queens.

title: Washington Notes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Amid earnest efforts by the White House to establish a conciliatory image for Presi dent Nixon, there is an equal ly fervent attempt to draw the line on how far this may go.

title: KLEPPE TO HEAD FEDERAL AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 President Nixon announced to day a recess appointment of Thomas S. Kleppe, the un successful Republican nominee for the United States Senate last year in North Dakota, to head the Small Business Admin istration.

title: A Retired Army General Denies Arms Theft Charge
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 18 (AP)Maj. Gen. Carl C. Turner, a retired high law enforcement officer of the Army, pleaded not guilty today to charges of hav ing unlawfully obtained more than 423 firearms from the Chicago Police Department and for evading $16,679 in Federal income taxes.

title: About Pro Football
description: MIAMI, Jan. 18Pro foot ball's Super Bowl promotion has become so big, so suc cessful that it has developed problems on three levels: tension, tickets and televi sion.

title: Ecuador Arms Aid Suspended by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The United States announced today that it was suspending all military sales, credits and guarantees to Ecuador fol lowing the seizure of United States tuna boats off the Ecuadorian coast.

title: PHONE REPAIRERS CONTINUE STRIKE
description: The strike of more than 48, 000 telephone repairmen and installers in most of the state entered its second week yes terday with little sign of a resolution of the conflict.

title: Warsaw to Hear Grievances of Workers' Group
description: GDANSK, Poland, Jan. 18  A strike at Gdansk's Lenin ship yards, where the December riots began, was called off after four hours today when the Gov ernment in Warsaw agreed to receive a combined manage mentworker delegation.

title: League Officials Quit
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18Marvin S. Antelman of Newton, Mass., New England coordinator of the Jewish Defense League, said today that he and seven chap ter chairman had resigned from the league because of the ir responsible actions of the na tional organization.

title: 8 in J.D.L. Indicted For Protests in City
description: Eight officials and members of the militant Jewish Defense League were indicted yesterday on a variety of charges, in cluding assault, inciting to riot, rioting, criminal mischief and burglary.

title: CORE GETS BOUT ON CLOSED CIRCUIT
description: The Congress of Racial Equality reached agreement yesterday with promoters of the Muhammad AliJoe Frazier fight to show the match on closed circuit television in black communities throughout the country.

title: Shure's Air of Sincerity Is Appealing at Piano Recital
description: Leonard Shure's consider able appeal as a piano re citalist does not depend on his technical aplomb, which now and then deserted him in his program at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night. If, in fact, recital success depended on easy command of the keys, beauty of tone or variety of color, the veteran artist, now on the faculty of the University of Texas, would have fared poorly.

title: Copters Support Troops
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 18 (AP)  American helicopter gunships flew at least three air strikes today in support of Cambodian troops trying to re open this key overland supply route to the sea.

title: 13 Black Panthers Arrested In Memphis Housing Dispute
description: MEMPHIS, Jan. 18 (AP) Thirteen Black Panthers were arrested early today after they barricaded themselves in a pub lic housing project ringed by policemen.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Five Cowles Subsidiaries Fined For Fraud in Magazine Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Five subsidiaries of Cowles Communications, Inc., were fined $10,000 each today after they pleaded no contest to crim inal charges of using fraudulent and deceptive practices in the sale of magazine subscriptions. and book club memberships.

title: Church Group Appeals to Heath
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 18The Central Commit tee of the World Council of Churches sent today what it described as an urgent appeal to Prime Minister Heath to abandon plans to resume the sale of arms to South Africa.

title: MRS. WILLIAM A. HANWAY
description: Mrs. Caroline S. Hanway, the wife of William A. Hanway, re tired secretary of the Interna tional Paper Company, died yes terday at Doctors Hospital after a long illness. She was 86 years old and lived at 340 East 72d Street.

title: UGANDAN WARNS HEATH ON SOVIET
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 18  If Prime Minister Heath decides to sell arms to South Africa, said President Milton Obote of Uganda today, he will have given an open invitation to the Russians to go in and replace the British in East Africa.

title: City Center to Remodel the Beaumont
description: The City Center will take over the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center and remodel it at a cost of more than $3million.

title: Conill Reports Net Up in 4th Quarter
description: The Collin Corporation, par ent company of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, Chicago, reported yesterday that net earnings, after securities transactions, rose to $14,560,000, or 85 cents a share, for the fourth quarter. The results compared with a net of $9,067,000, or 53 cents a share, in the like quarter last year.

title: JAMES BIRDSALL, LAWYER, 58, DIES
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 18James E. Birdsall of 102 Clarewill Avenue, a New York lawyer who was chief enforcement attorney for the Office of Price Administration in New York City in World War II, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital after a, short illness. He was 58 years old.

title: DECISION NEAR ON CALLING GUARD
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy warned yesterday that he was preparing for the agonizing decision of recom mending to Mayor Lindsay, possibly today, that National Guard troops be called to re place striking policemen.

title: Japan's 4 Opposition Parties Grope Toward United Front, Seeking to Avoid Duplication of Candidates
description: TOKYO, Jan. 18  Japan's four opposition parties, facing elections this year for local of fices and the upper house of Parliament, are groping toward a united front solid enough to weaken the LiberalDemocrats, who are entrenched in almost all areas, with a few notable exceptions such as Tokyo, Yokohama and Kyoto.

title: Ruby Sully Dies; CoAuthor Of Play The Hot Corner
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 18Mrs. Ruby Sully Mayberry, coau thor of the Broadway play The Hot Corner and wife of Prof. George Mayberry of Point Park College, an author, editor and critic, died Friday at their home after a short illness. She was 51 years old.

title: Dallas Loves a Loser
description: DALLAS, Jan. 18 (UPI)  The weather was chilly but the reception was warm today when the Dallas Cowboys, the Super Bowl losers, returned home to a tumultuous welcome that included a tickertape downtown parade.

title: 75 Imperiale Supporters Block Debate With Newark Moderates
description: NEWARK, Jan. 18A sched uled debate that was to include LeRoi Jones, the black militant playwright; Anthony Imperiale, the white militant polltician, and several moderate commu nity leaders was canceled here tonight after about 75 of Mr. Imperiale's supporters dis rupted the meeting.

title: HEROY M. DYCKMAN
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Jan. 18 Heroy M. Dyckman of 17 Crescent Place, a former vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, which he served for 25 years, died today at Overlook Hospital, Summit, after a short illness. His age was 81.

title: Dutch Cardinal in Rome
description: RONIE, Jan. 18 (UPI)?? ?? Jan Cardinal Alfrink, the liberal primate or the Roman, Catholic Church in the Nether lands, today arrived in Rome for talks with Pope Paul VI. One ?? certain to come up in the talks is the subject of married ?? a cause that Cardinal Alfrink has ?? ??

title: Bit of Odyssey Found on Columbia Papyrus
description: A graduate student at Co lumbia University has dis covered one of the oldest written fragments of Homer's Odyssey, dating to the third century B.C.

title: College Quarterbacks Eyed by Colts as Draft Nears
description: MIAMI, Jan. 18  Even be fore they dispersed following their Super Bowl triumph, the Baltimore Colts acknowledged today their interest in trading with the Boston Patriots for the No. 1 choice in next week's Na tional Football League draft, presumably Jim Plunkett, the Heisman Trophy quarterback from Stanford.

title: Calley Trial Recessed for Psychiatric Test
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 18  A defense psychiatrist brought the courtmartial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. to an abrupt halt today by testifying that the young of ficer had behaved like a robot during the alleged Mylai 4 mas sacre and had killed unarmed women and children because of a compulsion to obey orders from his father image, Capt. Ernest L. Medina.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: MARCOS SETS INQUIRY IN FEUD WITH AIDE
description: MANILA, Jan. 18 (AP)  President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who has been feuding with the family of Vice President Fer nando Lopez, today ordered an investigation of the Manila Electric Company, which the family controls.

title: Prison Guards Gain Power
description: CRANSTON, R. I., Jan. 18 (AP)  Warden Francis A. Howard of the Adult Correc tional Institutions granted guards in the prison's maxi mum security section greater control over inmates today after the guards had refused to report for work for two hours. John Galligan, a spokes man for the Brotherhood of Correctional Officers, which he said the guards formed today, said the guards had returned to work after Warden Howard had agreed to feed prisoners by cell block tiers, instead of all together, and to have a ducted.

title: YIELDS OFF AGAIN IN BOND MARKET
description: The credit markets boomed yesterday, propelled by the one two punch of a primerate re duction in the morning and a discountrate cut in the after noon.

title: Arrests May Continue
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Jan. 18 (Reuters)The Foreign Minis try said tonight that Ecuador would continue to arrest Amer ican fishing boats found within its territorial waters.

title: Foreign Policy: Kissinger at Hub
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18A Harvard professor named Henry A. Kissinger cursed his luck when Richard M. Nixon de feated Nelson A. Rockefeller for the Presidential nomination at the 1968 Republican convention in Miami.

title: RICHARD J. TONRY, 77, EXREPRESENTATIVE
description: Richard J. Tonry, a real es tate and insurance man who served in the State Assembly, on the Board of Aldermen and in the House of Representatives in the 193536 Congress, died yesterday at his home, 8020 Fourth Avenue in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, after a long illness. His age was 77.

title: Embargo by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) The United States postal service placed an immediate embargo today on mail bound for Britain, where a strike by postal workers is imminent.

title: Forever Mild
description: That part of Governor Rockefeller's State of the State message that dealt with the environment was evidently meant to be heard, not studied. It touched all the re quired basesair, water, waste and noiseand sounded just the proper tone of sternness toward those pol luters with a publicbedamned attitude. But for the most part his recommendations were mild, vague and insubstantial.

title: Office Tower Planned Downtown
description: A 40story office building will be connected to the World Trade Center by footbridge, it was announced yesterday at City Hall.

title: N.B.A. Can't Keep Haywood From Playing, Court Rules
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (UPI) United States District Court Judge Warren Ferguson issued a preliminary injunction today barring the National Basketball Association from interfering with Spencer Haywood playing for the Seattle SuperSonincs.

title: Executive Changes
description: Newsweek, Inc., has announced the appoint ment of Thomas 0. Darrigan as executive vice presi dent, Mr. Darrigan was previously vice president and secretarytreasurer. As secretarytreasurer and executive vice president, he will be responsible for corporate financial and budgetary matters.

title: GRAYBEARD LEADER IN LONG OCEAN RACE
description: CAPETOWN, Jan. 18 (UPI) The Canadian schooner Gray beard was leading the South Atlantic CapetowntoRio de Ja neiro yacht race tonight, with the Frenchman Eric Tabarly in the schooner Pen Duick III closing the gap, a spokesman at race headquarters said.

title: U.F.T. WITHDRAWS BACKING OF TOUR
description: The United Federation of Teachers has withdrawn its sponsorship of an Eastervaca tion study trip to the Soviet Union following widespread protests by union members be cause of the treatment of Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: Nixon Finds Bloopers In Super Bowl Super
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Like most American males, President Nixon watched the Super Bowl game on televi sion yesterday and had an opinion on the caliber of the contest

title: The Sukhomlinov Effect
description: Men have long scoffed at women as slaves of fashion. Occasionally, jour nalists and social historians have noted that men, too, are subject to the whims of fashion, but the general fix ation on women's thralldom to sar torial embellishment has obscured the importance of clothes in designating male social class, corporate status, and aspiration. Even less has been said about the meaning of uniforms as so cial indicators.

title: LILLIE M. WILKINSON
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 18 Lillie Merritt Wilkinson who appeared as a singer and dancer in Broadway productions, be tween 1910 and 1917, died yes terday in Stamford Hospital after a brief illness. She was 90 years old and had lived at 1150 Bedford Street for the last 42 years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: UNION AIDE PLEADS GUILTY IN KICKBACKS
description: The business manager of a Long Island local of the Paint ers Union pleaded guilty in Fed eral Court in Brooklyn yester day to charges of conspiracy and taking $8,000 in kickbacks on insurance premiums paid by the union's pension and welfare funds.

title: Festival of Pinter Plays Scheduled for The Forum
description: A festival of Pinter plays, the American premiere of Freidrich Duerrenmatt's Play Strind berg and two premieres of new scripts by young American play wrights will make up the sea son in The Forum, the experi mental playhouse of the Reper tory Theater of Lincoln Center.

title: ITALIANS RUN 1, 2, 3 IN BOBSLED TRIALS
description: CERVINIA, Italy, Jan. 18 (AP) The Italians, led by Maurizio Compagnoni, a reserve driver, swept the first three places in official trials today for the world twoman bobsledding championship.

title: In Rome, They're Showing ShortsHera, Women Wear Them
description: Spotting the longlegged blonde wearing shorts over a body stocking in the Res urrection boutique the other day, a man carrying an at tach case stopped to admire.

title: Births
description: SALOMONMr. and Mrs. Richard (?? Lorna Ryan) are thrilled to announce the birth of Kimberly and Leslie's brother Robert David, January 14, 1971, at Royal Victoria Hospital Montreal.

title: Greece Shuffles Envoys
description: ATHENS, Jan. 18 (Reuters) The Greek Government to day named 16 new ambassa dors as part of a shuffle of the diplomatic service.

title: SPINELLI DISPLAYS DRAMA AT PIANO
description: Henry Spinelli, a pianist from Pittsburgh who made his New York debut in 1966, is a young ish man who throws his hands high above his head in the pigeoncatching manner his torically associated with Franz Liszt. But Mr. Spinelli, in an enterprising program on Mon day night at Alice Tully Hall, refuted the eye's evidence and sounded all night like a deeply serious musician, one fully ca pable of finding drama in the music, but never theatrics.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISThree basic events last year altered the course of Europe's develop ment and almost certainly enhanced the vigor of the Common Market. These were, in order of their occur rence, the fact that French President Pompidou changed his mind about the likelihood of Britain's admission, the election of Tory Prime Minister Ed ward Heath, and the death of General de Gaulle.

title: Rap Brown Lawyer Wins Review of Arson Charge
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19 (AP) An attorney for H. Rap Brown successfully argued in court here today for a review of a contention that an arson charge lodged in Maryland against the black militant was fabricated.

title: Livery Fleet Owner Backs Taxi Unit
description: Calvin Williams, a new As semblyman from Brooklyn  and a central figure in the con troversy between citylicensed cab drivers and socalled gypsy operatorsis backing the taxi commission proposed by Mayor Lindsay as the hope for eas ing the city's taxi troubles.

title: Back From the Precipice
description: The disgraceful desertion of duty by the vast majority of the city's patrolmen has ended, thanks to a courageous assertion of leadership by their union president, Edward J. Kiernan.

title: Senator Russell Reported In Very Critical Condition
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI)  Senator Richard B. Russell suffered a setback in his respiratory infection early today and was reported to be in very critical condition to night.

title: Guerrillas Voice Satisfaction
description: AMMAN, Jan. 19 (UPI)Pal estinian guerrilla leaders said today that weapons had been collected from most of their parttime militiamen in Am man. They expressed satisfac tion at implementation of the latest ceasefire agreement with the Jordanian Govern ment and said that nearly all clauses of the accord had now been implemented. The agree ment was reached last Thurs day.

title: British Mail Workers Strike; Phone Service Is Also Affected
description: LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 20 (AP)  Britain's 200,000 postal workers went on strike at midnight last night, despite a lastditch Government at tempt to prevent it.

title: Vanden Heuvel Asks New Rehabilitation Effort at Queens Jail
description: A new rehabilitation pro gram for the Queens House of Detention for Men, in Kew Gar dens  the scene of three days of rioting last October was urged yesterday by Wil liam J. vanden Heuvel, chair man of the City Board of Cor rection.

title: NEW ECUADOR BAR WEIGHED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Sec retary of State William P. Rog ers was reported today to be considering further financial sanctions against Ecuador be cause of that country's continu ing seizure of American tuna fishing boats off her coast.

title: U.S. IS NOW FLYING COPTER MISSIONS FOR LAOS TROOPS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19A further enlargement of the United States air role in Indochina was reported here today as official sources said American helicopter gunships were flying combat missions in Laos in direct support of Laotian ground troops.

title: Costumes Evoke Caruso's Era
description: The Metropolitan Opera opened an exhibit of cos tumes worn by its most pop ular singer yesterday, 50 years after his death. The subject of the display, in stalled on the parterre box floor of the house, was En rico Caruso, of course. We still get more mail on him than all other singers com bined, said Francis Robin son, the Met's assistant man ager. You know the sort of thingWas it really true Caruso could break glass with his high notes? (An swer: not really.)

title: Ford Strike in Canada
description: WINDSOR, Ont., Jan. 19 (Ca nadian Press)About 14,100 United Auto Workers went on strike today against Ford of Canada, Ltd. Bargainers con tinued to work.

title: Javits Urges G.O.P. to Question Buckley
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits pro posed yesterday that Senate Republicans question James L. Buckley closely on his assertion that he will work and act as a Republican before they admit him to the Republican Senate Conference.

title: The Nixon Economy: I
description: WASHINGTON  Many observers seem puzzled by Mr. Nixon's espousal of the idea of balancing the Federal budget at full employment, with its implication that large actual deficits for the next year are not only toler able but a positively good thing. Some regard it as a deathbed conversion from the obsolete Puritan ethic to the brilliant discoveries of the New Eco nomics. Others consider it a politi cally motivated lapse from fiscal vir tue to demagoguery. Some of my more adroit friends have it both ways on the general principle that what was the New Economics for JFK is only the Old Politics for RMN.

title: LUDWIG E. HERBORN
description: Ludwig E. Herborn, a re tired engineer at the Bell Lab oratories in Murray Hill, N.J., died Sunday. He was 72 years old and lived at 622 West 141st Street.

title: Miss Firth Wins U.S. Ski Crown In Major Upset
description: DURANGO, Colo., Jan. 19 (AP)  Sharon Firth of Canada upset Martha Rockwell of Put ney, Vt., to win the women's fivekilometer crosscountry, race today in the United States Ski Association national cham pionships.

title: Boeing Grants Subcontract
description: PITTSBURGH Jan. 19 (UPI) The North American Rock well Corporation said yester day that its Autonetics division in Anaheim, Calif., had re ceived a $15.8million contract from the Boeing Company. It covers initial production of the master computer for the Air Force's shortrange attack missile.

title: GoldfieldAnaconda Deal Set
description: The Goldfield Corporation an nounced yesterday that it had signed a lease and option agree ment with the Anaconda Com pany covering Goldfield's San Pedro, Text., copper mine, mill and property near Albuquerque, N. M. The agreement provides that, if the option is exercised, Anaconda will purchase the San Pedro mine through payments spread over not more than 10 years.

title: Merger News
description: wholly owned subsidiary of Squibb BeechNut, Inc.), and the Standard International Cor poration announced yesterday they had agreed in principle on the acquisition of Standard's SO per cent owned subsidiary, Edward Weck & Co., for 316, 176 shares of Squibb Beech

title: Wisconsin Throws a Cheese Party Here
description: The State of Wisconsin wants all of us to eat more cheese. It wants that because eating cheese is good for us, and very good for Wisconsin, whose economy bobs on a sea of curdled milk.

title: Anchors Aweigh in Culebra
description: Two restrained cheers for the United States Navy for agreeing to phase out its activities on Culebra rather than buying up more of the tiny Caribbean island as target area for guided missiles and glide bombs. The third cheer will be delivered with greater enthusiasm when the Navy makes good its pledge to find an alter nate target zone and clears out of Culebra completely, leaving its 726 residents in peace and unaccustomed quiet.

title: Dutch Sentence 35 in Raid On Indonesian Aide's Home
description: THE HAGUE, Jan. 19 (AP) A Dutch court today sentenced 35 Indonesian refugees from the island of Amboina to prison terms for a raid on the Indo nesian Ambassador's residence in August in which a policeman was killed.

title: Federated Stores Starts Division at San Francisco
description: Federated Department Stores, Inc., the country's largest departmentstore chain, an nounced yesterday the estab lishment of a new division, Bul lock's North, in the San Fran cisco area.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: New buying and short cover ing reversed a downward trend of soybean and grain futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybean futures were up sharply, while those of wheat, corn and oats were ir regular or up slightly.

title: Dr. Dino Bousso, Invented Arm for Maimed Children
description: HAIFA, Israel, Jan. 19 (UPI) Dr. Dino Bousso, inventor of the gaspowered Bousso Arm for thalidomide  maimed chil dren, died here last night of a heart attack. He was 38 years old.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: KNOXVILLE, Jan. 19 (AP) Jerry Elliott, a defensive as sistant on the Kansas State football staff, has accepted a similar post at Tennessee, Coach Bill Battle announced today.

title: NIXON NAMES AIDE FOR TRADE POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 President Nixon drew the broad area of foreign economic policy into the White House today and named a new Cabinetlevel council and an executive direc tor to handle it.

title: MORE STEEL MAKERS JOINING IN PRICE RISE
description: Several more steel producers took pricing actions on struc tural steel yesterday that were in line with the 6.8 per cent increase initiated by the United States Steel Corporation.

title: Mediators Enter Telephone Strike; Meeting Today Set
description: The State Mediation Board intervened yesterday in the telephone strike and set meeting for today with the Communications Workers of America to try to resolve the dispute.

title: Watch Company Workers Battle 10% Pay Reduction
