description: LANCASTER, Pa., Jan. 19 (AP)An unhappy group of Hamilton Watch Company em ployes has hired a lawyer and may go to court to block a 10 per cent pay cut approved by the union to help the company ride out a financial crisis and keep the plant open.

title: West Leads Laker Victory
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPDJerry West made the Los Angeles fast break click with 33 points and Keith Erickson added a season high of 29 to night as the Lakers routed the Philadelphia 76ers, 134114.

title: SHAPP IS SWORN IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 19 Milton J. Shapp was inaugurat ed amid parade and pageantry today as the first Democratic Governor of Pennsylvania in eight years.

title: LEE R. STROHL
description: Lee R. Strohl, an advertising man principally in the field of amusements and entertainment, died on Monday. He was 70 years old and lived at 120 East 79th Street.

title: Namath's Wrist Fracture Pronounced Practically Healed by Jets' Physician
description: Joe Namath's fractured pass ing wrist was pronounced yes terday as healed practically in its entirety by Dr. James A. Nicholas, the New York Jets' orthopedist, but the quarter back's right forearm was placed in another cast.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Whenever it snows in the big cities the morning radio newscasts speak ominously of hazardous driving condi tions. But in New England ice is a part of everyday life, and drivers learn to live with it. In fact, they also en joy a lively seasonal sport ice racing on frozen lakes.

title: Girl's Letters Reread to Manson Jury
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 The TateLaBianca jury inter rupted its deliberations again today, this time returning to the courtroom to hear a read ing of what the prosecution calls the confession letters that Susan Atkins wrote from prison.

title: Colonels Triumph, 117110
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 19 (AP)The Kentucky Colonels connected on 31 of 36 free throws and pulled away in the final seconds to defeat the Memphis Pros tonight, 117110.

title: David J. Webster Chosen To Represent B.B.C. Here
description: David J. Webster has been named United States represent ative of the British Broadcast ing Corporation. He succeeds Leonard Miall, who will return to London in March to become controller of overseas and for eign relations. That post is now held by Donald Stephenson, who will retire in May.

title: A Real Test for Teachers
description: State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist has touched the central issue of school reform in pressing for fundamental changes in teacher certification. The fatal flaw in present procedures is their reliance on college course credit or on such special tests as those administered by the city's Board of Examiners. The only perfunctory nod to classroom performance is in the studentteaching requirement which, though a useful training device if properly organized, is far too hap hazard to serve as a certification criterion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: EXOFFICER IN LEGION CHARGED IN TAX CASE
description: A New York lawyer who served as state commander of the American Legion was charged yesterday with failure to file Federal incometax re turns on a total income of $112, 000 over four years.

title: Church Council Leaders Celebrate Ethiopian Fete
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 19Leaders of the World Council of Churches took a 24 hour respite today to eat, drink and say an occasional prayer with millions of Ethio pians observing the national feast of Timkat.

title: COUNSELOR SEIZED ON HEROIN CHARGE
description: A 27yearold counselor at Spofford House, the Bronx de tention center for boys, was arrested yesterday on charges of possession and sale of heroin.

title: Fame Comes Late For Clyfford Still
description: In this age of instant his tory, artists, like movie stars, are made overnight and are just as quickly forgotten. Their art, which is more often novelty than innova tion, is suddenly canonized, only to be excommunicated soon after. Clyfford Still, now 66 years old, calls the artists of today popes and cardinals who float to the top because they're light weights.

title: Singapore Talks Bogged Down In Bitter Debate on South Africa
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 19The conference of heads of the 31 Commonwealth countries bogged down today into a bit ter and inconclusive daylong debate on Britain's plan to sell arms to South Africa.

title: Fishing Interests Accused
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Jan. 19 (UPI)Ecuador accused United States fishing interests today of provocation in dispatching a fishing fleet, based on the West Coast, to South American ter ritorial waters.

title: Advertising:
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach, the world's top winner of awards for advertising creativity, will this year only be entering three major competitions in New York.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE AMERICAN HEALTH EMPIRE. A Report From the Health Policy Advisory Center (HealthPac). Prepared by Barbara and John Ehrenreich. 279 pages. Random. $7.95.

title: Bronx Fire Lieutenant Dies After Heroic Effort at Blaze
description: The Fire Department report ed yesterday that a Bronx fire lieutenant who spotted a fire on his way to work, and then went to search for occupants in the burning building, collapsed and died after the fire was put out.

title: PATROLMEN END SIXDAY STRIKE, HEEDING UNION DELEGATES' VOTE; PAY AND PENALTIES UNRESOLVED
description: The city's patrolmen ended a sixday wildcat strike yester day after their union delegates, at a tumultuous meeting, voted overwhelmingly to return to work.

title: S.E.C. SUIT NAMES EXTEXAS OFFICIAL
description: DALLAS, Jan. 19 (AP)  An injunction suit alleging fraud in sales of stock was filed yesterday against former Texas Attorney General Wag goner Carr and others.

title: McGovern Assails Nixon on Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Senator George S. McGovern charged today that President Nixon had violated the spirit and letter of the Cooper Church resolution by authoriz ing intensive American air activity over Cambodia.

title: Disposal Certificates for Autos Proposed by City
description: ALBANY, Jan. 19New York City asked the Legislature to day to require buyers of new motor vehicles to deposit $100 with the State Department of Motor Vehicles as a guarantee that they would not eventually abandon their cars. The Legis lature was also asked to re quire current owners of cars to deposit $50.

title: Suspect in 5 Coast Deaths Enters New Plea of Insanity
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Jan. 19 (AP)John Linley Frazier pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity today to the slaying of Dr. Victor M. Ohta and four others in the doctor's hilltop mansion near Santa Cruz last Oct. 19.

title: SevenUp Will Not Agree To an F.T.C. Consent Order
description: Ben H. Wells, president, an nounced yesterday that the SevenUp Company will not agree to the consent order pro posed by the Federal Trade Commission in a complaint against the company issued last Friday.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
United Air Lines Flights Cut 9.5% More in Slump
description: United Air Lines, the nation's largest airline, announced sharp new cutbacks in service yes terday because of the continu ing nationwide slump in air travel that has been brought on by the economic turndown.

title: EGYPT CRITICIZES ISRAELI POSITION
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 19The United Arab Re public was reliably reported today to regard the present Is raeli position in the indirect peace talks as inadequate on at least two issues.

title: New School to Rename Its Spanglish Coarse
description: The New School for Social Research announced yester day that it had agreed to change the name of a con troversial course on the nu ances of pronunciation, slang and vocabulary among Span ishspeaking New Yorkers.

title: Chrysler and Union Reach Pact; FourDay Week Will Be Studied
description: DETROIT, Jan. 19  The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers reached a threeyear tentative contract today, and both sides pledged to look into trying out a fourday, 40hour week.

title: Refugee, Wounded Man, Teacher: Impact of the Warfare in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 16The morale of Cam bodian civilians, and of sol diers who have not yet seen combat, still appears to be exuberant.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 (UPI) The University of Southern California added Arlie (Skip) Husbands, a former lineman of Utah State, to its football coaching staff. Husbands has been the line coach at Arizona Western College in Yuma for the last three years.

title: 5 MISSISSIPPIANS RETAIN SENIORITY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 House Democrats rejected to day a move to strip the five Mississippi Representatives of their seniority because of their failure to register with the in tegrated party that was recog nized by the 1968 Democratic National Convention.

title: Atlantic City Power Fails
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 19 An explosion and a fire in an electric transformer in the new sevenstory City Hall here to day forced the evacuation of 500 employes. A total of 3,700 customers of the Atlantic City Electric Company were without power for 21 minutes as a re sult of the explosion.

title: For People Made ShutIns by Obesity, a Project Called HOPE
description: There are people all over the city who never leave their homes because of extreme obesity. They cannot find shoes that will fit their feet. They cannot climb the steps to board a bus, or maneuver themselves into a subway. Bathing in bathtubs is an impossibility, as is going to the movies (they cannot fit into the seats) or making a call in a telephone booth.

title: PNOMPENH TELLS OF ROUTE 4 GAINS
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 19 (AP)  A South Vietnam ese armored force reportedly pushed closer today to a link up with Cambodian troops in the allied drive to clear Route 4, the nation's main supply route.

title: Indiana and Nebraska Face Loss of Welfare Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare an nounced today that it would cut off a major portion of matching welfare aid to Indi ana and Nebraska on April 1 because the two states are vio lating Federal public assistance regulations.

title: Oil Thrown in Pool
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (UPI)Standard Oil said to day that someone threw oil in a reflecting pool outside the company headquarters here last night.

title: Revenues and Net At Jersey Utility Advanced in 1970
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company reported yesterday gains in 1970 operat ing revenues and net income. However, share earnings dipped as the number of shares out standing increased by some 2 million to an average of 33, 504,421 for the year.

title: Forest Service Limits New Hampshire Camp
description: LACONIA, N. H., Jan, 19 (AP)The United States For est Service said today that it had set use limits to save Tuckerman Ravine in the White Mountain National For est in New Hampshire for fu ture generations.

title: Shaw, With $29,752, Leads In Pro Golf MoneyWinning
description: Tom Shaw, winner of the Bing Crosby national proam, took over as professional golf's leading moneywinner with $29,752, according to the fig ures issued by the Professional Golfer's Association yesterday.

title: Mr. Nixon Reorganizes
description: Since reorganization of the Executive departments and independent agencies has sooner or later become a favorite preoccupation of every President since Franklin D. Roosevelt, who invented big government in this coun try, it is no surprise that Mr. Nixon is now considering a major reshuffle.

title: Bulls on Top, 123111
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) The Chicago Bulls nearly lost a 21point lead, but saved enough punch in the final quarter to beat the Portland Trail Blazers, 123111, tonight. Chet Walker scored 32 points for Chicano,

title: Mrs. Friderike Maria Zweig, 85 A Novelist and Biographer, Dies
description: Mrs. Friderike Maria Zweig, the former wife of the late Ste fan Zweig, the Viennese writer, died Monday at 288 Ocean Drive West, Stamford, Conn. She was 88 years old and lived in Stamford for many years.

title: Liston's Death Laid to Lung Congestion
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 19 (UPI)  The former heavy weight champion, Sonny Liston, died of lung conges tion brought on by poor oxygen and nutrient blood supply to the heart muscles, the Clark County coroner, Mark Herman, ruled today.

title: SURGE BY PISTONS CONQUERS SONICS
description: DETROIT, Jan. 19 (UPI)  Dave Bing and Bob Lanier di vided Detroit's last 14 points tonight as they rallied the Pis tons from a 9492 deficit to a 106102 National Basketball Association victory over the Seattle Sonics.

title: Advertising:
description: Weather like yesterday's bonechilling, nosenipping coldcreates warm waves of pleasure and anticipation in Camden, N. J., and in the marbled halls of Batten, Bar ton, Durstine & Osborn.

title: Medical Aides Are Called No Panacea
description: A panel of health care train ing specialists said yesterday that paramedical workers were not a panacea for the health manpower shortage or the de livery of health services to all Americans.

title: Hamilton Wins in Hockey
description: CLINTON, N. Y., Jan. 19 (AP) Mike Thomas scored three goals and Scott Douglas two today in leading Hamilton College's hockey team to a 94 victory over Ithaca College.

title: BIG BOARD STOCKS SUSTAIN ADVANCES
description: The stock market, breathing a hit like a winded runner, managed to push forward again yesterday.

title: Knicks Beat Rockets in Overtime Here, 117113, After Losing 11Point Lead
description: The Knicks lost another player last night, but finally won a game. They scored a 117113 victory over San Diego in overtime after Dave De Busschere had sprained his right ankle at the end of the first quarter.

title: Warriors Sink Royals, 116108
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPI)Jerry Lucas sparked a fourthperiod scoring spree that lifted the San Francisco Warriors to a 116108 victory over the Cincinnati Royals to night.

title: Man Crippled by Policeman Awarded $425,000 by Jury
description: A 22yearold man who has been hospitalized since he was shot by a policeman on Nov. 19, 1966, won a $425,000 ver dict against the city yesterday from a jury in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: Bone Markings Indicate Ice Age Notation System
description: Analysis of markings on frag ments of ancient bone, antler and stone has revealed what appears to be a system of no tation used throughout most of Europe beginning some 34,000 years ago during the last ice age.

title: Screen: The Reckoning
description: Conceivably, a performance may be sufficient reason for going to a movie. I can think of severalby George Segal, Samantha Eggar, Dominique Sanda, George Scott and othersover the last year. But a performance is not suf ficient reason for making a movie, though I can think of no other reason for The Reckoning, which does not so much feature, as respect fully worship, the talent, the presence, the reactions of Nicol Williamson.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyer Will Head Presbytery Here
description: The new Moderator of the Presbytery of New York City was formally installed last night at a service in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at 55th Street.

title: ADVANCE SLOWED IN CREDIT MARKET
description: The credit markets yester day afternoon appeared to be approaching something of a turning point after their un interrupted climb for the last two weeks.

title: N. H. L. DECREES EXPANSION HALT
description: BOSTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) The 14team National Hockey League will not expand again before the 1973 season because of a dilution of playing talent, Clarence Campbell said today.

title: Futile Cambodia P.O.W. Raid Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19 (AP)Three hundred South Vietnamese paratroopers, air lifted by helicopter, raided a camp just inside Cambodia where 20 Americans were be lieved held but found it empty informed sources reported today.,

title: Amedee Tulane Aide
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19 (AP)  Lynn Amedee, Louisiana State quarterback in two bowl victories in the early ninteen sixties, was named offensive backfield coach at Tulane Uni versity today. He was assistant coach at Northeast Louisiana State University last fall.

title: DICTAPHONE UNVEILS RECORDING SYSTEMS
description: The Dictaphone Corporation introduced here yesterday three new recording systems aimed at diverse markets. Walter W. Finke, president and chairman, said at a news conference that the new products represented the initial items in an ambiti ous drive for 1971.

title: FLORIDIANS' RALLY TOPS NETS, 112107
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19 (AP) Mack Calvin scored 38 points, 20 in the second half, to give the Floridians a 112107 tri umph over the New York Nets in the first game of an Amer ican Basketball Association doubleheader tonight.

title: MRS. NORA S. BARNEY, ARCHITECT, 87, DIES
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 19 Mrs. Nora Stanton Barney, architect, civil engineer and life worker for equal rights for wo men and other liberal causes, died last night at her home on Steamboat Road. She was 87 years old and had lived here since 1923.

title: Small Surcharge Starts Nov. 1 For Overseas Air Passengers
description: GENEVA, Jan. 19Interna tional airline passengers will pay a new charge ranging from a few cents to a maximum of $10 beginning Nov. 1, the Inter national Air Transport Associa tion announced today.

title: ColorBlind Regime Vowed by Governor Of South Carolina
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 19 Gov. John C. West of South Carolina pledged today in his inaugural address to eliminate any vestige of discrimination from state government.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bugner. 20, Wins 31st Bout
description: LONDON, Jan. 19 (UPI)Joe Bugner, 217 pounds, outpointed Carl Gizzi, the 202pound Welsh champion, over 10 rounds tonight. The victory was the 31st in 33 bouts for the 20yearold Bugner, who turned pro three years ago.

title: Rostropovich Forced Again To Cancel Concert Abroad
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 19 (AP)  Informed sources said today that the cellist Mstislav Ros tropovich, a supporter of Alek sandr Solzhenitsyn, the novel ist, had been forced to cancel a concert in Paris.

title: Cavaliers Defeat Braves
description: SYRACUSE, Jan. 19 (UPI) The Cleveland Cavaliers scored their fifth victory in eight games against Buffalo tonight, beating the Braves, 11179. Cleveland has won only two other games all season.

title: Podgorny Flies Home
description: CAIRO, Jan. 19Nikolai V. Podgorny, the Soviet chief of state, flew home today after a sixday visit to the United Arab Republic during which the word war was strikingly ab sent from speeches by him and by President Anwar elSadat.

title: Man In the News
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19As the Lady Bird Johnson cam paign special rolled through the South in the fall of 1964, Thomas Hale Boggs of Louisi ana drew wild cheers from the trainside crowds.

title: Chilean Business Tells Allende Policy Will Kill Private Sector
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 19 Leading businessmen and own ers of large farms warned to day that they would go bank rupt soon unless Chile's leftist Government changed its wage, price and tax policies.

title: FORD FOUNDATION HELPS 16 PROJECTS
description: The Ford Foundation an nounced grants of almost $2million yesterday for 16 projects dealing with the de velopment of community pro grams in housing, day care centers, health and education.

title: Prosecution of Clay Shaw Is Blocked by Court Order
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19 (AP) A Federal judge issued a tem porary restraining order today blocking further state prosecu tion of Clay L. Shaw in connec tion with the assassination of President Kennedy.

title: Board of Ethics Is Reassessing Its Earlier Ruling on Kretchmer
description: The Board of Ethics is go ing to take another look at a ruling relating to Environmen tal Protection Administrator Jerome Kretchmer, whose name remains in the title of his former private law firm.

title: Did Jesus Marry?
description: The traditional assumption that Jesus was a celibate is totally incon gruous with the fact that marriage at an early age was a sacred obliga tion in the Hebrew culture in which he was reared. Celibacy was complete ly rejected in both theory and in prac tice among the ancient Jews.

title: Kiernan's Opponents Press Campaign to Unseat Him in P.B.A. Election in June
description: Despite his success in win ning a vote to have striking patrolmen return to work, Ed ward J. Kiernan, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent As sociation, appeared yesterday to be facing a new coalition determined to replace him when the organization elects of ficers in June.

title: Coast Slayer Sentenced
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (AP)Frank J. Thurber, 45 years old, of San Bruno, was sentenced yesterday to five years to life in prison for the murder of a newspaper execu tive, Allan W. Daly, 30, who worked for the strikebound San Rafael Independent Journal. Thurber, a member of the Mail ers Union, did not work for the newspaper.

title: WAGE RAISE ENDS PRODUCE STRIKE
description: Local 202 of the teamsters' union voted yesterday to end a strike that has kept the city's four major wholesale produce markets closed since last Sun day.

title: MRS. DAVID MILLAR
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. I., Jan. 19Mrs. Millie Young Millar, widow of David Millar, who was a director of Stephen F. Whitman & Sons, the candy company, died yesterday at her home after a long illness. She was 88 years old and lived at 480 Old Westbury Road.

title: Burger Bids U.S. Courts Cut Down on State Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger called upon the Supreme Court and the Federal District Courts today to become more reluc tant to strike down state laws without giving state courts a chance to rule on them first.

title: Handel Opera of 1733 Is Heard in Local Premiere
description: Handel's operas in recent years have been much writ ten about, and some of them have even been produced (notably the New York City Opera production of Julius Caesar), but most of them are entirely unknown. The Handel Society of New York has determined to do some thing about that, and it is giving three Handel operas at Carnegie Hall. The first of those three, Orlando, was heard on Monday evening, and it was listed as a first New York performance.

title: Dow to Write Off $43.3Million Loss
description: The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday that it had decided to write off its total investment of $43.3million in PhrixWerke, A.G., of West Germany, as an extraordinary loss.

title: HOME ICE SWEET FOR BLUE SHIRTS
description: The Rangers, back from an extended road trip that saw them lose two successive games for the first time this season, will meet the streaking Phila delphia Flyers in a National Hockey League contest tonight in Madison Square Garden.

title: Eye Funds, McCartney Asks Court
description: LONDON, Jan. 19The fi nancial affairs of the Beatles, Paul McCartney's counsel said today, are in an appalling state and there probably is not enough in the kitty to meet tax liabilities.

title: MacPherson Is Named
description: AMHERST, Mass., Jan. 19 (AP)Dick MacPherson, the defensive backfield coach of the Denver Broncos of the National Football League, was named today head football coach at the University of Mas sachusetts.

title: WideScale Mercury Poisoning Is Called Unlikely by Scientists
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) A Government scientific study group concluded today that widespread poisoning from mercury in food was unlikely. But it said that the Government must move with utmost urgen cy to remove deposits of the metal from polluted waterways.

title: School Board, in 32 Vote, Asks $1.9Billion Budget for 1972
description: The Board of Education, by a vote of 3 to 2, adopted record operating budget re quest of $1,920,694,513, yester day for the fiscal year begin ning July 1.

title: If Not for Galitzine, O Tempora, O Fashion
description: ROME, Jan. 19Irene Ga litzine, wearing black shorts and a thin silk blouse, upheld the honor of Italian fashion at her spring opening and proved that women over 18 can be trusted in short pants.

title: Zeffirelli to Depict Life of St. Francis In $2Million Movie
description: ROME, Jan. 19Franco Zef firelli is ready for the shooting of a movie on the life of St. Francis of Assisi to be titled Brother Sun, Sister Moon. The film, budgeted at $2mil lion, will, in Mr. Zeffirelli's words, present St. Francis as a very special young man, one of the first examples in history of the dropout, . . who more than 700 years ago had problems of identity and searched for fulfill ment, just as young people today.

title: RAW STEEL POURED IN '70 SHOWED DROP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) The steel industry poured 131,331,000 tons of raw steel in 1970, down about 10 million tons from the record 141,262, 000 tons poured in 1969, the American Iron and Steel Insti tute reported today.

title: How the City Escaped What Might Have Been
description: City officials, psychologists and a lot of ordinary citizens, agreed yesterday that coldl weather and the shrewd use of a small force of available police personnel were major factors in saving New York from the spectacular break downs in law and order that have hit other cities during police strikes.

title: LAYOFF WARNING ISSUED BY CARBIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)The Union Carbide Cor poration says it may have to lay off 125 employes next Sep tember and 500 or more by April, 1972, to comply with a Federal antipollution order at a plant in Marietta, Ohio, that employs about 1,400.

title: West Scores Early to Beat East, 21, in AllStar Hockey
description: BOSTON, Jan. 19In a game so lacking in excitement and rousing play that one fan shouted It's the Super Bowl on ice, the West Division gained its first victory over the East, 21, tonight in the National Hockey League's alleged All Star contest.

title: NATO to Get New Satellite
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 19 (AP) A second communications sat ellite for the exclusive use of the North Atlantic Treaty Or ganization will be launched from Cape Kennedy, Fla., on Jan. 27, it was announced to day. The first NATO satellite was put into orbit last March 20. The system is designed to provide quick and secure com munications for the leaders of the alliance.

title: FLOTH AND BADER INJURED IN CRASH
description: CERVINIA, Italy, Jan. 19 (AP)Horst Floth and Pepi Bader of West Germany were injured today when they over turned on the final stretch of the Cervinia track during of ficial trials for the world two man bobsledding competition.

title: EXAIDE TESTIFIES IN MURDER APPEAL
description: NEWARK, Jan. 19During a drive to the Mahwah gravel pit where the body of Victoria Zielinski was found 13 years ago, Edgar H. Smith told detec tives I'll fry in July, it was testified at a hearing here to day.

title: Vast Oil Spill Killing Birds Along San Francisco Bay
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 The beautiful Bay of San Francisco was ugly today.

title: Bank of America Cuts Yield on Savings
description: The small saver in many parts of the country is begin ning to feel the effects of the broad and sustained drop in interest rates.

title: J.D.L. Calls a Halt To Its Harassment Of Soviet Diplomats
description: Rabbi Meir D. Kahane, leader of the Jewish Defense League, announced yesterday an in definite moratorium in the organization's campaign of harassing Soviet diplomats and members of their families.

title: MRS. RICHARD BARNES
description: PARAMUS, N. J., Jan. 19Mrs. Jeannette Davenport Barnes, widow of Richard S. Barnes, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday in the Dunroven Nursing Home. She was 83 years old and lived on Ridgewood Avenue here.

title: BONAVENA SUFFERS HAND INJURY IN DRILL
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 19 (AP) Oscar (Ringo) Bonavena, the Argentine heavyweight, suf fered an injured left hand while working out at a punching bag today and his Feb. 12 match against Floyd Patterson in New York will be postponed, Bona vena's doctor said.

title: MITCHELL REPORTS GAIN IN CRIME WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) Attorney General John N. Mitchell asserted today that the Nixon Administration was winning the war against crime despite statistics from the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation that show lawlessness still on the rise.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Bell & Howell Company has announced the establishment of an executive office that will carry the operating responsibility for the company fol lowing the resignation of Peter G. Peterson, chair man, to accept an appointment as executive direc tor of the Council on International Economic Policy and as assistant to President Nixon for international economic affairs. The newly formed office will he composed of E. F. Wagner, vice chairman, Henry E. Bowes, president and Lawrence Howe, senior vice president for law and administration. The com pany also announced that Charles G. Mortimer, chairman of the executive committee, will func tion as chairman of the board and handle the re sponsibilities of the chairman with regard to board matters. He is chairman of the executive committee of the General Foods Corporation.

title: Frustration Evident
description: The frustration, humiliation and anger that have been build ing for years among the city's policementhe basic reasons for their walkoutstill smol dered yesterday as they re turned to work.

title: City Shivers in 4Above Cold; Albany Has Record 28 Below
description: A reading of 4 degrees above zero from 7:05 A.M. to 8:30 A.M. made yesterday the cold est day of the winter so far for New York City, and the coldest since January, 1968, when temperatures slid one degree below zero.

title: Stars Gain on Pacers
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 19 (AP)The Utah Stars took ad vantage of Indiana's poor third quarter shooting to beat the divisionleading Pacers, 116 106, in an American Basketball Association game tonight and move within half a game of Indiana in the Western Division standing. Willie Wise, with 23 points, and Zelmo Beaty, with 21, led the winners.

title: 2 Paterson Real Estate Agents Indicted in. F. H. A. Loan Fraud
description: NEWARK, Jan. 19Two Paterson realestate agents were indicted today on charges of filing false and counterfeit documents with the Federal Housing Administration in an effort to get F.H.A. guaranteed mortgages.

title: Detroit Bank Lists Quarterly Net Loss
description: The Bank of the Common wealth, Detroit, yesterday re ported a net loss, before secu rities transactions, of $7,516, 068 in the fourth quarter, com pared with earnings, before se curities transactions, of $4, 616,185, or 94 cents a share, in the same quarter a year ago.

title: Miss Moras Swim Victor
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 19 (AP)  Karen Moras defeated 14yearold Shane Gould to night in the 200meter free style final of a New South Wales swim meet. Both girls were timed in 2:12.7, but judges awarded Miss Moras the victory.

title: Suit Settled Against Maker Of Silicone for Injection
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)  The Government announced today the settlement of three year  old criminal charges against Dow Corning Corpora tion for misbranding a silicone substance sometimes used to bolster sagging bust lines.

title: Jordanians Accuse Syria on Deserters
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 15 Sources close to the royal palace here said today that Syria was helping to form a new brigade of the Palestine Liberation Army composed largely of deserters from the Jordanian Army.

title: Chaps Beat Rockets
description: DALLAS, Jan. 19 (AP)John Beasley and Wayne Hightower helped the Texas Chaparrals post a 148127 American Bas ketball Association victory to night over the Denver Rockets. Beasley hit for 27 points while Hightower added 26.

title: U. OF WASHINGTON HIRES BLACK AIDE
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 19 (AP) The University of Washington hired Donald K. Smith, a for mer Seattle newsman, as as sistant athletic director today. This completed a university mandate to add blacks to the sports administrative ranks.

title: Bridge : Games Tonight Across U.S. To Aid International Team
description: The considerable cost of sending American represent atives to the world team championship will be dou bled this year, since the United States is entitled, for the first time, to two teams.

title: Davidson Triumphs, 6052
description: GREENVILLE, N. C., Jan. 19 (UPI)Davidson held off a late East Carolina rally and turned back the Pirates, 6052, tonight to take over the undisputed lead in the Southern Conference. Steve Kirley and Joe Sutter had 15 points each to pace the Wildcats.

title: Bill to End Draft Is Backed By Hatfield and Goldwater
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)  Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, an nounced today that he and Senator Barry Goldwater, Ari zona Republican, would intro duce legislation later this week to abolish the Selective Service System by the end of 1971.

title: Seabee Unit in Charleston
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The Navy is establishing a new Construction Battalion, or Seabee, unit in Charleston, S. C., Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, said today. Mr. Thurmond, in a statement issued from his of fice here, said that the unit would consist of 30 enlisted men and an officer with a total annual payroll of about $160,00.

title: JOHN F. FINNEGAN
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Jan. 19 John F. Finnegan, who was general passenger agent of the Pennsylvania Railroad in New York City from 1948 to 1955, died yesterday at his home, 100 Bay Driveway, after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Dr. Alexander G. Ruthven Dies; U. of Michigan ExPresident, 88
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 19  Dr. Alexander Grant Ruth ven, president of the University of Michigan from 1929 until his retirement in 1951, was found dead today in his home. Dr. Grant, who was 88 years old, had lived alone since the death of his wife several years ago.

title: HENRY L. CULLEN, 65, NEWSPRINT LEADER
description: Henry Laurence Cullen, re tired senior vice president and a director of the International Paper Sales Company, died Tuesday in. Montreal, where he lived. He was 65 years old.

title: Status Quo Wins
description: At their caucus yesterday, the House Democrats voted to maintain the status quo in the character of their lead ership. As expected, they chose Representative Carl Albert of Oklahoma as their candidate for Speaker over token opposition. An able and fairminded man with progressive outlook, Representative Albert earned his victory.

title: Gierek Is Expected to Address Poles on TV Today as Labor Unrest in Gdansk Continues
description: WARSAW, Jan. 19  Polish Government sources indicated today that Edward Gierek, the Communist party leader, was considering an address to the nation tomorrow amid continu ing industrial unrest in Gdansk and evidence of restiveness elsewhere.

title: Palisades Park Expected To Close After Season
description: Palisades Amusement Park, one of the last of the play grounds that once dotted the outer reaches of the city and the nearby suburbs, may close after the 1971 season.

title: Lon Not Flies to Saigon For Two Days of Talks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 20 (Reuters) Premier Lon Nol of Cam bodia arrived here today for two days of talks with South Vietnamese leaders. He was met by the South Vietnamese Premier, Tran Thien Khiem, at Tansonnhut Airport.

title: VIRGIL FINLAY DIES; ILLUSTRATOR WAS 56
description: Virgil Finlay, an artist and illustrator, died on Monday evening after a brief Ilness. He was 56 years old and lived at 55 Cobalt Lane, Westbury, L.I.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTONYour Uncle Sam has been in here for his annual checkup, and in general he's in pretty good shape, but there are some things about the old boy that seem to be changing.

title: Lower Defense Spending Leads Grumman to Cut Work Force
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Jan. 27 The Grumman Aerospace Corp oration announced today that it planned to reduce its work force by 3,000 employes this year, an action that will in crease Long Island's already high unemployment rate.

title: U.S. Plywood Net Down in 1970
description: Lower earnings for 1970 were reported yesterday by a number of companies in var ious industries including forest products, steel and automobile equipment.

title: The Nixon Economy: II
description: Since the 1930's, the operational control of a capitalistic economy has been a twodimensional affair. These two dimensions have been fiscal con trol and monetary control. Economic managers at the national level have long felt that they had a degree of control over fiscal matters.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Long after history has hap pened, historians usually find an inevitable logic to events. But at the time events are mov ing the air is full of uncertainty and confusion. This was true of last week's confrontation between the Nixon Administra tion and the steel industry, which is now seemingly over, Bethlehem Steel having cut its price rise on structural steel from 12 per cent back to 6.8 per cent, matching United States Steel's increase. Until U. S. Steel came through with its lower price rise, undercutting Bethlehem's, the Administra tion spent many anxious hours trying to decide what it would do if the whole steel industry held firm with Bethlehem, de spite the President's use of the jawbone that he had so often denounced and had declared he would not use.

title: Adios Captures Final Heat To Win Cup Yacht Series
description: HOBART, Australia, Jan. 19 (AP)  Adios, sailed by Nor man Booth of New South Wales, won the final heat to day to capture the Prince Philip Cup yacht series on the river Derent.

title: Nassau Police Get Pact And Cease Job Action
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 19 Nassau County policemen discontinued their job action today after the settlement early this morning of a con tract dispute with the county.

title: Manta Wins Coast Race
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPI)Manta finished strongly to win the $30,000added Santa Anita Handicap against a fast distaff field today, covering the seven furlongs in 1:22. The Elmendorf Farm mare, ridden by Laffit Pincay Jr., finished a length ahead of Howard B. Keck's Beja. Manta returned $5, $4 and $3.60 while Beja paid $7.80 and $6.40. Night Staker returned $17.40 to show.

title: HARVARD SETS BACK DARTMOUTH, 81 TO 75
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 19 Harvard withstood Dartmouth's late rally and posted an 8175 Ivy League basketball victory tonight at Alumni Gym.

title: News Analysis
description: In 1964, before any of its units began to perform at Lincoln Center for the Per forming Arts, the City Center had to fight for Its primacy in the control and use of the New York State Theater. Now City Center has agreed to take over the Vivian Beau mont Theater, remodel it and broaden its serv ices to embrace films. Those who were aware of the intensity of the behindthe scenes conflict in 1964, only part of which became public knowledge, must be struck by the irony of this new develop ment. For City Center, the constituent that was to be limited in its activities, now will have control of two of Lincoln Center's buildings and will carry on a range of pro gramming in opera, theater, dance and films that will make Lincoln Center more useful to additional segments of the community.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Norway Seeking to Exploit Oil
description: OSLO, NorwayThis sea faring nation, after waking up one morning to discover she held a winning lottery ticket in the form of an oil strike by foreign concerns, is now trying to figure how to exploit her newly found riches.

title: Stage: No, No, Nanette Is Back Alive
description: Nostalgia may prove to be the overriding emotion of the seventies, with remembrance of things past far more com fortable than the realization of things present. For every one who wishes the world were 50 years youngerand particularly, I suspect, for those who remember it when it was 50 years youngerthe revival of the 1925 musical No, No, Nanette should provide a delightful, carefree evening. It also has a certain amount of taste and imagi nation.

title: DEMOCRATS NAME ALBERT AND BOGGS TO TOP HOUSE JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Ignoring liberal demands for change, House Democrats chose Carl Albert of Oklahoma as Speaker today and Hale Boggs of Louisiana as majority leader.

title: 3 U. S. Sledders Hurt
description: CERVINIA, Italy, Jan. 19, (Reuters)  Three members of the American team were in jured today during practice ses sions for the world bobsled championships this weekend.

title: TEACHERS APPEAL IN I.S. 142 DISPUTE
description: A group of teachers who were transferred from Inter mediate School 142 in Queens after refusing to teach there during a parentorganized boy cott appealed yesterday to School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner to intervene in the continuing dispute. They said he could overrule the local school board.

title: Uruguay Minister Ousted; Failed to Find Kidnappers
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 19 (AP)Gen. Antonio Fran cese, who advocated a refusal to negotiate with political kid nappers, resigned as Interior Minister today at the request of President Jorge Pacheco Areco.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Gilmour, Back From Acapulco, Helps Warm Up Trotting Fans
description: YONKERS, Jan. 19  A tanned Buddy Gilmour re turned to action last night at, Yonkers Raceway and his ap pearance warmed things up for his fans.

title: Lithuanian in Soviet Doomed as Hijacker
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 19  A Lithuanian was reported to day to have been sentenced to death and his pregnant wife to three years in a prison camp for an attempt last November to hijack a plane from the Soviet Union to Sweden.

title: HOUSING LOAN LIMITS RAISED IN NEW RULES
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 19 (Reuters) Preston Martin, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, announced today three new regulations effective today.

title: Wool Commission In Australia Acts To Support Price
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 19  The Australian Wool Com mission, a Government agency, is buying about 25 per cent of the greasy wool offered at Aus tralian auctions at a reserve price in an attempt to halt the fall in prices in one of Aus tralia's most important export products.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The Super Bowl is a lamentable mem ory by now, but professional football builds such irresistible and enormous mo mentum these days that the avalanche has not quite stopped rolling down the moun tainside. It undoubtedly will come as a surprise to some of the more inattentive gridiron nuts to learn that there even will be an allstar game between the top per formers in each conference on Sunday in Los Angeles.

title: Aldrin Shift Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) The Air Force officially con firmed today reports that Col. Edwin E. Aldrin Jr., the sec ond man to set foot on the moon, would leave the astro naut program in July to head a research pilot school in Cali fornia. Colonel Aldrin, 41 years old, will remain with the Na tional Aeronautics and Space Administration until he takes over the special flying school at Edwards Air Force Base.

title: Israelis See Some Hope
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 19  Is rael's policymakers today wel comed what they viewed as evidence that Cairo was ready for the most serious attempt at peace negotiations since the ArabIsraeli war of 1967.

title: Air Being Checked for Lead Content
description: The city quietly began test ing the air inside a Manhattan apartment for lead yesterday after an infant living there was found to have higher than aver age concentrations of lead in her blood.

title: McLain's Pitch as Baritone Called Slightly Off Base
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Dressed in banker's gray set off by an electric blue shirt, the heavyset, blond singer arched back in the best Frank Sinatra fashion and began. I've got to be me , he sang, in a shaky, uncertain baritone, I've got to be me

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SHOW FIRM TONE
description: The London stock market closed slightly firmer yester day, after a weak opening.

title: 0.25% DiscountRate Cut Set by Japan for Today
description: TOKYO, Jan. 19Japan decided today to lower her dis count rale by 0.25 per cent to 5.75 per cent. The new rate will take effect tomorrow. The slash in the discount rate was made to cope with the latest series of cuts in the United States Federal Reserve discount rate. The discount rate is the interest charged member banks when they bor row from the central bank.

title: Foreign Policy: The Economic Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19De spite deteriorating economic relations between the United States and the two other great trading powersthe European Common Market and Japan the Nixon Administration has been unable in the last two years to develop a comprehen sive foreign economic policy.

title: Public Health Group Names Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Charles C. Johnson Jr., an Assistant Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, was named today as associ ate executive director of the American Public Health Asso ciation, effective Feb. 1.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 CHILDREN RESCUED IN BROOKLYN BLAZE
description: Fighting heavy smoke and flames and quickly forming ice, firemen rescued three children from the top floor of a burning threestory building in Brooklyn last night.

title: PRESIDENT BLOCKS CANAL IN FLORIDA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 President Nixon today ordered a halt to further construction of the CrossFlorida Barge Canal to prevent potentially serious environmental damage.

title: NEEDLES N PENS VICTOR IN FLORIDA
description: MIAMI, Jan. 19 (AP)  Needles n Pens, a nearwinner of the 1970 Belmont Stakes, made his first start in four months today in the eighth race at Hialeah and scored a dec sive victory.

title: City's Unit Signs Leases For 7 More Bet Parlors
description: Leases for seven more off track betting sites were signed yesterday, but it could be quite a while before the shops begin taking bets.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Kiernan Is Attacked
description: Angry policemen who dis agreed with their delegates de cision that they return to work stormed out of the ballroom of the New Yorker Hotel yester day with such fury that the top of the door frame was torn out. It sounded like a rifle shot.

title: SOVIET CHARGES U.S. CONNIVANCE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 19  The United States today rejected Soviet and Iraqi diplomats charges of American connivance in the harassment of their missions by demonstra tors.

title: Istanboul in Rehearsal
description: Rochelle Owens's new play, Istanboul,' has gone into re hearsal for a Feb. 8 opening at the Actor's Playhouse. Miss Owens was last represented with Futz. Heading the cast of Istanboul' is the Greek actress Despo seen in such films here as Never On Sun day, and Topkapi. On Broadway she was in Cabaret and Ilya Darling.

title: COUNCIL FINISHING TAXI LEGISLATION
description: The possibility that the drop on a New York taxi meter might decline from the present 45 cents for the first fifth of a mile  rather than rise  remained alive yester day after a City Council com mittee came close to complet ing action on revision of the fare structure.

title: Market Place : Ground Leases At Penn central
description: Are the trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company, which is now in reorganization, asking them selves if there is gold in them thar acres lining Park Ave nue?

title: Heath Offer Reported
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 19 (Reu iters)Prime Minister Heath re portedly produced a peace seeking formula today offering to restrict any arms deals with South Africa to a replaceand maintain basis.

title: Jacksonville Coach Accuses Powers of Alibiing
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla, Jan. 18 (UPI)  Tom Wasdin, Jack sonville University's basketball coach, today accused the Man hattan College coach, Jack Powers, of alibiing and reaching for straws in his complaints about Manhattan's failure to beat Jacksonville with a freeze.

title: EXBRITISH STAR GETS SOCCER POST
description: New York's entry in the North American Soccer League named Gordon Bradley yester day as coach of the new fran chise, which joined eight others early last month.

title: SENATE'S LEADERS APPROVE REFORMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  The Senate leadership has de cided to implement in the new Congress some procedural re forms designed to hold down oratory and absenteeism and step up the pace of legislative action.

title: Muskie's Reaction
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Mr. Muskie said today that Mr. McGovern's action would foster intelligent discussion of campaign issues.

title: U.S Acknowledges a Rise In Cambodian Air Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  The White House today ac knowledged a recent stepup in the type and intensity of Amer ican air operations in Cambodia, but insisted that Administra tion policy had not changed from the guidelines laid down by President Nixon last summer.

title: OIL COUNTRIES FIRM ON A PRICE INCREASE
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 19 (UPI) Oilproducing countries con tinued to demand increased prices today in talks with major petroleum companies aimed at averting a showdown that could deprive Western Europe and Japan of their major source of fuel.

title: TAYLOR LAW BARS STRIKE AMNESTY
description: The state's Taylor Law man dates that Mayor Lindsay im pose penalties against all policemen who violated the statute's prohibition against strikes by public employes.

title: Heckscher Backs Metropolitan Museum's Plan
description: The Metropolitan Museum's controversial master plan has been approved by August Heck scher, the city's Parks, Recre ational and Cultural Affairs Ad ministrator.

title: AMEX RISES A BIT IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: The American Stock Ex change finished slightly higher yesterday in fairly active trading.

title: Importer of Race Horses Accused of Duties' Fraud
description: In an episode that might have come straight out of a Dick Francis novel, a major importer of race horses was charged yesterday with having defrauded the Government of more than $100,000 in duties by underdeclaring their value.

title: RALPH C. HAWLEY, TAUGHT FORESTRY
description: SUN CITY, Ariz., Jan. 19 Ralph C. Hawley, Morris K. Jesup Professor Emeritus of Silviculture at the Yale Univer sity School of Forestry, died here today. He was 90 years old.

title: Xerox Profits Up in 4th Quarter;
description: The Xerox Corporation real ized a 12.9 per cent gain in net income in the fourth quarter on an increase in revenues of 15.7 per cent, the company reported yesterday.

title: Stay at Downbeat Gives New Scope To Carrie Smith
description: Carrie Smith, a singer with a dark, lustrous voice and a repertory that ranges from ob scure blues and old pop tunes to contemporary rock, has been in town several times before but she has never had as good an opportunity to show her performing personality as she has now at the Downbeat, Lex ington Avenue at 42d Street.

title: News Analysis
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19Shortly after American troops went into Cambodia for two months last spring to join South Vietnamese forces in attacking enemy supply bases, President Nixon said at a news conference that when we come out our logistical support and air support will also come out with them.

title: In the 28th, Resentment Marks Return
description: Grudgingly and with mixed feelings, patrolmen of the 28th Precinct returned to work yes terday.

title: Dubai Oil Tax Rate Up 5%
description: The Continental Oil Company and other companies with inter ests in the offshore waters of Dubai agreed yesterday to an increase in the tax rate by the Persian Gulf sheikdom from 50 per cent to 55 per cent.

title: American Airlines to Reduce Flights
description: In another example of airline retrenchment because of the nation's sluggish economy, American Airlines said yester day that its flight schedule ef fective March 2 would offer 18 per cent fewer daily depart ures on eight routes than it did a year ago.

title: Executioner Takes Hibiscus in a 3Horse Photo Finish
description: MIAMI, Jan. 20A crowd of 15,048 made the October House Farm's Executioner a 910 favorite in the $32,350 Hibiscus at Hialeah and they got him home. But before they collected, they had plenty of worries.

title: TV: Big Bands Swing on Nostalgic Griffin Show
description: If Broadway firstnighters tapped a toe to Tea for Two in the revival of No, No, Nanette, television viewers also have had two evenings of nostalgia in a warm, tuneful and entertain ing remembrance of the league of forgotten men  the leaders of the Big Bands of yesteryear.

title: WINGATE DEFENDS HARLEM NUMBERS
description: Livingston L. Wingate, the executive director of the Ur ban League, told Howard J. Samuels yesterday not to mess with the numbers in Harlem when he brought offtrack bet ting to the black community.

title: Braves Rout Blazers, 126106
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 20 (UPI) The Buffalo Braves rushed to a 16point lead in the first 9 min utes tonight and thrashed the Portland Trail Blazers, 126106.

title: Pope Urges Understanding
description: ROME, Jan. 20Pope Paul VI said today that the Roman Catholic Church must over come an ancient, closed and diffident mentality toward other Christians and make an effort to understand them.

title: ST. JOHN'S DOWNS SETON HALL, 8870
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 20There was no lack of visit ing heroes tonight as four St. John's players scored double figures to lead the Redmen to an 8870 victory over Seton Hall before 2,762 fans in Walsh Auditorium.

title: In Snowy Town, 9 Below May Be the High
description: MUNICH, N. D.  As the cold teeth of January gnaw away at the nation, and New Yorkers shiver in nearzero weather, the spare frame houses of Munich sit huddled together as if for warmth amid the snowcovered wheat fields on the frozen prairie of northeastern North Dako ta. This is the coldest town in the contiguous states of the nation.

title: KnoxJohnston Maintains Lead in Yacht Race to Rio
description: CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 20 (AP)Robin Knox Johnston, the British yachts man, maintained his lead today on the fifth day of the Cape towntoRio de Janeiro race. His 71foot ketch, Ocean Spirit, was spotted some time after midday 830 miles north west of Capetown ahead of the other 56 yachts remaining in a starting fleet of 58. Ocean Spirit improved her handicap position to fifth after being in 16th place yesterday.

title: Men in the News
description: John J. Loflin Jr., who is arguing the city's case in the policeparity trial, has one of the busier jobs in the Lindsay administration, for which he serves as litigating assistant corporation counsel the city's standup law yer.

title: Advertising:
description: A couple of Madison Avenue's better known public relations men  George C. Whipple Jr. and Walter Carlson are striking out on their own to form Whipple & Carlson Associates. (Where did they ever think of a name like that?)

title: Martin Is Chosen to Study Rules of Stock Exchange
description: William McChesney Martin Jr., former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and one of the nation's foremost financial experts, has agreed to undertake a searching exam ination of the rules and pro cedures of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE ANNOTATED WALDEN. Walden; or, Life in the Woods. By Henry D. Thoreau. Together With Civil Disobedience, Detailed Chronology and Various Pieces About Its Author, the Writing and Publish ing of the Book. Edited, with an introduc tion, notes, and bibliography by Philip Van Doren Stern. 502 pages. Illustrated with maps, portraits, photographs, manuscript pages, drawings and decorations. Clarkson N. Potter. $10.95.

title: Mobil Oil Profits at Peak;
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation had increases of 5.7 per cent in annual earnings and 7.5 per cent in the fourth quarter, set ting records, Rawleigh Warner Jr., chairman, reported yester day.

title: Patterson and Bonavena Fight at Garden in April
description: The Oscar BonavenaFloyd Patterson heavyweight fight, postponed from Feb. 12 when Bonavena injured his left hand in training Tuesday in Buenos Aires, will be re scheduled for the first week in April. Harry Markson, Madison Square Garden's di rector of boxing, said the date would be announced later.

title: I. D. S. Discloses It Seeks Big Board Membership
description: Investors Diversified Services, Inc., the nation's largest mutualfund organization, disclosed yesterday that it had applied for membership on the New York Stock Exchange through a brokeragehouse subsidiary, Jefferies & Co., Inc.

title: Jockey Club ReElects Ogden Phipps Chairman
description: Ogden Phipps was re elected yesterday to his eighth term as chairman of The Jockey Club.

title: Court Hears Plea to Bar Army Spying on Civilians
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) An attorney for the Ameri can Civil Liberties Union argued today before a United States Court of Appeals that the Army had no business investigating civilian protest activities.

title: Mexico Names Envoy to U.S.
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 20 (UPI) President Luis Echeverria has named Jose Juan de Olloqui, financier, as ambassador to Washington.

title: Pro Golfers' Theme: By the Time I Get to Phoenix
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 20  The $125,000 Phoenix open, which gets under way tomor row over the flat and comfort able Arizona Country Club course, is expected to lift the morale of many of golf's tour ing professionals.

title: Dry Back at Tulsa
description: TULSA, Jan. 20 (UPI)  F. A. Dry was named yesterday athletic director of Tulsa Uni versity. Dry, an assistant coach with the Houston Oilers, re signed yesterday to return to Tulsa, where he previously was an assistant coach.

title: WALKOUT HALTS MAILS IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Jan. 20Britain's first national Post Office strike shut off all mail service today, but telephones worked reason ably well.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: F. HARRY JACKSON
description: F. Harry Jackson, formerly of Plandome, L. I., an insurance man here since 1907, died Fri day in Navesink House, Red Bank, N. J., after a short ill ness. He was 87 years old.

title: Joan London Miller, 70; Daughter of the Novelist
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI)  Joan London Miller, daughter of Jack London, the American novelist, and widow of Charles Miller, a stone worker, died Monday after an illness of two months. She was 70 years old.

title: BankAmericard in Spain
description: The Bank of America an nounced yesterday that the Banco de Bilbao, with 430 branches, will soon begin issu ing a Banco de Bilbao Bank Americard, the first bank credit card in Spain.

title: Kill the Pigs!And Government
description: The paramount duty of government is to supply law and order so that citizens are secure in their lives and lawful pursuits. A minority may pro test that the law and order provided do not do justice; but the majority must think otherwise in a democracy, else it would not consent. Certainly justice should be more, but it cannot be less, anywhere, than law and order. Hence the government's first task.

title: LANDMARKS UNIT OPPOSED MUSEUM
description: A Landmarks Preservation Commission report made last September and labeled con fidential recommended the re jection of the present design of the Metropolitan Museum's proposed Lehman pavilion and vigorously objects to other alterations of the museum's western facade, occasioned by the proposed reconstruction of the Temple of Dendur.

title: Telephone Test
description: The statewide strike of telephone repairmen and installers represents a fundamental test of the integrity of the parent Communications Workers of America, a test the international union has failed miserably so far.

title: 10 Years After the Kennedy Inaugural, a Political Belief Survives
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 There was no mantle of snow on the Capitol today. There were no reviewing stands along Pennsylvania Avenue. No top hats. No lectern with short circuited wiring belching smoke while the harshvoiced prince of the church tried to pray.

title: Gregg Leaves Packers' Post To Enter Business in Dallas
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Jan. 20 (AP)  Forrest Gregg, a 14 year standout with the Green Bay Packers who doubled as player and assistant coach the last three years, is resigning to enter business in Dallas.

title: Erin Martin Offers 2 Unusual Dances In Bill at La Mama
description: Erin Martin, the dancer and choreographer, prepared two works given at LaMama Tues day evening that were on the border of drama and dance and that seemed to combine the worst features of both. The dancers didn't dance enough and spoke far too much.

title: A Drawbridge Sticks Open in Jersey
description: People can cope with the cold; machinery cannot.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by major shareholders, directors and officers of listed companies. They include the following:

title: Coast Guard Concedes It Did Not Report an Oil Spill
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Jan. 20 (AP)The Coast Guard con ceded today that it did not di vulge the existence of a large oil spill from one of its own cutters cruising off the Atlantic Coast earlier this month.

title: JAMES L. LOOMIS, 92, INSURANCE OFFICER
description: GRANBY, Conn., Jan. 20 James Lee Loomis, retired board chairman of the Connec ticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, died yesterday in Hartford Hospital after a brief illness. He was 92 years old.

title: Candor Toward the Press
description: WASHINGTONTension between the Washington press corps and the President of the United States is chronic though it varies in degree from time to time and President to President. It is as necessary and crea tive a tension as that between Presi dent and Congress or Congress and Supreme Court. We are constantly told that a President has no obliga tion to hold news conferences. He has an inescapable obligation to do so, since he cannot be summoned by either Congress or the Court, and can, in this age of electronics, argue his own case uninterrupted to the whole nation directly, and at times and un der circumstances of his own choosing.

title: Britain Wins Compromise On Arms for South Africa
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 20Britain and her Commonwealth partners worked out an arrangement today leaving Britain free to supply arms to South Africa while establishing a Commonwealth study group to consider the question further.

title: Personal Finance
description: There's a speedup ahead for executors, lawyers, ac countants and bereaved rela tives, and they probably won't like it. In fact, some intense planning may be in order for many people.

title: T. W. A. Reports Net Loss
description: Trans World Airlines, Inc., reported yesterday a consoli dated net loss of $63.9million for 1970 in contrast to 1969 earnings of $19.8million, or $1.63 a share.

title: Mondale Writes President On Thais Reported in Laos
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20Sen ator Walter F. Mondale wrote President Nixon today asking for clarification of reports that United Statestrained Thai troops were operating against Communist supply lines in southern Laos.

title: LAIRD JUSTIFIES WIDENED AIR WAR TO AID CAMBODIANS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird today invoked the twoyearold Nixon Doctrine and a recent military aid bill to provide the rationale and authority for the expanded use of American air power in Cam bodia.

title: MISS JACOT FIRST IN DOWNHILL RACE
description: SCHRUNS, Austria, Jan. 20 (UPI)The French World Cup holder, Michele Jacot, streaked away today with the opening downhill event of the Golden Key women's ski meet to con tinue France's near monopoly of Alpine ski honors this sea son.

title: Merger News
description: Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., the world's largest producer of pri mary aluminum, announced yesterday it has agreed in principle to acquire the busi ness and assets of the Elixir Industries of Gardena, Calif., for 670,000 Alcan common shares.

title: Legislature Calls on Nixon To Start Revenue Sharing
description: ALBANY, Jan. 20The State Legislature urged the Nixon Administration today to imple ment promptly proposals for a system of direct Federal rev enue sharing with the states.

title: MARKET EDGES UP IN HEAVY VOLUME
description: The stock market, confound ing Wall Street chartists by re fusing to stumble on its tight rope, inched forward again yes terday.

title: Colotai Leaves Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 20 (AP) Rich Lolotai, allNew England and allIvy League middle guard at Yale, has withdrawn from school for personal reasons, the university said today.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O, BACKS HEALTH COVERAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The A.F.L.C.I.O. joined today with four of the major indepen dent trade unions to back revised national health insur ance proposal.

title: Escalation in the Air
description: The only American activity in Cambodia after July 1, President Nixon assured the nation last June, will be air missions to interdict the movement of enemy troops and material where I find that is necessary to protect the lives and security of our men in South Vietnam.

title: Jersey Man Held in Slaying Of His Father and Brother
description: EDISON TOWNSHIP, N. J., Jan. 20 (AP)A. 20yearold man with a history of mental illness killed his father and brother with a machete in an early morning rampage today, the police reported.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Cudahy Company has announced that Fred erick T. Barrett was elected president and chief executive officer. Mr. Barrett, who had been execu tive vice president, replaces Elias Paul who resigned. The United Brands Company announced that Mr. Paul was elected president of John Morrell & Co., a subsidiary.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POSTS PROFIT RISE
description: The American Electric Power Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday an 8.2 per cent gain in earnings for the fourth quarter of 1970. The pre liminary report placed net in come at $30,338,000, equal to 57 cents a share, up from $28, 050,000, or 56 cents a share, in the similar period of 1969.

title: Fines Against Police Have Long Way to Go
description: Mayor Lindsay's invoca tion of the Taylor Law against policemen who had staged a wildcat strike began a complicated procedure that could lead to a loss of pay for participants in the strike.

title: Foreign Policy: Pentagon Also Encounters Rebuffs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20  Though the Defense Department remains the largest, richest and most formidable Government agency, it, like other agencies, has lost to the Nixon White House some of its influence on foreign policy.

title: G.I's Reported on Ground
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 21 (AP)It was reliably reported today that American advisers and South Vietnamese officers were travel ing together on command and control helicopters in Cam bodia and periodically setting foot on the ground  despite Pentagon assertions to the con trary.

title: With Seconds Remaining, and the Game All but Won, Fortune Frowns on the Flyers
description: With the crowd 19 seconds away from booing what ap peared to be the Rangers' third straight defeat, Rod Gilbert poked the puck into the Flyers' net and lifted the New Yorkers to a 33 draw and a tumultuous standing ovation last night.

title: More Restrictions Placed on College Football Blocking to Reduce Injuries
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Jan. 20 (UPI)The National Colle giate Athletic Association Foot ball Rules Committee tightened restrictions today against crackback and spear block ing and further limited the num ber of timeouts.

title: STOCKS MIXED ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market closed mixed yesterday and trading was slack, mainly due to the break in communications caused by the postal strike.

title: Ailey Dancers Set Russians Cheering
description: The dance company that wowed them in Voroshilov grad last fall is back from its outoftown tour and play ing Broadway, at the ANTA Theater.

title: City Planning Board Backs Use Of Lofts as Artists' Residences
description: Deciding that art and manu facturing can exist as neigh bors, the City Planning Com mission voted yesterday to le galize the residential use of in dustrial lofts by artists in a 43block area of lower Man hattan.

title: DISMEMBERED BODY IS SHIPPED TO MIAMI
description: The dismembered body of a man, shipped from New York City on Monday in four suit cases via the Greyhound Pack age Express, was found yester in the bus terminal in down town Miami.

title: Daniel Berrigan Linked to Plea To Weathermen for Nonviolence
description: A taperecorded message to; the Weatherman underground, attributed to the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, pleads with the rad ical group to return to non violence, warning that: No principle is worth the sacrifice of a single human being.

title: LEONE PRESENTS A PRIORITIES LIST
description: Brooklyn's new Borough Pres ident, Sebastian Leone, said yes terday that new housing, jobs and the early construction of two spurs to existing subway lines were among the priorities he had set for the borough.

title: BUCKS TURN BACK BULLETS, 120116
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 20 (UPI) Bob Boozer sank a pair of free throws with 3 seconds left to clinch the Milwaukee Bucks' 10th straight victory, a 120116 decision over the Baltimore Bullets tonight. A sellout crowd of 12,289 saw the National Basketball Association game.

title: Census Figures for Counties in State
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20Following are the Census Bureau's final 1970 population counts for counties and major cities in New York., State. The percentage changes from 1960 are gains unless otherwise indicated.

title: SENIORITY SYSTEM REVISED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20  After years of prodding by re formers, House Democrats and Republicans both agreed today to modify the rigid seniority system by which members automatically rise to positions of power.

title: SHIELDS REPORTS 1970 PROFIT DROP
description: Shields & Co., a leading se curities house, disclosed annual financial results yesterday for the first time in its 48year history. It reported that net in come declined sharply in the bearmarket year of 1970.

title: Report Is Discounted
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 20  A spokesman for they United States command said today there was nothing new about a report yesterday that the United States was using helicopters for direct combat support of Laotian Government troops. The report, by The Associated Press, was published in The New York Times today.

title: Study Suggests a Big Reduction In Central Park Subway Digging
description: A consultants' report has recommended a tremendous reduction in the area of Cen tral Park that must be torn up for construction of a sub way connection.

title: UNREST DECLINING IN POLAND'S PORTS
description: WARSAW, Jan. 20  Work er unrest in Poland's northern coastal cities declined today in the aftermath of yesterday's meeting between Edward Gie rek, the Communist party lead er, and a delegation of ship yard workers.

title: Text of Egypt's Memorandum to Jarring
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan, 20  Following is the text of an Egyptian memo randum handed to Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring on Jan. 15 and transmitted today to this month's President of the Se curity Council, Sir Colin Crowe of Britain, by Dr. Mo hammed H. elZayyat with the request that it be circu lated as an official document of the Security Council.

title: NIXON'S NEW PLAN FOR TAX SHARING GIVES CITIES MORE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The Administration's new plan for sharing Federal tax revenues with state and local govern ments will give the latter a pro portionally much larger share of the money than the original proposal, a key Government official disclosed today.

title: Finland Offers a Successor for Thant
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan, 20  Finland today pro posed the candidacy of Max Ja kobson, her delegate here, to succeed U Thant as Secretary General nest year. Endorsement is expected quickly from the other Nordic states  Sweden, Norway, Iceland and Denmark.

title: Charges Disputed By Coast Exchange
description: The president of the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange disputed yesterday charges that regional stock exchanges were frag menting the nation's securities markets.

title: Soviet Aide Says Siberian Fields Will Help Outstrip U.S. in Oil Production
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 20  The Soviet Union's petroleum min ister predicted today that his country would overtake the United States and become the leading oilproducing nation.

title: IN THE NATION
description: At least one casual visitor in New York during the police job action would not have known it was going on if he hadn't read about it in the papers. Cab drivers said traffic was no better and no worse than usual and life in the streets, stores and res taurants of Manhattan appeared about as alwaysnoisy, tense, but under a sort of tacit internal control that was loose but effective.

title: PHILLIPS INCREASES PRICES FOR RESINS
description: The Phillips Petroleum Com pany said yesterday that it had reduced prices on three of its highdensity polyethylene resins used in the manufacture of plas tic bottles, tapes and toys.

title: Penn Wins 14th in Row
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (UPI)Fourthranked Pennsyl vania, led by the clutch shoot ing of Dave Wohl, Bob Morse and Steve Bilsky, rallied in the second half tonight for a 6248 victory over Temple.

title: Saigon Sets Tet CeaseFire
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 21 (Reuters) South Vietnamese troops will observe a 24hour ceasefire at Tet, the lunar new year holi day, a Foreign Ministry spokes man said today. The truce will start at 6 P.M. local time Jan. 26 and end at the same time the following day.

title: Shop Talk
description: One can scarcely walk along the street today without encountering young persons in the guise of peasants, In dians, girls of the Golden West and so forth. And anyone wandering around the seventh floor of Abraham & Straus will come across similar themes in home furnishings, in the six model rooms that opened Monday. Perhaps the prettiest of the rooms is an allwhite modern one with the bright color fur nished by a col lection of peas ant art from around the world. Lively tones dot the room in the form of batik or wool paintings, a people and camelfigured Tunisian wool rug ($700), a huge red tin tea bin that doubles as storage ($395), a charming appliqu hanging of chickens and roosters ($100), and all sorts of painted boxes, bas ketry, ceramics and so forth.

title: Ross an Aide at Rice
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 20 (AP)  Bill Peterson, new Rice Uni versity football coach, complet ed his staff today by adding Bob Ross as a defensive assist ant. Ross, 34, had been an as sistant coach at William and Mary the last four years.

title: Shouts Halt Council Meeting Before Vote on Newark Taxes
description: NEWARK, Jan. 20A City Council meeting broke up in confusion tonight before action could be taken on Mayor Ken neth A. Gibson's special state approved tax package.

title: Art: Trends of the Paris School
description: The work of two of the most renowned artists of the School of ParisHenri Lau rens (18851954) and Georges Braque (18821963)is the subject of a new exhibition that opened yesterday at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle. Laurens, who dominates the show, is represented by more than 60 sculptures and some 50 or more works .on, paper. (draw ings, prints and illustrated books). Braque, more modest estly, is represented by 14 Paintings and five small sculptures.

title: Buckley Undecided on Backing Javits
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20As Senator Jacob K. Javits pressed his case today to question the admission of Senatorelect James L. Buckley into the cau cus of Republican Senators, Mr. Buckley left open the matter of whether he would support Mr. Javits for reelection in 1974.

title: Sierra Club Opposes Morton
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 (UPI)The Sierra Club opposed today the confirmation by the United States Senate of Rogers C. B. Morton, President Nixon's nominee for Secretary of the Interior. The club Criticized Mr. Morton's conservation record.

title: 4 More Officers Seek U.S. War Crimes Inquiry
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 Four young military officers today called for an investiga tion of the responsibility of Gen. William C. Westmoreland, Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt and other United States military leaders for war crimes in In dochina.

title: Egyptians Disclose Reply To Proposals of Israelis
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan, 20The United Arab Re public, reacting to what its of ficials regard as deliberate Israeli press leaks, today made public the text of the Egyptian answer to the Israeli position in the indirect Arab  Israeli peace talks.

title: Hanoi Issues List of Raids; Defoliation Flights Alleged
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 20 (Agence France  Presse) North Vietnam today published, what it called a detailed list of recent United States air raids on North Vietnam. The raids, in the view of military experts here, are aimed at com pletely isolating North Vietnam from South Vietnam.

title: High School Loses Its Complaint Table
description: The operation of a contro versial parentmanned table at George Washington High School, set up last May to re ceive and channel student com plaints, has been quietly sus pended and its future is now in doubt.

title: Discount Rate in Denmark Reduced From 9% to 8%
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 20The Danish central bank reduced the bank rate by 1 per cent to 8 per cent today, the first change since May 12, 1969, when the rate was increased by 2 per cent as an emergency measure after national ex change reserves were exhausted.

title: The Soaring Cost of State Mall Is Up Another $130.4Million
description: ALBANY, Jan. 20  The rising cost of building the sprawling Capital Mall project here was indicated today in Governor Rockefeller's annual deficiency budget, which sought $130.4million in addi tional mall funding.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MAYOR INVOKES POLICE PENALTIES; NO DOCKING, SAYS P.B.A. LEADER; MURPHY TO SUSPEND ANY WHO BALK
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city was invoking mandatory penalties against patrolmen who had engaged in a wildcat strike, and the Police Commissioner promptly threatened to suspend any policeman henceforth re fusing assigned duty.

title: AMEX GAINS AGAIN AS VOLUME RISES
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange moved higher yester day as the list scored its eighth consecutive gain in fairly active trading.

title: Chess:There Are Pros and Cons To Using French Defense
