description: Governor Rockefeller's proposed budget for the State of New York underscores his appeal for the immediate enactment of a massive, nostringsattached, Federal revenuesharing scheme, far greater in allocation of new money than the figure mentioned by President Nixon in his State of the Union address last night.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDONWe have just completed nine weeks touring American univer sities and debating as representatives of Oxford University, England, Both of us are supporters of Edward Heath's Conservative Government in Britain, and we arrived with deep prejudices against America's radical student movement.

title: State Law Extends Board of Education For Another Year
description: Governor Rockefeller signed into law yesterday a bill again extending the life of the city's interim Board of Education for a year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Volume Sets Mark As Stocks Record Another Advance
description: The booming bull market in stocks scored still another ad vance yesterday as the volume on the New York Stock Ex change set a record of 21.68 million shares.

title: Police Sketch 2 Suspects in Slaying
description: The Police Department distributed the composite sketches yesterday of two suspects being sought in the slaying Wednesday night of a 67yearold woman in an apartment elevator in Brook lyn.

title: The Film Love Story Is Given Presidential Seal of Approval
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  Owners of theaters showing the film Love Story can post a new recommendation on their marquees tomorrow: I recom mend it  R.M.N.

title: Glossary of Terms
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Following is a glossary of technical terms important to an understanding of the President's program, as outlined in his State of the Union Message:

title: Market Place: Trends Aiding Insurer Stocks
description: William R. Spaulding was down from Boston crisply extolling the virtues of insur ance company stocks. What's that you say? How can these companies make worthwhile investments what with all the riots, hurricanes, auto accidents, and, in the life field, lots of lowcost policy loans outstanding?

title: Rockefeller to Ask For Tax Exclusion On Lower Incomes
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22Governor Rockefeller is expected to ask the Legislature to eliminate state income tax payments for about 700,000 taxpayers earn ing $5,000 a year or less.

title: Brazil Names Envoy to U.S.
description: BRASILIA, Jan. 22 (UPI) Appointment of Joo Augusto de Araujo Castro as Brazilian Ambassador to the United States was announced today. He will succeed Mozart Gurgel Valente, who died last month.

title: Oscar Lion, Leading Collector Of Whitman Poems, Dies at 94
description: Oscar Lion, a leading col lector of the works of Walt Whitman, 19thcentury Ameri can poet, died yesterday at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hos pitals. He was 94 years old and lived at 211 Central Park West.

title: 6Month Curb on Travel by Rostropovich Reported
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 22  Mstis lav Rostropovich, the cellist. was reported today to have been barred by Soviet author ities from traveling abroad for at least the next six months, presumably because of his pub lic denunciation of Soviet cul tural policy and his vigorous defense of Aleksandr Solzhen itsyn's right to receive the 1970 Nobel Prize for Literature.

title: Boston Fete: History and Champagne
description: BOSTON, Jan. 22  Old Back Bay railroad station, once bustling with Peabodys. Lowells and Cabots, and al so Fitzgeralds, Volpes and McCormacks, regained for a few hours tonight, in a fashion, some of its lost splendor.

title: BARRING OF WHITES QUERIED AT HARVARD
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 22 Harvard's Commission of In quiry, a university grievance committee, is investigating charges that 50 to 100 white persons were excluded from a public speech held last night in Harvard's Sanders Theater.

title: 3 ARE DEAD IN FIRE, 2 OF THEM CHILDREN
description: Two small children were killed in a fire in the Bedford Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn last night, and an elderly wom an died in another fire on the Upper East Side.

title: Week's Auto Output Steady
description: DETROIT, Jan. 22 (UPI) Heavy overtime at General Motors Corporation plants kept production by the Big Four auto makers this week almost at the same level as last week, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22A member of the International Business Machines Corpora tion research staff has in vented a technique that makes two small astronomical telescopes as powerful as a much larger one. For in stance, two 20 inch telescopes, installed in an orbiting satel lite, could get as clear a pic ture of a distant star as is possible with the largest tele scope, the 200inch reflector on Mount Palomar in Cali fornia. Dr. Janusz S. Wil czynski of the I.B.M. research division in Yorktown, N.Y., was granted Patent 3,556,630 this week for the method and apparatus.

title: Sato Stresses Desire for Better Relations With Peking
description: TOKYO, Jan. 22  Premier Eisaku Sato reiterated today his Government's desire to im prove relations with the Chi nese Communists and referred to their country for the first time as the People's Republic of China.

title: 81to1 Shot Helps Set Up $2,252 Fair Grounds Double
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 22 (AP)  A daily double payoff of $2,252, completed when an 811 shot romped home in the second race, was registered today at the New Orleans Fair Grounds.

title: Ecuador Is Said to Seize Two More U.S. Tuna Boats
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 22 (Reu ters)Ecuador today seized two more American tuna boats, bringing the total to 13 ves sels in the last 11 days, Ed Silva, president of the Amer ican Tuna Boat Association, said.

title: 61st National Boat Show Opens, Today at Coliseum
description: The 61st National Boat Show will open today at 10 A.M. at the Coliseum, with Mayor Lindsay expected to do the usual honors, accom panied by his son, John Jr.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: A RADICAL THREAT TO MEDICINE SEEN
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 23 A major American Jewish human rights organization said today that a growing radical leftist movement within the medical profession posed a threat of disruption and in stability for medical and so cial service institutions.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Dealers Assail Legislation
description: ALBANYNew legislation designed to protect the boat buyer is going to torpedo the credit structure of the boating industry in the slate, dealers are charging.

title: Black Capitalist
description: When the Johnson Prod ucts Company, Inc., of Chi cago was listed on the Ameri can Stock Exchange 10 days ago, there were a number of marks that distinguished it from the rest of the season's new offerings.

title: J. G. Fogg 3d Marries Leslie Solbert
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Jan. 23Miss Leslie Kirk Solbert and Joseph Graham Fogg 3d were mar ried here this afternoon at St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. T. Carlton Lee.

title: Blues Sink Sabres, 71
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 23 (UPI) Bill Roberts scored two goals and assisted on another tonight to lead the St. Louis Blues to a 71 victory that ended the Buf falo Sabres' unbeaten streak at four games.

title: Boatkeeping, She Says, Can Be Fun
description: Myrtle Corbman has her own Women's Lib movement under way. As the executive design consultant for Chris Craft, she is easing the bur den of boatkeeping for women.

title: Weather Aids and Charts Helping Boatmen Displayed
description: The exhibit of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration at the boat show features the nautical charts and weather aids pro vided by the Commerce De partment agency for the safety of the nation's recre ational boatmen.

title: New 23Foot Crestliner
description: A new 23foot fiberglass runabout, featuring a cuddy cabin and a deepV hull, and two modifiedV runabouts, are in the Crestliner exhibit at the show. They are sharing the booth with the largest of the company's trihull series, the 17foot Muskie.

title: REVENUE SHARING IS BACKED IN POLL
description: The concept of revenue shar ing, in which a percentage of Federal income tax receipts are shared with state and local governments, has overwhelm ing public support, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Cambodian Planes Aloft
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 23 (Reuters)Two Cambodian propellerdriven T28 fighter bombers circled over Pnompenh today in an apparent effort to reassure residents that the Government still had some air power.

title: Police Use Helicopter in Search For Man Who Killed Patrolman
description: The police used a helicopter yesterday to help search back yards and rooftops in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn for the possibly wounded gunman who killed an offduty patrol man Friday night.

title: Hot Line Carries Immediate Help In Emergencies
description: What powerboat owner hasn't at one time or another found himself miles from a friendly marina, in the hands of a strange boat repair yard and with nobody capable of diagnosing the cause of his craft's breakdown?

title: Son for Mrs. Smith
description: A son was born Dec. 15 to Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan Leslie Smith of New York at Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Smith is the former Miss Elinor John ston of Old Lyme, Conn. Her husband is a partner and managing director of Lehman Brothers, Inc., in vestment bankers. The child has been named Jonathan Quincy.

title: John Bentley Jr. Weds Miss Waldinger
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., Jan. 23  Miss Dorothy Davidson Waldinger, daughter of Mrs. Robert Hilgers Waldinger of Dover and the late Dr. Wal dinger, was married here this afternoon to John Charles Bentley Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Bentley of Elizabeth, N. J., and Osterville. The Rev. William Hawley Clark performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: Werther Revival Planned by the Met During 23d Week
description: Massenet's Werther which has not been performed by the Metropolitan Opera for 61 years, be revived by the company in a new production during the 23d week of the current season.

title: Inexcusable Oil Spills
description: Two tanker accidents that have spilled hundreds of thousands of gallons of oil on both Atlantic and Pacific coasts, in Connecticut and California, offer dismaying examples of the carelessness of major oil companies in handling their product in spite of mounting evidence of the disastrous ecological consequences of such spillages.

title: Patriots Choose First Thursday in Pro Draft
description: The Boston Patriots, who finished the 1970 season with the worst record in the Na tional Football League, are scheduled to make the first selection in the college draft here on Thursday.

title: Bourguiba Flies to Europe
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia, who was admitted to Walter Reed Hospital for medi cal tests 16 days ago, departed by air today for Switzerland, where his medical treatment will continue.

title: Deborah Crow, Becomes Bride
description: RYE, N.Y., Jan. 23Miss Deborah Montgomery Crow and Peter Westbrook Mills were married here this after noon in Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. Wendell Phillips.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Mississippi was described as a diamond in the rough economically in a recent, bluntly worded speech de livered to a group of busi nessmen by Taylor Webb, president of the Mississippi Economic Council, the larg est statewide business or ganization in Mississippi.

title: Boatmen's Cooperation Sought by City's Harbor Police
description: Whenever the Harbor Po lice pull a drowning man or a corpse out of New York's chilly waters, or grapple for five days in the freezing cold for a piece of evidence such as a gun, Sgt. Howard Smith of the unit likes to take out his notebook and pass arnong the curious onlookers on shore. With a wry smile, he asks:

title: Sabich Defeats Pyles in Final of Mount Snow Cup Slalom for Professionals
description: MOUNT SNOW, Jan. 23 Spider Sabich, who fared poorly early this season as a member of the United States ski team, scored a stunning victory in the final of a professional slalom today, but said the com petition was actually tougher than that he faced on the amateur circuit.

title: It's not so much fun to go home again
description: THE signs were there, all right. The little photography studio on the corner of Harvey and 116th Street, where I had looked at the latest brides, their lips retouched deep red and eyebrows dark, was now a karate and judo school. A storefront church, Pilgrim Rest B. C., was on 93d Street near Dickens. Protective grates guarded the front of Rosenbluth's, our local clothing store, whose recorded Santa Claus laugh had scared the patched corduroy pants right off me as a youngster. A public housing project rose from the mud. And in the streets there was a stillness.

title: Rhona Marks Is Betrothed
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 23 The engagement of Miss Rhona Ann Marks to Special ist 4 Andrew Smulian, U.S.A., son of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan Smulian of Bordentown, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Milton Alfred Marks of Dayton. A wedding in the spring is planned.

title: Movies
description: ISRAEL HOROVITZ, who wrote the screenplays for The Strawberry State and the upcoming Speed Is of the Essence, will climb into the director's chair for his next film, Ca merian Climbing. Who's the author of that screenplay? Why, it's an enterprising young fellow by the name of Israel Horovitz. The multi talented dynamo will start the MGM cameras rolling next July in his home town, Wakefield, Mass.

title: Evinrude Award to Nelson
description: Senator Gaylord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin, re ceived the 1971 Ole Evinrude Award from the Evinrude Boating Foundation on Wed nesday. Senator Nelson re ceived the award primarily for his legislative work as a conservationist, working for the preservation of water ways.

title: 5 COLLEGES PLAN TO REDUCE COSTS
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 23  The pooling of the re sources of five Nassau County colleges with those of other nonprofit institutions to pro vide better service at lower cost to Long Islanders was pro posed this week by Dr. Charles Vevier, president of Adelphi University.

title: FREDERICK BARBOUR
description: NORFOLK, Conn., Jan. 23 Frederick K. Barbour, retired president of the Linen Thread Company, died today at his home. He was 76 years old.

title: Penn Turns Back Villanova, 7870, For 15th in a Row
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 (AP)  Fourthranked Pennsylvania rallied tonight to defeat its crosstown rival, Villanova, 78?? in the second game of a doubleheader at the Palestra.

title: COUSY AMONG THREE ELECTED TO SHRINE
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 23 (AP)Bob Cousy and Bob Pet tit, two of pro basketball's greatest players, and the late Abe Saperstein, founder of the Harlem Globetrotters, have been elected to the National Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: ELLIOT AND MASON JOIN FOR VOCALS
description: Dave Mason and Cass Elliot seem an odd pair, to be sure, but they work together fairly well.

title: Carol Waugh Is Bride of Andrew Gull
description: EAST WILLISTON, L. I., Jan. 23Miss Carol Ann Waugh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Waugh Jr. of Westbury, was married here this afternoon to An drew Michael Gull, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Gull, also of Westbury. The Rev. Howard C. Shaffer Jr. per formed the Protestant cere mony in the Community Church

title: Colleges Upstate to Allow Students to Set Own Pace
description: GENEVA, N. Y., Jan. 23A new curriculum that will allow students to proceed at their own pace and graduate in three, four or five years will be started at Hobart and William Smith Colleges this fall.

title: AUSTRIA SLALOM TAKEN BY AUGERT
description: KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 23 (AP)Jean Noel Augert, the world champion, won an inter national slalom race today that did not count for World Cup points. But the only thing that mattered to the 21yearold Frenchman was the victory.

title: Stamps
description: WINTON M. BLOUNT will carry on as Postmaster Gener al of the United States Postal Service, and will be chairman of the Service's board of gover nors. The nine governors, who received an interim ap pointment by President Nixon on Jan. 5, met on Jan. 13 and named Mr. Blount to continue as head of the postal opera tion which will become, on July 1, a governmentchar tered corporation. Under the corporation program the post master general will no longer be a member of the Presi dent's Cabinet.

title: Decals Help to Preserve Resources, Fight Pollution
description: Two companies in the rec reation field have turned to decals in the fight against pollution and the drive to ward preserving the coun try's natural resources.

title: CHRYSLER SHOWS FIBERGLASS LINE
description: Chrysler is introducing eight new models in its line of fiberglass boats for 1971. Five of them are in an eight boat display at the show.

title: National Notes
description: Governor Rockefeller will not send the new state budget to the Legislature until a week from tomorrow, but last week there were some indications what the document would contain. The omens were bad.

title: O'Brien Says Nixon Ignored War and Economy Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) The Democratic National Chairman, Lawrence F. O'Brien, accused President Nixon today of ignoring two concerns that tower above all othersthe war and the economy.

title: Minifish, 12Ft. Sailboard, Introduced by AMF Alcort
description: AMF Alcort, Inc., of Waterbury, Conn., is intro ducing the Minifish, a new 12foot sailboard, at the show. The boat shares the display with the familiar Sunfish and Sailfish and the newer flyingfish.

title: Miss April Storm Is Married To Norman Braun Wenk 3d
description: FLORAL PARK, L. 1., Jan. 23Miss April Storm, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Crosby Storm of Garden City, was married here this after noon to Norman Braun Wenk 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wenk Jr. of Fort Salonga, formerly of Garden City.

title: Luckhurst's Century Paces 258 by English
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 23 (Reuters)  Brian Luckhurst, batting with an injured finger, hit a century for England today on the third day of the fifth cricket test against Australia.

title: Opponents of L.I. Nuclear Plant Succeed in Delaying It a Year
description: PORT JEFFERSON STATION, L.I., Jan. 23Conservationists Contending that nuclear power is dangerous and a potential pollutant have succeeded in de laying for at least a year the construction of Long Island's first nuclear generating plant.

title: Massachusetts Beaten
description: PROVIDENCE, Jan. 23 (AP) Ernie DiGregorio scored 33 points tonight as Providence knocked Massachusetts out of the unbeaten ranks, 7372.

title: Movies
description: IT'S no secret that Hollywood is in a transition stage and that as a result the big studios aren't making the same kinds of films any more; when a Ryan's Daughter or a Song of Nor way comes along, it is a reminder of a former era. But the upsets in Holly wood do not constitute the only current revolution in filmmakingeven more dramatic, and far more unsung, have been the recent, rapid developments in the evolution of the sex film.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Norwalk Conservation Association Achieving Its Purpose Island by Island
description: The crusade of a battalion of conservationists, the As sociation to Save the Norwalk Islands, has in its twoyear history been a cause for op timism in the case of people versus commerce.

title: Aluminum Boat Group Is Headed by Mansfield
description: The newly elected chair man of the Recreational and Marine Aluminum Commit tee of the Aluminum Associa tion is William Mansfield. He has served on the com mittee since 1965 and just concluded two years as chair man of the Van Container subcommittee of the Alumi num Association.

title: Penguins on Top, 41
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Penguins scored twice in the final period and handed the Vancouver Canucks a 41 defeat tonight.

title: Headliners
description: A few weeks ago Ruby Keeler, the pretty young hoofer of the '20's and '30's, told an interviewer, I'm scared to death. What Miss Keeler, now 60, was scared of was her approaching first ap pearance on Broadway since Show Girl in 1929. In between, course, there were all those zippy, good natured moviesfrom 42d Street to Shipmates Foreverand then marriage and children and life away from the bright lights. But not long ago she was asked to return as the star of the old hit, No, No, Nanette. The show opened last weekand it was quickly apparent that Miss Keeler had no reason to be scared. The nostalgic, rave reaction was symbolized by a grayhaired matron who shouted during one of the star's dance numbers, That 'a girl, Ruby!

title: Music
description: THIS is the story of Scott Joplin and me, and of a few weeks of ad venture with his music. It started just after the new year, when I played Joshua Rifkin's re cording of eight of Joplin's piano rags (Nonesuch 71248). I was enchanted. The music had a lovely swing, and as one rag succeeded another, it was clear that Joplin had a style very much his own. Melody succeeded melody, and even though Joplin was working in a rather circumscribed form, every rag sounded different. And the music not only had an elegance of its own, in such a work as Euphonic Sounds it had a good deal of delicate color and harmonic imagina tion. This was not just any man's music. The syncopationsand ragtime is based on syncopationwere as idiomatically applied as the rubatos in a Chopin ma zurka. Joplin was a real composer.

title: Harney Leads at Phoenix on 194
description: PHOENIX Ariz., Jan. 23 Paul Harney, a 41yearold Massachusetts club profession al and a United States golfing ambassador of goodwill, be came the 54hole leader in the $125,000 Phoenix open today with an aggregate of 194.

title: New Pearson 30 Blends Racing, Cruising Aspects
description: The new Pearson 30 intro duced at the boat show may rival the popularity and per formance of the Pearson 26, which made its debut last year, according to Bill Shaw, the designer.

title: Wilcox Performer of Wonders in a Runabout
description: MIAMI  A welltraveled sportsman remarked, after seeing a recent flatbottom inboard race in California, that the enthusiasm of pow erboat fans is rivaled only by crowds in Madrid bullfight ing arenas.

title: The World
description: WARSAWNobody here is at all certain how long it will last, or even how much it means, but new freedoms of communication and negotiation are being per mitted by the monthold regime of Edward Gierek, the Commu nist party leader.

title: JOHNSON IS VICTOR IN RICH BOWLING
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 23 (UPI)  Don Johnson swept through three straight oppo nents Saturday afternoon, the last one Barry Asher, by a 269 223 score, to ring up an $11, 111.11 jackpot in the Showboat invitation bowling tournament.

title: Palmer Engines Displays Gasoline, Diesel Models
description: The Palmer Engine Com pany of Cos Cob, Conn., has a line of gasoline and diesel engines that starts with a gnatsized onecylinder gaso line engine. It is the PW27 for midget oceanracing sail boats, which develops 8 horsepower, weighs 195 pounds, has magneto Igni tion, a selfstarter and gen erator. The 2:1 reduction gear is optional.

title: Penn State Downs Army
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Jan. 23 (AP)Bruce Mello, a 6foot 3inch guard, was the big gun for Penn State against Army, scoring 25 points to lead the Nittany Lions to a 6548 tri umph over the cadets.

title: Legal Heroin Rare in Britain as Doctors Turn to Methadone
description: Legal heroin has become a rather rare commodity in Brit ain, the nation that pioneered in prescribing it for addicts more than four decades ago.

title: Television
description: A MEMORY of Two Mondays was written in a cold time to keep warm. In 1955 in the United States there was plenty of pa triotism, plenty of fear, plenty of money and no issues. Everybody was either be ing psychoanalyzed or investigated by Congressional committees or divorcing. Social seers were announcing the end of ideology, a world without social con flict swiftly clothing itself with rich and smooth materials which would soon cover even the slumbering natives of Harlem, BedfordStuyvesant and Ap palachia. Names of things were chang ing; the poor now were merely the disadvantaged and the New Deal was Communism; Capitalism was Free Enter prise and all the bars came down off the windows of the banks, quite as though such institutions had lost the property sense and existed but to give away money to all who chose to apply. The trap had been sprung on Necessity, which was buried in an unmarked grave.

title: ST. JOHN'S TRIUMPHS IN SWIMMING, 7241
description: Winning all events except the dive and final relay, St. John's University's swimming team rolled past Kings Point yesterday, 7241, at the Alumni Hall pool on their Jamaica, Queens, campus.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The World
description: SAIGON  From the ground, the air war in Indochina had seemed to settle into a pattern. In North Vietnam, daily recon naissance flights and morefre quent attacks on threatening mis siles; in Laos, heavy bombing of the Ho Chi Minh Trail and sup port for Laotian forces; in South Vietnam, continuing, but declining, air activity of all types.

title: Graham, Teacher Corps Head Since'65 Founding, Removed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) Richard Graham, the only director the Teacher Corps has had since its inception in 1965, has been dismissed as head of the volunteer agency by United States Commissioner of Educa tion Sidney Marland, it was learned today.

title: The Berthing Syndrome
description: You've bought your first boat  a glossy fiberglass beauty that the man at the boat show assured you would sleep four. The question is now: Where are you going to keep it?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: New Chairman Named For Community Trust
description: The election of William Parsons as chairman of the distribution committee of the New York Community Trust and chairman of the board of Community Funds, Inc., was announced yesterday.

title: Bed and Board But Not Bored
description: IT comes as something of a shock when, toward the end of Bed and Board, Francois Truf faut's very funny new film at the Fine Arts Theater, An toine Doinel (JeanPierre Laud who has failed as everything from private de tective to florist's assistant, reveals that he is writing an autobiographical novel about his truly terrifying childhood. It is characteristic of Truffaut that the information is initi ally presented as the peg for a series of gags: Antoine is talking to Csarin, patron of the local bar. Csarin points out that another great novel ist, Baudelaire, had also be gun in flowers and he goes on to suggest a title for the book, With Neither Drum Nor Trumpet, since there will be no drums or trumpets in Antoine's novel.

title: Our Busy Waterways
description: A total of 44.07million people participating in rec reational boating, made use of the waterways more than once during 1970, according to an estimate of the Boating Industry Association.

title: Speed Record Engine On Display at Show
description: Renato Molinari, driving a 24foot craft designed by his father, broke the world speed record for diesel powered boats on Jan. 3 on Lake Como, Italy.

title: Interior Styling of Houseboats Is a Joy to the Women
description: Houseboat builders have come up with the ultimate in domesticity in their inno vative designs for the fleet of houseboats on display at the boat show. They're of fering the feminine members of the crew enough choices of interior layouts so that they can keep busy all sum mer just rearranging the fur niture.

title: National Notes
description: It was just a year ago that President Nixon, who has so often felt the lash of outraged conservationists, rose to the de fense of the wildernessand doomed efforts to build a new jet airport in the Florida Ever glades. Last week, he came to the rescue of Florida wildlife once more.

title: Ski Jump Trophy Captured by Stone
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 23Larry Stone, the cap tain of the 1966 Williams Col lege ski team, outjumped 24 rivals today to capture the Ramapo Mountain Ski Club's Eisenhower Trophy before 7,500 spectators.

title: Mayor Opens Boat Show at Coliseum
description: Winter seemed to vanish and spring magically appear yester day as the 61st National Boat Show opened its doors to the public for a nineday run at the Coliseum.

title: A A FREESPEECH SUIT BY BERRIGANS FAILS
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 23 (AP) A Federal judge has refused to grant the Rev. Daniel Berrigan and the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan, antiwar Roman Catholic priests, the right to send their writings and taperecorded sermons out side prison without censorship.

title: Cup Races Boon to Newport Economy
description: NEWPORT, R. I.Four 12 meter yachts lie dormant here inside big shipyard sheds awaiting warm sum mer winds to set forth again on America's Cup waters.

title: Jacksonville 9376 Victor
description: MACON, Ga., Jan. 23 (AP) Artis Gilmore, Greg Nelson and Vaughn Wedeking combined for 17 points with 3:43 remaining to clinch a 9376 victory for Jacksonville over Mercer to night.

title: Leg art
description: Minilovers, take heart. When the weather turns warmer, it will be all right to show your legs again. Un less you want to cover them down to the ankles. That's the choice many designers are offering for spring and summer. The short lengths aren't all skirts, however; they may be shorts or even rompers. But they're not meant for the beach. They're for stepping out at night.

title: The Masks of Kurt Vonnegut Jr.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. ENGLISH V, creative writing, met on the 10th floor of Holy oke Center, an uncharacteris tically sleek and new building at Harvard. I was early; there were just two people in the room. Is this Vonnegut's seminar? I asked. A man with a beard and hair that hung from his head like black tinsel said, in a warm way, Yes, I'm Kurt Vonne gut. He moved his head in the direc tion of a girl in a maroon midi skirt: This is Mrs. Vonnegut. But he was a student and she was Jill Krementz, the photographer, there to photo graph and to taperecord the class. It was a few minutes later, when the room was about half full, that Kurt Vonnegut Jr., wearing a greenish tweed suit appeared.

title: Seaford Instruction Course
description: Coast Guard Auxiliary, Flo tilla 138, of Seaford, L. I., has scheduled a public in struction course in smallboat handling and seamanship to be held at Seaford High School on Tuesday at 8 P.M.

title: World Groups Set Parley In Belgium on Soviet Jews
description: PARIS, Jan. 23Jewish na tional and international organ izations plan to meet in Brus sels next month to intensify their efforts on behalf of Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: Barry Brown to Run In K. of C. Meet Here
description: Barry Brown, the indoor track season's fastest two miler, filed his entry yester day for the New York Knights of Columbus meet Feb. 5 at Madison Square Garden. Other early entries have come from Dick Quax of New Zealand in the mile, Dr. Delano Meri wether in the 60yard dash and Reynaldo Brown in the high jump.

title: Margaret Dunn Smith Fiancee Of Winthrop Hiram Smith Jr.
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Jan. 23Miss Margaret Dunn Smith, a sophomore at Wheat on College in Norton, Mass., plans to be married in Au gust to Winthrop Hiram Smith Jr., an Amherst Col lege senior whose late father was president and board chairman of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, the stock brokerage firm.

title: Son for the Formatos
description: A son was born Jan. 8 to Mr. and Mrs. Lee Stephen Formato of New York at Doctors Hospital. Mrs. For mato is the former Miss Pamela Jane Fromme of New York. Her husband is execu tive vice president of Brandt Theaters. The child has been named Brian Everett.

title: $500,000 Is Raised to Build Theater at Kennedy Center
description: The President's Advisory Committee of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Per forming Arts announced here yesterday that more than $500,000 had been raised toward completion of the cen ter's 1,142seat Eisenhower Theater.

title: Irwin Back in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) Under Secretary of State John N. Irwin 2d returned to day from a factfinding trip to the Middle East for Presi dent Nixon and said that he was encouraged about pros pects for avoiding a crisis over oil supplies for the Western world.

title: UglyDuckling Tugboat Gets a Streamlining
description: The tugboat is a familiar sight in the harbors of the world, pushing or pulling many times its own weight to the neverending astonish ment of onlookers. But it has never been considered a pleasure craft.

title: Jewish Convert to Mormonism Is Now a Better Jew
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 19 Jerry Horowitz, 49 years old, was born in Brooklyn and is now a member of a leading law firm in Ogden, Utah. He is a Jew, and he frightened his family badly when he be came a convert of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U. S. Foreign Policy: A Firm Nixon Style
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  The men and minds at work on foreign policy have changed. The techniques and tactics of American diplomacy have changed. The troops are coming out of Indochina almost as fast as they once went in. The cast of leading characters on the world stage has changed and the rhetoric with which Wash ington addresses them has changed even more, Most strik ingly, the people of the United States have changed their view of the world overseas.

title: Morse D. Levitt, 75, Dies; ExState Insurance Aide
description: Morse D. Levitt, deputy Commissioner of the State In surance Department from 1944 to 1954, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 54 River side Drive.

title: Princeton Wrestlers Win
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 23 Princeton University's wres tling team captured eight of 10 matches today to rout Lafay ette, 286, and register its sev enth victory in eight out ings. Princeton's Chuck Dressel pinned Harry Norton at 1:20 of the heavyweight match to rec ord the only fall.

title: Merrill C. Sexton to Wed Miss Williams
description: CHATTANOOGA, Jan. 23 Miss Margaret Hard wick Williams, a print stylist with Avondale Mills, manu facturers of sportswear fab rics in New York, plans to be maarried in early April to Merrill Callaway Sexton, an assistant cashier with the First National City Bank in New York.

title: U.S.Japan Venture a Rousing Success
description: Pacemaker Corporation of ficials recently took a long hard look at their joint boat building venture with Nisshin Steel Company of Japan and liked what they saw.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: CAGLIARI, Sardinia, Jan 23 (AP)  Ships and helicopters resumed a search today for 15 seamen still missing from an Americanowned oil tanker dev astated by two explosions and a fire yesterday. Twentythree other seamen, including the captain of the 38man crew, have been rescued.

title: The Complex Past of Meir Kahane
description: The story of Meir Kahane moves from Talmudic acad emies in Brooklyn to a con gregation that rebuffed him, to an existence under an as sumed name unknown to most of his friends and then to the reemergence of Rabbi Kahanethis time as the founder of a militant Jewish group embroiling itself in in ternational controversy.

title: Salmon's Friends Gather at Waldorf
description: A welfare family may be shivering in the publicity of a $76aday suite upstairs, but in the elegant Hilton and Empire Rooms below, doublebreasted suit nudges string tie as dcolletage, flowing dresses and hot pants bask through the television lights in style.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Winches Useful to Sailor For a Variety of Tasks
description: Winches have more uses than just for trimming sheets while racing.

title: National Notes
description: The public was outraged, and the pressure from state offi cials in Albany was mounting. So the New York Telephone Company brought 1,000 upstate workers into New York City. They came as volunteers, with guarantees of overtime pay and other benefits. Their mission: to cut the long delay in new tele phone installations and catch up on lagging repair service.

title: Interne Is Fiance Of Felicia Salvest
description: COLTS NECK, N. J., Jan. 23Miss Felicia Salvest, a lawyer with the chief coun sel's office of the Army Elec tronics Command at Fort Monmouth, and Dr. Joseph Falkowski, an interne, at the John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital in Stratford, plan to be married in early July.

title: Army Tops Northeastern
description: WEST POINT, N . Y., Jan. 23 Army broke a 11 tie in the second period with two goals and then hung on to defeat Northeastern, 32, tonight. Don Coleman scored two goals for the cadets. Matt Eaton scored Army's other goal.

title: East Pakistani Party Gains 21Seat Assembly Majority
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 23 (AP)The Awami League, East Pakistan's dominant political party, has won nine more seats in the new National Assembly, assuring it of a majority of 21 seats, according to unofficial results from voting last Sun day.

title: Photography
description: A COMPACT new elec tronic flash unit re cently introduced is about the same size as a pack of cigarettes but pro vides light output and cover age that is equal to many units that are a good deal larger. Powered by a builtin re chargeable nickel cadmium battery, and supplied with a dual voltage (120 or 240 volts) charger, the unit offers a guide number of 42 for Kodachrome II (ASA 25) and will flash up to 50 times on one charge. Called the Braun F111, and distributed by Braun North America, 235 Wyman Street, Waltham, Mass. 02154, this electronic flash has a list price of $49.95 and recycles in nine seconds. It can also be operated di rectly off house current by using the charger as a power source and keeping the light plugged in while in use. The F111 comes with a hot shoe contact mounting, as well as a PC cord.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: A LongNurtured Pipe Dream Reaches Journey's End
description: Years ago, While at school, some friends and I distracted ourselves from the pressures of our studies by talking of buying, at some vague future time, a schooner, in which we would take a long sailing voyage, perhaps around the world. That talk of romance and adventure helped get us through a couple of rough years. It hardly mattered that none of us potential salty mariners knew precisely what a schooner was.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Alumni Notes:

title: Predicted Log Group Strives to Simplify Its Competition
description: Even in predicted log com petition the mini is an issue. In this case, however, it is the minimile and it will be up for more than a little dis cussion at the predicted log seminar that is scheduled for Jan. 30 during the boat show.

title: It Sounds Like Kate Millett, But It Works Like Henrik Ibsen
description: THE difficulty with Ibsen today is that we must try to take two sep arate things seriously, the playwright's ideas and the playwright's playwriting. The ideas, of course, present no particular problem. One has only to listen to Claire Bloom's last long speech in the current  and very sleek  revival of A Doll's House, which will soon be alternating with Hedda Gab ler at the Playhouse, or to glance at the brief excerpts from Ibsen's Notes for a Modern Tragedy that have been included in the program to know that the ideas were sound, advanced, on target. A woman cannot be herself in modern society, the notes read, It is an exclusively male society, with laws made by men and with prosecutors and judges who assess female conduct from a male stand point. Kate Millett sounds oldfashioned beside that.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  This is a time of humility among the men who make Government economic policy. On the eve of the President's major pol icy messages, the Budget and Economic Reports, they are aware of how a once orderly and predictable world has gone wrong  not terribly wrong, but sufficiently wrong to bring humility.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BONNBerlin is the root of all pol icy for Chancellor Willy Brandt, who as chief of West Germany's coalition Government skates brilliant diplomatic figures on the thinnest of political ice. For the city and the fate of its Western sector remain the impetus for everything the handsome, heavyset statesman tries to do not only for Germany but for Europe.

title: Flotsam and Jetsam Watch
description: Boatmen should always keep a sharp lookout for floating debris. There is a saying that you only see about onethird of an ice berg because the rest is under water. The same could be true of what appears to be a small floating object. It could be large enough to damage a hull.

title: YUGOSLAVIA CUTS THE DINAR BY 17%
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 23A 17 percent devaluation of the Yugoslav dinar was of ficially announced today by officials who blamed dramatic and steady increases in imports for forcing their decision. The present rate of the 12.50 dinars to the dollar was changed Saturday to 15 dinars.

title: Snow place
description: In direct contrast to their Connecticut glass house, which was designed by Philip Johnson, the Richard Hodgsons (he is a vice president of I.T.T.) wanted a rambling structure of wood and stone for their yearround vaca tion retreat in Snowmass, Colo. And that is what Eliot Noyes, the archi tect, gave them  plus a New England touch, a covered bridge joining the living and sleeping quarters of the 6,000squarefoot cedar and Colo rado granite dwelling. Set on a mountain ridge overlooking the ski slopes, this house is brilliantly engineered for comfort and privacy.

title: Mrs. McCay Wed to David Kelly
description: The marriage of Mrs. Joan Tillman McCay to David Barry Kelly, a Foreign Serv ice officer with the Depart ment of State in Washington, took place here yesterday afternoon.

title: Resolved: More Boating Fun in '71
description: Did last year's blahs get you down, Mr. Boatowner? Did you have your fill of polluted waters, registration fees, holdingtank laws, regatta protests, snarled spinnakers, empty gas tanks and dry rot?

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: A crisis was at hand and the chilling thought of panic was permeating the atmos phere in the executive suites of Wall Street. It was the August doldrums of 1970, when the stock market was at low ebb and the fortunes of the securities industry were even lower.

title: Attacks Are Reported By Portuguese Guinea
description: LISBON, Jan. 23The mili tary command in Portuguese Guinea reported today new border violations from Sene gal and the Republic of Guinea.

title: Television
description: WE should be receiving the tapes of Adolf's guest shots any day now. But since you were out of the country and missed his various appearances, I thought I might just fill you in.

title: Trying to Get Behind Those Japanese Screens
description: THE exhibition of Japa nese screens from New York collections now at Asia House the first half of a double exhibition, the second to be held in midFebruarystarts out with all the cards stacked against it. But it comes through a winner, thanks to a combination of tact and scholarship in the presenta tion of the material and the preparation of a catalogue by Miyeko Murase. Of course there are also the screens themselves, including five from the Metropolitan. But it is not true that it is im possible to make a bad show from good material. It has been done from time to time, the trick being to try to remedy irremediable difficul ties by theatricalizing side issues. Nothing like that has been done here.

title: Australia Urged to Take More Pacific Isle Immigrants
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 23  A growing population crisis on many South Pacific islands has inspired a new debate here on Australia's selective immi gration policy.

title: Study Shows Artificial Turf Is Hotter Than Grass
description: Pennsylvania State Uni versity's Human Performance Laboratory has just com pleted the first phase of a major new research project designed to find out if arti ficial turf increases the po tended for heat injuries in athletes.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: S. J. Perelman, Meet Miss Nellie Bly
description: S.J. PERELMAN'S recent announce ment that he will go around the world in the style of Jules Verne's fictional hero Phileas Fogg brings to mind another American writer who tackled the same challenge 81 years ago with a grit and flair that must certainly command the admiration of the intrepid humorist.

title: FUND IS SET UP FOR BOAT GROUP
description: A trust fund to provide as sistance to the victims of power boat racing accidents was offered to the American Power Boat Association yester day and accepted by the organization's council at its meeting in the Essex House.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Mediterranean Holiday Cruises ?? $625. A wouderful buy in travel. See ad Travel Section 10, page 34. Columbia Tours. ?? Fifth Ave, NY 10017, 6618900 Adv.

title: Rebellion in Cameroon Reported Virtually Crushed
description: YAOUNDE, Cameroon, Jan. 23 (AP)  This West African nation has almost extinguished a 10yearold insurrection in its forested central highlands, but other problems lie ahead.

title: Soviet Tops U.S. In 6 of 11 Matches To Take Boxing
description: LAS VEGAS, Jan. 23 (UPI) The Soviet Union national box ing team built a 61 lead today and went on to beat a United States amateur squad, 6 matches to 5, in the third meet ing between the nations.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The United States is in the final phase of an interna tional competition that de serves more attention than it is getting. We might even classify this competition as a fourman medley relay race, in which most of the stakes are riding on the anchorman, whom I shall call our technologically intensive products.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The port of Seattle, which not long ago purchased the original plant and property of the Boeing Company, has continued to expand its facil ities and increase the ton nage and value of its ship ments and imports.

title: Music
description: HIS first name is Bruno and he was dressed in brown brown turtleneck sweater, suit, socks and shoes. It was not an affec tation, but more likely the result of his wife's packing. My wife likes brown, the man said in response to a comment on his appearance.

title: SOVIET SCHOOLS BATTLE RELIGION
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 23I lined the pupils up and ordered all those who considered them selves Baptists to come forward two paces. About 30 came for ward. I asked them if they in tended to go an praying. They all replied that they would. Then I ordered the teachers to give them all low marks for conduct.

title: J. P. Wells Weds Rosemary Jackson
description: Miss Rosemary Herrick Jackson and Joseph P. Wells of New York were married here at noon yesterday in the Unitarian Church of All Souls by the Rev. Dr. Walter Donald Kring.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Mary O'Shea Is Bride
description: Miss Mary Agnes Eileen O'Shea, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. O'Shea of Flushing, Queens, was mar ried yesterday morning to David Sivewright Milne Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. David S. Milne of Hollis, Queens, in the Roman Catholic Church of Mary's Nativity in Flush ing by the Rev. George T. Deas, rector of Cathedral Col lege in Douglaston, Queens.

title: RELATIVE IS CHARGED IN A BAILJUMPING
description: The fatherinlaw of a for mer Colombian diplomat who jumped $250,000 bail after be ing convicted of smuggling co caine was arrested yesterday as he boarded a plane bound for Colombia with the smuggler's four children.

title: PRINCETON BEATS 3 FOES IN TRACK
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 23 Bill Foucher of Princeton cap tured three events today as the undefeated Tiger track team won a quadrangular meet by collecting 82 points to 26 for Fordham, 24 for New York University and 19 for Seton Hall.

title: Music
description: IT was bound to happen sometime in that small ring called the concert circuit. One of Jacqueline du Pr's old boy friends was signed on to play the Bartk third piano Concerto with the Hall Orchestra in Manchester before he had any way of knowing that the conductor was to be Daniel Baren boim, the young Israeli who married the blonde British cellist. Relations be tween a concert soloist and his con ductor can be touchy enough without .a girl problem to make them worse. But then accidents come along sometimes to make problems go away.

title: Clarkson Tops Yale 51
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 23 Clarkson extended its hockey mastery over Yale tonight, beating the Elis, 51. It was Clarkson's 17th consecutive vic tory over Yale. Jerry Kemp scored twice as Clarkson in creased its wonlosttie record to 1721. Yale has a 1111 mark.

title: Music: Dichter Performs Schumann
description: About 40 years ago, Schumann's F sharp minor Piano Sonata was very much a repertory piece. Hofmann and Bauer played it glorious ly, among many others. But it has fallen on evil, days, and there are not many who care to engage this long, difficult, whimsical and ultra romantic work.

title: Accessories Assure a Pleasant Cruise
description: Did you ever try to slip a normal bedsheet over a pieshaped berth? Or put a backyard barbecue on the aft deck of a 30footer?

title: Chess
description: WHICH is more important in chess, tactical flair or strate gic soundness? Imperturbable philosophy or studied psychol ogy? The appended games, among the best of 1970, illustrate the interaction of these aspects of play.

title: The World
description: LONDON  In ordinary times, the British Post Office provides what Americans and most other people would regard as a serv ice so good as to approach fan tasy.

title: Canada Will Double Outlay To Reduce Pulp Pollution
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 23 (UPI)  The Government next year will double its contribution for re search aimed at reducing water pollution from the pulp and paper industry, the Fisheries and Forestry Minister, Jack Da vis has announced.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: This month the Federal Trade Commission is sched uled to take another look at important industry guides it issued in 1969 dealing with cooperative advertisingthe method by which manu facturers contribute to the local advertising costs of re tailers.

title: Mohibullah Khan Gains
description: TORONTO, Jan. 23 (Canadian Press)Mohibullah Khan of Boston, a fivetime winner of the North American squash racquets title, gained the sec ond round of the 1971 cham pionships yesterday. He beat Steve Moysey of Toronto, 1510, 1618, 1215, 1715, 158.

title: Gair Betts Fiance Of Susan Hubbard
description: REMSENBERG, L. I., Jan. 23Mr. and Mrs. Ralph I. Hubbard have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Susan Carol Hub bard, to Gair Gill Betts, son Of. Mrs. Derick Whitefield Betts of Westhampton Beach and the late Mr. Betts.

title: DEMOCRAT WANTS CONSERVATIVE AID
description: SYOSSET, L. I., Jan. 23 Lewis J. Yevoli, the only Demo cratic Town Councilman in Nas sau County, announced this week that he would be a candi date for the post of Supervisor of the Town of Oyster Bay and would seek Conservative party endorsement.

title: MAJOR FIRE RAGES IN SAIGON SLUM AREA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Jan. 24 (UPI)Saigon's biggest fire since the 1968 Tet offensive raged through a slum along the city's border with adjoining Cholon today. Flames raced through several square blocks of homes and shops.

title: U.S. Copter Downed
description: SAIGON, Sunday, Jan. 24 (Reuters)  Vietcong gunners shot down a United States OH6 spotter helicopter in South Vietnam's northern mountains yesterday, the United States command said today.

title: 385,000 Gallons of Oil Spill Into Sound
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 23  A 685foot tanker ran aground on a rock ledge, at the mouth of New Haven Harbor before dawn today, spilling about 385, 000 gallons of light fuel oil into the harbor and Long Island Sound.

title: Gains for Public Reported By G. M. Watchdog Panel
description: DETROIT, Jan. 23Five busi ness leaders appointed by the General Motors Corporation to watch over the effects of the giant company's policies on the general public say they deserve credit for the recent appoint ment of the first black man to the corporation's board of trustees.

title: Answers to God from a cyclone cellar
description: Ramon Guthrie is a magnificent American poet in his seventies who has been overlooked. By over looked I mean that his name and titles don't appear in either Who's Who or Who's Who in the East and that the most recent representa tive anthology of modern American poetry that I have seen, one edited by Hayden Carruth, doesn't include him. Guthrie is 74 or so and has been writing excellent verse for at least 40 years. This means that Un termeyer missed him in the thirties, that Oscar Williams missed him in the forties and fifties, that despite the efforts of James Laughlin, Poetry, the Wesleyan and Yale University Presses, The New Yorker, Evergreen Review, Playboy, Esquire, The New York Review, etc., Guthrie has been missed. Why is it that during the last 25 years we have heard so much of say, Robert Lowell and, latterly, of Allen Ginsberg and nothing at all of Guthrie, who is slightly better than both at their best? How does Guthrie stack up against a wellpub licized new poet like Eugene Mc Carthy? (He is much more profes sional than the Minnesota bard for a start.) Where does he stand with respect to Leonard Cohen, author of Suzanne? But let's be serious.

title: El Barrio Travel Agents: Tickets and Sympathy
description: ADISTRAUGHT and angry man came into a small travel agency in East Harlem recently to purchase a oneway ticket to Puerto Rico. Before taking his money, Mrs. Milagro Toro, the owner of the agency, who is a former social worker, sat the custom er down and asked him to explain his problem. He did, without much prodding.

title: Reading the Stars
description: The DowJones industrial average is in for a rough time this year, according to the world's oldest investment advisory servicethe stars.

title: CALDER AND CARTER WIN AWARDS IN ART
description: Alexander Calder, the sculp tor, and Elliott Carter, the composer, have been named the recipients of this year's Gold Medal Awards of the National Institute of Arts and Sciences. The gold medals are presented each year to 2 of 13 categories for distinguished achievement in the arts.

title: Article 13  No Title
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 (AP) Kent Scott tossed in 30 points today to help Pittsburgh down North Carolina State, 8975.

title: 1971 Waterway Guides Revised and Augmented
description: Three editions have been prepared by Waterway Guide for 1971. The 24yearold yacht publication for cruising boatmen (power and sail) also has been revised, up dated and augmented.

title: For a world where a man is a man, a poet a poet
description: The recent publication of Robert Hayden's new book of poems, Words in the Mourning Time, once again brings us the work of one of the most underrated and unrecognized poets in America. Until the publica tion of Selected Poems in 1966, Hayden was unrepresented by a book of his own poems, except for two small, privately printed books and a volume published in England. Now 57 years old, he has had to wait too long for the recognition that his work has merited for 20 years. But that is primarily because he is black.

title: H. A. Clements to Wed Miss Jennifer Weller
description: Mr. and Mrs. Royal Hurl burt Weller of so Paulo, Brazil, have announced the engagement of their daugh ter Miss Jennifer Weller, to Harold Albert Clements, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Emery Clements of Winter Park, Fla.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: STEEL PRICE INCREASES for construction products were rolled back to 6.8 per cent by U. S. Steel in wake of White House criticism of earlier 12 per cent rise by Beth lehem Steel. Bethlehem and other steel makers followed move by U. S. Steel

title: The Jigsaw Puzzle of History
description: SOME years ago, in reviewing Arthur Schlesinger's A Thou sand Days for Harper's Maga zine, I suggested that there was some resemblance between the volumes then flowing from Schlesinger, Soren sen, Salinger, and other lesser luminaries at Camelot, and the medi eval monastic chronicle. If anything, events since that time have reinforced this prejudice.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: U.S. STEEL YIELDS ON LAKE DUMPING
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 23  The United States Steel Corpora tion, one of the largest water and air polluters around Lake Michigan, agreed this week to a plan that will end all dump ing of waste into the lake at its enormous South Works in Chi cago.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Mention the name Ferrari to a race fan and his instant association is Commendatore Enzo Ferrari himself, the Wizard of Maranello. No one questions that the fame is well deserved, but it does ob scure another name associ ated with Ferrari racing Luigi Chinetti of Greenwich, Conn. Chinetti, over 70 now and still speaking with a strong Italian accent, is the majordomo of the North American Rac ing Team, which has done much to enhance the Ferrari luster. The last Ferrari to win the TwentyFour Hours of Le Mans was an N.A.R.T. entry in 1965. A year earlier an N.A.R.T. Ferrari won the TwentyFour Hours of Day tona. And, come to think of it, the first Ferrari to win at Le Mans, in 1949, was co driven by Luigi Chinetti.

title: WOMEN INFLUENCE IN YACHT DESIGN
description: Women have entered the boating market in a big way, and manufacturers are look ing more and more to the distaff side in planning new designs and improvements.

title: Dayton Dazzles Detroit
description: DETROIT, Jan. 23 (UPI) Dayton, with George Jackson scoring a career high of 30 Points, utilized its shuffle of fense to thwart a second half Detroit press today and turn a 3736 halftime edge into an 8877 triumph.

title: Princeton Downs Davidson
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 23 Brian Taylor and Ted Manakas, sophomore guards, combined for 44 points tonight to spark Princeton to a 9171 victory over Davidson. Paced by Mana kas's 15 points in the first half, the Tigers sprinted to a 3825 lead and increased the margin to 27 when Taylor made the score 7952 on a 20foot jumper at 14:28 of the second half.

title: Journalism Award Is Won
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Jan. 23 (AP)  Vermont C. Royster, former editor of The Wall Street Journal, was named today as the 22d recipient of the the Wil liam Allen White Foundation's national award for journalistic merit. Mr. Royster, who won a Pulitzer Prize for editorial writ ing in 1953, will receive the award in ceremonies in connec tion with William Allen White Day at the University of Kansas on Feb. 10.

title: HEALTH MAGAZINE BIG SOVIET SELLER
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 23A prin cipal source of inspiration and information for Russians wor ried about old wives' tales, sexual problems, rare diseases, proper nutrition and a host of other concerns is a slickly de signed soberly written maga zine called Zdorovye (Health).

title: Justin E. Beals Weds Elaine Paul Donovan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 In Holy Trinity Roman Cath olic Church in Georgetown today, Miss Elaine Paul Don ovan, daughter of Thomas J. Donovan of New York and Mrs. Horace W. Dietrich of Ellicott City, Md., was mar ried to Justin Edward Beals, son of Mr. and Mrs. Justin Q. Beals of Upper Marlboro, Md. The Rev. Don Murray performed the ceremony.

title: UGANDA MAY KILL 4,000 ELEPHANTS
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Jan, 17  Trustees of the Uganda na tional parks are considering a proposal that almost 4,000 ele phants be shot within the next four years in Murchison Falls National Park.

title: AUDIENCE YIELDS TO SEGOVIA SPELL
description: Not the least remarkable as pect of Andres Segovia's Phil harmonic Hall recital Friday night was the rapt, almost hypnotic spell the Spanish guitarist cast over his au dience. Whole pieces went by without a cough from any part of the soldout house, and even the warm applause sometimes seemed startling after the pin drop silence that accompanied the music.

title: NETS FACE UTAH FIVE TODAY IN HEMPSTEAD
description: The New York Nets face the Utah Stars this afternoon in an American Basketball Asso ciation game at Island Garden, West Hempstead, L. I.

title: Bucks Trounce Trail Blazers, 142117, Hitting on 63% of Shots From Floor
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 23 (UPI) The Milwaukee Bucks, stung by their second home loss of the season last night, bounced back today and trounced the Portland Trail Blazers, 142117, in a National Basketball Asso ciation game.

title: Patricia Coffin, Morton Fry 2d, Law Students, Plan May Bridal
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Jan. 23 Miss Patricia Laylin Cof fin and Morton Harrison Fry 2d, students at the Yale Law School, are planning a May wedding.

title: Marquette Wins, 7351
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 23 (UPI) De Paul gave Marquette a firsthalf scare tonight, but the Warriors roared back from a 12point deficit to win, 7351, for their 14th victory without a loss.

title: Emanuel X. Frisch, 58, Lawyer And Randforce Executive, Dies
description: Emanuel X. Frisch, a lawyer who was prominent in the mo tion picture theater industry, died Thursday of a heart at tack at his home, 196 Beach 142d Street, Neponsit, Queens. His age was 58.

title: Plan for Economic Department Involves Big Shifts of Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan.23 Presi dent Nixon's proposal for a new department of economic devel opment would involve the most drastic shakeup of present Gov ernment departments of any of the reorganizations proposed in last night's State of the Union Message.

title: Movies; But They Still Say Larry Who?
description: IN most of the gross and subtle ways that count, The Graduate was the most successful motion pic ture of 1967. It made Dustin Hoff man famous. It made Katharine Ross famous. It made author Charles Webb and screenwriter Buck Henry famous. It made director Mike Nichols super famous.

title: Booklet on CleanUp of River A Good Deed by Girl Scouts
description: One of the more useful, positive and action  oriented projects conceived for last spring's Earth Day celebration has been given a longlasting opportunity for countrywide expansion by a troop of Con necticut Girl Scouts.

title: Plane Lands in Libya
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 23 (UPI)A hijacked Ethi opian airlines DC3 with 23 persons aboard, five of them Americans, landed in Benghazi, Libya, on the Mediterranean coast today, 2,150 miles off its scheduled course, the Ethiopian press agency said. Four hi jackers, said to be Eritreans, were arrested, the agency said.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: DaimlerBenz of West Ger many, which sold nearly 30, 000 MercedesBenz cars in the United States last year, is zeroing in on the commer cial vehicles market.

title: Institute Denied Funds For Research on Soul
description: PHOENIX, Ariz,, Jan. 23 (AP)The Arizona Supreme Court has ruled that the Barrow Neurological Insti tute of Phoenix is not en titled to $175,000 left by James Kidd, a bachelor miner, for research to prove that each person has a soul that lives after death.

title: Home Improvement
description: IN the summer many of us complain about excess humidity, but in the win ter the problem inside house is jst the opposite there usually is not enough humidity in the air.

title: They bombed in New Haven
description: Model City is about the failures of redevelopment in Mayor Richard Lee's New Haven. It traces the his tory of redevelopment up to 1967 cursorily and as a Prelude to New Haven's riot of that year. The bulk of the book describes the city admin istration's shabby treatment of the local Hill Parents Association with all the ramifications for the official redevelopment organizations such as Community Progress, Inc., Model Cities and so on.

title: Caren Haas Affianced
description: Mrs. Doris Haas of New York and William P. Haas Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Caren Haas, to Paul Pohlen Jr. He is the son of Colonel Pohlen, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Pohlen of Downey, Calif. The couple will be married Feb. 6 in Downey.

title: Stamps
description: AT 41 YEARS of age, Emily Carr was labeled a failure as an artist. This year on Feb. 12, Canada will reproduce one of her paintings on a 6cent stamp to commemorate the centenary of her birth and in recognition of the acclaim that followed her return from artistic oblivion.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Maryland Atom Plant Gets a Permit
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 23A con struction permit for a Maryland nuclear power plant, the source of controversy in the state for more than two years, was ap proved this week by the State Public Service Commission.

title: National Notes
description: More than 1,000 American firms trade with the Soviet Union, a complicated business at best. Last week they had a new problem: the Jewish Defense League.

title: Horse Show News
description: The American Horse Shows Association still is working out the details of the Devereux Trophy that will be awarded annually in the memory of Walter Devereux.

title: The Nation
description: When New York City's taxi drivers went on strike for 15 days last month, nobody seemed to notice and pretty soon peo ple were asking: Do we really need taxis?

title: An Appraisal
description: Of all the American entries in the competition for small car sales, the Ford Motor Company's Pinto comes clos est to the European and Jap anese imports in size, price and operating economy. To these qualities Ford has add ed contemporary styling and frontseat comfort.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Shortly aft er Senator Edward M. Kennedy was surprisingly deposed last week as Democratic whip, Repre sentative Morris K. Udall, the Arizona liberal who had been resoundingly defeated in his bid to become Democratic leader of the House, called the Senator to offer the following condolences:

title: A STENCHGAS BOMB SET OFF AT CONCERT
description: At least one stench bomb was set off and five unexploded stench bombs were found shortly after 9 P.M. last night in Carnegie Hall during a per formance by the Soviet violin ist Leonid Kogan.

title: Stage: A Coward Bauble
description: The Equity Library Thea ter has done very well in deed by Nol Coward's Pres ent Laughter, as typical a bubble as ever floated by the British playwright. Excellent ly directed by Raphael Kelly and neatly siphoned at a brisk clip by a good, game cast, the comedy is being given its last and 11th per formance this afternoon at the Master Theater, 310 Riv erside Drive.

title: Mercury Outboards Finish '70 In Stunning Sweep at Havasu
description: It was a rather lean year for Kiekhaefer Mercury out boards in the winner's circle, but the bigengine manu facturer capped its 1970 racing campaign with an awesome display of power in the outboard world cham pionship at Lake Havasu City, Ariz.

title: Float Trip Really a Matter of Paddling Your Own Canoe
description: When Larry Gelber, a St. Louis medical student, told his wife, Carol, that they were going on a float trip, she imagined herself drifting lazily down a gently rippling stream, sipping lemonade and plunking a ukulele. It didn't take her long to discover that the term float trip is a mis nomer  the midwestern streams are greenish brown and ukuleles cause finger blisters.

title: National Notes
description: Portrait of a Presidential can didate: a former seminarian  a lowkeyed, deliberate, speaker  a dove on Vietnam from a conservative farm state with only a handful of electoral votes. Add them all together and you have Senator George McGovern of South Dakota who last week announcedmore than a year and a half before the 1972 poli tical conventionsthat he was a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: In the Mailbox
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: In addition to other appel lations being applied to it, 1970 probably will go down in business annals as the year of the big writeoff. The start of the trend al ready is being seen in the rising tide of annual reports covering last year's opera tions.

title: Art Notes
description: WITHIT art worldlings have known for a while that the toughest, hairiest, of the searchingest , outpost of the avantgarde is the Jean Free man Gallery at 26 West 57th St., opened last fall. Its roster of five farout conceptual shows to date has included a Lightning Piece by Justine Dane, Daniel Warren's Plas tic Deterioration, and the current Water Planet by Michael O'Day.

title: Boys and Girls Are Now Maturing Earlier
description: From surveys involving thousands of girls, four gen erations of Harvard boys, rec ords of the choir of Johann Se bastian Bach and numerous other studies, researchers on human growth have concluded that the rate at which boys and girls mature has been in creasing steadily.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: FIREMEN DEMAND ANY RAISE GIVEN BY CITY TO POLICE
description: The head of the Uniformed Firefighters Association served notice on the city yesterday that firemen would not accept any new contract that did not maintain their pay parity with policemen.

title: Rum Pimlico Victor
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 23Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Rum recorded his fifth straight victory today in capturing the $28,350 Pim lico Stakes before a crowd of 18,106 at Pimlico Race Track.

title: Western Judge Retires
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) President Nixon announced on Tuesday the retirement of William J. Lindberg as Federal District Judge for western Washington, effective March 1.

title: Going Back to Basics on an Island in the CaribbeanRiding Rafts in Jamaica
description: BERRYDALE, Jamaica While our cruisers become bigger and more elegant and our sailing ships take on the posh appointments of an East Side penthouse, there still remains a vestige of man's earliest efforts to trav el on water.

title: A former friend of Fidel has let Cuba down
description: On April 22, 1970, Fidel Castro interrupted an oration in Havana marking the centenary of the birth of Lenin and delivered a scathing at tack on certain leftist European in tellectual critics of Cuba. These days, as you know, there are superrevolu tionary theoreticians, superleftists, real supermen you might say, who are capable of crushing imperialism in two seconds with their tongues. These superrevolutionaries, Castro went on, construct imaginary, hypo thetical worlds from Paris and Rome, while they themselves live in comfort and haven't the slightest notion of reality or the problems and difficul ties of a revolution.  they won't even forgive the Soviet Union for existing  and this from positions on the left!

title: State Leaders Cautious
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) Spokesmen for the nation's state legislative leaders said today that they wanted to see the details of President Nixon's revenuesharing plan before they decided whether to give it their full endorsement.

title: Apollo 14 Recovery Ship Puts to Sea for Mission
description: PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Jan. 23 (UPI) The Apollo 14 pri mary recovery ship, the helicop ter carrier New Orleans, went to sea today in preparation for the Jan. 31 moon launching.

title: National Safety Act Is Nearing Port
description: After three years of de liberations in Congress the original Boat Safety Act of 1968 appears to have a good chance of becoming the Boat Safety Act of 1971.

title: Gifts to Neediest Cases Fund Still Lag Behind 1970 Total
description: Contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are still lagging behind those of last year, but the gap is getting smaller.

title: In the Mailbox
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Nature Groups Unite to Save a Swamp
description: Two of the nation's leading conservation organizations, the National Audubon Society and the Nature Conservancy, have joined hands to raise $1,450,000 to purchase and preserve one of the finest remaining black water swamps on the East Coast

title: A froth of chestnuts
description: The French chef who first dubbed a mousse a mousse had a felicitous way with words as well as food. Mousse means froth, and that's all it isa bit of fluff made stable with a touch of gelatin. Mousses come in many flavors, but few are the equal of the delicacy on this page, a chestnut mousse lightly laced with rum and served with a rich English custard. It is the recipe of chef Marcel Gosselin, the former owner of Manhat tan's L'Armorique restaurant. On the following page is a recipe for poached pears with chestnuts.

title: Stamps
description: JOHN SLOAN'S painting, Wake of the Ferry, somber view from the rear of a Staten Island ferry boat about 1907, will provide the design for the 1971 American Artist stamp. The multicolored stamp is to be produced at the Buitau of Engraving, Washington, although the method of pro duction has not been deter mined. The date of issue has not been set, although Aug. 2 would be appropriate, as it would mark the centenary of the artist's birth at Lock Ha ven, Pa., in 1871. If the August date is approved, the stamp will more than likely be of 8cent denomination, since the firstclass postage rate will be raised from six to eight cents this Spring. Currently, Bureau technicians are working on both 6c and 8c designs.

title: The New Movies
description: LUPO!, written and directed by Menahem Golan, is an Englishspeaking comedy set in contemporary Tel Aviv, but its heart belongs to Yiddishspeaking Sec ond Avenue, says Vincent Canby. Lupo, a middle aged widower who outwits City Hall, is played by Yuda Barkan, a 25year old Israeli. Under all those layers of makeup and charm, Mr. Barkan is, I suspect, an actor of real talent. The movie is harm less but, just to be safe, I'd advise people with bloodsugar problems to give it a wide berth.

title: Western Kentucky Loses
description: MURRAY, Ky., Jan. 23 (AP) Murray State stunned West ern Kentucky, 7371, tonight and tied the Tilltoppers for the Ohio Valley Conference lead.

title: Duquesne Five Upsets St. Bonaventure, 8968, for Sixth Straight Triumph
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 (AP) Jarrett Durham led a second half Duquesne assault on St. Bonaventure today as the Dukes upset the Bonnies, 8968.

title: NOTRE DAME UPSETS U.C.L.A., 8982
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 23 Notre Dame, with Austin Carr scoring 46 points, knocked topranked University of Cali fornia, Los Angeles from the undefeated ranks, 8982, today.

title: New Look, Same Old KnowHow
description: A year brought an inter esting change in John Dane 3d of Tulane University. Slender, closely barbered and babyfaced as a 19yearold sophomore in 1969, Dane was a husky, modmaned and mustached 20yearold junior by last October. But Dane's sailing skill didn't change. He was the winning skipper in the Douglas Cup intercollegiate match race sailing series off Long Beach Harbor, Calif, both years, each time registering a per fect record of victories against top rivals.

title: Yolanda Agatha Cifarelli Is Bride
description: LIVINGSTON, N. J., Jan. 23  Miss Yolanda Agatha Cifarelli, assistant curator of decorative arts at the New ark Museum, was married here this afternoon to Frank Anthony Digaetano Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Digaetano of Short Hills. The Rev. Mar tin F. Sherry performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Raphael Catholic Church.

title: White House Proposal to Reshape the Cabinet Meets Cool Congressional Response
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  From the negative reaction of key legislators, it was apparent today that President Nixon's proposal for a massive reor ganization and consolidation of Government departments faced a bleak future in Congress.

title: Horses' Names Not Picked Out of Air
description: A phone rings in the Registry Office of The Jockey Club at 300 Park Avenue.

title: The Sculpture of Henri Laurens: The Ripening of Formss
description: At the New York Cultur al Center in Columbus Circle there is cur rently installed a dou ble exhibition or the works of Henri Laurens and Georges Braque, drawn from the official Donations Lau rens et Braque a L'Etat Francais, the sizable gifts donated to the national mu seums of France by Claude Laurens, the sculptor's son, who serves as executor of the estates of both artists. I want this week to speak about the work of Laurens, which con stitutes the larger portion of the exhibition. Next week I hope to discuss the Braques.

title: Dartmouth Wins, 6865
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 23 Dartmouth staved off Boston University in the second half to score a 6865 victory and snap an eightgame losing streak to night. The Indians, led by James Brawn's 22 points and 16 by Paul Erland, won the game with four foul shots by Bud Martin in the final two minutes after Boston University had twice cut Dartmouth's lead to a single point.

title: Outboard Racing Guide Compiled by Evinrude
description: Outboard RacingAn ex planation of Classes, Types & Rules, is a 12page directory now available from Evinrude Motors.

title: Yachting Fever Sweeps France, With Three Challengers for America's Cup
description: PARISOnce there was a single French challenger for the America's Cup  now there are three.

title: City Losing $16Million In Delay on School Plan
description: Plagued by delays in starting special school programs, New York City has lost $16million in state funds meant to im prove education in the slums.

title: 5,900 Berthing Sites
description: There are 5,900 marinas, boatyards and yacht clubs with waterfront stations in the United States, according to Boating Industry Associ ation.

title: In the Mailbox
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Tract Record
description: For those who missed the radical call the first time round, Greenwood Reprint Corporation, of Westport, Conn., now offers 410 volumes of re printed Radical Periodicals in the United States, 18901960. Here are the passions of a thousand lost bat tles and the polemics of more, care fully disinterred for the pecunious reader with $17,116.50 to burn.

title: USE OF GASOLINE COOKING HAZARD
description: There are no appetites to compare with those that de velop aboard a boat. For some odd reason a family can get up from a full meal, board their boat and head to sea, and within a few minutes everyone is hungry.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When I was a young reporter learning my trade by covering an infinite variety of sports, I eventually reached a point where I ranked as the resident expert on, of all things, fencing. Intercollegiate cham pionships in those days were considered so important they commanded four and five columns of space. That alone should demonstrate how times and The Times have changed.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: Ralph Nader, the crusading lawyer, has concluded that only the Federal Government is big enough to regulate cor porate behavior effectively.
