He told The New York Times in an interview that he was currently drafting legislation that would give the Govern ment new powers over many aspects of corporate activity that are unregulated now.

title: Investor's Newest Retailer
description: The Continental Grain Company, with its $2billion sales volume a year mostly in commodities, has diversi fied sidewards. It has entered the commodity futures busi ness for the man in the street.

title: Richey Takes 2Mile at Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23  Lee Evans flew crosscountry to run against himself in the Phila delphia Track Classic tonight.

title: Rosemary Frank Is Wed
description: Miss Rosemary Frank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Frank of 501 East 87th Street, was married here yesterday evening to Stephen M. Schmelkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Schmel kin of New York. The Rev. Dr. Nathan I. Perilman per formed the ceremony in the Bethel Chapel of Temple EmanuEl.

title: Truman Has Colitis; Condition Called Good
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 23 (AP) The ailment of for mer President Harry S. Tru man, who was hospitalized on Thursday, has been diag nosed by his physician as colitisinflammation of the large intestine.

title: College Coaches Warned to Be Alert to Drug Use
description: Two medical authorities in the field of sports have warned coaches and athletic directors of the serious im plications of stimulants and other drugs on the lives of athletes who seek an easy ride to victory.

title: Johnson Triggers Bullets
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 23 (AP) Gus Johnson scored 31 points and pulled down 31 rebounds tonight to lead the Baltimore Bullets to a 127120 victory over the San Diego Rockets.

title: Alamos May Be Very Quiet, But It Does Have Its Moments
description: ALAMOS, MexicoOnce the capital of the State of Sonora, this for mer silver mining town, nestled in the Sierra Tarahumara foot hills of northwest Mexico and nine hours driving time from the American border, is today the most colonial city in the republic. Mexican law preserves its iden tity. Alamos is also the jumping bean capital of the world because this type of bean, with its very live and active worm inside, is grown commercially here.

title: Architecture
description: I HAVE had two contin uing love affairs with Beaux Arts buildings in New York, the Metro politan Museum and the FortySecond Street Library. Both institutions have opened doors to the discovery of the wonders and beauties of the universe for me as a child and an adult, some thing the big city is supposed to doand does.

title: Six Cars Drop Out Early in Monte Carlo Rally as Bad Weather Takes a Toll
description: MONTE CARLO, Jan. 23 (AP) Six cars, including a French factory Alpine Renault, have dropped out of the Monte Carlo rally after less than a day's driving, the organizers of the event reported tonight.

title: Bridge Captain's Life Is a Busy One
description: It is not as romantic as liv ing in a lighthouse, or being yeoman of the guard or a Beefeater, the famous ward ers of the Tower of London, but Henry Johnson leads a pretty exciting life in his bridge on the River Harlem.

title: 2 From Brooklyn Are Killed As Car Hits Parked Trailer
description: Two Brooklyn residents were killed and three others injured early yesterday when an auto in which they were riding crashed into the rear of a com mercial trailer that was parked in front of 4403 56th Road, Maspeth, Queens.

title: Plunkett No.1 on the List, but He's Not the Only One
description: Bill Sullivan Jr., the pro crastinating team president, is supposed to make up his mind tomorrow about how his team, the Boston Patriots, will start off Thursday's an nual draft of 442 college players by pro football's 26 teams.

title: N.Y.U. Appoints Art Scholar
description: New York University has an nounced the appointment of Dr. Hugo Buchtal, a leading scholar of early Christian and Byzan tine art, as the first occupant of the newly established Ailsa Mellon Bruce Chair in Fine Arts at the university's Institute of Fine Arts.

title: Apollo Backup Pilot In Helicopter Crash But Escapes Injury
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Jan. 23 (UPI)Comdr. Eugene A. Cer nan of the Navy, the Apollo 14 backup pilot, escaped injury today when his helicopter crashed into the Indian River here and burst into flames while the astronaut was mak ing simulated lunar landings.

title: Redskins Obtain Kilmer In a Trade With Saints
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23 (AP)  The New Orleans Saints traded a quarterback, Billy Kilmer, to the Wash ington Redskins today for two undisclosed draft picks and a linebacker, Tom Rous sel.

title: 1971 PASSAGE IN CONGRESS DOUBTED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Whether Congress accepts or rejects President Nixon's reve nuesharing proposals, it will be able to add $8billion in the coming year to the Govern ment's outlays for aid to states and cities without exceeding the President's new budget.

title: Bertolt Brecht: Collected Plays
description: By now Bertolt Brecht has been fully accepted into cultural history, where his presence continues to give difficulty to pedagogues and others with a stake in clear, orderly classi fications. No important contempo rary playwright has inspired such vehement polemic; none is more re sistant to schemes of interpretation. His extraliterary life, notable for a highly idiosyncratic Marxism and a capacity to improvise commitments, has been thrown back at his art or used to help justify it. The alter native portraits are of Brecht as wily, selfserving, a hoodwinker, or as infinitely resourceful, a master strategist of survival. The one thing clear is that his influence on the theater, which derives as much from his theoretical writings as from his plays, has been rivalled in our time only by those of Stanislavski and Artaud.

title: For Young Readers
description: Black consciousnessraising is an ambiguous phrase: it can suggest raising the level of con sciousness among whites about blacks as well as making black more selfaware. In the case of each of these books at hand, both references apply.

title: Chartering Yacht Helps Owner Beat Maintenance Costs
description: J. P. Morgan's famous dic tum to the contrary, an in creasing number of today's moneyconscious salts are thinking about the cost of maintaining a yacht and, as a result, can afford to own one.

title: The World
description: SINGAPORE  The 31 mem ber nations of the British Com monwealth last week ended nine days of talks here, and the par ticipants adjudged the meeting a success because the worst that might have happened did not oc cur: No one walked out of the conference or the Common wealth.

title: The Nation
description: The strike New Yorkers had dreaded mosta walkout of the police force  came and went last, week with less upset of metropolitan life patterns than has been caused in recent months by strikes of janitors, fuel oil drivers or even Off Broadway actors. But the city's deliverance from fears of whole sale looting, mugging and riot on policeless streets brought no surcease of worry that its eight million people might yet be en gulfed in a holocaust on the embattled Civil Service front.

title: Katherine Francis Becomes a Bride

Morris performed the ceremony in the chantry of St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: For a Rainy Day
description: Showers can come up sud denly when on the water, so boating experts suggest carrying a suitable number of inexpensive plastic rain coats in the dash compart ment.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) Death sentences imposed re cently on two American soldiers, in South Korea have focused new attention on the quality of justice for United States serv icemen accused of crimes against civilians in foreign countries.

description: The number of stockmod el boats on the market in creases each year. In 1971 a newboat buyer will have 3,726 models to choose from, with a boat for every need and every pocketbook, ac cording to an industrywide survey conducted by Boat ing magazine.

title: Guest Unable to Attend
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 23 (AP) Gov. Preston Smith invited Steve Robertson to his inaugu ration Tuesday but he could not attend. Robertson had struck up a written correspondence with the Governor's office and two weeks ago received an invitation to the inauguration. Robertson is in prison at Crans ton, R. I., serving a life term for murdering two sailors.

description: Not at all by coincidence, the editors of a new maga zine called On the Sound, photographed, written and edited for a special regional audience oriented toward the sea, have chosen the boat show for its debut.

title: Donald Proctor Schenk Plans To Marry Deborah E. Huffman
description: LOUISVILLE,. Ky., Jan. 23 Miss Deborah Elizabeth Huffman and Donald Proctor Shenk have made plans to be married here on June 26.

title: S. R. Anthony Jr. Weds Anne Sampsell
description: Miss Anne Corley Samp sell and Silas R. Anthony Jr. were married here yesterday afternoon in St. James' Epis copal Church. The Right Rev. Anson P. Stokes Jr., retired Bishop of Massachusetts, per formed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Almus M. Thorp Jr. A re ception was held at the River Club.

title: Lines Harden in Britain On the Common Market
description: LONDON, Jan. 23Long ex pected and long delayed, Brit ain's most fundamental politi cal confrontation in many years has at last begun. It is the fight over the Common Market.

title: Tommy's Bag Is Full of Bombs (and Cliches)
description: NEW HAVEN THERE was a point about 20 minutes into Where Has Tommy Flowers Gone?, now being given its first performances at the Yale University Thea ter, when I suddenly had high hopes for the play. Tommy's brother, casually revolving a beer can in his hand as he peered at us from behind hornrimmed glasses, men tioned that he really rather liked Tommy but then went on to say a few words about his own not very satis factory life. His wife was sleeping around, for one thing; he knew that, but didn't really know what to do about it. Didn't have any particular urge to do anything about it, in fact. Why move, why take steps, why adopt attitudes in a world turned altogether irresponsible?

title: The Market, Technically Speaking
description: Most economists foresee only a slow and hesitant re covery in 1971, with inflation sapping most of the increase in gross national product and corporate profits remaining under considerable pressure. A few, on the other hand, see a much sharper recovery, with excellent gains in corpo rate profits.

title: Stability in the Balance
description: Balancing the weight in an outboardpowered boat is im portant because a load too far forward will cause the bow to bury, while a load too far aft makes the boat hard to handle and may raise the bow so high that it limits the driver's view.

The law also provides for removal of the silver content in our half dollar and disposal of the 2.9 million silver dollars now be ing held by the Tresury De partment.

title: The Cattle Car

They were done up in spanking new suits and ties, and looked inevitably like a team of per forming midgets. The mother explained that her husband had lost his walter's job in New York and she was joining him in Areciboa coastal townto be gin a new life.

title: Muskie Criticizes Administration on Economy and Asia Policy
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 23Senator Edmund S. Muskie criticized the Nixon Adminis tration's economic tactics and Southeast Asia policies today; assuming a more partisan stance than usual.

title: The Nation

description: It is doubtful that there is a boat owner anywhere who has not had passengers ask, How fast are we going? while out for a spin.

title: What's New in Theater?
description: A DOLL'S HOUSE, a new adaptation of Ibsen's play by Christopher Hampton, got nine enthusiastic re views, one mixed and one negative. Clive Barnes called it a superlative re vival. A Doll's House was years ahead of its time in its eloquent asseveration of women's rights and its clearminded exposition of women's subjection. Nora is what Women's Lib now adays calls a sexual ob ject. As Nora, Claire Bloom is giving a thrilling performance that has a complexity and depth to it that remind me of the in stinctive doomeager pas sion she brought to her Juliet at the Old Vic many years ago. Donald Mad den's Torvald is also a commanding portrayal and the rest of the cast were excellent. Christopher Hampton's new adaptation has the freshness of a new play about it. Patrick Gar land's staging is deft and intelligent. All in all, this production captures all the excitement that Ibsen's own audience must have felt when the play was new. For Walter Kerr, see Page 1.

description: Beginners and experts are welcome at the fourth annual Predicted Log Seminar on Saturday in conjunction with the boat show.

title: Stay Clear of Fishermen
description: When cruising, steer wide, of anchored fishermen. They may have lines or nets out for 50 yards or more and chances are they would be cut, by coming too close. Also recommended is slow ing down as you approach fishermen and not opening up to cruising speed until well past their boat.

description: MYSTIC, Conn.The Mys tic Seaport has reported that, in expanding its Junior Museum, it was seeking arti facts involving children who went to sea under sail in the old days with their parents.

title: U.S. Businesses Sounding Out Peking on Trade
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 23A number of American business men have made informal ap proaches to Chinese Communist sources here with the aim of exploring trade possibilities. One approach produced some discussion but the response has been disappointing.

Spilman performed the cere mony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: NIXON TO STUMP FOR REFORM PLAN;
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  President Nixon plans to cam paign nationally for broad, bi partisan support of his govern meat reform proposals.

United Nations Secretary General Thant was able to express his cautious optimism and to say that the mood was shared by Gunnar V. Jarring, his special representative.

title: Orthopedists Discuss Knee Injuries in Football

title: CANADIENS DOWN RED WINGS 6 TO 2

title: Photography
description: IN 19thcentury Italy there was a village high in the Sabine hills that fur nished the artists Rome with most of their models. Every autumn, when the harvest was in, the vil lagers came down to Rome in their colorful local cos tumes and took up their sta tions at the foot of the Span ish Steps, where the tourist camera now ceaselessly clicks. At the same season the artists of Rome came back from their summer jaunts to the lakes, the moun tains or the Sorrentine penin sula. Artists and models met and agreed upon fees, and the following spring there would flow back to London, Paris, Stockholm and New York an abundant stream of foxy grandpas, mischievous urchins, smiling girls with pitchers on their heads, bare footed jealous swains and other mementos of pictur esque peasant life in the sunny Southpaintings des tined to bring a spot of warmth and color into the wintry gloom of closely cur Northern

title: WAR STALLS WORK ON MEKONG DAM
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 23  Fighting in Cambodia has stalled work indefinitely on the $27million Prek Thnot power and irrigation project be gun in 1969 as the first major step to develop the huge Me kong River basin.

title: N. AUSTIN HANAU
description: VERONA, N. J., Jan. 23N. Austin Hanau, a marketing executive, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here. He was 77 years old and lived at 14 Green Acres Drive.

title: Snowmaking: A Flurry of New Machines

title: Science
description: Our image of the cave man is vivid. He was filthy, hairy, stoop shouldered, dull  witted and carried a roughhewn club. According to the cartoonists, he liked to pull girls around by the hair.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Should a gentleman offer a lady a seat at dinner? Not if it's a dinner of the pres tigious Economic Club of New York, which still follows a 63yearold policy of men only at its dinner meetings (perhaps with the idea that economics is not a fit subject for feminine ears or inter est).

title: Tickets for Frazier Fight Go on Sale Tomorrow
description: A limited number of tickets for the Joe FrazierMuham mad Ali heavyweight title bout on March 8 at Madison Square Garden will go on sale tomorrow at 10 A.M. at the Felt Forum box office.

title: Miss Reynolds, Mt. Holyoke '71, Becomes Bride
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23Miss Patricia Callan Reynolds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Callan Reyn olds of Westbury, L.I., was married here this afternoon to William Felton Barrett 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barrett Jr. of Great Barrington. The ceremony in St. Paul's Epis copal Church was performed by the Rev. G. D. Krumbhaar.

title: PHONE UNION HEAD IN PRIVATE TALKS
description: The president of the New York Telephone Company and the president of the Communi cations Workers of America met privately here yesterday to seek a way out of the tenacious statewide telephone strike.

title: 10 Million Acres in 10 Years
description: An estimated 10 million acres of new boatingfishing waters will be created during the coming decade by new governmentsponsored im poundments.

title: City Is Assailed on Agreement to Pay $100,000 a Year, to a Welfare Hotel to Hire Private Guards
description: The city has agreed to pay welfare hotel nearly $100,000 a year to hire private guards, ac cording to a community plan ning board and Representative Edward I. Koch, who strongly attacked the arrangement.

title: Shirley Burden, A Banker Here, Weds Mrs. Lyon
description: Shirley C. Burden, an in vestment banker here, was married yesterday morning to Mrs. Julietta Valverde Lyon, a Chilean widow. Mr. Burden a former motion picture pro ducer lives in Beverly Hills and Montecito, Calif., and maintains an apartment here. His son is City Councilman Carter Burden.

title: Meltzers Have Son
description: A son was born at Mount Sinai Hospital on Jan. 18 to Mr. and Mrs. Irving Meltzer of Brookville, L. I. The child has been named Ross William Walter.

title: Natural Resources Agency: Old Idea but New Impetus
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The idea of a department of natural resources that would have re sponsibility, now dispersed in several departments and inde pendent agencies, for energy fuels, water power, minerals, forests and such soft re sources as national parks has been around for a long time.

title: John Cioffi to Wed Lee Woodman
description: NEW LONDON, N. H., Jan. 23 Dr. Everett M. Wood man, president of Colby Junior College, and Mrs. Woodman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss E. Lee Wood man, to John A. Cioffi. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Cioffi of Wilmot. A wedding in June is planned.

title: SANTA ANITA PAYS DOUBLE OF $4,028
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 23 (UPI)Longshot winners of the first and second races com bined today to form a Santa Anita record dailydouble pay off of $4,028 on a $2 ticket.

title: Education
description: The function of schools has long been a subject of Ideologi cal controversy. Should schools confine themselves to academic teaching? Or should they branch out into a wide area of com munity activities and involve themselves in the entire range of children's education and wel fare?

title: Sally Hubbard Will Be Bride
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Jan. 23Mr. and Mrs. John Al ford Hubbard of Brookville and Londonderry, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Margaret Hubbard, to James Montgomery Cronk. An early spring wedding is planned.

title: He Gave Up Writing for Winery on High Tor
description: Twenty miles north of the George Washington Bridge, about a mile west of the Hudson along winding, rural South Mountain Road in Rockland County, it is possible to find High Tor Vineyards if someone has told you how to get to it. There is no sign on the road.

title: Boating on the Nilea Gift, a Perfection
description: CAIROBoat life on the Nile is the most enjoyable of all restora tives for the sick, and (is a per fection) for lovers of all that is luxurious in travel. This unattributed paean, quoted in John Murray's Hand book for Travellers in Lower and Upper Egypt (London, 1900), has rung true for many a tourist over the last 70 years.

title: Shipwreck Diving a Major Attraction of Cayman Islands
description: GEORGETOWN, Grand Cayman, W.I.If diving for shipwrecks is your thing, one of the grooviest places to do it is in the waters surround ing the Cayman Islands.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Kansas on Top, 9055
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Jan. 23 (AP)  Fifth  ranked Kansas raised its Big Eight Conference record to 20 with a 9055 rout of Oklahoma State tonight be fore a seasonhigh crowd of 16,100.

title: Ryun Wins Mile in 4:04.4 in First Race Since1969 and Is Eager to Run Again
Tanker Crash Off Thames; No Oil Spills Are Reported
description: SOUTHEND ON SEA, Eng land Jan. 23 (Reuters)A Brit ish oil tanker and a sludge car rier collided at the mouth of the Thames today, but no inju ries or oil spills were reported.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONPresident Nix on came through his first confrontation with private in dustry over prices last week with a compromise that was evi dently acceptable to him but that left the industry far from pleased.

title: LAYER WINS AGAIN IN TENNIS SERIES
description: DETROIT, Jan. 23 (UPI) Rod Laver of Australia rallied from two sets down tonight to capture his sixth straight $10,000 match in the $210,000 Tennis Champions Classic. He posted a 57, 57, 62, 62, 62 victory over Tom Okker of the Netherlands before 5,152 fans.

title: Striker Markets 54Foot, LongRange Motor Yacht
description: A new 54foot luxury motor yacht with a cruising range of 750 miles without refueling and speeds up to 21 knots has been introduced by Striker Aluminum Yachts, Inc. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: About Pro Basketball
description: The question is the same, and only the name is differ ent. What's wrong with the Knicks? A few months ago, it was the prevalent sports question among New York fans, only the last word was Mets. Before that it was Jets.

title: Boeing's 747 Confounded Forecasters in First Year
description: Just before the Boeing 747 jumbo jet went into service a year ago, insurance experts were predicting two disastrous orashes in the first 18 months.

title: Poems to be understood, you understand
description: T. S. Eliot assured us that genuine poetry often communicates before it is understood, and in his Dream Song 366 John Berryman made the assurance even more explicit: These Songs are not meant to be understood, you understand./They are only meant to terrify & comfort. Of course, there is a joke here, but the Songs did become easier to understand as they went along; and though Berryman was impelled to write a prefatory note insisting that they were essentially about an imaginary character (not the poet, not me) named Henry, something more than a fictional speaker was operating when an alive andkicking Berryman could be heard lamenting the deaths of Delmore Schwartz or Randall Jarrell, or telling us what he read at Columbia or how he felt about living in Ireland.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: BERTRAM UNVEILS 28FOOT CRUISER
description: A 28foot Bertram cruiser is making its debut at the show. She is accompanied by a 35foot sport fisherman and a 24foot Moppie II run about. All are made of fiber glass.

title: Catholics in Belfast Criticize Bishop
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 23We're the Bally murphy mums, said Mrs. Teresa Cahill, mother of eight, as she led her delegation of 15 mothers up the driveway to the Bishop's brick mansion.

title: L.G. King Weds Mrs. Granducci
description: BATH, Me., Jan. 23Mrs. Carolyn Miller Granducci of Foster's Point and St. Thom as, the Virgin Islands, was married here this morning to Lewis G. King of Chilmark, Martha's Vineyard, Mass. Cir cuit Court Judge Donald Spear performed the cere mony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Justus H. Miller of Foster's Point and Boynton Beach, Fla.

title: Providence Hockey Victor
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 23 Capt. Richard Pumple scored two goals and assists today to lead Providence College's hock ey team to an 83 triumph over Princeton.

title: African Team in U.S. Track
description: DURHAM, N. C., Jan. 23 (AP) An official United States team will meet a team from Africa in track and field next July 16 and 17 at Duke Univer sity's Wade Stadium.

title: WOMEN GET ROLE ON AUTO TRACKS
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 23 The barriers against women in United States Auto Club racing are beginning to crumble. The club, which has had a long tra dition of men only in the pits and other working areas of a racetrack, has decided to li cense women as racing officials.

title: Kiekhaefer Adding to Plant For New Line of Engines
description: Kiekhaefer Aeromarine Mo tors, Inc., has begun construc tion of additional plant fa cilities at Fond du Lac, Wis., to produce its new line of snowmobile and recreational vehicle engines, E. C. Kiek haefer, president of the com pany, announced.

title: Banking Aide Plans to Wed Miss Leathers
description: Leslie J. Leathers, whose father, Viscount Leathers, was a former British Min ister of Transport, and Mrs. Leathers of Lindfield, Eng land, have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Rosemary Elizabeth Leathers, to Winfried Franz Wilhelm Bischoff of Hong Kong, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Bischoff of Johannes, burg, South Africa.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 23 (AP) Mr. Johnson has shown up with a hearing aid which he does not care to hear about. He wore the device, attached to his glasses, at the dedication of a building at the University of Texas on Thursday. How do you like the hearing aid? a newsman asked. Mighty good to see you, was Mr. Johnson's reply.

title: Flyers, Stars in Draw
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 23 (UPI)  Bill Lesuk scored with two seconds to play to night to give Philadelphia a 22 tie with Minnesota and keep the Flyers 1 point ahead of the North Stars for third place in the West Division.

title: Small VDiesel Engine Introduced by Cummins
description: The Cummins Engine Com pany of Columbus, Ind., has introduced a small Vdiesel engine.

title: SERIES INTRODUCED BY NEW AMSTERDAM
description: Variety may be spicy, but too much of it, carelessly blend ed may be indigestible and fla vorless. This seemed to be the trouble with the New Amster dam Ensemble's concert, the first of a series, in Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday night. There was a dash of everything, from the classicism of Mozart to the nolonger avantgardism of a contemporary Dutch com poser, Rob du Bois.

title: Jacob J. Rosenblum Dead at 73; Dewey's Homicide Bureau Chief
description: Jacob J. Rosenblum, who re tired as chief of the homicide bureau of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office at the end of 1941, died here yes terday. He was 73 years old and lived at 180 East 79th Street.

title: Cutting Costs In San Juan: The Guesthouse
description: SAN JUAN, P. R.Good bargains these days for travelers bearing slim, recessionstyle purses are the guesthouses of San Juan. The typical guest house here is a converted home accommodating 10 to 20 visitors, and it is usually run by the owner. There are well over 30 of them in San Juan, and the best offer wellappointed, airconditioned rooms with friendly atmosphere often lacking in luxury hotels.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Portland, long vying with Seattle for honors as the No. 1 port in the Pacific North west, has recently bestirred itself administratively, phy sically and financially to bolster Its facilities.

title: Janet E. Lee Planning Bridal to Bruce Beach
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 23  Miss Janet Ellingwood Lee, a senior at Skidmore College, plans to be married to Bruce Kershaw Beach, a junior at Dartmouth College who served as a first lieutenant with the Army in Vietnam.

title: 4 ARRESTED IN RAIDS ON L.I. GAMBLING RING
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 23 Nassau County and New York City detectives made two raids in Valley Stream today that District Attorney William A. Cahn said had smashed one of the richest gambling operations ever uncovered in the country.

title: Marine Charts Can Help Calculate Boat's Speed
description: To calculate boat speeds without running a measured mile, experienced drivers de termine distances in feet between objects on shore, using scales and channel markers or landmarks shown on marine charts.

title: Harry I. Moatz to Wed Susan J. Goldman
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Jan. 23 Capt. Peter J. Goldman, U.S.N., and Mrs. Goldman of Arlington and New York, have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Susan Jane Goldman, to Harry I. Moatz. He is the son of Mrs. Francis I. Moatz of Miami and the late Sam uel Teitelbaum of New York and was adopted by his late stepfather, Mr. Moatz of Syracuse, N. Y.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THERE WAS no dearth of news last week, news prices, news of interest rates, news of the financial markets. For all the succession of events, however, the big news for the business and financial com munity was news awaitedthe State of the Union Mes sage after the close of business Friday night and the budget and economic messages still to come.

title: Headliners
description: He is 93d of 100 in seniority (past Government service puts him ahead of seven other freshmen). He is slimmer (down to 170 pounds), older (59) and his hair curls modishly down alongside his ears. He is Hubert Horatio Humphrey who last week returned to the United States Senate as junior Senator from Minnesota. Settling into his fiveroom suite of offices with his staff of 22 still unpacking piles of cardboard cartons, the former Vice President, who first en tered the Senate in 1949, said he was glad to be home. He also promised that President Nixon, to whom he lost in the 1968 Presi dential election, is going to hear from me. But he warned his Democratic colleagues to put their minds not only on how to at tack Nixon, but on how to attack problems. If we do thatand Nixon's one of the problems, of coursewe can show the country the Democrats can govern.

title: Ban Sought on C.I.A. Aid For Radio Free Europe
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Senator Clifford P. Case, Re publican of New Jersey, charged today that the Central Intelli gence Agency had spent several hundred million dollars over the last 20 years to keep Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty func tioning.

title: Bailing Before Sailing
description: If a boat tied to a dock for a period of time has water in it, bail or pump it out be fore going afloat. This way you won't start out and then discover that the problem is a serious leak.

title: Penn State Writer Honored
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23 (UPI)Stephen D. Solomon, 22 years old, Penn State Univer sity senior majoring in journal ism, has been awarded first place in the editorial writing competition of the William Randolph Hearst Foundation's 11th annual journalism awards program. He received a $900 scholarship and his school of journalism received a matching grant.

title: FALSE FIRE CALLS ARE UP 24% IN CITY
description: A phenomenal increase of 24 per cent in false alarms answered by firemen here in 1970 was reported yesterday by Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery. He said there were two false alarms for every three actual fires.

title: Israelis Report a New Blood Test for Early Detection of Cancer
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 23Israeli medical researchers have re ported the development of a new blood test for diagnosing cancer far earlier than under present diagnostic methods.

title: CHURCH COUNCIL MAY BE WIDENED
description: LOUISVILLE, Jan. 23  A plan for the reorganization of the National Council of Churches that would open its doors to Roman Catholics and the more theologically conservative de nominations such as the South ern Baptist Convention and the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Sy nod was unveiled today.

title: CUT IN FOE'S FLOW OF TROOPS NOTED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The rate of infiltration of North Vietnamese troops toward the South has dropped surprisingly in December and January after a sharp rise at the start of the dry season, according to United States military intelligence sources.

title: the traveler's world
description: KAMPALA, UgandaTouristmind ed Ugandans toss two questions at almost every American visitor who sets foot in this capital. The first is put timidly: Do you like Kampala? and after the visitor admits most honestly that it is a beautiful little city, clean and fresh, there comes the inevitable second question: Does it re mind you of San Francisco? The an swer, regretfully, is that it does not, despite the seven hills inside and the many hills outside the city, treecovered and green.

title: Swedish Lifter Sets Record
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, Jan. 23 (AP)A Swedish weight lifter, Bo Johansson, 25 years old, bet tered the world middle heavy weight record yesterday in the press by 2.2 pounds, lifting here.

title: MANHATTAN HALTS SETON HALL, 8064
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 23  Manhattan College's bas ketball team, after losing six straight games to such nation ally ranked powers as Florida State, Jacksonville and Penn, turned on an old rival tonight and beat Seton Hall, 8064, in Walsh Auditorium.

title: In the Mailbox
description: READINGTON, N. J., Jan. 23 Miss Glisten, a 7yearold gray mare who adamantly re fused to go over a fence two years ago, won the combined limitopen jumper champion ship today at the Four Seasons Farm horse show.

title: Stainless Steel Shaft Boon to Idle Boat
description: The amateur auto expert you meet at the gas station often maintains that you can get a good deal by buying a traveling salesman's used car. His theory is that a car in constant use stays in better shape than one that makes only short trips to the gro cery store.

title: Barbara W. Dancik Wed in Bronxville
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 23In the Village Lutheran Church here today, Miss Bar bare Walach Dancik, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. William John Danclk, was married to Paul Cutler Hartshorn, son of Dr. and Mrs. Calvin War ren Hartshorn of West Deer field, Mass. The Rev. Howard L. Halter performed the cere mony.

title: Blades Flash Before Dawn as Figure Skaters Practice for U.S. Championships
description: The most talented of the nation's figure skaters, in cluding 21 in the metropoli tan area, are bounding out of bed even earlier than usual these days.

title: Steam Engine Found in River
description: ANDERSON, Calif., Jan, 23 (UPI)A steam engine that toppled from a ferry into the Sacramento River in 1896 has been found by divers. The en gine, which divers said was in such good condition that the numbers on its boiler were easily recognizable, had been used to haul timber from the forests to the mill.

title: News of the Rialto
description: THESE are troubled times for serious plays, ob served director Alan Schneider the other day, knowing full well that he was not the first, nor will he be the last, to utter the contemporary theater's lamentable truism. Still, and quixotically, he's going ahead with serious plays. As of the moment, he's engaged in stagingfor the fourth timea production of Waiting for Godot, which should be ready for an early February opening at the Sheridan Square Playhouse. Immediately thereafter he hopes to turn his attention a serious play indeed, Uptight, by Gnter Grass, the German writer who has gained international standing with such novels as The Tin Drum, Dog Years and Cat and Mouse.

title: In the Mailbox
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Court Censures Judge on Coast For Comments to a Rape Victim
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23  The California Supreme Court has censured a Superior Court judge because he spoke harsh ly to a woman who had com plained that he had been leni ent to two men who raped her.

title: Some Second Thoughts About WellMeant Rule
description: On a stormy night in the not too distant future there will be a major yachting disaster. How many, if any, lives will be lost will depend on nothing but sheer luck. But the real tragedy will be that the disaster need not have happened.

title: 7 Seale Jurors Are Selected in 70 Days
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 23  When jury selection started for the trial of Bobby G. Seale and Mrs. Ericka Huggins last Nov. 17, lawyers for the two Black Panthers complained that the clock on the courtroom wall was noisy and erratic. They asked if it could be fixed.

title: Lion Sleeps Wins at Hialeah for Sixth in Row
description: MIAMI, Jan. 23I told you he was all heart, said a beam ing John Zarthar. They can run to him but they're not go ing to run by him.

title: Paper Makers Grope for Upturn
description: The strength of the re covery in the pulp, paper and paperboard industry this year depends heavily on the degree of the upturn in the economy as a whole.

title: Monorail System Is Speeding Production at MFG
description: MFG Boat Company of Union City, Pa., which pro duces thousands of fiberglass boats annually, may be one of the few factories in the world to give its boats a monorail ride.

title: Pamela B. Kerr Of Bryn Mawr Plans Nuptials
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 23 Miss Pamela Burgess Kerr, a physical education instruc tor at Bryn Mawr College, plans to be married to David Lydig Frothingham Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frothingham.

title: Bruins Trounce Black Hawks, 62, Scoring 3 Times in ThirdPeriod Surge
description: BOSTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) Wayne Carleton scored from out of a pileup in front of the Chicago goal tonight to break a deadlock and spark the Bos ton Bruins to a 62 victory over the Black Hawks in a battle between the National Hockey League division leaders.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Books:
description: Getting into the mutual fund business, as one of the contributors to this interest ing symposium notes, is a bit more difficult than starting a delicatessen. And yet, new funds are started every year. A few succeed.

title: Auxiliary Built in Greece
description: The Olympic Princess, a 30 foot fiberglass sailing auxili ary built in Greece, is being shown by Olympic Yachts, Ltd., of Montreal.

title: Schwartzes Have a Son
description: ORANGE, Calif., Jan. 23 A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. John L. Schwartz on Tuesday in St. Joseph's Hos pital here. The child, who has been named David Jonathan, is a grandson of George Stromberg of New York and of Harry Schwartz, a member of the editorial board of The New York Times, and Mrs. Schwartz of Scarsdale, N. Y. The child's father is a resi dent in psychiatry at the Uni versity of California Medical Center.

title: Stamps
description: THREE stamps will be issued by the United Nations on March 12 to promote Interna tional Support for Refugees. Two of the stamps, 6 cents, brown, and 13 cents, blue. will be in United States cur rency, for use on mail from United Nations headquarters here. The third stamp, 50 centimes, red, will be for use at the Geneva, Switzerland, offices of the world organi zation. Of the 6cent stamp, 2,400,000 will be printed; of the 13cent, 2,000,000; and of the 50c, 1,900,000. The printing will be by offset at the security printing works of Joh. Enschede en Zonen, Haarlem, the Netherlands.

title: Polly Baker To Be Bride
description: FAR HIILS, N. J., Jan. 23 Miss Anne Whitman Baker and Stephen L. Parker of Washington plan to be mar ried in June.

title: Arizona StripMining Project Leaving Navajo Land Unscarred
description: BLACK MESA, Ariz., Jan. 19 Here on the sagebrushdotted upland of northern Arizona, one of the nation's largest coal com panies is embarking on a dis tinctively twosided project.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Among the 185 State of the Union messages delivered to the American Con gress, few have been so ambi tious in scope as that delivered two nights ago by President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Gardens
description: ONE of the joys of winter walk is the tracery of darkon light as branches stand against the snow. Even against bare ground, twigs bracing up against the ele ments have a beauty of their own. Like a fine painting, the total is produced by the blending of form and color and line.

title: Science
description: Another countdown begins to morrow. Another manned flight to the moon begins next Sunday. It might have been just another moonlanding mission, fairly rou tine by spaceage standards, had it not been for Apollo 13. But the near disaster of that mission last April has placed a special burden on the engineers and as tronauts of Apollo 14.

title: A Careful Review of Boat Insurance Is of Utmost Importance
description: Boatowners should review the condition of their insur ance as well as their craft before putting the boat into the water.

title: French General's Son Killed
description: FORTLAMY, Chad, Jan. 23 (Reuters)The son of the com mander of French Forces in Chad was one of two soldiers killed Friday in a clash with rebels in the north of the coun try, military sources said here today. The son was Bertrand Cortadellas, 24 years old, a non commissioned officer. His fath er, Gen. Edouard Cortadellas, commands 2200 French troops in Chad.

title: From Soup to Nonsense in German. Museums
description: WHATEVER it is in a national character that makes people collect things, the trait cer tainly comes out strongly in West Germany's multiplicity of oddball museums. The as sembled curiosa range all the way from soup to bedbugs, from torture instruments to thimbles.

title: Mounted Trot Title Race Today to Test French Jockeys
description: PARIS, Jan. 23They look like silkclad Don Quixote, bouncing straightbacked in their saddles, their crops held like lances as if to frighten hostile windmills.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: StandUp Cyclist to Stay Seated Here
description: When Barry Briggs of England competes in American motorcycle races, he cannot help attracting attention because his stand up riding style is radically different from the American method. But tomorrow night Briggs wants to be inconspicuous.

title: Robin Lerner Fiancee Of Richard M. Kagan
description: Miss Robin Lerner, a grand daughter of the late Joseph J. Lerner, founder of the Ler ner Shops, a nationwide chain of fashion stores, and a niece of Alan Jay Lerner, the playwright and lyricist, will be married to Richard Mark Kagan of Beverly Hills, Calif., son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel B. Kagan of Edison, N. J., on May 29 in the Beverly Wil shire Hotel. A reception for 100 guests will be held there.

title: Shakespearean Actors Keep Audience Calm in Fire
description: Flames and smoke shot over the stark white sets of the Royal Shakespeare Company's production of A Midsummer Night's Dream at the Billy Rose Theater last night. But the troupe's actorsbantering with startling appropriate lines successfully calmed the capa city audience.

title: The V.I.P. Ghosts in Virginia: A Spectral Who's Who
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Mason McCon naughey was awakened from a deep sleep in the dead of night by the whining of her dog. Slipping out of bed, she crept fear fully into the drawingroom. There, in front of the fireplace, she saw a luminous figure in a white flow ing gownthe Haw Branch ghost. De scribing the apparition to her mother, she said, The ghost was tall and had dark eyes and hair. It smiled at me and then vanished.

title: MRS. JAMES RANDALL
description: URBANA, III., Jan. 23Ruth Painter Randall, a historian, died in Burnham City Hospital, Champaign, last evening. She was 78 years old.

title: FLEMMING RESIGNS AS COLLEGE'S HEAD
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 23  The board of trustees of Macalester College, which has encountered financial troubles attributed in part to a halt in contributions by DeWitt Wallace, has accept ed the resignation of its presi dent, Arthur S. Flemming.

title: Three Records Are Set In N.A.I.A. Track Meet
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 23 (UPI)Rex Maddaford, a 24 yearold New Zealander run ning for Eastern New Mexico, clipped more than five seconds off the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics indoor record in the twomile tonight, covering the distance in 8 min utes 47.7 seconds.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Jan. 23 (AP)Larry Harris, a sophomore, and Wil Robinson, a junior, combined for 53 points today to lead West Vir ginia to a 10790 victory over Rhode Island.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONIn his proposals for Government reorganization and rev enue sharing with the states, President Nixon has followed the wise adage to think no small thoughts. He has sug gested the most sweeping reform of the Federal system ever put forward by any President; and the net effect on American life, if these plans should be carried out, might well be compa rable to the rather more improvised New Deal revolution of the thirties.

title: Today's Little Boats Fit Youngsters
description: The boat you owned as a kid remains very special even if you continue that traditional yachting progres sion to larger and more lavish hulls later in life. I wonder what Commodore Vander bilt's first boat was like. Sir Thomas Lipton's was made from a Clydeside packing case; my own was a humble rowboat.

title: Soprano Hurt in Fall on Stairs During Her First Met Fidelio
description: Since singing the part of Leonore in Beethoven's Fide lio is hazardous enough under any circumstances, a soprano who falls down steps during a performance and gets a bloody nose as a result cannot be called lucky.

title: Suburban Housing for Blacks Eases
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 23  In two years of operation here, a nonprofit corporation called Westchester Residential Oppor tunities, has helped more than 100 black families find and buy homes in Westchester County.

title: Measles Strikes Brooklyn Areas; Immediate Immunization Urged
description: A measles outbreak has be gun in three areas of Brooklyn, Dr. Mary C. McLaughlin, the city's Health Commissioner, re ported yesterday. She urged all parents of preschool children throughout the city to have them get immunizations im mediately.

title: END OF ERA NEAR FOR U. OF TEXAS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 23 Frank C. Erwin Jr. will soon step down as chairman of the Board of Regents of the Uni versity of Texas system. It may be the end of an era of shake ups and reorganization.

title: ST. JOHN'S ROUTS ST. FRANCIS, 9857
description: St. John's made basketball look easy last night as the Red men trounced St.Francis, 9857. It was the, highest winning score in the 58 games of the local series.

title: AT ARMS LENGTH FIRST IN STAKES
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23  Duplicating her performance in the prep for this race, At Arms Length raced to her first stakes victory as she won the $32,650 Heirloom Handicap by 1 lengths today before a crowd of 20,893 at Liberty Bell Race.

title: Ranger Game With Stars Here Today on Television
description: The New York Rangers, un beaten in 21 consecutive home games this season, will try to extend that streak this after noon when they take on the Minnesota North Stars at Madi son Square Garden. Game time is 1:05 P.M., and the contest will be televised nationally, live and in color, over the CBSTV Network.

title: Karen Kohler Hartmann Married
description: Miss Karen Kohler Hart mann, daughter of Dr. Hans A. Hartmann of New York and the late Mrs. Mary Rid der Hartmann, was married yesterday afternoon to Rob ert Allen Hoffman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Hoff man of Mequon, Wis.

title: AristoCraft 19 Stays Afloat
description: The Atlanta (Ga.) Boat Works builds only one boat, the AristoCraft 19, and she is on display at the Coliseum. Available either as a hardtop day cruiser or as an open boat, she is of fiberglass with foam designed to keep the boat upright even when com pletely full of water, with the largest optional engine, all equipment and a full passen ger load.

title: Sunrise
description: Dawn still comes late, with official sunup around 7:00. The sun is a slugabed and won't get up before 6:00 until midMarch. So almost anyone can see the dawn now without feeling that he is getting up soon after midnight.

title: Law
description: Once there were 26, Six teen were officers, from lieu tenant to general. Ten were enlisted men, from private to sergeant. What linked them was a hamlet called Mylai 4 in South Vietnam where, on March 6, 1968, perhaps 500 Vietnamese civilians were slaughtered by an American company. All 26 faced United States Army courtmartial on charges ranging from pre meditated murder to derelic tion of duty in attempting to cover up what had happened.

title: Professional Propeller Test
description: Since the propeller is the sole driving force of an out board motor and since an improper one can rob an owneroperator of top en gine performance, boatmen are advised to check propel lers with dealers who have accurate tachometers and testwheels.

title: Newport Shipyard To Build Custom Boats
description: Newport Shipyard has an nounced that the 136year old Rhode Island company would move into the custom building of yachts and com mercial vessels.

title: Gadgets, Utilitarian and Otherwise, Vie With Boats for Yachtsmen's Attention
description: There is a strong feeling among the panjandrums who run the boat show that it would not be quite complete without the displays of nau tical gadgetry turned out every year by marine bou tiques.

title: Outboard Motors Tested For Degrees of Pollution
description: The marine exhaust study currently under way may settle once and for all the question of whether outboard motors are water polluters.

title: Son to the Dunns
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 23 A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wesley Dunn Jr. on Jan, 12 at the Green wich Hospital. The child has been named John Endicott. Mrs. Dunn is the former Miss Olivia Endicott Hutchins, daughter of Mrs. Hurd Hutch ins of New York and the late Mr. Hutchins. The child's father is a vice president of Kidder, Peabody & Co., New York investment bankers.

title: Algonac, Mich., Cradle of Powerboating, Adjusts to Life Without ChrisCraft
description: ALGONAC, Mich.  This town, located where the St. Clair River splits into the South and North channels, is slowly adjusting to the closing last summer of the original ChrisCraft plant. The company had made Al gonac the cradle of power boating and the onetime speedboat capital of the world.

title: National Notes
description: How to get rid of the glass bottles and abandoned cars that litter the streets of New York City? Last week, two solutions were offered, one for cars, one for bottles, and both incorporat ing the notion of returnable de posits. But neither seems likely to make much on an immediate dent.

title: Invincible Overcomes Torture Test
description: Most conscientious pleas ure boat builders put their product through some pretty ?? tests before offering ?? to the public, especially ?? new designs or new con struction materials are in olved.

title: Miss Elena Drake Prospective Bride
description: BATH, Me., Jan. 23Fred erick Ellis Drake Jr. has an nounced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Elena Drake, to Peter Vandervoort of Ridgewood, N. J., son of Mrs. Vincent Vandervoort and the late Mr. Vandervoort.

title: Books:
description: Mr. Chasan offers a quick Cook's tour of Alaska, its problems and its potential. Like most hurried tours it suffers from superficial treat ment of complicated matters and clichs.

title: Egypt Rebuffs U.S. on Truce Extension
description: CAIRO, Jan. 23The United Arab Republic has formally re buffed a United States sugges tion that the ceasefire along the Suez Canal be extended beyond its expiration date, Feb. 5. It called upon the United States to take further steps to warrant optimism that the indirect peace talks with Israel would lead to a with drawal of Israeli forces from occupied Arab areas.

title: Woman Is at Helm on AustraliaGibraltar Sail
description: Face it, there are going to be a lot of problems for any woman who decides to buy a 61foot auxiliary ketch and sail it around the world. Not the least of them is trying to explain to people why in the world she decided to take up this sort of life.

title: An Artist Who Can Make A Corkscrew His Own
description: THAT William Copley's new show at the Iolas Gallery is his second in nine months indicates the continuing energy and popularity of this curious American surrealist who signs his colorful, cartoony paint ings CPLY. Now 52, Copley was born in New York and began painting in 1946 in California, where he befriend ed and was influenced by the distinguished colony of refu gee artists that included Max Ernst and Man Ray. Since then he has divided his time between New York and Paris, meanwhile staying remark ably faithful to his original in spiration, which might be said to owe equal fealties to the vivid decorative effects of French painters including Matisse and Raoul Duly, to the obsessive iconography of Magic Realists like Magritte, and to the bumptious charm of the comic strip. And, while scarcely major, his work remains a singular and in triguing sidelight to American art of the last 25 years.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Charles Flowers's first novel, IT NEVER RAINS IN LOS ANGELES (Coward, McCann Geoghegan, $5.95), has the structure of the classic detec tive story, beginning with the murder of a black student in a California high school and ending with the solution. Judged solely in terms of our genre, this structure is not flawless: the killer's schema is unnecessarily contrived and all the questions raised are not fully answered. Let me add at once that such matters are un important in this brilliant tour de force. It Never Rains in Los Angeles offers so much more than the usual pattern of crime and detection that most readers will be fascinated instantly by the tumultuous events that follow the killing. Only the hardened addicts will question the armature that sup ports them.

title: Leon Oler, 71, a Leader Of the Jewish Labor Bund
description: Leon Oler, a leader of the Jewish Labor Bund, a Socialist organization here, died yester day at Madison Avenue Hospi tal. He was 71 years old and lived at 330 West 28th Street.

title: An American Tragedy
description: Harriette Arnow's brutal, beauti ful novel, The Dollmaker, has a permanent effect upon the reader: long after one has put it aside, he is still in the presence of its people, absorbed in their trivial and tragic dilemma, sorting out their mistakes, rearranging their possibilities, pon dering upon the fate that makes certain people live certain lives, suffer certain atrocities, while other people merely read about them. Because Harriette Arnow's people are not articulate, we are anxious to give their confusion a recognizable order, to contribute to their reality, to complete them with language. They are assimilated into us, and we into them. The Dollmaker deals with human beings to whom language is not a means of changing or even expressing reality, but a means of pitifully recording its effect upon the nerves. It is a legitimate tragedy, our most unpretentious American master piece.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Bitterness Mounting in Teheran Against Western Oil Companies
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 23  Signs of bitterness against Western oil companies ap peared to be mounting here as ministers of oilproducing countries prepared for next week's meetings with the com panies' negotiators.

title: Television
description: CBS's new halfhour gift to Tuesday nights, All in the Family, is kind of like wishing for a little more frankness in political dia logue and getting your wish in the form of Spiro Agnew. A workingclass family situation series with a message, All in the Family is vulgar and silly. And after the disgustatfirstshock wears off, the vaudeville clinkers passed off as humor are totally predictable, both in themselves and as means of conveying the show's moral: All preju diceracial, class, sophisticated against unsophisticated and vice versais bad.

title: Bonn Study Finds Similarities Between the 2 German States
description: BONN, Jan. 23Despite the differences in their political sys tems, East Germany and West Germany appear to be develop ing their economies and social services at a parallel pace in most fields, according to a study published here this week.

title: KNICKS BEAT CELTICS, 128107, HERE;
description: The New York Knicks, whose performances lately had been offensive to their fans, were really offensive last night against the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden.

title: Three New Powerboats Being Shown by Century
description: Five fast fiberglass power craft, including three new models, are in the Century BoatCompany's display at the show. New for 1971 are the Arabian 19, a sterndrive runabout powered by Chrys ler 330 horsepower engines; the Raven 21, a modified deepV design, and the Raven 17, an inboardoutboard ski boat.

title: Air France Orders 6 Jets
description: PARIS, Jan. 23 (AP)  Air France has announced that it has ordered three more Boeing 727's and three more Boeing 747 planes. The 727's will be delivered in early 1972 and the 747's about a year later.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: The World
description: PARIS  The flow of oil to industrialized countries and Western influence in the Medi terranean were at stake last week in a confrontation between giant international companies and the countries where much of the world's oil is found. Fifteen com panies  most of them Ameri can but also those from Britain, France and the Netherlands  and 10 producer countries  seven Arab countries plus Iran, Venezuela and Indonesia  were locked in negotiations over new royalty demands.

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE OPENS ON APRIL 5
description: BOSTON, Jan. 23 (AP)The American League baseball sea son gets off to its earliest start this year, with the traditional opening game in Washington on Monday, April 5.

title: Bates Picks CoCaptains
description: LEWISTON, Me., Jan. 23 (AP)Ferdinand Russo of Port land, Me., and Peter Rubins of Manchester, Conn., will co captain next season's varsity football squad at Bates College.

title: Chrysler Outboard Line Expanded to 51 Models
description: Chrysler has expanded its line of outboards to 51 models and most are shown at the Coliseum.

title: WORLD PANEL BACKS PHILADELPHIA FAIR
description: PARIS, Jan. 23  The planned bicentennial exposition in Philadelphia in 1976 gained international status yesterday with approval by the 34nation International Bureau of Exposi tions.

title: U.M.W.'S SPENDING DETAILED IN SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Nearly 11 months after saying it would seek immediately an injunction against the United Mine Workers of America to force the union to keep financial records required by law, the Labor Department this week got its case to trial here.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Question: George Washington administered nine Federal programs. How many does President Nixon ad minister? Answer: No one knows for sure, but there are 1,400 grantinaid programs alone.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Philadelphia's financial as sets include the Girard Bank of Philadelphia, whose roots in the community date back to 1836 and whose assets exceed $2billion. The city's culturaal assets include the noted Philadelphia Orchestra.

title: All Aboard for the Cattle Car
description: PUERTO RICANS themselves call it the cattle car because of its reputation for overcrowding from the old days. Snobbish stewardesses refer to it as the roach coach because they expect the passengers to be unclean. A San Juan travel agent indelicately calls it the vomit comet allu sion, I imagine, to the great number of babes in arms or inexperienced travelers aboard the planes.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: AquaDart Adds New Ideas for '71
description: The AquaDart division of Leisuredyne, Morristown, N. J., has added a few new ideas or its 1971 AquaDart. Stand ard equipment is a 20horse power, watercooled engine, electric starter and choke and a Coast Guardapproved automatic fire control sys tem. The 25mileanhour craft is seven feet long and three feet wide and offers an engine hour meter and se lectspeed governing system. The boat retails for $995.

title: A Choice Bouquet of Churches
description: I WOULD like to murmur a few words in praise of churches, al though these may sound like heret ical words to some. I do not be lieve that churches should be inflicted upon travelers, imposed upon them as Shakespeare is sometimes forced upon reluctant school children. I do not be Hove that travelers should be bullied into seeing churches just because they axe the repositories of centuries of his tory and may be unique expressions of man's aspirations. They should be vis ited not because they are vast, not be cause they are awesome, but rather for the simple reason that they immediately give the spectator a keen sense of pleas ureeven excitement.

title: Friendship Put Magoon on Road to Two Championships
description: From Monday through Fri day, like any other ophthal mologist, Bob Magoon puts in a long day at the office and hospital. On weekends, unlike any other eye sur geon or anyone else, he drives powerboats fast enough to win national championships.

title: Program for the 92d
description: President Nixon's State of the Union Message provided a more than ordinarily aggressive and fundamental chal lenge to the new Congress. Rather than a shopping list of legislative proposals, Mr. Nixon asked approval for a broad program of government reorganization and of re distribution of power within the Federal system.

title: SAIGON WILL MOVE 5,300 WHO HELPED IN ROUTE 4 BATTLE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 23The South Vietnamese com mand announced today that it would soon withdraw its 5,300 troops who helped Cambodian soldiers clear Cambodia's stra tegic Route 4.

title: Son to the Watsons 3d
description: WESTON, Mass., Jan, 23 A son was born on Jan. 14 to Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Watson 3d in the Boston LyingIn Hospital. The child has been named Thomas William. Mrs. Watson, the former Miss Margaret T. Pattison, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Pat tison of Los Angeles. The child is the grandson also of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Wat son Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. His grandfather is chairman of the board of the Inter national Business Machines Corporation. The child's father is a firstyear law student at Boston College.

title: Religion
description: ADDIS ABABA  The ecu menical movement began in the late 19th century when forward looking Protestant leaders be gan to suspect that they had more to lose by separation than by cooperation. Their reasoning was translated to the interfaith level in the 1920's and 1930's with the first bold experiments in putting a minister, priest and rabbi on the same platform to talk about brotherhood.

title: 200 Hobie Cat Regattas
description: The Hobie Cat Class Asso ciation has released a regatta schedule for 1971 to include 128 events. By spring, the association expects to have over 200 regattas scheduled throughout the United States.

title: Civil Rights
description: ATLANTAOn Friday, as thousands filed past the cof fin of Senator Richard Rus sell, an aging state legislator with tears in his eyes stood on the steps of the Georgia Capitol mourning more than the death of a man. He's in there in the rotunda, dead and gone for good, he mut tered, dabbing at his face with a paper tissue, and there's that no good Carter up there in the Governor's officealive and kicking and giving the whole thing away to the nigras.

title: Coal Mining Becomes Key Issue For Kentucky Governor's Race
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 23 Judge Todd Hollenbach got mud on his wingtip shoes the other day and coal dust on his James Bond trench coat.

title: Governor Hails Aid Idea But Asks More U.S. Funds
description: Governor Rockefeller praised President Nixon yesterday for making historic and imagina tive proposals for revenue sharing with the states and lo cal governments, but the Gov ernor said he would press for double the $5billion suggested by the President in new and unrestricted funds.

title: PENN SIX WINS, 54, FROM DARTMOUTH
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 23 Sam Gellard's powerplay goal after 56 seconds of overtime gave Penn a 54 victory over Dartmouth tonight. Dartmouth had battled back from 20 and 42 deficits to tie the contest at 44 on Ken Davidson's two thirdperiod goals.

title: Securing Middle East Borders
description: In rejecting Egypt's proposal for an international police force to guarantee a Middle East settlement, Premier Golda Meir of Israel protests that such a force could not be a substitute for secure, recognized and defensible borders.

title: Rookies' Agents Are Prepared to Take the Football Field After Pro Draft
description: With the approach of the National Football League draft, the sport's acute tri angle is about to reappear the clubs, the rookies and the rookies' agents.

title: $3.44Billion Expended
description: Retail spending totaled $3.44billion during 1970 for new and used boats, motors, accessories, safety equip ment, fuel, insurance, dock ing, maintenance, launching, storage, repairs and club memberships, the Boating Industry Association esti mates.

title: Ohio State Wins, 6866
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 23 (AP) Luther Witte tipped in a basket with five seconds to play today, giving Ohio State a 6866 Big Ten basketball vic tory over Minnesota.

title: Getting Down To Basics
description: FEEDING birds can be as simple as tossing out leftover bread on the ground to filling elaborate feeding areas with a dozen kinds of bird food and protection from predators.

title: 7 Challenges Are on File For '73 Race
description: Lobster pots will outnum ber 12Meter yachts in the waters off Newport, R.I., as usual during the summer of 1973, but the way the Ameri ca's Cup situation is shaping up, maybe not by much. There will be a match for the old mug there that year and the aspirants will be more numerous than ever before.

title: Toledo Area Votes Transit Authority And Operation Tax
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 23 Voters in Toledo and five ad joining communities approved this week a tax increase and creation of a regional transit authority, staving off a threat that bus service in the area would stop at the end of the month.

title: Ice Boating on Hudson: Even Losers Love It
description: PIERMONT, N. Y., Jan. 23 To John Vargo Jr., ice sailing is exhilarating. The ice chips fly in your face, you feel the wind pressure against your chest, you go up on two runners and give out a wild whoop, the 12 yearold said excitedly today after taking his father's 12 foot boat out on the frozen Hudson River.

title: Lectures and Courses
description: A FOURSESSION course on House Plants will begin at the Brooklyn Botanic Gar den on Friday. Classes will meet from 10.30 A.M. to 12 noon. Miss Frances Miner is the instructor. Students will learn how to know, grow and propagate indoor plants and take them home. The fee is $15. Advance reg istration is required as en rollment is limited.

title: Poles Oust Police Official In Wake of Price Rioting
description: WARSAW, Jan. 23Poland's Interior Minister, Kazimierz Switala, was replaced today by one of his deputies, Franciszek Szlachcic, as the new leader ship of Edward Gierek continu ed its purge of those held res sponsible for the December riots over food prices.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Seventh Avenue is a busy place these days with hun dreds of garment manufactur ers showing their lines for spring. But none of them are busier than E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., in the Empire State Building, show ing fashion concepts for fall.

title: Bridge
description: ONE of the first things a bridge be ginner learns is the elementary finesse. With small cards in his hand and a suit headed by the acequeen in dummy, he is told to lead a low card and play the queen when the second player follows low. And grad ually he acquires the art of finess ing in many other situations with different holdings.

title: Flotation and Life Preservers Keys to Reducing Deaths
description: Despite the fact that the number of pleasure boats in use has grown steadily with each passing year, official figures show that for the last several years the an nual number of fatalities in the sport has hovered around the 1,300 figure for the Unit ed States. On the bright side this proves that bigger, bet ter boats plus widespread boating education efforts are paying dividends.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Turbines Are Expected To Gain as Marine Power
description: Turbines may be the ma rine power of the future.

title: GEORGIA VANQUISHES MISSISSIPPI, 88 TO 80
description: ATHENS, Ga., Jan. 23 (AP) Barry Cohen sank seven free throws in the final five minutes today as Georgia defeated Mis sissippi, 8880. Johnny Neu mann, the nation's leading scorer, tallied 38 points for the losers.

title: Bronx Grocer's Wife Slain Resisting Holdup at Home
description: The 39yearold wife of a Bronx grocer was shot to death early yesterday in her apart ment in the Morrisania section as she and her husband fought two holdup men. The two es caped after taking $100, the police said.

title: Martin Brings an Expert's Scrutiny to Big Board
description: Nobody can predict the out come of the examination of the New York Stock Exchange that will be undertaken by William McChesney Martin Jr., but few people in Wall Street doubt that it will be penetrating and per haps controversial.

title: Venezuelan Oil Profits Go Mainly to the Government
description: CARACAS, Venezuela The sudden development of a tight world petroleum supply situation last autumn did lit tle to cheer the largely for eigncontrolled oil industry here.

title: Calle First in Bronx Run
description: Augustin Calle of Brooklyn won yesterday a 16mile run sponsored by the Road Runners Club of New York, in the Bronx. He was clocked in 1 hour 30 minutes 30 seconds. John Gar lepp of Lyndhurst, N. J., was second in 1:32.11 and Hecto Alonso of Queens was third in 1:33.48.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
IRVING FIELDMAN
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 24 Irving Fieldman, a real estate broker for 51 years, died yes terday at his home. He was 80 years old and lived at 625 North Broad Street, here.

title: A New Bottleneck Slows Court Appeals
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24In these days of frequent court congestion, it is not too un usual that though more than three years have passed since Hubert Hall Irvin Jr. was con victed of robbing a bank in California and 11 life insurance salesmen were found guilty of conspiracy in South Carolina, their convictions have not been reviewed on appeal.

title: Ecuador's Goalthe New Venezuela
description: QUITO, Ecuador  The Government imposed new economic reforms here last year as Latin America's lead ing bananaexporting coun try prepared to become a major petroleum supplier as well.

title: British Experts Doubt Authenticity of Khrushchev Remembers
description: LONDON, Jan. 24  British experts on the Soviet Union, reviewing Khrushchev Remem bers, have been much more skeptical than some American reviewers about the authentic ity of the purported memoirs of the former Soviet leader.

title: HARRIS CAPTURES SKI JUMP TROPHY
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 24Dave Harris, a 24 yearold draftsman from Brat tleboro, Vt., who has been jumping off ski hills for 16 win ters, scored the most important triumph of his career today.

title: Convict Loses Bid To Put Own Lock On Cell for Safety
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. T., Jan. 24John L. Mertz, for merly of Bergen County and now a resident of Wood bridge, charged in Superior Court today that his land lord had removed the lock from his door and had re fused to protect his property in a highcrime area.

title: 12Mile Slick Held Back From Sound Shore by Ice
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 24Ten knot winds and the tides have driven a large oil slick in Long Island Sound against the icy Connecticut shoreline and stretched it into a 12milelong ribbon.

title: ARNOLD CONSTABLE TO CLOSE L.I. STORE
description: A major store in the Miracle Mile shopping section in Man hasset, L. I., for many years a shopping center for affluent Long Islanders, will close this week after 18 years because its business failed to keep up with rising expenses.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: During a recent confrontation be tween King Hussein's bedouin troops and some guerrillas occupying a Pales tinian refugee camp near Amman, a group of refugees attempted to quit the camp and march toward the Israeli occupied areas west of the Jordan River. They are reported to have de clared they would rather live under the Israelis than endure more of the harsh tyranny of the Hashemites.

title: Unexplained Tank and Rifle Fire Break Out in Capital of Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Monday, Jan. 25 (Reuters)  Tank and rifle fire and explosions broke the early morning stillness in Kampala today and sporadic shooting was still going on some hours later.

title: National Conference Wins, 276, as Renfro Scores Twice
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 Mel Renfro of the Dallas Cow boys made two dazzling touch down runs of 82 and 56 yards with fourthquarter punt re turns today to lead the Na tional Conference AllStars to a 276 victory over the Amer ican Conference AllStars in the National Football League's Pro Bowl.

title: China, Friendship or Business?
description: TORONTOIn November a few weeks after Canada and China established diplomatic relations, a group of foreign businessmen were re turning to Hong Kong from the semi annual trade fair in Canton.

title: Chess:The King's Indian Defense, For Lovers of the Complex
description: The King's Indian Defense (1 PQ4, NKB3; 2 PQB4, PKN3) is a favorite with selfreliant and imaginative players who as Black will not cede White any firstmove initiative for psychological reasons.

title: Whose Rights?
description: It is easy to see why the Supreme Court divided in the case of Mrs. Barbara Jones, a welfare recipient who refused to admit a caseworker to her home. The New York law calling for periodic home visits does have an element of snooping that can be degrading to the receiver of public aid. Yet the manner and purpose of such visits are both legal and essential. The case under review was not a simple matter of a woman's home being her castle. The relief program involved was Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the whole nature of which seems to have been ignored in superficial criticism of the Court's decision as a blow to civil liberties.

title: N.Y.U.BLACKSPUBLISH NEW MAGAZINE, IMANI
description: The first issue of Imani, a magazine that will seek to create vehicles for the ex change and dissemination of information between black peo ple, has been put out by black students at New York University.

title: Shah of Iran Warns West That Oil May Be Shut Off
description: NIAVARAN, Iran, Jan. 24 The Shah of Iran said today, that Iran and nine other pro ducing countries would seri ously consider stopping the flow of their oil to the West if their negotiations with West ern companies broke down in the next nine days.

title: Autos of Colombia Come in All Sizes
description: BOGOTA, Colombia  The Colombian Government has authorized this nation's three automobile assembly plants to produce 26,360 vehicles in 1971. In addition, 12,000 as sembled vehicles  the year ly average for the sixties are expected to be import ed.

title: NEW TOOL ORDERS UP FOR DECEMBER
description: New orders for American machine tools rebounded sharp ly in December, rising to more than double the depressed November total. Thus it was a relatively encouraging end to an extremely disappointing year.

title: Paraguay in Role Of Money Market
description: ASUNCION, ParaguayA small wave of prosperity en gulfed, this remote nation of 2.3 million people last year despite a downturn in its smuggling traffic.

title: FURTHER DECLINE IN BOND RATES DUE
description: The grand sweep of the money and capital markets to ward lower, interest rates moved ahead last week as strongly as ever, and Wall Street expects it to continue this week.

title: GERMANHUNGARIANS TAKE SOCCER FINAL
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 24  The GermanHungarians de feated New York Hota, 20, today in the final of the indoor tournament of the German American Soccer League at the Westchester County Center be fore 2,013 fans.

title: The Talk of Latin America
description: LIMA, PeruAt one time all a United States businessman traveling in South America needed were dol lars, the addresses of United States embassies and the names of local con tact menor fixers.

title: 6 IN FAMILY KILLED IN A QUEENS BLAZE
description: Six members of a Flushing, Queens, family were killed early yesterday when a flash fire swept their threestory frame home. Two neighbors who are firemen tried in vain to save the victims.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME CLERGYMEN DEFY SOUTH AFRICA
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Afri ca, Jan. 24Church members in some parishes were urged to stand up and be counted to day as the continued detention of the Anglican Dean of Johannesburg focused attention on the deteriorating relations between the church and state in South Africa.

title: Recruiting of Negro Police Is a Failure in Most Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The cry of the nineteensixties for more black policemen has lowered to a whisper today, with only the District of Colum bia among the nation's major cities able to lay claim to any real success in significantly in creasing the number of blacks on its force.

title: Arts Abroad
description: STOCKHOLM  This sea son Goran Gentele leaves his position as head of the Royal Opera in Stockholm for the Metropolitan. In all probability this means that a rather bright period in the long history of the Swedish national opera house has come to an end.

title: 8 Bodies Found Off Sardinia
description: CARLOFORTE, Sardinia, Jan. 24 (AP)An Italian Navy ves sel recovered from the sea to day the bodies of eight of the 15 seamen missing from the Americanowned oil tanker Uni verse Patriot.

title: Barker, Schoenlink Advance In Men's State Indoor Tennis
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 24Robert Barker, the thirdseeded player, and Claude Schoenlink, seeded fourth, posted straightset victories to day and advanced in the New York State men's indoor tour nament at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: AUGERT CAPTURES AUSTRIAN SLALOM
description: KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 24 (AP)  JeanNoel Augert, France's 21  year  old world slalom champion, won the Hahnenkamm slalom race to day and assumed the individual lead in the World Cup ski standings.

title: Woman's Role in Society Is Troubling Soviet, Too
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 24Soviet women, who are expected to do everything, from digging ditches to producing babies, are grumbling these days about job discrimination, male chauvinism and lack of concern by Soviet authori ties.

title: Kheel Asks Joint Union Talks on City Pay
