description: Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, said yesterday that the four police and fire unions had a moral obligation to join together in their present contract negotiations with the city to avoid a repetition of last week's strike by policemen.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Trinidad Is Looking to Oil Treasure
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad The Administration of Prime Minister Eric Williams, which was badly shaken by an army mutiny and black militant rioting last April, is looking to the recent offshore oil and gas finds to pay for the country's economic re covery.

title: STATE FILES SUIT OVER L. I. BEACHES
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I,, Jan. 24 The state went to court here last week in a move to force a company to tear down two jet ties and to restore adjacent eroded beaches and cliffs on the North Shore in Jamesport to their natural condition.

title: N.Y.U. Names Buchthal To New Chair in Arts
description: New York University has announced the establishment of the Ailsa Mellon Bruce Chair in Fine Arts at the university's Institute of Fine Arts and the appointment of Dr. Hugo Buchthal, an in ternationally renowned scho lar of early Christian and Byzantine art, as the first holder of the chair.

title: MENDES RETURNS WITH BRASIL '66
description: Sergio Mendes brought a re vamped version of his Brasil '66 to Philharmonic Hall Satur day night for two perform ances. Gone was Lani Hall, the young singer who, in the last two years, had become the focal point of the group. And gone, too, was the finesse the group once had.

title: CITY CONSIDERING ZOO, MUSEUM FEES
description: The Lindsay administration announced yesterday that it was reevaluating its opposi tion to admission fees in city aided museums and zoos.

title: McGovern Urges Recognition Of Peking Government by U.S.
description: STOCKTON, Calif., Jan. 24 Senator George S. McGovern urged tonight that the United States recognize Communist China and press for its ad mission to the United Nations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Acadia, Scenic but Poor, Ponders the Future
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia Canada's beautiful, but poor, eastern provinces have been pinning their hopes for a prosperous future on a massive ingestion of new in dustries. This would bring in new capital and modern technology and absorb the labor force no longer em ployed by dying farms, mines and fisheries.

title: Airline to China? One of These Days
description: Sometime this year, or per haps in 1972, an American built DC8 bearing the en sign of Canadian Pacific Airlines will brake to a stop at Shanghai's Rainbow Bridge Airport in Communist China and discharge its passengers Canadian tourists, business men, diplomats and Latin American supporters of the Peking Government.

title: Stability, a Fleeting Dream
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argen tines are relearning the art of living with inflation.

title: GOSPEL STYLE NOTED IN MAYFIELD RECITAL
description: After ten years as lead singer, principal composer and focal point of the very successful Im pressions, Curtis Mayfield is out on his own at the Bitter End, where he is appearing through tonight.

title: Trade Woes Seen If E.E.C. Expands
description: The United States should prepare itself to face new trade problems that will result if Britain joins the European Eco nomic Community, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company said in its monthly survey for Janu ary, which was released over the weekend.

title: Bonn Expresses Shock
description: BONN, Jan. 24 (Reuters)  An official West German spokesman said today that his Government was deeply shocked over the sentencing of a West German citizen by Guinea's National Assembly to life at hard labor.

title: LIABILITY INSURANCE AT PENNSY DISCLOSED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Four months after the Penn sylvania Railroad acquired the New York Central Railroad through merger, directors of the consolidated company voted to buy a $10million Lloyd's of London insurance policy, it was learned today.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: ROMEMy wife, Maria A. Mac ciocchi, Communist deputy in Parlia ment, and I have just returned from a sixweek visit to the Chinese Peoples Republic. We left with a certain num ber of questions and returned with a certain number of clear ideas about the reality of that great country.

title: Kogan Plays Program Of Sonatas at Carnegie
description: The calm assurance of Leonid Kogan's performance was quite at odds with the air of tension in Carnegie Hall as the Soviet violinist began his recital Satur day night.

title: Boom Town Is Built on Coal
description: GRANDE CACHE, Alberta  Dropping swiftly into a corridor between two stands of trees, the Twin Otter plants its oversize winter wheels lightly on the snow covered gravel airstrip and taxis to the shed next to the road, leaving tracks in the snow.

title: IND Service Interrupted
description: Uptown service on the IND Eighth Avenue line was inter rupted last night from 11:15 to 11:55 after a man fell or jumped onto the tracks from the 42d Street station, the police said. The man, who was identified as Charles Nagel Jr. of Parsip pany, N. J., was in critical con dition early this morning at St. Clare's hospital.

title: Ivan Davis Presents a Program Entirely of NonPiano Pieces
description: If there is one thing con certgoers share nowadays, it is a hunger for novelty. Some performers have come to re alize this and are beginning to break out of the repertory straitjackets that have made thousands upon thousands of programs almost indistin guishable from one another over the last two decades.

title: LINDSAY CAUTIOUS ON REVENUE PLAN
description: Mayor Lindsay said last night that if Congress fully ap proved President Nixon's pro posal to allocate $5billion in Federal funds for unrestricted use by cities and states, New York City would receive about $150million to $160million.

title: Cut U.S. Role? Drive Bogs Down
description: TORONTO  The Canadian Government's effort to write a comprehensive foreignin vestment policy that would diminish United States eco nomic influence in Canada has bogged down.

title: AMON, IN A MATRA, ARGENTINE WINNER
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 24 (AP)  New Zealand's Chris Amon, driving a Matra Formula One car, sped to victory today in the 100lap Argentine Grand Prix auto race. He scored by half a lap.

title: HORSEMEN FIGHT OFFTRACK BETTING
description: Harness horsemen and breed ers who makeup the New York District of the United States Trotting Association requested their directors yesterday to challenge in State Supreme Court the constitutionality of the offtrack betting law.

title: MARQUETTE COACH SHUNS NO. I SPOT
description: Should the University of Cali fornia, Los Angeles, remain the nation's No. 1 college basket ball team after its loss to Notre Dame?

title: Boy, 10, Halts Pot Party
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 24 (AP)A 10yearold boy turned in his baby sitter and three other teenagers for marijuana violations, the police reported today. They said the youngsters called headquarters last night to report that a pot party ws going on in the house. They sid the boy told them he had learned to recognize the smell of marijuana at a state police narcotics unit exhibit last year and had learned what it looked like from public service pro grams on television.

title: The Need for Basic Research
description: Synthesis of human growth hormone, the most com plex biological chemical ever produced by man, is one of the great triumphs of modern biochemistry, a feat that almost guarantees Dr. Choh Hao Li and Dr. Donald H. Yamashiro of the University of California a Nobel Prize within the next few years. Yet this work has a dark shadow over its future because of growing Federal budgetary cutbacks.

title: Squeeze on Foreigners Tightening in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  After years of economic boom and high living, Venezuelans were asked to pay the bill in the form of tax increases last year. They promptly passed the bill to the foreign business community in a manner that sent a chill throughout this land.

title: Books of The Times
description: UP THE SANDBOX! By Anne Richardson Roiphe. 155 pages. Simon & Schuster. $4.95.

title: Treeless Tundra, A Forest of Rigs
description: INUVIK, Northwest Terri tories  In midNovember, Imperial Oil, Ltd., the biggest oil company in Canada, aban doned a dry hole near the Blow River, in the Yukon Territory, near the Arctic coast. The drill had dug 14, 000 feet  nearly three miles  down, and the hole had cost more than $2mil lion.

title: For Mothers, a Bewildering Choice
description: Bye baby bunting, Daddy's gone ahunting, Gone to get a rabbit skin To wrap the baby bunting in.

title: In a Nation of Beef Eaters, Packer Fails
description: BUENOS AIRES  Not so very long ago, Compaia Swift de la Plata, Argentina's biggest privately owned meat packing company, was to Argentina what General Mo tors is to the United States.

title: Hearings Set on Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) The Environmental Protec tion Agency said today that it would hold hearings in April to investigate charges that in terstate pollution is damaging Christmas trees in western Maryland. The agency's admin istrator, William D. Ruckels haus said the hearings were requested by Gov. Marvin Man del of Maryland, who thinks discharges from the Virginia Electric and Power Company's plant at Mount Storm, W. Va. Are damaging the trees.

title: 11 CENTRAL BANKS STUDIED IN ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24For eign central banks, unlike the Federal Reserve System in the United States, play an active role in channeling credit for various social welfare pur poses, a study prepared for the House Banking Committee disclosed today.

title: Allende's Weapon: The Law
description: SANTIAGO, ChileWe all have one foot in jail, a retailer said here the other day, and the other is never far away. The merchant's remark was similar to scores of others heard during a re cent tour of Chile, Peru, Bolivia and Ecuador.

title: Stage:Enjoying a Strong and Honest Uncle Vanya
description: Chekhov's plays always start too lateat least too late for the characters. Their opportunities are lost in the past, and they can only look to some nebulous future for relief. Uncle Vanya, one of the most exquisitely wrought of the plays, is no exception. There is no real tragic feel ing in Chekhovonly pathos tuned to the pitch of tragedy, which, of course, is why the plays are so touching and so personal.

title: JOBLESSNESS ROSE TO 7.6% LAST YEAR IN SLUM SECTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Un employment in poor urban neighborhoods, which was on the decline prior to last year, increased sharply in 1970, the Labor Department reported today.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other International lending agencies here.

title: Point of View
description: THE decade of the nine teenseventies finds the interAmerican community in a situation of disarray and confusion, which is fitting and proper for any self respecting part of the world today. Strife and turmoil have become normal.

title: Theater: Arena Stage's Ruling Class
description: WASHINGTONThe Arena Stage opened its new Kree ger Theater last week with the American premiere of Peter Barnes's The Ruling Class  a doublebarreled event of great theatrical im portance.

title: Bay St., Like Wall St., Was Mauled by the Bears
description: TORONTO  I guess the time it really hit home to me, my friend the stockbroker was saying, was when the guy at the next desk came in one morning with his lunch wrapped up in a brown paper bag inside his attache case. It  you know, it sort of dramatized the whole thing for me.

title: Princeton Battle Site Stirs Dispute
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 24 The Institute for Advanced Study here, dedicated to the expansion of knowledge and the preservation of Western culture, is under attack for alleged insensitivity toward the significance of 12 acres of ground in early American his tory.

title: ULSTER PLANS FAIR INSPITE OF UNREST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 24The Government of Northern Ireland is taking a calculated risk in proceeding with plans for a summer exhi bition, Ulster '71, despite fears that it could provoke rioting between Protestant and Roman Catholic extremists.

title: Vietnam's Presidential Election
description: As South Vietnam's presidential election campaign gets under way, President Thieu's advantages are enor mous. He is a wartime incumbent in control of the mili tary, the police, the provincial governors, a farflung bureaucracy and vast patronage in a country new to ballotbox politics. But the possibility that he might be beaten in the Oct. 3 voting, perhaps by a peace candi date, cannot be totally ruled out. It is that small possi bility that heightens interest in the political maneuvering now going on.

title: Spanish Prince Begins U.S. Visit Today
description: MADRID, Jan. 24  Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon, Gener alissimo Francisco Franco's des ignated successor, begins a five day visit to the United States tomorrow with two difficult missions.

title: Bacallao Victor in Final
description: Dr. Pedro Bacallao of the Princeton Club won the limited A squash racquets final yester day by defeating Pablo Pick of the Seventh Regiment, 155, 1514, 1014, 158, at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

title: Mrs. King Wins Again
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 24 (UPI) Mrs. Billy Jean King, the leading money winner on the $100,000 Virginia Slims tennis circuit, earned $2,500 today by defeating Rosemary Casals, 63, 62, in the final of the tourna ment at the Brook Club.

title: Yale to Stress a Social Ministry
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 24The Yale Divinity School and its smaller neighbor, the Berkeley Divinity School, will merge this spring and establish a theologi cal training program that will stress field community work instead of the academic studies that have traditionally domina ted preparation for the minis try.

title: Central America
description: GUATEMALAThe Central American Common Market suffered Its worst setback in a decade with the virtu al withdrawal of Honduras from the fivenation group early this year.

title: Author Robbed in Home
description: MARSHFIELD, Mass., Jan. 24 (AP)Edward Rowe Snow, an author and historian and his wife were bound and gagged in their home last night by three gunmen who made off with $2,400 worth of rare coins, books and regular cash, ac cording to the police. The Snows were able to work themselves free about 15 min utes after the robbers left the house.

title: Braves Take 3d in Row
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 24 (AP)Bob Kauffman scored 30 points to day as the Buffalo Braves whipped the Portland Trail Blazers, 123111, for their third victory in a row.

title: Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. Dies at 75
description: Mrs. Martha Baird Rockefel ler, widow of John D. Rocke feller Jr. and stepmother of Governor Rockefeller, died of a coronary occlusion at her home, 740 Park Avenue. She was 75 years old.

title: Peru Treads Path Between Ideologies
description: LIMA, Peru The military Government continued to march Peru down its new path between capitalism and Communism in 1970, and again managed to confound its enemies in both camps.

title: FIRST PENNSYLVANIA EXPANDS EARNINGS
description: The $3.29billion First Penn sylvania Corporation, whose principal subsidiary is the First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company, reported over the weekend that net earnings climbed 14.4 per cent during 1970 while earnings before se curities transactions rose 14.3 per cent.

title: Behind the Library Counter, the Image Is Starting to Change
description: To some people the word librarian conjures up the image of a whispery old lady in musty crepe, who exists only to stamp books, riffle through card catalogues and perhaps suggest the latest mystery novel.

title: ORDERS CONTINUE HEAVY FOR STEEL
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24  The steel inventory boom was regarded as an accomplished fact last week.

title: Havlicek Stars as Celtics Win
description: BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)The Boston Celtics built a 29point lead in the third period today and coasted to a 121110 vic tory over the hapless Cleveland Cavaliers as John Havlicek and Jo Jo White combined for 64 points.

title: Bogota Attracting Investors
description: BOGOTA, Colombia  Ap plications to invest in Colom bia are reaching the Depart ment of Planning here at a rising rate, with about 70 per cent of them from the United States. All foreign invest ments of more than $100, 000 require the department's approval.

title: Miss Magnussen Wins Title
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Jan. 24 (Canadian Press)  Karen Magnussen of Vancouver won her third Canadian senior wom en's figure skating champion ship in four years yesterday. Miss Magnussen, who won the senior title in 1968 and lost it the following year to Linda Charbonetto, received 5.9 of a possible 6 points from six of the seven judges for artistic impression in her free saking.

title: Late Arrival Keeps KickBoxing Crown On Early Knockout
description: A capacity crowd of 2,400 showed up at Sunnyside Gar den in Queens last night to see Joe Lewis and Ronnie Barkoot indulge in a new kind of may hem for the first time on the East Coastkickboxing.

title: A Pert Marilyn Horne Stars in Met's Barber
description: It was Marilyn Horne's night at the Metropolitan Opera. Up to now she has been sharing the spotlight in Norma with her colleague and good friend, Joan Suth erland. On Saturday evening she appeared as Rosina in II Barbiere di Siviglia, and this time she was on her own as the mezzosoprano star in the production.

title: Surinam Values Ties to The Hague
description: PARAMARIBO, Surinam At a time when nationalism is sweeping, most of South America, the major fear of the 420,000 Surinamese is that The Hague may cast them adrift. Since 1956 this former Dutch colony has had a relationship with the Nether lands akin to that of the United States and Puerto Rico.

title: Colombia Names 5 Oil Associates
description: BOGOTA, Colombia  On the prairies that reach 30 miles from the eastern cordil lera of the Colombian Andes to the Orinoco River, the Co lombian Government's petro leum corporation has devised an association with foreign corporations in an attempt to do something new in the oftenwayward relations be tween such corporations and LatinAmerican governments.

title: TUNNEY AIDE WINS CALIFORNIA RACE
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 24Charles Manett, a Los An geles businessman and a prin cipal organizer of John V. Tunney's successful Senate campaign, was elected today as the new Democratic chairman for California.

title: U.S. Order Points to Rise In Raids on North Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 24United States fighter bomber pilots flying over Laos have been given instructions that foreshadow increased American attacks on radarcontrolled, antiaircraft missile installations in the border re gions of North Vietnam.

title: DANKNER SYMPHONY IS GIVEN PREMIERE
description: Few doctoral dissertations ever manage to leave the col lege library shelf. Stephen Dankner's Spmphony, offered in support of his Doctor of Musical Arts Degree at Juilli ard, is an exception, and the work received its premiere Fri day night in Tully Hall at the hands of the Juilliard Theater Orchestra.

title: TERRORIST BLAST IN PNOMPENH HITS ELECTRIC OFFICE
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 24An explosion destroyed the headquarters of Cambodia's electric power utility today, se riously injuring six Govern ment employes in the build ing.

title: Lakers Top Royals, 142131, As Chamberlain Scores 35
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 (UPI) Wilt Chamberlain scored 35 points and collected 29 re bounds and Jerry West added 32 points tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers beat the Cin cinnati Royals, 142131.

description: To the Editor:

title: MONTE CARLO RUN HIT BY MORE SNOW
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 24 (UPI)Drivers remain ing in the Monte Carlo Rally faced roads blocked by a fierce Alpine blizzard today as they awaited a night of racing across Europe towards the sunny Mediterranean.

title: BERRIGANS HAILED BY REP. ANDERSON
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 24 Representative William R. An derson, Democrat of Tennes see, a veteran of both World War II and the Korean War, hailed the Berrigan brothers today as heroes in the non violent struggle for peace.

description: DETROIT, Jan. 24Things change rapidly in the life of Willis Reed, a man Coach Red Holzman of the Knicks thinks vitally important to his team.

description: MANY people interested in the problems of Latin America are asking what sig nificance the new Govern ment of the Unidad Popular party has.

title: Castro Diagnoses Cuba's Malaise
description: MIAMIMore hard work, scarcities and austerity ap pear to be in store for Cuba's 8.3 million people this year.

title: Plane Crashes Into House
description: SIDNEY, Ohio, Jan. 24 (UPI) A light plane crashed into the side of a house in this western Ohio community last night, touching off a fire that could be seen for miles. The occupants of the house, Mr. and Mrs. Harold Linker, es caped injury. The pilot, Ralph Evans, 45 years old, of Linden, Mich., was killed.

title: TV Review
description: A largescale perforMance on television rarely has much visual excitement. The cam era cuts from conductor to orchestra players to chorus to vocal soloists, and that is all. Not much more than this happened in a disappointing televised performance of Beethoven's Missa Solemnis in St. Peter's in Rome, which was shown in a 90minute color special by the National Broadcasting Company yes terday afternoon.

title: Sabres Subdue Flyers, 64
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 24 (AP) Donnie Marshall's two goals triggered a fourgoal Buffalo outburst in the second period tonight as the Sabres scored a 64 victory over the Philadel phia Flyers.

title: MAYOR CURBS USE OF HOTEL HOUSING BY CITY AGENCIES
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday or dered a halt to the placing of welfare and relocation families in hotels except for cases of extreme emergency, such as fires.

title: Points of View
description: FEW people even in Can ada realize that the Ca nadian, dollar has had a float ing exchange rate for more than half of the last 40 years. The floating rate system is more of a way of life than a Canadian experiment, and it has been a successful one.

title: Lane Gets Brewers' Post
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 24 (UPI)  The Milwaukee Brewers an nounced yesterday the hiring of Frank Lane as director of player personnel.

title: 7 Men Using BedSheet Ropes Escape From U.S. Prison Here
description: Seven men, using improvised bedsheet ropes, sawblades and tin shears, escaped early yes terday from the Federal House of Detention on West Street.

title: An 18YearOld Girl Joins Delaware G.O.P. Committee
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 24 An I8yearold girl was named yesterday to the Repub lican State Committee.

description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 24 (Reuters)Three California girls swept past their singles opposition today and moved into the third round of the Victorian open tennis cham pionships.

title: Thai Battle Reported
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 24 (ReutersThat border police and helicopter gunships were reported to have killed or wounded today about 30 hos tile Meo tribesmen who were obstructing construction of a highway through their opium fields near here.

description: VERSAILLES, France, Jan. 24Jacques Soustelle, once a powerful figure in French poli tics until he fell out with de Gaulle over the Algerian problem, today started a new party.

description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 24  Mil waukee policemen intensified their strike today, leaving this city of 717,000 population with only minimal police protection.

title: Urban Population Pressures Spur New Land Rush in the West
description: BOZEMAN, Mont., Jan. 18 A land rush is on in one of the last of the wide open spaces, the Rocky Mountain states.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The football season finally ended yesterday, the same day the American League released its 1971 baseball schedule. The weeks until April 5 stretch long and dreary and cold for those who have never cultivated the somewhat special tastes of the indoor season. Has Jim Ryun found his emotional second wind? Will Arthur Ashe crack the tie breaker barrier? Can the Knicks regain their unselfish ness before Philadelphia catches up? Is there really a Bobby Orr? Will the Muhammad AliJoe Frazier fight make Armageddon anticlimactic? And is the Norwegian elkhound really this year's hot dog?

title: 37 Injured as L.I. Train Jumps Tracks
description: BRENTWOOD, L. I., Jan. 24 Thirtyseven persons were in jured here today when a Long Island Railroad train hit an ap parently sabotaged switch and hurtled off the tracks.

title: Israel to Stay in Talks Despite the Absence of Diplomatic Secrecy
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 24  The Israeli Cabinet agreed today on further ideas and questions to be put to the neighboring Arab governments, in pursuit of in direct peace talks through the United Nations intermediary, Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring.

title: Bolivia's New Force, Indians
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia  The confusion that seized this country after Gen. Juan Jose Torres deposed Gen. Alfredo Ovando Candia as President last Oct. 7 continued to ob scure the economic scene at year's end.

title: Bruins Down Canadiens by 42;
description: BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)Bob by Orr scored his 20th goal and helped set up two other goals tonight in leading the Boston Bruins to a 42 National Hockey League victory over the Mont real Canadiens.

title: News Analysis
description: LONDON, Jan. 24From Venezuela to the Middle fast to Indonesia, the oilexporting countries have long had their quarrels with the big Western companies that extract their oil and sell it all over the non Communist world.

title: Johns Hopkins Names Cornell Man as Provost
description: Dr. Steven Muller, the vice president for public affairs at Cornell University, has been named provost of Johns Hop kins University.

title: East Side Democrats Hold Spirited Brunch
description: East Side Reformers, com fortably chic and comfortably Democratic, crowded the bal cony of the 86th Street Auto mat yesterday for a cham pagne and Bloody Mary brunch honoring Representa tives Shirley Chisholm and Bella Abzug.

title: House Majority Whip Thomas Philip O'Neill Jr.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Whether he's talking with constituents in Cambridge pubs, debating on the floor of the House or negotiating behind the scenes with other politicians, Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts likes to make his points with stories andp ersonal anec dotes. So when R epre sentative Hale Boggs of Louisiana sought him out a coupleof weeks ago and began talk ing in generalities about whom Mr. O'Neill would sup port for majority leader, Mr. O'Neill told him a story.

title: U.A.R. BIDS ARABS ACT ON EAST FRONT
description: BELRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 24 A representative of President Anwar elSadat of the United Arab Republic arrived in Am man, Jordan, today for what was described as a last at tempt to reactivate the eastern front against Israel.

title: MobileHome Shipments Down 8% for November
description: Shipments of mobile homes declined during November from the yearearlier figure, the Mobile Homes Manufactur ers Association reported over the weekend.

title: Chile, Now in the Aftermath of Her Discontent
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  The election of Latin America's first Marxist government last Sept. 4 changed the business climate in Chile overnight and gave rise to many ques tions about the future.

title: YOUNG ADMIRERS FILL TAYLOR FOLK RECITAL
description: James Taylor played an afternoon concert yesterday before a full house at Philhar monic Hall, as part of Lincoln Center's Great Performers series.

title: G.O.P. Legislators Postpone Action on Blaine Repeal
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24Republi can legislative leaders have postponed action on a consti tutional amendment that would repeal the socalled Blaine Amendment, which bans state aid for nonpublic schools.

title: BARBER CARDS 261 TO WIN AT PHOENIX
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 24 Billy Casper scored a finalround 62 and Dave Hill sank a holein one, but Miller Barber won the Phoenix open today with a 23 underpar 261, a new low for the tournament.

title: Thousands Mourn Over Mishima's Ashes
description: TOKYO, Jan. 24  Thou sands of people, from fervent admirers to passersby with shopping bags, attended a memorial service for Yukio Mishima in one of Tokyo's largest Buddhist temples to day.

title: DR.CHARLES PIERCE
description: OCEAN CITY, N. J., Jan. 24 (AP)Dr. Charles B. Pierce, superintendent of schools here for 19 years, died yesterday at Shore Memorial Hospital in Somers Point. He was 69 years old.

title: Bridge: Skillful Play After Good Bids Overcomes a 50 Trump Split
description: Some bridge deals seem designed by the fates to ir ritate one partnership. On the diagramed deal, for example, good bidders will reach the excellent contract of four hearts with the NorthSouth hands.

title: Law Student Weds Myrna Margulies
description: At the Central Synagogue yesterday afternoon, Miss Myrna Debra Margulies, a recent graduate of Clark Uni versity, was married to Wil liam Arthur Breitbart, a law student at New York Uni versity, by Rabbi David J. Seligson.

title: Fear Lingers in Quebec
description: MONTREALAt the legislative building in Quebec, visitors on business must pass a security check at the front door. It includes opening packages.

title: Tucson Area Put Under Curfew Alter Violence Near University
description: TUCSON, Ariz, Jan. 24 Flowered hats bobbed in the sunlight today in the neighbor hood of the University of Ari zona as elderly women attended the old churches they had at tended for years, ignoring the many squad cars that patrolled the streets.

title: Counterfeit Money Seized
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 24 (AP)Secret Service agents seized $2million in counterfeit $100 bills today and arrested three men they said were load ing the counterfeit money into a car to drive to the Middle West to distribute it. The men were apprehended without re sistance in a parking lot on the outskirts of Palm Springs.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: WASHINGTONThe recent publica tion of Albert Speer's memoirs, Inside the Third Reich, has given many people the impression that at the trial held by the International Military Tribunal at Nuremberg Speer, driven by his conscience, risked his life by assuming full responsibility for the war crimes and crimes against humanity committed by the Nazi regime. The introduction to Speer's book certainly conveys this impression, as well as the impression that the book is an exten sion of this process.

title: Nets Trade Bunting
description: The Nets traded Bill Bunting to the Squires yesterday for Virginia's secondround choice in the recent draft. That choice was Bob Kisane a 6foot8inch forward from Chaminade High School, who is averaging 20 points, a game at Holy Cross College.

title: $229BILLION CALLED NIXON BUDGET FIGURE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) President Nixon reportedly will ask Congress for $229.2 billion to finance a full em ployment budget designed to lift the economy out of its re cession.

title: Parting Marijuana Mists
description: Although we reject the old notions that marijuana is physically addictive, that it leads to violent or aggressive behavior or that it is a direct cause of graduation to heroin and other narcotic drugs, we have found substan tial evidence that marijuana is a dangerous drug.

title: Four Killed in Washington State As Avalanche Hits a Ski Resort
description: TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 24 An avalanche swept over two ski cabins near the summit of the Cascade Mountains today, killing four persons and leav ing two others buried alive for 11 hours before rescuers could dig them out.

title: Screen: 'Zachariah,' an Odd Western
description: Although billed as "the first electric Western," George Englund's "Zachariah," which opened yesterday at the Juliet I and the Little Carnegie Theater, is really something a good deal odder. It is, at least in my experience, the first movie to parody the Western with the apparent intention of propagandizing homosexual love. I am aware that male relationships are a stock in trade of most Westerns and that, in Andy Warhol's brilliant "Lonesome Cowboys," there has already been a homosexual parody.But for dead-headed didacticism and sheer perseverence in straining the medium to the message, I can think of nothing to match "Zachariah."Of course, "Zachariah" tries to be pretty electric, too. Which means that as it opens, in yet another "2001" take-off, a giant slab in the desert turns out not to be a giant slab at all, but rather its spiritual analogue, the speaker for an electric guitar. And everywhere there is rock or country and Westernand with it, uncomfortably on the sidelines, an appreciative audience of grooving teenyboppers.This would seem to indicate that "Zachariah" has set its sights, its more commercial sights, on whatever has supplanted the audience for the beach blanket movie of the early 1960's. But in keeping with the changing times, it aims to be heavy, so that when near the end young Zach tumbles in the sand with his friend and mentor, the Old Man, the confluence of images suggests less an aspiration to "How to Stuff a Wild Bikini" than to "Zabriskie Point."The Old Man, always dressed in a pair of overalls of many colors, has dragged Zack off to experience the desertas part of an educational program intended to dissuade him from being number-one gunfighter and to teach him the wisdom of settling back at peace with himself and the earth, contented obscurely to cultivate his own garden of grass. Zack had previously risen from comparable obscurity to such outlaw eminence that he had almost challenged the great Job Cain to a battle and had enjoyed the favors of the great Belle Starrbefore realizing that male dominance and bed with Belle were not, for him, the answer.However, his boyhood buddy Matthew has meanwhile sought glory in earnest. He kills Job Cain and then comes gunning after Zack, merely because he is there. It is during this great confrontation that love defeats death, and the two young fellows, embracing warmly, ride off into slow motion and a gaily colored sunset.John Rubinstein, as Zachariah, and Don Johnson, as Matthew, exhibit the readiest smiles and the whitest teeth in the West. It is difficult to assess their performances because their direction seems to have consisted of the admonition, with appropriate moods for appropriate moments, "be nice." William Challee, the Old Man, plays the white man's Chief Dan George, though without a fraction of the feeling. And Elvin Jones, Job Cain, is called upon to be black (he is the only man in "Zachariah" afflicted with two symbolic names) and plays the drums. The various specialty rock groups are neither functional nor good.George Englund decorates his wide open spaces with symbolic facadesas if to indicate that he takes his themes, if not his genre, seriously. His scene designer is up on several current styles, Belle Stair's border bordello, for example, hides behind a series of flats painted in the pop-art manner of a Wesselmann lithograph.The only person associated with "Zachariah" about whom I very much care, Pat Quinn, as Belle Starr, suffers the most. Admirers of "Alice's Restaurant" will remember that she is a woman of extraordinary sensual pressence. But here she is made to bump and grind and to affect a surface sensuality with the result that her performance resembles nothing so much as some untalented drag queen's ritual imitation of Mae West.

title: Screen: Ken Russell's Study of Tchaikovsky Opens
description: Peter Ilich Tchaikovsky was born in Kamsko-Votinsk in 1840 and died in St. Petersburg of cholera in 1893. In between he composed some of the world's loveliest, most romantic music, married unhappily, suffered terrible bouts of depression that were linked to both his genius and his homosexuality (which he hid and referred to in his writings only by means of a hieroglyphic), and was acclaimed at home and abroad.Although such authentic genius defies rational interpretation, except, perhaps, by another genius, Ken Russell's "The Music Lovers" sets out to do just that. At least, I assume that's what the film set out to do. Because "The Music Lovers" plays rather loosely with some of the facts of Tchaikovsky's life, it can be accepted only as the kind of interpretation that certifies the most baroque speculation.Never, perhaps, has one movie contained so many smashed champagne glasses, so many lyrical fantasies (with so many white swans), so many sordid confrontations, so many clothes torn off in twisted passion, so many references to the joys and terrors of artistic creation, even so much musicbut all to such little ultimate effect.Mr. Russell's "Women in Love" was a fairly gaudy movie, but if you put it alongside "The Music Lovers," it would seem, I suspect, as austere as an Army training film. Unfortunately, Mr. Russell's romanticism, though quite brave in its headlong intensity, and in its sincere attempts to find cinematic equivalents to mysteries for which there are no equivalents, is of a far lesser order than Tchaikovsky's.Melvyn Bragg's screenplay more or less takes off from "Beloved Friend," a collection (edited by Catherine Drinker Bowen and Barbara Von Meck) of letters that passed between Tchaikovsky and Nadejda Von Meck, the wealthy patron he never met but who, in one of the sillier sequences in "The Music Lovers," spends some ecstatic hours lying beside his sleeping form.Even though Mme. Von Meck was probably the most important woman in Tchaikovsky's adult life, the film allots much more time (almost, in fact, as much as it allots to Tchaikovsky) to Nina, the neurotic, sluttish girl he married, lived with for several weeks and then left. Even if Tchaikovsky effectively put Nina out of his mind, the movie doesn't.Some of Mr. Russell's most fanciful set-pieces are devoted to Nina's decline and fall into madness, largely at the hands of her mother, who pimps for her and is inclined to introduce a new customer by saying that "Mr. Rimsky-Korsakoff has come to see you, dear."However, Mr. Russell's speculations are not as offensive as his frontal  and often absurdattacks on the emotions. Richard Chamberlain, who had to go to England to prove himself an actor, is fine as Tchaikovsky, looking a bit like a haunted faun, and Glenda Jackson is all sinewy nerves as Nina, but they are hard put to match the (what seems in retrospect, anyway) nonstop hysteria of the production that surrounds them.When Tchaikovsky sits down to play a public performance of his Piano Concerto in B flat minor at the Moscow Conservatory (which he never did), the concerto becomes a repository of such fulsome flashbacks (suggesting an incestuous relationship with his sister) that it's impossible to hear the music, and to respond to it, without focusing your eyes slightly off-screen, as you might do when you're seasick and don't want to throw up.If the actors are not moving, the camera is, and sometimes everything is moving, as in an extraordinary honeymoon scene on the train that is taking Tchaikovsky and Nina back to Moscow, Nina, drunk and naked, rolls around on the floor of their compartment as her husband studies her in terrorwhile the camera studies both of them from a vantage point on the ceiling that is probably occupied by a ventilator. It's just a little too spectacular, and too undulant. The effects eventually cancel themselves out.The music, played by the London Symphony Orchestra conducted by Andr Previn, is decent enough, that is, when you can hear it in spite of all the scenic cutaways (which are only a little more interesting than the fjords favored by Andrew Stone in "The Song of Norway").I expect many people may look on "The Music Lovers" as an advance on the classical musical biographies turned out by Hollywood in the 1940's, but for all of its so-called frankness, there isn't much difference between this kind of sensational, souped-up popularization and the sort of pious, souped-down popularization that cast Cornel Wilde as Chopin and Robert Walker as Brahms.By the time "The Music Lovers" and Tchaikovsky end, Mr. Russell has told us a lot less about Tchaikovsky and his music than he has about himself as a filmmaker. Although Tchaikovsky died of cholera, for which a hot bath was prescribed, the implication of "The Music Lovers" is that he was simply boiled to death, which is what the movie does to his genius.

title: Mrs. Hicks Leaves Council

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25One of the most eloquent passages in President Nixon's State of the Union Message followed his assertion that as the forces that shape our lives seem to have grown more distant and more impersonal, a great feeling of frustra tion has crept across the land.

title: VOORHEES INSTITUTE WOULD JOIN CITY U.
description: The Board of Higher Educa tion agreed yesterday to merge the Voorhees Technical Insti tute, a private school founded 90 years ago, into the City Uni versity system.

title: News Analysis
description: The disclosure that one wel fare family spent two nights in the WaldorfAstoria has ac complished what thousands of families living for months, even years, in squalid, crumbling, ad dictinfested welfare hotels failed to do  prompt Mayor Lindsay to declare all hotels off limits, in effect, to all welfare recipients except those deprived of their homes by extreme emer gency, such as fires. City offi cials may find it difficult to implement the Mayor's order, however. In a certain sense, all the 1,100 welfare families now lodged in hotels, and many more still in slum tenements, face extreme emergency when it comes to housing.

title: Pledge to Cairo Reported
description: CAIRO, Jan. 25Unimpeach able sources said today that the United States had assured Egypt that it still believes a peace settlement in the Mid dle East must include Israeli withdrawal from virtually all of the Sinai Peninsula and the occupied areas of Jordan.

title: RENAULTS RUN 1, 2 AT MONTE CARLO
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 25 (UPI)  Ove Anders son of Sweden, racing over ice and snow in his Alpine Renault, swept into the lead today of the Monte Carlo auto rally at the end of the first stage.

title: Origins of Coup Assessed
description: LONDON, Jan. 25  Reports reaching London diplomatic sources today indicated that the coup had both ideological and tribal origins. Ideologically, it was seen as a revolt from the right.

title: Guard Is Indicted With 8 Prisoners In Riots at Tombs
description: A guard and eight inmates or former inmates of the Tombs were indicted yesterday for their alleged role in the prison's riots last October.

title: Judges of Book Awards Revolt On Use of Nationwide Polling
description: The National Book Awards candidates were announced yesterday. There was also an unannounced revolt by the judges against new selection procedures that were to have allowed a nationwide poll of booksellers, librarians and critics to select half of the 70 nominees.

title: AntiSemitism Found on Far Right and New Left
description: PALM BEACH, Jan. 25 American Jewish communal leaders warned today that for the first time since World War II Jewish communities in the United States faced a politi cally powered antiSemitism operating under the guise of antiZionism and opposition to Israel's position in the Middle East.

title: BIG BOARD POSTS 7TH GAIN IN A ROW
description: The stock market leveled off yesterday at midsession for a bit of profit taking and con solidation. Then it promptly pulled another surprise by pow ering forward in the afternooon.

title: Intelsat 4 Communications Craft Orbited
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 25A new generation of com mercial communications satel lites was introduced tonight with the launching into earth orbit of the first Intelsat 4.

title: States' Revenue Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The White House made pub lic today a table showing how much money each of the 50 states would receive of the $5billion that would turned over to them under President Nixon's proposed pro gram for general revenuesharing.

title: Brandt and Pompidou Affirm Accord on Europe
description: PARIS, Jan. 25Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany arrived today for one of the semiannual meetings with France and dissipated talk of a crisis in Western Europe over methods of achieving an eco nomic and monetary union.

title: Chase to Add Predicasts
description: The Chase Manhattan Cor poration announced yesterday an agreement in principle un der which Predicasts, Inc., a Clevelandbased business infor mation research firm, would become an autonomous sub sidiary. Predicasts, which pub lishes business indexes, ab stracts, forecasts and research studies, was founded in 1960 and had sales last year of $1.25million.

title: RATES FALL AGAIN IN CREDIT MARKET
description: Interest rates on shortterm taxexempt notes took a big step downward yesterday as the credit markets continued to dis play the extraordinary strength they have built up recently.

title: Haber Asserts P.B.A. Ran Out On FactFinding for Parity Issue
description: Herbert L. Haber, the city's Director of Labor Relations, tes tified in State Supreme Court yesterday that the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association ran out on an oral agreement to participate in a factfinding hearing aimed at a permanent settlement of the payparity problem.

title: Rose Defiant as His Trial Opens For Slaying of Quebec Minister
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 25Paul Rose, charged as a principal in the kidnapping and murder of Pierre Laporte, Quebec's Minis ter of Labor and Immigration, went on trial today in a Queen's Court. He told the court that his real trial would come only when Quebec is truly free.

title: DETAILS ANNOUNCED IN SPARTANS MERGER
description: The proposed $180million merger of Spartans Industries, Inc., which operates the Kor vette discount department stores, and Arlen Properties, Inc., a realestate developer, calls for Spartans' chairman, Charles C. Bassine, to relinquish the top post in the merged com pany to his soninlaw, Arthur G. Cohen.

title: CAVALIERS RECORD 8TH VICTORY, 117116
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 25 (UPI) Dave Sorenson sank a 25foot shot at the buzzer tonight that gave the Cleveland Cavaliers a 117116 victory over the Boston Celtics.

title: L.I.U. Loses to Utah State
description: LOGAN, Utah, Jan. 25 (UPI) Utah State gained its 11th consecutive victory tonight with an 8274 victory over the nation's thirdbest defensive team, Long Island University.

title: For the Fight Fans, It Was Either Be There Early or Get Shut Out
description: In the boxing office at Madi son Square Garden yesterday, Duke Stefano picked up his phone.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dentzer Asks Wide Changes in State Banking Setup
description: William T. Dentzer Jr., who last April was named New York State Superintendent of Banks, laid out in definitive terms yesterday legislative pro posals that would bring sweep ing changes in the state's banking structure.

title: INJURED NEWSMAN SUES FOR $2MILLION
description: Werner Bamberger, a re porter for The New York Times, filed a suit for $2million in damages against three shipping companies yesterday as a result of injuries he sustained while on a ship news assignment last Dec. 14.

title: North Carolina Will Mail Food Stamps to Families
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 25 Gov. John C. West, who pledged last week in his in augural address to end hunger and malnutrition in South Car olina, announced today a plan to cut red tape for welfare re cipients who buy food stamps.

title: I.O.S. CHAIRMAN DUE TO SHIFT HIS ROLE
description: GENEVA, Jan. 25  Sir Eric Wyndham White, board chair man of the Investors Overseas Services parent company, will give all his attention to the establishment of a special inde pendent committee to oversee the operations of its funds in the interests of its share holders, it was anounced to night.

title: The Welfare Tragedy
description: It is a surrealist reflection of the urban tragedy that indignation over the lodging of one welfare family in the WaldorfAstoria threatens to overshadow the fact that for thousands of others the city has been paying even higher rents in more than forty of the most dismal, crimeinfested hotels.

title: Polish Church to Get Lands Ceded by Germans
description: WARSAW, Jan. 25  The Polish Government, in an ap parent concession to the Roman Catholic Church, moved today to give it title to church lands in territory won from Germany after World War II.

title: Egyptian Gas Find Reported
description: The Phillips Petroleum Com pany and the Egyptian General Petroleum Corporation an nounced yesterday that they had found natural gas at their joint exploratory well, Buseili 1X, on the banks of the Nile River four miles south of Roset ta on the Mediterranean coast.

title: RENT CURB SOUGHT IN MITCHELLLAMA
description: A bill to limit rent increases to no more than 10 per cent in any twoyear period in middle income housing developments supervised by the city was sub mitted yesterday to the City Council.

title: KIESINGER ASSAILS BRANDT ON EAST
description: DUSSELDORF, West Ger many, Jan. 25Kurt Georg Kiesinger, the West German opposition leader, accused Chancellor Willy Brandt's Gov ernment today of plunging the country into a hectic adven ture by its policy of seeking better relations with Eastern Europe.

title: CANADA TO CHECK INVESTING BY U.S.
description: TORONTO, Jan. 25  In a longpromised step to diminish United States influence in Can ada, the Government in troduced in Parliament today legislation to create a Canada Development Corporation.

title: Doctors Find Apollo 14 Crew Ready to Fly as Moon Shot Countdown Begins
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 25As the countdown began today for the Apollo 14 flight to the moon, space agency physicians gave its threeman crew a medical green light for the launching that is scheduled for Sunday afternoon.

title: Big Allis Breaks Down in Tests; New Power Crises Threatened
description: Consolidated Edison's most powerful generator, a million kilowatt turbine that has been inoperative since last July, broke down again during test ing over the weekend, delaying indefinitely its return to service.

title: Sperm in the DeepFreeze
description: Throughout his history man has been battling cold as if it were an enemy. The Arctic squirrel, the mar mot, the brown bat retire into hiber nation and let the chilling winds pass them by. The bird, propelled by physi ological drives from one continent to another, escapes from winter. The in ternal temperature of the coldblooded creature matches that of his external world. But warmblooded man has not evolved in ways that help him to endure all seasons in all climates, and cold can bring him suffering and death.

title: Text of Jordanian Reply to Jarring on Israel's Points
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 25  Following is the text of a Jordanian statement submitted Jan. 18 to Dr. Gun nar V. Jarring, the United Nations intermediary, in re sponse to Israeli suggestions given to Dr. Jarring during his visit to Israel Jan. 810:

title: New Law's Details Issued by Federal Reserve Board
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 The Federal Reserve Board made public today its proposed regulations implementing the new law that limits the activi ties of onebank holding com panies. The regulations detail 10 specified activities that are considered so closely related to banking as to be per missible for bank holding com panies.

title: PANEL TO DECIDE TELEPHONE ISSUE
description: A threeman arbitration board headed by Mitchell M. Shipman, a New York lawyer, will arbitrate the dispute be tween the Communications Workers of America and the New York Telephone Company over the use of outoftown re pairmen.

title: Illinois Official's Aides Charged With Illegal Transfer of Funds
description: VIENNA, Ill., Jan. 25 (UPI) The private secretary and the chief administrative aide to the late Paul Powell Illinois, Secre tary of State, were charged to day wth illegally transferring a portion of Mr. Powell's cash hoard after his death.

title: DR. HARRY L. BUSH
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 25 Dr. Harry Lewis Bush of 341 Fort Hill Road, a dentist here for the last 12 years and for 30 years before that in Manhattan, died Saturday in White Plains Hospital after a short illness. He was 77 years old.

title: How 23d Precinct Looks to Ray Flynn
description: By 11:30 P.M., when the 4tomidnight shift is near ing an end, the cramped front seat of the car and the constant crackle of the radio produce an ache as sharp as needles behind each eye, and a patrolman is so tired that the long drive home, still to come, seems an intolerable idea.

title: N.C.A.A. Probing Report Collegians Have Agreed to Play Pro Basketball
description: The National Collegiate Ath letic Association has been in vestigating for some time re ports that college basketball players have signed contracts with professional teams or made agreements with agents to negotiate contracts for them.

title: Merger News
description: The General Host Corpora tion announced yesterday that it had exercised its option to purchase 437,700 shares of its own common stock from the Goldfield Corporation. The shares being reacquired by General Host are approximately 17 per cent of the total out standing. The option was exer cised at a price of $12.9625 a share, the average mar ket price for Gen eral Host stock during the last 10 trading days. General Host is paying the exercise price by ap plying its total cost of $5,673, 686 to reduce principal and in terest on notes it holds from Goldfield and its 60 per cent owned subsidiary, the Tantalum Mining Corporation of Canada, Ltd.

title: JORDANIAN STAND ON TALKS IS TOUGH
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 25The Government of Jordan was revealed today to be tak ing a tough attitude in the indirect ArabIsrael peace talks under Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations interme diary.

title: Court Says Groppi's Rights Were Violated in '68 Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  The Supreme Court ruled today that the rights of Milwaukee's protesting priest, the Rev. James E. Groppi, were violated in 1968 when he was denied a transfer of his trial to another locale on grounds that he was only charged with a mis demeanor.

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Hemlengths Start Inching Upward In France, at Least
description: PARIS, Jan. 25Well, there was no place for them to go but up, right? Even though the rise in hemlines was predictable, American manufacturers and retailer here for the spring couture shows tend to regard it as the end of the world. After they've bled for the longer skirt, how can theychoke suggest women show their chokeknees?

title: Saigon's Armed Forces Improving, but Big Test Is Still Ahead
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 18  The South Vietnamese armed forces are rapidly as suming the major part of the ground fighting in Vietnam. They are doing by far the most killing and dying, and they are doing it with better trained men, more modern equipment and greater mobil ity than ever.

title: 2 Princeton Players Excel As College Tennis Opens,
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Jan. 25Ivy League stars were out standing today as the Concord Hotel opened its fourth annual intercollegiate indoor tennis tournament. Thirtynine varsity players from 19 schools were represented in the only collegi ate event on the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's winter schedule.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Once again it is midterm, and parents are receiv ing those messages from headmasters about their boys away at school. Like this one:

title: Aluminum lndustry Offers Process to Recycle Waste
description: The aluminwn industry pre sented a plan yesterday for a recycling plant that could take in all municipal garbage as a raw material and process it into reusable material ranging from sand and paper to vari ous types of metal.

title: Sunset for Railpax
description: When the bill to establish the National Rail Passenger Corporation was being drafted, a high official of the Transportation Department said candidly in private: The purpose of this bill is to get passenger service off the backs of the railroads, run the wheels off the existing equipment, and then put an end to passenger trains in this country.

title: HOUSING PLAN SET FOR RELIEF CASES
description: Simeon Golar, chairman of the City Housing Authority, said yesterday his agency pro posed to use one or more pend ing vestpocket housing projects and buildings renovated under the municipal loan program to help cut down the need for hotels for welfare recipients.

title: Florida Cold May Lift Price of Fresh Oranges
description: LAKELAND, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP)As a result of freezing weather in Florida's citrus belt, the nation's housewives may find fresh oranges more expensive next week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: King Resources Is Named By S.E.C. in a Fraud Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)The Securities and Ex change Commission today ac cused two officers and a for mer officer of the King Re sources Company, Denver, of fraudulent transactions in volving the company's funds.

title: Roudebush Is a Consultant To Veterans Administration
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Former Representative Rich ard L. Roudebush of Indi ana accepted today a position as consultant to Veterans Ad ministrator Donald E. Johnson, according to a spokesman for the Veterans Administration.

title: UTILITY ON COAST SHOWS PROFIT DIP
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company reported yesterday a decline of 11 per cent in net income for 1970 despite a rise of 4.6 per cent in revenues.

title: STANLEY M'ARTHUR, OUT DOORAD MAN, 75
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 25 Stanley V. MacArthur, a re tired outdooradvertising exec utive, died yesterday in the New Rochelle Hospital after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived at Larchmont Acres here.

title: Rockets End Losing String
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 25 (UPI) Elvin Hayes and Stu Lantz, each with baskets as the San Diego Rockets rolled away from a 9696 tie and beat the Buffalo Braves, 114106, to night. The Rockets had lost their preceding 10 games.

title: 30 Senators Sponsor Bill for Public Service Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25At tempting to get the jump on the Administration, 30 Sena tors, Including New York Re publican Jacob K. Javits, in troduced a bill today that would create federally funded public service employment.

title: Restructuring of Colleges Urged To Achieve Greater Relevance
description: Prof. Amitai Etzioni, chair man of the department of so ciology at Columbia University, has urged in a federally fund ed study a restructuring of American higher education to make it more relevant to the future needs of society.

title: Bronx School Blaze Initiates 39 Fire Cadets in New Career
description: Thirtynine young men being sworn in as fire cadets in a South Bronx Model Cities pro gram got an unexpected taste of their new careers yesterday. A fire interrupted the ceremony at Public School 161, at Tinton Avenue and 151st Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Kentucky Downs Alabama
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Jan. 25 (UPI)  Kentucky, down six points early in the second half, outscored Alabama 207 in the final six minutes tonight and won a Southeastern Confer ence game, 8673.

title: South African Police Rebuff Protests on Dean's Arrest
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Jan. 25 (UPI)The Gov ernment said today that it would not release the Anglican Dean of Johannesburg despite the daily bellringing by his church to protest his detention.

title: After Coast Riot, Cultural Flowering
description: LOS ANGELES  The American theater has always been something that you went downtown to, you al ways got dressed up and went to dinner and all of that, said C. Bernard Jackson, his hands weaving patterns in the air. That's different from the concept we're try ing to develop.

title: TEACHER TESTING BY STATE IS URGED
description: The adoption of a state licensing examination for new teachers was urged yesterday by Murry Bergtraum, president of the City Board of Education.

title: CITY AIDE IS WARY OF NIXON PROGRAM
description: City Budget Director Edward K. Hamilton said yesterday that the city might lose money un der President Nixon's revenue sharing program.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Angling's ultimate refine ment is to release all fish caught.

title: GREYHOUND DEAL UP TO HIGH COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)  The Supreme Court decided today to review the merger of the Greyhound Corporation and Armour & Co., the nation's sec ond largest meat packer.

title: Stage:Barry's Heritage
description: P. J. Barry calls his play, Heritage, an American folk tale about the Lincoln women. The womengrand mother, mother, stepmother, sweetheart, wifeare the principal characters on stage, but the play is about Lincoln Mr. Barry's contribution to theater history is that his is a Lincoln play in which Lin coln does not appear.

title: Australia Lifts Ban On Tropic of Cancer
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 25 (AP)For the first time in 36 years, it is legal for Aus tralians to read Henry Mil ler's Tropic of Cancer.

title: Basketball Poll
description: COACHES' RATING

title: City Board Backs a School Site Under Flight Path to Kennedy
description: The site for a new intermedi ate school in Queens approved by the Site Selection Board yes terday is under a flight path to Kennedy International Airport.

title: HIGH COURT BARS SEX BIAS IN HIRING IN TEST OF '64 ACT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  Employers cannot refuse to hire women solely because they have small children unless fathers of small children are also denied jobs, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Tricky Maneuver: Going Against the Flow in Garden Motorcycle Race
description: New York, which has sur vived police strikes, subway breakdowns, blackouts and John Lindsay, had its first in door motorcycle race last night. The town survived, but there are other tests to comethe show may be repeated next year.

title: History Museum Picks Actress as a Trustee
description: The American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday that Miss Miriam Colon Edgar, an actress known professionally as Mi riam Colon, had been elected a member of the museum's board of trustees.

title: ExMuseum Aide Is Fined
description: A former museum official from Denver must pay $10,000 in fines, if he loses his appeal of the sentence, on charges of transporting stolen works of art from Colorado to New York. William Van Voast Warren Jr. was sentenced last Friday to fines of $10,000 on each of four counts in Federal Court here. But Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon said the fines would be levied concurrently so that Warren would have to pay $10,000, rather than $40,000, in addition to remaining on probation for two years.

title: 23 Senators Support New Plan For National Health Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 A revised national health insur ance plan that would pay $50 billion a year to cover more than twothirds of the medical expenses of all Americans was introduced in the Senate today.

title: Freedom Prize Awarded
description: VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Jan. 25 (AP)The judges of a letter contest on the subject of free dom have given the 1970 De fender of Freedom Award to a United States Army captain who fled his native Hungary after the uprising there in 1956. He is Capt. Tibor Bier baum, who now lives in Fayetteville, N. C.

title: CONTRACTORS SAID TO OVERCHARGE U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) The agency charged with eliminating excessive profits on space and defense contracts has reported that during the fiscal year 1970 it found private con tractors overcharging the Gov ernment by nearly $33.5million, the highest overcharge total in a decade.

title: Market Place: Taking a Look At Tokyo Stocks
description: Naomichi Toyama was in town from Tokyo yesterday to talk about the Japanese economy and, as executive vice president of the Nikko Securities Co. Ltd., the pros pects for particular Japanese stocks in the months ahead.

title: DEPRECIATION SUIT HALTED BY PLEDGE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25Two lawyers affiliated with Ralph Nader agreed today not to press immediately their suit to block a proposed $2.6billion tax cut for business. They withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction barring the tax ac tion after the Treasury Depart ment promised, in open court, to hold public hearings on the issue.

title: Thais Bolster Cambodian Border
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 25 Thai army reinforcements have been sent to the border with Cambodia following the increase in Vietcong activity around Pnompenh.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)  The Defense Department today listed the names of the following Army men from the New York area as having been killed in Southeast Asia:

title: Terrorism Issue Divides 0.A.S. As Ministers Open Conference
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  Western Hemisphere foreign ministers opened a conference here today to seek means to prevent kidnappings of diplo mats and other political terror ism.

title: The Fate of Alaska
description: The Department of the Interior's draft statement on the proposed Alaskan oil pipeline is impressive. It pre sents the Government's first comprehensive view on the pipeline's probable impact on the environment including not only those dangers that might be over come by standards to be set for its construction but also those that the Department concedes cannot be overcome at all. In the end the report favors the careful building of the line, not because it would be altogether safe but because in the Department's opinion the harm it would do would be outweighed by consid erations of national security and America's oil position in the world market. In this conclusion we think the Department has overreached itself.

title: Attacks Near Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Tues day, Jan. 26North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers launched attacks last night against the defense perimeter of this tense Cambodian capital, which is under dawntodusk curfew be cause of an enemy war of terror.

title: Trento a Battleground for Italian Left and Right
description: TRENTO, Italy, Jan. 24  Bombings have become com monplace in this once staid Al pine city, where activists of the extreme right and extreme left are mobilized in a run ning war.

title: MAGIC GLOVE STEALS SERIES SHOW AGAIN
description: The film of last October's World Series, starring Brooks Robinson, made its debut yes terday in a special preview at Toots Shor's restaurant.

title: Tremor Felt in Aleutians
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) The National Earthquake Center reported a moderately strong earthquake today about 90 miles southwest of Adak in the Aleutian Islands. The quake, at 11:08 A.M., had a magnitude of 6.3 on the Richter scale, the center said.

title: 7 Prisoners Still at Large
description: Seven prisoners who escaped Sunday from the Federal House of Detention at 427 West Street were still at large yes terday, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported. The F.B.I. was called in to conduct the in vestigation because all seven men involved in the escape were charged with Federal offenses.

title: City Building Aide Sworn In
description: Joseph Stein, former assistant commissioner for planning and construction with the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor Lindsay as deputy commissioner of the Department of Buildings.

title: Truce Reported Broken
description: SAIGON, Tuesday, Jan. 26 (Reuters)  The Vietcong vio lated their announced fourday lunar new year truce twice within three hours of its start today, a South Vietnamese Gov ernment spokesman said, with attacks that left six persons dead and 22 wounded.

title: Boy's Weekof Joyriding: 60 M.P.H. Atop a Pillow
description: He spotted it eight days ago as he was walking home from schoola big shiny Oldsmobile, unlocked and with its keys in the ignition. So he took it, and for nearly a week, playing hooky from P.S. 6, he kept it to himself.

title: 12 Negro Professors to Help Defend Angela Davis
description: A panel of 12 black law professors from 11 colleges will provide advice and counsel to the defense of Angela Davis, according to Haywood Burns, director of the National Con ference of Black Lawyers.

title: Republic Net Plunges
description: Two of the nation's largest steel companies, the Republic Steel Corporation and the Na tional Steel Corporation, report ed yesterday that their earn ings in the fourth quarter and in all of 1970 dropped sharply from the 1969 levels.

title: 2 Shots Hit a Police Jeep In Park; Glass Cuts Driver
description: Two shots were fired at a Police patrol jeep in Central Park at West 101st Street yes terday, breaking the window next to the driver, who was cut on his forehead and left wrist by flying glass.

title: Agnew Says Rep. Anderson Is Popping Off for Political Reasons in Attack on Case Against Berrigans
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  Vice President Agnew charged today that a member of the House of Representatives was popping off for political rea sons about Federal conspiracy accusations against the Berri gan brothers.

title: Some Phone Service Is Returning to Divided Berlin
description: BONN, Jan. 25West Berlin's million or more citizens who have been unable to visit their relatives in the city's eastern sector since 1966 will at least be permitted to talk with them directly by telephone starting Sunday under a new agreement.

title: Cooke Relaxes Stand on Blaine Issue
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25Cardinal Cooke, the state's leading Cath olic prelate, declared today that the repeal of the socalled Blaine Amendment, which pro hibits state aid to nonpublic schools was not a matter of urgency.

title: MARIJUANA PANEL ASKS SOFTER LAW
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25A sharp reduction of penalties for mari juana offenses that would avoid the criminal stigma for first offenders was recommended to day by the Temporary State Commission to Evaluate the Drug Laws.

title: PENN STATE TOPS PRINCETON, 7062
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Jan. 25 (AP)  Penn State took ad vantage of two Princeton scor ing lapses to record a 7062 vic tory tonight.

title: Williams Sextet Wins, 43
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 25 (AP)Doug Morrell's goal at 3 minutes 32 seconds of overtime carried William to a 43 victory today over Army in hockey.

title: Dance: Bejart's Ballet
description: Lovers of good dancers will find a lot of good dancers to love at the Brooklyn Acad emy of Music, where last night the Belgian National Ballet, which calls itself the Ballet of the 20th Century, made its United States debut.

title: Mrs. Kasabian Not Surprised
description: MILFORD, N. H., Jan. 25 (AP) Mrs. Kasabian said today that she was not surprised by the verdict of guilty. I'm not surprised, but my heart really grieves for them, she said.

title: Striana Leads Ocean Race
description: CAPETOWN, Jan. 25 (UPI) The French ketch Striana led the fleet after eight days in the Cape to Rio de Janeiro yacht race, headquarters reported to day. Striana took the lead from the Canadian ketch Greybeard and the British ketch Ocean Spirit.

title: Lieutenant Accuses Commander of Base Of Neglecting Duty
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Jan. 25 (AP)First Lieut. Louis P. Font filed charges of dereliction of duty today against the com mander of this military base, accusing him of maintaining barracks unfit to live in.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The phone rang at Millrose headquarters last week and the operator reported that Jim Ryun, the 23yearold miler, was re turning the call of Fred Schmertz, the 82yearold director of Friday's showcase Millrose footracing carnival in Madison Square Garden.

title: MRS. M. JAY BROWN
description: Mrs. Barbara Ann Buell Brown, an account executive at Franklin Spier, Inc., an adver tising agency specializing in publishing, died of cancer Sun day. She was 42 years old and lived at 44 West 94th Street with her husband, M. Jay Brown, a professor at The City University.

title: Pros Top Cougars, 115107, As 3 Jones Boys Set Pace
description: SIKESTOWN, Mo., Jan. 25 (AP)Memphis's three Jones boys combined for 66 points tonight and the Pros defeated the Carolina Cougars, 115107, in an American Basketball As sociation game.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX CONTINUE TO RISE
description: The American Stock Ex change scored its 11th consecu tive advance yesterday as the list continued to move ahead in active trading.

title: RARE MUSIC IS SUNG BY DESSOFF CHOIRS
description: True to form, the Dessoff Choirs sang a program of music rarely heard anywhere for their concert at Tully Hall Sunday night.

title: SIR POMPIAN WINS LIBERTY BELL DASH
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 Mrs. J. D. Marquette's Sir Pompian rallied from far back today to catch Winds at War and Northern Joy at the top of the stretch and went on to win the sixfurlong feature by 1 lengths at Liberty Bell.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 It takes a special talent for a technological dropout to become head of a highly suc cessful business concern that specializes in research, devel opment and manufacture of complex equipment.

title: ExJersey Judge Suspended Over Fees for Marriages
description: TRENTON, Jan. 25 (AP) James Del Mauro, former pre siding magistrate in Newark, was suspended by the state to day for one year from prac ticing law on the ground that he accepted fees for perform ing marriages, a violation of a directive of the court.

title: PATMAN HITS PENNSY FOR INSURING BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) Representative Wright Pat man, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Commit tee, said today it was atro cious that the Penn Central. Transportation Company could insure its directors against wrongdoing charges. He de manded an investigation by the Interstate Commerce Commis sion.

title: Manson, 3 Women Guilty; Prosecution to Ask Death
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25  Charles M. Manson and three young women who were mem bers of his hippie family were found guilty today of the Tate LaBianca murders.

title: REAGAN TO SUPPORT NIXON IN 1972 RACE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  Gov. Ronald Reagan of Califor nia gave President Nixon high marks today in assessing his first two years in the White House and pledged to support him in the Presidential election of 1972.

title: Bridge:Swiss Team Championships Change Strategy of the Game
description: Many tournament enthusi asts find that the Swiss team championships now enjoying great popularity at the ex pense of the traditional board amatch game introduce a new strategic dimension In to bridge.

title: OILERS' GRANGER TRADED TO SAINTS
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Phe Houston Oilers traded Hoyle Granger, their career rushing leader, two other play ers and an undisclosed draft choice today to the New Orleans Saints for a defensive tackle, Dave Rowe, and a wide receiver, Ken Burrough.

title: Saigon to Get More U.S. Jets to Take Over Air War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  The Nixon Administration, working to equip South Viet nam to take over full responsi bility for the air war within its boundaries once American air power has been removed, has decided on another sub stantial increase in the size of Saigon's air force.

title: Advertising:
description: On the subject of the pro duction of television commer cials, Jeanne Harrison says, The women's angle is miss ing. Well, she's ready to supply it at Harrison Produc tions, 16 West 46th Street.

title: Oberstar 170Mile Leader As Snowmobile 500 Starts
description: CROOKSTON, Minn., Jan. 25 (AP)Charles Oberstar of Mar quette, Mich., captured the first round lead today in the Winni pegSt. Paul 500 snowmobile race.

title: No Welcome to Hijackers
description: Libya's arrest of four Eritreans who hijacked an Ethio pian airliner to Benghazi the other day is an encouraging sign of progress in the international effort to curb aerial piracy.

title: COMMITTEE JOBS SHIFTED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The Senate game of musical chairs on committee assignments has resulted in a slightly more lib eral cast to the conservative dominated Finance Committee. It has also given Senator Ed mund S. Muskie of Maine a foreign policy platform on the Senate Foreign Relations Com mittee.

title: F.T.C. Seeks Warnings On Phosphate Detergents
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  The Federal Trade Commission moved today to require water pollution warnings in adver tisements and on labels for detergents that contain phos phates.

title: INCOME DROP NOTED BY CHURCH COUNCIL
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 25  Operating income of the Na tional Council of Churches de creased by 2.6 per cent in 1970, according to a report re leased here today by the coun cil's Committee on Finance and Administration.

title: Maazel Speeds Wedding
description: Lorin Maazel, conductor of the Berlin Radio Symphony Or chestra, obtained a waiver yes terday of the statutory 24hour waiting period between getting a marriage license and being married. Supreme Court Jus tice Irving H. Saypol granted permission for the 40yearold musician to marry Israele Mar galit, 30, a concert pianist, im mediately. They were married in Mexico last year after Mr. Maazel obtained a unilateral divorce from his wife, Miriam. She later had the divorce set aside and obtained a Mexican decree of her own.

title: Kodak to Raise Outlays
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 25 (AP) The Eastman Kodak Company announced today it plans spend ing $364million on capital improvements around the world this year.

title: Cloninger and Reds Agree
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 25 (AP) Tony Cloninger, a righthanded pitcher, signed a contract to day for the 1971 season with the Cincinnati Reds. Cloninger, who is 30 years old, posted a 97 wonlost record last season. He also gained a victory over Pittsburgh in the National League playoffs.

title: Ohio Prison Guards Strike
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 25 (AP)Forty guards at the Ohio Penitentiary here struck today in a dispute over the assign ment of overtime work. The strike affected about half the guard force scheduled to report to work at 6 A.M. Some guards working overnight were kept at work past the normal shift change.

title: Du Pont Sales Also Off
description: The preliminary net income of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., in the final quarter of 1970 fell to $63,258,000, or $1.29 a share, from $79,246, 000, or $1.55 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1969, it was reported yesterday.

title: Nun Told to Testify
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 25 (AP)A Roman Catholic nun named as a coconspirator in the alleged kidnapping and bombing plot was granted im munity from prosecution today and ordered to testify before a Federal grand jury investigat ing the case.
