title: SIDNEY STRONGIN, 84, BROOKLYN LAWYER
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25 Sidney F. Strongin, a Brooklyn lawyer, died or a heart attack Friday while on vacation here. He was 84 years old and lived in Far Rockaway, Queens. His office was at 189 Montague Street in Brooklyn.

title: Chile Expects Castro Visit
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 25 Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba will visit Chile this year, ac cording to El Siglo, the news paper of the Chilean Commu nist party.

title: Dartmouth Names Assistant
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 25 (UPI)William D. (Dub) Fes perman, 36 years old and the defensive coach at the Univer sity of Massachusetts for the last three years, was named to a similar football post at Dart mouth today.

title: Muldaur Rites Saturday
description: A memorial service for Charles E. A. Muldaur, a for mer New York advertising ex ecutive, will be held at Christ Church, Pelham Manor, N.Y., at 2 P.M. Saturday. Mr. Mul daur died last Wednesday at Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

title: Soviet Aide Denies Harassing of Jews As Cited by C.B.S.
description: The First Secretary of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations, in a taped editorial broadcast yesterday and today over WCBS, has replied to a C.B.S. editorial condemning the harassment of Soviet officials in the United States. The edi torial referred to official harassment of Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: Tensi Quits as Player
description: DENVER, Jan. 25 (AP)Steve Tensi, quarterback for the Den ver Broncos since 1967, said today he was retiring from pro fessional football and would seek a job as a college coach.

title: HUMPHREY OUTLINES FUNDSHARING PLAN
description: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, out lined yesterday at New York University a revenuesharing plan he said he would introduce today in the Senate.

title: KNICKBUCK GAME A TEST OF POWER
description: With basketballs and fig urative yardsticks, the two best teams in the National Basket ball Association will do battle once again tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: Senate Panel Calls Rogers on Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided today to in vestigate whether the Adminis tration was complying with Congressional restrictions in expanding the American mili tary role in Cambodia.

title: U.S. WILL OVERSEE CAMBODIANS' USE
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 25  American officials have developed a program for a military equipment delivery team that would send United States military representatives through the Cambodian coun tryside to check on deployment of American military equip ment.

title: Camerata Singers Go Beyond Routine In Concert Choices
description: Abraham Kaplan's Camerata Singers investigated some of the choral repertory's lesslived in rooms in their Philharmonic Hall program on Monday night, as well as a familiar chamber or two, and put together a con cert of great technical polish and much musical interest. Mr. Kaplan, the Israeliborn conduc tor who is the Juilliard School's director of choral music, chose works of a generally undra matic nature. He stressed suav ity of tone and restraint rather than highly emotional expres sion, even in so deeply tragic a piece as Monteverdi's La mento d'Arianna. The cele brated lament, presented in its madrigal rather than its solo version, made an effect of cool, mannered sadness that is not usually associated with this powerful music.

title: Release of Ill P.O.W.'s Is Proposed by Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 26 (AP)  The South Vietnamese Govern ment proposed today that it and North Vietnam release immediately all sick and wounded prisoners of war, including American airmen held in North Vietnam.

title: N.&W. Down 9Million
description: John P. Fishwick, president of the Norfolk & Western Rail way, which regularly makes more money from running trains than any other railroad, yesterday described 1970 as just a rotten year for the rail roads.

title: MRS. GEORGE J. EDER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Mrs. Marcel Gray Eder, wife of George Jackson Eder, a lawyer here, died of cancer today at a nursing home in Chevy Chase, Md. She was 64 years old.

title: Merger News
description: Two major commodity con cerns that shared the same origin announced yesterday that they had rejoined forces. They are the A. C. Israel Com modity Company, Inc., and Leon Israel & Bros., both with headquarters in New York and headed by first cousins.

title: Greece Reported Planning To Free 2 Prisoner Groups
description: GENEVA, Jan. 25The Greek Government notified the Inter national Committee of the Red Cross last week that it would release 343 political prisoners held as administrative de tainees in the next four months.

title: Lindsay and Westchester Chief Confer on Financing of Welfare
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 25 Mayor Lindsay and Westchester County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian met for more than an hour in Mr. Michaelian's office here this morning to dis cuss what both consider their most pressing common problem: the financing of welfare.

title: Union Oil Dips 17.5%
description: Earnings of the Union Oil Company of California fell 17.5 per cent for 1970 it was dis closed yesterday.

title: 2 ARAB STATES PLAN PRESIDENTIAL VOTES
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 25 Libya and Syria, both ruled by military Governments, will soon hold national referen dums to choose presidents.

title: All 4 Auto Manufacturers Expanded Jan. 1120 Sales
description: DETROIT, Jan. 25Newcar sales continued to run ahead of last year in midJanuary with all four United States car makers showing gains. An improvement was expected because of last year's sales slump in January and because of the General Motors Corpo ration's strike makeup now.

title: Needles N Pens Scores Second Straight Hialeah Victory With a Late Rally
description: MIAMI, Jan. 25 (UPI)  Needles N Pens scored his sec ond straight victory at Hialeah today with a strong rally in the $8,000 allowance feature at 1 miles.

title: Truman's Condition Called Better
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 25 (UPI)  Doctors at Re search Hospital said today that former President Harry S. Truman's condition had improved from fair to good and said his appetite was better, too.

title: Florida Routs Mississippi
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 25 (UPI)Tony Miller, a sopho more, scored 28 points and Earl Findley added 23 tonight to pace Florida to a 10686 victory over Mississippi.

title: TAXSHARING FOES AGREE TO HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  Two key opponents of Presi dent Nixon's revenuesharing proposal said today that they would allow a Congressional hearing on the plan but would still oppose it.

title: About Pro Hockey
description: The teethgnashing for Ranger fans begins tonight, when Derek Sanderson will discuss his tactics of intimi dation on the Dick Cavett show. Tomorrow night, of course, is the game that Mad ison Square Garden habitus have waited two months to seethe Boston Bruins vs. the New Yorkers. There are more than faceoffs in volved in a Rang erBoston game here. There is, on the part of fans, longings for revenge against a team that ousted the New Yorkers from the playoffs last season and has generally bullied their darlings about.

title: Carrier and Oiler Brush
description: QUONSET POINT, R. I., Jan. 25 (UPI)  The carrier Wasp brushed with an oiler during refueling operations in heavy seas off Bermuda several days ago, the Navy reported today.

title: DAMAGE IS SLIGHT FROM OIL IN SOUND
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 25A belt of ice that had been pro tecting beaches near here from a giant oil slick in Long Island Sound has broken up, but so far no major damage has been re ported.

title: Two American Carriers Off Cambodia Pulled Out
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 25The United States com mand said today that two American naval vessels had withdrawn after nearly two weeks of operations off Cam bodia in which they were sup plying and fueling American armed helicopters supporting South Vietnamese troops.

title: Boat Accessory Makers Keep Watch on Products and Buyers
description: Although it's pretty obvi ous that marine accessories manufacturers have made a concerted effort to capture the imagination and enthusi asm of yachtsmen at the Na tional Boat Show, the tyro may find the thirdand fourthfloor Coliseum arrays befuddling.

title: Tories Balk Unusual Labor Protest in Commons
description: LONDON, Jan. 25  Left wing Labor party members to day disrupted the House of Commons in protest against the Conservative Government's po litical tactics.

title: Young Prefers Foot Race to Rat Race
description: George Young retired from track and field two years ago to run in the competitive world of big business. He found more fast hands, el bows and politics in corpo rate board rooms than he ever saw on an 11lap board track.

title: Dodging Trucks Was a Part of the $125 Tour
description: Who put in the bathrooms the artists or the land lords? demanded Mrs. Emil Strauss from her seat direct ly behind the bus driver at the outset of yesterday's tour to two artists' studiohomes and the Max Hutchinson art gallery in the downtown SoHo district.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDENTS PUT OUT A RECALL EXTRA
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 25  Thirtyfive highschool stu dents here, disturbed by the widespread hysteria and con fusion they say has developed over the possible recall election of the chairman of the Board of Education, have spent their entire winter and spring budget to publish a special edition of their school newspaper devoted entirely to the controversy. The job cost $600.

title: JUDGE REAFFIRMS CURB ON WIRETAPS
description: DETROIT, Jan.25A Federal District Court judge here, in the second such decision in a month, reaffirmed today that the Attorney General does not have the right to order wire taps without a court warrant in domestic cases on the ground of protecting the national security.

title: Advertising:
description: A round little actor with long hair, granny glasses and an Attila the Hun mus tache might well become the most formidable voice in the consumer movement. That's because he's got a sense of humor. It can be a dangerous ingredient when properly used.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nickel Bags of the Mighty Horse
description: Some day we'll say: We didn't know. Didn't know how real the problem was, how drugs would destroy so much of what existsso many minds, so many of our children. We will sit in some distant easy chairs, chilled whis key in our hands, claiming we were too busy putting the revolution to gether, too caught up screaming Right on! and It's nation time, or All power to the people. Those of us who are black. Who are black and justly proud but who

title: About Pro Football
description: The pro football establish ment's efforts to continue the old National LeagueAmeri can League rivalry have fallen on hard times because of the candor of the coaches and players and the skepti cism of the fans.

title: Venezuelan Plane Crashes in Andes; 30 of 48 Rescued
description: MERIDA, Venezuela, Jan. 25 (AP)A Venezuelan airliner with 48 persons aboard crashed today in the Andes. Rescuers located 30 survivors by to night.

title: Isobel Lennart Killed in Crash; Wrote the Book for Funny Girl
description: HEMET, Calif., Jan. 25 (UPI)  Isobel Lennart, awardwin ning writer of the book and screenplay for the Broadway musical and film Funny Girl, died today of injuries suffered in a traffic accident.

title: Bill W. of Alcoholics Anonymous Dies
description: William Griffith Wilson died late Sunday night and, with the announcement of his death, was revealed to have been the Bill W. who was a cofounder of Alcoholics Anonymous in 1935. His age was 75.

title: Helpmann and Dancers Here From Australia
description: Sir Robert Helpmann, di rector of the Metropolitan Meat Company in Australia, a family firm, notes jokingly that the company calls me the dancing butcher. By company, however, he means the Australian Ballet in which he is, with Dame Peggy van Praagh, a different kind of director. Artistic director. The ballet company makes its New York debut tonight at the City Center.

title: INSTITUTIONS GAIN IN EXCHANGE BID
description: A highlevel committee of the New York Stock Exchange broke with tradition yesterday and endorsed the concept of institutional membership on the exchange, coupled with nego tiated commission rates for in stitutional transactions above a size to be determined.

title: Election by N.Y.U. Board
description: Taggart Whipple, a senior partner in the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardell was elected to the hoard of trustees of New York University yesterday. Mr. Whipple was born in Manches ter, N. H., 58 years ago. He is a 1934 graduate of Harvard College and received his law degree from the New York Uni versity Law School in 1938. Mr. Whipple is a trustee of the New York University Law Center Foundation and of the univer sity's Institute of Fine Arts.

title: Jersey City Plans Tax Rise to Meet Starvation Budget
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 25 (AP) Mayor Thomas J. Whelan an nounced today a $109million starvation budget for 1971 that will still necessitate an in crease in the property tax rate.

title: DR. EMILY PIERSON, EARLY SUFFRAGETTE
description: CROMWELL, Conn., Jan. 25 Dr. Emily Miller Pierson, a suffragette who went on to a second career as a physician, died Friday in Middletown at the age of 89.

title: Hoak of Steelers Retires
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 (AP) Dick Hoak, second leading rusher in the history of the Pittsburgh Steelers, announced his retirement today after a decade with the National Foot ball League club.

title: Books of The Times
description: MODEL CITY. By Fred Powledge. 350 pages. Simon and Schuster. $7.95.

title: Executive Changes
description: Smith, Kline & French Laboratories announced yesterday a major realignment of the corporate or ganization, plus the retirement of Walter A. Munns, chairman, in April. Also announced was the election of Robert F. Dee to executive vice president, report ing to Thomas M. Rauch, president. No one was ap pointed to replace Mr. Munns, but it was felt that Mr. Rauch would receive the additional position of chairman at the April board of directors meeting. In his new post, Mr. Dee, formerly group vice presi dent for consumer, animal and instrument products, will be responsible for all line operations. Reporting to Mr. Dee will be two new group vice presidents Alfred J. D'Angelo and Lewis E. Harris.

title: Surplus of Trade Doubled In'70 as Gold Reserve Fell
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 The nation's surplus of exports over imports doubled last year but monetary reserves declined, two Government reports dis closed today.

title: MRS. R. T. ANDERSON
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 25 Mrs. Madeline Leonhard Ander son. widow of Richard Terhune Anderson,, a vice president of the Paterson Parchment Paper Company of Bristtol, Pa., died Saturday in Princeton Hospital after a short illness. She was 86 yaers old.

title: Pentagon Explains Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  A Pentagon spokesman, Jerry W. Friedheim, said today that Con gressional limitations, as he in terpreted them, did not prohibit the sending of American mili tary instructors into Cambodia so long as they were not as signed as advisers to Cam bodians military units.

title: Kinsella, Swimmer, Gets Sullivan Award
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 25 (AP) John Kinsella, the 18yearold Indiana University  swimming sensation, was named today as the 41st winner of the Sullivan Trophy as the nation's out standing amateur athlete in 1970.

title: Vandalism Cancels Classes
description: BOSTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Classes were canceled today at Boston Trade School after van dals opened water ducts flood ing the first and second floors of the old building. Officials estimated damage at $30,000.

title: PEKING MAY WIDEN AIR LINKS ABROAD
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 24 (Reu ters)Communist China's cam paign of broadening its foreign relations may soon lead to ex pansion of its international air services.

title: TAX BREAKS URGED TO AID CHARITIES
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (UPI)A private commission on founda tions and philanthropy led by a recently appointed assistant to President Nixon called today for new and better tax incen tives to encourage charitable giving.

title: Groppi Says He's Pleased
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 25Father Groppi, reached in Montreal where he had a speaking en gagement, said he was very happy with the decision. He said he thought his profession and skin color (white) played a part in the fact that I'm still out of jail.

title: Manila's Left Jeers as Congress Opens
description: MANILA, Jan. 25  The President and Congress of the Philippines and its angry, alien ated radical youth movements faced each other across a sun drenched no man's land today that stretched from the build ing of Congress to Manila City Hall. But contrary to the ex pectations of this tense city, no clash occurred.

title: Decline Is Shown In U.S. Bill Rates At Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  Treasury bill, rates declined again at today's auction from last week's levels, the Govern ment reported yesterday.

title: Vietnam Allies Begin Truce To Mark the Lunar New Year
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 27 (Reuters) United States and South Viet namese forces began a 24hour truce last night in observance of Tet, the Vietnamese and Chi nese Lunar New Year.

title: U.S. Bobsledder Sidelined After Spill at World Meet
description: CERVINIA, Italy, Jan. 26 (AP)The United States' bob sled team dwindled to nine today as another spill in the accidentriddled world cham. pionships sidelined David Dunn of Elm Grove, Wis.

title: Feb. 9 Mortgage Sale Set By Home Loan Bank Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, a subsidiary of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, will sell at auction $50million of Governmentbacked mort gages on Feb. 9, it was an nounced today.

title: 76ERS OVERCOME HAWKS, 129 TO 122
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (UPI) Hal Greer scored 36 points tonight as the Philadelphia 76ers defeated the Atlanta Hawks, 129122, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: POLICE BRUTALITY DENIED IN SUFFOLK
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 26 Charges of police brutality and denial of constitutional rights brought by the son of a New York City Housing and Develop ment Administration official last October were rejected here today by a special grand jury.

title: Land Seizures Denounced
description: SANTIAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) The chairman of the Chilean Senate said today that illegal land seizures by peasants in a southern province appeared to be an attempt to establish a kind of terrorist regime, typi cally totalitarian.

title: DOW INDEX UP 1.17; VOLUME NEAR HIGH
description: Improved newcar sales and a dividend increase by the In ternational Business Machines Corporation helped to extend the stock market's remarkable advance a bit further yester day.

title: Young, McGrady Plan to Pass Up Millrose Games
description: Two stars withdrew yester day from Friday night's Mill rose Games at Madison Square Garden.

title: MRS. JOHN M. WALKER
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., Jan. 26 Mrs. Caroline Silliman Walker, wife of John M. Walker, sales manager of Revere Copper & Brass, Inc., died today of a cerebral hemorrhage in Green wich Hospital. She was 57 and lived at 83 Riverside Avenue here.

title: Tufts Tuition to Rise
description: MEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 26 (AP)Tuition costs for under graduates in the College of Liberal Arts at Tufts University will increase from $2,700 to $2,850 effective next Septem ber. The same increases will apply to Jackson College, Tufts' women's branch, the Engineer ing School and the School of Arts and Sciences.

title: 5 Latin Americans Found Guilty Here in Drug Conspiracy Case
description: Five Latin Americans were found guilty yesterday of con spiring to smuggle in from Panama 88 pounds of cocaine with a retail value of more than $4million.

title: Olympic Body Is Polled On Eligibility of 10 Skiers
description: PARIS, Jan. 26The eligi bility of 10 Alpine skiers for the 1972 Winter Games at Sapporo, Japan, will be decid ed by members of the Inter national Olympic Committee.

title: Mr. Agnew Looks South
description: In a significant departure from the decisions of his recent predecessors, Vice President Agnew has ruled favor of the profilibuster minority in the Senate. Rather than declare forthrightly that the majority of a new Senate has the right to adopt its own rules, he has thrown the issue back to the Senate for unlimited debate.

title: P.&G. Up;
description: The Procter & Gamble Com pany had record earnings of $131,061,000 in the six months ended Dec. 31, a gain of 14 per cent over the $114,821,000 cleared in the yearearlier pe riod, the company reported yesterday.

title: NEW TARIFF CHIEF WAITS FOR HIS PAY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The new chairman of the Tariff Commission attended his first hearing today, but it may be a long time before he collects his first paycheck.

title: Film Retrospective to Honor Kazan
description: Elia Kazan will be hon ored with a twoweek retro spective showing of 15 of the films he has directed since 1945. It will be held at the Museum of Modern Art, starting at 8 P.M. tomor row.

title: Santa Barbara, 2 Years After Its Oil Well Blowout, Still Hopes to Curb Offshore Drilling
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.  Two years after an oil well blowout drenched its beaches with black goo, this palm dotted resort community is still struggling  rather weak ly and controversiallyto stem pressures for more oil produc tion.

title: GARVIN TAYLOR, 80, A JERSEY PUBLISHER
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 26 Garvin P. Taylor, chairman of the board and publisher of The Montclair Times and The Ve ronaCedar Grove Times, died today at Montclair Community Hospital after a heart attack. He was 80 years old and lived at 51 Elston Road in Upper Montclair.

title: Villagers Vent Their Wrath At Kretchmer on Street Filth
description: The more I come to these meetings, the man at the microphone said with exaspera tion, the more I'm convinced that City Hall is like Alice in Wonderland.

title: NUN, IN CONTEMPT, IS ORDERED TO JAIL
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 26 A United States district judge ordered a Roman Catholic nun to jail today for her refusal to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the alleged bombing and kidnapping plot of the socalled Harrisburg Six.

title: Hard Work, Paying Off, Captures Hialeah Sprint
description: MIAMI, Jan. 26 (AP)Dixi ana's Hard Work shook loose from Master Hand on the far turn and drew off to score by threequarters of a length today in the eighth race at Hialeah before a crowd of 14,419.

title: PRICES RISE AGAIN FOR ORANGE JUICE
description: Higher prices of orange juice are ahead for the housewife. That was evidenced recently by the freeze in Florida, which in duced rising prices for frozen orange juice concentrate in fu tures trading and a recent price markup on frozen juice by a leading producer.

title: St. John's Is Beaten in Last Second
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Jan. 26 A lastsecond shot by Joe Sutter gave Davidson a 5654 victory over St. John's tonight before 5,468 at the Charlotte Coliseum.

title: McLain Signed by Senators For One Year at $100,000
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) Denny McLain signed his contract today with the Wash ington Senators for the 1971 season.

title: Ari Will End Brief Run
description: Ari, the musical based on Leon Uris's novel, Exodus, will end it. Broadway engage ment at the Mark Hellinger Theater after Saturday night's performance, the 19th. The show, which costars David Cryer and Constance Towers, was capitalized at $750,000.

title: Chinese Open Year of the Pig
description: The Chinese New Year of the Pig, 4669, starts today. The city's Chinese residents began five days of celebrations last night to welcome in the year and usher out the Year of the Dog.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BONNChancellor Willy Brandt's Ostpolitik Would seem, as he explains it, to have the rather modest purpose of unfreezing the icepack surrounding West Berlin but, in fact, its aims are ultimately far more grandiose.

title: Textile Issue Delays Nixon's Trade Bills
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  The White House said today the outcome of negotiations with Japan on limiting textile imports would have a bear ing on trade legislation that President Nixon would send to Congress later this year.

title: Police Spy Tells of Seeing Panther Make Bomb
description: A police undercover agent testified yesterday that he had watched a Black Panther leader put together the components of a bomb in an antipoverty pro gram office in which they were both employed.

title: Errors in Planning of Mall To Cost State $85Million
description: ALBANY, Jan. 26  The state will have to pay con tractors at least $85million more to compensate them for losses caused by improper state planning of the South Mall proj ect here, a high state official, conceded today.

title: Computer Helps Professor Put His Stamp of Approval on Boat
description: In the time it took to phone a computer, Prof. Dan Savit sky put his stamp of ap proval on a 23foot power boat yesterday at the Coliseum.

title: Soviet RentaCar Dies Of an Overdose of Rules
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 26The So viet authorities have closed down their rentacar system, which at one time was supposed to provide a socialist method of meeting the country's auto mobile needs but which turned out to be a fiasco.

title: HERMAN HOTH, 85, NAZI COMMANDER
description: GOSLAR, Germany, Jan. 26  Former Col. Gen. Herman Hoth, who led the unsuccessful drive to relieve the encircled German Sixth Army in Stalin grad, died here yesterday. He was 85 years old.

title: Jets Hope to Draft J. D. Hill of Arizona State Tomorrow
description: In tomorrow's National Foot ball League draft, the Jets and the Giants each know which player they want in the first roundif that player remains available.

title: Number of Executions by Guinea in Invasion Plot Now Unclear
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Jan. 26 (Reuters)There were con flicting reports today on how many of 92 defendants con victed of treason in neighboring Guinea had actually been ex ecuted. The radio in Conakry, the Guinean capital, which ye terday reported the execution of some of those convicted, has not specified a number.

title: NEW ISSUES STRAIN COALITION IN ROME
description: ROME, Jan. 26A contro versial farm bill and regional politics in Sardinia caused new strains today in the sixmonth old CenterLeft Government of Premier Emilio Colombo.

title: FISH ARE UNHARMED BY SOUND OIL SPILL
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 26 (UPI) A Federal water quality con trol team reported today there was no evidence of damage to fin fish or shellfish as a result of a 386,000gallon oil spill in Long Island Sound.

title: Radiation Study Finds No Need To Tighten Exposure Standards
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  Despite recent public contro versies, the nation's foremost group concerned with radia tion protection sees no need for changing most limits set to prevent overexposure.

title: Cardin Makes Styles Look Like Fun Again
description: PARIS, Jan. 26  Pierre Cardin made the world safe for the miniskirt yesterday, but that was only one of his achievements. His spring col lection, the first triumph of the couture openings here, had enough ideas to keep fashion going for years, even at its present rate of ob solescence.

title: Liquefied Gas Plant Set
description: MAHOMET, Ill., Jan. 26 (AP) Plans to build a $13million liquefied gas plant and storage facility near Mahomet were an nounced today. The plant, to be built in Champaign County southwest of Chicago, will con vert and store conventional supplies of natural gas in a compact liquid form known as LNG.

title: Bridge: IMP Pair Games Below Level Of Tournament Gaining Favor
description: The tournament trend in recent years has been toward natural methods of scoring that bring duplicate play closer to the rubber bridge game. The traditional board amatch team contest, which in this country, but nowhere else, was staple tournament diet for almost 40 years, has almost disappeared.

title: Ferber: Unusual Piano Program, Tastefully Played
description: Albert Ferber, the Swiss born, Londonbased pianist who made his American de but about five years ago, returned to New York on Monday night. He gave a re cital in Alice Tully Hall, and chose a most unusual pro gram. All of it he handled like the fine pianist and sen sitive artist he is.

title: Tupamaros Warn Police Not to Hunt for 3 Hostages
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 26 (AP)The Tupamaros urban guerrillas said today that the lives of three foreign hostages would be in danger if the Uruguayan police found where they were being held.

title: Former Reporter Convicted
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (UPI)Harry. J. Karafin, a former reporter for The Phila delphia Inquirer, was convicted of perjury charges yesterday in Common Pleas Court. The charges stem from an April, 1968, hearing regarding black mail offenses allegedly com mitted by Karafin. He was later convicted of 20 counts of black mail and 20 counts of extortion.

title: ALI FIGHT BARRED IN OKLAHOMA CITY
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 26 (AP)  The Oklahoma City Council debated for 20 minutes today and decided it would not allow city property to be used for televising the Muhammad AliJoe Frazier title fight.

title: Cottonseed Support Halted
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) The Agriculture Department said today it will not operate a price support program for cot tonseed this year because cash prices for the crop are expected to be higher.

title: A Chance to Freeze ABM's
description: The Nixon Administration has ob viously been concerned about possible Soviet strategic arms development of two kinds: the growth of a capability to destroy a very large fraction of our ICBM's by preemptive attack; and the possibility that a sufficiently effective Soviet ABM system might be deployed so that neither we nor they would believe in the retaliatory capabilities of our strategic forces.

title: Hawks Tie Canucks, 33, On Bobby Hull's 50Footer
description: VANCOUVER, Jan. 26 (UPI) Bobby Hull's 29th goal of the season, a 50foot slapshot, lift ed the Chicago Black Hawks to a 33 tie with the Vancouver Canucks tonight.

title: SAMUEL R. FELLER
description: Samuel R. Feller, a lawyer who had served as deputy State Superintendent of Insur ance and as special counsel to the State Superintendent of Banks, died yesterday at his home, 310 East 44th Street. He was 66 years old.

title: 3 Renaults Lead Monte Carlo Run At Halfway Point
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 26 (UPI)  Three French Alpine Renaults swept into the lead at the halfway mark of the Monte Carlo automobile ral ly tonight, but Bjorn Walde gaard of Sweden, in the only surviving Porsche, was press ing them hard in fourth place.

title: 7 BROOKLYN HOUSES SWEPT BY FLAMES
description: Seventeen families were driven from their homes when a threealarm fire swept through seven threestory houses in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn early this morning.

title: MAIL SERVICE BOARD TO SEEK RATE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) The Board of Governors of the new United States Postal Service voted today to request increases in mail rates expected to produce an 8cent firstclass stamp by about midMay.

title: MANSFIELD BACKS SMALLER CABINET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Senator Mike Mansfield, in a Democratic response tonight to President Nixon's State of the Union Message of last Friday, praised the President's pro posed reorganization of the Federal Government as a move in the right direction.

title: About Motor Sports
description: If Wyer comes, can spring be far behind? Here it is, the end of January, and with it come two of the early har bingers of springthe Twen tyfour Hours of Daytona and John Wyer defending the world manufacturers cham pionship. Practice opens at noon today for the 24hour endurance event, which will begin at 3 p.m., on Sat urday. Wyer, who is 61 years old, is managing director of JW Automotive Engineering in England, which prepares those orange and skyblue Porsches for the GulfPorsche racing team.

title: Jersey Man Held in Slaying Of an 11YearOld Newsboy
description: KEYPORT, N. J. Jan. 26 (AP)A 21yearold man was charged today with strangling an 11yearold newsboy.

title: A South African Court Drops Miscegenation Case Against 19
description: CAPETOWN, Jan. 26  The scheduled trial of five white men and 14 black women on miscegenation charges was abandoned today because the prosecution witnesses were re luctant to testify.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: IMPASSE REPORTED ON LOCKHEED COST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  With a month to go before its major military program stops for lack of money, the Lock heed Aircraft Corporation is re ported to have reached an im passe in negotiations with the Pentagon to save the company from bankruptcy.

title: Knicks Topple Bucks, 10798, as Reed Outscores Alcindor, 35 Points to 29
description: Strong defense, perfectly blended movement, clutch bas ketsthe qualities that made them champions last year were put on display by the New York Knicks last night and brought them a 10798 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks at Madison Square Garden.

title: Leader Feared Military Coup in Kampala for Months
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 26 Milton Obote of Uganda had feared for months the pos sibility of the military coup d'tat that deposed yesterday him as President of that East African nation.

title: POLES DROP PLAN THAT LED TO RIOTS
description: WARSAW, Jan. 26Poland's leaders have decided to shelve the controversial incentive sys tem of wage payments that was the basis of the riots in Decem ber and last week's renewed unrest in the northern coastal cities.

title: Defection Report Denied
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 26 (UPI)Alex Metreveli, one of the best tennis players in the Soviet Union, said today that he had no intention of defect ing to Australia and that he would leave for home next Tuesday.

title: Woolf Diaries Purchased From Dealer, Not Estate
description: The New York Public Library said yesterday that it had ac quired the diaries of the late Virginia Woolf from a dealer rather than from the estate of her husband, Leonard Woolf, who died in 1969.

title: Spanish Prince and Princess Are Feted at a White House Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 President and Mrs. Nixon en tertained Prince Juan Carlos de Borbn, heir to the Spanish throne, and Princess Sophia, his Greekborn wife, at a whitetieanddecorations din ner and ball at the White House tonight.

title: Court Upholds Consumer Act And Curb on Creditors' Actions
description: New York State Supreme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold has upheld the constitutionality of the City's Consumer Pro tection Act and a regulation under it that forbids creditors to contact a delinquent debtor's employer without first getting a judgment for the money owed.

title: Coco Is Missed
description: PARIS, Jan. 26It was the first Chanel show with out Chanel.

title: Rockefeller U., in Red, Plans Fund Drive
description: Rockefeller University, the East Side graduate institution that has never had to mount a fund drive in its 70year history, announced yesterday a longrange campaign to raise $118million to strengthen all areas of the university.

title: Man in the News
description: When Mitchell Shipman, the chairman of the three man board chosen to arbi trate the telephone repair men's dispute, left the first meeting of the panel yester day afternoon, his dentist was waiting outside the door to take him away for a check up. Mr. Shipumn has been so busy recently, the dentist explained, that the only way to make sure of his patient is to corner him be tween meetings. One reason he is so busy is that his 40 years of experience on labor relations, conciliation and arbitration panels in a vari ety of industries keeps him in demand for settling new problems.

title: MAN KILLS HIMSELF, WIFE AND 4 CHILDREN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (UPI)A businessman said to be under the strain of bank ruptcy, loss of his country club membership, his automobile and his home shot and killed his wife, four of his children and himself today.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: BOSTON, Jan. 26 (AP)Bob McKillop scored 18 points, in cluding three decisive free throws in the final 70 seconds, in lifting Hofstra to a 6059 basketball victory over Boston University tonight.

title: 12 Pupils in Bronx Treated For Gas Inhalation in School
description: Twelve children were treated for gas inhalation at Fordham Hospital yesterday after nox ious fumes had leaked into their portable classroom build ing at Public School 67 in the Bronx.

title: I.B.M. Directors Raise The Quarterly Dividend
description: Directors of the Interna tional Business Machines Cor poration raised the quarterly dividend yesterday to $1.30 a share from $1.20. It will be distributed Feb. 28 to stock holders of record Feb. 10.

title: Haber, on Stand in P.B.A. Suit, Says He Was Silent on Terms
description: Herbert L. Haber, Director of Labor Relations for the city, acknowledged under crossex amination yesterday that he had not mentioned any oral under standings or special conditions in replying to an inquiry from the firefighters about terms of a new patrolmen's agreement in February, 1969.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON ADVANCE SLIGHTLY
description: The London stock market was slightly firmer yesterday, but trading was slack.

title: Calley Calls Mental Tests An Unwarranted Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 26 (AP) First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. arrived today for an ex haustive mental examination he calls unwarranted and unnec essary.

title: Charles H. Tuttle, Civic Leader Here for Many Years, Dies at 91
description: Charles H. Tuttle, a leader in law, education and religion here for six decades, died, yesterday in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital. He was 91 years old, but until he became ill last month he appeared regularly at his office at Breed, Abbott & Morgan, of which he was counsel and former senior partner, from his home at 1 University Place.

title: U.S. WILL OPPOSE WHITE MOTOR TIE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)  The Government an nounced today that it would fight the pending merger of two Cleveland manufacturing con cerns that are among the 200 largest corporations in the na tion.

title: Con Ed Off
description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., yesterday reported a decline in pershare earnings for 1970 de spite higher revenues. The com pany also said that fourthquar ter earnings ran higher than the yearearlier level.

title: Medical Cost Relief Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) Senator J. Caleb Boggs, Re publican of Delaware, intro duced legislation today de signed to relieve the financial burden of families whose mem bers are struck with sudden and expensive illnesses. The bill seeks to encourage the insur ance industry to offer policies providing coverage for such illnesses.

title: Birds, Saved From Oil, Dying at Zoo on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 (UPI)  Hundreds of birds that were rescued from the San Francisco Bay oil slick are dying at the San Fran cisco Zoo, where they were taken after volunteers cleaned the oil off their feathers last week.

title: MRS. AMY WERTHEIMER
description: WILLAMANTIC, Conn., Jan. 26Mrs. Amy Wertheimer, the binder of rare books for the University of Connecticut, died here yesterday at the age of 81. She was also a teacher of book bindery and had practiced the art as a member of the Silver mine Guild of Artists in Fair field County before moving here in 1953.

title: Heath Acts for Compromise on Arms Sale
description: LONDON, Jan. 26  Prime Minister Heath opened the way today for a compromise that could quiet the uproar over his plans to sell arms to South Africa.

title: ITT Sheraton Expands
description: ITT Sheraton International, Inc., the subsidiary of the ITT Sheraton Corporation of Amer ica that operates overseas ho tels, said yesterday it was starting an expansion program calling for the franchising of hotels and motor inns around the world. Claude Feninger,

title: MISS HOGAN GAINS IN AUSSIE TENNIS
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 26 (AP)Patti Hogan defeated Kristine Kammer, 62, 62, in a match between Americans to day in the third round of the women's singles at the Vic torian Tennis Championships.

title: Latin Press Official Finds Wide Curbs on Publications
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 26 (AP)The chairman of the Freedom of the Press Commit tee of the InterAmerican Press Association painted a bleak pic ture today of liberty of the press in the hemisphere.

title: TaxiBill Vote Due Tomorrow Despite Uncertainty in Council
description: Leaders of the City Council counted votes yesterday, then decided to call up the contro versial package of taxicab leg islation for action tomorrow.

title: Italian MeetPros Only
description: ROME, Jan. 26 (UPI)The Italian International Tennis Championships, one of the ma jor events of the world circuit, will be a professional tourna ment this year.

title: Beryllium Alloy Price Rise
description: The Brush Beryllium Com pany announced yesterday that it had raised prices of beryl liumcontaining alloys. Wrougt product base prices and billet prices were increased by 12 cents a pound. Casting ingot was raised from four cents to eight cents a pound depending on beryllium content, while the price of master alloys was in creased by $3 a pound of con tained beryllium.

title: FANNY MAY LIFTS PRICE FOR STOCK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (Reuters)The Federal Nation al Mortgage Association an nounced today an increase in the price at which it issues stock to mortgage sellers un der its mandatory stockpur chase and retention require ments.

title: ZealforMr.Hawthorne Leads to Labor of Love
description: A 46yearold Michigan businessman's enthusiasm for a man he calls Mr. Haw thorne led to the publica tion this week of The Na thaniel Hawthorne Journal, the first volume of a pro jected annual, of which he is the editor.

title: U. S. Figure Skate Events To Start Today at Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, Jan 26Berths on the national team that will compete in Canada and France will be at stake as the United States figure skating cham pionships begin tomorrow at two sites here.

title: 3 Hold News Conference
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 26Three of the six persons indicted in the alleged plot to kidnap Mr. Kissinger said today that they believe we have been framed by the Government through the F.B.I. and the Justice Depart ment and the Government is interested in paralyzing the peace movement.

title: Opposes OneParty System
description: KAMPALA, Jan. 26 (Agence FrancePresse)General Amin said at the news conference that the military leadership in tended to end the oneparty system set up under President Obote.

title: Blake Sends Telegram
description: GENEVA, Jan. 26Dr. Eu gene Carson Blake, general sec retary of the World Council of Churches, appealed today to President Tour of Guinea to call an immediate halt to ex ecutions and to reduce if at all possible the severity of the prison sentences.

title: BUCKLEY NAMED TO SENATE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  Senator James L. Buckley of New York, who unseated a Re publican Senator in the Novem ber election, has been appoint ed to the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, which will work for the election of G.O.P. Senate candidates in 1972.

title: Ohio Architect Appointed As New Capitol Architect
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) The White House has ap pointed an Ohio architect, George M. White, as the new Capitol architect, Senator Wil liam B. Saxbe announced today.

title: COURT BACKS BUNGE IN HANOVER LAWSUIT
description: The State Supreme Court upheld yesterday a suit of near ly $3.5million against the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company filed by the Bunge Corporation, a dealer in vege table oils.

title: TWO SKI RESORTS AGREE TO MERGE
description: The modestsized Big Vanilla at Davos ski center in New York's southern Catskills at Woodridge has acquired a big brotherthe giant Mount Snow ski area in southern Vermont.

title: Kennedy and Ervin Planning a Test in Supreme Court of President's Pocket Veto Power
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Sam J. Ervin Jr. of North Carolina, hoping to force a Supreme Court test of a President's pock et veto powers, are preparing to seek an appropriation for a medical training program that was vetoed last December by President Nixon.

title: Margin Credit Exemption Weighed for Block Firms
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Federal Reserve Board published for comment today a proposed rule that would exempt block positioners from its margin requirements. Block positioners are broker age firms and others who buy all or part of a large block of stock that is offered for sale for which no other immediate buyer can be found.

title: ROCKEFELLER SEES TAX ADJUSTMENT
description: ALBANY, Jan. 26Governor Rockefeller said today that some adjustments would have to be made in state taxes to meet $1.5billion in mandated increases in state spending for the new fiscal year, including $900million for schools and local governments.

title: U.S. Bill Rates Drop Sharply At Treasury's Monthly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Monthly Treasury bills rates posted a sharp decline at to day's auction of 272 and 365 day bills to their lowest levels since May 1967, the Govern ment announced late this after noon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: Insouciant Pianist
description: A pianist who starts out his recital with Ravel's Gas pard de la Nuit, which may no longer hold the title of most difficult piece ever writ ten for the instrument but is certainly nobody's warm up exercise, shows an ap pealing insouciance. Thomas Simons began that way at Town Hall on Monday night, when he appeared in the Young Concert Artists Se ries. He then made his way through works of Ruggles, Stockhausen, Scriabin and Thomas Simons, most of which demanded technical command and musicianship at least on the level of the Ravel.

title: Ralph T. Urich, Vice President Of Reichhold Chemicals, Dead
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 26 Ralph T. Urich, senior vice presidentsales of Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., died of a heart attack at his home yesterday. He was 62 years old and lived here at 25 Hillside Terrace.

title: Dance: No One's Sitting on His Hands
description: Something of the excite ment of a bullfight prevails lately at the ANTA Theater, where the Alvin Ailey Ameri can Dance Theater presented a premiere and a revival Monday night.

title: SOVIET SAYS CRAFT LANDED ON VENUS AND RADIOED DATA
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 26The So viet Union announced today that its unmanned Venera 7 last month made the first soft landing on Venus's torrid sur face and sent back data for more than 20 minutes.

title: LOUIS N. FIELD, 67, LAWYER SINCE '26
description: Louis N. Field, the lawyer representing citizens who suc cessfully took the then Parks Commissioner Robert Moses to court in 1956 to stop him from extending the parking lot at the TavernintheGreen in Central Park, died Monday in Polyclinic Hospital after suffer ing a heart attack in his office at 1501 Broadway. He was 67 years old and lived at 40 East Ninth Street.

title: Economic Analysis
description: There is always danger that the economic and business sig nificance of a Presidential State of the Union address will be lost in all the rich poetry and rhetoric required by our na tional traditions. Each address is expected to attain a higher moral level than any preceding speech, except for the moral heights scaled by the Founding Fa therswhich must at least be equaled. This requirement was fully met by President Nixon's latest address in which he declared that the people of this nation are eager to get on with the quest for new greatness, affirmed that it is for us here to open the doors that will set free again the real greatness of this nation the genius of the American people, and even called for a new American revolution  a revolution as profound, as farreaching, as exciting, as that first revolution almost 200 years ago.

title: German Critics Score Marceau For His MimeDrama Candide
description: BONN, Jan. 26  The world premiere of Marcel Marceau's new mimedrama Candide at Hamburg's State Opera House Sunday night appeared to be heading for moderate success until intermission. It rapidly slid downhill afterward, how ever, and the critics called it a flop.

title: Rangers Get Sather From Penguins Before Bruins' Game at Garden Tonight
description: On the eve of their battle with the rugged and good Bruins, the Rangers last night traded for a former Bostonian, Glen Sather, once one of the team's major bouncers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Explosions in Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Jan. 26  Two explosive charges went off in downtown Pnompenh this afternoon, injuring four civil ians, including a 3yearold boy in his father's arms.

title: Foster Knocks Out Marshall
description: George (Kid) Foster of Cin cinnati stopped Lloyd Marshall of Newark at 2 minutes 49 sec onds of the eighth and last round last night in the feature bout at Sunnyside Gardens. Foster, who weighed 135 pounds to Marshall's 135, opened a cut over Marshall's left eye in the fourth.

title: Sales at Big Retail Chains Climbed 7.8% in December
description: Leading chain store organ izations in the country, helped by a lastminute surge of Christmas business, lifted vol ume 7.8 per cent last month from the level of December, 1969. Sales during 1970 as a whole climbed 7.7 per cent.

title: 60 Groups Here Join To Oppose Proposal For City U. Tuition
description: A coalition of 60 civic, re ligious and educational organ izations announced yesterday its opposition to a proposal for a sliding scale of tuition fees for undergraduate students at the City University.

title: Market Place: Different Kind Of Merger Seen
description: Now that the stock market has developed a full head of steam, you are probably won dering why mergers have not begun to dominate financial news.

title: FLORIDIANS SCORE OVER NETS, 12197
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 26 The Floridians, hitting on 60 per cent of their shots in the first half, kept up the pace to the final whistle to turn back the New York Nets, 12197, in an American Basketball Associa tion game tonight.

title: Obote Pledges Return
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Jan. 26 (Reuter)  Mr. Obote said at a news conference to night that he believed the take over was staged to prevent a murder trial that might have implicated the army command er who overthrew him.

title: Notre Dame Wins, 10480
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 26 (UPI)Notre Dame gained its 10th victory tonight, beating Michigan State, 10480. It was the first Irish triumph over the Spartans in six seasons.

title: Henry Dankner, Designer Of Jewelry, Is Dead at 73
description: Henry Dankner, an interna tionallyknown master jewelry designer, died on Monday at the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 216 West 89th Street.

title: Nixon Again Asks $1.5Billion Fund For Desegregation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 President Nixon today asked Congress, for the second time in a year, to provide $1.5billion to ease the proc ess of school desegregation in the South.

title: Marquette Wins No. 26
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 26 (UPI) Marquette took a 65 lead and went on to swamp North ern Michigan, 10657, tonight. For the thirdranked Warriors the victory was the 15th in a row this season and 26th straight over two years.

title: Kings Get Backstrom In 3Man Hockey Deal
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 26 (AP)  Ralph Backstrom was traded by the Montreal Ca nadiens to the Los Angeles Kings today in a threeplayer National Hockey League ex change.

title: Report Accepted Here
description: The Soviet report that Venera 7 landed intact on the planet Venus and transmitted data to earth was viewed here last evening as probably correct.

title: Lakers 136111 Victors
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26 (UPI)Despite being bothered by a jammed toe, Jerry West sank 33 points tonight to pace the Los Angeles Lakers to a 136111 rout of the Chicago Bulls. It was the Lakers' fourth onesided victory in a row.

title: ALBERT REID OFFERS 2 NEW DANCE WORKS
description: Albert Reid is a choreographer with a firm and imaginative creative grasp but an infrequent desire to use it. Monday even ing he presented two compel ling new works on a mixed pro gram at the Cubiculo.

title: SCHOOLS REPORT ON READING SKILL
description: The Board of Education made public yesterday the 1970 read ing scores for pupils in the city's 770 elementary, inter mediate and junior high schools and, at the same time, desig nated the 313 schools that now will be eligible to select new teachers outside the normal licensing process.

title: NICHOLAS A. MILAS, EXPERT ON VITAMINS
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 26 (AP)Prof. Nicholas Athana sius Milas, a retired expert in the synthesis of vitamins, died yesterday at his home in subur ban Belmont after a long ill ness. He was 74 years old.

title: 74 Troopers Call In Sick
description: SCITUATE, R. I., Jan. 26 (AP) The state police barracks said that 74 troopers had called in sick today after rejecting state contract proposals yesterday. All offduty members of the 142man force were ordered to report this morning to fill the gap.

title: City's Manpower Training Is Disjointed, Study Finds
description: The wideranging manpower training programs in New York City were described yesterday as a fragmented, disjointed, overlapping conglomerate that cost the taxpayers $100million to $120million a year.

title: State University Expected to Raise Tuition Today
description: ALBANY, Jan. 26The board of trustees of the State Univer sity of New York is expected to approve tuition increases for most of the 155,000 students in its 32 institutions.

title: Theater: In New England Winter
description: Ed Bulling is probably the most ambitious of America's younger playwrights. He is currently working on a 20 play cycle, the second play of which, In New England Win ter, opened last night at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater. It is a rare appearance, before crit ics, in the commercial theater for Bullins.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Seized in Rockland Raid Held on Numbers Charges
description: ROCKLAND LAKE, N. Y., Jan. 26The police raided what they said was the head quarters of the entire Hudson Valley numbers racket tonight.

title: Amex Prices Rise in Heavy Trading
description: The American Stock Exchange turned in its 12th advance in a row yesterday in the heaviest trading in almost four months.

title: Rogers of lona Wins Twice To Gain Tennis Semifinals
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Jan. 26Billy Rogers of Iona upset two seeded players and reached the semifinals of the Concord Hotel intercollegiate indoor tennis tournament to day.

title: Apollo 14 Crew Rehearses MoonLanding Maneuvers
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 26The Apollo 14 astronauts rehearsed moonlanding maneu vers here today as preparations for their launching Sunday continued without interruption.

title: Frigid Winds Send Construction Debris Crashing to Street
description: A bonechilling wind sliced through the metropolitan area last night, knocking pieces of concrete off halfconstructed buildings and pedestrians near ly off their feet.

title: MRS. FREDERICK FATZER
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 26 Mrs. Therese Stuven Fatzer, wife of Frederick Fatzer, former owner of the Freehold Raceway, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital, New York. She was 73 years old and lived at 11 South Crescent Avenue.

title: MRS. SIDNEY P. ALLEN
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 26 Mrs. Leontine Polk Allen, a textile designer for several well known New York fabric houses, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital after a brief illness. She was 67 years old and lived at 17 North Chatsworth Avenue in this community. Her hus band, Sidney P. Allen, died in 1966.

title: Laird Again Urges Hanoi To Allow Camp Inspections
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)  Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird today renewed his plea to North Vietnam to live up to the Geneva Convention and permit the International Red Cross to inspect its prisonerof war camps.

title: Dalton Headmaster Supported by Board In Unanimous Vote
description: The board of trustees of the Dalton School, one of the city's largest and most prestigious private schools, gave a unani mous vote of confidence last night to the school's head master, Donald Bair.

title: Lewis M. Gibb, 69, Headed Brooklyn's Loeser Store
description: Lewis M. Gibb, former presi dent of Frederick Loeser & Co., Inc., a Brooklyn department store now closed, died on Sun day in Hialeah, Fla., where he spent his winters. His home was in Middleburg, Va.

title: 2,000 at Lehman Register as Voters As Well as Students
description: Enterprising students at Leh man College in the Bronx are registering classmates to vote as they wait in long lines out side the school gymnasium to register for spring semester classes.

title: Super Bowl Loser Gets Part of Spoils
description: Charles Louis (Chuck) Howley, the weakside line backer of the Dallas Cow boys, rose out of the ashes of athletic anonymity yesterday to receive his automobile and applause for his efforts in the recent Super Bowl game.

title: Southern Earnings Rise;
description: The Southern Railway, long among the most profitable rail roads in the country, reported yesterday record operating rev enues and earnings for 1970.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE HOUSE ON JEFFERSON STREET. By Horace Gregory. 276 pages. Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $6.95.

title: INCOME TAX URGED FOR CONNECTICUT
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 26A bi partisan body appointed by the General Assembly recommend ed today the imposition of a state income tax and increases in many existing taxes.

title: Xerox Consolidation to Cut 250 RochesterArea Jobs
description: The Xerox Corporation an nounced yesterday plans for consolidating several of its ac tivities in the Rochester area with the resultant loss of some 250 jobs over the next few weeks.

title: Dunne Scores Panel Plan On Marijuanaas Indulgent
description: ALBANY, Jan. 26A special state commission's proposals for reducing minor marijuana of fenses to noncriminal violations were criticized as excessively indulgent today by the chair man of the commission's mari juana panel.

title: Suns Rout Braves, 11482
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 26 (AP)  Buffalo's coldshooting Braves were no match for Phoenix to night as the Suns coasted to an 11482 triumph. The Braves were never in contention, hit ting only four of 18 fieldgoal attempts to fall behind 3014 after one quarter.

title: European Nations Tackle a Rising Problem The Aged
description: BERLIN, Jan. 16  Mrs. Charlotte Rynar sits on her bed, twisting the strap on her handbag. I am 76, I have managed, she says tremu lously. But I get worried now, I get lonely. I think of death. What will happen? What will happen to me?

title: Oil Profits Mixed;
description: Declines outnumbered ad vances yesterday as the oil in dustry began to pump out its preliminary earnings reports for 1970.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Du Pont Perfects System Of Colorfast Cotton Dyeing
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., has perfected a new sys tem of colorfast printing and dyeing of blends of polyester and cotton.

title: Greece Names Press Chief
description: ATHENS, Jan. 26 (Reuters) George Georgalas, a former Communist who joined the Cabinet of Premier George. Papadopoulos last summer, was named today as head of the Government's information serv ices abroad. He also was given full authority over Greek news papers.

title: WIDER BASE SOUGHT BY CHURCH COUNCIL
description: LOUISVILLE, Jan. 26The National Council of Churches began today a process of reor ganization that is designed to broaden its ecumenical base while still permitting it to speak out on controversial issues. The council's policy making general board ended a fourday meeting here this afternoon in the Seelbach Hotel.

title: MOHAWK PLANNING 20% CUT IN FLIGHTS
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Jan. 26 (AP)  Russell Stephenson, chief executive officer of Mohawk Airlines, said today that the airline planned a 20 per cent systemwide reduction of passenger flights when its pilots' strike was settled.

title: BOND RATES FALL FOR LONG TERM
description: The Bell System sold a bond issue yesterday that was priced to yield 6.80 per cent, down more than a full percentage point from one sold only three weeks ago.

title: Majority of Senate Backs Proposal to Ease LongStanding Rule for Curbing Filibusters
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 A majority of the Senate began today an uncertain and prob ably prolonged effort to mod ify the Senate's antifilibuster rule, which has aften ?? as a roadblock to legislation.

title: 1,828 Arab Guerrillas Killed Since '67 War, Dayan Says
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 26 (Reu ters)Israeli troops killed 1,636 Arab guerrillas in border clashes and 192 in the occu pied territories since the six day war of June, 1967, Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said to day.

title: U.S. Steel's 3Month Profit Falls 40%
description: The United States Steel Cor poration, the nation's leading steel producer, reported yester day that earnings in the final quarter of 1970 dropped 40 per cent below those of the year earlier period. For the full year, net income was down 32 per cent from the 1969 level.

title: Examiners Board Defended at Rights Panel Hearing
description: A member of the city school system's Board of Examiners yesterday defended the board as an impartial body that pro tects against the hiring of illit erate or deficient candidates for teaching jobs.

title: Federal Tax Chief Is Resigning; Cites Personal Considerations
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) Randolph W. Thrower will resign at the end of February as Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, the White House said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising:
description: Boy, oh boy, things are really looking good for maga zines. Or at least that's what they told us yesterday at the first All Magazine Industry Sales Conference.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis Said to Ask $500Million More In Credit From U.S.
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 26 (Reu tors)  Official sources here said today that Israel had asked the United States for an addi tional $500million in economic and military credits for the coming year.

title: SAMUEL COLEMAN, 59, COLUMBIA LECTURER
description: Samuel Coleman, a lecturer in philosophy at Columbia Uni versity, died of a heart attack on Monday at Mount Sinai Hos pital. He was 59 years old and lived at 404 West 116th Street.

title: Obote's Ouster in Uganda
description: In a pamphlet circulated to his governing party last year, President Milton Obote of Uganda declared that he was perhaps the only African leader not afraid of a military takeover. This may have been wishful think ing in view of the coup that deposed him this week and the evident deterioration over the past months in his relations with Gen. Idi Amin, who has now taken over.

title: Perspective on Revenue Sharing
description: The green light that has now been given for Congres sional hearings on President Nixon's proposal to share Federal tax revenue with the states and localities pro vides a needed opportunity for exploring the proposal's strengths and potential pitfalls.

title: A WagePrice Review Board Is Recommended by Woodcock
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  Leonard Woodcock, the presi dent of the United Automobile Workers, suggested today the creation of a wageprice review board to cope with inflation.

title: British Unruffled by a Week of No Mail (or Bills)
description: LONDON, Jan. 26Bri tain's Post Office strike is a week old today, and life goes on with hardly a twitching upper lip.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rise in December Savings Was Biggest Monthly Gain
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (Reuters) New deposits at savings and loans increased by $2.7billion in December over the bal ances in November, the largest monthly increase ever experi enced by the business, the United States Savings and Loan League said today.

title: Basketball Poll WRITERS' RATINGS
description: The top 20, with points figured on a 201816141210 987654321 basis for first through 15th places (firstplace votes in parentheses) and won lost records through games of last Saturday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Vandals Close Airport
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass, Jan. 26 (UPI)The Pittsfield municipal airport was closed tonight be cause vandals had knocked out threequarters of the floodlights along the runway, officials said.

title: Ballet: Australians and Nureyev Bow
description: Dance companies are pour ing in from everywhere  from Belgium, from Siberia, and last night, at the New York City Center, the Aus tralian Ballet. Or rather, to quote the company's adver tising: NUREYEV as guest artist with the AUSTRALIAN BALLET.

title: Demagogy on the Rent Front
description: The clearest lesson of the welfare hotel scandal is that the city desperately needs more housing. Now Manhat tan's Democratic leaders are engaged in a demagogic political exercise that threatens to decrease the already meager housing supply.

title: Palicka Criticizes HurdleTopplers
description: When John Palicka sees other runners knocking down hurdles and winning, he starts wondering.

title: NEW NADER GROUP SEEKING TIPSTERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  Ralph Nader has set up a new organization to encourage what he calls responsible whistleblowing by scientists, engineers and other profes sional employes of corporations and government.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Addressograph Mul tigraph Corporation an nounced yesterday in Cleveland the election of Charles L. Davis as presi dent and chief executive officer, effective Feb. 1. Mr. Davis, 51 years old, who has been an execu tive vice president of Honeywell, Inc., succeeds William H. Wilson, 67, who is retiring after 51 years with the office machine company. Mr. Wilson will continue to serve as a consultant for the company that employs 24,000 worldwide. The company said the elec tion of Mr. Davis concluded a comprehensive evaluation of candidates for the chief executive responsibility. Mr. Davis headed Honeywell's computer and communications opera tions when they became the second largest force in the industry, Addressograph said. Honeywell, Inc., Minneapolis, announced the election of C. W. Spangle as executive vice president to succeed Mr. Davis, who resigned to take the Addressograph Multigraph presidency. Since last August, Mr. Spangle, 45, had been senior vice president with primary operating responsibility for Honeywell's worldwide computer operations.

title: WASHINGTON
description: When you look into President Nix on's proposals for changing the power structure in Washington, three things are fairly obvious: (1) He is right in saying that the present organization of the Federal Government is ineffi cient; (2) he has a powerful case for centralizing the Federal departments and agencies and for decentralizing the allocation of Federal funds through revenue sharing, though this looks like a contradiction; but (3) it is fairly clear that there is a fundamental con flict of principle both about reorgani zation of the Government and revenue sharing not only in the Congress, but within the Nixon Administration itself.

title: 2 Suspects Held in Flatbush Slayings
description: The police arrested two sus pects yesterday in two holdup murders that with another kill ing have spread fear among the elderly residents of a neighbor hood in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: Brandt Backs Britain on Period Of Transition on Market Rules
description: PARIS, Jan. 26Chancellor Willy Brandt came to the aid of Britain today by telling Pres ident Pompidou that the Brit ish, if admitted to the Common Market, ought to have an addi tional three years beyond a fiveyear transition period to adjust to the market's agricul tural regulations.

title: Penny Postal Card Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, introduced a bill today to bring back the penny postal card. He said that since postal, tele phone and telegraph rates had risen so high, the onecent card was needed to give the needy a means to communicate.

title: Pentagon Acknowledges That Americans Landed at Pnompenh Airport
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  The Defense Department ac knowledged today that 15 to 20 Americans in civilian clothes landed at Pnompenh airport last night to retrieve two damaged helicopters and take them back to South Vietnam for repairs. The men were disclosed to have been carrying sidearms.

title: List of ReadingAchievement Scores for Pupils in City School System
description: The following list shows last year's median reading achievement test scores for the city's elementary, inter mediate and Junior high schools, as reported by the Board of Education. Median means that 50 per cent of the pupils in the grade were above this score and 50 per cent below.

title: VATICAN ATTACKS U.S. ON BIRTH CURB
description: ROME, Jan. 26 (AP)The United States Government is the chief target of the Vatican's newest campaign against arti ficial contraception, and the United Nations is in second place.

title: U.S., SOUTH KOREA AGREE ON CUTBACK
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 26  Defense Minister Jung Nai Hiuk said today that an accord had been reached on the 20, 000man reduction of United States forces and an offsetting South Korean military modern ization program.

title: Park Ave. Gets a Nevelson Sculpture
description: A massive environmental steel sculpture by Louise Nevelson was lifted into place by crane yesterday at the Seagram Building Plaza, 375 Park Avenue between 52d and 53d Streets, where it will be on exhibit for the next six weeks.

title: The Black Legend of Spain
description: MADRIDSpaniards complain about their Black Legend abroad. They are the dogs of the Inquisition. They are cruel and perfidious.

title: Woman Robbed of Clocks
description: A 60yearold Queens woman was punched and robbed in her apartment last night by a man who gained entry by posing as a detective. Among the items taken from the victim, Pearl Feinstein of 4220 Kissena Boulevard in Flushing, were about 50 miniature antique clocks, the police said.

title: Europeans Deplore Move
description: PARIS, Jan. 26 (Agence FrancePresse)Horror was ex pressed in Europe today at news of the executions in Guinea.

title: Eastern Air Posts Profit
description: Eastern Airlines reported yes terday a $5.5million net profit for calendar 1970, but a fourth quarter net loss of $6.7millions In 1969 the carrier sustained a $2.3million loss for the full year, while reporting a fourth quarter loss of $52,000.

title: PENTAGON SEEKS MISSILE DEFENSE AROUND CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Defense Department has urged the White House to seek Con gressional authority to begin work on missile defense of the nation's capital, according to wellplaced officials.

title: Sports of The Times
description: No formal subtitle was offered for the documentary film of the World Series last October between the Baltimore Orioles and the Cincinnati Reds. But it seemed to be there nonetheless, written in golden letters and screaming its presence on the sound track. It penetrated consciousness as The Brooks Robinson Story.

title: DAYAN SAYS SYRIANS HAVE SAM MISSILES
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 26 (UPI) Defense Minister Moshe Dayan told the Israeli Parliament to day that Sovietbuilt SAM2 antiaircraft missiles were de ployed in Syria.

title: SCIENCE CONTACTS WITH ALL FAVORED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Sec retary of State William P. Rog ers told Congress today that it was American public policy to seek exchanges of technical data with the scientists of all countries, even those with which the United States had no dip lomatic relations.

title: Advertising:
description: It didn't take long for an experienced traveler like Caskie Stinnett to make the trip from Holiday magazine, where he was editor and publisher, to Travel & Leisure magazine, where he officially becomes editor in chief on Monday.

title: MRS. EMORY KLINEMAN
description: Mrs. Julia Stuhlberger Kline man, wife of Emory Klineman, retired chairman of Majestic Specialties, a sportswear con cern, died of a heart attack on Monday in St. Lucia in the Caribbean. She had been on a cruise aboard the Nieuw Am sterdam. Her age was 66 and she lived at 650 Park Avenue.

title: Food for Pets Found Above Human Standard
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Jan. 26 (UFI)  A scientist who has gained recognition for his studies of mercury levels in tuna and swordfish said today cats and dogs are far ing a lot better than people.

title: G.M. Lagging in Effort to Meet Safety and Clean Air Standards
description: MILFORD, Mich., Jan. 26  The General Motors Corpora tion said today that it was further behind in its effort to meet Federal safety and anti pollution standards than the company had previously indi cated.

title: Obote Is Free to Return, New Ugandan Chief Says
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Jan. 26 (Reuters)  Maj. Gen. Idi Amin, leader of the new mili tary Government in Uganda, said tonight that the deposed President, Milton Obote, was free to return to Uganda.

title: 6 Inmates at Auburn Indicted For Role in November Rioting
description: AUBURN, N. Y., Jan. 26 The Cayuga County grand jury yesterday indicted six inmates of Auburn State Prison in con nection with a riot last Nov. 4 in which 30 guards were held hostage for a day and prisoners took over most of the prison.

title: Ecuador Charges U.S. Aggression in Fishing Dispute and Urges Urgent Meeting of O.A.S. Ministers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Ecuador charged the United States today with aggression in the dispute over American tuna fishing boats seized by the Ecuadorean Navy and requested an emergency meeting of the hemisphere's foreign ministers for Friday.

title: MILLS DENOUNCES REVENUE SHARING AS INFLATION RISK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Representative Wilbur D. Mills denounced today President Nixon's proposal for unrestrict ed revenue sharing and pro posed alternative approaches to meeting the needs of states and cities for more money to finance essential public services.

title: NASA Aide Hails Feat
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 26George M. Low, acting ad ministrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Admin istration, issued a statement here today praising the Soviet Venus mission as a significant achievement.

title: Senate Panel Backs Morton to Replace Hickel at Interior
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Senate Interior Committee unanimously approved today President Nixon's nomination of Representative Rogers C. B. Morton, Republican of Mary land, to be Secretary of the Interior.

title: Bednarski Replaces Talts as Lift Champion
description: PARIS, Jan. 26 (AP)Two years after the event, Robert Bednarski of York, Pa., was recognized by the Interna tional Weight Lifting Federa tion today as the world heavyweight weightlifting champion for 1969, replac ing Ian Talts of the Soviet Union.

title: Sale of Police Information Brings Indictments Here
description: Eight private detective agen cies, six of their executives and two airlines were indicted here yesterday on charges of using bribery to obtain confi dential information from the Police Department.

title: PROXY FIGHT LOOMS AT GAF CORPORATION
description: A possible proxy fight is shaping up at the GAF Cor poration.

title: Bullets Win, 10398
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 26 (UPI) Earl Monroe and Jack Marin combined to score 47 points to night and Gus Johnson had 22 rebounds as the Baltimore Bul lets beat the San Francisco Warriors for their third straight victory, 10398.

title: Thieu Links Peace Candidates With Communists
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26  President Nguyen Van Thieu opened the South Viet nam presidential and legislative campaign today by indirectly linking peace candidates with the Communists and repeating his own hard line of victory over the Communists.

title: Lindsay Orders an Inquiry On Blackout Possibility
description: Mayor Lindsay ordered an in vestigation yesterday into the possibility of blackouts here next summer because of power failures.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: NORBERT LYONS DIES; A NEWSMAN, WAS 87
description: Norbert Lyons, a newspaper man and foreign correspondent, died in Lenox Hill Hospital on Sunday. He was 87 years old and lived at 350 East 77th Street.

title: PAUL SIEBEL SINGS AND PLAYS PROGRAM
description: Strumming a guitar and sing ing in a high, tight, nasal voice, Paul Siebel hovered between country, pop and protest song without really getting into any thing during his concert Mon day night at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

title: OILMEN GAIN HOPE ON LIBYAN TALKS
description: TRIPOLI, Jan. 26Pending the outcome of the current discussions in Teheran on oil prices, oil companies here are slightly more hopeful of avert ing a major crisis with the Libyan Government.

title: CITY WILL CLOSE SANITATION DEPOT
description: After an inspection de manded by the Uniformed Sani tationmen's Union, Jerome Kretchmer, the Acting Sani tation Commissioner, an nounced yesterday that the city would close a sanitation garage at 108th Street near First Ave nue. He said he had found it unsafe and unsanitary.

title: Pennsylvania Tax Gains
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 26 (AP)A proposed constitutional amendment to permit a gradu ated income tax in Pensylvania was approved today by the House Rules Committee. The proposal now goes before the entire House. To become law, it must pass two sessions of the General Assembly and then be voted upon by the electorate.

title: Phone Rates Go Up
description: The cost of persontoperson telephone calls between New York and Washington was raised 25 cents yesterday as rates also went up on other calls requiring operator assist ance, such as creditcard and collect calls.

title: Johnson Took Key Steps
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare noted today that the United States did not establish a Government familyplanning unit until 1966 and did not appropriate foreign aid funds for birth control pro grams until 1967, when Lyndon B. Johnson was President.

title: Leftist Authorities in Chile Denounce Judicial System
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 26 Chile's judicial system, from the Supreme Court to the low est district judgeship, is under fire from leftists in power here under President Salvador Al lende Gossens.
