description: In a report replete with de tails of leaking roofs and dilap idated rooms, of official con fusion and of teachers who sometimes refuse to teach, a special panel investigating the city's three juvenile detention centers recommended yesterday that their administration be transferred from the judicial system to the Mayor's office.

title: Point of View
description: THERE'S no such place as Africa! I was told not long ago by an official from East Africa, tired of the way people regarded the con tinent as an entity.

title: Prosecutor Stands Ready
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 28 (AP) Perry Dickinson, special state prosecutor at Kent, said the judge apparently doesn't feel a grand jury has any right to issue reports. He said he fore saw no trouble in prosecuting the cases as long as the indict ments stand.

title: Rankin Says He Practices Law, But Denies Conflict of Interest
description: Corporation Counsel J. Lee Rankin said yesterday that he had engaged in a limited private law practice since be coming the city's top lawyer in 1966.

title: An Old Scenario in Cambodia
description: History is repeating itself in Southeast Asia. The in sidious insertion of American military power into Cam bodia in support of a faltering regime ominously paral lels the events of early 1965 which entrapped the United States in a major war in neighboring Vietnam.

title: Johnston and Eichelberger Share San Diego Golf Lead on 6UnderPar 66's
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 28Ralph Johnston, a rookie on the pro golf tour from New York scored an amazing 66 in the opening round of the $150,000 Andy Williams San Diego open tour ney today.

title: Tunisians Search for Liberalized Solutions
description: TUNIS  Tunisians are searching for more liberal methods to solve their politi cal and economic problems in the years ahead..

title: Congo: Prosperity Comes to Kinshasa
description: KINSHASA, the Congo The recent vigorous expan sion of the Congolese econ omy reached a high point last year as copper production and exports set records.

title: Patriots Choose Plunkett as No. 1 in College Draft, Spurning Trade Offers
description: The Boston Patriots picked Jim Plunkett of Stanford first in the National Football League draft yesterday, spurning trade offers right up to 9:50 A.M., 10 minutes before the selec tion of 442 college players be gan.

title: For Gambia, Austerity and Sunbathing Bring Rewards
description: BATHURST, Gambia  Shortly after proclaiming Gambia a republic last April, Sir Dauda Jawara, former premier and new president, announced that his Govern ment would defer, for an other year or two, the estab lishment of a permanent mis sion to the United Nations.

title: Veeck Quits as Head Of Suffolk Downs Track
description: BOSTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) Bill Veeck said tonight he had resigned as president of the Suffolk Downs race track.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Whoever came up with the idea un questionably was an old  time Brooklyn fan with a soft spot in his heart for those delightful Dodgers of an almost forgotten era when the once beloved Bums were known as the Daffiness Boys. At any rate, someone with nostalgic yearnings per suaded the Sports Lodge of B'nai B'rith to reassemble a batch of old Dodgers as honored guests for the annual dinner last Saturday.

title: At Last, Egypt's Mighty Dam
description: CAIROThe mighty Aswan High Dam has finally been completed after 11 years of toil by Egyptians and Russians in the heat of Upper Egypt. Its 12 Sovietsupplied turbines stand ready to generate a total of 10 billion kilowatt hours of electricity annually. And the Nile has filled Lake Nasser to about half of its ultimate capacity of 157 billion cubic meters, assuring Egypt of a steady flow of water for its irrigated fields.

title: Power Crisis
description: The past two weeks have proved that New York City's electric power problems are not confined to the summer when air conditioners are turned up to maximum per formance. Four times in the last few days Con Edison and other New York State power companies have had to reduce voltages as their resources proved inadequate to meet the demands generated by the intense cold weather.

title: Litton Gets Destroyer Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) The Navy today awarded Lit ton Systems, Inc., of Pasca goula, Miss., a $357.8million modification of a contract for construction of six ships of a new class of destroyers.

title: LOUIS HEMSEY GIVES RECITAL ON GUITAR
description: Louis Hemsey, a 22yearold guitarist and a graduate of the Mannes College of Music, gave a recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night. His prograin included Britten's Nocturnal, an arrangement of Bach's Chaconne in D minor for unaccompanied violin, pa vanes by Milan, a suite by John Duarte, preludes by VillaLobos and Turina's Rafaga.

title: Butazolidin Gives a Lift To Santa Anita Favorites
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan 28 The horses are running slightly more to form in the early part of the Santa Anita season this year and the Cal ifornia Horse Racing Board thinks Butazolidin may have something to do with it.

title: Algeria Relying on Oil to Spur Economy
description: PARIS  Algeria has be come one of the leaders of the campaign by the oilpro ducing nations to Increase their share of benefit from oil extraction and sales.

title: U.N. Is Reported Planning Plea on CeaseFire
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 28Secretary General Thant and Dr. Gunnar V. Jar ring, his special representative for the Middle East, were re ported today to be preparing a public statement asserting that the indirect ArabIsraeli peace talks had begun satisfac torly and must be continued

title: $40Million Loss Reported by UAL
description: UAL, Inc., the holding com pany that owns United Air Lines, Inc., reported yester day that it had incurred $40,877,000 consolidated net loss for 1970, on the basis of preliminary unaudited results.

title: Union Carbide Chairman to Retire in April
description: Birny Mason Jr. announced yesterday that he planned to retire as chairman and chief executive officer of the Union Carbide Corporation and that F. Perry Wilson, president, would succeed him in both posts, effective after the company's annual meeting April 21.

title: TV: Miller's A Memory of Two Mondays Shown
description: In the spoken preface to his play A Memory of Two Mondays, put on last night by National Education Tele vision over Channel 13, Arthur Miller remarked that he doesn't share the nostalgia for the thirties that he finds cropping up now among the young, who never lived through those times. I don't wish them on anybody, he says.

title: Market Place: Bond Fund Set For Big Board
description: What's that you say? Bonds trading on the Big Board's main floor? Yes, that's right. Starting this morning, inves tors will be buying and sell ing shares in the American General Bond Funda $45 million closedend fund with a portfolio bursting with fixedinterest securities.

title: CONDUCT OF JUDGE TO BE SCRUTINIZED
description: The Court on the Judiciary will be convened this year to investigate the judicial conduct of State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer.

title: J. & L. Registers a Loss
description: The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, the sixth largest American steel producer, which is 81 per cent owned by LingTemcoVought, Inc., re ported yesterday that it sustained a net loss  count ing nonrecurring charges of $19.7million in the final quarter of 1970.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Protecting G.L's, Agnew Says
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 28 (AP) Vice President Agnew said today United States aid to Cam bodia was designed primarily to protect American troops in South Vietnam as President Nixon's troop withdrawal time table continues.

title: DepartmentStore Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  The Department of Commerce reported today that depart mentstore sales for the week ended Jan. 23 were an esti mated total of $571million, an increase of 14 per cent above the $502,000,000 in sales for the corresponding week of last the $502million in sales for the latest week were estimated at $6.431billion, an increase of 8 per cent above the $5.98 billion in sales for the year earlier week.

title: China Helping a Desert Nation
description: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania The Mauritanian economy Improved solidly in 1970 and hopes run high for this year.

title: Africa: Ferment for Better Life
description: ACCRA, GhanaTake a walk through any African city, visit its markets. In an hour you will learn more about why there is such a strong urge for development in Africa than from any long study of the latest fiveyear plans.

title: Joblessness Plagues Kenya
description: NAIROBI, KenyaOfficial predictions that Kenya's eco nomic growth would exceed 7 per cent in 1970 seemed at midyear to be overly optimis tic, but Government officials now believe that the goal was met and are pleased by prospects for this year.

title: Libya's Young Leaders Stir Turbulence in Oil Industry
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The in ternational oil industry Lis in for a turbulent experience in 1971, and the revolutionary military Government of Libya is largely responsible.

title: World's Recession Jolts Sierra Leone
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone A slump in diamond mar kets, one of the relatively minor effects of the eco nomic slowdown in the United States and elsewhere in the developed world, is threatening a major economic setback for this small West African country.

title: Vigilance in Moscow
description: Soviet thugs who are almost certainly secret police agents have exacerbated SovietAmerican relations by employing violence against two American correspondents in Moscow, James R. Peipert of the Associated Press and Anthony Astrachan of The Washington Post. In both cases the KGB hoodlums acted when the Americans involved met Soviet friends, suggesting strongly that the incidents were planned with the help of information gained by wiretapping.

title: Maria Callas to Discuss Opera Here Next Week
description: Maria Callas will make her first nonsinging appearance on a New York stage next week during a visit to the Juilliard School at Lincoln Center. On Wednesday, at 4 P.M., the soprano will discuss opera and related musical subjects in the Juilliard Theater and will answer questions from the audience at the end of the session.

title: Belfast's Rightists Fail To Oust ChichesterClark
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 28 (AP)Prime Minister James ChichesterClark defeat ed attempts by rightists in his Unionist party to unseat him. A heated 12hour debate today in the provincial parliament end ed with a 297 vote rejecting what amounted to a motion of no confidence in the Govern ment's ability to maintain law and order.

title: Executive Changes
description: PrenticeHall, Inc., in Englewood Cliffs, N. J., announced yesterday the election of Richard Pren tice Ettinger, chairman and cofounder, to the post of chairman emeritus. He was succeeded by Paul R. Andrews as chairman. Frank J. Dunnigan, ex ecutive vice president, was appointed to replace Mr. Andrews as president and chief executive officer. Howard M. Warrington, group vice presi dent, was made executive vice president and Robert D. Hess, controller, was elected to the additional post of treasurer.

title: Financial Writers'
description: John J. Concannon, an as sistant editor of Newsweek, has been elected president of the New York Financial Writers' Association. He succeeds Leon ard Sloane, a business and fi nancial reporter of The New York Times.

title: Detroit Widower, 61, Is Winner Of $ 1Million New York Lottery
description: A 61 yearold Detroit widow er won the top prize yester day in the second special $1 million New York State lottery.

title: Thaw With France Is Welcome in Rabat
description: RABAT  Two major po litcal events of 1970 will have a major impact this year on the Moroccan economy: the election of a new Parliament for a sixyear term and the comple normalization of relations with France.

title: Customs Accord Aids 3 Nations
description: JOHANNESBURG, South AfricaThe growing eco nomic role in southern Africa of the three former British territories of Swaziland, Bot swana and Lesotho was rec ognized last year by the signing of a revised customs agreement between the three countries and South Africa.

title: VENETIAN BRASS PLAYS AT HUNTER
description: Much Venetian music of the late Renaissance was meant to be played antiphonally, which is to say by instrumental groups divided into opposing bands facing off across town squares or church interiors. So, one's ears picked up at the start of Wednesday night's concert at the Hunter College Playhouse when four members of the Ve netian Brass performed from the stage and four others from the balcony in a Giovanni Gabrieli Canzona.

title: Makarova Wins Suit Ta Enter Apartment And Get Her Shoes
description: Natalia Makarova, the Soviet ballerina who defected to the West last September and is now dancing with the Ameri can Ballet Theater, won a State Supreme Court order yesterday to enable her to reenter her Park Avenue apartment and get her costumes and ballet shoes.

title: WELFARE FAMILY HAS $54,080 RENT.
description: A welfare family of 13 is be ing housed in four rooms at a Bronx motel at a yearly rate of $54,080.

title: JAZZ IS PRESENTED BY JIMMY RUSHING
description: Applying the term jazz sing er to a performer is one of the easier ways to start an argu ment. But there is never any doubt about Jimmy Rushing.

title: U.S. Admiral Directed Mekong Fuel Convoy
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (UPI)A South Viet namese convoy in which fuel ships were escorted to Pnom penh was organized and com manded by radio by an Amer ican admiral, allied military sources said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nebraska College Closing
description: BEATRICE, Neb., Jan, 28 (AP) Students at financially troubled Pershing College were told today to vacate their dor mitories by tomorrow because the private school is being of ficially closed. It went into operation five years ago.

title: MGM Says Profit In 2d Fiscal Quarter Will Register Gain
description: CULVER CITY, Calif., Jan. 28  MetroGoldwynMayer, Inc., will improve its profits in the second fiscal quarter and remain profitable throughout the year, James T. Aubrey Jr., president, told the annual meet ing of stockholders here today.

title: PRESIDENT URGES MILITARY PAY RISE TO HELP END DRAFT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 President Nixon asked Congress today to approve $1.5billion in pay increases and other benefits for servicemen to help achieve his goal of ending the military draft by mid1973.

title: Patriots Look to Plunkett To Help Fill New Arena
description: The Boston Patriots, look ing for a future hero to help fill their new stadium in suburban Foxboro, Mass., are going to hold on to Jim Plunkett, their new gem they acquired at the top of the National Football . League draft yesterday.

title: Judge Rules Jury Report On Kent Strife Is Illegal
description: CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 28  United States District Court Judge William K. Thomas ruled illegal today a report by the Portage County grand jury on the disorders last May at Kent State University.

title: Sterling Drug Net Shows Rise; National Distillers Posts Drop
description: Sterling Drug, Inc., in a pre liminary report, said yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1970 totaled $15, 825,000, or 41 cents a share, an improvement of 12.3 per cent over a net of $14,087,000, or 37 cents, in the 1969 quarter.

title: NADER IS ASSAILED BY HESTER OF N.Y.U.
description: James M. Hester, president of New York University, criti cized Ralph Nader yesterday for attacking him because he had remained a member of the board of directors of the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: MRS. HARRIS A. DUNN
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Jan. 28 Mrs. Harris Ashton Dunn, the widow of the former vice presi dent of the Bowery Savings Bank, died here yesterday at a nursing home. She was 88 years old.

title: Emanuel R. Freedman
description: A Richard Harding Davis or Vincent Sheean wins re nown for the flamboyance of his journalistic achieve ments, part of a glamorous tradition in which the corre spondent often outshines the story. Emanuel R. Freed man was of a very different school of journalism, less spectacular but indispensable to intelligent public under standing of a world in chaotic transition.

title: Agnew Visits Truman in Hospital
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo,, Jan. 28 (UPI)  Vice President Agnew met Harry S. Truman for the first time today in the 86yearold former Presi dent's hospital room. Mr. Ag new described Mr. Truman as alert and very relaxed.

title: GEORGE WARREN, BANKING OFFICIAL
description: George Earle Warren, who retired in 1947 as a vice presi dent of what is now the Chase Manhattan Bank but continued until last spring as clerk of the trustees of Columbia Uni versity, died yesterday after a sudden illness in Clearwater, Fla., where he had been making his annual visit.

title: Postwar Nigeria: Twice the Oil
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  The postwar recovery of Nige ria's booming oil industry is complete, according to year end statistics and insiders' evaluations here.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ROME, Jan. 28 (AP)The head of the Vatican's Peace and Justice Commission called upon Guinea today to grant clemency to those sentenced to death. The plea followed by a day an attack by Pope Paul VI on Guinea for public hangings that he termed a blind and wicked vendetta.

title: MISS DREXEL FIRST IN DOWNHILL SKI
description: PRA LOUP, France, Jan. 28 (AP)  Austria's Alpine mar vels raced back to form today with a 12 finish in the 12 nation World Cup women's downhill ski competition.

title: Panel Urges Concession to Win MIRV Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28A prestigious Administration ad visory panel has reportedly, urged President Nixon to make a new effort to reach agree ment with the Soviet Union on banning multiple warhead mis siles by dropping the American demand for onsite inspection to check Soviet compliance.

title: Barnstorming Mrs. Gandhi Brings Out Crowds, Not All Cheering
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 28  Prime Minister Indira Gandhi sits in the back of her convert ible as it speeds along the Faizabad  Gorakhpur highway in Uttar Pradesh on the way to an election meeting at Mani ram.

title: Gabon Exploiting Wealth
description: LIBREVILLE, Gabon The Frenchspeaking African re public of Gabon entered the 1970's with the scales loaded heavily in her favor.

title: Mobil Is Fined $150,000
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 28 (AP)Federal District Court Judge James A. Cotnisky fined the Mobil Oil Corporation $150,000 today for failing to have safety devices on oil wells in the Gulf of Mexico. The company had been charged in connection with the operation of eight wells from October 1969 to 1970.

title: East Germans Set Congress
description: BERLIN, Jan. 28The ruling Socialist Unity (Communist) party of East Germany has scheduled its party congress, the eighth, for June 14 to 19, it was announced today.

title: MRS. JULIAN GOLDMAN
description: Mrs. Lillian Levy Goldman of 2 East 86th Street, wife of Julian Goldman, president of the Goldman Stores Corpora tion and donor of the bridge trophy that bears his name, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. She was 70 years old.

title: Modernity Edging Into Ethiopia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia Record coffee earnings last year and the current harvest of bumper food crops have brought a relative brightening of development prospects for Ethiopia, the oldest of Africa's independent countries.

title: Bruins Down Flyers, 62, and Lead Rangers by 5 Points
description: BOSTON, Jan. 28 (UPI)Ken Hodge and Fred Stanfield scored consecutive powerplay goals tonight and Don Marcotte add ed a shorthanded tally to pace the Boston Bruins to a 62 vic tory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Ewbank's Selection Is Riggins, a Big Kansas U. Back
description: When the Jets' turn de veloped in the first round of the National Football League draft, their primary choice, J. D. Hill of Arizona State, had been selected by the Buffalo Bills. Presumably, the Jets now would choose John Brockington, the big run ning back from Ohio State.

title: Man in the News
description: When Dr. James G. Emer son Jr., was named to head the Community Service So ciety in 1969, he said his first job would be to see how the familyservice agency could best contribute to the city.

title: Lisbon's Colonies: More Autonomy?
description: LISBON  Premier Mar cello Caetano's offer of great er autonomy to Portugal's colonies has opened new eco nomic as well as political perspectives, particularly for the two vast and potentially wealthy African territories of Angola and Mozambique.

title: CASSESE SAYS CITY AGREED ON PARITY
description: John S. Cassese, former presi dent of the Patrolmen's Benev olent Association, testified in State Supreme Court yesterday that the P.B.A. reached a final, absolute agreement with the city on Jan. 29, 1969, and that it contained a parity adjustment provision without any condi tions or qualifications.

title: GOVERNOR HAILS MALL IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28  Stung by criticism of the massive South Mall state office building proj ect, Governor Rockefeller de clared today that the mall is going to turn out to be the greatest thing that has hap pened to this country in 100 years.

title: Advertising:
description: From now on, gang, if you want to do business with MAGI'S MAILSAVE Match and Purge Duplication Iden tification Services, get in touch with its new repre sentative, Dependable Mail ing Lists, 425 Park Avenue South.

title: In Egypt, Attention Turns to the Common Man
description: CAIRO  For the Egyptian people burdened by the costs and casualties of warfare with Israel, 1970 brought a respite through a ceasefire along the Suez Canal and, impor tantly, promises of a new period of attention to the eco nomic and social needs of the common man.

title: Nyerere Is Critical
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Jan. 28 (Agence FrancePresse) President Julius K. Nyerere to day described the coup in neighboring Uganda as an act of treason to the whole course of African progress and free dom.

title: Brandt Spurs East Germans on Detente
description: BONN, Jan. 28Chancellor Willy Brandt called on the leaders of East Germany today to stop trying to undermine his policy of seeking improved relations with the Soviet bloc and to help set an example for the outside world of two friendly but contrasting states.

title: U.S. Warns Newark to Cut Housing Waste or Lose Aid
description: NEWARK, Jan. 28A team of Federal housing spe cialists charged today that the Newark Housing Authority was topheavy with superfluous employes and wastefulin its management of this city's public housing and ur ban renewal programs.

title: Milk Is Growing Business in Nigeria
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  When the tropical sun here sends the afternoon temperature up into the 90's, a common sight is a cluster of brightly dressed Nigerians standing around a street vender's bi cycle drinking cold milk out of halfpint cartons that were printed in Chicago.

title: Biafra Plods Hard Road Back From Devastation
description: ENUGU, NigeriaAfter be ing closed for nearly three years because of Nigeria's civil war, the Permatex Spin ning and Weaving Company here is back in business.

title: U.S. WAR DEATHS INCREASE IN WEEK
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP)The United States command today reported an increase in American casual ties in Indochina last week, and spokesmen attributed the rise largely to two plane crashes that killed 14 servicemen.

title: Dr. Frank A. Thornton, City College Economist
description: GARNERVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 28Dr. Frank A. Thornton, a former Federal mediator and assistant professor of econom ics at City College in New York, died today at his home here. He was 72 years old.

title: Mencken's Letters Displayed Today
description: The correspondence of H. L. Mencken, the satirist, wit, iconoclast and confirmed enemy of what he called boobus Americanus, will be made available to scholars for the first time today when the New York Public Library lifts the seal binding the material since his death 15 years ago.

title: Bloomingdale's to Build Garden City Store
description: Bloomingdale's, the Man hattan  based department store chain, announced yes terday that it would erect 250,000squarefoot store in Garden City, L. I., to open in fall 1972. It will be only two blocks from a branch store of Abraham & Straus, which, like Bloomingdale's, is owned by Federated Department Stores, Inc., of Cincinnati.

title: Merger News
description: Skaggs Companies, Inc., has started preliminary discussions to acquire Albertson's, Inc., operators of more than 200 supermarkets, through an ex change of stock valued at ap proximately $103million based on the closing price of Skaggs yesterday. Both companies noted yesterday that negotia tions were at a very early stage but preliminary discussions are based on a pro posal for a 5 per cent stock dividend to Skaggs stockholders that would be an exchange of two shares of Skaggs for each three shares of Albertson's.

title: CHESTER M'CUTCHEON
description: HOHOKUS, N. J., Jan. 28 Chester S. McCutcheon, a re tired executive of the Bell Tele phone Company, died yesterday in Valley Hospital, Ridgewood. He was 73 years old and lived at 120 Blauvelt Avenue.

title: Morton Is Confirmed As Interior Secretary
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI)By unanimous voice vote and with fewer than a dozen members present, the Senate confirmed today the nomination of former Repre sentative Rogers C. B. Mor ton to be President Nixon's new interior Secretary.

title: JAIL FIGHT DELAYS PANTHERS' TRIAL
description: The trial of 13 Black Pan thers in State Supreme Court here was delayed an hour and a half yesterday because of an altercation in jail between sev eral of the defendants and Cor rection Department guards.

title: GUINEAN IS ADAMANT ON DEATH SENTENCES
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Jan. 28 (Reuters)President Sekou Tour of Guinea has refused to spare those condemned to death for having taken part in last November's abortive coup, the Conakry radio reported today.

title: Oil Companies Drop Demand for a Global Accord
description: LONDON, Jan. 28Western oil companies dropped their de mand for a global price agree ment with producer countries today, according to oil industry sources and news reports, but found stiff conditions attached to even a regional agreement covering the Persian Gulf.

title: Laver Wins From Ashe For 7th Victory in Row
description: Arthur Ashe paid Rod Laver the supreme tribute last night after the redhaired Australian had won his seventh straight $10,000 match in the $210,000 Tennis Champions Classic.

title: 21 SEIZED IN SITIN AT OFFICES OF A. &P.
description: Twentyone persons, includ ing a number of clergymen, were arrested last night when they refused to obey a court order to end their occupation of the executive offices of the A. & P. food store chain at 420 Lexington Avenue.

title: Some May Keep Jobs
description: KAMPALA, Jan. 28 Gen eral Amin is surrounded by of ficials who worked closely with Mr. Obote and is planning to use several ministers from the Obote Cabinet.

title: History of Social Service Agency
description: The Community Service Society is an outgrowth of a social agency formed in 1848, the Association for Improv ing the Condition of the Poor. From the outset, the theme of its work was help for the individual and counseling for the family.

title: 500 Police Give Farewell Salute To Patrolman Slain in Brooklyn
description: It was exactly 10:05 A.M. yesterday when the hearse bearing the body of Patrolman Robert Bolden, shield No. 20025, stopped in front of the small Baptist church in Brooklyn.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28In a seemingly routine press re lease issued late yesterday, the Office of Education announced the appointment of an acting director of the Teacher Corps, which sends 3,000 young teach ers to help out in schools in poor communities across the country. In fact, the announce ment constituted a bold salvo in a high  level, three cornered internal struggle over the shape and direc tion of the new national service corps, which President Nixon proposed two weeks ago. Cou pled with other recent develop ments, the press release offers a rare look at how bureaucra cies wage war.

title: ROGERS ASSURES SENATORS ON ROLE IN CAMBODIA WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  Secretary of State William P. Rogers assured a restive Sen ate Foreign Relations Commit tee today that the Administra tion had no intention of expand ing the scope of American mili tary activities in Cambodia.

title: Athlete Pleads Guilty
description: BOSTON, Jan. 28 (AP)Rich Johnson, formerly with the Bos ton Celtics of the National Bas ketball Association and now with the Carolina Cougars of thte American Basketball Asso ciation, pleaded guilty today to a charge of passing a counter feit bill. Federal District Court Judge W. Arthur Garritt Jr. continued the case for two weeks.

title: Council Group Votes Taxi Bill, But Full Passage Is Delayed
description: A City Council committee yesterday approved a package of taxicab legislation, including a fare increase that would come to $41million a year and the setting up of a regulatory commission for medallion cabs and forhire limousines.

title: VOLPE ENLARGES RAILPAX SYSTEM
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Sec retary of Transportation John A. Volpe issued today a final outline of basic rail passenger service to be operated by a quasigovernmental corporation beginning May 1.

title: The Nixon Plan Makes Sense
description: WASHINGTONThe President's pro posal to reorganize eight of the Cab inet departments into four depart mentshuman resources, community development, natural resources, and economic developmentwill raise the hackles of virtually every special in terest group in Washington.

title: SmallBoat Fan Finds Inflation Can Be Fun
description: In more and more cases, looking for a dreamboat means looking for a boat that floats on air.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE GERMAN DICTATORSHIP. The Origins, Structure, and Effects of National Social ism. By Karl Dietrich Bracher. Translated from the German by Jean Steinber. With an Introduction by Peter Gay. 553 pages. Praeger. $13.95.

title: In Gold, All's Well, But for Platinum
description: JOHANNESBURG, South AfricaGold is the backbone of South Africa's mining in dustry, and the opinion here is that the international monetary crisis of the last two years has helped the na tion's gold industry.

title: SIBERIAN TROUPE BUBBLES IN DEBUT
description: If you think you have seen Russian virtuoso dancers up to now, take another look at a new folk group, the Siberian Dancers and Singers of Omsk, which opened for 12 perform ances last night at Carnegie Hall.

title: Estimate Board Votes Zoning For Artists in the SoHo Area
description: Art is, after all, a devel oped tastelike eating olives, Assemblyman Louis DeSalvio told the Board of Estimate yes terday as he took issue with a provision of the new zoning being created for artists in 43block area south of Houston Street.

title: A 3YEAR LICENSE FOR TEACHERS ASKED
description: Dr. John H. Fischer, president of Teachers College, Columbia University, advocated yesterday a plan for the state licensing of the city's public school teach ers, under which they would have to prove their competency at least twice during their ca reers. He said he did not favor the present tenure for life.

title: Colson Beats Dugan to Win Intercollegiate Tennis Final
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Jan. 28Billy Colson of Princeton justified his standing as the East's No. 1 college tennis player today by winning the Concord Hotel's fourth annual intercollegiate indoor tourna ment.

title: Student Editors Report Nixon Plans Troop Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Eleven college newspaper editors discussed American policy in Indochina with Sec retary of State William P. Rogers today and, in an un expected 15minute meeting, with President Nixon at the White House this afternoon.

title: MRS. ROBERT AMORY
description: Mrs. Leonore Cobb Amory, wife of Robert Amory, a re tired vice president of Springs Mills Inc., textiles, died Wednesday at the Oakwood Home in Manchester, Mass. Her age was 85.

title: LEFRAK SETTLES U.S. SUIT ON BIAS
description: The Department of Justice and Samuel J. Lefrak, one of the nation's largest builders, reached an agreement yester day in which the Lefrak Orga nization promised to prohibit discrimination in apartment rentals.

title: First Vote of Tariff Aide Is Against Import Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 A new member of the Tariff Com mission cast his first vote to day, and it was against an im port restriction.

title: THE CAGE IS DANCED BY MISS KIRKLAND
description: The Cage, a protowomen's lib ballet featuring an ingenue, earning her fangs, was danced Wednesday evening for the first time by Gelsey Kirkland as the Novice. The work, long a staple of New York City Ballet's repertory, was prodded interestingly by Miss Kirk land's virulent spontaneity as the girl learning to destroy the male she loved as well as the one she didn't love.

title: Samuel Gottscho, Photographer, Dies
description: Samuel H. Gottscho of 15035 86th Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, a leading photographer of gar dens and flowers, domestic and wild, for half a century, died yesterday in Parkway Hospital a few days short of his 96th birthday on Feb. 8.

title: Japanese Movement Seen In Talks on Import Quotas
description: The Japanese have begun to show some degree of flexibility in their attitude toward United States import quotas, Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, said here last night.

title: College Helps Veterans
description: AMHERST, Mass., Jan. 28 (UPI)The University of Mas sachusetts announced new ad mittance plans today for stu dents who have served in the armed forces during the Viet nam war. The school said it would accept veterans with lower than average scores on scholastic aptitude tests and would overlook poor grades re corded prior to military service.

title: Linda Bardo Wed to Roger Poor
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 28 Miss Linda Ethel Bardo and Roger Merrill Poor were married this afternoon in the Princeton University Chapel. The Rev. Dr. Ernest Gordon, dean of the chapel, performed the nondenominational cere mony.

title: NaderRaiding No Plush Job
description: WASHINGTON  Samuel Simon works for a secre tive monklike bachelor who frowns on hard liquor, cigar ettes, bridge, suburbanites staring at television and other frivolous activities.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES RECORD DECLINES
description: Wide fluctuations continue to dominate soybean trading. At one point, prices for the beans were down almost 3 cents a bushel yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE MILITARY ESTABLISHMENT. Its Impacts on American Society. By Adam Yarmolin sky. 434 pages. Harper & Row. $10.

title: Moskill Names 2 Officials
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 28 (UPI) Gov. Thomas J. Meskill today named his Commissioners of Public Works and of Taxes. He picked the Mayor of Milford, Edward J. Kozlowski, for the public works position and sent his name to the State Senate for confirmation. F. George Brown, a Bridgeport business man and Republican district leader, was Governor Meskill's choice for Tax Commissioner.

title: Nationalization In Sudan Rolls On
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Po litically and economically, Sudan maintained its leftist trend in 1970.

title: African Airlines Go TransAtlantic
description: In airline boardrooms from one end of the African con tinent to the other, 1971 is expected to be an exciting and challenging year for the carriers that make their bases south of the Mediterranean.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Discussion
description: GANVIE, DahomeyAlthough still in the early stages of economic development, Dahomey has learned that technological gains some times pose ecological problems.

title: Gomulka, Ill, Unlikely to Speak to Party
description: WARSAW, Jan. 28  A medical report indicating a worsening of Wladyslaw Gom ulka's illness has ended specu lation that the former Com munist party chief might seek to defend himself at a forth coming meeting of the Central Committee.

title: Wings, Blues in 11 Tie
description: DETROIT, Jan. 28 (UPI) Frank St. Marseille and Ren Leclerc scored offsetting goals in the first two periods tonight and the Detroit Red Wings gained their first point against St. Louis this season in a 11 tie with the Blues.

title: BOUNTY PROPOSED TO REDUCE REFUSE
description: The city's Environmental Pro tection Administrator, Jerome Kretchmer, proposed yesterday that the growing garbage prob lem here be eased through taxes on, and incentives for the return of, bottles, jars and sim ilar packaging.

title: City Studying Proposal to Close Parts Of Broadway and 2 Avenues as Malls
description: The Lindsay administration is weighing a plan to decon gest midtown Manhattan by closing portions of Broadway and Madison and Lexington Avenues to automobile traffic and making them permanent pedestrian malls.

title: Bribing of 3 Pennsylvania Officials for Cable TV Right Laid to Teleprompter
description: A Federal indictment charged here yesterday that the Tele prompter Corporation obtained an exclusive cable television franchise by bribing the Mayor and two other officials of Johnstown, Pa.

title: Washington Notes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 President Nixon's busy court ship of Congressmen from both parties this week is without precedent in his Administration. It arises both from the importance he at taches to his domestic pro gram and from the new open door approach to Congress brought to the White House by former Repre sentative Clark MacGregor of Minnesota, now Mr. Nixon's top adviser on Congressional affairs. Yet despite the Presi dent's more frequent contacts with key Congressional lead ers, he is under no illusion that warm bipartisan appeal will, by itself, be enough to sell his revenuesharing and Federal reorganization plans to a skeptical andin the case of Representative Wil bur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, chairman of the Ways and Means Commit teedownright hostile Con gress.

title: 1930's Again? Both Dior and Courreges Turn Clock Back
description: PARIS, Jan. 28  Fashion is waking up from one of its nightmares, and the House of Dior is certainly contributing to the new feeling of well being.

title: Indebted Ghana Gaining
description: ACCRA, GhanaAlthough still burdened by the heavy debts inherited from the gov ernment of Kwame Nkrumah, Ghana made encouraging progress last year toward the goal of again becoming one of West Africa's most pros perous countries.

title: A.C.L.U. Doubts Fair Trial
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 28 (UPI)  The American Civil Liber ties Union, which filed the suit challenging the report and is defending several of those in dicted, said today that it doubt ed whether a fair trial was now possible.

title: Korean's Home Bombed
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 28 A homemade bomb exploded last night at the home of the opposition presidential candi date, Kim Dae Jung, who is visiting Washington with his wife.

title: A Mining Infant Grows Up
description: WINDHOEK, South  West Africa  Mining, the infant prodigy of SouthWest Afri ca's economy in the sixties is an infant no longer. The industry has expanded rapid ly since 1966 when the World Court dismissed an Ethiopian suit challenging South Afri ca's League of Nation's man date over SouthWest Africa.

title: Magazine Writers Elect
description: The election, of Jhan Robbins, of Roxbury, Conn., as president of the Society of Magazine Writers was announced yester day. Mr. Robbins, who is a visiting professor of journalism at the University of Bridgeport, collaborates with his wife, June, in writing of magazine articles. He served as president of the society 10 years ago.

title: Uganda's New Ruler Releases 55 Political Prisoners
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Jan. 28 (Reuters)Uganda's new ruler, Maj. Gen. Idi Amin, today freed 55 political prisoners, dismissed the Cabinet of the ousted Pres ident, Milton Obote, and im posed a temporary ban on po litical activities.

title: South Africa Sees The Boom Is Past
description: JOHANNESBURG, South AfricaDespite a labor shortage, a growing balance of payments deficit, rising living costs and the threat of inflation, South Africa's economy showed a healthy growth in 1970 and Govern ment officials say the coun try can look to the future with confidence.

title: Mrs. Elias Lieberman, 74, Biology Teacher, Is Dead
description: Mrs. Dorothy Shapiro Lieber man, widow of Elias Lieberman, a prominent labor lawyer here, died Tuesday of a heart ailment in Hollandale, Fla. She was 74 years old and lived at 860 Fifth Avenue.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Change and revolution are generally supposed to be two of the most painful proc esses in human experience, but most of the talk in Washington now is about painless change and painless revolution.

title: Dance: A Century Short
description: In most of Maurice B Jart's work, even the worst, there is usually a shrewd kind of theatricality. In Messe Pour Le Temps Pre sent, which was given its United States premiere Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, there seemed to be no qual ity at all to redeem or even mitigate the boring, preten tious pomposity of a work that was numbing in its intentions and excruciating in its execution.

title: RABBIS REBUTTED ON AID TO SCHOOLS
description: A group of national and lo cal Jewish organizations reaf firmed their opposition yester day to state aid for religious education, saying that such aid posed a grave threat to the independence of religion and the stability of government.

title: Committees Discuss Plans As Pony Club Parley Opens
description: The 17th annual convention of the United States Pony Clubs got under way yesterday at the Plaza Hotel with 11 com mittees in session.

title: Letter From a Saigon Prison
description: The following letter was handwritten inside a South Vietnamese Government jail on Dec. 21 and smuggled out shortly thereafter. It is signed by three monks, representing some 500 of different re ligions, who are mainly imprisoned for their refusal to bear arms.

title: U.A.W. MAINTAINS A JERSEY SUBURB KEEPS OUT POOR
description: NEWARK, Jan. 28  The United Auto Workers and the National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing filed a complaint here today charging that local zoning laws are de priving union membersmany of them lowincome blacks from living near their jobs at the Ford Motor Company as sembly plant in Mahwah.

title: Court Issues Rules on Right of Poor to Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  The Supreme Court instructed all Federal magistrates today that they do not have to in form defendants in petty cases that defense lawyers will be furnished by the Govern ment if they are too poor to hire their own counsel.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: GAC Cuts Dividend
description: The GAC Corporation an nounced last night that it had cut its dividend for the fourth quarter to 20 cents a common share, compared with 37 cents the preceding year. The dividend is payable March 15 to stockholders of record Feb. 16. S. Hayward Wills, chair man, said that it appears that GAC will show substantially reduced earnings for 1970, compared with 1969.

title: U.S. Role in Route 4 Drive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, San. 28  The United States command made public today a general summary of American involvement in last week's joint CambodianSouth Viet namese operation to clear Route 4 south of Pnompenh but refused when asked to provide a specific count of American bombing strikes or other air missions.

title: U.S. Teams Out of Uniform To Check Aid in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 28The United States military teams that are to move through Cambodia to check on the use of American military aid are to travel in civilian clothes with instructions to remain out of combat areas, official sources said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In his essay Did Jesus Marry? [OpEd Jan. 20], William E. Phipps takes a potshot at the cherished be lief of a Jesus, celibate and virginal, hoping to bring down the Catholic Church's position on celibacy and virginity.

title: MISS HOGAN TAKES DEFEAT TO HEART
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 28 (AP)  Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., stomped off the court in anger today after losing a close match to Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia in the quar terfinals of the Victorian tennis championships.

title: Bridge: Jordan and Robinson Return To International Play Today
description: One of the world's great partnerships returns to inter national competition today after a long period of retire ment. Robert Jordan and Arthur Robinson of Philadel phia, who have played bril liantly for America in several world championship contests, begin play in London in the Sunday Times Invitation Pair Tournament.

title: BACH GROUP CHANGES ARIAS AT TULLY HALL
description: The Bach Aria Group had to change its Bach program sub stantially for its concert at Tully Hall Wednesday night. Its soprano, Lois Marshall, was ill, and so alto, tenor and bass arias were substituted wherever there had been soprano ones.

title: The Screen:'Last Valley' Recalls a Story of Survival
description: "The Last Valley" is a kind of historical movie, a type of adventure drama, a sort of epic, and something of a parable, and it winds up being a bit more boring than is absolutely necessary, considering the possibilities.Experiencing the movie is very much like riding in a big, handsome, old Rolls-Royce that keeps wandering from one side of the road to the other, slipping its gears, speeding up and then suddenly breaking  all because the driver doesn't know where he's going or how fast he wants to get there, although it's apparent he wants to travel in all of the style that money can buy.The driver is James Clavell, the novelist ("King Rat") and film writer-director ("To Sir, With Love"), who wrote, directed and produced this adaption of J. B. Pick's 1960 novel set against the background of the Thirty Years' War (1618-1648), which was almost an anthology of war.Beginning as a rebellion of Protestant German princes against the Catholic Habsburgs, it evolved, over the decades, into a series of see-saw battles, mixed alliances and desperate power plays involving France, England, Spain, Denmark and Sweden, in addition to Austria and the German states. By the time the Treaty of Westphalia was signed, most of Germany had been devastated and about the only thing that had been accomplished was the irrevocable end of the Holy Roman Empire, which was dead anyway."The Last Valley" is a rather dreamlike story of survival set in a magnificent valley protected from the outside world by high mountains. Into this valley comes Vogel (Omar Sharif), a one-time school teacher who has been on the run for years, followed shortly afterwards by a small, exhausted army led by the Captain (Michael Caine), whose men kill and burn and rape on reflex and have long since forgotten what they're fighting for.The Captain, using Vogel as a go-between, effects a truce with the people of the valley, pledging to protect them from invasion in return for food, shelter and women for the winter, at the end of which the Captain goes off to fight another battle and Vogel is evicted, to continue his wanderings. The people of the valley survive, simply by enduring.Like Bertolt Brecht in "Mother Courage," Mr. Clavell, I suspect, sees the incredible horrors of the Thirty Years' War as a metaphor for contemporary horrors, but he seems either incapable ofor uninterested indeveloping a physical drama with any kind of intellectual substructure. Vogel, a pragmatic dreamer, and the Captain, a career soldier whose cynicism is not quite complete, talk quite a lot about war and religion but the quality of their dialogue would not embarrass the folks on "Gunsmoke." When, in the spring, the Captain departs to engage in yet another battle, the outcome of which will make no difference to anybody, all he can say is that he must go to the battle "because it's there."So much money was obviously spent on the lavish productionon scenery, costumes, occasional battles and extrasthat I suspect Mr. Clavell thought he was making a statement about civilization, and perhaps even Vietnam, that would somehow work as an action melodrama. Although Mr. Clavell, as a writer, has nothing in common with Shaw, "The Last Valley" kept reminding me of Guy Hamilton's misguided attempts some years ago to turn "The Devil's Disciple" into a popcorn movie.It's difficult to judge Mr. Clavell's effect on his performers, except to remark that Mr. Sharif and Mr. Caine, who've never struck me as especially subtle actors, are quite good, while Per Oscarsson ("Hunger"), who is, I think, a great actor, seems to be acting up a storm in a dramatic vacuum. It may be, however, that in his make-up as a slightly mad Catholic priest he looks just a little too much like Charles Manson.One technical point: the film, which opened yesterday at the Rivoli and Juliet 2 Theaters, favors such slow lap dissolves that you will spend what seems like most of the movie seeing double images.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BONN  Currently, Europe's most talked about foreign policy is that of West Germany's Chancellor Willy Brandt, which seeks, by taking the initiative, to lower existing barriers with the Soviet bloc. Brandt's much debated Ostpolitik gambles that Com munist society so desperately needs access to Western techniques and materials that it is willing to pay with political concessions.

title: 9 Banks Agree to Finance Housing Over East River
description: Nine of the city's largest commercial banks have formed a consortium to provide nearly $72million to make possible construction of Waterside, the longdelayed housing develop ment for 1,460 families on a sixacre platform over the East River alongside Bellevue Hos pital.

title: 2 IN HOUSE UPSET BY ASSIGNMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  House Democrats completed their biennial game of musical chairs with committee assign ments today, leaving two angry freshman members from New York holding seats they did not want.

title: ARTHUR S. VAN WINKLE
description: Arthur S. Van Winkle, who retired in 1945 as president of the Empire City Savings Bank, now the Empire Savings Bank, died Wednesday in Cobourg, Ontario after a short illness. He was 92 years old.

title: Washington Comments
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Pen tagon and State Department spokesmen tonight discounted the likelihood that members of the aid delivery teams in Cam bodia would travel to areas where they might be captured.

title: MARKET RISE LED BY AIRLINE GROUP
Falconry Flying High in Kuwait
description: MINAQISH, Kuwait, Jan. 10Abdul Aziz alGhanim ignored the desert around him and the Bedouin retain ers who had kissed the bridge of his nose as they greeted him.

title: Rubinstein and Liszt Fill Philharmonic Hall
description: Playing in Philharmonic Hall Wednesday night, on the eve of his 84th birthday, Ar tur Rubinstein did not sound as if he were growing old gracefully. After hearing his performances of Liszt's Fu nrailles and Twelth Rhap sody, the listener could only conclude that the great pian ist was growing young mag nificently.

title: SOCIALWORK UNIT CHANGING TACTICS
description: The city's oldest private so cial agency, the Community Service Society, announced yes terday that it would end 123 years of family casework and individual counseling.

title: City Official Calls Blue Cross A Factor in Hospital Cost Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  Gordon Chase, the New York City health services administra tor, appeared before Congress today to accuse medical in surance plans such as Blue Cross of helping to drive up spiraling health care costs by failing to crack down on the inefficiencies of hospitals.

title: Dining: Not Great but Not Bad
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: State Unit Asks More Aid for Culture
description: The New York State Com mission on Cultural Re sources is recommending that the state appropriate $30 million for local assistance to cultural institutions in the next fiscal year.

title: Thompson, Runner From West Texas, Is Webster's Pick
description: After talking endlessly about the need to bolster their defense, the New York Giants wound up making two little publicized offen sive players their first two draft choices yesterday. They were Ralph (Rocky) Thomp son, a running back from West Texas State who will be used as a wide receiver, and Wayne Walton, an offensive tackle from Abilene Chris tian.

title: Welcome Was Warm for League's IceSkating Clinic
description: David Wiggins, 10 years old, lives within walking dis tance of Central Park's Lasker Rink at 110th Street, but he never ventured down Lenox Avenue to watch the skaters gliding across the ice, and he certainly never fig ured to take up ice skating.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Neighborly Spirit Glows Warmly In a Snowbound Upstate Village
description: The Village of Warsaw, one of the many upstate com munities virtually isolated from the rest of the state by snow Tuesday and Wednesday, began to dig its way out yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: LINKS OF BUSINESS TO CRIME STUDIED
description: The Joint Legislative Commit tee on Crime opened a public hearing yesterday into the al leged connections between or ganized crime and the busi ness dealings and associations of Lewis S. Rosenstiel, the multimillionaire former chair man of the board of Schenley Industries, Inc.

title: JERUSALEM SLOWS HOUSING PROJECTS
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 28May or Teddy Kollek announced to day that controversial new Is raeli housing projects on the rocky hillsides around Jeru salem would be delayed pend ing further esthetic and urban development study.

title: Nigeria Prosperous Again
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  This country has a genuine and powerful economy, and that makes it different from its neighbors, a member of Ni geria's growing middle class explained the other day. If only we can remain unified politically, there will be no way that we can be stopped, he said.

title: Arabs in Israel: Minority Torn Between 2 Worlds
description: ABU GHOSH, Israel, Jan. 28 AS Israeli Arabs, our prob lem is that other Arabs dismiss us as Israelis and other Israelis suspect us as Arabs.

title: New LASH Ship Arrives in Port to Get First Cargo
description: The LASH Italia, a new type of ship that has been plagued by labor problems, arrived here yesterday, in troducing a different concept of cargo handling to the port.

title: Connally Tells Senators Nixon Seeks Tax Reform
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28John B. Connally Jr. told the Senate Finance Committee today that President Nixon had directed him to develop a broad tax reform program once his nomination as Secretary of the Treasury has been con firmed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 368371 Wins in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Jan. 28 (AP) This week's winning number in the New Jersey lottery is 368371. Holders of tickets with all six digits win $50,000; if the last five number match, the holders win $4,000; the last four, $400; the last three, $40, and the last two, a free ticket in the millionaire lottery drawing.

title: Secret Reports Keep Air Force Informed on Radicals
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Commanding officers at hun dreds of Air Force bases in this country and abroad reg ularly receive secret reports on the activities of antiwar, dis sident and radical groups, chiefly the Black Panther party.

title: Bengals Get Fred Willis
description: Fred Willis, the star running back who set numerous Boston College and New England rec ords during his career, was picked by the Cincinnati Ben gals yesterday in the fourth round of the National Football League draft.

title: GINZBURG PUSHES PROBATION PLEA
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 Ralph Ginzburg, the New York publisher who has remained free since being sentenced to prison in 1963 on an obscenity conviction, fought today to have the sentence reduced to probation.

title: TanzaniaZambia Railway: a Bridge to China?
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tan zaniaThe biggest economic event in this East African country last year was the start of construction by Com munist China of the much discussed, longawaited Tan zanianZambian railway.

title: SOUTH AFRICA FREES CHURCHMAN ON BAIL
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Jan. 28 The Anglican Dean of Johannesburg, detained eight days ago by the security police, was released on $7,000 bail hare today after being charged with distributing Com munist pamphlets calling for guerrilla warfare.

title: HEAD OF TAX AGENCY NAMED BY GOVERNOR
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28Governor Rockefeller announced to day the appointment of Norman F. Gallman as State Commis sioner of Taxation and Finance. He has been Acting Commis sioner since the resignation of Joseph W. Murphy July 1, 1969.

title: Rafferty Appointed Dean Of University in Alabama
description: TROY, Ala., Jan. 28 (AP) Dr. Max Rafferty, former super intendent of Public Instruction in California, will become dean of the newly established school of education at Troy State Uni versity.

title: UNDEFEATED PENN WINS IN OVERTIME
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 Corky Calhoun gave the Univer sity of Pennsylvania an 11th hour reprieve against Princeton tonight when he sank a 22foot jump shot with two seconds left in regulation time, tying the score at 60all.

title: PLOT JUDGE BIDS A PRIEST TESTIFY
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 28 A federal court today or dered a Jesuit priest to testify before a grand jury that has indicted six persons on charges of conspiracy to blow up Wash ington heating tunnels and kid nap a Presidential adviser, Hen ry A. Kissinger.

title: E. Simms Campbell, Illustrator For Major Magazines, Dies at 65
description: E. Simms Campbell, cartoon ist and illustrator for Esquire magazines and King Features syndicate, as well as many other outlets, died Wednesday in White Plains Hospital, after a brief illness. He was 65 years old.

title: Zambia Strives for SelfSufficiency
description: LUSAKA, ZambiaWhite Rhodesians used to chuckle as they pointed out that the United Nations economic sanctions against their break away British colony were hurting neighboring Zambia. And they were right.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: UDALL IS CLEARED OF SHOPLIFTING
description: FAIRFAX, Va., Jan. 28 (AP) Former Secretary of the In terior Stewart L. Udall was cleared today of a charge of shoplifting after the store in volved dropped the case.

title: The Screen
description: TALES, a film by Cassandra Gerstein, camora by Andrea Loomis, producer, Bill Snyder, distributed by New Line Cinema. At the Whitney Museum of American Art, Medison and 75th Street. Runnino time: 70 minutes.

title: Prelaunching Strike Threat Disclaimed for Apollo 14
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 29  Labor union officials pledged today that launching pad machinists, who are pro testing impending pay cuts, will not walk off their jobs or do anything to disrupt prep arations for the start Sunday of the Apollo 14 moon mis sion.

title: Sports of The Times
description: After Rod Laver won his seventh straight match of the year, a tough and often exciting victory over Arthur Ashe, he rubbed his reddened hands and analyzed the four sets. I came up with some volleys that were difficult points and that saved me, said Laver, his eyes ingenuously wide in a freckled face saved from boyishness by a strong, beaky nose. At 32 he is considered the world's top player, cer tainly one of the best ever to play this fierce and unnatural game, and seven straight Tennis Champions Classic victories, seven straight $10, 000 purses in the first 28 days of January, might lead one to believe he had his game together. Well, actually, said Laver, now rubbing his reddened knees, when you're middling the ball, then all you have to worry about is getting some direction.

title: Anticrime Programs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Nixon Administration has begun to apply the brakes on the rapidly accelerating pro gram of Federal aid to local law enforce ment, while increasing expenditures for corrections and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Warriors Conquer Braves
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 (UPI)The San Francisco War riors survived a fourthperiod threat and defeated the Buffalo Braves. 106100, tonight.

title: DIVIDEND REDUCED BY ARMCO STEEL
description: The Armco Steel Corpora tion reduced yesterday its quar terly dividend while announc ing sharply lower earnings for the final quarter of 1970 and the whole year.

title: Utica Man Is Elected President of State Bar
description: Hugh R. Jones of Utica, N. Y., a former chairman of the State Board of Social Welfare, was named yester day as presidentelect of the 22,000member New York State Bar Association at its annual meeting in the New York Hilton.

title: Pirates Trade Matty Alou and Brunet to Cardinals for Briles and Davalillo
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29 (UPI)  The Pittsburgh Pirates traded their star center fielder, Matty Alou, and a relief pitcher, George Brunet, to the St. Louis Cardinals today for Nelson Briles, a righthanded hurler, and Vic Davalillo, a center fielder.

title: City Moves Some Welfare Families Out of Hotels
description: In its effort to reduce the number of welfare tenants liv ing in squalid hotels here, the Lindsay administration has be gun moving some families into permanent apartments by waiv ing rules on rent levels that it set a month ago.

title: The Ultimate Minis
description: PARIS, Jan. 29Jap styles (Jap is the in boutique in Paris) will very likely take over the young junior crowd.

title: Caroline Gets a Wish and Roses, While Nureyev
description: Caroline Kennedy, who had wanted to go backstage to meet Rudolf Nureyev, got her wish the other night at the City Center. She also got the red roses that fans had given the dancer, and he got his finger scratched on a thorn. The 13yearold daughter of the late President Kennedy was accompanied by two friends, a governess and a Secret Service man to a benefit performance by the Australian Ballet Thursday night. Because her mother, Mrs. Aristotle S. Onassis, had sent the dancer a note, they were allowed to watch cur tain calls from the wings. Another backstage visitor was Sir James Plimsoll, Aus tralian Ambassador to the United States. The benefit was for the Stanley M. Isaacs Neighborhood Center.

title: CHICAGO UTILITY LISTS 1970 GAINS
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries re ported yesterday gains in oper ating revenues and net income for 1970.

title: SABRES TRIUMPH OVER SEALS, 4 TO 2
description: OAKLAND, Jan. 29 (UPI) Gil Perreault, a rookie, scored three goals tonight, the last into an open net, to pace the Buffalo Sabres to a 42 Nation al Hockey League victory over the California Golden Seals.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: NIXON, IN EXPANSIONARY BUDGET, FORESEES DEFICIT OF $11.6BILLION;
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 President Nixon sent to Con gress today a budget of $229.2 billion that he termed expan sionary but not inflationary for the nation's economy.

title: ROGERS SAYS U.S. MIGHT AID A DRIVE BY SAIGON IN LAOS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  Secretary of State William P. Rogers held open today the pos sibility that United States air power might be used to sup port a South Vietnamese ex pedition against Communist supply bases in southern Laos.

title: GUGGENHEIM LEAVES FUND $12MILLION
description: Harry F. Guggenheim, philan thropist, publisher and co founder of Newsday, a Long Island daily, left more than $12 million to various philanthro pies in a will filed yesterday for probate in the Surrogate's Court of Nassau County.

title: Landing Trainer Crashes
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 28 (UPI)  A $1.9million moon landing trainer, one of two craft used by Captain Shepard during his training, crashed and exploded today at nearby Ellington Air Force Base.

title: CITRUS FUTURES STAGE A REBOUND
description: Frozen orange juice futures, which had risen three previous sessions, continued to climb yesterday.

title: West German Boat Fired On
description: BAD BRAMSTEDT, West Ger many, Jan. 29 (AP)An East German patrol boat opened fire on a West German dredger and boarded her in the Baltic Sea yesterday, border patrol of ficials reported here today.

title: RadioactiveWaste Repository Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Atomic Energy Commission plans to develop in Kansas a storage facility for radioactive wastes big enough to meet the nation's needs for the rest of the century.

title: NETS TOP CONDORS ON OVERTIME SHOT
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 29A goaltending bas ket by Rick Barry with four seconds to play tonight gave the New York Nets a 132131 victory in overtime over the Pittsburgh Condors at Island Garden.

title: A Kiss for New Interior Secretary
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)Rogers C. B. Morton Was sworn in today as Sec retary of the Interior with instructions from President Nixon to restore the beauty of America which has been so marred by what we have done to it in recent years.

title: Stock Volume Tops 100 Million in Week
description: The stock market extended its massive advance yester day as volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to a weekly figure of 100 million shares for the first time on record.

title: STRONG ECONOMIC GAIN PREDICTED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The Administration is forecast ing a very strong economic re covery this year, with the gross national product rising to $1,065billiona figure that is $15billion to $20billion higher than the predictions being made by most private econo mists.

title: Exchanges to Close Feb. 15
description: The New York Stock Ex change and the American Stock Exchange will be closed for trading on Monday, Feb. 15, in observance of Washington's Birthday. Feb. 15 is also a bank holiday.

title: Executive Office
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The budget for the fiscal year 1972, released today, lends statistical support to the judg ment of most observers here that Presi dent Nixon has consolidated within his own executive office more power than any of his predecessors.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: President Hails Budget In White House Signing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)  President Nixon for mally signed and sent to Congress today two green leatherbound volumes set ting out the $229billion budget by which he hopes to stimulate the nation's econ omy.

title: Cairo Stresses Warning That Truce Ends Friday Unless Talks Advance
description: CAIRO, Jan. 29  The Egyp tian Government went all out today to convince domestic and world opinion that the Suez Canal ceasefire would end next Friday barring a substan tial development in the indirect peace talks with Israel under Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring at the United Nations.

title: Floods Ravage Area in Mozambique
description: BEIRA, Mozambique, Jan. 29 (Reuters)  Hundreds of people were feared dead to day and more than 500,000 were believed to be trapped in floods in the northeastern region of this Portuguese African territory.

title: Big Board Issues Revision Of ShortInterest Totals
description: Each month the member firms of the New York Stock Exchange report their custom er's total short positions, and the exchange collates the totals into a report, issued around the twentieth of each month.

title: The Danger Behind Revenue Sharing
description: Revenue sharing is to end the financial drought that shrivels our domestic programs. It is my belief that while it will temporarily revive the programs, it will in the long run only aggravate their condition.

title: Worsley Shines for Stars
description: VANCOUVER, Jan. 29 (UPI) Gump Worsley excelled in the goal tonight as the Minne sota North Stars gained a 21 triumph over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Daetwyler Wins Downhill
description: MEGEVE, France, Jan. 29 (AP)  JeanDaniel Daetwyler of Switzerland outsped the fa vored French and won the men's downhill today in the 27th Grand Prix de Megeve World Cup ski competition.

title: Immunity Part of '70 Crime Act Ruled Invalid by Federal Judge
description: A key provision of the 1970 Federal omnibus crime act was declared unconstitutional yes terday on the ground that it failed to provide sufficient pro tection against selfincrimina tion.

title: Polish Church Welcomes Bid by Regime
description: WARSAW, Jan. 29Poland's Roman Catholic leaders have decided during a twoday meet ing in Warsaw to accept the bid by the nation's Communist leadership to seek normal churchstate relations.

title: CHANGE FORESEEN IN MEDICAL CARE
description: The health manpower short age and the new models for dispensing care mean that the onedoctor to onepatient rela tionship is become archaic, Dr. Carl E. Wasmuth said yes terday at a national conference on physician's assistants.

title: A CLEANAIR CODE PROPOSED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency proposed standards to day to limit six common pol lutants in the air anywhere in the United States.

title: TREASURY PLANS TO BORROW LESS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The Treasury will borrow less in the new fiscal year than in the present year, but there will be another huge increase in bor rowing by Federal agencies and in various Government loan guarantees, President Nix on's budget disclosed today.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  Two Maryland engineers were awarded a patent this week for an anthropomorphic dum my named Dynamic Dan. The mansized figure has al ready been put to work at the Wright  Patterson Air Force Base in Ohio, testing the effects of pilot ejection from aircraft. Peter R. Payne and Stephen J. Chris assigned Patent 3,557,471 to Wyle Laboratories, El Segun do, Calif. The prototype of Dan, the only one delivered so far, is built to simulate the major dynamic character istics of the human body.

title: Who Is Senator Byrd?
description: The great bulk of the reporting on the surprising result of the contest for Senate whip has focused on the man who lost the contest. Not nearly enough attention has been paid to the man who won, and what his victory says about the Democratic party in the United States Senate.

title: College Art Meeting Avoids Fights
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 29  There has been lots of talk but contrary to expectationslittle confrontation so far at the 59th annual meeting of the College Art Associations at the Conrad Hilton Hotel here.

title: Jeremiah O'Connor, Detective Who Was Cited 21 Times, Dies
description: Jeremiah O'Connor, a retired firstgrade detective of the Police Department, who won 21 citations, including the Medal of Honor and the Sheridan Medal for Valor, died Thursday of pneumonia in Union Hospital, the Bronx. He was 57 years old and lived at 2842 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

title: G.E. Sets $41 Million Plant At Site in North Carolina
description: DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 29 (AP) The General Electric Com pany announced plans today for construction of a $41mil lion plant near the Research Triangle Park.

title: GENERAL CLEARED OF MYLAI CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The Army dismissed all court martial charges today against Maj. Gen. Samuel W. Koster, the division commander of the troops who were at the ham let of Mylai 4 at the time of the alleged mass killings of South Vietnamese civilians there on March 16, 1968.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: Anniversaries

title: Somali Opposes Relations
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Jan. 29 (Reuters)  Somalia today joined Tanzania in re fusing to recognize the new military regime in Uganda and said it still regarded Mr. Obote as President.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Jan. 26.

title: Nixon Under Political Pressure In California Legal Aid Battle
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Strong political pressures mounted on the White House today as the Administration waited until the last minute to choose between Gov. Ronald Reagan of California and a program of legal services for the poor.

title: Peking Envoy in Rome
description: ROME, Jan. 29 (Reuters)  A Chinese diplomat, Feng Hsien Pi, arrived here today to open Peking's first embassy in Rome since the Communists took over China 22 years ago. He will be China's charg d'affaires in Italy until an ambassador arrives.

title: Merger News
description: The proposed merger of the Norfolk & Western Railway and the Chesapeake & Ohi?? Railway was further delayed yesterday by the Interstat?? Commerce Commission. The regulatory body granted a request by the Penn Cen tral Transportation Company to post pone from Feb. 11 to May 15 its submission o certain required material deal ing with the possible loss o traffic if the merger were per mitted.

title: F.D.I.C. Arranges to Pay Depositors in Texas Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) The Federal Deposit Insur ance Corporation's directors voted today to pay as much as $50millionup to $20,000 each to the approximately 25,000 depositors in the Sharps town State Bank of Houston, which was ordered closed Mon day.

title: Gap in Talks Still Wide
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 29  The second day's negotiations over new revenue increases for six Persian Gulf countries, which supply most of West Eu rope's oil, ended here today with the gap between the sides still wide.

title: Environment
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  President Nixon asked Congress in his Budget Message today to appropriate roughly twice as much in the next fiscal year for environmental protection as it did in the current year.

title: Health
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The new budget gives few clues to the Adminis tration's plans for what President Nixon, in his State of the Union Mes sage, called a new era in American medicine.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Tobacco Warehouse Held Up
description: Eight gunmen tied up 17 per sons in a Lower East Side to bacco warehouse yesterday, loaded the company's truck with $45,000 worth of ciga rettes and tobacco and escaped. The gang entered the Booth To bacco and Confectionery Com pany at 179 Eldridge Street, near Rivington Street, at 9:15 A.M. In addition to the tobacco products, the gunmen took several thousand dollars from George Elicofon, 58 years old, one of the owners.

title: Improper Questions
description: The Office of Legislative Research for the State Legislature has asked the presidents of all the colleges that make up the State University of New York to submit a detailed syllabus for every course offered in American history, political science and the social sciences. The questions focus specifically on the cur riculum dealing with revolution, the Establishment, sociology and urban studies, with particular attention to the instructor's thrust.

title: Executive Changes
description: American Export Isbrandtsen Lines, Inc., an nounced yesterday that Joseph G. Barkan has re signed as president of the American Export Indus tries, Inc., subsidiary. Mr. Barkan said that he had been considering various situations that would make greater use of his overall transportation experience, and that to pursue these possibilities it was neces sary and proper for him to relinquish his present assignment. Adm. John M. Will, chairman, will as sume the post of president, effective Feb. 1.

title: Swede Survives Foul Claim To Win World Dragon Sail
description: HOBART, Tasmania, Jan. 29 (AP)  Peter Sunderlin of Sweden, sailing Debutant, sur vived a foul claim and won the championship today in the world Dragon Class yachting competition.

title: Brooklyn G.I. Dies in War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI)  The Defense Department an nounced today that Pfc. Alfonso A. Brito of Brooklyn had been killed in the war in Southeast Asia.

title: Oddy and Tully Advance In Title Squash Racquets
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 29 Fourseeded Roland Oddy of New York scored a 154, 159, 156 victory over Bill Money, the Atlantic City titleholder, in the opening round of the 30th Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship tonight at Chal fonteHaddon Hall.

title: KENNEDY CRITICAL OF HEALTH AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  Senator Edward M. Kennedy accused the Nixon Administra tion today of appointing some strange looking, consumers to healthcare advisory councils.

title: Employe Arrested As the Mastermind Of L.I. Bank Holdup
description: An assistant bank manager who had described himself as the victim of a $154,244 holdup last May in Suffolk County was arrested yesterday and charged with being its insti gator.

title: MISS PROELL WINS IN FRENCH SLALOM
description: ST, GERVAIS, France, Jan. 29 (AP)Anne Marie Proell of Austria won the 12nation women's special slalom with a flashing second run today.

title: ISAIAH ABRAHAMS, ENGINEER, WAS 84
description: Isaiah S. Abrahams, a retired civil engineer and former chair man of the structural depart ment of Brooklyn Technical High School, died Wednesday in a nursing home in New Lon don, Conn. He was 84 years old and lived at 7 Lantern Lane, Wethersfield, Conn.

title: Dr. Mary Bunting To Resign in 1972 As Radcliffe Head
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Jan. 29 (AP)  Dr. Mary I. Bunting, a microbiologist and the first wo man member of the Atomic Energy Commission, will retire as the fifth president of Rad cliffe College June 30, 1972, the school announced today.

title: Charles S. Garland Dies at 72; Former U.S. Davis Cap Player
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 29 (AP) Charles S. Garland, a former Davis Cup tennis star who went on to become a leader in bank ing, education and civic affairs, died last evening. He was 72 years old.

title: Glossary of Key Terms in the Federal Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Fol lowing is a glossary of the im portant technical terms used in the Federal budget:

title: Black Religion Seeks Own Theology
description: A disparate group of black religious leaders is seeking to merge the traditionally strong Negro church with the intensified feelings of black consciousness to produce a functional black theology.

title: First Big Strike Grounds Lufthansa;
description: BONN, Jan. 29Lufthansa, the West German airline, was grounded today by its first major strike.

title: Union Abandons Fight Against B.E.A.
description: LONDON, Jan. 29  The Government won a victory to day in its effort to hold down wage increases and break the inflationary spiral.

title: Governor Tells U.S. Legislators Revenue Sharing Is Not Enough
