description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Governor Rockefeller traveled here today to support President Nixon's revenuesharing pro posal but warned that the Federal Government had to go even further to prevent state and local governments from virtually falling to pieces.

title: Revenue Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 President Nixon proposed today that several of the largest and most controversial Fed eral urban and poverty programs be turned over to state and local govern ments in a special form of revenue sharing.

title: Redskins Trade Linemen
description: George Allen, the Redskin general manager  coach, traded Leo Carroll, a defensive end and Washington's 17thround choice yesterday to the New Orleans Saints for Mike Taylor, an offensive guard. Allen had gotten six of his former Los Angeles players and a draft choice in a deal with Los Angeles Thursday.

title: Bob Shaw Cards 68 for 135 to Lead by Stroke at Halfway Mark in San Diego
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 29Bob Shaw became a new foreign golfing challenger on the pro tour today as he climbed into the pacemaker's spot with a 135 aggregate at the halfway mark in the $150,000 Andy Williams San Diego open.

title: Law of SelfDefense In Nebraska Voided By Top State Court
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 29The Nebraska Supreme Court ruled unconstitutional today the self defense act passed by the Leg islature in 1969. The law, which attracted national attention, authorized a person to use any means necessary ot de fend him self or his property from attack.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX CONTINUE TO RISE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to advance yesterday in the heaviest trad ing in four months.

title: Moscow Response
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 29  Tass, the Soviet News Agency, re ported today that Zionist hooli gans had tried to disrupt last night's New York opening of the Siberian Dancers and Sing ers of Omsk but that the audi ence was indignant, and stormily applauded the Soviet artists.

title: and Capitol Architect
description: Most of the marble has been spilled on Capitol Hill, but better late than never is as appropriate a sentiment in architecture as it is in politics. The naming of George White as Architect of the Capitol is also appropriate: he is an architect and a vice president of the American Institute of Architects, a fact that represents a stun ning and welcome departure from recent practice in which professionalism has been eliminated in favor of party service. The appointment is good news.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: HAROLD JAMES KRESS
description: EASTON, Pa., Jan. 29Har old James Kress, who retired as a lawyer with the American Telephone and Telegraph Com pany in 1966, after more than 42 years of service in the Bell System, died Thursday of a heart attack at the age of 70.

title: Mediator Seeks to Avoid Strike At Garages Here Set for Tonight
description: A state mediator strived yes terday for a settlement of a dispute between garage work ers and owners that could shut down 650 public parking ga rages in Manhattan and the Bronx when the contract ex pires at midnight tonight.

title: Dance: Australian Fare
description: Thursday's program of the Australian Ballet, now mak ing its New York debut at the New York City Center, gave a better idea of the company itself than had Ru dolf Nureyev's staging of Don Quixote, which had opened the engagement at the beginning of the week.

title: Knicks Subdue Celtics, 118 to 111, as Stallworth Paces 4thQuarter Rally
description: BOSTON, Jan. 29  The Knicks, getting a needed lifft in the final period for the sec ond straight time from Dave Stallworth, fought their way to a difficult 118111 victory over the Boston Celtics tonight at Boston Garden before a capa city crowd of 15,203.

title: Bolt's 137 Leads by 5 Shots
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP)Tommy Bolt shot a fourunderpar 68 today and took a fivestroke lead at 137 after the second round of the $40,000 Professional Golf ers Assocation seniors golf championship. Bab Hamilton, the firstround leader at 66, carded a 76 and tied for second with Julius Boras at 142.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Man in the News
description: As Jerry Lerman was driv ing to work yesterday morn ing, the news broadcast on his car radio reported that President Nixon was sending a proposed $229.2billion Fed eral budget to Congress for the next fiscal year. It's dif ficult for most people to think in terms of $229billion, Mr. Lerman said as he steered through the traf fic on the Tri borough Bridge. They don't even know what $1billion is. To Mr. Lerman, who is a 49 yearold general manager of a toy manufacturing plant in the South Bronx and a homeowner in Bayside, Queens, and to most New Yorkers the Federal budget may seem like an abstract document.

title: Edrich's 130 Paces England To 276 for 2 in Cricket Test
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 29 (Reuters)A century by John Edrich led England to a formidable firstinnings total of 276 runs for two tickets to day on the opening day of the sixth cricket test against Aus tralia.

title: Poverty
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Office of Economic Opportunity, launched in 1965 as the flagship of former President Johnson's War on Poverty, will not be scuttled by President Nixon's new budg et as some had predicted. But neither will it be a warship.

title: Richfield Net Off for Quarter and Year
description: The Atlantic Richfield Com pany reported yesterday net income of $59,930,000, or $1.06 a share, for the fourth quarter of 1970, down from the year earlier $65,029,000, or $1.15 a share. Sales rose to $830,443, 000 from $771,313,000 in the 1969 quarter.

title: Antiques: Art Nouveau by Grueby
description: Grueby is a name becom ing increasingly important to collectors of the American art nouveau.

title: Tuna Men on West Coast Doubt a Pact With Latins
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif. Jan. 29 The West Coast tuna fleet, with a $200million investment and 1,700 crewmen, is skep tical about the prospects of settling the United States 18 year dispute with Ecuador and Peru over fishing rights.

title: DECEMBER PRICES ROSE BY 0.8% HERE, 0.5% ACROSS U.S.
description: The Consumer Price Index for the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area rose eight tenths of 1 per cent in Decem ber compared with an increase of onehalf of 1 per cent for the country as a whole, the Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported yesterday.

title: U.S.C., MARQUETTE REMAIN UNBEATEN
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (UPI) Unbeaten Southern California's No. 1 ranked five put together a 45point second half tonight to roll to its 15th victory, 8168, over Illinois in the Chicago Stadium.

title: Economies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  President Nixon's budget, like its predecessors, includes a long list of proposals for savings, but the approach to Congress is somewhat different from past Presi dential recommendations along these lines.

title: 2 AGENCIES ACTING IN BRUTALITY CASE
description: The office of District Attor ney Frank S. Hogan and the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board are investigating a case in which two teenaged boys were re ported to have been seriously injured while they were being arrested on charges of disor derly conduct and harassment.

title: Text of President's Message to Congress on Federal Budget for Fiscal Year 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Following is the text, photographically reproduced, of President Nixon's Budget Message as presented to Congress today:

title: Lakers Beat Sonics, 122115
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 (AP) The Los Angeles Lakers, led by Happy Hairston, Jerry West and Wilt Chamberlain, downed the Seattle SuperSonics, 122 115, tonight.

title: STATE WARNS CITY OF NEW JAIL RIOTS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29  The State Correction Commission warned today that continued overcrowding in three New York City jails could produce new outbreaks of rioting.

title: Live TV Coverage of Apollo Set for Europe and Africa
description: GENEVA, Jan. 29The Euro pean Broadcasting Union said today that it would provide live color television coverage of Apollo 14 for 21 countries of Western Europe and North Africa.

title: BUCKS TROUNCE 76ERS, 142 TO 118
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP) Hal Greer joined the National Basketball Association's 20,000 point career club tonight, but the Philadelphia 76ers lost to the Milwaukee Bucks, 142118, before a sellout crowd of 15,246 at the Spectrum.

title: NASA AIDE CHOSEN FOR SCHOOL POST
description: An official of the National Aeronautics and Space Admin istration's Manned Spacecraft Center at Houston has been selected by Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner to be the top busi ness executive for the city school system.

title: Norton Unit Raises Prices
description: Price increases ranging from 5 to 7 per cent on most of its bonded abrasive products were announced yesterday by the grinding wheel division of the Norton Company. The higher prices go into effect April 1. Excluded from the increases are diamond wheels and rein forced raised hub wheels.

title: Many Aging Face an Economic Nightmare
description: MIAMI BEACH  Not far from Miami Beach's opulent strip of oceanfront hotels, where a room for the night costs upward of $50, the 69 yearold widow of a Bronx tailor was recently caught trying to steal a 25cent can of soup in a supermarket.

title: FRENCH RENAULTS RALLY AT FINISH
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 29 (UPI)Ove Andersson of Sweden and David Stone of Britainled from start to finish today to win the tough est Monte Carlo Rally in mem ory. The French Alpine Re nault team swept the first three places.

title: Germany Maps School Reform
description: BONNChancellor Willy Brandt's coalition Govern ment in Bonn is seeking to restore Germany's reputa tion as a nation of scholars, scientists and educators.

title: DefenseMinded Army and Navy Play City Fives at Garden Today
description: For students of defense, the two basketball games sched uled for Madison Square Gar den this afternoon  Navy against New York University and Army against Manhattan should prove instructive.

title: MILTON ARONSOHN
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Jan. 29 Milton Aronsohn. vice presi dent and general manager of S. J. Aronsohn Silk Manufac turing Company of Dunmore and a community leader here, died Tuesday at the age of 71.

title: U.S. Saturation Air Raids Continuing in South Laos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 29Saturation raids were flown again today against North Vietnamese infiltration and supply routes in southern Laos, continuing what is described here as one of the most in tensive aerial campaigns of the Indochina war.

title: U.S. LISTS RESULTS OF ITS REFINANCING
description: The Treasury announced yesterday that investors hold ing $19.5billion of maturing Government notes and bonds agreed to exchange $10.8billion of them for new notes in its ??ig refinancing operation earlier this week.

title: Thursday Night Fights
description: Los AngelesManuel Mendoza, 118 pounds, Mexico, knocked out Roberto Tirado, 118, Mexico, 3 rounds.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Swanson Is Sidelined
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (UPI)  Gloria Swanson, the star of Butterflies Are Free, missed her performance at the Forrest Theater here tonight because she was hospitalized for a severe nosebleed. A spokesman at Jefferson Hospi tal said the 72yearold actress was admitted there last night and given emergency treat ment. He said, however, that she would be discharged in time to resume her role tomor row night.

title: McGregor Expanding Knitwear
description: Before the end of the cen tury, knits possibly may be the only material in men's apparel. We want to be ready now.

title: U.S. Tapping I.M.F. For $250Million
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Treasury announced today a United States drawing of $250 million from the International Monetary Fund, evenly split be tween Dutch guilders and Bel gian francs.

title: Oil Under East China Sea Is the Crux of 3Nation Issue
description: TOKYO, Jan. 29Only sea birds inhabit the lonely reefs of five rockgirt islets, in the East China Sea that have be come the focus of a territorial dispute between Japan. com munist China and Nationalist China.

title: Genet Views U.S. With Sorrow
description: Janet Flanner has lived in Paris for almost 50 years, and for the best part of that time she has fixed the splen dors of France in The New Yorker's Paris Letter.

title: RANGEL ATTACKS POLICE ON GRAFT
description: Charles B. Rangel, freshman Representative from Harlem, charged yesterday that New York City policemen put on the American flag when it's time for a raise, but refuse to recognize that law and order means lack of corruption.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: FullEmployment Budget
description: President Nixon has submitted a budget for fiscal 1972 that strains credulity  not because it is so deep in deficit, with $11.6 billion marked in red ink, but because the deficit is not still deeper.

title: Argentine Workers Strike
description: CORDOBA. Argentina, Jan. 29 (UPI)  Thousands of work ers went on strike today for higher wages and improved working conditions. The sched uled 14hour walkout started in heavy rain, which forced cancellation of a mass demon stration.

title: Mines Unit Asks Prosecution in Blast Fatal to 38
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The United States Bureau of Mines said today that the coal mine explosion that killed 38 men near Hyden, Ky., last month was caused by so many viola tions of Federal safety regu lations that it was asking the Justice Department to prose cute those responsible.

title: The Talk of Temuco
description: TEMUCO, Chile, Jan. 25 At the home of an elderly judge here, the cork popped from a champagne bottle and five glasses were filled for a toast.

title: Donohue, in Ferrari, Wins Pole for 24 Hours of Daytona Run
Bridge: Swis Team Event to Replace Mixed Pairs in Contest Here
description: The American Bridge Asso ciation, primarily organized for Negro players, has fol lowed the lead of the larger American Contract Bridge League in scheduling Swiss Team contests.

title: 17% IN SURVEY SEE PAY RISE IN 6 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) The Commerce Department reported today that 17.2 per cent of the families questioned in a survey this month expect an increase in their income in the next six months, while 6.7 per cent of the families antici pate a decline.

title: Mrs. Sabin Gets Divorce
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 29 (AP) Mrs. Jane Sabin, wife of Dr. Albert Sabin, developer of oral polio vaccine, was granted a divorce today in Hamilton County Court of Domestic Rela tions.

title: Jersey Climbers Found Safe on Mt. Washington
description: MOUNT WASHINGTON, N. H., Jan. 29 (AP)Four New Jersey mountain climb ers, missing since Tues day in subzero weather on Mount Washington, the Northeast's highest peak, were found in good condi tion today by rescue teams.

title: Alan Badel Stars As Sartre's Kean Crosses Channel
description: LONDON, Jan. 29  It has taken more than 20 years for JeanPaul Sartre's Kean to achieve its West End premiere, at the Globe Theater. This time lag may be the result either of London's disbelief in Sarte as an entertainer or the lack of any actor up to the title role. The second obstacle is now magnificently overcome by Alan Badel, whose performance should go a long way to de molishing the first.

title: 3 Federal Judges Reject Illinois Ban on Abortions
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (UPI)A panel of three Federal judges ruled unconstitutional today an Illinois law prohibiting abor tions by licensed physicians.

title: Providence Papers Up to 15c
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 29 (AP)The Providence Journal Company announced today that the newsstand price of the morning Journal and Evening Bulletin would rise 3 cents, to 15 cents a copy, effective Feb. 1.

title: Classes at Julia Richman To Close 4 Days Next Week
description: Julia Richman High School, the scene of student disturb ances and other problems in recent weeks, will be closed for the first four days of next week for reorganization, the Board of Education announced yesterday.

title: The Wild Blue Space Shuttle
description: ITHACA, N. Y.With a minimum of debate, the Senate recently decided to appropriate $110 million for NASA's proposed space station and reusable shuttle. Such a system, when completed in the late 1970's, will cost more than $14 billion, and could pave the way for a $50 to $110billion manned Mars landing near the end of the century.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: I renew my protest. I renew my request that our air force mechanics be withdrawn from Indochina. For the good they do, the risk is too great. We are taking steps that lead our men directly into combat

title: State Offtrack Betting Law Faces Another Court Test
description: SYRACUSE, Jan. 29 (AP) Members of District 8 of the United States Trotting Associa tion voted at their convention today to test in the courts the constitutionality of the state's new offtrack betting law. Two harness tracksVernon Downs and Saratoga Raceway  al ready have filed suit against the law.

title: As jets Gather Speedy Men for Kick Returns
description: Chris Farasopoulos, a Greekborn holder of two national collegiate records, loomed yesterday as a threat to Mike Battle as the New York Jets campleted their draft of college talent with an emphasis on kickoff return and puntreturn spe cialists.

title: Interprovincial Pipe Line
description: TORONTO, Jan. 29 (Canadian Press)  The Interprovincial Pipe Line Company reported yesterday that net income in 1970 rose to $29.5million, or $1.16 a share, from $24.4mil lion, or 96 cents a share, in 1969.

title: GEORGES VAN PARYS, FRENCH COMPOSER, 68
description: PARIS, Jan. 29Georges Van Parys, who wrote the music for about 300 French movies as well as hundreds of popular songs, died here today after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: LTV BankLoan Payment Of $23Million Is Extended
description: DALLAS, Jan. 29 (Reuters)  LingTemcoVought, Inc., said its $23million bank loan payment due Jan. 31, 1971, has been extended to July 31, 1971.

title: ALEXANDER C. EWEN
description: SANFORD, Me., Jan. 29 (AP) Alexander C. Ewen, a former dean of faculty at Dean Acad emy in Franklin, Mass., died yesterday in a nursing home here. He was 92 years old and lived in Acton.

title: Hawks Halt Cavaliers, 119111
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 29 (UPI) Pete Maravich scored 38 points tonight as the Atlanta Hawks posted a 119111 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: ERIE LEGISLATORS INDICTED ON BRIBE
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 29  Two members of the Erie County Legislature were charged to day with conspiracy to solicit a $100,000 bribe in return for not blocking approval of coun ty funds for a proposed sta dium.

title: Science
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The pro posed Federal budget for the fiscal year 1972 appears to include the first real increase for scientific research and de velopment in five years.

title: Mexico Seizes U. S. Boat
description: TAMPICO, Mexico, Jan. 29 (UPI)A Mexican Navy mine sweeper today seized a United States fishing boat for allegedly operating within Mexican ter ritorial waters. Navy head quarters said the shrimper Ed ward Clinch, of Brownsville, Tex., had been operating five miles offshore. It was escorted into Tuxpan.

title: Haze Hangs Over Miami
description: MIAMI, Jan. 29 (AP)Bil lows of haze blanketed the Florida coast today as smoke from a 4,000acre grass fire in Palm Beach County drifted as far south as Miami.

title: Guinea Announces Break In West German Relations
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Jan. 29 (Agence France  Presse)  Guinea has decided to break off all diplomatic relations with West Germany, the Con akry radio said in a broadcast monitored here today.

title: Pistons Rout Rockets, 131104
description: DETROIT, Jan. 29 (UPI) Dave Bing's 34 points paced the Detroit attack and helped the Pistons break a threegame losing streak tonight as they beat the San Diego Rockets, 131104.

title: The U.S. in the O.A.S. Dock
description: If doubts existed about the low standing of the United States in hemisphere politics, the action this week by the Organization of American States must have removed them. Over strenuous Washington objection, O.A.S. for eign ministers voted 22 to 0 to call an emergency meeting today to consider Ecuador's charges against this country arising from American retaliation for seizure of tuna boats inside the 200mile territorial limit claimed by Ecuador. The United States has never before suffered such a decisive setback in an O.A.S. vote.

title: At Saint Laurent, Styles From the Demimonde
description: PARIS, Jan. 29The death Knell sounded for the long skirt today. Yves Saint Lau rent did it with a bit of a leer. The designer who was as responsible as anyone else for the fall of the hemline took it all back. Practically everything he made stopped at the knees. A goodly num ber of dresses were four or five inches above them. A lot of people were in hysterics. They looked as if they wanted to cry, when the de signer obviously wanted them to laugh.

title: Monitor Names Editorialist
description: BOSTON, Jan. 29 (AP)The appointment of Joseph C. Harsch, a columnist, as chief editorial writer of The Chris tian Science Monitor was an nounced today. He succeeds Joseph G. Harrison, who was appointed editor of general publications of The Christian Science Publishing Society.

title: Bullets Sink Royals, 145118
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 29 (UPI) Earl Monroe scored 11 of his 20 points in the first period to night as the Baltimore Bullets breezed to a 145118 victory over the Cincinnati Royals.

title: Is It Jeffersonian?
description: For American historians, President Nixon's State of the Union Message had an agreeably nostalgic ring. The further away government is from peo ple, he said, the stronger govern ment becomes and the weaker people become.  Local government is the government closest to the people and more responsive to the individual per son; it is people's government in a far more intimate way than the Govern ment in Washington can ever be.

title: LAXITY IS CHARGED TO WATER BOTTLERS
description: The executive director of the American Water Works Asso ciation said yesterday that some bottled water sold in the state might be unsafe, unclean or not much more than strained tap water. He named no spe cific bottlers.

title: Huge Farm Costs Vexing Common Market
description: PARIS  The European Common Market is contin uing to spend staggering sums supporting agriculture.

title: Vatican Reports Drop in Number of World's Priests
description: ROME, Jan. 29A Vatican report published today showed that the ranks of the Roman Catholic priesthood were dwin dling.

title: Protest March for the Poor Heads for Cape Kennedy
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP)Protesting that Amer ica should be spending money on the hungry instead of send ing men to the moon, about 75 persons set out for Cape Ken nedy today on what they called a march against moonrocks.

title: Ulbricht Rebuffs Brandt, Demands Recognition
description: BERLIN, Jan. 29Walter Ul bricht, the East German Com munist leader, today rejected Chancellor Willy Brandt's pro posals for cooperation between East and West Germany and demanded instead that Bonn ex tend diplomatic recognition to East Germany.

title: Jewish Defense League Plans To Resume Harassing Russians
description: The Jewish Defense League announced yesterday that it would resume its antiSoviet harassment tactics.

title: CHIEF RESIGNING AT RETAIL GROUP
description: James J. Bliss yesterday sub mitted his resignation as pres ident of the National Retail Merchants Association after six years as its chief staff of ficer. The N.R.M.A., the retail ing industry's largest trade as sociation, has been troubled in recent years by financial re verses and membership de clines.

title: U.N. PANEL REBUFFS BID BY SOUTH AFRICA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 29  A United Nations body declared today that South Af rica had no right to conduct a plebiscite in SouthWest Africa

title: Vietcong Truce Ends
description: SAIGON, Saturday, Jan. 30 (Reuters)The Vietcong ended their fourday Tet lunar new year truce early today, and allied reports said that the guerrillas had violated their ceasefire at least 74 times.

title: Local School Board Members Hear New Ideas in Education
description: I am here to prod, to nudge, to urge, to advocate, to try to persuade.

title: 2 Albany Bills Would Bar Kennedy's Growth Into Bay
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29  Bills were introduced in the Legisla ture today that would prohibit the extension of runway facili ties at Kennedy International Airport into Jamaica Bay be cause an extension would ad versely affect the ecology of the bay's 9,151acre wildlife refuge.

title: Speaker of House Describes Budget As Step Forward
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) House Speaker Carl Albert, Democrat of Oklahoma, said today the Administration's pro posed $229.2billion budget was a major step forward for a Republican President.

title: PETKEVICH WINS IN FIGURE SKATING
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 29Despite falling in the final seconds of his program, John Misha Pet kevich of Great Falls, Mont., received a perfect score from one judge to capture the senior men's event of the United States figure skating champion ships tonight at War Memorial Auditorium.

title: Approval Given for Drug
description: The International Chemical and Nuclear Corporation an nounced yesterday that it had received approval from the United States Food and Drug Administration to market the drug LDopa, which is said to offer symptomatic relief to victims of Parkinson's disease.

title: Music From Marlboro Series Presents TripleTreat Program
description: The Music From Marlboro concert at the Metropolitan Mu seum Thursday night was a tripletreat affair in which a handsomely turned perform ance of Beethoven's Kakadu Variations (Op. 121a) was fol lowed by a splendid interpre tation of Debussy's Proses lyriques, which in turn was followed by a vivid and stirring account of Dvork's Piano Quintet in A (Op. 81).

title: Nixon Takes Holiday In the Virgin Islands
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Vir gin Islands, Jan. 29Presi dent Nixon settled in today at a Dutch plantation villa for a weekend of rest, read ing and backyard barbecues.

title: Giants Put Emphasis on Bolstering Defense
description: The Giants finished their 1971 draft yesterday by pick ing four linebackers, one de fensive tackle, one offensive guard, a tight end, a wide re ceiver, a running back and a quarterbacknone of them with startling reputations.

title: Pennsylvania Upsets Order Banning Electrocution Law
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 29 (AP)  Pennsylvania Attorney General J. Shane Creamer for mally rescinded today the opinion of his Republican pred ecessor that Pennsylvania's electrocution low violates the United States Constitution.

title: Music: Miss Ushioda and Seiji Ozawa
description: Manchurianborn, Japanese and Russiantrained, most recently a pupil of Josef Szigeti, Masuko Ushioda came on the stage of Phil harmonic Hall on Thursday night to play the Second Violin Concerto by Bla Bar tk. She did not exactly walk to stage center; she sort of was wafted. A slight figure, she wore a gauzy gown that had batlike ap pendages, and she looked like a fairy in Oberon's retinue, ready to be picked up and blown away by any passing wind.

title: CITY OFFERS PLAN FOR ARBITRATION
description: Herbert L. Haber, Director of Labor Relations for the city, suggested yesterday that co ordinated bargaining by muni cipal unions and final arbitra tion of differences might be the way to resolve the city's com plicated labor problems.

title: BUDGET PREPARED BY A NEW OFFICE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The 1972 budget is the first pre pared by the Office of Manage ment and Budget, formed by the President last summer to replace the Bureau of the Budget and concentrate budget decisionmaking in the White House.

title: In Giacometti's Graphic Art, Adventure
description: Although the sculpture of Alberto Giacometti (1901 1966) enjoys an honored place in the history of mod ern art, and the artist's paintings have likewise been much acclaimed, his graphic art has tended to receive scant attention. Yet Giaco metti would be assured the status of a master had he produced nothing but his graphic oeuvre. The art of drawing was central to his esthetic vision, and he brought to the graphic media all the pressure, anxiety and eloquence of his extraordi nary sensibility.

title: ExV.M.I. Coach Gets Job
description: GREENVILLE, N.C., Jan. 29 (AP)  Vito Ragazzo, former head football coach at Virginia Military Institute, was hired today as an assistant to the head coach at East Carolina, Sonny Randle.

title: Hopes of Arranging Laos Peace Negotiations Dim
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 24 The prospects for a separate settlement of the war in Laos have receded again with another failure by representa tives of Vietntlane and the Communistled Pathet Lao to agree on conditions for peace negotiations during two months of desultory contacts here.

title: Developments Changed Current Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The recession, those angry Post Of fice Department workers in New York City, welfarerights leaders and a majority of those in Congress unknowingly worked together during past months to turn the Govern ment's budget for this current year into something that is a far cry from what President Nixon foresaw this time last year.

title: Priorities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Federal budget for 1972, massive as it is, is part of a still bigger economic aggregate the trillion dollar United States econ omy.

title: $47 GHANDI FIRST IN SNOWBALL PACE
description: YONKERS, Jan. 29 James Darren, regarded by some ob servers as the best Down Under import since Cardigan Bay, failed to live up to his reputa tion tonight. Instead, a 221 shot, Ghandi, won the final of the Snowball Pacing Series at Yonkers Raceway in a driving snowstorm.

title: YOKO NOZAKI SHOWS FACILITY AS PIANIST
description: In matters of sheer facility, Yoko Nozaki, who played at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night, is a satisfying pianist. Her fingerwork is even, her phrasing neat as a pin. She is not a big pianist in the grand Manner, but she has a useful range of loudness and softness that she applies tastefully.

title: STATE U. COURSES TARGET OF INQUIRY
description: The research office of the State Legislature, acting for a group of Senators and Assemblymen, has asked the presidents of 16 State Univer sity colleges for information on the content and thrust of political and social science courses, particularly those deal ing with revolution and the Establishment.

title: G.O.P. WOMEN QUIT STATE COMMITTEE
description: The women of the Republi can party in New York State, angered because the party's state committee took away their control of the commit tee's No. 2 post, declared their independence of the committee yesterday.

title: Market Place : McDonnell Bid On Conductron
description: Unfortunately, the story has an all too familiar ring. The ladyshe requested ano nymity because her husband, aged 70, is a $75aweek run ner in Wall Streetsays she is a survivor of a Nazi con centration camp.

title: Miss Holmberg Bride of Ensign In the Suburbs
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Jan. 29  Miss Margaret Dodds Holmberg, daughter of Albert William Holmberg Jr., president of The Chattanooga Times, and Mrs. Holmberg of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., formerly of Pelham, was mar ried here this evening to Ens. Roy Demarest Duckworth 3d, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Duckworth of Bronxville.

title: Rockefeller Pyramid
description: Pyramidal is the word for the fiscal irresponsibility symbolized by the South Mall in Albany. Governor Rock efeller's extravaganza of five blocks of state buildings, underground arcades, lagoons, museums, a library and amphitheater has long since turned into a chain reaction of miscalculations.

title: Nun in Alleged Plot Ordered Released Without Bail Despite U.S. Objections
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 Over the objections of the De partment of Justice, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit here today ordered Sister Jogues Egan released from jail without bail pending appeal of a lower court order citing her for contempt.

title: Concert by Rostropovich In Philadelphia Canceled
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP) The first official cancellation of an American concert by the Soviet cellist Mstislav Rostro povich was received today by the Philadelphia Orchestra.

title: Lindsays Skiing in Vermont
description: Mayor Lindsay and his wife are spending the weekend ski ing in Vermont. Accompanied by Mr. Lindsay's brother Rob ert, they drove last night to South Londonderry.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON LONDON BOARD
description: The purchase of Government bonds dominated trading on the London stock exchange yes terday. Trading was described as heavy.

title: Washington Wallops L.I.U.
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 29 (AP) Washington's Huskies held Long Island University to three field goals in the first nine minutes tonight en route to a 98?? basketball victory.

title: HELPWANTED INDEX IS UP FOR 2D MONTH
description: Helpwanted advertising in December rose for the second consecutive month and stood at 152 per cent of the 1957 1959 average, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: Prices Increased Sharply in December
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Government reported today that consumer prices rose sharply again in December, bringing to a close the nation's second most inflationary year, since the Korean War.

title: Books of The Times
description: CHARLES SUMNER AND THE RIGHTS OF MAN. By David Donald. 595 pages. Knopf $15.

title: RECALL PETITIONS ON WHELAN VOIDED
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 29An attempt to force a recall elec tion to replace Mayor Thomas J. Whelan appeared to have failed today when the City Clerk announced that 13,098 signatures on recall petitions were invalid.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The numbers are overwhelming and the prose is simultaneously bloated and dense as usual. But among the dizzying charts and slogans of the second Nixon, budget, there is at least as much political doctrine as there is economic strategy. Above all else, President Nixon is saying in this budget that, after a decade of Fed eral concern about what is done with social spending at home, he wants to concentrate for a while on how it is done.

title: Education
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29In hard cash, the amount of money the Admin istration intends to spend on education in the coming fiscal year will rise only about 5 per cent, to $5.8billion.

title: JACK TAYLOR
description: Jack Taylor, a salesman for Harmay Dresses, 498 Seventh Avenue, died on Wednesday at University Hospital. He was 63 years old.

title: HUDSON H. BUBAR, 92, A RETIRED ENGINEER
description: Hudson H. Bubar, who re tired in 1947 as head of Bubar Dust Systems, 15 Park Row, which developed dustcollecting apparatus for power plants, sugar refineries and cement plants, died Thursday In High land Hall, Essex, Conn. He was 92 years old and formerly lived in Hamburg Cove, Lyme, Conn.

title: Kuwait's Ancient Sailing Vessels Are Vanishing
description: AL DOHA, Kuwait, Jan. 10 The clang of hammers, the pop pop of mallets hitting wood, the scraping sound of adzes being honed this morning drowned out the whisper of the Persian Gulf's turquoise waters lapping on Al Doha beach.

title: Civil Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  President Nixon asked today for an increase of almost 100 per cent over last year in money to help minorities. The funds would support programs ranging from aiding school desegregation to fighting sickle cell anemia.

title: A BIG BAND ROARS INTO THE DOWNBEAT
description: A new, kingsized band came come roaring onto the jazz scene yesterday afternoon at Downbeat, Lexington Avenue at 42d Street. The Horns of Manhattan, a 25piece band organized and led by Gene Roland who used to play trumpet and write arrange ments for Stan Kenton, made an impressive debut as part of the Jazz Adventures series, held every Friday at noon

title: Art: A Rich Show of Italian Drawings
description: If you are at all pressed for time, drop this and get out to the Metropolitan Mu seum where The 18th Cen tury in Italy: Drawings from New York Collections, opens today. But if you have a minute, let me tell you about a dream I had more than 50 years ago as a small boy in Dallas.

title: Claims to Distant Isles Arouse Chinese Here
description: A dispute between the Jap anese Government and both Communist China and National ist China over five tiny un inhabited islands in the East China Sea has aroused Chinese students here, spurring intense political activity.

title: 8 More Arrested at SitIn At A.&P. Executive Offices
description: Eight person were arrested yesterday when they refused to end their sitin at the ex ecutive offices of the A. & P. foodstore chain at 420 Lexing ton Avenue near 43d Street.

title: Wesson Is Selected Again To Head U.S. Pony Clubs
description: Rufus Wesson or Honoeye Falls, N. Y., was reelected president of the United States Pony Clubs yesterday at the final session of the group's two day convention at the Plaza Hotel

title: POLICEMAN CLEARED OF PERJURY CHARGE
description: A suspended patrolman was acquitted yesterday of perjury charges arising from a special rackets grand jury investiga tion of a social club in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn said to have been used as a torture chamber by organized crime.

title: He's Had a Varied Life and His Design Collection Shows It
description: Dressed as he is in a Turn bull & Asser shirt and made toorder London leathers and twillall sixfootfive of him talking as he does in a very British accent, arriving as he has with impressive decorating credentials (for Lords and Ladies and Vidal Sassoon), who would dream that William Billy McCarty hails from Miami?

title: Israelis Doubt New Shooting
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 29  Israeli lookouts along the Suez Canal reported today that there were no signs of Egyptian, prepara tions for offensive or defensive actions. The reports contra dicted news dispatches that the Egyptians were massing forces at the canal.

title: License Deadline Extended
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29 (UPI)The deadline for renewing auto mobile registrations and driv er's licenses that expire Jan. 31 was extended today until Feb. 3 by Motor Vehicle Commissioner Vincent L. Tofany. He cited the effects of weather conditions, especially in western New York, as the reason for the ex tension.

title: Cambodian Sweep Continues
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 29 (AP)  Government forces continued a sweep of outlying areas around Pnompenh today in an effort to clear out enemy troops who have been harass ing the capital's outer defense line. No significant contact was reported for a fourth day of the operation.

title: Art: Downtown Scene
description: The marriage between art and technology has rarely been a happy or successful one. If anything, the exhibi tions illustrating such unions, like the ones held within the last few years at several gal leries and at the Museum of Modern Art and the Brooklyn Museum, have been, more than anything else, outright encouragements that the two had better find another way to get along or separate.

title: 5 OF 7 NEW ISSUES ADVANCE IN WEEK
description: The newissue market, where shares of companies that have never had public owners are traded, registered its sixth con secutive advance this week in very active trading.

title: Auto Production Declines in Week To 179,346 Units
description: DETROIT, Jan. 29 (AP)  Auto output in the United States eased a bit this week as General Motors used less over time in its plants and the Ford Motor Company trimmed oper ations for the week at its Dear born and Wixom, Mich., plants.

title: Suns Stop Blazers, 131122
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 29 (AP)Dick Van Arsdale and Clem Haskins scored 19 points between them in the final quar ter tonight, pacing the Phoenix Suns to a 131122 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: U.S. to Seek Court Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The United States will soon propose that its dispute with Ecuador and with other Latin American nations over their claims to a 200mile territorial jurisdiction be referred to the International Court of Justice.

title: Princeton Plans to Cut Staff and Raise Tuition to Reduce Deficit
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 29 Princeton University announced today that it planned to cut 100 people from its payroll next year, raise tuition fees and put severe restraints on faculty salaries in an effort to reduce a deficit.

title: Instrumental Works Stand Out In Multimedia From Cleveland
description: Hunter College's New Image of Sound series played host to an organization from Cleve land on Thursday night, the Donald ErbLawrence Berger Multi Media Theater. To this musically oriented listener, it was the purely instrumental works that were most satisfy ing and stole the show from the more spectacular and com plex multimedia efforts.

title: Jordanian Moves Reported
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 29 According to reliable informa tion reaching here today from Amman, Jordan has moved mil itary reinforcements to her ceasefire line with Israel in the last three days.

title: Blase Mood at the Cape A Disquieting Contrast
description: COCOA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29  There are 11 large motels along A1A, the main highway here, and not one has lettered any good luck wishes to the Apollo 14 astronauts on its roadside signpost.

title: Pipeline in Syria Is Reopened After Nine Months
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 29  Americanpumped Saudi Arab ian oil began flowing to the Mediterranean coast today after an interruption of nine months and after the trans Arabia pipeline had been re paired.

title: Year of the Quarterback Is Theme as Draft Ends
description: Professional football's draft of college players concluded yesterday with the selection of 170 athletes on the last 10 of the 17 rounds of selec tion. The total number of players drafted in the two day session was 442 by the National Football League's 26 teams.

title: Liguori Posts 4:00.6 and Takes Wanamaker Mile 3d Year in Row at Garden
COUPLE WIN A STAY IN ADOPTION DISPUTE
description: A couple who adopted a baby girl eight months ago won a temporary stay yesterday of a court order requiring them to return the child to her natural mother.

title: Transportation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Nixon Administration's new budget reveals an optimistic commitment to reviving the supersonic transport airplane, despite the political and practical problems that nearly killed the program last year.

title: Highlights of the Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Following are highlights of President Nixon's new budget:

title: UGANDAN WANTS TIES TO CONTINUE
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Jan. 29 Maj. Gen. Idi Amin, Uganda's new military head of state, today called together heads of more than 30 diplomatic mis sions in Uganda and told them that Uganda wanted diplomatic relations already established to continue.

title: 2 L.I. ACCOUNTANTS CONVICTED OF BRIBE
description: Two Long Island accountants were convicted here last night of conspiracy and attempted bribery of a tax agent to in fluence an investigation of al leged corruption in the Inter nal Revenue Service.

title: Following 2 Years of Decline, Pentagon Aims Budget Upward
Science/Medicine
description: Perhaps man will never stand on the surface of Venus, for its conditions are properly described as hellish. But if he does so, enveloped in a space suit or capsule with extraordinary in sulating properties, it will be a remarkable experience.

title: What's It Like? Tale a Trip and Find Out!
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y.Clear the track to the half. The track is clear. Twoman racingpractice sled on the line, United States Air Force, driven by Gary Sheffield. Aaaaand, they're off!

title: The FemLib Case Against Sigmund Freud
description: NOT long ago a man in his early 40's sat listening to the dis cussion at a women's libera tion meeting. That he and other men were there meant the organization was among the more moderate of its kind; yet he became increasingly agitated as the evening went on. Fi nally rising to his feet, he proceeded to tell the women, his voice husky with sincerity, that he understood and sympathized with their com plaints but was certain they were on the wrong track. The answer to their problems, as it was the answer to those of men as well, was psycho analysis. The word was scarcely out when he was assailed by hoots, cat calls and epithets from everywhere in the room. Bewildered, he sat down, while the people around him mar veled at the innocence that had led him to press so wrong a button.

title: GRIMNES CAPTURES MIDDLEBURY'JUMP
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Jan. 30 (AP)A 177foot leap on his final attempt won the third an nual Middlebury College invita tional jumping tournament for Martin Grimnes of the Univer sity of Vermont.

title: Chinese Students Here Protest Tokyo Claim to Isles
description: About 1,000 Chinese students from cities along the East Coast gathered here yesterday to pro test Japan's claim to the Sen kaku Islands, a potential oil bearing area northeast of Taiwan.

title: Kings Point Beats Babson By 7964, as Moore Stars
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., Jan. 30 Lou Moore, a junior from Levittown, N.Y., scored 25 points today as the United States Merchant Marine Acade my basketball team defeated Babson College, 7954.

title: For Young Readers
description: Laurie James is an adolescent be coming acquainted withnot sex and drugs  bathtubs, elevators, towns and people. It's not always easy to believe in her background but it's worth the effort.

title: Roberta Jackier Will Be Married
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 30Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Jackier of the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Roberta Jackier, to Arthur H. Schain, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Schain of Harrison.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Reynolds & Co. is one of the few major Wall Street brokerage houses that fin ished in the black last year; in fact, it had one of the most profitable years in its 40year history.

title: Have You Dug Wall Drug?
description: SOMEWHERE in Vietnam a couple of G.I.'s pose for a picture with a sign reading 12,301 miles to Wall Drug Store, In Venice grinning tourists hold up a notice in the Piazza San Marco: 6,250 miles to Wall Drug Store. A sign in the Paris Mtro reads: 5,961 miles to Wall Drug Store. One in La hore, Pakistan, reads: Wall Drug Store 10,728 miles.

title: C.C.N.Y. Edges Stony Brook
description: Art Baclawski's jump shot bounced off the rim as time ran out last night, insuring a 7170 victory for City College over Stony Brook at the victor's Wingate gymnasium.

title: An invert, playwright, devil
description: A careful and exact title. Shakespeare's Iago, like any other stage character, is words on a page, and behind those words there is no solidity. Iago has no past anterior to the opening act, and no future af ter the final curtain. His per sonality and psychology are a matter of as though, of pre tense that he is a real person, of supposition and illusion. No one can dig out a motive for his actions that shall be singly and wholly convincing, and so we must have the late Stanley Ed gar Hyman's pluralism, the some approaches of his title. The approaches are, needless to say, not alternatives: they are to be combined in multilinear counterpoint. But, in Shakes peare criticism, we have all supped full of complexity anti can open our jaws without dis comfort for the most plurally layered of sandwiches.

title: The World
description: An economic and political dis pute over fishing rights that has smoldered for years between South American countries and certain other nations, especially the United States, developed new heat last week.

title: BRANDT IS SEEKING FORCE REDUCTION
description: BERLIN, Jan. 30Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany appealed today for peace in Europe, declaring that his main political purpose in proposing cooperation with the Soviet bloc was to bring about a mutually balanced reduction of forces from the heart of the Continent.

title: Child to Mrs. Klein Jr.
description: A daughter was born Jan. 3 to Mr. and Mrs. Louis Klein Jr. of New York in Doctors Hospital. Mrs. Klein is the former Jane Holzman. Her husband is a principal in the Anvil Management Car poration, an investment con cern. The child has been named Alexandra Elizabeth.

title: New York
description: At breakfast in their $80a month Harlem walkup, Cornelius listens intently as his wife tells him of the dream she had last night. Together, they study the Gold Seal Dream Book, a $2 bargain that links scientifically selected numbers to 10,000 dif ferent words and they discuss the significance of the fact his favorite Daily News cartoon .appears that day on page 64.

description: The City government's top lawyer agreed yesterday to halt his private legal practice, at least for a while.

description: To the Editor:

title: Purpose of Laos Drive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30 (AP)An objective of South Vietnamese incursion into Southern Laos would be to sever the Ho Chi Minh trail, the network of roads used by North Vietnam to send rein forcements and supplies to South Vietnam and Cambodia.

title: News of the Riallto
description: YOU never heard of George Mason? Who has? And yet, he's going to be a candidate for the Presidency in 1976. For the moment, to be sure, Mason exists strict ly on paper. But any day now he'll be breathing and, by Feb. 22, rehearsing for The Selling of the President, a musicalized version of Joe McGinniss's topselling account of the Nixon tele vision campaign, The Selling of the President 1968.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Body of Westchester Man, Missing 2 Days, Is Found
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y. Jan. 30  The body of Jack Heller, 59yearold vice president of the House of Lords, manufac turers of women's wear in New York City, was found yesterday embedded in ice off a pier in a boatyard here.

title: WARREN MARCHESSAULT
description: Warren T. Marchessault, a member of the legal depart ment of Batten, Barton, Dur stine & Osborn, the advertis ing agency, died Friday of cancer at Westchester Square Hospital, the Bronx. He was 55 years old and lived at 1670 Metropolitan Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Dahlberg on Dreiser, Anderson and Dahlberg
description: The most prodigious mishap of the young American writer is that he has no Master, or an elder of letters to guide him; and so he relies wholly upon himself, a very unreliable teacher. I was lucky; I knew Theo dore Dreiser and Sherwood Ander son.

title: Apollo 14 Ready to Fly Today to. Moon's Highlands
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 30Three astronauts, including the first American space pilot, were set tonight to embark tomorrow on a crucial voyage to the moon's rugged and ancient highlands in search of clues to the solar system's birth.

title: BALLET BY BEJART MAKES U.S. DEBUT
description: The Program

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The. Nixon budget is so complex, so, unlike the Nixon of the past, so unRepublican that it defies rational analysis. So, in the confusion, we have had to fall back on our old electronic truth detector Uniquack for help.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Seymour Asks Fight on Official Graft
description: District attorneys of the State of New York were told yesterday that they should be more zealous about wiping out official corruption in order to raise public opinion of public officials.

title: FUND DRIVE BACKS ACQUITTED MAYOR
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 30Cit izens of San Diego began col lecting a $15,000 gift of atone ment for their Mayor this week, after the almost complete col lapse of a bribery scandal in volving him and seven other public officials.

title: Iowa in Front
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 30 (UPI) Fred Brown scored three straight baskets with less than four minutes left today to help Iowa fight off a rally and post its first Big Ten victory of the season, 8785, over North western.

title: Harold Gabow Plans to Marry Dr. Patricia Anne Acquaviva
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Pa., Jan. 30Mr. and Mrs. Rich ard Helmintoller have an nounced the engagement of Mrs. Helmintoller's daughter, Dr. Patricia Anne Acquaviva, to Harold Gabow. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Gabow of Hollis Hills, Queens, New York. A wedding in June is planned.

title: FitzGibbon Seeded First
description: Herb FitzGibbon of New York, the defending titleholder, was seeded first yesterday for the annual Eastern men's in door tennis championship start ing Friday evening at the Sta dium Tennis Center in the Bronx. Following him are King Van Nostrand of Brightwaters, L. I.; John Adams of Haver ford, Pa., and Bob Barker of Port Washington, L. I. Forty players are in the draw.

title: Something In the Wind
description: Something in the Wind tells about the withdrawal from life of a young girl whose boy friend and mentor has been killed in a car accident. (Charles made my mind  and if he's really dead, then I don't know what will go on in my head.) Brooke Kincaid drifts through her first year at college, feeling selfconsciously disoriented, until she runs into a golfing jock named Bentley T. Hooksa cussing, loving fool who has what it takes to snap Brooke out of her unresponsive mood. Miss Smith has a nice flair for thumbnail impressions and for describing the back ground of her heroine's crisis.

title: ALBANIA SOFTENS PROMAO STANCE
description: BELURADE, Jan. 30  pro Chinese propaganda has de dined in Albania, but the Com munist Government still keeps up its attacks on everything from Soviet revisionism to long hair and rock music, a Yugoslav writer who recently made his second visit to Alba nia in five has reported.

title: Bonisolli, Tenor, To Bow in Barber At the Met Feb. 24
description: Franco Bonisolli, an Italian tenor, will make his Metropoli tan Opera debut during the 24th week of the company's current season appearing as Count Almaviva in Rossini's Il Barbiere di Siviglia on Feb. 24. The cast for the performance will also include Gail Robinson as Rosina, Sherrill Milnes as Figaro and Fernando Corena as Dr. Bartolo. Thomas Schippers will conduct.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: West Virginia Wins
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Jan. 30 (AP)The homecourt charm held for the Mountaineers of West Virginia as they posted a 10596 basketball victory over George Washington today.

title: Stamps
description: THE private vendors now privileged to offer mail service In Eng land during the cur rent postal strike are carry ing on a longestablished practice, especially in their creation of stamps that are affixed to the letters or par cels they are handling. Simi lar services were offered in limited areas during mail stoppages in New York and other cities last year. It was not a national stoppage, as most cities were not struck, and New York mails had at least some service when the Army was called in.

title: Maple Leafs Turn Back Canadiens, 54, as Ullman Accounts for Two Goals
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 30 (UPI) Norm Ullman scored two goals and Paul Henderson added 4 points tonight to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 54 victory over the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Bina Hayes Is Fiancee Of Randall Thompson Jr.
description: Miss Delia M. C. Hayes and Randall Thompson Jr., plan to be married on March 27 in the chapel of Villa Aurelia in Rome, once used for de fense by Giuseppe Garibaldi, the Italian patriot and sol dier. The villa's topfloor ballroom will be the scene of the reception for about 200 or more wedding guests.

title: Rehitch Wins by 5 Lengths, Pays $4 at Lincoln Downs
description: LINCOLN, R. I., Jan. 30 (AP) Rehitch streaked five fur longs in 58  seconds today for one of the fastest clockings at Lincoln Downs this year, romping to a fivelength vic tory in the $7,500 Newport Handicap.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Troubled Airlines
description: The nation's airlines, whose profits last year went into a tailspin, are hoping for brighter skies in 1971.

title: Princeton Takes 6 of 7 Field Events and Retains Jersey College Track Crown
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 30 Princeton University's track team captured first places in six of seven field events today and successfully defended its title in the second New Jersey college championships.

title: Dance
description: NEVER want to be a choreographer! Choose some relatively easy profession such as Pres ident of the United States, or walking across the Niagara Falls on a tightrope. Chore ography is not simple.

title: Alarmed by Growing Pollution, Italians Are Demanding Action
description: ROME, Jan. 30Huge oil slicks fouling Rome's beaches, A hecatomb of fish in waste laden rivers and sundarkening smog are causing ecological alarm in Italy.

title: Art
description: THERE can hardly be a more vivid contrast of esthetic intentions than that offered by the current exhibitions of two contemporary sculptors, Er nest Trova and Julius Tobias. Trova, 44, an artist with an established reputation whose sculpture for years has been dedicated to a recurrent themethe falling man is currently the subject of an exhibition at the Pace Gal lery, 32 East 57th Street. To bias, 55, less wellknown and an advocate of the new envi ronmental modes of art, is presently showing at the Max Hutchinson Gallery, 127 Greene Street. It is not sim ply that these artists display markedly different sensibili ties, but that their concep tions of what sculpture is or ought to be place them worlds apart.

title: Soviet and Canada Agree On Industrial Cooperation
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 30 (Reuters) Canada and the Soviet Union have signed their first industrial cooperation agreement provid ing for scientific and techno logical exchanges.

title: BELGIAN SOCIALISTS PICK 2 PRESIDENTS
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 30The Belgian Socialist party has ap pointed two party presidents, representing the Dutchspeak ing Flemish and Frenchspeak ing Walloon communities.

title: Shot From Patrolman's Gun Blinds Friend in Right Eye
description: A civilian employe of the Police Department was blinded in the right eye yesterday by a shot fired from a policeman's gun. The policeman said the gun had discharged accidental ly when he took it off to put it in the glove compartment of his car.

title: No More Waiting!
description: IT all started, as Vladimir says, a million years ago, back in 1955 when Michael Myerberg, at the suggestion of Thornton Wild er, rang me up in the wilds of Wisconsin to ask if I might be interested in directing Bert Lahr and Tom Ewell on Broadway in something called Waiting for Godot by some one named Samuel Beckett, a mad Irishman living in France, whose play was cur rently a hit of some propor tions in London.

title: The much, the many and the few
description: Achtung, Jaeger! Sudden ly Peter Leushake, the Heinkel's observer, saw three fighters curving up steeply from below. The words were hardly past his lips when bullets ripped into the Reinkel and killed him.  Only Unteroffizier Karl Missy, in the top rear gun position, re mained to defend the stricken aircraft. He aimed carefully and fired at the leading Hurricane.

title: Hull Nears Another Milestone: Richard's 544 Goals
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) The hairline has receded. The nose has been broken repeatedly. Even the jaw once had to be wired.

title: Mary Hobler Is Betrothed
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 30 The engagement of Miss Mary Bassett Hobler to Eric A. Hyson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Archibald M. Hyson of New ark, Del., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Hobler.

title: Reader's Report
description: The latest novel by William Goldman covers a day in the life of Amos McCracken, song writ er, doting papa, divorc and allaround nut. Out of his hero's tender sensibilities and hyper active fantasy life, Mr. Gold man whips up a fugue in which the two are hardly distin guishable. McCracken takes his little girl to the park on visita tion day, where she is involved in a playground accident. From this point, on, daddy goes into an orbit that finds him in a hospital emergency ward, in the apartments of his mistress and his treacherous excollaborator, in pawnshops, in an airline ter minal and in shock. Weaving together flashbacks and current happenings, the author com poses his hero's personality with offhand expertise. It is a virtuoso performance in which the lightning tempo counteracts a tendency to cloy.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Green Light
description: The revised railroad network announced by Transpor tation Secretary Volpe flashes a green light for continued rail passenger service in this countrybut much more has to be done if service is not only to be continued but improved to a satisfactory level.

title: City Opera to Open Season on Feb. 17 With Cenerentola
description: The New York City Opera will open its spring season at the New York State Theater on Feb. 17 with a performance of Rossini's La Cenerentola. The role of Cinderella will be taken by Susan Marsee, and the cast will also include Lois Crane, Beverly Evans, Kenneth Riegel and Richard Stilwell. Jorge Master will conduct.

title: Jordan Reports She Seized Arms Smuggled Into Capital
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 30 The Jordanian authorities have reportedly seized nine tons of weapons and ammunition that were smuggled into Amman last night by Al Fatah, the ma jor Palestinian guerrilla organ ization.

title: HANLEY AND LYONS TAKE FIELD EVENTS
description: Jack Hanley of Maryland won the Millrose Athletic As sociation 16pound shotput yesterday at Baker Field. Han ley, a senior and the Intercol legiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America champion, triumphed with a toss of 58 feet. John Jessup of North Car olina was second and Robert Brady, a Manhattan College freshman, third.

title: Post Hits High of 114 Points
description: BROOKVILE, L.I., Jan. 30 C. W. Post set a school scoring record of 114 points as it de feated Merrimack, 11480, to night in a NorthEast League game.

title: FAVORECIDIAN WINS PIMLICO HANDICAP
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 30 (AP) Hickory Tree Stable's Favore cidian responded to the whip of Billy Passmore in the final six teenth of a mile today and won the $27,800 City of Baltimore Handicap at Pimlico.

title: ST. JOHN'S DOWNS DARTMOUTH, 6656
description: Greg Cluess provided the firsthalf offensive muscle and Mel Davis led the attack after the intermission last night as St. John's defeated Dartmouth, 6656, before 3,490 fans in the Redmen's Alumni Gymnasium.

title: FIVE METS RETURN SIGNED CONTRACTS
description: The New York Mets received five signed contracts yesterday, raising the total of satisfied players on their major league roster to 26, Fourteen remain unsigned.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Theater in Washington, D.C.
description: WASHINGTON, D.C.

title: In Brief
description: If I was to state the length of time he spoke, the editor of a Kentucky newspaper wrote of William Jennings Bryan's first soaring speech in the House of Representatives, I would say that it was about an hour and a half. In fact, the speech had enthralled the House and its visitors for fully three hours and four minutes. If I were to estimate the length of Charles Morrow Wilson's biog raphy of Bryan, I would say it is about a thousand pages. Ac tually it is less than half that.

title: Apollo 14
description: There is a special tension that surrounds Apollo 14, its astronauts, its ground crew and the vast United States space organization these final hours before this after noon's scheduled launch in the fourth attempt to land men on the moon. This flight represents a fateful and perhaps decisive step in this country's program of manned lunar exploration.

title: Pop
description: IKE & TINA TURNER: Workin' Together (LST 7650 Liberty) . After a decade or more of scratching it out on the r & b circuit, Ike and Tina Turner finally are beginning to receive the rewards their talent deserves. The formula they have developed is sim ple enough: keep the soul phrasing and r & b rhythms, add their own versions of pop tunes like Let It Be, Get Back and Proud Mary, and mix it all to gether with a heavy dose of Tina Turner's indescribably rough, driving voice. (The product is so effective that I'm surprised more black groups haven't taken the same route; perhaps they will.) The principal ingredi ent, however, is Ike Turner's impeccable sense of struc ture balance and musical pac ing. He has carefully avoid ed producing black covers of white pop songs. When Tina Turner sings songs by the Beatles and John Fogarty, she finds qualities that al most make them sound like new material. The lyrics to Let It Be, for example, are changed from When I find myself in times of trouble, Mother Mary comes to me to When I find myself in times of trouble, evil thoughts they come to me  The alteration quite literally changes the meaning of the tune, giving it an erotic qual ity that is devastatingly ap propriate for Miss Turner's aggressive sexuality.

title: SMUTFREE
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: News of Dogs
description: Friends of Little Daddie will be glad to know that he is frisky as ever and right now is enjoying life on a Florida trip aboard a trailer with his owners, Mr. and Mrs. E. W. Tipton Jr. of Kingsport, Tenn. He's the miniature pinscher who in 1963 was retired from the show ring after setting a world record for the breed75 best in show awards. His proper name is Ch. Rebel Roc's Casanova von Kurt and he is 12 years old. He was a spirited show man who made a hit with his high hackney gait. He al ways appeared to enjoy his work.

title: Trot Dinner Site Shifted
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 (UPI)  The United States Harness Writers' Association's 23d awards dinner will be held here this year after being held for 22 years in the New York area. The dinner will be held Feb. 21 at Liberty Bell Park.

title: Miss Murphy Becomes Bride
description: WILTON, Conn., Jan. 30 Miss Maryann Elizabeth Mur phy was married here at noon today to Michael Reed Poliquin. The Rev. Arthur Norton performed the cere mony and celebrated the nuptial mass in Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church.

title: Son for the Lerners
description: A son was born last Wednesday to Mr. and Mrs. Laurence M. Lerner in the LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Ler ner is the former Susan Goodstein. Her husband is with Drummond Associates, Inc., an executive placement concern here. The child, the couple's second, has been named Marc Harold.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: New York critics embrace ??

title: the traveler's world
description: ADDIS ABABA, EthiopiaThe antic ipation of Ethiopia by today's traveler is not diminished by the reality of it because this country more than lives up to its tourist organ ization's propaganda.

title: CHARLES GLAVIN, FIRST BOSTON AIDE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 30 Charles C. Glavin, chairman of the executive committee of the First Boston Corporation, investment banking house, died today in Greenwich Hospital after a stroke. He was 60 years old and lived at 34 Copper Beach Road.

title: POOR AND UFFORD GAIN SEMIFINALS
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 30 Tom Poor, the defender; Charles Ufford, the 1960 and 1961 champion; Maurice Heck scher and Kalid Mir gained the semifinal round of the 30th At lantic Coast squash racquets championship today by scoring two victories apiece at the ChalfonteHaddon Hall Racquet Club.

title: Language mirrors the world, or does it?
description: Ludwig Wittgenstein (1889 1951) was one of the leading philosophers of this century; yet his work, if not his name, is little known outside narrow academic circles. The main rea son for this is obvioushis principal works, the Tractatus LogicoPhilosophicus and the Philosophical Investigations, are so difficult as to be virtu ally incomprehensible to any one except the specialist, David Pears, himself a philosopher of some eminence, has done an admirable job of making Witt genstein's thought accessible to the nonspecialist. His book is divided into two parts, corres ponding to the two major peri ods of Wittgenstein's work; and there is a long introduction in which Wittgenstein's thought is placed in the larger context of modern philosophy.

title: SLAYING AROUSES CHAPEL HILL, N.C.
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jan. 30 This beautiful college town has seldom protested its national reputation as a charming island of liberalism amid a swamp of Southern backwardness.

title: National Notes
description: The power failed and the lights went out one morning last week in parts of Brooklyn and sections of Elizabeth and Newark, N. J. The blackout lasted less than an hour, but for those affected and for millions more in New York City and the rest of the northeastit may have been a foretaste of things to come.

title: Pollution Is Linked to Genetic Defects
description: PORTLAND, Ore,, Jan. 30 Pollution not only is shortening man's life but also is leading to genetic defects, three scien tists said here yesterday in a symposium on the effect of the environment on personal health.

title: Our police are precious to us, and we need policemen we can trust and respect
description: Most Americans have a simple minded view of the police. To many, the policeman is a mythical figure made up of one part Officer Friend ly, one part allknowing detective and one part sternjawed trooper who, armed with shotguns and gas mask, is protecting America from rampaging students and angry blacks. To many other Americans, the po liceman is the pig, a grotesque figure of brutality, hatred and cor ruption.

title: Yale to Let Students Spread Out Tuition For Up to 35 Years
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 30The trustees of Yale University reportedly agreed in principle today to allow students to pay their tuition over a 35year period.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: For Young Readers
description: Ivan Bunin, the Russian writer who won the Nobel Prize in 1933, is perhaps best known in this coun try for The Gentleman From San Francisco. It's curious to realize that Velga, written for children and unencumbered by ideology, is a much greater story.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Bar  Pat Manufacturing Company, a blackownedand operated electronics concern, proudly and hopefully hung up its shingle in Bridgeport, Conn., last fall. George M. Bellinger, founder and presi dent, says he's still hopeful, despite the nationwide sag in the electronics business.

title: ANTISEMITISM AND ANTIZIONISM
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Sing Along With Fridtjof Nansen
description: WHENEVER I am asked the diffi cult question: What, sir, is the best way to get to know the peculiar ethos of a faroff, alien people? I clear my throat and respond in one of two waysWho is your dentist? or, if the questioner dis plays no remarkable inlay work, Through their music, clod, how else? It was in this spirit that I set out to record the actual musical utterances made by the valiant folk who inhabit the vast Arctic expanse of Fridtjof Nan sen Land, which you geography buffs know is somewhere around Novaya Zemlya. The hardwon product of my travail is the important, soon to be re leased record album, Songs of Fridtjof Nansen Land (Arcane Label, $1.98). My albumliner notes are printed here in order to prove my original thesis.

title: Rally Wins for Purdue
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., Jan. 30 (UPI)Purdue reeled off 7 straight points to overcome a deficit and gain a 7974 victory over Marshall tonight.

title: Susan Howard Plans Nuptials
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 30Miss Susan Dunlap How ard and James H. Case 3d, teachers at the Brookline High School, plan to be married April 17.

title: Crete Reduces Sentences For U.S. Hashish Runners
description: ATHENS, Jan. 30  An ap peals court in Crete today re duced prison sentences given to five Americans involved in an attempt to smuggle $3million in hashish from Lebanon into the United States by plane.

title: Japan Is Planning To CodeNumber All of Her People
description: TOKYO, Jan. 30 (Reuters) The Japanese Government is planning to introduce code numbering of the country's 104 million citizens.

title: LINDSAY PROPOSES A CAPITAL BUDGET OF $1.55BILLION
description: Mayor Lindsay proposed what his aides called a non austerity construction budget of $1.55billion for fiscal 1971 72 yesterday, but with a warn ing that the city might be com pelled to curtail some capital projects in the next year.

title: Canada Aids Ceylon Project
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 30 (Reuters)Canada and Ceylon have signed a development loan agreement under which Canada will supply $4.5 million and assist in establishing a mechanized logging project.

title: Baseball Writers to Frolic Tonight
description: The sports dinnerandsat ire season will reach a peak of sorts tonight when New York's baseball writers hold their 48th annual dinner and follies at the Americana.

title: Mohawk Airlines Chief Says Small Towns Face Service Cuts
description: The president of Mohawk Airlines has predicted many small towns will face curtail ment of their air service this year because of the airline in dustry's financial difficulties.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: A few days ago, while making small repairs to our summer cottage, I acciden tally knocked a powder horn from its peg on the wall and that simple act ended my labors for an hour.

title: Canada Dry Bubbling
description: Things have been popping at the 66 yearold Canada Dry Corporation since July. 1968, when it and two other wellknown companies Hunt Foods and the MCall Corporation  were consol idated into the then newly formed Norton Simon Cor poration, Inc. Canada Dry, originally a Canadian con cern, had been in this coun try for 50 years.

title: Bobsled Race Put Off; No Doctors Available
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 30 (AP)  Bobsledders found out today that there really is a shortage of doctors.

title: Palmer Receives Bob Jones Award for Distinguished Sportsmanship in Golf
description: Arnold Palmer's acceptance of a prestigious award, Philip H. Strubing's reelection and the announcement of the 1971 Walker Cup team highlighted the United States Golf Associ ation's annual meeting yester day at the Biltmore Hotel.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: CITY BALLET DANCES A BALANCHINE SUITE
description: Balanchine's Suite No. 3 is a ballet of second thoughts, good and bad. After choreo graphing only the last move ment in 1947, he decided to add the three other movements in 1970, a brilliant second thought. After its premiere he reconsidered the new dcor and decided to remove the ro mantic scrim that covered the stage for the first three move ments and pretty much ruined the sense of the dcor. Friday evening at the State Theater, the lead roles of the last movement were danced by the New York City Ballet's Kay Mazzo and Peter Martins for the first time.

title: Mrs. Jane Post Is Wed in Mexico To Alfredo Millet, Tennis Pro
description: Mrs. Barbara Jane Post, known as Jane, was married yesterday afternoon in Aca pulco, Mexico, to Alfredo Millet, a tennis professional there.

title: Don't Ask for Sherry When You re on Madeira
description: FUNCHAL, MadeiraIf pain shows for a fleeting second in the eyes of the man behind the bar in the Madeira wine lodge, he is to be forgiven. A tourist has just asked him for a sample of his best sherry. To confuse Madeira wine with sherry is as wounding to a Madeiran as to con fuse Portugal with Spain, whence the wines draw their respective nationalities.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Industrial development in Oklahoma includes a special focus on the state's latest assetstwo ports. They are the Tulsa port of Catoosa, on the Verdigris River, and the port of Muskogee, on the Arkansas River.

title: SOUTAR CAPTURES TITLE IN BOWLING
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 30 (UPI)Dave Soutar of Gilroy, Calif., won the 11th title in his 10year pro career today when he defeated Dick Ritger, 235 210, for the championship and $6,000 in the $50,000 Greater Los Angeles bowling tourna ment.

title: About Motor Sports
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Tight money or no, the United States Auto Club exudes an air of optimism these days. With a massive infusion of cigarette money and the wearingin of a good profes sional staff, there was a no ticeable sprightliness in last weekend's annual USAC meeting here. This is not to say any miracles have oc curred in this con servative estab lishment; for one thing, the board of directors rejected a proposal to permit a groundeffect vehicle to race in the championship di vision. For another, there still is much pulling and hauling among the disparate inter ests represented on the board, with a few men making hay in the sunshine of their mem bership.

title: Member of Ore. State Five Is Killed in Auto Accident
description: LITCHFIELD, Calif., Jan. 30 (AP)  A starter on Oregon State University's basketball team was killed today when a car went off a highway near this northern California com munity.

title: RodriguezOliver Team Leads at Daytona
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Sun day, Jan. 31A threecar ac cident at 11:45 P.M. last night eliminated two sports cars from leading positions in the Twenty Four Hours of Daytona. There were no serious injuries.

title: Muffie Bancroft Fiancee Of C. Minot Amory Jr.
description: Miss Margaret Woodward Stewart Bancroft, blond debu tante daughter of the Duchess d'Uzs, the blond Standard Oil heiress, and C. Minot Amory Jr. plan to marry in the summer. Announcement of their engagement has been made by Miss Bancroft's father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Bancroft Jr. of Old Westbury, L. I.

title: TREMBLEY EQUALS SWIMMING RECORD
description: NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30John Trembley of Ten nessee tied a National Collegi ate swimming record last week and Rick Colella of Washing ton missed a record by a tenth of a second. Their performances highlighted the weekly list of the season's fastest times, re leased today by Swimming World magazine.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: NEW WEEKLY BIOGRAPHICAL SERVICE. The New York Times Biographical Service. Write: The New York Times. Library Services, Box FP480, ?? West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: U.N. AID UNIT PLANS REGIONAL OFFICES
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 30The United Nations Development Program voted this week to try to improve its efficiency in helping developing countries by decentralizing re sponsibility among four region al bureaus here.

title: Headliners
description: Prince Juan Carlos de Borbn of Spain found last week that there's a big difference between a sonofapretender and a kinginwaiting.
