As a pretender's son, the 33yearold Princeand his Greekborn wife, Princess Sophiamade three visits to the United States; and they received polite but largely unofficial attention. Last week they returned officially; but this time Juan Carlos was the designated successor to Generalissimo Francisco Franco, the Spanish Head of State. The couple received the fullblown state treat ment: White House dinner, government briefings and the Apollo launching. The royal couple, said Secretary of State William Rogers in a toast, represents the future genera tion of Spain.

title: A Sofa of the 1920's Returns
description: CHICAGO  As an archi tect, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe altered the look of 20th century cities with his sky scrapers. But he did more.

title: Music
description: YOU can't keep a secret in New York. When a famous conductor goes to the music li brary and starts looking through scores by a given composer, one of the page boys, who may also be a Juilliard student, tells his friends, and they tell other friends, and within a week everybody in the field knows about it. Or the Philharmonic assigns certain repertory to certain soloists, and it is sup posed to be a secret, but no musician has as yet been born with tape permanently over his mouth.

title: The World
description: LONDON  A stranger arriv ing in Britain last week would be forgiven for thinking the coun try was in chaos, approaching a state of civil strife. The Postal Service was in the second week of a national walkout, British European Airways (B.E.A.) was shut down by labor troubles and the huge Union of Engineering Workers threatened a series of political strikes.

title: A Power Cutoff Strands 12 Men In 275Ft. Welfare Island Shaft
description: An electricity mixup on Wel fare Island stranded a dozen workmen at the bottom of 275foot shaft yesterday morn ing for three uncomfortable, but undangerous, hours.

title: North Carolina Bolsters League Lead With 105 79 Victory Over Maryland
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jan. 30 (UPI)North Carolina jumped to a 255 lead today and rolled up a 10579 victory over Mary land in an Atlantic Coast Con ference game.

title: 2 of Maderna's Musical Works Unfold Rich Shadings at Tully
description: Bruno Maderna is an Italian avantgarde composer whose music should be better known here than it is, and, as it hap pens, the Juilliard School and Lincoln Center are doing some thing about the matter this weekend.

title: Jay Pearly Is Fiance Of Susan M. Nunn
description: Mrs. Hal Burgess of Mid dle Village, Queens, has an nounced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Susan Marie Nunn, to Jay Jeffery Pearly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Pearly of Huntington Station, L. I.

title: The Nation
description: Hot Pants  Les Shorts  Shortootsies  Happy Legs. Suddenly the fashion industry, badly burned by its effort to foist the midi on resisting womankind, has counterattacked. Its chief weapon: shorts.

title: Foreign Notes
description: On his trip to the United States in 1959, Nikita Khrushchev, then the Soviet leader, commented that there were too many cars carrying too few people in Amer ica. He had a better way, he said.

title: Pruzansky Streak Hits 40, But Fairleigh Matmen Lose
description: TEANECK, N. J., Jan. 30 Stu Pruzansky recorded his 40th straight dual meet wres tling victory for Fairleigh Dick inson today, but his team lost, 368, to Montclair State.

title: Connecticut Communities Striving to Make Superhighway Blend In
description: NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 27 When Connecticut officials pro posed cutting a superhighway north from this coastal city through the hilly woodlands toward Danbury virtually no one objected.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON The Ameri can housewife, in theory, will buy anything as long as it's pro moted on television. But her con cern over the environment has triggered a new retailing phe nomenon throughout the country a sudden boom for the un advertised, nonphosphate deter gent. American women by the tens of thousands are switching from the bigname, heavily ad vertised brands of detergents to products few people have ever heard of, including some that didn't even exist a few months ago.

title: Education
description: In its report last Septem ber, the President's Commis sion on Campus Unrest said, Faculty members who en gage in or lead disruptive conduct have no place in the university community. Al though the statement met with wide agreement, the question remained as to who should bell the cat.

title: KeyClub Restrooms Planned
description: LONDON, Jan. 30 (UPI)The British Petroleum Company has announced plans for keyclub restroom facilities at its auto mobile service stations through out the country. The price of the key will be $2.40 a year, a company spokesman said, en titling holders to use special restrooms of the type found in luxury hotels.

title: U.S. and Ecuador Reach Agreement On Fishing Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The United States and Ecuador re solved today their dispute over American commercial fishing operations off the Ecuadorian coast.

title: Prince Michael Goes Home
description: LONDON, Jan. 30 (UPI) Prince Michael of Kent, 28 yearold cousin of Queen Eliza beth, returned to London today to recuperate from a broken jaw, cuts and bruises suffered Thursday when his bobsled overturned at the world four man bobsled championships in Italy.

title: A THEODORAKIS SONG COSTS GREEK $300
description: ATHENS, Jan. 30A Greek! farmer has paid the highest price ever for a single playing of a record by the composer Mikis Theodorakis  a $300 fine. The title of the costly song: Great Is the Grief.

title: Flyers Extend Mastery In Routing Rangers, 52
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 Without the least bit of mys tery, the Flyers showed to night why they possess the power to cloud the Rangers' minds and send the New York ers into a funkthey outplay them.

title: 4 Out of 10 Wives Employed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) The Labor Department re ports that four out of every 10 husbands in the United States had wives who were employed last year. The ratio of working wives compared with an over all figure of three out of 10 decade ago.

title: S. ILLINOIS UPSETS GEORGIA TECH, 8969
description: CARBONDALE, Ill., Jan. 30 (AP)  Greg Starrick led the way with 25 points today as Southern Illinois upset Georgia Tech in basketball, 8969.

title: Child to Mrs. Abrams
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Abrams of Brooklyn on Jan. 9 at the Brooklyn Hospital. Mrs. Abrams is the former Miss Susan Resnick. Mr. Abrams is a Publisher of children's books. His father, Harry N. Abrams of New York is a publisher of art books. The child has been named Jor dana Lee.

title: John Young Weds Miss Peterson
description: Miss Pamela Joyce Peter son of St. Louis Park, Minn., and John Adam Young of Rye, N. Y., a vice president and creative director of Lippincott & Margulies, Inc., New York consultants in de sign, marketing and com munications, were married here at noon yesterday in the United Nations Chapel. The Rev. Dr. Carl Soule performed the nondenominational cere mony.

title: Philadelphia Drug Deaths Up
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 (UPI)The number of drug related deaths in Philadelphia last year increased by 70, to 184, with more than 50 per cent of the victims under 25 years old, the medical examin er's office reported. Deaths from pills, chemicals and nar cotics were included in the report.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times
description: When it comes to a question of height, Donald Davidson of the Atlanta Braves is no more to be trusted than an, oversized basketball player. Like them, he exag gerates. According to the unreliable Donald, he is 4 feet 1 inch tall, a palpable misstatement of fact. Everyone in the base ball business knows that he is exactly 4 feet tall. The extra inch he adds is a shameless bit of ostentation.

title: 5 Tied With 207's For San Diego Lead
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 30Lee Elder, one of the two black professionals who qualified for the last two rounds of the $150,000 Andy WilliamsSan Diego open tourney, moved into a fiveway tie for the 54 hole lead today.

title: Susan Low Engaged To Frederick A. Cohen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Low have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Susan Barbara Low, to Frederick Arnold Cohen, son of Mr. and Samuel Cohen of Brooklyn. An August wed ding is planned.

title: Science/Medicine
description: In 1949, a spellbinding cancer researcher sat before a commit tee of Congress and said: Give us the money and in 10 years we'll give you a penicillin for cancer. In the flush of success of the atom bomb, radar and the rediscovery and development of penicillin itself, all in wartime crash programs, the prediction and the promise ignited the com mittee's optimism. Congress gave the money.

title: Foreign Notes
description: The ancient British county of Cornwall, scene of some King Arthur legends, has as its em blem a redbilled, redlegged bird with glossy black plumage, the Cornish chough (pronounced chuff). But the last native chough has not been seen since Decem ber and is believed dead.

title: INGE BORKH SINGS DYER'S WIFE ROLE
description: Inge Borkh, a German so prano who last appeared with the Metropolitan Opera 10 years ago, as Elektra in the Richard Strauss opera, returned to the company on Friday night to sing the role of the Dyer's Wife in the same composer's Die Frau ohne Schatten.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: To Sail a Car and Anchor a Memory
description: AT the dinner table the other night, after helping friends drain an ex cellent bottle of Chateau Pichon Lalande '65, I overheard myself declaiming on the inflated value of wine visavis more lasting civilized pleas ures. After all, when you've finished the wine, it's gone, I said. What's lefty at best, is a pretty bottle and a fleeting memory; at worst, the sort of fatuous epitaph that delights wine buffs and wine buffoonsa precocious little vintage with promise of a gay ma turity.  I was hooted down and gladly dropped the argument. I resurrect it here only because of the bearing it has on another of life's fleeting pleasures, the winter vacation.

title: Exposition by a believer but not a fanatic
description: It is useless to pretend that Freud's theory of the mind is just one more scientific theory, disputable and un proven but still to be expounded and understood as any scientific theory would be. Freud's thought is both more and less than this. It is more than a scientific theory because ex perience shows that any exposition of it must take account of the emo tions of listeners and readers, who are apt to be either disturbed and angry about it or uncritically com mitted to it.

title: Fire Kills Economic Aide To Philippine U.N. Mission
description: The economic adviser of the Philippine Mission to the United Nations, Francisco M. Rod riguez, 39 years old, died yes terday in a fire in his studio apartment at 250 East 39th Street.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  A historic and massive reversal of the flow of power in America. That was the way President Nixon, in his Budget Meseage to Congress last week, described his proposal to put $16billion a year into two forms of revenuesharing with the state and local governments.

title: Music
description: JANIS JOPLIN was born on January 19, 1943, in a Texas town of 60,000 called Port Arthur, just off the Louisiana border. She died, presumably from an overdose of heroin, in a little plaster room in a Hollywood motel on October 4, 1970. When she died she was 163 years old.

title: U.S. WILL TIGHTEN ALIEN JOB RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30As a result of rising unemploy ment, the Department of Labor plans to stiffen its regulations for admitting alien profession als and several other groups who wish to become perma nent residents of the United States.

title: Aid Is Given Jersey Central
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) Gov. William T. Cahill signed into law yesterday the $2mil lion state subsidy for the Cen tral Railroad of New Jersey. It had been reported that the bankrupt railroad might still not be able to provide service after March, even with the subsidy. The Governor, in sign ing the bill, said that more than $36million in state funds had been given to the railroad, and added: Taxpayers of this state can no longer afford to pour additional millions into the Jersey Central.

title: Horse Show News
description: Britain was the top show jumping team in the world last year, with West Ger many a close second, accord ing to an unofficial survey.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Mailbox:
description: To the Editor:

title: as Jets Strengthen Running Game
description: The Jets appear organized to fulfill their Super Bowl ambition next season.

title: TEMPLE DEFEATS SYRACUSE BY 7170
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 (AP) Temple erased a 12point halftime deficit and scored 13 straight points late in the game tonight to defeat Syracuse, 7170, in the second game of a doubleheader at the Palestra.

title: Berlin: Will Moscow Act?
description: Willy Brandt could not have chosen a better moment to reiterate in strong terms West Germany's right maintain its political links with free West Berlin. As the Chancellor was telling the Bundestag in Bonn last week that any Berlin solution would have to guarantee the right of free assembly, East German officials were clamping the worst traffic holdup in years on the auto bahns leading into and out of the divided city.

title: Iona Downs LeMoyne
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 30Iona College, overcame a 14point halftime deficit to night and defeated LeMoyne, 6765, in a Middle Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference game. Iona's wonlost record is 84.

title: Nixon Is Taking It Easy In San in Virgin lands
description: CANEEL BAY, St. John, V.I., Jan. 30 (UPI)President Nixon relaxed today in the serenity and 85degree weather of this tropical island, where he hoped to read three books he brought along from the White House library.

title: Miss Anderson Wed To an Engineer
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 30 Miss Nancy Anderson, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Anderson, was married here this afternoon to William Ralph Congleton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Congleton of Lexington, Ky.

title: Zambia Seeking Employes In Guyana for Local Duties
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Jan. 30 (Reuters)The Government of Zambia is conducting a re cruitment drive in Guyana and elsewhere in the Caribbean for localgovernment personnel.

title: Man in Space Or Chip in Space?
description: THIS week man goes into space again with the Apollo 14 lift off. The mission is aimed at the exploration of the Fra Mauro region, immediately south of the Sea of Showers and just under the left eye in the face of the man in the moon. From the viewpoint of the scientist, this region is particularly interesting because it is a part of the moon known as the lunar highlands, which differ as much from the sites of pre vious Apollo landings as the earth's continents differ from its ocean floors. The highlands are the oldest part of the moon, and the part on which the astronauts are most likely to turn up clues to the birth of the planets.

title: 600 Million Will Watch Apollo 14 Voyage on TV
description: More than 600 million peo ple throughout the world will watch the voyage of Apollo 14 on television, with half the viewers in North America and the rest in Europe.

title: Boston U. Six Wins, 63
description: BOSTON, Jan. 30 (AP)Bob Gryp and Wayne Gowing scored two goals apiece tonight in leading Boston University to a 63 hockey victory over St. Lawrence. It was the 15th triumph of the season for the Terriers against one loss and one tie. The Larries are 89.

title: That GroundHog Myth
description: Day after tomorrow will be GroundHog Day, and the old myth will be dusted off. But the ground hogs will be sleeping quietly in their dens, as usual, with at least another month of hibernation ahead. And one wonders why, if we look to the animals for omens, we don't choose one that knows the year entire instead of one that never experiences winter.

title: TV, Hit by Worst Slump, Looks to New Life in 1972
description: Television is in the worst slump since the commercial in ception of the home screen in the early 1950's. The medium, once likened to a license to print money, is staggering un der the dual blows of the loss of cigarette advertising and a depressed economy that has thrown the sale of advertising spot announcements into a frantic auction mart.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Kennedy Expects Muskie Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  Senator Edward M. Kennedy not only counts himself out of the 1972 Democratic Presiden tial competition but he also counts Senator Edmund S. Muskie in  without endorsing him.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Study Finds 15 Gave Over $50,000 Each to Political Parties in '68
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The most extensive compilation of campaign contributions ever as sembled showed today that at least 15 Americans each gave more than $50,000 to national political causes in 1968.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: JACKSON, Tenn. Jan. 30 (UPI)Led by the three Jones boys, who combined for 74 points, the Memphis Pros beat the Floridians, 10996, tonight. Steve Jones led all scorers with 32 points, followed by Jimmy Jones with 24. Wilbert Jones had 18.

title: Crew Stays Healthy After Strict Isolation
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 30Strict preflight isolation and intense medical surveillance are expected to allow the Apol lo 14 astronauts a healthy start to the moon tomorrow after noon.

title: National Notes
description: Outside the county jail in York, Pa., last week, a group of demonstrators, including several nuns, marched quietly through the bitter cold night, lighted candles in their hands. We will keep this vigil up, said one of the nuns, until Sister Jogues is released.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Stiff Crime Bill to Take Effect in Capital Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 One of the Nixon Administra tion's most controversial crime control measures, the omnibus District of Columbia Crime Control Act of 1970, goes into effect Monday amid efforts to strike down several of its key provisions as unconstitutional.

title: Political Pressure Laid to Guard Chief In an Alabama Suit
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 30 An Alabama Air National Guard officer has filed suit in Federal District Court here charging that his commanding general sought to force him to make a political contribution.

title: Miss Janet Goldblum Engaged to a Seaman
description: The engagement of Miss Janet Goldblum to Seaman 1st Cl. Christopher T. Fiedler, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Fiedler of Waltham, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jack Goldblum of New York.

title: Oliver Taylor Marries Patricia O'Neill
description: Miss Patricia Ann O'Neill and Oliver Beckwith Taylor were married yesterday morn ing in Christ Episcopal Church in New Brighton, S. I. The Rev. Frederick P. LeFebvre performed the ceremony.

title: Swalsky Is Promoted To Monticello Secretary
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Jan. 31 (UPI)Ralph Swalsky, 30 years old, of Montreal, has been promoted to racing sec retary at Monticello Race way. Swalsky, who had served for three years as assistant racing secretary, previously was associated with tracks at Montreal, Ottawa and Sherbrooke in Canada.

title: ROYALS DEFEAT ROCKETS, 116110
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 30 (AP) Flynn Robinson, who did not play in the first half, scored 19 points in the second as Cincin nati registered a 116110 Na tional Basketball Association victory tonight over the San Diego Rockets.

title: Bridge
description: SINCE courage and confidence are two necessary qualities for suc cess in the game, Christopher Colum bus would probably have been a good bridge player. He may well have been a card player, for playing cards were well known in Spain and Italy during Renaissance times.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 30 Providence College defeated Army, 30, tonight. Mike Gaff ney scored early in the opening session. Jerry Fitzgerald and Gary Williamson scored the other goals in the third period.

title: ExRep. Chester Thompson, An Expert on Waterways
description: ROCK ISLAND, I??., Jan. 30 (AP)  Former Representative Chester C. Thompson died to day in a Rock Island hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Obote's Departure Reported
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sunday, Jan. 31 (Reuters)Mr. Obote left here last night for Mombasa, Kenya, to hold talks with Kenya's President, Jomo Kenyatta, the Tanzanian Gov ernment newspaper, The Sun day News, reported today.

title: Talks Between Italian and French Leaders Fail to Bridge Differences on Approach to European Unity
description: PARIS, Jan. 30Premier Emilio Colombo and Foreign Minister Aldo Moro of Italy returned to Rome today after a day and a half of talks here about what the French call their pragmatic approach to European unity.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONIf the fi nancial and business commu nityand economistshave a sense of skepticism about President Nixon's new budg et, and particularly the esti mate of the deficit, the feeling is entirely understand able.

title: Monclair State Triumphs
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 30  Montclair State College cap tured its 10th victory in 12 games tonight by downing Southern Connecticut State, 79 72. Bruce Davis led the winning Indians with 23 points. Mont clair State is now 102 for the season. Southern Connecticut State is 56.

title: BOLT AHEAD BY SHOT IN SENIOR GOLF TEST
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP)Tommy Bolt strained a back muscle today in the third round of the $40, 000 Mercury Senior golf tour nament and watched Julius Boros chop his fivestroke lead to one shot.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 10  No Title
description: ORONO, Me., Jan. 30 (AP) The University of Maine dom inated the boards today and up set the University of Connecti cut, 11299, for its third Yan kee Conference basketball vic tory of the season.

title: KANSAS CITY LOSES SOCCER FRANCHISE
description: The North American Soccer League announced here late Friday night that the franchise of the Kansas City Spurs, one of the original teams in the league, had been terminated because of the club's failure to comply with the league's con stitution.

title: What's New in Theater?
description: NO, NO, NANETTE, a reviv al of the 1925 musical by Otto Harbach and Frank Mandel, Vincent Youmans and Irving Caesar, was praised unanimously by the critics. Clive Barnes: For everyone who wishes the world were 50 years young erand particularly, I suspect, for those who re member it when it was 50 years youngerthe revival of No, No, Nanette should provide a delightful, carefree evening. Vincent Youmans' music is music to hum and particularly music to dance to. Note also the lyrics by Irving Caesar and Mr. Harbach. Ruby Keeler dances like a trouper and wears indomi tability shyly like a badge of service. She is just enor mously likable. But for my money the best performan ces came from Bobby Van as the suave, debonair, dancing lawyer (the man is a superb tap dancer) and the adorable Helen Gallagher as his shortsuffering wife. For Walter Kerr, see Page 1.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Ack Ack, a Cain Hoy Colt, Is Bought by Greer Garson
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 30 (UPI)Ack Ack, one of the na tion's top stakes horses, has been purchased by Mr. and Mrs. E. E. Fogelson from the estate of Capt. Harry F. Guggenheim, the purchasers disclosed today.

title: LONDON THEATER ADDS FIVE DANCES
description: LONDON, Jan. 30During its current sixweek season in its headquarters at The Place, the Contemporary Dance Thea ter is trying to consolidate both its repertory and its audience. So far it seems more successful with the latter than the former. Enthusiasm runs high from the mainly young supporters.

title: A Door Opens, Miss Keeler Enters
description: THE secret of No, No, Nanette lies in Ruby Keeler's sobriety. Actually, she isn't the only one who has it, it has spread to infect the earnest, wideeyed girls who dance on the tops of beach balls and the straightfaced, straightlaced boys in plusfours who linger about the grand piano fingering their welltempered ukuleles. And Miss Keeler, of course, isn't onstage all of the time. She does only two numbers. (Only two, did I say? They could have donated one to Ari and they'd still have a smash.)

title: A crime against the state that incriminates the state
description: On the face of it, The Quest for Christa T. bears all the stigmata of the conventionally experimental nov el. But the ambiguities that lurk just beneath the enigmatic ripples of its prose turn out to be authentic, earned rather than fashionable. Like trap doors they open onto unsuspected depths and end in questions that, for never being asked outright, tend to grow all the more insistent. The con tours of silence and the outline of things articulately left unsaid loom large in the muted brilliance of this novel. And since it was written in the realm of King Ulbricht, where raising questions is much like raising the dead, the book becomes an act of necromancy tantamount to trea son. At least it would be difficult otherwise to account for the grim fury which this wholly apolitical work seems to have aroused in East Germany.

title: Truman in Good Condition
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 30 (UPI)Former President Harry S. Truman was reported today to be in good condition. His speedy recovery from colitis in dicates that he may soon be released from the hospital, but no date for his dismissal has been set.

title: Would You Buy Used Manuscript From This Man?
description: WHO Is this smiling Soviet in ternational traveler, Victor Louis, who seems to be in charge, among so many other re sponsibilities, of transporting forged and dubious literary documents, em barrassing photographs, curious vari ations of repressed texts by famous writers, advance copies suspected of being arranged by the C.I.A. or the K.G.B. (or by both, according to some wouldbe paranoids), and in one case at least, even played nursey and com panion to a shrill novelist, Valeri Tarsis, whom the Soviet Government judged crazy enough to be harmless and therefore fit to be deposited in the eager hands of English and Amer ican literati?

title: Deception on Drugs Charged
description: IOLA, Kan., Jan. 30 (UPI) Two youths working in coop eration with the police told the authorities that they had bought sugar cubes and carrot tope that the seller had said were filled with drugs. Police analysis, however, showed that they were only carrot tops and sugar cubes, and the authorities arrested Michael Lorrance, 18 years old, on charges of theft by deception. The youth plead ed guilty and was placed in the custody of his father.

title: The Moon as Tourist Trap? That's Not Really So Far Out
description: FIFTY years ago, the Idea of a saleslady buying a roundtrip ticket to Europe would have sounded fantastic, Dr. Wernher von Braun told me recently, yet now they go over in droves every summer. I wouldn't be at all surprised if, fifty years from now, the same range of people who go to Europe nowadays would be able to afford a trip to the moon.

title: National Notes
description: The South Mall State Office Building in Albany is known variously as Rockefeller Center North, the Taj Mahal, Rocke feller's Pyramids and Brasilia North. A pet project of Governor Rockefeller, it has been knee deep in fiscal controversy since it was first announced eight years agoand last week a new chapter was added.

title: MILITARY BARBERS LEARN TO CUT AFRO
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 30  A group of 49 military barbers and beauticians returned to their bases across the United States and in the Far East this week, prepared to start a black hairstyling program among the Negro enlisted men and women of their units.

title: 2 Parties Recess Talks
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 30 Three days of talks on Pakis tan's future constitution be tween Sheik Mujibur Rahman and Zulfikar Ali Bhutto ended inconclusively today in Dacca, East Pakistan's capital.

title: The Living Alone Phenomenon: Signs of It Are Everywhere
description: LOS ANGELESAfter Barbara Stanley graduated front college she moved into an apartment with three other girls in New York. When she earned a promotion, and a raise, she moved to a new place with only one roommate. After a year she moved again, this time to her own apartment.

title: CENSUS TECHNIQUE IRKS PORTUGUESE
description: LISBON, Jan. 25 Portugal's national census closed today, six weeks late and in a general wave of frustration and dis belief.

title: SOUVANNA WARNS HANOI IS BEGINNING OFFENSIVE IN LAOS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 30 Premier Souvanna Phouma said today that he was convinced that the North Vietnamese were beginning a general offensive against Laotian Government po sitions.

title: Former Theater in Bronx Gutted by 2Alarm Fire
description: A fire that produced heavy smoke burned out of control for more than two hours in the old Winter Garden Theater building at 1874 Washington Avenue in the Bronx early this morning.

title: Two idealists, visvis the Vietnam War
description: First things first  and this book by a young newspaperman who is also a veteran of Army Intelligence is above all a first novel. In its civilized approach to love it might have been written 30 years ago:

title: Ann L. Ferrick Plans Nuptials
description: MARLBORO, Mass., Jan. 30 Miss Ann L. Ferrick and John Oliver May, seniors at Marietta College, are plan ning a summer wedding.

title: 2 KASHMIRIS HIJACK AN INDIAN AIRLINER
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 30 Two young Kashmiris, said to belong to the National Liber ation Front, an organization in Indianheld Kashmir, today hi jacked an Indian Airlines plane and forced its pilot to land at the Lahore airport.

title: Hamlet Raskolnikov meets the dumb jock
description: At Syracuse University in the fifties, youth culture had not yet been designated with an imprimatur by the popes of alienation; the really large division in student sensibilities was between those who went to football games and those who didn't.

title: Recordings
description: WHAT an affront to Hispanic compos ers must be the jibe: The best Span ish music has been written by Frenchmen, How Gaulling! Alicia De Larrocha, a mighty mite of a pianist from Barce lona, takes up the gauntlet and casts it in the teeth of her countrymen's detractors in her recent London Records album in which she plays Spanish Piano Music of the 20th Century (London CS 6677).

title: Architecture
description: CONTRARY to popular belief, there is a lot that faith, hope and charity can do in New York. It took faith, hope and $1million in the case of the Clinton Youth and Family Center at 314 West 054th Street, operated by the YMCA of Greater New York and the Rotary Club of New York in a section once known evocatively as Hell's Kitchen and now known sociologi cally as a multiproblem area. The language is less colorful but the meaning is the same. Too many of its people are and in trouble.

title: The World
description: LONDONThe few Ameri cans who have seen Uganda will know it as a land of spectacular tourist sights: Birds and croco diles, papyrus swamps and dry plains, the Nile flowing over Murchison Falls, the mist shrouded Mountains of the Moon on the Congo border to the west.

title: Gardens
description: THERE is something magic about a trip to Florida in midwinter. To board a plane under cold, leaden skies and in a little over two hours step off into a land of blue skies, white beaches and flamboyant poinset tias is an exciting experience.

title: Barbara Bloch Engaged to Wed Israeli Lawyer
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 30  Miss Barbara Susan Bloch, a greatgrandniece of Miss Kate Wollman, who gave the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink and the Kate Wollman Memorial Rink in Brooklyn, to the City of New York, and Yehuda Vinitsky of Jerusalem plan to be married in the Oakwood Country Club here on April 24.

title: Faculty at Berkeley Is Drafting a Code of Conduct
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 30 Faculty members at the Uni versity of California here are hard at work hammering out a proposed code of conduct for themselves, after they rejected a tentative code put forward by the university administration.

title: On Teaching the Young How to Dance
description: In his dark blue suit lightly striped with red, his discreet tie and polished black shoes, the man with the silver gray hair and erect carriage could pass for floor walker at one of the deeper piled emporiums or perhaps manager right here at the Pierre.

title: Airlines in Bitter Struggle On Atlantic Charter Rates
description: At least a dozen London bound jetliners take off each day from Kennedy Internation al Airport, On most of them, oneway economy class ticket costs $210. On Laker Airways Flight GK 280, which leaves Fridays only at about 1 P.M. a ticket to London costs $115.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor

title: Australia is First to Enter World Cup Skiing in Quebec
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 30 (Cana dian. Press)Atistralia has be come the first country to enter the World Cup, ski competition at Mont Ste. Anne near Quebec City.

title: Miss Mary Ellis Bell Is Bride Of Fred Robinson Harwell Jr.
description: Miss Mary Ellis Bell and Fred Robinson Harwell Jr. were married here yesterday afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest by the Rev. J. Burton Thomas.

title: Hanoi Reports Bombings
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 30 Reu ters)The Hanoi radio said to day that United States planes had raided North Vietnam for the last five days.

title: Their Own Thing
description: The growing dissatisfac tion among youth with work ing for a large corporation is taking a new form. Now, students are challenging big business by starting their own ventures. In contrast to the campus businessmen of a few years ago, student en trepreneurs today are likely to be running a sophisticated operation, applying advanced concepts in marketing and fi nance.

title: Airmail Letter Boxes Added
description: Distinctive airmail letter boxes, with red, white and blue striping, are being placed at various sites in Manhattan, the Post Office has announced. The special boxes, for airmail and special delivery letters, are de signed to afford such mail the priority treatment to which it is entitled, the Post Office said.

title: DR. JOHN W. RICE
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Jan. 30 Dr. John W. Rice, emeritus pro fessor of bacteriology at Buck nell University and director since 1946 of the university's health service, which he found ed in 1925, died yesterday in Danville. His age was 79.

title: Geoffrey Drummond Dies; Political Columnist Was 40
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) Geoffrey Drummond, author of a syndicated newspaper column with his father, Roscoe Drummond, died last night after a heart attack. He was 40 years old.

title: 5Man Undersea Research Vessel Is Commissioned
description: FORT PIERCE, Fla., Jan.. 30 (AP)The Smithsonian Institu tion commissioned yesterday a fiveman submersible research vessel designed to operate in water to a depth of 3,000 feet.

title: Miss Marguerite McKee Bride In Raleigh of Robert L. W. Moss
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 30 Miss Marguerite McPheeters McKee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James McKee, was mar ried here this afternoon to Robert Lancaster Williams Moss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ambler Holmes Moss of Bal timore.

title: Drumtop and Mongo's Pride Score on Hialeah Grass
description: MIAMI, Jan. 30Before to day's running of the $26,625 Palm Beach Handicap at Hialeah, Kenny Noe Jr., the racing secretary, was certain that Drumtop was the best grass mare in the nation. After the running of the first division of the stakes he amended his opinion slightly.

title: Mediators Pressing Talks To Avert Bakers' Strike
description: Federal and state mediators worked with union and man agement yesterday to reach a contract settlement that could avert a strike by 6,000 bakers in 520 retail and wholesale bakeries in the metropolitan area.

title: BERIA IS IGNORED IN SOVIET VOLUME
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 30  The Soviet Union's new encyclo pedia, with three of its 30 vol umes now published, continues to speak in a relatively ob jective, undogmatic tone. It nevertheless reflects the Krem lin's sensitivity to certain his torical personages.

title: Suns Sink Sonics, 134116
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 30 (AP) The Phoenix Suns beat the Seattle SuperSonics, 134116, tonight. Dick Van Arsdale of the Suns scored 30 points to lead all scorers.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: The New York Financial Writers' Association, an all male sanctuary since 1938, will remain that way, for a while at least. At the associa tion's annual meeting last week, a proposal to admit women members failed to win approval of the neces sary twothirds of all the ac tive and life members. The vote was 8115 in favor of the proposition, which re quired 90 votes to pass.

title: Music
description: REALITY is strangely suspended when you are in the presence of Christa Ludwig. Not because the Austrian mezzo  soprano is possessed of one of today's most ex pressive and superbly placed voices, nor because her personal magnetism is so overwhelming. The unreality of Christa Ludwig lies more within the province of her life and her thinking. What is strange and unreal about Miss Ludwig is that she seems to exist en tirely and exclusively within the dream of her voice. No husband, child or po tential lover has entry into this dream the mundane byproducts of life are not permitted to interfere with a dizzy ing career and an instrument that has justly earned the singer a brilliant in ternational reputation.

title: Mrs. Agnew Scores Feminist Campaign; Nixon Aides Concur
description: Two of President Nixon's highestranking women offici als and the wife of the Vice President joined forces here yesterday to attack the wom en's liberation movement as unfeminine and rather un seemly.

title: H. B. DesRoches And Pauli Mara Plan Marriage
description: STOWE, Vt., Jan. 30Miss Pauli Marie Mara and H. Brian DesRoches, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry DesRoches of Windsor, Ontario, plan to be married hero July 10 in Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church.

title: Notre Dame Upset
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (UPI) Nick Weatherspoon, Nick Con ner and Fred Miller scored baskets and Greg Jackson made two free throws to give Illinois a 6966 upset triumph over sev enthranked Notre Dame at the Chicago Stadium tonight.

title: New Ugandan Regime Accuses Sudan Of an Invasion and Warns Her to Stop
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Sunday, Jan, 31 The head of Ugan da's new military Government charged tonight that the coun try was being attacked by the Sudan, her neighbor to the north.

title: The Nation
description: The Federal Government is determined, said President Nixon, to take an activist role in bring ing about the kind of prosperity that has rarely existed in the American economya prosperity without war and without run away inflation.

title: The Nation
description: United Air Lines Flight 3, a DC8 with 110 seats, leaves Newark Airport for Los Angeles each morning at 9 o'clock. In the last three months, it has carried an average of 20 pas sengers. But, at that, it has done better than United's Flight 311 between Toledo and Detroit which has averaged one passen ger.

title: Article 13  No Title
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 30 Greg Rivet's unassisted power play goal at 13:39 of the third period led Yale to a 64 Ivy League victory over Dartmouth before 2,000 fans at Davis Rink tonight.

title: Letter to the Editor 4  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Rural Bias Found in U.S. School Aid
description: A Ford Foundationsupported study of Federal aid to educa tion has found that rural areas get far more aid per pupil than do urban areas, where the financial, educational and so cial problems are generally re garded as greater.

title: Columbia Keeps Ivy League Record Unblemished by Downing Cornell, 5648
description: Columbia University kept its Ivy League basketball record spotless last night by beating Cornell, 5648 in University Gymnasium before a crowd of 1,107 fans.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Members of the family, honored bankers, de partmentstore credit managers, over duebill dunners, distinguished collec tors of Federal, state and city taxes, salesmen and price gougers

title: Coins
description: THE American Revolu tion Bicentennial Com mission's advisory panel on coins and medals has reached no de cision on issues to commem orate the nation's 200th birth day in 1976. Numismatists, spokesmen for private indus try and Government repre sentatives aired their views and exchanged ideas at re cent meetings in Washington.

title: YAHYA CONCEDES ECONOMIC DEFEAT
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 30 (UPI)President Agha Mo hammad Yahya Khan, who ad mits that hit twoyearold mili tary Government has failed to improve Pakistan's deteriorat ing economy, says he will pass the problem to his civilian suc cessors.

title: U.S. BUSSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Industrial development em phasis these days in West Virginia includes a special focus on the state's multi million  dollar road  building program.

title: Reader's Report
description: This Catholic's answer to Portnoy's Complaint is in tended to show, says its author, that not everybody who had trouble growing up is Jewish. If the question were ever in doubt, Mr. Byrne's novel set tles it once and for all. Tommy Shannon, an eighthgrader at St. Procopius School in Dubuque, Iowa, circa 1943, has as much flair for erotic baffle ment and allaround adolescent misery as any of his peers since Holden Caulfield. The result of his troubles is not neurosis, however, but a replenishing store of callow optimism in the face of daily corporal pun ishment and an unblemished record of sexual frustration. Mr. Byrne, a Dubuque alumnus himself, describes his hero's misadventures with a fine blend of slapstick and realism, We've all been in Tommy Shannon country before, of course, but Mr. Byrne is both a funny and an appealing guide.

title: Dance: Australians in 3 Pas de Deux
description: The Casts

title: Une de Mai Is French Trot Choice Today
description: PARIS, Jan. 30Tell me about Fresh Yankee, asks the Count de Montesson. What news have you?

title: For Young Readers
description: A Southern grandmother, an old fashioned black family, a militant black architectural student, a redneck storekeeper and two 12  year  old girls, best friends, one black and one white, form the cast of characters for this highly literate story of racial tension. The plot is touched off by the redneck storekeeper provoking Howard, the black militant, into a fight and the two girls are the only witnesses, the only ones who know that Howard has escaped into the dangerous and forbidden Peppersalt Land, They promise not to tell. Then they follow Howard, get lost and have a fight of their own.

title: Stranahan, Homenuik Share Lead in Maracaibo Open
description: MARACAIBO, Venezuela, Jan. 30 (AP)Dick Stranahan of the United States and Wilf Homen uik of Canada tied for the thirdround lead today in the $17,500 Maracaibo International Open golf tournament as Albert Rivadeneira of Colombia, the halfway leader, fell virtually out of contention.

title: SOUTH BEND FAILS TO ANNEX SCHOOLS
description: NOTRE DAME, Ind., Jan. 26 Everything was back to nor mal at the university of Notre Dame today. The university was still secure and inviolate out side the city limits of South Bend because the city Common Council, after a fourhour pub lic hearing last night, voted against annexing Notre Dame, along with St. Mary's College for Women and Holy Cross Junior College.

title: Fairleigh Loses by 7159
description: RUTHERFORD, N. J., Jan. 30 Mike Laughna scored 6 straight points to break a 54all tie and propel Georgetown to a 7159 Victory over Fairleigh Dickinson tonight. Laughna fin ished as the game's high scorer with 20 points.

title: Dr. Meriwether Finishes First, Equaling Dash Mark at Boston
description: BOSTON, Jan. 30Dr. Delano Meriwether did it again tonight in the 82d annual Boston Ath letic Association Indoor Games at Boston Garden.

title: Retirement
description: Donald J. Sherbondy, a toplevel executive with PPG Industries in Pittsburgh, is phasing out his long and re warding corporate career in gradual steps.

title: The logic of shirts
description: The restless world of fashion is turning away from the costumeparty madness of the past season to the reality of the classics. And what is more valid than the shirt look? Whether it's a rich, sude coat or an uncluttered dress, the shirt mood is refined and cool, but never dull.

title: The Confessions Of Edward Dahlberg
description: Edward Dahlberg is the literary phoenix of his generation. No greater proof exists that Fitzgerald's famous dictum about the absence of second acts in American life is susceptible to splendid contradiction. Once a muchpraised practitioner of that most mythical of American literary enterprises, the proletarian novel, Dahlberg repudiated not only his early fame but the books on which it was based, consigning himself to years in the wilderness where he virtually began his literary career all over again.

title: Big Plans For Long Weekends
description: HAVE you made your plans for the fourday holiday coming up the weekend after next? And for the other eight long weekends (see box on Page 7) in store this year? The year 1971 will have more three day and fourday weekends than any previous year in the modern era be cause the Monday Holiday Law en acted by Congress a couple of years ago is just now taking effect. (The de lay was deliberate to give people like calendar makers a chance to adjust.)

title: Mrs.Beachman of Britain Sets 1,500Meter Mark
description: COSFORD, England, Jan. 30 (UPI)Mrs. Margaret Beacham, a 24yearold secretary, set a world record today in winning the women's 1,500meter run in 4 minutes 20.5 seconds at the British indoor track and field championships.

title: Television
description: SINCE showbiz's royal couple, the Burtons, briefly abdicated to tele vision by appearing on the sea son's opening Here's Lucy show, it may be only a matter of prime time before similar celebrated holdouts join the inexorable march to TV from the stage and screen.

title: Carolina Abduction of 8 Called A Scheme to Free Angela Davis
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 30 A State Senator whose wife was shot two weeks ago in an attempted kidnapping plot said this week that two young black men Involved had planned to demand ransom and to at tempt a trade of their victims for Angela Davis, the black militant accused of murder in California.

title: 200 New Garbage Trucks Will Replace Last of the Noisy Ones
description: The last of the earsplitting clanks and grinds are scheduled to be taken out of the Sanita tion Department's fleet of garbage trucks.

title: New Unit of Army To Combine Tanks And Missile Craft
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)  The Army plans to experi ment with a new type of divi sion combining tanks and mis sileequipped helicopters to counter Soviet armor in Europe.

title: WARSAW DELAYS NEW CAR DESIGN
description: WARSAW, Jan. 30The Po lish Government has postponed a decision to produce a new small car and told the nation that it will have to be satisfied with a modified version of its decadeold Syrena.

title: Miss Maerkel Is Victor At Hunt Farm Horse Show
description: THREE BRIDGES, N. J., Jan. 30Debbie Maerkel of Somer lille dominated the Hunts Farms horse show today by winning three of the six classes.

title: Diana Hallowell Is Affianced To Milton McC.Barlow, Lawyer
description: Miss Diana Hallowell, who is on the staff of the Mayor's Council of the Environment, and Milton McClintock Bar low, a lawyer with Shearman & Sterling, a law firm here, will be married in April in Andover, Mass.

title: Ardis Hacker Wed to Alan Schmidt
description: Miss Ardis Ann Hacker was married yesterday after noon to Alan Willard Schmidt. The Rev. Dr. Walter Donald Kring performed the cere mony in the Unitarian Church of All Souls.

title: Merger Plans of Canadian Protestants Faltering
description: TORONTO, Jan. 30Canada's two largest Protestant denomi nations, the United and Angli can Churches, elected new leaders this week amid signs that the long, patient campaign to merge the two organizations is faltering.

title: DR. JULES VANDOW, HEALTH OFFICIAL
description: Dr. Jules E. Vandow, former chief of the Division of Social Hygiene of the city's Depart ment of Public Health, died of a heart attack on Friday at his country home in Kent Cliffs, N.Y. He was 62 years old and lived at 750 Kappock Street in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Navy and Manhattan Triumph at Garden
description: Army and Navy played defen sive basketball games at Madi son Square Garden yesterday and the middies came out much better than their archrivals. Navy whipped New York Uni versity, 5750, before Manhat tan downed Army, 4938, before 5,442.

title: Chess
description: A CONSTELLATION of stars illus trating three brilliant chess mas terpieces from Nebraska, Bulgaria and Panama are appended. In the one, the sack of a rook blends with the blockade of a defending queen; in the other, perpetual harassment deflects a defending queen, and finally a decoy of the foe's defense destroys a vulner able target.

title: Leeds Subdues Manchester City, 20, in English Soccer
description: LONDON, Jan. 30. (Reuters) Leeds United ran its first place soccer lead to 5 points, today in the English League First Division with a 20 vic tory over Manchester City as secondplace Arsenal lost to Liverpool.

title: In Russia Huckleberry Finn would be a nice boy
description: When it comes to educating children in a scientific manner, the Soviet Union has a head start on America, according to Urie Bronfenbrenner, professor of psychology at Cornell Uni versity. He offers a lively and readable book which is the most complete description of Soviet methods of childrearing and education yet available. Draw ing upon manuals of childcare as well as his own observations and interviews, Mr. Bronfen brenner describes how Soviet children are exposed from the crib onwards to a scientifically planned education.

title: Sex Education in Hungary
description: VIENNA, Jan. 30 (AP) Hungary is planning separate sexeducation courses on tele vision for parents, teachers, teenage boys and teenage girls, the Hungarian press agency, M.I.T., has reported.

title: SERBS AND CROATS IN LANGUAGE SPLIT
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 30A longstanding linguistic feud, colored by both tradi tional and contemporary politi cal rivalries, has halted a cooperative project to produce an official dictionary of the SerboCroatian language, spok en by two out of three Yugoslavs.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Music
description: WHEN it was announced last month that Igor Stravin sky was intending to sell his collection of manuscripts for a reported $3.5million, it reminded John Vincent, the West Coast composer, that the collection of Arnold Schoenberg was also availablebut not to buy.

title: BROADWAY BRIGHTENS
description: With the opening on successive nights of No, No, Nanette and A Midsummer Night's Dream, both of which won almost unani mous praise from the critics, thea tergoers suddenly found them selves with something to look for ward to. Above, in the musical No, No, Nanette, maid Patsy Kelly tells Jack Gilford and Susan Watson, as. Nanette, that she's quitting. At the right, in A Mid summer Night's Dream, Mary Rutherford, as Hermia tangles with a wire?? Peter Brook's un orthodox staging of Shakespeare's comedy. For Walter Kerr's view of the Dream, see Page 5.

title: For Young Readers
description: Goblin Market is one of those poems children enjoy for its narra tive pace and pictorial delights and that adults relish for its symbolic suggestiveness. The religious cast of the poem can be felt in the idea of temptation that lies at the core of the work, in the use of forbidden fruit as the basis for suffering and in the idea of redemption through sisterly love.

title: Labor
description: DETROITAt its Mound Road engine plant here, Chrysler has tried giving out green stamps; at its factory in Fremont, Calif., General Motors has offered sets of glasses. But neither promotion has been very effective in getting employes to show up for work on Fridays and Mondays.

title: Criminals At Large
description: A lusty branch on the detectival tree is what who dunit fanciers call the med ical  a puzzle that stars the act of murder against a backdrop of pathology, psy chiatry or operating room. Mur der, however, is not the precise crime that is committed in the O.R. Hugh McLeave describes with baleful detail in A QUES TION OF NEGLIGENCE (Har court Brace Jovanovich, $5.95).

title: A policeman's lot, if not a happy one, has its compensations
description: This may be an overdramatic way of saying that this novel about three cops and their prog ress through five years of the Los Angeles Police Department performs one of those essential and enduring functions the noveland the novel alone can perform. It takes us into the minds and hearts, into the nerves and (sometimes literally) into the guts of other human beingsand, in the hands of a good writer, it achieves a mix ture of empathy and objectivity that creates genuine under standing. Of course the empathy is more important for the cop haters, who seem so numerous these days. But the objectivity is equally important for the cop loversthe boosters and the buffs who see every member of the force as a knight on horseback defending law and order, as if that shadowy entity were a virgin about to be ren dered by the Visigoths.

title: Tyler Nickel to Wed Miss Melinda Ochs
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 30Mr. Mrs. Robert C. Ochs have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Me linda Ochs, to Tyler Prime Nickel, son of Dr. and Mrs. William F. Nickel of Man hasset, L. I. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Warriors Lose Portman
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 (UPI)  Bob Portman, the San Francisco Warrior forward, has fractured his shooting hand and will be out of action for at least two weeks, the club said today. Portman injured his right hand during a game against Buffalo last night, but the fracture wasn't discovered until Xrays were taken today.

title: 76ERS'
description: After a brilliant comeback sparked by Dave DeBusschere, the Knicks failed to score a point in the final 1 minute 49 seconds, lost a 3point lead and bowed to the Philadelphia 76ers, 106105, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: FALMOUTH RIVEN BY SEWAGE PLAN
description: FALMOUTH, Mass., Jan. 28 The town spreads out here at what looks on a map like the elbow of Cape Cod and, though it spreads inland, and north, the sea is really its rea son for being.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: One of the big suppliers of spots to the nation's tele vision and radio stations is the Federal Government.

title: U.C.L.A. on Top
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30 (UPI)  Secondranked University of California, Los Angeles, in its first start since being upset by Notre Dame, defeated the Uni versity of California at Santa Barbara, 7461, today.

title: U Nu's Force Said to Grow In 4 Lower Burma Bases
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 26  Burmese expatriates here claim a considerable gain in strength for the rebel move ment begun in Burma recently by the former Premier, Ti Nu, but concede that it is still far from being a present threat to the regime of Gen. Ne Win, which it seeks to overthrow.

title: Akron Detergent Battle Seen as Vital
description: The detergent industry won the first step last week in its battle to prevent communities from banning phosphates in detergents as a means of con trolling pollution.

title: Herbs on a Windowsill
description: SEED catalogues are ar riving. Their bright colors and brighter promises kindle every herb gardener's longing for fresh green growth to replace the drab winter landscape.

title: Amateurs Writing for Red Chinese Press
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 30Peas ants, workers and soldiers are more prominent as writers in the press of Communist China to day than professional journal ists. The professionals, whose ranks were thinned by the purges of the Cultural Revolu tion, have mostly become anonymous figures working be hind the scenes.

title: Gifts to Neediest Ahead of a Year Ago
description: Contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have caught up to and slightly passed those of last year. The latest total recorded by the fund$925,010.34is more than $1,000 above the comparable amount of a year ago.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: High School Insulated From Plane Noise
description: Insulation from the roar of lowflying jets and from the damp effects of unusually high tides has been designed into a new high school nearing completion on the shore at Long Beach, L. I. The 21acre site of the $9million structure is on Blackheath Road, near Reynolds Channel, about a dozen miles southeast of Kennedy International Airport, right under an airline traffic pattern. So Donald Z. Bailey, a Long Beach ar chitect, raised the threestory building on 10foothigh concrete columns and wrapped the classroom core in a double layer of glass. A daydreaming student will he able to look out his classroom window, across a ninefootwide hallway and through a second window to the outside. The hallway acts as a noise baffle and a thermal barrier to improve heating and aircondi tioning efficiency. The 1,800student school, scheduled for completion in late spring, will contain an audito rium seating 900 persons. A swimming pool and a gymnasium with a seating capacity of 2,000 will be housed in a separate wing.

title: A.A.U. to Donate Funds From Series To Track Groups
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 30  The Amateur Athletic Union announced plans today for a club aid program designed to pump revenue into track clubs.

title: Allende Sharply Denies Charges Chile's Press Is Being Harasse
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 30President Salvador Allende Gossens has reacted with out rage to the charge that the press is being harassed under his administration.

title: FELONIES STUDIED IN COURT REPORT
description: Three out of every four adults charged with felonies in Man hattan Criminal Court have their cases disposed of before they reach trial on those charges, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Soviet Affirms Position
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 30 (AP)The Soviet Union declared today that the Western allies were ig noring irresponsible actions in West Berlin and thereby demonstrating disrespect for the fourpower talks.

title: Old Hebrew Grammar Found
description: LENINGRAD, Jan. 30 (AP) The Soviet press agency Tass reports that a copy of a 12th century Hebrew grammar, which is described as the first published Hebrew grammar on record, had been found in the depository or the Leningrad Public Library.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Your fashion business can grow slowly or at a rapid pace, but the important thing is that it grow solidly, says Jack Baker, president of Sue Brett, Inc., one of the larger and betterknown dress houses in the Seventh Ave nue area.

title: Fort Ross, Calif. A Russian Outpost in 1812
description: FORT ROSS, Calif.The white, blue and red flag with the black imperial doubleeagle of Czarist Russia first flew over Fort Ross (short for Rossiya, a poetic term for Russia), 70 miles north of San Fran cisco, in 1812, and continued to wave there for the next 29 years. In 1841 the fort was sold for $30,000, a trans action that, it could be argued, may have cost the Russians control of north ern California, Oregon, Washington and even British Columbia. Indeed, the sale of the fort may have been a greater blunder for the Russians than their sale of Alaska in 1867.

title: HUN SENIOR SETS SHOTPUT RECORD
description: The 22d Cardinal Hayes Games produced only one meet record yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory, but the fans were treated to a host of good per formances.

title: Ann C. Sherman Becomes a Bride
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 30 Miss Ann Clarke Sherman and Richard William Rahn were married at noon today in the Beverly Heights United Presbyterian Church, Mount Lebanon, by the Rev. Dr. Bruce Middaugh.

title: Yale Defeats Colgate
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 30Mike McLaren and Jim Morgan com bined to score 66 points tonight as Yale defeated Colgate, 10286. McLaren got 34 points and Mor gan 32 to pace the Elis to their third victory in 14 games.

title: Linda Brooks Engaged
description: HEWLETT, L. I., Jan. 30 Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Brooks have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Linda Ellen Brooks, to Sidney Howard Golden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Golden of East Rockaway. The couple's fathers are law yers. Mr. Brooks is also a vice president of Weissberger Moving & Storage Co., Inc., New York.

title: Steeplechasing Changes Intended to Woo Bettors
description: Sweeping changes in steeple chasing will be made at New York tracks this season in an effort to build public confi dence in the jumpers as a good betting proposition.

title: STRIKE IS PUT OFF IN GARAGE DISPUTE
description: A threatened strike that could shut down 650 public parking garages in Manhattan and the Bronx was postponed last night, amid reports of prog ress in contract negotiations.

title: Concern Seeks Plant Sites To Convert Coal Into Gas
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 30 (UPI)Studies will be under taken by a private company to identify potential coal reserves and locate possible sites for plants to convert coal into gas in Appalachia.

title: AnnWoodward Is Bride Of Stephen McD. Russell
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30  St. Edward's Roman Catholic Church was the set ting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Ann Talmadge Woodward to Ste phen McDonald Russell. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. Arthur DeBevoise, was attended by family and close friends. A reception for 300 was held at the Everglades club.

title: Computer Portables
description: After a day of work at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N. Y., Maj. David Gledhill may at times be seen toting away what appears to be an over size attach case. At home, after dinner, he removes from that case a machine that, although it looks like a type writer, is bulkier and more complex.

title: NewProduct Salvation
description: A cosmetic company that had just developed a new line of products in the men's toiletries field was puzzled about which distribution sys tems to use in selling the merchandise. After a series of market tests conducted by a management consultant, the corporation made a since profitable decision to place three of the items in depart mentstore distribution and sell the other two through supermarkets.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: POLLUTION DELAY LAID TO CONFUSION
description: MILFORD, Mich., Jan. 30 The General Motors Corpora tion says that overlapping re sponsibilities of various govern ment bodies caused a delay in the installation of antipollution systems at its Chevrolet plant on the Hudson River at Tarry town, N. Y.

title: BILINGUAL FUNDS FOR STATE AT ISSUE
description: New guidelines issued by the United States Office of Educa tion may deprive New York State of additional funds for programs dealing with bilingual education in the next fiscal year,

title: GREATEST NATURAL DISASTER
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: COLLEGE'S CLOSING SHOCKS STUDENTS
description: BEATRICE, Neb. Jan. 30 (AP)When Gloria Zoranski ar rived here from her home in Upland, Pa., to start her under graduate studies at John J. Pershing College, she was greet ed by the news the school had, folded.

title: The Nation
description: LOS ANGELES During his closing arguments in the Sharon Tate murder trial, prosecutor Vin cent Bugliosi described Charles Manson as a man of a thousand faces, each catering to the dif ferent needs and expectations of his companions. Indeed, Manson was so sensitive to people, so sharp in picking the right face, that many of the girls he recruit ed for his nomadic band thought he was psychic.

title: Pattern on pattern
description: A fresh phenomenon has burst onto the decorating scenepattern lavishly layered on pattern. In the vanguard of the trend is designer Seymour Avigdor, whose mini geometric prints helped spark the move ment. In this Manhattan apartment, Avig dor displays the look in its totality. Prints there are 18 in allcover most surfaces, blending by virtue of related colors and linear styling. Whether the look will last is a question, but timidity in the use of pattern has been banished once and for all.

title: St. Francis Wins, 9079
description: Mike McDermott scored 21 points to lead St. Francis to a 9079 win over Wagner College last night at Sutter Gymnasium, Staten Island. The Terriers fought back from a 10point halftime deficit to outscore Wagner, 234, as the second half began.

title: Home Improvement
description: A NEWLY styled nonfer rous baseboard heat ing panel now avail able has several fea tures that should prove of in terest to homeowners plan ning additions to, or remodel ing of, their hydronic (hot water) heating systems. Suit able for use in any room where baseboard radiators would normally be used, these new models are lower than most competitive units less than seven inches high as compared to eight, nine or ten inches for most. In addi tion, these units can be in stalled above walltowall carpeting without need for trimminga decided advan tages on many alteration jobs.

title: Stamps
description: COLLECTORS of Cinder ella stamps  locals and the likeare hav ing a bonanza because of Britain's postal strike. By unprecedented action on Jan. 18 the British Government authorized the Post Office to allow infringement of its jealously guarded monopoly over mail handling.

title: Norwegian Granted $21,600 In Contraceptive Pill Death
description: OSLO, Norway, Jan. 30An Oslo court has awarded $21,600 in damages to the husband of a woman whose death six years ago, it said, was caused by birth control pills.

title: Job Bias Against Women Easing Under Pressure
description: DETROIT, Jan. 30Even the Lord, according to the Old Testament, figured a woman's effort was worth less.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE TOPS SETON HALL
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 30 A Basket and two fouls by Jim O'Brien enabled Boston College to nip Seton Hall Uni versity, 7370, tonight before an overflow crowd of 3,200. The victory raised the Eagles' wonlost record to 116. The Pirates, who are in a fourgame losing streak, are 510.

title: Home Improvement
description: ANY doityourselfer capa ble of wielding a putty knife can now create the appearance, tex ture, feel and natural beauty of real stone on almost any in terior wall of his or her home or apartment. Authentic re productions of natural stones which duplicate the actual material so closely that even after touching and feeling a person cannot be sure he is not looking at the real thing, are available in various sizes and styles for cementing up with a special mastic ad hesive.

title: Middies to Man Yacht In Race Across Pacific
description: ANNAPOLIS, Jan. 30 (AP) The United States Naval Academy will enter the 2,250 mile transPacific yacht race for the first time this year with a yacht manned by mid shipmen.

title: Keller Sets Skate Mark
description: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 30 (Reuters)  Erhard Keller, the Olympic champion from West Germany, set a 500meter sprint skating record today for the Davos course and a West Ger man record when he won an in ternational competition in 38.7 seconds. Hans Lichtenstern of West Germany was second, with 40.2, and Jim Keane of the United States third, with 40.6.

title: V.M.I. Rifle Coach Dies
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Jan. 30 (UPI)Perry Norris, 24 years old, the coach of the Virginia Military Institute rifle team, died tonight after being injured in a cartruck collision south of here yesterday. He underwent surgery for head in juries at University Hospital.

title: Syrian Leader Will Visit Soviet Officials Tomorrow
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 30 The Syrian strongman, Lieut. Gen. Hafez alAssad will go to Moscow Monday to discuss the Middle East situation with So viet leaders, an official an nouncement in Damascus said today.

title: Art
description: View Toward S. Maria Maggiore, in Ingres in Rome, National Gallery, Washington, D.C. With Ingres as your proxy eye, a new poetry, a new gentleness

title: Augert of France Wins World Cup Slalom in Combined Time of 96.70 Seconds
description: MEGEVE, France, Jan. 30 (UPI)JeanNoel Augert, 21, of France streaked through the two slalom courses at the com bined MegeveSt. Gervais Meet today to win the World Cup skiing event with a combined time of 96.70 seconds, more than a full second faster than Gustavo Thoeni of Italy.

title: Con Ed Hopes to Increase Power Margin in Summer
description: The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that it hoped to have a wider power margin this summer than last 600,000 to 800,000 kilowatts more. But both the utility and the city administration said that the outlook was very serious because of uncertain ties.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THE ECONOMIC and financial scenario for 1971 seems to be unfolding without any great sur prises after one month of the new year. Though high unemployment and inflation remain as seri ous problems, the economy is gaining momentum rapidly and the bear market in stocks and bonds has definitely passed.

title: BROOKLYN SKATER SETS SPEED MARK
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 30 (AP)Lee Mazzilli of Brooklyn accounted for the only record in the open ing races of the 72d national outdoor speed skating cham pionships today.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BONNThe quintessential argu ment over Willy Brandt's Ostpolitik is whether the Soviet empire is wax ing or waning. Those who think it is gaining strength want to cool off the Federal Chancellor's eagerness to ne gotiate new accords with the East.

title: RYEN DOMINATES SKI JUMP EVENTS
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 30Thorbjorn Ryen, a 21year old carpenter from Staten Island by way of Norway, dominated the metropolitan skijumping tournament today.

title: National Notes
description: Only a year ago, Maj. Gen. Samuel W. Koster was one of the brightest stars in the Army's galaxy. Commandant of the United States Military Academy at West Point, he had an ex emplary pastservice in World War II, the Korean war and Vietnam, where he commanded the Americal Division, recipient of the Distinguished Service Medal, the Silver Star with oak leaf and other medals. At age 50, his future seemed limitless.

title: Iceland Fishes for Profits
description: REYKJAVIK, IcelandIce landers are drinking the health of fishlovers these days, especially those in the United States who put a packet of quickfrozen cod, haddock, or ocean perch in their supermarket baskets.

title: AmericanMade  in Mexico
description: SAN YSIDRO, Calif. Maria Dolores Ramirez came across the border from Ti juana one recent evening with her week's wages of 276 pesos, or $22.08, to buy some American cosmetics and shop for material for a new dress at Albert Stein's Fashion Remnants Store.

title: A policeman's lot, if not a happy one, has its compensations
description: Cops, said Joseph Wam baugh, know what evil is, and they know what weakness is, and they know the difference.

title: Ottawa Announces Program To Combat Drug Abuse
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 30  John R. Munro, Minister of Health and Welfare, announced a $4.5mil lion program this week to combat drug abuse.

title: MINE ISSUE HEATED IN WEST VIRGINIA
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 30This Is Our State, the picket sign announced. We Belong HereRockefeller Does NotWe Need Our Strip Mines.

title: 2 Investment Services Assailed By Beame on City Bond Ratings
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beame sharply questioned two of the major investmentrating services yesterday for what he pictured as a double stand ard that was costing the city millions of dollars in interest.

title: South Carolina Wins, 9270
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 30 (UPI)  South Carolina's de fense forced Virginia into Sev Ieral errors in the first half as the Gamecooks avenged an ear lier loss by defeating the Cava liers, 9270, tonight.

title: ARMY TRACKMEN ROUT PENN STATE
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan, 30 Army defeated Penn State in track today, 6949, at the West Point Field House, bouncing back from a 5950 upset at the hands of Cornell a week ago. The victory was Army's sev enth of the season against one loss.

title: Television
description: AT 9:20 P.M., last Dec. 5, Fred Stew art, a character actor who en joyed a reputation as a solid citizen of the theater world, was seated at his desk at the Actors Studio, jovially spoofing On the Waterfront with a fellow actor. A moment later, Mr. Stewart keeled over dead, the vic tim of a heart attack. His death at 63 was a grievous loss to the Actors Stu dio, which he had selflessly served as an actor, director, and producer with out pay since its inception. By way of earning his bread, Mr. Stewart had most recently been a regular member of the cast of the CBSTV soap opera, Love of Life, and his death was felt no less keenly by his associates there. In addi tion, it posed a serious problem with regard to the continuity of the show's story, which is normally developed some three weeks in advance of actual shooting.

title: AID TO REFUGEES INCREASES IN YEAR
description: The International Rescue Committee reported yesterday that it aided more refugees in 1970 than in any year since its founding 38 years ago.

title: 500 to Meet Here on Recycling Of Waste to Useful Purposes
description: In an attempt to find out whether recycling, or turning waste into something useful, can solve the nation's growing garbage problem, 500 indus trialists, government leaders, environmentalists and civic leaders from all over the coun try will meet at a conference here Tuesday.

title: Art Notes
description: IT'S been all quiet on the Whitney Museum front for several hoursbut don't let that fool you. Today the good, gray pro testprone pile on 75th and Madison will be the site of yet another demonstration this time against its sched uled April attraction, Black Artists in America, a show of more than 100 works by some 70odd black contem poraries. Paradoxically, the protest action is spearhead ed by the Black Emergency Cultural Coalition, the very group of black artists who, during six months of con sultations in 1969 persuad ed the museum to mount such a show in the first place. Branding the Whitney a racist, irrelevant institu tion, BECC is urging par ticipants in the show to stage a massive boycott of it.

title: M. C. Brooks to Marry Diana Dwyer
description: LAUREL HOLLOW, L. I., Jan. 30Mr. and Mrs. Martin Dwyer Jr. of Laurel Hollow and Hobe Sound, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diana Noyes Dwyer, to Michael Christopher Brooks, son of Mrs. Charles Welles Brooks of Wilton, Conn., and the late Mr. Brooks.

title: Joyce Glassman Will Be June Bride
description: LIVINGSTON. N J., Jan. 30 Mr. and Mrs. Max Glass man have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Joyce Glassman, to Ben jamin Schlesinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Schlesing er of Harrison, N. Y.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONThe way Secreta ries Laird and Rogers tell it, any air strike for any purpose anywhere in Southeast Asia serves the Administra tion's ultimate goal of protecting the withdrawal of American troops from South Vietnam, and is therefore justi fied. That means that in the guise of winding down the war, the Nixon Ad ministration is widening the war in the most destructive way.

title: Andre de Limur Is Dead at 80; ExFrench Count and Diplomat
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Andr de Limur, a former French count and diplomat, died yesterday in his home at the age of 80.

title: U.S. Silent on Speculation About an Invasion of Laos
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Ad ministration officials declined today to discuss speculation that the South Vietnamese, with American air support, were about to invade southern Laos.

title: CHARTER BUS LINE SET UP IN HARLEM
description: After 14 months of opposi tion from more than 30 bus companies, including Grey hound and Continental Trail ways, a blackowned charter bus service was begun in Har lem last week.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONSaid Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, last week, after listen ing to Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird's testimony on Cam bodia:

title: Wright Again to Head Ox Ridge Show in June
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 30 David H. Wright of Darien was named today chairman of the OX Ridge Club horse show for the third consecu tive year.

title: N.Y.U. TURNS BACK COLUMBIA IN TRACK
description: Dwight Epps of New York University edged Mitch Orfuss of Columbia in the 500  yard run, and came back to nose out Orfuss on the final leg of the onemile relay, to lead the Vio lets to a 6048 win over Colum bia in a track dual meet held in the Mason Airdome at Baker Field yesterday.

title: The House Of the Deer
description: Of course you remember Ger ald BurleighBrown, of Gerald and Elizabeth. Well, in this se quel, Gerald goes up to the Highlands for a vacation of deer stalking, falls in love with the daughter of the manor (who had been described to him as full of beans and very good fun) and gets himself waylaid by a gang of master criminals. These worthies, operating un der such sobriquets as Spin ner, Lanky and Grooby, want to sweat out of Gerald the plans of the burglar alarm system at MacCallum's Ship Building Yard, where he works. D. E. Stevenson fans will stay up way past their bedtime to finish this one.

title: Undefeated Temple Beats Fordham's Fencers, 243
description: Temple notched its sixth straight fencing victory of the season today by defeating Fordham, 243, at the Rose Hill gymnasium.

title: Auto Insurer Makes Money
description: LOS ANGELESThis city boasts a company, the Mer cury General Corporation, which is making a profit un derwriting insurance, a busi ness most of its competitors lose money on.

title: The Nation
description: PNOMPENH  When does a Military Equipment Delivery Team turn into a Military Advi sory Assistance Group? This question, which was another way of asking whether the United States was getting sucked into a new military commitment in Cambodia, posed itself last week following the disclosure that American officials were ready to implement plans for a military team to check on how this coun try's army was using United States war matriel.

title: From Underground, Father Berrigan Speaks to Actors
