description: Before being apprehended by the FBI last summer, Father Berrigan taped a message from underground to the actors in his play, The Trial of the Catonsville Nine. This article is excerpted from that message.

title: New Buildings and Roads Make Kinshasa Hotter
description: KINSHASA, the Congo, Jan. 30 (AP)Temperatures in the Congolese capital are rising in proportion to development.

title: BRUNNER SETS PACE IN TOBOGGAN MEET
description: VALDAORA, Italy, Jan. 30 (AP)Karl Brunner of Italy overtook Leonard Nagenrauft of Germany today in the sec ond heat of the world toboggan championships, while Mrs. Erika Lechner, another Italian, held onto her lead in the wom en's competition.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Holmes, who well appreciat ed a pretty ankle, once ex pressed the skepticism of many lawyers about society's capacity to legislate equal treatment of the sexes: It will need more than the 19th Amendment, he grumbled, to convince me that there are no differences between men and women.

title: Books:
description: ASPIRATIONS AND AF FLUENCE. By George Katona, Burkhard Strumpet and Ern est Zahn. 239 pages. McGraw Hill $12.95.

title: Judith A. Duffy Sets Marriage
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Jan. 30 Miss Judith Ann Duffy will be married here to Paul Sundermann of Los Angeles on April 2 in St. An drew's Roman Catholic Cathe dral.

title: YALE DEFEATS ARMY IN SWIM FOR NO. 73
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 30  The Yale swimming team, whose last loss in dualmeet competi tion was to Army in 1966, de feated a strong West Point team, 6350, to remain un beaten. The Eli fiveyear vic tory skein is now 73.

title: Clergy to Lobby at U.N. for End to War
description: In modest offices near the United Nations, clergymen of all major world religions have set up shop with the aim of lobbying for a number of, causes: to end the Vietnam war, to promote disarmament, to combat racism.

title: Commissioned by a sister and brother to kill a son
description: Just last summer Tom McHale pub lished his first novel, Principato, and the rapid issuance of this sec ond one is entirely consonant with the flourish, vigor and slambang im petuosity to be encountered within the covers of both books. Mr. Mc Hale is nothing if not headlong in his assault on his material and the equilibrium of his readers. One sees him as a tennis player, coming on with a cigar in his teeth and a racket in either hand. Or as a juggler toss ing up multitudes of oranges, apples and soap bubblesrecycling some of them before they smack on the floor, and endlessly replacing those that shatter with more from his pocket or pipe.

title: Swiss Envoy Says Cubans Do Not Welcome Hijackers
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 30 (UPI) The departing Swiss Ambas sador to Cuba, Alfred Fischle, says that plane hijackers are not wellreceived in Cuba. They are sent to prison or to mental hospitals, he said.

title: The Turbotrain: A Study in Incongruities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30At the start of a new twoyear ex periments the turbotrain be tween Boston and New York can be seen as either the last best hope of rail passenger service, or a sign that good trains cannot happen here any more. Just possibly it is both.

title: Hot Rodders Race Friday
description: POMONA, Calif., Jan. 30 (UPI) The National Hot Rod Association's 11th annual win ter nationals will be held at the Los Angeles County Fair grounds Feb. 5 to 7.

title: Ellen Christine Lougee Plans Marriage to Matthew Simmons
description: WINCHESTER, Mass., Jan. 30Mr. Laurence Wheeler Lougee of Winchester and Rockwood, Me., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Christine Lougee, to Matthew Roy Simmons of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy W. Simmons of Keyesville, Utah.

title: New York
description: New York City, having stag gered through a wildcat police strike, a firemen's job action and a brief welfare stoppage, is steeling 'itself for a possible squareoff this week with its unionized sanitationmen.

title: Pleasure Boat Manufacturers at the Coliseum Are Optimistic About 1971
description: What comes down must go up may be the new motto of the 61st National Boat Show, following yesterday's survey of consumer and dealer response at the Coliseum.

title: AGNEW SEES GAINS FOR REVENUE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  Vice President Agnew said to day that he had received gen eral support for the Adminis tration's revenuesharing plan from 42 of the nation's 50 Governors, although several of them indicated that they had reservations about specific as pects.

title: Miss Ratner Is Betrothed
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 30Miss Joanne Ratner and Jeffrey H. Cooper are plan ning to be married this June.

title: Hardluck Class of '70
description: At about 2:30 P.M. each weekday Charles T. Jones snaps the lid on his bulging dinner pail and starts off on a 20mile commute from Rock ford, Ill., to the big Chrysler plant in nearby Belvidere.

title: N.Y.U. Fencers Beat Navy
description: New York University, the de fending National Collegiate fencing champion, defeated Navy yesterday, 1413. The Vio lets are 50 wonlost this sea son and have a record of 18 consecutive victories in the last three years. Marty Lang of N.Y.U. won three foil bouts, in cluding the decisive 27th bout with Steve Sisa.

title: KhanBinns Team Advances In Squash Racquets Event
description: Mohibullah Khan of the Harvard Club of Boston and Ken Binns of the Skyline Club of Toronto, the topseeded team, gained the semifinal round yesterday in the George C. Johnson Memorial Open squash racquets doubles tour nament at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn. They eliminated Mel Sokolow of the Lone Star Boat Club and Roger Alealy of the Princeton Club, 1511, 1512, 156.

title: 11 Arrested in 4 Counties In Jersey Gambling Raids
description: Eleven persons were arrested yesterday in simultaneous raids in four New Jersey counties and charged with gambling vio lations.

title: PRINCETON DOWNS RUTGERS, 65 TO 58
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 30With a neutral Gov. Wil liam T. Cahill watching from the balcony, Princeton's cool band of sophomores defeated Rutgers, 6658, today behind the firsthalf shooting of Ted Manakas and the secondhalf shooting of Brian Taylor.

title: First Army's Chief Censures Gen. Koster in Mylai Incident
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) Maj. Gen. Samuel W. Koster, cleared yesterday of charges that he had covered up the alleged massacre at Mylai 4, has been censured and could receive further stiff adminis trative penalties, the Army said today.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: Today's attorneys, who more than occasionally won der how they might fare in the ranks of business Management, might like to ponder a case historyDon ald B. Smiley, who will be come chief executive officer of R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., on Aug. 1.

title: Pompidou's PopularityHolds
description: PARIS, Jan. 30 (Reuters) President Pompidou's popular ity is holding steady, with 65 per cent of the public satisfied with his performance, accord ing to a survey published by FranceSoir. The figure was 69 per cent in November.

title: Spacecraft Is Modified For Safety
description: COCOA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30 Spaceship stylists have kept the familiar exterior look on the 1971 Apollo vehicle that takes off for the moon tomor row. But on the inside there are more than a dozen Changes contributions to safety dic tated by the near catastrophe on the Apollo 13 flight last April.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MOSCOW ASSURES TOURISTS ON VISITS
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 30Intour 1st, the official Soviet travel organization, was reported to day to have assured travel agencies that American tourists would not be harassed in the Soviet Union.

title: VICTORIA IMPRESSES IN A FOLKSONG BILL
description: Victoria, a fraillooking folk singer from San Francisco, is proving very impressive during her engagement at the Gaslight Cafe, 116 Macdougal Street, where she stays through to morrow evening.

title: FREDERICK R. FAST
description: NAPLES, Fla., Jan. 30Fred erick R. Fast, president and chairman of the Employers Benefit Service Company and vice president of the Associated Pension Trust Company, both of Newark, N. J., died here on Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

title: Headmaster Post Filled
description: BELMONT, Mass., Jan. 30 The appointment of David A. Aloian as headmaster of the Belmont Hill School, effective July 1, was announced by Carl H. Amon, Jr., president of the Board of Trustees. Mr. Aloian succeeds Charles F. Hamilton who has been headmaster for 29 years. Mr. Aloian is cur rently headmaster of the Con cord Academy. The Belmont Hill School is one of the lead ing private schools in New England.

title: China Discovers a New Friend In AfricaEquatorial Guinea
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 China appears to have found a new African friend in the tiny but strategic Republic of Equatorial Guinea.

title: Transit Policeman Rushing to Help Captain in Melee Kills IND Rider Accidentally
description: A passenger sitting on a crowded subway train in Har lem was accidentally shot and killed early yesterday by a Transit Authority patrolman rushing to assist a transit po lice captain who was struggling with three men and a woman.

title: City's New Parking Violation Bureau Speeds Hearing of Cases
description: In my eyes I'm not guilty, said Rena Smilowitz as she paid a $25 ticket for parking too close to a fire hydrant. I can't say I'm responsible for something when I'm not there, especial ly since I made every effort to make sure I was not in violation.

title: Kentucky Beats Vanderbilt
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 30 (UPI)Kentucky outscored Vanderbilt, 224, in one stretch of the first half to night and went on to gain a 10292 Southeastern Confer ence victory.

title: Mr. Nixon's Priorities
description: The Federal budget affects the welfare of the American people in two fundamental ways: it has a fiscal impact on the nation's economic growth and stability, and it allocates resources among competing national claims.

title: Movies
description: STRANGELY enough, Husbands, a movie made by men about men's love for other men, is the strong est statement of the case for wom en's liberation I have yet seen on stage or screen. In fact, it is virtually the only movieexcept for a single scene Eleanor Perry wrote into Diary of a Mad Housewifein which one can hear even an echo of the passionate voice rising in women across this land these past five yearsmillions of women marching across the lines of generation, race, class, on the unfinished business of equality between the sexes.

title: Photography
description: ANY addition to the everthin ranks of gal leries devoted to the exhibition and sale of photographic prints is a wel come one, for the sheer vol ume of serious work produced todayto say nothing of the diversitycould fill the walls Of twice as many fulltime galleries as are presently available.

title: In Brief
description: If you can't say something nice, Thumper Rabbit used to say, don't say nothing at all. Katie Louchheim has been in politics for the past three decadesas the Vice Chairman of the National Democratic Committee and as an official in the State Departmentand she has met nearly everyone who passed through Washington in those years. In recalling the figures she met she has written a Thumper Rabbit book: 293 pages of gossip without a single mean word, except for rude Krishna Menon (not a member of the Democratic party), who once sat next to her at dinner and rattled sugar cubes in his pocket.

title: Church Council Will Build Villages in East Pakistan
description: GENEVA, Jan. 30The World Council of Churches plans to build three new villages in East Pakistan to provide homes for 1,800 families who were victims of the hurricane last November.

title: Foreign Notes
description: A pillar of South Africa's apartheid race laws is the Im morality Act, passed in 1950, which prohibits sexual relations between blacks and whites. The penalty for conviction is seven years' imprisonment and flogging for male offenders.

title: New Federal Rule Curbs Loss To Owner of Stolen Credit Card
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI)  Rules have gone into effect to make it harder for someone to use a stolen credit card, and to make the rightful owner less liable for a thief's purchases.

title: The Troubled Nations of Middle Africa
description: On Sept. 28, 1958, Guinea's Skou Tour became an instant hero to African nationalists and a commanding figure in the Pan African movement. It was the date on which Guinea, alone among France's colonies of West and Central Africa, said non to Charles de Gaulle and voted overwhelmingly for indepen dence rather than for home rule inside the French Community.

title: Mrs. McAdoo Wed To G. R. Heinrichs
description: PELHAM, N. Y., Jan. 30 Mrs. Natalia A. McAdoo and George Richard Heinrichs were married here this after noon in the Huguenot Me morial Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. William C. Schram.

title: In the Mailbox:
description: To the Editor:

title: Art
description: I LIKE the rule that corrects the emotion. Georges Braque's fam ous dictum, first pub lished in Pierre Reverdy's magazine NordSud in 1917, evokes for us a mode of sensibility far removed from the expressive pressures un der which much of the art of our own day is both pro duced and consumed. It would no doubt be an exag geration to suggest that now adays it is either all rules and no emotion or all emo tion (the nastier the better, too,) and no rules, but it would be the kind of exag geration that discloses a truth. We seem to prefer to take our art directly into the bloodstream, where it need not be mediated by any of the more delicate processes of cerebration, or directly into our heads, where it can lodge itself with the swift, unambiguous certainty of an arithmetic equation. We no longer seem inclined to sum mon the kind of inner re sources that keep the rule and the emotion in a mean ingful and fertile harmony.

title: Movies
description: NEIL Simon's Last of the Red Hot Lovers is getting warmed up for the screen. The current Broadway hit has been purchased by Para mount, the company that has sponsored movie adaptations of a string of Simon suc cesses that includes Come Blow Your Horn, Barefoot in the Park, The Odd Couple and Plaza Suite, which will be a summer at traction at Radio City Music Hall.

title: In the Mailbox:
description: To the Editor:

title: The surface of Lou Colfax, complete with scars
description: John Knowles has written a beau tiful, funny, moving novel about a young man in trouble. If The Para gon is flawedand I think it is the cracks may shorten its life but they won't seriously impair the pleas ure of reading it. Knowles, who got his medals for A Separate Peace, is an intelligent man telling us things we need to know about ourselves. He tells them well.

title: Reader's Report
description: If movies were what they used to be, this one by Nathan iel Benchley would be coming into the Music Hall for next Christmas. Consider. A ruthless plutocrat decides to glorify his mother's birthplace, a sleepy port on the Intracoastal Water way; he plans the abolition of poverty by turning the place into a tourist trap. The owner of a small boatyard goes along with the plutocrat's scheme, un til he sees that his friends and neighbors are being hornswog gled. Then, Jimmy Stewart or Henry Fonda or Gary Cooper (or Sam Marin, as he is called in the book) hatches a plan of counterattack. I can almost see the marquee and hear the old cry: Immediate seating in the balcony.

title: Daughter for the Sterns
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. E. Mark Stern of New York and Amagansett, L. I., on Jan. 12 in Roosevelt Hospital. Mrs. Stern is the former Miss Virginia Fraser Underwood. Dr. Stern, a psy chologist, is associate pro fessor in the Graduate Divi sion of Pastoral Counseling at Iona College. The child has been named Cailean Fraser.

title: Heavy Toll Discounted In Mozambique Flood
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mo zambique, Jan. 30 (AP)Offi dials today discounted reports of especially high casualties in yesterday's floods.

title: Counter Market Awakes
description: The overthecounter mar ket, which had been slum bering for some time, is showing signs of wakening.

title: The story of a Greek village, as told by a native son
description: ANYONE who wants to analyze Greek politics today must visit not only Athens and Salonika and the other large cities, but the vil lages as well. At the least, he should try to know some of the many village natives who now live in the cities. The harsh life style and the isolation of Greece's villages strongly affected their inhabitants and account for many of the contradictory aspects of current Greek life:

title: Urban League Is Concerned Over Angela Davis Trial
description: The National Urban League has expressed grave concern that Angela Davis may not re ceive the fair and impartial trial to which she is entitled.

title: Kings Tie Red Wings, 3 to 3
description: DETROIT, Jan. 30 (UPI)  Doug Robinson's goal from in close at 16 minutes 19 seconds of the third period tonight gave the Los Angeles Kings a 33 deadlock with the Detroit Red Wings.

title: OUR CHERI AMOUR FIRST IN MILITIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 Mrs. Helen D. Vizzi's Our Cheri Amour, an $1,800 bargain filly, beat 10 colts today in the $33,975 Militia Stakes at Lib erty Bell race track.

description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 30 (UPI)Mrs. Ann Jones of Brit ain used her experience to de feat Tory Fretz of Los Angeles, 62, 61; in the second round of a $12,500 women's professional tennis tournament tonight.

description: ATHENS, Jan. 30A Greek court has refused the appeal of a retired army general to be released from prison because of poor health.

In a second tall tale, Icaromenippus, the same author launched yet another hero with a handcrafted pair of wings.

title: Ambush on Highway 4
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 30 (AP)The Cambodian com mand reported an ambush by enemy troops on Route 4, the sole overland supply link be tween the capital and the sea. The command said a convoy of four trucks had been am bushed while attempting to bring supplies from the port of Kompong Som.

title: Photography
description: A SERIES of 15week courses in basic pho tography is being of fered at the Brooklyn Central Branch of the YMCA of Greater New York, 62 Joral emon Street, Brooklyn 11201. There will be one set of classes for 15 to 18yearolds and another for those over 18. The first will be held on Tuesday evenings, the sec ond on Wednesday evenings. There will also be classes held on Saturday afternoons for the 10 to 15yearold group. All will start this week, and the fee for each will be $15, plus membership dues for the YMCA ($10 for adults, $5 for youngsters un der 18). Those interested can call Mr. Robert E. Jacobs at (212) JA 26002.

title: Climb Off My Knee, Sonny Boy
description: IT is some kind of crazy commentary on contemporary American movies that what is happening in the movie industry itself, or what's left of it, is a lot more interesting and significant than anything contained within the movies the industry has been releasing in recent months. Last week there were reports that Jack L. Warner, who was one of the founders of Warner Brothers in 1923, and who sold his stock in that company four years ago, is toying with the idea of coming out of retirement and buying National General Pictures, a small, comparatively new company that has not been especially, successful as a movie producer.

title: Cornell Tops Princeton, 32, In Overtime Hockey Game
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 30 Larry Fullan, a junior center, scored a goal at 1 minute 27 seconds of a suddendeath over time period today to give Cor nell's Hockey team a 32 vic tory over Princeton.

title: Tina Bucheit Wed in Capital To Neil Diver
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  Miss Mary Christina (Tina) Bucheit, an assistant to Her bert G. Klein, director of communications for President Nixon, was married here to day to Neil Longfellow Diver, who is vice president of fi nance for the Urban Systems Development Corporation, a subsidiary of Westinghouse Electric, in Arlington, Va.

title: Nutmeg No. 3 Rink Wins
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 30  The Nutmeg Curling Club No. 3 rink, skipped by Robert Peter son, reached the final of the Nutmeg Stone invitation bon spiel today with the Philadel phia C. C. No. 1, skipped by Arthur Zimmer.

title: The Nation
description: Since the establishment of the United States Bureau of Mines in 1910, more than 80,300 work ers have been killed in accidents in the nation's coal mines. Last month, at the Finley Brothers mine in Kentucky's impoverished mountain area, an explosion claimed 38 lives.

title: The Scented Geraniums
description: ONE or two scented leaved geraniums are pleasant to have on a sunny kitchen window sill during the winter months. Unlike other members of the geranium family, which pro duce colorful foliage or flow ers, the scentedleaved types are grown primarily for their fragrant foliage. The scented leaves must be touched or crushed to release their pun gence.

title: Floods Orphaned 15,000 In Pakistan, UNICEF Says
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30 (UPI)  The United Nations Children's Fund estimates that 15,000 to 20,000 children be come orphans in one dayrduring the East Pakistan cyclone and tidal wave in November.

title: In Brief
description: Historians and journalists have more in common than they readily admit to each other, Henry Graff, the chairman of Columbia's history department, remarks in this book. The dif ference, of course, is in the length of the perspective they prefer. In that context, Mr. Graff reviews four sets of in terviews he had with President Johnson and his Tuesday luncheon group, or Tuesday Cabinet as Graff calls it, in cluding Rusk, McNamara, Bundy, Moyers and later Ros tow, Christian and Clifford. Speaking casually to these men between 1966 and 1968, Graff had a precious opportunity to analyze the decision making process, as he calls it, as ap plied during a time of increas ing American involvement in Vietnamand he wasted it entirely.

title: 2 Women Enshrined
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 30 (AP)Mrs. Shirley Garms and Mrs. Tess Small, two Chicago area bowlers, have been named to the Woman's International Bowling Congress Hall of Fame.

title: Gary Bashian Weds Jackie Barba
description: TENAFLY, N.J., Jan. 30 Miss Jacqueline Angeline Barba and Gary Edward Bashian were married here at noon today in St. Thomas Armenian Church by the Rev. Arnak Kasparian. The Rev. Roy Selenske assisted.

title: Judge John Worth Kern, Former Head of Tax Court
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) John Worth Kern, retired judge of the United States Tax Court and a former mayor of Indianapolis, died yesterday of lung cancer. He was 70 years old. Judge Kern served two 12 year terms on the court and retired in 1961 after six years as chief judge. He was recalled to active service, which con tinued until his death.

title: Stephanie Forrest Is First In Alta Snow Cup Slalom
description: ALTA, Utah, Jan. 30 (UPI) Stephanie Forrest of Belling ham, Wash., placed first today in the Alta Snow Cup Slalom.

title: WILLOWICK, $26.60, WINNER ON COAST
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 30 (UPI)  Kentuckybred Willo wick raced to a surprise victory by a length today in the 19th running of the $67,600 San Fernando Stakes for 4yearolds at Santa Anita. The heavily favored Loud finished fourth.

title: R W. Gerbe Weds Ruth McKinney
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 30Miss Ruth Ann Mc Kinney and Lieut. (jg.) Ron ald W. Gerbe, U.S.N., were married here this morning in the Unioia Congregational Church by the Rev. Dr. Glenn Young, senior minister of the church.

title: Warriors Down Lakers
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 30 (UPI)The San Francisco War riors built a 14point first period lead and then held on to defeat the Los Angeles Lakers, 8785, tonight before 11,945 fans at the Oakland Arena.

title: Allies Clash in Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Jan. 30 (UPI) South Vietnamese sailors and Cambodian soldiers battled for 15 minutes with mortars and maohineguns in the city center today. The Cambodian army called in tanks and troops to break up the melee. One Cam bodian bystander was killed and 10 other persons were injured. The incident apparently started with an argument between South Vietnamese and Cam bodians.

title: Specialty Steels: Special Woes
description: When the White House re acted with sharp and un expected displeasure to pro posed increases in steel prices earlier this month, it probably was fair to say that no single group was more alarmed than the executives responsible for American spe cialty steels.

title: University in Jerusalem Plans 2Year Program Not in Hebrew
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 30  He brew University, the bulwark of the Hebrew language in modern Israel, finally suc cumbed this week to appeals from Jews throughout the world to establish a twoyear academic program in foreign languages for overseas stu dents.

title: 2 Tropical Parrots Nesting in Yonkers Again This Winter
description: A pair of brilliantly colored parrots native to the Amazo nian tropics have turned up for the second year in Westches ter County and appear to be thriving in the current cold weather.

title: Ousted Bowler Sues
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 30 (AP) Mrs. Maggie Ossitifin has filed a $100,000 suit charging three parties with conspiring to force her off a bowling team. She brought the suit in Montgomery County Common Pleas Court against the E. F. MacDonald Company, sponsor of the team; an agent of the company; and the Dayton Women's Bowling Association. Mrs. Ossitifin contended that being dropped from the team brought her embarrassment, which caused her to lose her job.

title: H. F. Clarks. Jr. Have Son
description: A son was born on Jan. 11 to Mr. and Mrs. Harold F. Clark Jr. of Frankfurt, West Germany, in the Privat frauen Klinik there. Mrs. Clark is the former Miss Julia Denny of New Canaan, Conn. The child has been named Gregor Tatum. His father is with J. Walter Thompson, the advertising agency, in Frankfurt.

title: Pathet Lao Accuse U.S.
description: TOKYO, Jan. 30 (AP) Pathet Lao accused the United States and the Laotian Gov ernment today of deliberately delaying proposed peace talks.

title: ESKIMO SYMBOLS TAUGHT IN ALASKA
description: COLLEGE, Alaska, Jan. 30 A class of 15 Eskimo children, meeting in a small, yellow school building at Nunapitchuk in southwestern Alaska, has spent the first half of this school year learning a new al phabet for the language they and their families speakthe Yuk (pronounced yook) dia lect.

title: WILLIAMS SIX TOPS MIDDLEBURY BY 21
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Jan. 30 (AP)Bob Schmitz scored on a breakaway with 59 seconds remaining tonight, to give Wil liams an upset 21 hockey vic tory over Middlebury.

title: New York
description: It takes a lot to shock New Yorkers. But the discovery that employes of the City's Human Resources Administration had lodged a welfare family  a mother and her four children  at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel set tongues wagging: The city was paying $76.32 a day so the very poor could live in the domain of the very rich.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: People need housing and they want forests.

title: Reader's Report
description: For the connoisseur of West ern decline and fall, this book is vintage stock, with a touch of the old HuxleyWaugh bou quet. Like his literary antece dents, Philip Oakes (Atticus of The Sunday Times of Lon don) is a disapproving moral ist. Of such is the kingdom of television, he notes dourly, as a show is hatched out of poprocksex and religion. Of such is the kingdom of heaven, observed Aldous Huxley, as Burlap and Beatrice got into the tub together in Point Counter Point. (There is also a big bathtub scene in Mira cles.) And in the manner of Waugh, Mr. Oakes develops par allel themes of complex and primitive cruelty: one in London andd one in the Congo.

title: W.H.O. SEEKS CURB ON TOBACCO CROP
description: GENEVA, Jan. 30The World Health Organization hopes to step up its campaign against cigarettes by, reducing the world's production of tobacco.

title: SeasonTicket Sales Surge As Patriots Get Plunkett
description: BOSTON, Jan. 30 (AP)The Boston Patriots announced to day the sale of 30,990 season tickets for the 1971 campaign, when the team will move into a new 60,000seat stadium in Foxboro.

title: Van Nostrand, Gerulatis Gain State Tennis Final
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 30 King Van Nostrand and Vitas Gerulatis, an un seeded player, gained the final of the New York State men's indoor tennis championship to day at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: National Notes
description: For 123 years, the Community Services Society, New York City's oldest private social agency, has followed the tradi tional approach in helping the poor: family casework and in dividual counseling. Last week, the agency announced a dra matic aboutface that may have a farreaching effect on the nature of charity in America.

title: Logical Kafka, obsessive Beckett, Borges without his brilliance or flatness
description: Peter Bichsel's Children's Stories (the German title is Kinder geschichten) start from restricted mental states: there was a man with nothing else to do; another who didn't want to know anymore; and another who had given up talking. And, with compulsive force, they move briskly toward conclusionsif this, then this. But, more subtly than mere logical sequence, each performs deft, witty turns and illuminates a hypothetical instance of man used up by history (nothing to do, to say, to know), or impoverished by technological va riety (a born inventor finds there is nothing left for him to invent), or debased by behavioristic attitudes (a man who memorized the train sched ule thinks trains come and go strictly to get somewhere on time; so he wonders, if you know the schedule, why take a train?). The book is selective mirror of our day in which we discover ourselves at extremes of petulence and impotence  like childrenand its original title, Kin dergeschichten, bespeaks its charac ter, unity, and point; its title in the American edition, There Is No Such Place as America, bespeaks some one's anxiety about sales.

title: Burton Bowler of Year
description: AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 30 (UPI) Nelson Burton Jr., of St. Louis, who won four tournaments on the 1970 Professional Bowlers Association Tour, was named today as the P.B.A. bowler of the year by the Sporting News.

title: Foreign Notes
description: On the basis of analysis and evaluation of the new incentive system, it should not be intro duced in its present form this year. Thus, a Polish Deputy Pre mier, Josef Kulesza, last week explained why the Government of Poland was abandoning a key part of a new fiveyear plan in troduced late last year.

title: Charlotte Louise Saville Is Bride
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 30Miss Charlotte Louise Saville, daugher of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Saville of Plainfield, N. J., was married here this afternoon to Michael Pierce Metcalf, assistant to the president of The Provi dence Journal.

title: Dear Pete, You oil Are Being Recruited
description: The letters come from all parts of the country and only the names and addresses of the recipients are different. But generally, the contents are the same. This is one ex ample, culled from among 65 letters received by Peter Crotty, a high school senior in Rockville Centre, L. I.:

title: '71 Giants Look to Backfield Speed
description: Having completed a rather, unspectacular draft, the Giants can now look ahead to the 1971 season. Just how do they shape up?

title: Automated Medicine
description: A Canadian coed walked into a Toronto pharmacy re cently and noticed some thing new on the countera stack of small boxes, each containing a doityourself pregnancy test.

title: Municipal Projects Set Record in '69'70
description: Led by school, transit and water supply projects, the city's capital construction program reached a record high in the fiscal year ended last June 30, the Bureau of the Budget re ported yesterday.

title: James Perkins, ExPresident Of Cornell, Weds Mrs. Ruth Aall
description: PRINCETON, N. J, Jan. 30  James A. Perkins, former president of Cornell Univer sity, was married here this afternoon to Mrs. Ruth Ber gengren Aall. The bride, a native of Boras, Sweden, is a daughter of Mrs. Axel Ber gengren and the late Mr. Bergengren, who was presi dent of the Boras Vaveri Textile Company. Her previ ous marriage to Christian Aall ended in divorce.

title: What Europe did to us and what we did to one another
description: The discovery of the Americas set off a European expansion that has continued unabated for five cen turies. With the beginning of plane tary (transoceanic) empires, Europe swiftly rewrote its own mythology of world history; the balance re mains substantially unredressed.

title: New Owner at Portland Nine
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 30 (UPI)Pacific Coast League of ficials approved today transfer of the Portland Beavers fran chise to its new owner, Bill Cutler. They also announced that Portland had entered into a working agreement for next season with the Minnesota Twins. The Beavers were affili ated with the Milwaukee Brew ers last season.

title: Pamela Goldberg Wed
description: MANHASSET, L.I., Jan. 30Miss Pamela Goldberg, daughter of Stanley Goldberg of Bayside, Queens, and the late Mrs. Goldberg, was mar ried here this evening to Paul H. Altman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Altman of Rockville Center. Rabbi Max J. Routtenberg performed the ceremony in Temple Judea, assisted by Cantor Ben Belfer. The bride is an alumna of Rider College. Her husband, a graduate of the University of Cincinnati, is with Clarence Rainess & Co., certified public account ants in New York.

title: U.S. BOBSLED OUT AS RACE IS PUT OFF
description: CERVINIA, Italy, Jan. 30 (UPI) Officials announced a 24  hour postponement of the world fourman bobsled cham pionships today after fresh snow made the treacherous Blue Lake course even more dangerous and caused three accidents.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Alfred Hoeberechts, Hotel Aide, Will Marry Laurie M. Carmody
description: WOODBURY, Conn., Jan. 30Miss Laurie Morriman Carmody, Whose father, Gue rin B. Carmody, is a former Chief Justice of the Connec ticut Trial Justice Courts, will be married in June to Alfred C. C. M. Hoeberechts.

title: STATE HOUSING CHIEF SCORES COUNCIL BILL
description: New York State's highest housing official warned last week that a City Council pro posal to limit rent increases in cityaided MitchellLama hous ing projects would have poten tially disastrous effects on the program.

title: Dutch Skaters Take Lead As Oslo Team Meet Opens
description: OSLO, Norway, Jan 30 (AP)  The Netherlands took a 3.5 point lead over Norway after the first day of the fifth inter national team match between the world's five top speedskat ing nations.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: With major stock market indexes up 36 per cent or so from last year's bearmarket lows, Wall Street analysts are beginning to scan about for stocks that have failed to share in the market's re covery.

title: Margaret G. Alton Lawyer's Fiancee
description: The engagement of Miss Margaret Grace Alton to Thomas Stuart Weisser has been announced by her pa rents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter George Alton. Mr. Weisser is a son of Mrs. Shirley Cane Redmond and Henry Weisser, both of New York. The cere mony will take place on Feb. 20 at the home of the future bridegroom's mother.

title: Diplomacy as the art of the impossible
description: The trick of understanding Arab politics is to remember that most Arab leaders rose to power by mak ing promises they knew they couldn't keep, and committing themselves to goals they knew to be unobtainable. Once in power, their ability to stay there must to a large extent depend on their skill at blaming others for their failure to deliver.

title: Scranton Is Host to Stars
description: HAZELTON, Pa., Jan. 30 (AP) The Eastern Basketball Asso ciation awarded today the league's AllStar game to Scranton. The game will be played Wednesday, Feb. 17.

title: POLL SHOWS MORE ASK SWIFT PULLOUT
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 30 The Gallup Poll reported today an upsurge of public support for the HatfieldMcGovern pro posal to end United States troop involvement in South Vietnam by the end of the year.

title: Headliners
description: Earlier this month, Stewart L Udall, the former Secre tary of the Interior, had a moment of absentmindedness. On leaving a chain drugstore in the Washington suburb of McLean, Va., he paid for one 95cent pack of cigars but for got about another pack he had stuck in his pocket. Within seconds Mr. Udall, who now practices law in Washington, was arrested and charged with shoplifting. Protests of absentmindedness to the arresting officer, store manager and a justice of the peace brought only replies of It's out of my hands.  Last Thursday, Mr. Udall appeared in court to face trial, but his case was dismissed when higher chain store management overruled the local people and withdrew the charge. Said Mr. Udall: Maybe I ought patronize small stores where people know you.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Penguins Beat Hawks
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 30 (UPI) Val Fonteyne scored his first two goals of the season, one while killing a penalty in the final five minutes, to lead the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 31 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.

title: Hart and 5 Others Sign Giant Baseball Contracts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 (AP)Jim Ray Hart and five other players have signed for the 1971 baseball season, the San Francisco Giants an nounced today.

title: U.S. AND REAGAN AVOID SHOWDOWN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Nixon Administration, confront ed with a dramatic legal and political choice between Gov. Ronald Reagan of California and the leading Federal pov erty law program in the state, announced tonight a lastmin ute, sixmonth compromise.

title: Cougars Top Rockets, 114109
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Jan, 30 (UPI) The Carolina Cougars over came a 6054 halftime deficit tonight and scored 31 points in the fourth period to defeat the Denver Rockets, 114109.

title: Tenants Protest Demolition Plan For Columbus Hospital Parking
description: Elected officials and tenants held a news conference on East 19th Street yesterday to protest the arrogance of Columbus Hospital, which they said is evicting tenants and planning to tear down two tenements to construct a 27car parking lot.

title: U.S. Judge Voids Conviction of Man Confined 15 Years
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (UPI) A Federal judge has voided the confession and murder con viction of a man who has spent more than 15 years on death row.

title: Movies
description: FOR months now, Hollywood has been talking about a se cretly made feature film being directed by Orson Welles, his first American movie since Touch of Evil 14 years ago. Made largely on location in Los Angeles, the picture's cast includes Marlene Dietrich, and it is financed by Welles him self. Shooting began last September, but few have known exactly when or where since; the crew has been loyally silent, few of the cast can be reached for comment. In a controversial exchange in these pages last year, Peter Bogdanovich, Welles's Boswell, denied that Welles was making the picture at all, even though he had assisted him in the production, which was shooting at that time. Yet the same day that Bogdanovich's denial appeared, Welles was creating a sequence at Century City, and there wasn't a selfrespecting gossip in town who hadn't spread word of it.

title: Mississippi Five Wins As Neumann Tallies 63
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 30 (UPI) Johnny Neumann scored 63 points for Missis sippi today in a 11390 South eastern Conference basketball victory over Louisiana State.

title: Television
description: THE tricky issue of men tioning marijuana on the air arose recently in connection with the television show made from film footage of Bob Hope's annual Christmas tour of overseas military bases, and Hope's own remarks about the show as broadcast, The version that finally reached the home screen gave view ers no indication that Hope's wisecracks about pot had evoked perhaps the heartiest laughter among the troops; nor did the pictures on the tube ever confirm what Hope freely told the press and, in deed, discussed earlier and openly with Johnny Carson on the Tonight show.

title: Boat Show: 40 Years Before the Masts
description: A National Boat Show visitor (this one) left the New York Coliseum last week with the feeling that he had seen it all before and what he had just seen was not so much different. Yes, he had seen it all before because no show had escaped him since the early 1930's, when the event was held in Grand Central Palace on Lexington Avenue.
